Mawunyakpukpui Siwo Meŋlɔ Da Ði
My scripture journal
Nu kae ameɖokuisisi nye?
What is cutting?
Ameɖokuisisi nye eɖoɖo koŋ atsɔ lãnuwo anɔ nu vevi wɔm ame ɖokui.
Cutting is the practice of compulsively harming oneself with a sharp object.
Esia nye nu vevi wɔwɔ ame ɖokui gbogbo siwo li la dometɔ ɖeka ko.
It’s just one form of self-injury.
Ðewoe nye dzotsɔtsɔ amè ame ɖokui kple ameɖokuiƒoƒo.
Others include burning, bruising, or hitting oneself.
Nyati sia ku ɖe ameɖokuisisi ŋu, gake mɔfiame siwo le eme ate ŋu akpe ɖe ame siwo wɔa nu vevi bubuwo wo ɖokuiwo hã ŋu.
This article is about cutting, but the principles discussed apply to all forms of self-injury.
Do wò sidzedze kpɔ: Nyateƒee alo aʋatsoe.
Test your knowledge: True or False.
Nyɔnuviwo koe sia wo ɖokuiwo.
Only girls cut themselves.
Ameɖokuisisi nye Biblia ƒe sedede si le 3 Mose 19:28 si gblɔ be: ‘Migasi mia ɖokuiwo o’ la dzi dada.
Cutting violates the Bible command at Leviticus 19:28, which says: "You must not make cuts in your flesh. "
Ŋuɖoɖo nyuitɔwo:
Correct answers:
Aʋatsoe.
False.
Togbɔ be nyɔnuviwo koŋue sia wo ɖokuiwo hã la, ŋutsuvi aɖewo hã sia wo ɖokuiwo eye wowɔa nu vevi ƒomevi bubuwo hã wo ɖokuiwo.
While the problem seems more prevalent among girls, some boys cut themselves and engage in other forms of self-injury too.
Aʋatsoe.
False.
Nya si 3 Mose 19:28 gblɔ la ku ɖe trɔ̃subɔla siwo nɔ anyi le blema ƒe kɔnuwo ŋu, ke menye nu vevi wɔwɔ ame ɖokui si ŋu míele nu ƒom tsoe le nyati sia me ŋu o.
Leviticus 19:28 refers to an ancient pagan ritual, not to the compulsive practice of self-injury discussed in this article.
Ke hã susu le eme be míaƒo nya ta be mía Wɔla lɔ̃ame la medi be míawɔ nu vevi mía ɖokuiwo o. 1 Korintotɔwo 6:12; 2 Korintotɔwo 7:1; 1 Yohanes 4:8.
Nevertheless, it stands to reason that our loving Creator doesn’t want us to harm ourselves.​ 1 Corinthians 6:​12; 2 Corinthians 7:1; 1 John 4:8.
Nu ka tae amewo wɔa nu sia?
Why do people do it?
Do wò sidzedze kpɔ: Nya siawo dometɔ kae nèsusu be enye ŋuɖoɖo nyuitɔ?
Test your knowledge: Which statement do you think is most accurate?
Amewo sia wo ɖokuiwo . . .
People cut themselves . . .
be yewoatsi nuxaxa nu.
because they are trying to cope with emotional anguish.
be yewoawu yewo ɖokuiwo.
because they are trying to kill themselves.
Ŋuɖoɖo nyuitɔ: A. Ame siwo sia wo ɖokuiwo ƒe akpa gãtɔ medina be yewoaku o.
Correct answer: A. Most people who cut themselves don’t want to die.
Ðeko wowɔnɛ be yewoatsɔ atsi nuxaxa nu.
They just want to end their emotional despair.
Kpɔ nya siwo sɔhɛ siwo sia wo ɖokuiwo dometɔ aɖewo gblɔ ɖa.
Note what some young people have said about their practice of cutting.
Celia : "Enana nye dzi dzea eme. "
Celia: "It brought me a sense of relief. "
Tamara: "Ewɔna nam abe ɖe nuxaxa nu yi ene.
Tamara: "It seemed to provide an escape.
Veve si ame sena ne ewɔ nu vevi eɖokui la nyo sãsãsã wu nuxaxa. "
The physical pain was better than the emotional pain. "
Carrie: "Nyemedina be malé blanui kura o.
Carrie: "I hated feeling sad.
Ne mesi ɖokuinyea, nye susu meganɔa nye blanuilélea dzi o, nye susu va nɔa abi si le veyem la boŋ dzi. "
Cutting took the focus off my sadness and put it onto my physical pain. "
Jerrine: "Ɣesiaɣi si mesi ɖokuinyea, nye susu dzona le kuxi ɖe sia ɖe kloe dzi, eye megahiãna be makpe akɔ kple nye kuxiwo o.
Jerrine: "Every time I cut myself, I became almost unaware of my surroundings, and I wouldn’t have to deal with my problems.
Tɔtrɔ sia dzɔa dzi nam. "
I welcomed the change. "
Ne kuxi sia le ŋuwò la, aleke nàwɔ atasii?
If you have this problem, how can you stop?
Gbedodoɖa na Yehowa nye nu vevi si kpena ɖe ame ŋu wòdzudzɔa nuwɔna sia.
Prayer to Jehovah God can be a vital step to recovery.
Biblia gblɔ be: ‘Midro miaƒe dzimaɖitsitsiwo katã ɖe eyama dzi, elabena eléa be na mi.’ 1 Petro 5:7.
The Bible says: "Throw all your anxiety upon him, because he cares for you. "​ 1 Peter 5:7.
Aɖaŋuɖoɖo: Gbã la, do gbe kpui aɖe ɖa, ɖewohĩ nàgblɔ na Yehowa ko be, "Mehiã kpekpeɖeŋu. "
Suggestion: Start with brief prayers, perhaps simply telling Jehovah, "I need help. "
Le ɣeyiɣi aɖe megbe la, ŋutete ava su asiwò nàgblɔ wò dzimenya geɖewo na "akɔfafa katã ƒe Mawu " la. 2 Korintotɔwo 1:3, 4.
In time, you will be able to open up and pour out your feelings to "the God of all comfort. "​ 2 Corinthians 1:​3, 4.
Menye susumenu dzro aɖe si nana ame sena le eɖokui be yekpɔ gbɔdzɔe gbedodoɖa nye o.
Prayer is not some psychological crutch.

Enye dzeɖoɖo ŋutɔŋutɔ kple Fofowò si le dziƒo, ame si do ŋugbe be: "Mègavɔ̃ o, elabena meli kpli wò; ŋɔ megadzi wò o, elabena nyee nye wò Mawu, mali ke wò, makpe ɖe ŋuwò, eye matsɔ nye xɔname ƒe nuɖusi alé wò. "
It is real communication with your heavenly Father, who promises: "I will really help you.
Yesaya 41:10.
I will really keep fast hold of you with my right hand of righteousness. "​ Isaiah 41:10.
Ame siwo sia wo ɖokuiwo dometɔ geɖe kpɔ gbɔdzɔe esi woƒo nu tso woƒe kuxia ŋu na wo dzilawo alo ame tsitsi aɖe si dzi woka ɖo.
Many who have struggled with cutting have also found comfort in talking to a parent or another trusted adult.
Se nya siwo sɔhɛ siawo dometɔ etɔ̃ gblɔ la ɖa.
Consider the following comments from three young people who did just that.
Gbebiame
Interview
Diana, ƒe 21
Diana, 21
Kathy, ƒe 15
Kathy, 15
Lorena, ƒe 17
Lorena, 17
Ƒe nenie nèxɔ esime nète ɖokuiwò sisi?
How old were you when you started cutting yourself?
Lorena: Mexɔ ƒe 14.
Lorena: I started when I was about 14.
Diana: Mexɔ ƒe 18, menɔa ɖoɖo nu o.
Diana: I was 18, and the frequency varied.
Mesia ɖokuinye gbe sia gbe hena kwasiɖa ɖeka alo eve, eyome menɔa anyi ɣleti ɖeka sɔŋ esi nyemewɔa nu sia o.
I would cut every day for a week or two and then go for a month without doing it at all.
Kathy: Mexɔ ƒe 14.
Kathy: I started when I was 14.
Megawɔnɛ ɣeaɖewoɣi kokoko.
I still have occasional setbacks.
Nu ka tae nèwɔa nu vevi ɖokuiwò?
Why did you want to hurt yourself?
Kathy: Elabena meléa fu ɖokuinye.
Kathy: I struggled with feelings of self-hatred.
Ewɔna nam be ame aɖeke medi be manye ye xɔlɔ̃ o.
I felt as if no one could possibly want me as a friend.
Diana: Ɣeaɖewoɣi la, blanuiléle nana be nu tena ɖe dzinye eye dzi ɖena le ƒonye.
Diana: Sometimes my sadness would turn into frustration, and my frustration into despair.
Dziɖeleameƒoa nu nɔa sesẽm va se ɖe esime wòwua tsɔtsɔ nam.
The despair would grow until it became overwhelming.
Ðeko wònɔna abe lã wɔadã aɖee le menye eye wòhiã be madze ɖokuinye ne wòado go ene.
It was like a huge beast inside me, and it was as if I had to cut myself to let it out.
Lorena: Nu tena ɖe dzinye vevie, medoa dziku eye nyemegakpɔa ŋudzedze ɖe ɖokuinye ŋu o.
Lorena: I would get really depressed or angry or just feel down about myself.
Ewɔna nam be meƒo ɖi, eye medina be maɖe seselelãme dziŋɔ ma aƒu gbe.
I would feel like dirt, and I wanted to get rid of all that horrible emotional junk.
Ɣeaɖewoɣi la, mesusunɛ be ele be mawɔ nu vevi ɖokuinye.
Sometimes I would feel like I deserved the physical pain.
Ðe wò dzi dzea eme ne èwɔ nu vevi ɖokuiwòa?
Did hurting yourself make you feel better?
Diana: Ɛ̃.
Diana: It did.
Mevona le ɖokuinye me abe ɖe wodro agba kpekpe aɖe le ta nam ene.
I felt lighter afterward, as if a burden had been lifted from me.
Kathy: Ede sɔsɔ ge kloe kple avifafa.
Kathy: It’s almost like a form of crying.
Nye dzi dzea eme ne mesi ɖokuinye abe ale si ko ame aɖewo hã ƒe dzi dzea emee ne wofa avi wosu wo nyuie ene.
I felt better after I cut myself the same way that some people feel better after a good cry.
Lorena: Nu vevi wɔwɔ ɖokuinye le ko abe bɔl aɖee le menye si me wotu nye nuxaxawo ɖo la ŋɔŋɔ ene.
Lorena: Self-injury was like puncturing a small hole in the balloon of negative emotions inside me.
Maho o; ɖeko ya ado le eme eye wòaɖe asi le nye nuxaxawo katã ŋu woado le menye vivivi.
It wouldn’t pop; it would just leak and let all the negativity out slowly.
Ðe nèvɔ̃a nuƒoƒo tso nu si me tom nèlea ŋu na ame bubuwoa?
Were you afraid to tell anyone what you were doing?
Lorena: Ɛ̃.
Lorena: Yes.
Mevɔ̃na be woabum be menye ame sagã.
I was afraid people would think I was weird.
Eye nyemedina hã be amewo nanya nye agbemenyawo o.
Plus I didn’t want others to know about my personal life.
Diana: Amewo gblɔna ɣesiaɣi be yewobuam ame sesẽe, eye medi be woanɔ buyem nenema.
Diana: People always told me that they thought I was strong, and I wanted them to keep believing that.
Mesusunɛ be ne mebia be woakpe ɖe ŋunye la, ekema medo kpo nu.
I felt that asking for help would have been a defeat.
Kathy: Mevɔ̃na be amewo abum be nyemele nyuie o, eye esia awɔe be ale si mebua ɖokuinyee la nagagblẽ ɖe edzi kura.
Kathy: I was afraid that people would think I was messed up, which in turn would make me feel even worse about myself.
Gawu la, ewɔna nam be medze na nu vevi si wɔm mele ɖokuinye la.
Besides, I felt that I deserved what I was doing to myself.
Nu kae kpe ɖe ŋuwò nètasii?
What was a turning point for you?
Lorena: Meƒo nu tso nye nuwɔnaa ŋu na nɔnye.
Lorena: I told my mom what I had been doing.
Ðɔkta aɖe hã na kpekpeɖeŋum, ekpe ɖe ŋunye meɖu nye seselelãme manyomanyoawo dzi.
I also got help from a doctor, who helped me control my negative emotions.
Megawɔnɛ ɣeaɖewoɣi ya, gake Biblia-sɔsrɔ̃ edziedzi kpe ɖe ŋunye.
I had a few setbacks, but improving my Bible study routine helped.
Meƒoa ɖokuinye ɖe Kristotɔwo ƒe subɔsubɔa me edziedzi hã.
I also stay active in the Christian ministry.
Ðewohĩ ahiã be makpe akɔ kple viɖemanɔameŋu ƒe seselelãme tso ɣeyiɣi yi ɣeyiɣi le nye agbe me katã ya, gake medzea agbagba be nyemaɖe mɔ wòakpe dzinye o.
Perhaps I will always struggle with occasional feelings of worthlessness, but when they arise, I try not to let them rule me.
Kathy: Nɔvinyɔnu Kristotɔ si tsi wum ƒe ewo la de dzesi be nane le fu ɖem nam, eye meɖe nye nyawo gblɔ nɛ mlɔeba.
Kathy: A Christian sister who is about ten years older than I am could tell something was wrong, and I eventually confided in her.
Nukutɔe la, eya hã to nɔnɔme ma me kpɔ.
To my surprise, she too had once struggled with cutting.
Ŋu mekpem be maƒo nu tso nye kuxia ŋu nɛ o, elabe eya ŋutɔ hã to nɔnɔme ma me kpɔ.
I didn’t feel awkward talking to her because she had been through it herself.
Meyi ɖakpɔ ɖɔkta aɖe hã, ekpe ɖe nye kple dzinyelawo ŋu míeva se nuwɔna sia gɔme nyuie wu.
I also got help from a doctor, who helped me and my parents to understand what I was going through.
Diana: Mele atsu kple asi aɖe si dzi meka ɖo la ƒe aƒe me zã aɖe me eye srɔ̃ŋutsua de dzesii be nane le fu ɖem nam.
Diana: One night I was at the home of a couple whom I trusted, and the husband noticed that something wasn’t right.
Ede dzi ƒom nam veveseseɖeamenutɔe be magblɔ nu si le dzɔdzɔm ɖe dzinye la na yewo.
He kindly urged me to tell them what was wrong.
Nɔvinyɔnua lé nye asi eye wòkpla asi kɔ nam abe ale si ko nɔnye wɔna nam le nye ɖevime ene.
His wife held me and rocked me in her arms just the way my mom used to when I was a little girl.
Mewò avi, eye eya hã wò avi.
I started to cry, and so did she.
Esesẽ nam be magblɔ nu si me tom mele la na wo, gake dzi dzɔm ŋutɔ esi megblɔe na wo.
It was hard to tell them what I had been doing to myself, but I’m glad that I did.
Aleke Biblia kpena ɖe ŋuwò?
How has the Bible helped you?
Diana: Biblia kpe ɖe ŋunye mekpɔe dze sii be nye ɖeka nyemate ŋu akpe akɔ kple nuwɔna sia o.
Diana: The Bible has helped me to realize that I can’t fight this on my own.
Mehiã Yehowa Mawu ƒe kpekpeɖeŋu.​ Lododowo 3:5, 6.
I need Jehovah God’s help.​ Proverbs 3:​5, 6.
Kathy: Biblia-xexlẽ kple enyanya be Mawu gbɔe gbedeasi si le eme la tso faa akɔ nam ŋutɔ!​ 2 Timoteo 3:16.
Kathy: Reading the Bible​ and knowing that its message comes from God​ gives me such deep comfort!​ 2 Timothy 3:​16.
Lorena: Ne mawunyakpukpui aɖe wɔ dɔ ɖe dzinye la, meŋlɔnɛ ɖe agbalẽ me, eye meva dea ŋugble le eŋu emegbe.​ 1 Timoteo 4:​15.
Lorena: When I come across scriptures that touch me, I write them in a notebook so I can reflect on them later.​ 1 Timothy 4:​15.
Mawunyakpukpui kae wɔ dɔ ɖe dziwò vevie?
Is there a scripture in particular that touched you?
Diana: Lododowo 18:1 gblɔ be: "Ame si ɖe eɖokui ɖe aga le eya ŋutɔ ƒe dzodzro yome dim la, etsia tre ɖe nunyanyawo katã ŋu. "
Diana: Proverbs 18:1 says: "One isolating himself will seek his own selfish longing; against all practical wisdom he will break forth. "
Ɣeaɖewoɣi la, esesẽna nam be manɔ amewo dome, gake mawunyakpukpui sia kpe ɖe ŋunye meva kpɔe be afɔku le ameɖokuiɖeɖe ɖe aga me.
Sometimes I find it difficult to be around people, but this scripture helps me to realize that to isolate myself is dangerous.
Kathy: Mateo 10:29, 31 nye mawunyakpukpui eve siwo dɔa dzidzɔ nam ŋutɔ, afi si Yesu gblɔ le be atsutsrɔe ɖeka teti hã mekuna le Yehowa Mawu ƒe manyamanya me o.
Kathy: Two Bible verses that I love are Matthew 10:29 and 31, where Jesus said that not even a sparrow dies without Jehovah God noticing it.
Eye wògblɔ kpee be: "Migavɔ̃ o: Miexɔ asi sãsãsã wu atsutsrɔe geɖewo. "
And then he added: "Have no fear: you are worth more than many sparrows. "
Va se ɖe egbe la, ne mexlẽ nya mawo la, eɖoa ŋku edzi nam be Yehowa dea asixɔxɔ ŋunye.
Even now, reading those words reminds me that I’m valuable to Jehovah.
Lorena: Mekpɔa ŋudzedze ɖe Yesaya 41:9, 10 me nyawo ŋu ŋutɔ.
Lorena: I appreciate the passage at Isaiah 41:​9, 10, where Jehovah says to his people: "I have not rejected you.
Yehowa gblɔ na eƒe amewo le afi ma be: "Nyemegbe wò o; megavɔ̃ o, elabena meli kpli wò; . . . mali ke wò. "
Do not be afraid, for I am with you. . . . I will fortify you. "
Ne mele nu si li ke ŋu bum la nye susu yia nane si sesẽ goŋgoŋ, glikpɔ sesẽ, si naneke mate ŋu aŋɔ o dzi.
When I think of something that is fortified, I think of something impenetrable, a structure with stone walls.
Mawunyakpukpui sia doa ŋusẽm, elabe menyae be Yehowa lɔ̃m eye wòli kplim.
This scripture makes me feel empowered, knowing that Jehovah loves me and that I will have him by my side always.
Biabia Siwo Ŋu Nàde Nugble Le
Questions for reflection
Ne èdi be yeabia kpekpeɖeŋu la, ame kae nàdi be yeaƒo nu tso yeƒe kuxiawo ŋu na?
When you are ready to reach out for help, in whom could you confide?
Nya kae nàte ŋu agblɔ tso kuxia ŋu ne èle gbe dom ɖa na Yehowa Mawu?
What can you say in prayer to Jehovah God about the matter?
Àte ŋu ayɔ mɔnu eve aɖewo (siwo menye nu vevi wɔwɔ ame ɖokui o) siwo dzi nàto aɖu wò nuteɖeamedzi kple nuxaxaa dzia?
Can you name two methods (that do not involve self-injury) that you can use to release your stress and anxiety?
Mawunyakpukpui Siwo Meŋlɔ Da Ði
My scripture journal
Aɖaŋuɖoɖo: Ne èxlẽ mawunyakpukpui aɖe si na nèkpɔe be Yehowa lɔ̃ ye alo kpe ɖe ŋuwò be nàda asɔ le ale si nèbua ɖokuiwò kple wò gbɔdzɔgbɔdzɔwoe la, ŋlɔ mawunyakpukpui ma da ɖi.
Suggestion: When you come across a Bible passage that assures you of Jehovah’s love or that can help you to develop a balanced view of yourself and your failings, write that scripture in a journal.
Ŋlɔ nu si tae mawunyakpukpui ma le vevie na wò la le nyagbe ɖeka alo eve me ɖe egbɔ.
Include a sentence or two about why the passage is meaningful to you.
Be nàkpɔ ale si yeate ŋu awɔ esiae la, mawunyakpukpui aɖewoe nye esi Diana, Kathy kple Lorena ŋlɔ da ɖi.
To help you get started, here are some scriptures that Diana, Kathy, and Lorena found helpful.
Romatɔwo 8:​38, 39
Romans 8:​38, 39
"Mawunyakpukpui siawo ɖee fiam be Yehowa lɔ̃m nenye be mese le ɖokuinye me be nɔnɔmea wu tsɔtsɔ nam gɔ̃ hã. "​ Diana.
"These verses show me that Jehovah loves me, even when I feel that things couldn’t get any worse. "​ Diana.
Psalmo 73:23
Psalm 73:23
"Mawunyakpukpui siawo tɔgbi naa kakaɖedzim be nyemetsi akogo o.
"Scriptures like this one assure me that I’m not alone.
Ðeko wòle abe ɖe Yehowa le gbɔnye tututu ene. "​ Kathy.
It’s as if Jehovah is right here next to me. "​ Kathy.
1 Petro 5:​10
1 Peter 5:​10
"Ate ŋu adzɔ be mímakpɔ gbɔdzɔe enumake o; abia be ‘míakpe fu vi aɖe.’
"Relief may not come immediately; we may have to suffer ‘a little while.’
Gake mlɔeba la, Yehowa ate ŋu ana ŋusẽ si hiã la naɖo mía ŋu míado dzi atsɔ nɔnɔme ɖe sia ɖe. "​ Lorena.
In the end, though, Jehovah can make us strong enough to endure anything. "​ Lorena.

Electronic game quiz

Ƒe nenie ame siwo ƒoa fefe siawo la ƒe akpa gãtɔ xɔna?

Ƒe 18
Ƒe 30

Ŋuɖoɖoawo (wotu wo ɖe ƒe 2013 ƒe nyatakakawo dzi):
Answers (based on 2013 data):
B. Ƒe 30.
A. Nyɔnu 45 le alafa me ye ƒoa wo, esia nye fefe siawo ƒolawo katã ƒe afã kloe.
A. Females make up 45 percent​ close to half​ of all players.

A. Nyɔnuvi siwo xɔ ƒe 18 kple esiwo tsi wu ema la woe nye ame siwo ƒoa fefe siawo katã ƒe 31 le alafa me, evɔ ŋutsuvi siwo xɔ ƒe 17 kple esiwo mekpɔ xɔe haɖe o nye fefe siawo ƒolawo ƒe 19 le alafa me.
A. Women 18 and older make up 31 percent of the game-​playing population, while boys 17 and under make up 19 percent.
Nyatakaka mawo na nèkpɔ ame siwo ƒoa fefe siawo wu.
Those statistics might give you an idea of who is playing.
Gake nyatakaka mawo meɖe ŋusẽ si fefe mawo kpɔna ɖe dziwò la fiana o, eɖanye nyuia alo gbegblẽa o.
But they don’t tell you the effects​ good or bad​ that electronic games can have on you.
Eƒe viɖeawo
The good
Nya siawo siwo wogblɔ tso elektronikfefewo ŋu dometɔ ka dzie nèda asi ɖo?
Which of the following statements about electronic games do you agree with?
"Wonye mɔnu nyui aɖe siwo nana be ƒometɔwo dome nɔna kplikplikpli. "​ Irene.
"They’re a fun way to bond with family and friends. "​ Irene.
"Wonye mɔnu nyui aɖe si dzi míetona sina le agbemenyawo nu. "​ Annette.
"They’re a nice escape from reality. "​ Annette.
"Wonana míebua tame. "​ Christopher.
"They enhance your reflexes. "​ Christopher.
"Wonana míesrɔ̃a ale si míakpɔ míaƒe kuxiwo gbɔ. "​ Amy.
"They help you develop problem-solving skills. "​ Amy.
"Wonana míezãa míaƒe susuwo; wonana míebua tame, wɔa ɖoɖo ɖe nuwo ŋu henyana ale si míawɔ aɖo wo gbɔ. "​ Anthony.
"They’re mentally engaging; they make you think, plan, and strategize. "​ Anthony.
"Fefe aɖewo nana mí kple mía xɔlɔ̃wo míewɔa nu aduadu. "​ Thomas.
"Some games encourage teamwork with friends. "​ Thomas.
"Fefe aɖewo nye kamedede eye wonana ame nɔa lãmesẽ me. "​ Jael.
"Some games help you work out and get in shape. "​ Jael.
Èda asi ɖe nya siawo dometɔ aɖewo​ alo wo katã gɔ̃ hã dzia?
Do you agree with some of those statements​ or even all of them?
Videofefewo ate ŋu akpɔ ŋusẽ nyuiwo ɖe míaƒe susu kple ametia dzi.
Video games can have mental and physical benefits.
Togbɔ be fefe aɖewo nye modzakaɖeɖe ko eye "wonye mɔnu nyui aɖe si dzi míetona sina le agbemenyawo nu " abe ale si Annette gblɔe ene hã la, menye ɣesiaɣie wònyea nu gbegblẽ o.
Even if some games are just a way to pass the time and are​ as Annette put it "a nice escape from reality, " that’s not always wrong.
Biblia gblɔ be "ɣeyiɣi li na nu sia nu wɔwɔ le dziƒoa te, " esia lɔ fefe hã ɖe eme. Nyagblɔla 3:1-4.
● The Bible says that there is "a time for every activity under the heavens, " including recreation.​ Ecclesiastes 3:​1-4.
Eƒe nugbegblẽ
The bad
Ðe elektronikfefewo xɔa wò ɣeyiɣiwo katã?
Are electronic games robbing you of your time?
"Ne menya dze eƒoƒo gɔme ko la, esesẽna nam be matɔ.
"Once I start playing, I find it hard to stop.
Menɔa gbɔgblɔm na ɖokuinye be, ‘Magaƒo vi aɖe ko!’
I keep telling myself, ‘Just one more level!’
Kaka manya la, gaƒoƒo eve va yi xoxo eye megblẽ ɣeyiɣi geɖe tsɔ ƒo fefe siawo xoxo! "​ Annette.
Before I know it, a couple of hours have flown by and I’ve spent way too much time in front of the screen! "​ Annette.
"Videofefewo tea ŋu gblẽa ɣeyiɣi na ame ŋutɔ.
"Video games can be time vacuums.
Ànɔ anyi anɔ eƒom gaƒoƒo geɖe ahasusui be yewɔ nane de goe, elabe èkpɔe be yeɖu dzi zi atɔ̃ le fefea me, gake le nyateƒe me la, mewɔ nemi teti o. "​ Serena.
You sit there for hours and then feel as if you accomplished something because you won five games, but in reality you haven’t accomplished anything at all. "​ Serena.
Ŋutsuvi aɖe nɔ anyi ɖe aba dzi le videofefe ƒom
A young boy sitting up in bed playing a video game
Nya vevitɔ: Ne wò ga fiã la, àgate ŋu akpɔ bubu emegbe.
The bottom line: If you lose money, you may be able to get it back.
Gake mele alea le ɣeyiɣi gome o.
But that’s not true when you lose time.
Le susu sia nu la, ɣeyiɣi xɔ asi wu ga.
In a sense, then, time is more valuable than money.
Eya ta mègaɖe mɔ fefewo nagblẽ ɣeyiɣi na wò o!
So don’t let yourself be robbed!
Biblia gblɔ be: "Miyi edzi miazɔ le nunya me . . . miwɔ miaƒe ɣeyiɣi ŋu dɔ le mɔ nyuitɔ nu. " Kolosetɔwo 4:5..
● The Bible says: "Go on walking in wisdom . . . , making the best use of your time. "​ Colossians 4:5.
Ðe elektronikfefewo kpɔa ŋusẽ ɖe wò susu dzia?
Are electronic games affecting your thinking?
"Wowɔa ŋutasẽnu siwo ta woade ame ga alo atso kufia na ame la le videofefewo me faa. "​ Seth.
"Crimes that would be punishable by imprisonment or death are ‘committed’ in a video game without a second thought. "​ Seth.
"Le fefe geɖewo me la, ehiãna be amewo naɖu woƒe futɔwo dzi ale be woate ŋu aɖo woƒe taɖodzinuwo gbɔ.
"Many games involve defeating enemies to reach your goal.
Zi geɖe la, esia biana be woawu wo anyratɔe. "​ Annette.
Often, that means killing them in various gruesome ways. "​ Annette.
"Ɣeaɖewoɣi ne wò kple xɔ̃wò miele fefea ƒom la, màganya kura be ye xɔlɔ̃e yele gbɔgblɔm na be, ‘Ku la!’ alo ‘Mawu wò!’ o. "​ Nathan.
"Sometimes you can’t believe what you are saying to your friends as you play​ statements like ‘Die!’ or ‘I’m going to kill you!’ "​ Nathan.

Nya vevitɔ: Ƒo asa na fefe siwo me wowɔa nu siwo Mawu lé fui, abe ŋutasẽnuwɔwɔ, gbɔdɔnuwo alo gbegblẽnuwo wɔwɔ kple trɔ̃subɔsubɔ alo gbɔgbɔyɔyɔ ene.​ Galatiatɔwo 5:19-21; Efesotɔwo 5:10; 1 Yohanes 2:15, 16.
The bottom line: Avoid games that promote things that God hates, including violence, immoral sex, and spiritism.​ Galatians 5:​19-​21; Ephesians 5:​10; 1 John 2:​15, 16.
Biblia gblɔ be Yehowa lé fu "ame sia ame si lɔ̃a ŋutasẽnuwɔwɔ, " menye ame siwo wɔnɛ ɖeɖe koe o.
● The Bible says that Jehovah "hates anyone who loves violence "​ not just commits violence.
(Psalmo 11:5) Nenye be elektronikfefewo meɖe ame si nèdi be yeava nye la fia o hã la, ate ŋu aɖe ame si nènye xoxo la afia.
(Psalm 11:5) Even if your choice of electronic games doesn’t indicate the kind of person you will become, it may say something about the kind of person you already are.

Bu nya sia ŋu: Agbalẽ si nye Ale Si Nàlé Ðokuiwò Kpoo (ele yevugbe me) gblɔ be "anɔ eme godoo be videofefe siwo me wowɔa ŋutasẽnuwo le kpɔa ŋusẽ gã aɖe ɖe ɖeviwo ƒe nuwɔnawo dzi wu televisiondzifefewo, elabe menye film-meme xɔŋkɔawo ƒe adãwɔwɔ kple woƒe amewuwu teƒe ko wonɔa kpɔkpɔm o, ke boŋ wobunɛ be yewo ŋutɔwoe nye film-meme xɔŋkɔawo.

To think about: According to the book Getting to Calm, "violent video games probably have a greater impact on behavior than television, because kids aren’t merely watching the fierce and bloody hero​ they are the hero.
Esi fefewo le abe nufialawo le sukuxɔ me ene ta la, nu si koŋ wofiaa amewoe nye ŋutasẽnuwɔwɔ. "​ Tsɔe sɔ kple Yesaya 2:4.
Because game playing mirrors principles of learning, they’re essentially teaching violence. "​ Compare Isaiah 2:4.
Nyateƒea ŋutɔŋutɔ
Back to reality
Sɔhɛ geɖewo srɔ̃ ale si woada sɔ le elektronikfefewo zazã me.
Many young people have learned to be balanced in their use of electronic games.
Kpɔ esia ƒe kpɔɖeŋu eve aɖewo ɖa.
Consider two examples.
"Tsã la, menɔa videofefewo ƒom ʋuu zã koe tina. Menɔa gbɔgblɔm na ɖokuinye be: ‘Menye gaƒoƒo atɔ̃ ƒe alɔ̃ koe mehiã oa?
"I used to play video games until the latest possible hour, thinking: ‘I only need five hours of sleep, right?
Magaƒo vi aɖe kpɔ.’
Just one more level.’
Gake fifia meva srɔ̃ ale si mada sɔ le videofefewo gome.
Now, though, I’ve learned to put video games in their proper place.
Mebua videofefewo be wonye modzakaɖeɖe dodzidzɔname nyui aɖe si me manɔ gome kpɔm le ɣeaɖewoɣi.
I view playing them as a nice hobby that I can engage in from time to time.
Gake ele be mawɔ nu sia nu le ŋuɖɔɖo me. "​ Joseph.
But everything has to be done in moderation. "​ Joseph.
"Meɖe videofefewo ƒoƒo dzi kpɔtɔ, eye mekpɔa ɣeyiɣi wɔa nu geɖewo!
"I cut back on gaming, and I get so much more done!
Metrɔ asi le nye gbeƒãɖeɖedɔa ŋu wòganyo wu, mekpɔa vovo ɖe míaƒe hamea me tɔwo ŋu, eye mete ŋu srɔ̃ haƒoƒo gɔ̃ hã.
I’ve been able to improve my ministry, reach out to help others in my congregation, and even learn a musical instrument.
Nu bubu geɖewo li mate ŋu awɔ! "​ David.
There’s a whole other world out there! "​ David.

Biblia gblɔ be ŋutsu kple nyɔnu siwo si nuteƒekpɔkpɔ su ‘dana sɔna le nuwɔna me.’ (1 Timoteo 3:2, 11) Wosea vivi na modzakaɖeɖe, gake woɖoa seɖoƒe nɛ, eye wotea ŋu ɖua wo ɖokui dzi wɔa esia.​ Efesotɔwo 5:10.

● The Bible says that mature men and women are "moderate in habits. " (1 Timothy 3:​2, 11) They enjoy their recreation but know when to stop, and they have the self-control to do so.​ Ephesians 5:​10.
Nya vevitɔ: Elektronikfefewo ate ŋu anye modzakaɖeɖe nyui aɖe nenye be woɖo seɖoƒe na wo.
The bottom line: Playing electronic games can be good recreation if kept in its place.
Gake mègana fefeawo naxɔ wò ɣeyiɣiwo le asiwò alo awɔe be wò ŋku nadzo le agbemenu vevitɔwo dzi o.
But don’t let the games control your time or make you lose focus on the important things in life.
Le nyateƒe me la, le esi nàɖoe kplikpaa be yeaɖu dzi le fefe aɖe me teƒe la, ɖe manyo wu be nàɖoe be yeaɖo yeƒe agbemetaɖodzinuwo gbɔ ale be nànye dziɖula le agbemenuwɔna ŋutɔŋutɔwo me oa?
Really, instead of focusing too much on trying to achieve a goal in a game, wouldn’t it be better to invest that effort to reach your goals so that you can be a winner in real life?

WHAT YOUR PEERS SAY

Madison
"Ne videofefewo le wò xɔ dɔme eye mètea ŋu ɖua ɖokuiwò dzi o la, di teƒe bubu na wo!

Ele bɔbɔe be nàɖo ɣeyiɣi ɖe wo ƒoƒo ŋu, gake ne wole wò xɔ dɔme ya la, wo ƒoƒo dzi ko nànɔ zã bliboa katã. "​ Madison.
It’s easy to say that you’ll stop playing after a certain amount of time, but if they’re in your bedroom, you will probably just keep playing all night. "​ Madison.

Corbin

"Saying you’ll stop playing in 10 or 20 minutes never works.
Ɣeaɖewoɣi la, ahiã be nàtso kplaa, atsi fefea ahadi nu bubu aɖe awɔ.
Sometimes you just have to get up, turn off the game, and find something else to do.
Ðe manyo be nàte ‘videofefewo tete ame ɖokui’ kpɔ oa?
In fact, why not try a ‘video-game cleanse’?
Dzudzɔ videoƒoƒo ŋkeke ʋɛ aɖewo, eye nàtsɔ nu bubuwo abe baskɛtbɔl ene ƒoƒo aɖɔli wo. "​ Corbin.
Stop playing for a couple of days, and replace video games with something active, like basketball or working out. "​ Corbin.

Alexandria
"Ne ènɔa videofefe aɖe ƒom kaka zã ga ɖeka ƒona alo wua ema kura la, ke videofefe ma kpɔ ŋusẽ ɖe dziwò ale gbegbe be fefeae va ɖoa ɣeyiɣi si wòle be nàmlɔ anyi la na wò.
"If you’re staying up until 1:​00 a.m. or later playing a video game, then that game is controlling you to the point that the game tells you when to go to bed.
Medea ame ƒe lãmesẽ dzi kura o, eye mehiã be nàɖe mɔ esia nana ɖeɖi nate ŋuwò le ŋufɔke o. "​ Alexandria.
It’s not healthy, and it’s not worth feeling exhausted the next day. "​ Alexandria.
Aleke Mawɔ Aɖu Nye Seselelãmewo Dzi?
How Can I Control My Emotions?
"Ne mele dzidzɔ kpɔm sẽ ko kasia megalé blanui.
"One day I feel great, and the next day I’m down in the dumps.
Nu siwo dze nu bɔbɔe aɖe nam etsɔ si va yi la va dzea nu gã siwo ŋu léƒe mele o nam egbea. "​ Carissa.
Things that I viewed as no big deal yesterday become difficult to deal with today. "​ Carissa.
Ðe nèkpɔa dzidzɔ sẽ ko galèa blanui abe ale si mɔ dzekpodzeʋe le enea?
Do your emotions seem to go up and down like a bumpy road?
Ne nenemae la, nyati sia ate ŋu akpe ɖe ŋuwò!
If so, this article can help you!
Nu si gbɔ wòtsona
Why it happens
Nu etɔ̃ siwo nàte ŋu awɔ
Three things you can do
Nya siwo hawòtiwo gblɔ
What your peers say
Nu si gbɔ wòtsona
Why it happens
Dzidzɔkpɔkpɔ kple blanuiléle wòagbɔ eme nyea tɔtrɔ siwo vana le ƒewuime ƒe akpa aɖe.
Emotional highs and lows are common when you’re going through the changes of puberty.
Ne èle wò ƒewuiwo me yina ɖe ƒewuiwo ƒe nuwuwu lɔƒo gɔ̃ ha la, awɔ nuku na wò be tɔtrɔ siawo aganɔ vavam kokoko, mànya nu si gbɔ wotso o.
Even when you are well into your teen years, however, you might be surprised at how erratic and unpredictable your emotions can be.
Ne ètɔtɔ le ale si wò seselelãmewo trɔnae ŋu la, ɖo ŋku edzi be lãmetsiwo ƒe tɔtrɔ, vɔvɔ̃ kple makamakaɖeameɖokuidzi siwo vana ne ame le tsitsim gbɔe seselelãme siawo ƒe akpa gãtɔ tso.
If you’re confused by your up-and-down emotions, remember that many of these feelings are due to hormonal changes along with the insecurities and uncertainties that are a normal part of growth.
Nya nyuiae nye be, ate ŋu ase wò seselelãmewo gɔme ahanɔ te ɖe wo nu.
The good news is, you can understand and learn to cope with your emotions.
Nyateƒenya: Ele vevie be nàsrɔ̃ ale si nàɖu wò seselelãmewo dzi esime nènye ɖevi, elabe àva zã ŋutete sia le nɔnɔme vovovowo me ne ètsi.
Fact of life: Learning how to control your emotions while you are young is important, because you will need this skill in a variety of circumstances as an adult.
Ðekakpui aɖe le asa ƒom na dowo le mɔ aɖe dzi
A young man tries to avoid potholes in a road
Seselelãme manyomanyowo le abe mɔ si dzi dowo le ene.
Negative emotions are like potholes in a road.
Ne èdze aɖaŋu la, ate ŋu aƒo asa na gbegblẽawo eye nàyi wò mɔzɔzɔa dzi
With skill, you can avoid the worst ones and smooth out your ride
Nu etɔ̃ siwo nàte ŋu awɔ
Three things you can do
Ƒo nu tso eŋu.
Talk.
Biblia gblɔ be: "Xɔlɔ̃ vavã lɔ̃a ame ɣeawokatãɣi, eye ame nɔvi wònye wodzi ɖe xaxagbe ŋu. "​ Lododowo 17:17.
The Bible says: "A true friend shows love at all times and is a brother who is born for times of distress. "​ Proverbs 17:17.
"Xɔlɔ̃ aɖe le míaƒe ƒomea si, si ŋu mete ŋu tena ɖo.
"We have a close family friend whom I view as an aunt.
Eɖoa tom vevie ne mele nya aɖe gblɔm nɛ, eye meɖea dzi ɖi gblɔa nye nyawo nɛ.
She really pays attention to what I have to say, and I feel free to express myself to her.
Ne meɖe nye susu gblɔ eye wònyo la, ekpɔa dzidzɔ ɖe ŋunye, eye ne susua menyo o la, eɖɔam ɖo le mɔ nyuitɔ nu. "​ Yolanda.
When my viewpoint is right, she is proud of me, and if I’m wrong she corrects me in the best possible way. "​ Yolanda.
Kpekpeɖeŋu: Le esi nànɔ nu ƒom tso wò seselelãmewo ŋu na hawòtiwo​ siwo ɖewohĩ woawo hã le nɔnɔme ma ke me​ ɖeɖeko teƒe la, ɖo dze tso eŋu na dziwòlawo loo alo ame bubu si dzi nèka ɖo.
Tip: Rather than talking only to your peers​ who may be going through the same emotional ups and downs that you are​ talk to a parent or another trusted adult.
Ŋlɔ nu tso eŋu.
Write.
Biblia gblɔ be esi dzi ɖe le Hiob ƒo vevie la, egblɔ be: "Matrɔ nye dzimaɖitsitsiwo aƒo ɖi bababa.
The Bible tells of Job, who in the depths of despair said: "I will give vent to my complaints.
Maƒo nu le nye vevesese helĩhelĩ la ta! "
I will speak out in my bitter distress! "
(Hiob 10:1) Tsɔ kpe ɖe nuƒoƒo tso kuxia ŋu na ame aɖe ŋu la, mɔ bubu si nu ‘nàƒo nu’ lee nye be nàŋlɔ nu tso ale si nèle sesem le ɖokuiwò me ŋu la ɖi.
(Job 10:1) Besides talking to someone, another way you can "speak out " is by writing about your feelings.
"Agbalẽvi aɖe nɔa ŋunye ɣesiaɣi.
"I take a small notepad everywhere.
Ne nane dzɔ si do dziku nam la, meŋlɔnɛ ɖi.
When something happens that upsets me, I write about it.
Nuŋɔŋlɔ alea nana nye dzi dzea eme ŋutɔ. "​ Iliana.
Writing is incredibly therapeutic for me. "​ Iliana.
Kpekpeɖeŋu: Agbalẽvi aɖe nenɔ asiwò si me nàte ŋu anɔ ale si nèsena le ɖokuiwò me, nu si nana nèsena le ɖokuiwò nenema, kple ale si nàte ŋu aɖu wo dzi la ŋlɔm ɖo.
Tip: Keep a journal in which you can write about the emotions you feel, what triggered them, and how you might deal with them.
Dɔwɔgbalẽvi si kpe ɖe nyati sia ŋu la ate ŋu akpe ɖe ŋuwò.
The worksheet that accompanies this article can help you do that.
Do gbe ɖa tso eŋu.
Pray.
Biblia gblɔ be: "Dro wò agba ɖe Yehowa dzi, ekema alé wò ɖe te.
The Bible says: "Throw your burden on Jehovah, and he will sustain you.
Mana ame dzɔdzɔe nadze anyi akpɔ o. "​ Psalmo 55:22.
Never will he allow the righteous one to fall. "​ Psalm 55:22.
"Medoa gbe ɖa na Yehowa edziedzi ne dzi ɖe le ƒonye.
"I pray to Jehovah constantly when I’m distressed.
Ne megblɔ nye dzimenyawo nɛ vɔ la, nye dzi dzea eme. "​ Jasmine.
I always feel relief after I pour my heart out to him. "​ Jasmine.
Kpekpeɖeŋu: Togbɔ be àtsi dzimaɖi hã la, bu nu etɔ̃ siwo ta nàda akpe ɖo le wò agbe me la ŋu.
Tip: Despite the anxiety you feel, think of three things in your life you can be thankful for.
Ne èdo gbe ɖa na Yehowa la, bia kpekpeɖeŋu, eye mègaŋlɔ be nàda akpe nɛ ɖe yayra siwo su asiwò la ta o.
When you pray to Jehovah, ask for help​ but also express thanks for the blessings you have.

In some lands, young people are spending less time being physically active, and it is putting their health at risk.
Ðeko wòsɔ nyuie be Biblia gblɔ be "ŋutilãmamla nyo. " (1 Timoteo 4:8) Bu nya siwo gbɔna ŋu kpɔ:
For good reason, the Bible acknowledges that "physical training is beneficial. " (1 Timothy 4:8) Consider the following:
Kamedede ate ŋu ana dzi nanɔ dzɔwòm wu.
Exercise can improve your outlook.
Kamedede nana ahɔhɔ̃a tua lãmetsi siwo woyɔna be endorphins, si nana ame ƒe dzi dzea eme eye wòkpɔa dzidzɔ.
Physical activity releases endorphins brain chemicals that make you feel relaxed and happy.

"Ne mefɔ ŋdi kanya vɛ ƒu du la, mewɔa dɔ nyuie wu le ŋkekea me eye dzi dzɔam.

Duƒuƒu nana nye dzi dzea eme. "
Running lifts my mood. "

Regina.

Balanced exercise will help you become stronger, fitter, and more likely to project self-confidence.
"Dzi le dzɔyem ŋutɔ be fifia metea ŋu dea kame le mɔ aɖe si nu menya wɔna nam le ƒe si va yi me o!
"It feels great to be able to do ten chin-ups a year ago there was no way I could do even one!

Kamedede ate ŋu ana nànɔ agbe didi.

Kamedede nana ame ƒe dzi, ʋukawo kple dzitodzitowo wɔa dɔ nyuie.
Being active benefits your cardiovascular and respiratory systems.
Kamedede ate ŋu ana hã be ame maxɔ dzidɔ o dzidɔ nye dɔléle siwo wua ŋutsuwo kple nyɔnuwo siaa wu la dometɔ ɖeka.

Ðɔ ŋu ɖo
Be balanced
Biblia gblɔ na ŋutsuwo kple nyɔnuwo siaa be "woada asɔ le nuwɔna me. " (1 Timoteo 3:2, 11) Eya ta ɖɔ ŋu ɖo le kamedede ŋu.
The Bible tells both men and women to be "moderate in habits. " (1 Timothy 3:2, 11) So be balanced about exercise.

People who take working out to extremes often come across as vain.
Ðetugbui aɖe si ŋkɔe nye Julia gblɔ be: "Ne ɖekakpui aɖe tsia dzi ɖe ale si wòana eƒe lãme natò ŋu gake metsia dzi ɖe susu ŋu dɔ wɔwɔ ŋu tututu o la, eƒe nu manyo ŋunye o. "

Ðetugbui aɖe si ŋkɔe nye Vera gblɔ be: "Nyɔnuvi geɖe dzraa ame siwo wodina be yewoaɖi la ƒe fotowo ɖo henɔa wo kpɔm be wòade dzi ƒo na yewo ne yewoade kame.
