Hadede vɔ̃wo gblẽa nɔnɔme nyuiwo. "​ 1 Korintotɔwo 15:33.
Bad associations spoil useful habits. "​ 1 Corinthians 15:33.
Kpekpeɖeŋu: Tia ame si si nɔnɔme nyuiwo le, ke menye ame si nya kpɔ le gotagome ko o.
Tip: Choose someone who has good qualities, not merely an impressive outer appearance.
Ne menye nenema o la, wò mɔkpɔkpɔ azu dzodzro.
Otherwise, you may be setting yourself up for disappointment.
"Ne ètsɔa ɖokuiwò sɔna kple ame siwo dze ɖeka alo dze tugbe hedzrana ɖo kpeɖii ɣesiaɣi la, àse le ɖokuiwò me be ye ya yemele ɖeke me o.
"It makes you feel very small and ugly when you constantly compare yourself to glamorous people.
Ate ŋu ana nàva tsi dzi fũu akpa ɖe wò dzedzeme ŋu. "​ Tamara.
It can make you obsess over your appearance. "​ Tamara.
Bu nya sia ŋu: Kuxi kawoe ate ŋu ado mo ɖa ne ame xɔŋkɔwo kple kamedefefewɔlawoe nye ame siwo ƒe kpɔɖeŋu nèsrɔ̃na?
To think about: What may be the pitfalls of choosing celebrities and athletes as role models?
Ame siwo ƒe kpɔɖeŋu nàsrɔ̃ ate ŋu ana nàɖo wo taɖodzinuwo gbɔ loo alo màɖo wo gbɔ o.
Your choice of role models can affect whether you achieve your goals.
Biblia gblɔ be: "Ame si zɔna kple nunyalawo la, adze nunya. "​ Lododowo 13:20.
The Bible states: "The one walking with the wise will become wise. "​ Proverbs 13:20.
Kpekpeɖeŋu: Tia ame siwo si nɔnɔme nyui siwo nèdi be yeaɖe afia la le.
Tip: Select role models whose conduct demonstrates the good qualities you want to display.
Ne èle ŋku lém ɖe wo ŋu la, àte ŋu asrɔ̃ afɔ ŋutɔŋutɔ siwo nàte ŋu aɖe be nàtu nɔnɔme mawo ɖo.
As you observe them, you may learn specific steps you can take toward your goal.
"Be nàɖo taɖodzinu gbadzaa ko abe ‘Medi be maɖo ta’ teƒe la, àte ŋu agblɔ be, ‘Medi be maɖo ta abe Jane ene.
"Rather than setting a vague goal like ‘I want to be more responsible,’ you can say, ‘I want to be more responsible like Jane.
Enɔa game dzi ɣesiaɣi eye wòléa fɔ ɖe eƒe dɔdeasiwo ŋu wɔna.’ "​ Miriam.
She is always on time and takes her assignments seriously.’ "​ Miriam.
Nya vevitɔ: Ne èsrɔ̃ ame si ɖɔ ʋu ƒe kpɔɖeŋu la, àva zu ame si ƒomevi nèdi be yeanye.
The bottom line: When you choose a good role model, you take control over the type of person you will become.
Ðekakpui aɖe dze ame aɖe si ƒe kpɔɖeŋu wòate ŋu asrɔ̃ yome
A young man follows a good role model
Ame siwo ɖoa kpɔɖeŋu nyui ƒe kpɔɖeŋu sɔsrɔ̃ ate ŋu anye mɔ bɔbɔetɔ si dzi nàto aɖo wò taɖodzinuwo gbɔ!
Following a good role model can be a shortcut to achieving your goals! How to choose
Ame si ƒe kpɔɖeŋu nàsrɔ̃ la tiatia
You can select a role model in one of two ways.
Àte ŋu atia ame si ƒe kpɔɖeŋu nèdi be yeasrɔ̃ le mɔ eve siawo dometɔ ɖeka nu.
You can pick a quality you want to work on and then find someone you admire who has that quality.
Àte ŋu atia ame si ƒe nu dzɔa dzi na wò eye nàtia nɔnɔme nyui aɖe si le esi si nèdi be yeatu ɖo.
You can choose someone you admire and then select a quality he or she displays that you want to develop.
Dɔwɔgbalẽvi si kpe ɖe nyati sia ŋu la akpe ɖe ŋuwò nàwɔ esia.
The worksheet that accompanies this article can help you do that.
Ame siwo ƒe kpɔɖeŋu nàte ŋu asrɔ̃ la dometɔ aɖewo ate ŋu anye:
Your role models can include:
Hawòtiwo.
Peers.
"Medi be manɔ abe xɔ̃nye vevia ene.
"My best friend is someone I want to be like.
Ne vovo mele eŋu o gɔ̃ hã la, etsɔa ɖe le eme na ame.
She is never too busy to stop and show concern for someone else.
Menye xoxo nɛ, gake mekpɔ nɔnɔme nyui aɖewo siwo mele asinye o la le eŋu eye medi be masrɔ̃ eƒe kpɔɖeŋu. "​ Miriam.
She is younger than I am, but I see in her beautiful qualities that I lack, and it makes me want to follow her example. "​ Miriam.
Ame tsitsiwo.
Adults.
Esiawo ate ŋu anye dziwòlawo alo ame siwo le subɔsubɔ ɖeka me kpli wò.
These can be your parents or members of your faith.
"Ðikeke mele eme o, dzinyela eveawo nye ame siwo ƒe kpɔɖeŋu mesrɔ̃na.
"Without a doubt, both of my parents are role models for me.
Nɔnɔme nyui aɖewo le wo si.
They have wonderful qualities.
Wowɔa vodadawo ya, gake mekpɔe be wokpɔtɔ nye nuteƒewɔlawo hã.
I do see their faults, but I also see that they are still faithful despite them.
Ne metsi abe woawo ene la, avivi nam ne woate ŋu agblɔ nenema tso ŋunye. "​ Annette.
When I am their age, I hope the same can be said of me. "​ Annette.
Bibliamemewo.
Bible characters.
"Metia Bibliameme geɖe siwo ƒe kpɔɖeŋu medi be masrɔ̃ ɖe susu vovovowo ta. Woawoe nye Timoteo, Rut, Hiob, Petro, Israel-nyɔnuvi suea.
"I have chosen several role models from the Bible​ Timothy, Ruth, Job, Peter, the little Israelite girl​ each for a different reason.
Zi ale si mesrɔ̃ nu tso wo ŋu la, zi nenemae wonyea ame ŋutɔŋutɔ nam.
The more I learn about Bible characters, the more real they become.

Ŋutinya siwo le Srɔ̃ Woƒe Xɔse gbalẽa me kple ‘Bibliameme Siwo Ƒe Kpɔɖeŋu Nàte Ŋu Asrɔ̃’ siwo le Questions Young People Ask​ Answers That Work (Les jeunes s’interrogent​ Réponses pratiques) babla evea siaa me dzodzro do dzidzɔ nam ŋutɔ. "​ Melinda.

I’ve really enjoyed studying the accounts in the book Imitate Their Faith, as well as the ‘Role Model Index’ found in both volumes of the book Questions Young People Ask​ Answers That Work. "​ Melinda.
Kpekpeɖeŋu: Mègatia ame ɖeka aɖe ko o.
Tip: Don’t limit yourself to only one role model.
Apostolo Paulo gblɔ na hati Kristotɔwo be: "Miaƒe ŋku nanɔ ame siwo le zɔzɔm ɖe kpɔɖeŋu si míeɖo na mi nu la ŋu. "​ Filipitɔwo 3:17.
The apostle Paul said to fellow Christians: "Keep your eye on those who are walking in a way that is in harmony with the example we set for you. "​ Philippians 3:​17.
Ènyaa?
Did you know?
Ame aɖe hã ate ŋu asrɔ̃ wò kpɔɖeŋu!
You can be someone’s role model!
Biblia gblɔ be: ‘Nye kpɔɖeŋu na nuteƒewɔlawo le nuƒoƒo me, le agbenɔnɔ me, le lɔlɔ̃ me, le xɔse me, le agbe dzadzɛ nɔnɔ me.’​ 1 Timoteo 4:12.
The Bible says: "Become an example to the faithful ones in speaking, in conduct, in love, in faith, in chasteness. "​ 1 Timothy 4:​12.
"Togbɔ be ɖewohĩ ègakpɔtɔ le asi trɔm le wò nɔnɔmewo ŋu hã, ame aɖe ate asrɔ̃ kpɔɖeŋu si nèɖona le ɣeyiɣi ma ke me.
"You can be a work in progress and still help others to be better at the same time.
Mànya ame si le ŋku lém ɖe ŋuwò o, eye mànya ale si nya si nàgblɔ la ate ŋu atrɔ ame aɖe ƒe agbenɔnɔ o. "​ Kiana.
You never know who is watching, and you never know how what you say can change a person’s life. "​ Kiana.
Nya siwo hawòtiwo gblɔ
What your peers say
Emma
Emma
"Fefewɔla xɔŋkɔ geɖe gblẽa nu le woƒe ŋutilã si Yehowa na wo ŋu.
"Many celebrities abuse the body that Jehovah gave them.
Ne míesrɔ̃ ame mawo tɔgbi la, ɖeko wòagblẽ nu le mía ŋu eye wòakpɔ ŋusẽ gbegblẽ ɖe ale si míenɔa agbe nyui la dzi. "​ Emma.
Looking up to people like that will only do us harm and may distort our view of the normal way to behave. "​ Emma.
Justine
Justine
"Ame nyui aɖe ƒe kpɔɖeŋu sɔsrɔ̃ kpena ɖe ame ŋu wòkpɔa dzidzedze le agbe me.
"Having a good role model helps you succeed in life.
Egblẽa nu le ame ŋu ne èto nanewo me hafi srɔ̃ nunya tso eme, gake enyo wu ne èlé ŋku ɖe ame aɖe ŋu eye nènya nu si tututu wòle be nàwɔ. "​ Justine.
You can find out the hard way by experience, or you can watch someone and know exactly what you need to do. "​ Justine.
Micah
Micah
"Ahiã be nàdi ame siwo ƒe kpɔɖeŋu nàdi be yeasrɔ̃, esia bia be nanya amewo eye nàna kadodo nanɔ mia dome.
"You may have to search for role models, which involves getting to know people and developing a relationship with them.
Àte ŋu akpɔ ame siawo le teƒe si mele mɔ kpɔm na o. "​ Micah.
Role models can be found in unexpected places. " Micah.
Ke Ne Lãmesẽkuxiwo Ðe Kpe Nam Ðe?
What if I Have a Health Problem?
Akpa 1
(Part 1)
Ènya sɔhɛ aɖe si lãmesẽkuxiwo ɖe kpe na veviea?
Do you know a young person who is dealing with a serious health problem?
Ðe nèle dɔ aɖe lém si na be mètea ŋu wɔa nu siwo hawòtiwo wɔna oa?
Do you have an illness or disability that prevents you from enjoying the activities that others your age take part in?
Nenye nenemae la, eme kɔ be dzi ate ŋu aɖe le ƒowò ɣeaɖewoɣi.
If so, it’s only natural for you to be discouraged at times.
Wɔwòla, Yehowa Mawu, nya nɔnɔme si me nèle la nyuie.
The Bible, however, contains two very comforting thoughts.
Gawu la, ‘etsɔa ɖe le eme’ na wò.
Your Creator, Jehovah God, knows your situation.
1 Petro 5:7.
More than that, "he cares for you. " 1 Peter 5:7.
Yehowa Mawu ɖoe be yeaɖe dɔlélewo katã ɖa!
Jehovah God’s purpose is to cure all sickness!
Àte ŋu axlẽ nu tso esia ŋu le Biblia me le Yesaya 33:24 kple Nyaɖeɖefia 21:1-4.
You can read about that in the Bible at Isaiah 33:24 and Revelation 21:1-4.
Sɔhɛ siwo lãmesẽkuxiwo ɖe kpe na dometɔ geɖe kpɔe be kaka ɖe Mawu kple eƒe ŋugbedodowo dzie lé yewo ɖe te.
Countless young people who face challenging health problems have found that faith in God and in his promises sustains them.
Wo dometɔ ene aɖewoe nye esi.
Consider four examples.
YEIMY
YEIMY
MATTEO
MATTEO
BRUNA
BRUNA
ANDRÉ
ANDRÉ
YEIMY
YEIMY
Esi mexɔ ƒe wuiɖekɛ la bunɔkeke me menɔna hafi tea ŋu yia afi sia afi.
By the time I was 11, I needed a wheelchair to get around.
Naneke menya wɔna nam o, nu suetɔ kekeake gɔ̃ hã kɔkɔ nyea dɔ nam.
I’m unable to perform simple tasks, such as lifting even light objects.
Esi mexɔ ƒe atɔ̃ la, wokpɔ lãmekawo ƒe gbɔdzɔgbɔdzɔdɔ si nana wɔna vɔna le ame ŋu le ŋunye, esia na naneke meganya wɔna nam o.
At age five, I was diagnosed with muscular dystrophy, a degenerative illness that greatly limits me.
Dzi ɖena le ƒonye ɣeaɖewoɣi elabe nyemetea ŋu wɔa nu siwo hanyetiwo wɔna o.
At times, I get discouraged because I can’t do the things that others my age can.
Gake dzinyelawo kple míaƒe hametɔwo naa ŋutilã me kple seselelãme kpekpeɖeŋum eye wòkpena ɖe ŋunye le mawusubɔsubɔ gome hã.
But my parents and those in my congregation give me physical, emotional, and spiritual support.
Menye ɣeyiɣiawo katã ƒe subɔla, eye nye haxɔsetɔwo kplɔam zi geɖe míeyina ɖasrɔ̃a Biblia kple ame siwo tsɔ ɖe le Biblia me nyawo me.
I serve as a full-time minister, and fellow Christians often accompany me as I conduct Bible studies with interested ones.
Yesu gblɔ be ŋkeke ɖe sia ɖe kple eƒe dzimaɖitsitsiwoe.
Jesus said that each day has its own anxieties.
(Mateo 6:34) Eya ta medzea agbagba be manɔ te ɖe ŋkeke ɖe sia ɖe ƒe kuxiwo nu eye meɖoa taɖodzinu siwo gbɔ mate ŋu aɖo la na ɖokuinye.
(Matthew 6:34) So I try to take one day at a time and set realistic goals for myself that I can reach and achieve.
Mele mɔ kpɔm na xexe yeye si me "agbe vavã " asu asinye le, afi si mavo tso dɔléle vɔ̃ɖi sia si me le.
I look forward to the day in God’s new world when I will be able to have "the real life, " free of this debilitating illness.
1 Timoteo 6:19.
1 Timothy 6:19.
Bu nya sia ŋu: Yeimy kpɔe be ede ye dzi ŋutɔ esi yeɖo "taɖodzinu " siwo gbɔ yeate ŋu aɖo la na ye ɖokui.
To think about: Yeimy finds it helpful to "set realistic goals. "
Ðe manyo be wò hã nàwɔ nenema oa? 1 Korintotɔwo 9:26.
How can you do the same? 1 Corinthians 9:26.
MATTEO
MATTEO
Dzime tem veve esi mexɔ ƒe ade, eye ɖɔktawo gblɔ gbã be esi mele tsitsim tae.
My back began to hurt when I was six years old, and at first the doctors blamed growing pains.
Gake wova de dzesii le ƒe ɖeka megbe be nutete aɖe le nye dzimeƒu ŋu.
A year later, though, they discovered that a tumor had developed along my spine.
Wowɔ dɔ nam, gake nutetea ƒe akpa 40 le alafa me koe ɖɔkta te ŋu ɖe.
I had an operation, but the surgeon was able to remove only about 40 percent of the tumor.
Ke hã le ɣleti eve pɛ ko me la, nutetea gatrɔ gbɔ keŋ!
And then in just two months the tumor was back to its original size!
Tso ɣemaɣi la, wodom kpɔ zi geɖe, wote dɔdamɔnu geɖewo kpɔ, eye mekpɔ mɔ zi geɖe be woada dɔa nam gake ɖeko wòglo.
Since then, I’ve had many examinations, many treatments, and many disappointments.
Ɣeaɖewoɣi la, nutete la nana mesea veve abe yi tɔmee wole afi sia afi nam ene, gake vevesesea nu sẽna wu le dzime kple akɔta.
At times, the tumor causes pain like knife stabs all over, but mostly in my back and chest.
Medzea agbagba be nyemagaɖe mɔ nye nɔnɔmea nakpe dzinye o.
Still, I try not to be consumed with my situation.
Meɖoa ŋku edzi na ɖokuinye be ame bubuwo tɔ wu tɔnye gake womenaa ta o.
I remind myself that others have endured terrible things too, and yet they’ve remained positive.
Nu vevitɔ si kpena ɖe ŋunye dzi gakpɔtɔ le ƒonyee nye ale si meka ɖe edzi be Yehowa Mawu ana ŋugbe si wòdo be yeaɖe fukpekpe ɖa nava eme gbe ɖeka.
My greatest help in maintaining a positive attitude is my confidence that one day Jehovah God will fulfill his promise to end all suffering.
Nyaɖeɖefia 21:4.
Revelation 21:4.
Bu nya sia ŋu: Aleke ŋugbe si Mawu do be yeaɖe fukpekpe ɖa ate ŋu akpe ɖe ŋuwò abe ale si wòkpe ɖe Matteo ŋu ene?
To think about: How can thinking about God’s promise to end suffering help you endure, as it helped Matteo?
Yesaya 65:17.
Isaiah 65:17.
BRUNA
BRUNA
Esi wònye be nye dɔlélea medzena le gota wokpɔna o ta la, ame aɖewo buna be kuviatɔe menye.
Since there are no outward signs of my disease, some people might think that I’m lazy.
Gake le nyateƒe me la, naneke menya wɔna nam o, eɖanye aƒemedɔwo alo nusɔsrɔ̃ o, eye avu kple kɔe fɔfɔ le aba dzi gɔ̃ hã nyena nam.
Really, though, everything can be difficult for me, including chores, study, or even getting up from bed.

Wokpɔ ʋukamexexedɔ le ŋunye esi mexɔ ƒe 16. Dɔ sia si nana be wɔna vɔna le ame ŋu va le tsitsim ɖe edzi. Ewɔe be nyemegatea ŋu wɔa dɔ o, eye Kristotɔwo ƒe dɔ siwo madi be mawɔ la gɔ̃ hã menya wɔna nam o.

When I was 16, I was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis, a debilitating and progressive disease that has affected my ability not only to work but also to share in Christian activities to the extent that I would like.
Mexlẽa 1 Petro 5:7 enuenu, kpukpui sia gblɔ be: "Miedro miaƒe dzimaɖitsitsiwo katã ɖe eyama dzi, elabena eléa be na mi. "
I repeatedly read 1 Peter 5:7, which says: "Throw all your anxiety upon [God], because he cares for you. "
Enyanya be Yehowa tsɔa ɖe le eme na mía dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe la doa ŋusẽm ŋutɔ.
I draw strength from the thought that Jehovah cares for each of us individually.
Esia kpɔtɔ doa ŋusẽ va se ɖe egbe.
It continues to strengthen me to this day.
Bu nya sia ŋu: Aleke wò dzimaɖitsitsiwo dodro ɖe Yehowa dzi ate ŋu aɖe vi na wò abe ale si wònɔ le Bruna gome ene?
To think about: How can you benefit by throwing your anxieties on Jehovah, as Bruna does?
Psalmo 55:23.
Psalm 55:22.
ANDRÉ
ANDRÉ
Ame aɖewo wɔa nu ɖe ŋunye abe ƒe 10 vi dzaa ko menye ene.
Some people treat me as if I were a 10-year-old child.
Nyemebu fɔ wo o, elabe meɖi ƒe 10 vi hã vavã.
I can’t blame them, though; after all, I look like one.
Esi mexɔ ƒe eve la, wokpɔ kansa ƒomevi aɖe si mebɔ o le nye dzimeƒuka me eye dɔ sia va ge ɖe nye ahɔhɔ̃ me emegbe.
At age two, I was diagnosed with a rare type of cancer that began in the spinal cord and then traveled to the brain.
Ðɔktawo dze agbagba lé enu, gake atike siwo wòzã nam la na meku te.
Doctors managed to control the disease, but the treatments affected my growth.
Egbea nye kɔkɔme katãe nye meta 1 kple sentimeta 37 pɛ ko.
Today, I’m only 1.37 meters (4 ft 6 in.) tall.
Ne megblɔ na amewo be mexɔ ƒe 18 la, ɖeko wo dometɔ geɖe susunɛ be aʋatso kam mele!
Many people think I’m lying when I tell them that I’m 18 years old!
Le Kristo-hamea me la, amewo dea bubu ŋunye.
In the Christian congregation, people treat me with dignity.
Womeɖua fewu le ŋunye abe ale si nye sukuhatiwo wɔna ene o.
They don’t play childish pranks on me, as did the kids with whom I went to school.
Medzea agbagba be nyemagaɖe mɔ nye nɔnɔmea nana dzi naɖe le ƒonye o.
I try to keep a positive attitude about my situation.
Le nyateƒe me la, nu nyuitɔ kekeake si ate ŋu asu amegbetɔ si la su asinye, eyae nye be menya Yehowa!
Really, the best thing that could happen to a human being has happened to me I’ve come to know Jehovah!
Eɖanye fukpekpe kae nye dɔlélea ahe va dzinye o, meka ɖe edzi be Yehowa akpe ɖe ŋunye le mɔ sia mɔ nu.
Whatever I must endure, I am sure of Jehovah’s care every step of the way.
Xexe yeye wɔnuku si ƒe ŋugbe Yehowa Mawu do la ŋu bubu kpena ɖe ŋunye medoa dzi.
Thinking of the marvelous new world that Jehovah God has promised helps me to keep a positive attitude.
Yesaya 33:24.
Isaiah 33:24.
Bu nya sia ŋu: Nu ka tae Yehowa nyanyae nye "nu nyuitɔ kekeake si ate ŋu asu amegbetɔ si " abe ale si André gblɔe ene?
To think about: Why is coming to know Jehovah, as André puts it, "the best thing that can happen to a human being "?
Yohanes 17:3.
John 17:3.
Ke Ne Lãmesẽkuxiwo Ðe Kpe Nam Ðe?
What if I Have a Health Problem?
Akpa 2
(Part 2)
Lãmesẽkuxi ƒomevi vovovowoe li.
Health problems come in many forms.
Ame aɖewo tɔ dzena le gota wokpɔna, gake ame bubuwo ya tɔ nɔa ememe.
Some people have symptoms that are evident on the outside, while others have effects that are felt only on the inside.
Lãmesẽkuxi aɖewo nɔa anyi sẽe gadzona, gake bubuwo ya nɔ anyi ɖaa eye wòhiãna be woakpe akɔ kplii gbe sia gbe.
Some health problems "visit " only on occasion, while others "move in " and present challenges every day.
Wotea ŋu daa wo dometɔ aɖewo alo léa wo nu, gake ɖewo ya nu nɔa sesẽm eye wotea ŋu wua ame gɔ̃ hã.
Some can be cured or at least managed, while others are degenerative​ perhaps even threatening a person’s life.
Sɔhɛwo dzea ŋgɔ lãmesẽkuxi siwo katã ŋu míeƒo nu tsoe fifia.
Young people face all the types of health challenges noted here.
Nya siwo wo dometɔ ene siwo le avu wɔm kple lãmesẽkuxi siawo tɔgbi gblɔ la dze le nyati sia me.
In this article, you will meet four who have such challenges.
Ne dɔléle aɖe ɖe kpe na wò la, nya siwo wogblɔ ate ŋu ade dzi ƒo na wò.
If you suffer from a health problem, you may be encouraged by their comments.
GUÉNAELLE
GUÉNAELLE
ZACHARY
ZACHARY
ANAÏS
ANAÏS
JULIANA
JULIANA
GUÉNAELLE
GUÉNAELLE
Nu si sesẽna nam wue nye be malɔ̃ ɖe edzi be dɔnɔe menye.
The hardest thing for me is to accept my limits.
Medina be mawɔ nu gbogbo aɖewo, gake nu siwo nɔnɔmea ɖe mɔ be mawɔ gbe sia gbe koe metea ŋu wɔna.
I want to do so many things, but each day I have to adapt to my condition.
Lãmekadɔléle aɖe le ŋunye si wɔnɛ be nyatakakawo metea ŋu tsoa ahɔhɔ̃a gbɔ yia ŋutilã ƒe akpa bubuwo tututu o.
I have a motor-neuromuscular disorder that prevents my brain from correctly passing information to my body.
Ɣeaɖewoɣi la, nye ŋutilã ƒe akpa ɖewo, tso ta va ɖo afɔgɔme, ʋuʋuna alo tuna.
Different parts of my body, from head to toe, will sometimes tremble or become paralyzed.
Nu siwo le bɔbɔe gɔ̃ hã wɔwɔ sesẽna nam.
I have difficulty with basic tasks, such as moving, speaking, reading, writing, and understanding others.
Esesẽna nam be mazɔ, maƒo nu, maxlẽ nu, aŋlɔ nu alo awɔ dɔ bubuwo.
When things are especially hard, the elders from my congregation pray with me.
Ne nɔnɔmeawo sesẽ nam ŋutɔ la, hamemetsitsi siwo le míaƒe hamea me doa gbe ɖa kplim, eye nye dzi dzea eme enumake.
When they do that, I feel calmer right away.
Le kuxi ɖe sia ɖe me la, mesena le ɖokuinye me be Yehowa Mawu li kplim ɣesiaɣi eye wòdoa ŋusẽm.
Whatever trials I face, I feel that Jehovah God is always there to sustain me.
Nyemedina be maɖe mɔ nye dɔlélea nawɔe be mado kpo esubɔsubɔ bliboe o.
I do not want my illness to prevent me from serving him fully.
Nye taɖodzinu vevi aɖee nye be makpe ɖe amewo ŋu woasrɔ̃ nu tso Biblia me ŋugbedodo si nye be madidi o Yehowa Mawu ana anyigba nazu paradiso, afi si fukpekpe maganɔ o, la ŋu.​ Nyaɖeɖefia 21:1-4.
I make it a priority to help others to learn of the Bible’s promise that soon Jehovah God will make the earth a paradise, where suffering will be no more.​ Revelation 21:1-4.
Bu nya sia ŋu: Abe ale si Guénaelle wɔe ene la, mɔ kawo nue wò hã àte ŋu akpe ɖe ame bubuwo ŋu le?​ 1 Korintotɔwo 10:24.
To think about: In what ways can you, like Guénaelle, show your compassion for others?​ 1 Corinthians 10:24.
ZACHARY
ZACHARY
Esi mexɔ ƒe 16 la, ɖɔktawo kpɔ ahɔhɔ̃mekansa vɔ̃ɖi aɖe le ŋunye.
When I was 16, I was diagnosed with an aggressive form of brain cancer.
Wogblɔ nam be ŋkeke enyi koe maganɔ agbe.
The doctors told me I had only eight months to live.
Eye menɔ avu wɔm kple dɔléle ma tso ɣemaɣi va ɖo egbe.
I have been battling for my life ever since.
Fifia metu le nye ɖusikpa dzi elabe ɖusikpa dzie kansaa le.
Because of the placement of the tumors, I am now a right-side hemiplegic.
Esi nyemetea ŋu zɔna o ta ehiã be ame aɖe nanɔ gbɔnye le aƒea me anɔ kpekpem ɖe ŋunye.
Since I am unable to walk, someone always needs to be at home to help me get around.
Esi dɔlélea nyra ɖe edzi la, nye nuƒo me megakɔna o.
The progression of my disease has made it difficult for me to communicate clearly.
Tsã la, mewɔa nu geɖewo. Mekua skii le tsi dzi, eye meƒoa basketball kple volleyball hã.
I used to be a very active person who enjoyed waterskiing, basketball, and volleyball.
Esi wònye Yehowa Ðasefoe menye ta la, medoa vevie nu le Kristotɔwo ƒe gbeƒãɖeɖedɔa hã me.
As one of Jehovah’s Witnesses, I was active in the Christian ministry.
Nyemeka ɖe edzi be ame geɖe ate ŋu ase ale si wosesẽ be ŋutete maganɔ ame ŋu wòawɔ nu siwo wɔwɔ doa dzidzɔ nɛ vevie la o gɔme o.
I don’t think most people understand what it’s like to lose the ability to do the things you love so much.
Nya siwo le Yesaya 57:15 de dzi ƒo nam ŋutɔ, elabe wona kakaɖedzim be Yehowa Mawu li kple ‘ame siwo wogbã gudugudu’ la eye wòléa be na wo.
I find the words recorded at Isaiah 57:15 encouraging because they assure me that Jehovah God is there for those who are ‘crushed in spirit’ and that he cares for me.
Eye ŋugbe si Yehowa do le Yesaya 35:6 be magazɔ ake eye manɔ lãmesẽ blibo me asubɔ ye la hã dea dzi ƒo nam.
Also Isaiah 35:6 contains the promise from Jehovah that I will be able to walk again and serve him in perfect health.
Togbɔ be nye dɔlélea nu sẽna ɣeaɖewoɣi ŋutɔ hã la, meka ɖe edzi be Yehowa li kplim.
Even though at times it can be very difficult to deal with my illness, I am assured that I have Jehovah’s backing.
Ne nu te ɖe dzinye alo mele vɔvɔ̃m be nye agbe nu le yiyi ge la, medoa gbe ɖa na ame ɖeka si mate ŋu aƒo nu na ɣesiaɣi la.
By means of prayer, I always have someone to talk to when I’m feeling down or fear for my life.
Naneke mate ŋu amam ɖa tso Yehowa ƒe lɔlɔ̃ la gbɔ o.​ Romatɔwo 8:39.
Nothing can separate me from Jehovah’s love.​ Romans 8:39.
Zachary ku esime míebia gbee ƒe ɣleti eve megbe, exɔ ƒe 18.
Zachary fell asleep in death at the age of 18, two months after he was interviewed.
Exɔe se vevie be Mawu afɔ ame kukuwo woava nɔ paradiso me le anyigba dzi va se ɖe gbe si gbe wòku.
His faith in God’s promise of a resurrection to a paradise earth remained strong to the end.
Bu nya sia ŋu: Aleke gbedodoɖa ate ŋu akpe ɖe ŋuwò be nàkpɔtɔ anɔ Mawu ƒe lɔlɔ̃ la me abe Zachary ene?
To think about: How can prayer help you, like Zachary, to remain in God’s love?
ANAÏS
ANAÏS
Esi wodzim eye mexɔ ŋkeke ʋɛ aɖewo ko la, ʋu ɖuɖu ɖe ahɔhɔ̃ me nam, eye esia wɔe nye ame bliboa mezu wɔametɔ, vevietɔ nye afɔwo.
When I was just a few days old, I had a brain hemorrhage that left me with a disability affecting my entire body, especially my legs.
Egbea metea ŋu zãa atizɔti zɔna yia kpuiƒewo, gake bunɔkekee mezãna zi geɖe hafi tsɔ yia teƒewo.
Today, I can go short distances with a walking frame, but I usually need a wheelchair to get around.
Esi wònye be meƒona tititi ta la, nyemetea ŋu wɔa dɔ aɖewo, abe nuŋɔŋlɔ, ene o.
I also have spasms that make it difficult to perform precise tasks, such as handwriting.
Nye dɔlélea ɖea fu nam ŋutɔ eye nye atikewɔwɔa hã mele bɔbɔe o.
Besides the stress of my condition, my treatment has been challenging.
Meɖo ŋkui be medea ɖɔkta siwo hea lãme na ame gbɔ zi geɖe le kwasiɖa ɖeka me hena ɣeyiɣi didi aɖe.
I’ve had physiotherapy sessions several times a week for as long as I can remember.
Zi gbãtɔ si wowɔ dɔ sesẽ aɖe nam la, mexɔ ƒe atɔ̃, eye wogawɔ etɔ̃ bubuwo nam le ema megbe.
I had my first major surgery when I was five years old, and I’ve had three more since then.
Dɔwɔwɔ eve mamlɛ siawo ya sesẽ ŋutɔ, elabe menɔ kɔdzi dzinu etɔ̃ hafi nye lãme haya.
The last two procedures were particularly difficult because I was away from home for three months while I recuperated.
Nye ƒomea kpe ɖe ŋunye ŋutɔ.
My family have been a big help.
Míekoa nu, eye esia kpena ɖe ŋunye ŋutɔ ne nu te ɖe dzinye.
We laugh together, which really helps when I’m down.
Nɔnye kple nɔvinye nyɔnuwo dzrana ɖo nam nyuie, elabe nye ŋutɔ nyemate ŋui o.
My mother and my sisters help me to look nice, since I can’t do this alone.
Eveam be nyemate ŋu ado kɔlegɔmewo (afɔkpa zɔkɔkɔ) o.
I regret not being able to wear high heels.
Gake metee kpɔ gbe ɖeka, meƒo asi ɖe afɔkpawo me henɔ tatam eye wòɖi kokoe na mí katã míeko ʋuu!
But I did manage to do it once as a child by crawling with shoes on my hands, and we all had a good laugh over that!
Nyemeɖe mɔ na nye dɔlélea wòxɔ ŋusẽ le asinye keŋkeŋ o.
I try not to let my situation define me.
Mesrɔ̃ gbe vovovowo.
I study languages.
Togbɔ be nyemetea ŋu kua ʋuƒo le sno alo tsi dzi o hã, meƒua tsi, eye esia doa dzidzɔ nam ŋutɔ.
I swim, which helps make up for my not being able to surf or snowboard.
Esi wònye Yehowa Ðasefoe menye ta la, edzɔa dzi nam be mayi aɖaƒo nu tso nye dzixɔsewo ŋu na amewo.
As one of Jehovah’s Witnesses, I like to go out in the ministry to share my faith with others.
Edze abe amewo lɔ̃a toɖoɖom vevie ene.
It seems that people are very attentive when I speak to them.
Dzinyelawo na menya tso gɔmedzedzea ke be ɣeyiɣi kpui aɖe ƒe nu ko nye dɔlélea nye.
My parents taught me early on that my condition is only temporary.
Tso ɣemaɣi la, meva xɔ Yehowa kple ŋugbe si wòdo be yeaɖe fukpekpewo katã ɖa, siwo dome nye fukpekpeawo hã le ɖa la dzi se.
Since then, I’ve built my own faith in Jehovah and his promise to end all suffering, including mine.
Esia do ŋusẽm mele ŋgɔ kpɔm tẽe.​ Nyaɖeɖefia 21:3, 4.
This gives me the strength to move forward.​ Revelation 21:3, 4.
Bu nya sia ŋu: Aleke nàwɔ be wò lãmesẽkuxiwo maxɔ ŋusẽ le asiwò keŋkeŋ o abe ale si Anaïs wɔe ene.
To think about: In what ways can you, like Anaïs, not let your health problem "define " you?
JULIANA
JULIANA
Dɔléle sia tea ŋu gblẽa nu le ame ƒe dzi, dzitodzito kple ʋu ŋu.
I have a painful autoimmune disorder that can affect the heart, lungs, and blood.
Egblẽ nu le nye ayikuwo ŋu xoxo.
It has already affected my kidneys.
Mexɔ ƒe ewo esi wokpɔ dɔléle sia le ŋunye, dɔléle sia nana mesea veve, nu tia kɔ nam eye sẽe ko meléa blanui.
I was ten years old when I was diagnosed with lupus, a disease that has caused me pain, fatigue, and mood swings.
Ɣeɖewoɣi la, ewɔna nam be viɖe aɖeke mele ŋunye o.
At times, I feel worthless.
Esi mexɔ ƒe 13 la, Yehowa Ðasefo aɖe va míaƒe aƒe me.
When I was 13, one of Jehovah’s Witnesses called at our home.
Exlẽ Yesaya 41:10 nam. Yehowa Mawu gblɔ le afi ma be: "Megavɔ̃ o, elabena meli kpli wò; . . . matsɔ nye xɔname ƒe nuɖusi alé wò. "
She read me Isaiah 41:10, in which Jehovah God says: "Do not be afraid, for I am with you. . . .
Ɣemaɣie Yehowa Ðasefowo dze Biblia sɔsrɔ̃ gɔme kplim.
I will really keep fast hold of you with my right hand of righteousness. "
Egbea, ƒe enyi aɖewoe nye esia, mele Mawu subɔm kple nye dzi blibo eye meɖoe kplikpaa be nyemaɖe mɔ nye dɔlélea nakpɔ ŋusẽ ɖe nye agbe dzi o.
That’s when I began studying the Bible with Jehovah’s Witnesses.
Mesena le ɖokuinye me be Yehowa na "ŋusẽ si gbɔ dzɔdzɔmetɔ ŋu " lam ale be dzi nanɔ ƒonye le agbe me.
Today, some eight years later, I serve God wholeheartedly, and I’m determined not to let my illness control my life.
2 Korintotɔwo 4:7.
I feel that Jehovah has given me "power beyond what is normal, " so that I can keep a positive attitude.​ 2 Corinthians 4:7.
Bu nya sia ŋu: Aleke Yesaya 41:10 ate ŋu akpe ɖe ŋuwò be dzi nanɔ ƒowò le agbe me abe ale si ko wòkpe ɖe Juliana ŋu ene?
To think about: How can Isaiah 41:10 help you to keep a positive attitude, just as it helped Juliana?
Ke Ne Lãmesẽkuxiwo Ðe Kpe Nam Ðe?
What if I Have a Health Problem?
(Akpa 3)
(Part 3)
Sɔhɛmenɔɣi nye ɣeyiɣi si me wogblɔna be ame nɔa lãmesẽ me eye ŋusẽ geɖe nɔa eŋu.
The teenage years are often associated with vibrant health and seemingly inexhaustible energy.
Ke hã le sɔhɛ aɖewo ya gome la, dɔléle sesẽwo na be wɔna boo megale wo ŋu o.
Some young people, however, are limited by serious illness.
Alea wòle le gowòmea?
Is that true of you?
Ne nenemae la, ke nu siwo me V’loria, Justin kple Nisa to la ade dzi ƒo na wò. Yehowa Ðasefowoe wo katã wonye.
If so, you may be encouraged by the experiences of V’loria, Justin, and Nisa​ all three of whom are Jehovah’s Witnesses.
De dzesi ale si wowɔ nɔ te ɖe lãmesẽkuxi sesẽ aɖewo nui la ɖa.
Note how they are able to deal with their debilitating health problems.
V’loria
V’loria
Lãmekaveamedɔ le ŋunye tso esime mexɔ ƒe 14 pɛ ko.
I’ve had fibromyalgia since I was 14.
Kaka maxɔ ƒe 20 la, wokpɔ ƒunukpeƒetetedɔ kple dɔléle vɔ̃ɖi siwo woyɔna be lupus kple Lyme le ŋunye.
By the time I was 20, I also had arthritis, lupus, and Lyme disease.
Esi wònye be megbɔdzɔna ɣesiaɣi ta la, esesẽna nam be mawɔ nu siwo katã medina be mawɔ.
It’s hard to do all the things you want to do when you always feel weak.
Ɣeaɖewoɣi la, metutuna tsia bunɔkeke me.
At times, I was paralyzed from the hips down and needed a wheelchair.
Nane si ɖea fu nam wu nye dɔlélea ŋutɔe nye ale si wòtena ɖe dzinye vevie be nyemetea ŋu wɔa nu bɔbɔetɔ teti gɔ̃ hã o, abe nuŋɔŋlɔ alo nuʋuʋu le ze nu ene.
Worse than the physical aspect of my illnesses was the mental torment I put myself through for not being able to do simple tasks such as writing or opening a jar.
Ne mekpɔ ɖeviwo le zɔzɔm la, nyemetea ŋu sea nu si tae azɔlizɔzɔ sesẽna na nye ya nenema gbegbe ɖo la gɔme o.
I would see children walking and wonder why it was so hard for me to do so.
Mesena le ɖokuinye me be medo kpo nu.
I felt like a failure.
Dzidzɔtɔe la, nye ƒometɔwo kple Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe hame si me mele la me tɔwo naa kpekpeɖeŋum.
Thankfully, I had help​ not only from family members but also from the congregation of Jehovah’s Witnesses that I am associated with.
Hamea me tɔwo va kpɔam ɖa, eye esia nana be nyemegasena le ɖokuinye me be metsi akogo o.
Those from the congregation often visited me, which made me feel less alone.
Togbɔ be menɔa bɔbɔe be woakɔm le nye bunɔkeke me alo akɔm de ʋu loo alo akɔm do go le ʋu me o hã la, hamea me tɔ aɖewo kpeam hena hadomewɔnawo.
Some invited me to social events, even though it’s not easy getting me out of my wheelchair and in and out of a car.
Ame tsitsi siwo le hamea me la kpena ɖe ŋunye ŋutɔ, elabena wosea nye nɔnɔmea gɔme nyuie.
The older ones in the congregation were especially helpful because they knew what it was like to have health problems.
Wokpe ɖe ŋunye mekpɔ afi si nye ŋutete se ɖo, eye wona mese egɔme hã be mele be wòate ɖe dzinye ne nyemetea ŋu wɔa geɖe abe ame bubuwo ene o.
They helped me accept my limitations and not feel guilty about not being able to do as much as others.
Afi siwo mekpɔa dzidzɔ le wue nye hamea ƒe kpekpewo me kple gbeadzi.
When I am at congregation meetings and in the ministry is when I am the happiest.
(Hebritɔwo 10:25) Le ɣeyiɣi mawo me la, mekpɔnɛ be togbɔ be mele dɔ lém hã la, nyemeto vovo boo tso ame bubuwo gbɔ o.
(Hebrews 10:25) On those occasions, I realize that despite my illnesses, I’m really not that different from others.
Meɖoa ŋku edzi na ɖokuinye be Yehowa naa nu siwo akpe ɖe mía ŋu míado dzi la mí.
I keep in mind that Jehovah gives us what we need in order to endure.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, Biblia gblɔ be ne míaƒe gota gome le gbegblẽm hã la, ame si míenye le ememe ya ate ŋu anɔ "yeye zum gbe sia gbe. " (2 Korintotɔwo 4:16) Nenema tututue mesena le ɖokuinye me!
For example, the Bible says that even if a person is wasting away on the outside, the person he is inside can be "renewed from day to day. " (2 Corinthians 4:​16) That is certainly how I feel!
Bu nya sia ŋu: Ne dɔléle vɔ̃ɖi aɖe ɖe kpe na wò la, nu ka tae wòle vevie be nàdi kpekpeɖeŋu tso ame bubuwo gbɔ?
To think about: If you are afflicted with a serious health problem, why is it important to reach out to others?
Ne èle lãmesẽ me la, aleke nàte ŋu akpe ɖe ame aɖe si le dɔ lém la ŋu?​ Lododowo 17:17.
If you are healthy, how can you support someone who is sick?​ Proverbs 17:17.
Justin
Justin
Justin
Justin
Medze anyi, eye nyemegate ŋu le fɔfɔm o.
I fell to the floor and couldn’t get up.
Nye akɔta lia goŋgoŋ, eye nyemete ŋu le ʋaʋãm o.
My chest felt tight and I couldn’t move.
Wokɔm enumake yi kɔdzixɔ si me wokpɔa nɔnɔme kpatawo gbɔ le la me.
I was rushed to the emergency room.
Gbã la, ɖɔktawo mete ŋu nya nu si tututu nɔ fu ɖem nam o.
At first, the doctors couldn’t figure out what was wrong with me.
Gake esi nu sia gadzɔ ɖe dzinye zi geɖe la, wova de dzesii be Lyme-dɔlélee le fu ɖem nam.
But after several more incidents, they reached a diagnosis​ Lyme disease.
Lyme-dɔléle sia gblẽ nu le nye ahɔhɔ̃mekawo ŋu.
Lyme disease took a toll on my nervous system.
Le nyateƒe me la, megaƒona tititi ɣeaɖewoɣi togbɔ be ƒe geɖee nye esia wokpɔ dɔléle sia le ŋunye hã.
In fact, I still shake, sometimes uncontrollably, even though it is several years since I was diagnosed.
Gbe aɖewo gbe la, lãme kple asibidɛwo veam ale gbegbe be nyemetea ŋu ʋãa wo o.
There are days when my body will ache or my fingers will hurt so badly that I can’t even move them.
Ðeko wòwɔna nam abe ɖe nye ƒunukpeƒewo katã nyunyɔ ene.
It’s as if my joints were all rusted.
Megblɔna na ɖokuinye be, ‘nyemekpɔ tsi madze dɔ sia o ɖe,’ eye esia nana medoa dziku.
I used to think to myself, ‘I’m too young to be sick,’ and that made me angry.
Mefaa avi na Mawu gbe sia gbe hebianɛ be, "Nu ka tae mele nɔnɔme sia me tom? "
I would cry to God each day, asking him, "Why am I going through this? "
Meva nɔ sesem le ɖokuinye me gɔ̃ hã be Mawu gblẽm ɖi.
I even began to feel that God had abandoned me.
Gake mede ŋugble tso Hiob ƒe ŋutinya si le Biblia me la ŋu.
But then I thought about Job in the Bible.
Hiob mese nu si tututu tae wònɔ kuxi geɖe me tom la gɔme o, gake eyi edzi wɔ nuteƒe na Mawu.
Job didn’t fully understand why he had to face so many challenges, yet he remained faithful to God.
Ne Hiob te ŋu wɔ nu nenema le kuxi gbogbo mawo me la, ke nye hã mate ŋu awɔ nenema ke.
If Job could do that with the enormous problems he faced, I can do the same.
Hamemetsitsi siwo le míaƒe hamea me la kpe ɖe ŋunye ŋutɔ.
I have great support from the elders in my congregation.
Wova kpɔa nye fɔfɔme ɖa ɣesiaɣi.
They always check up on me and ask me how I’m feeling.
Hamemetsitsi aɖe gblɔ nam be mate ŋu ayɔ ye ɣesiaɣi si medi be maƒo nu kple ame aɖe.
One elder told me to call him whenever I needed to talk, whatever the hour.
Medaa akpe na Yehowa gbe sia gbe ɖe xɔlɔ̃ siawo tɔgbi ta!​ Yesaya 32:1, 2.
I thank Jehovah every day for friends like these!​ Isaiah 32:​1, 2.
Ɣeaɖewoɣi ne míele dɔ lém vevie la, míeŋlɔa nyateƒenya vevi aɖe be, eyae nye be Yehowa nya nɔnɔme siwo me tom míele.
Sometimes when we face serious illness, we forget the obvious​ that Jehovah knows what we’re going through.
Biblia gblɔ be: "Dro wò agba ɖe Yehowa dzi, ekema alé wò ɖe te. "
The Bible says: "Throw your burden on Jehovah, and he will sustain you. "
(Psalmo 55:22) Nu siae medzea agbagba wɔna gbe sia gbe.
(Psalm 55:22) That is what I try to do each day.
Bu nya sia ŋu: Aleke ame siwo lɔ̃ wò ate ŋu akpe ɖe ŋuwò nànɔ te ɖe lãmesẽkuxiwo nu?​ Lododowo 24:10; 1 Tesalonikatɔwo 5:11.
To think about: How can a support system help you to endure a health problem?​ Proverbs 24:10; 1 Thessalonians 5:​11.
Nisa
Nisa
Nisa
Nisa
Esi menye sɔhɛvi ko la, wokpɔ dɔléle si woyɔna be Marfan le ŋunye. Enye dɔléle aɖe si nana be ame ƒe ƒunukpeƒewo gbɔdzɔna.
When I was in my mid-teens, I was diagnosed with Marfan syndrome​ a disorder that affects the joints, making them weak.
Dɔléle sia gblẽa nu le ame ƒe dzi, ŋkuwo kple lãmenu vevi bubuwo hã ŋu.
Marfan syndrome can also affect your heart, eyes, and other vital organs.
Nyemesea veve gbe sia gbe ya o, gake ne eho nam la, nye dzi koe dina be yeage ɖe dɔ me nam.
I’m not in pain every day, but when I am, it can be severe.
Esime wokpɔ dɔ sia le ŋunye la, avi dzi ko menɔna.
When I was first diagnosed, I cried a lot.
Mevɔ̃na be nyemagate ŋu awɔ nu siwo katã wɔwɔ doa dzidzɔ nam la o.
I was worried that I wouldn’t be able to do all the things that I enjoy doing.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, melɔ̃a ɣeɖuɖu, eya ta ne mebu eŋu kpɔ be gbe ɖeka la, vevesesea nu asẽ ale gbegbe be nyemagate ŋu aɖu ɣe alo azɔ azɔli teti o la, esia nana mevɔ̃na na etsɔme.
For example, I enjoy dancing, and to think that one day it might be too painful for me to do that​ and maybe even too painful for me to walk​ made me fearful of the future.
Nɔvinye nyɔnu tsitsia kpe ɖe ŋunye ŋutɔ.
My sister was very supportive.
Ekpe ɖe ŋunye ale be nye nu megawɔa nublanui na ɖokuinye o.
She helped me to get out of that phase of feeling sorry for myself.
Egblɔ nam be mele be manɔ vɔvɔ̃m o, elabena esia ana wɔna navɔ le ŋunye le agbe me.
She told me that I shouldn’t live in fear, because that would consume my life.
Ede dzi ƒo nam hã be manɔ gbedodoɖa dzi vevie, elabena ame si nya nu si me tom mele hese nye nɔnɔmeawo gɔme nyuie wu lae nye Yehowa.​ 1 Petro 5:7.
She also encouraged me to persevere in prayer, because if anyone knew and understood exactly what I was going through, it was Jehovah.​ 1 Peter 5:7.
Mawunyakpukpui si de dzi ƒo nam ŋutɔe nye Psalmo 18:6, egblɔ be: "Meyɔ Yehowa le nye xaxawo me, eye mele ɣlidodo dzi na nye Mawu be wòaxɔ nam.
One scripture that really encourages me is Psalm 18:6, which says: "In my distress I called on Jehovah, to my God I kept crying for help.
Ese nye gbe tso eƒe gbedoxɔ me, eye nye ɣlidodo be wòaxɔ nam la ɖo eƒe to me. "
From his temple he heard my voice, and my cry to him for help reached his ears. "
Mawunyakpukpui sia kpe ɖe ŋunye mekpɔe be ne medo gbe ɖa na Yehowa hebiae be wòakpe ɖe ŋunye manɔ te ɖe nye dɔlélea nu la, aɖo tom ahakpe ɖe ŋunye.
That verse helped me to realize that when I pray to Jehovah and ask him to help me cope, he will hear me and help me.
Ele klalo be yeakpe ɖe ŋunye ɣesiaɣi.
He is always there for me.
Mesrɔ̃e be esɔ be míalé blanui alo ado dziku gɔ̃ hã ɖe nɔnɔme madeamedzi si me tom míele la ta, gake mele be míaɖe mɔ be nɔnɔmea nana wɔna navɔ le mía ŋu le agbe me alo agblẽ mí kple Mawu dome o.

I’ve learned that it’s OK to feel sad and even upset about a tragedy that confronts us because those feelings are normal​ as long as we don’t let those feelings consume our life and affect our friendship with God.
Menye eya gbɔe míaƒe kuxiwo tso o, eye ne míena wònye ame vevitɔ na mí le agbe me la, magblẽ mí ɖi kpɔ gbeɖe o.​ Yakobo 4:8.
He is not the cause of our problems, and he will never leave us as long as we put him first in our life.​ James 4:8.
Bu nya sia ŋu: Ðe wòle be míabu fɔ Mawu ɖe míaƒe fukpekpewo ta?​ Yakobo 1:13.
To think about: Is God to blame for our suffering?​ James 1:​13.
Nu Ka Tae Wòle Be Makpe Ðe Amewo Ŋu?
Why Should I Help Others?
Nu vevi eve siwo ame geɖe menya o
Two secrets many people don’t know
Sɔhɛ siwo tsɔa ɖe le eme na ame
Young people who care
Aleke makpe ɖe amewo ŋue?
How can I help others?
Nu vevi eve siwo ame geɖe menya o
Two secrets that many people don’t know
Nu vevi #1: Ne èkpe ɖe ame aɖe ŋu la, àkpɔ eteƒeɖoɖo!
Secret #1: When you give, you are likely to get back!
Amewo ade dzesii be enyoa dɔme.
People will notice that you are generous.
Esia ana woawo hã nanyo dɔme na wò.
As a result, they’ll probably be generous to you.
Biblia gblɔe ale:
The Bible puts it this way:
"Minɔ nu nam amewo, eye amewo ana nu mi. . . .
"Practice giving, and people will give to you. . . .
Dzidzenu si mietsɔ le nu dzidzem na amewo la kee woatsɔ adzidzee na miawo hã. " Luka 6:38.
With the measure that you are measuring out, they will measure out to you in return. "​ Luke 6:​38.
"Ale si nèwɔ nu ɖe amewo ŋu la, nenema kee woawɔ nu ɖe ŋuwò. " Luka 6:38, Contemporary English Version.
"The way you treat others is the way you will be treated. "​ Luke 6:​38, Contemporary English Version.
Nu vevi #2: Kpekpeɖeŋunana amewo nye kpekpeɖeŋunana ame ɖokui!
Secret #2: When you help others, you help yourself!
Nyuiwɔwɔ na ame bubuwo nana ame kpɔnɛ be yele bo nu eye dzidzeme si le nunana me la sua ame si.
Doing good things for others boosts your self-respect and makes you feel the satisfaction that comes from giving.
Biblia gblɔe ale:
The Bible puts it this way:
"Dzidzɔ geɖe le nunana me wu nuxɔxɔ. " Dɔwɔwɔwo 20:35.
"There is more happiness in giving than there is in receiving. "​ Acts 20:35.
"Ne èɖo kplɔ̃ la, kpe ame dahewo, nuwɔametɔwo, atatututɔwo, ŋkuagbãtɔwo; eye àkpɔ dzidzɔ, elabena naneke mele wo si woatsɔ aɖo eteƒe na wò o. "
"When you spread a feast, invite poor people, crippled, lame, blind; and you will be happy, because they have nothing with which to repay you. "​ Luke 14:13, 14.
Young people who care
Sɔhɛ siwo tsɔa ɖe le eme na ame la le afi sia afi!
Young people who care about others are everywhere!
Se wo dometɔ aɖewo ƒe numenya kpɔ.
Consider some examples.
"Ɣeaɖewoɣi ne menya nɔ anyi ɖe zikpui me be makpɔ television ko la, meɖoa ŋku ale si papa kple dada le dɔ dzi vevie ɖaa kple ale si ɖeɖi ate wo ŋu hafi woagbɔ va aƒe mee la dzi.
"Sometimes when I just want to sit on the couch and watch TV, I think about my mom and dad, who are working, and how tired they are going to be when they come home.
Eya ta metsona heklɔa agbawo, kplɔa xɔa me hetutua nuwo ŋu.
So I get up and wash the dishes, vacuum, and dust.
Meɖoa kɔfi hã dana ɖi na wo elabena dzinyelawo lɔ̃a kɔfinono ŋutɔ.
I’ll also make a pot of coffee because my parents love coffee.
Ne nɔnye ge ɖe aƒea me la, egblɔna be, ‘Aƒea me nya le kpɔkpɔm ŋutɔ!
When my mom gets home, she says, ‘Oh, it looks so nice in here!
Eme le ʋeʋem lilili.
And it smells good too.
Vinye lɔlɔ̃a, akpe na wò kakaka!’
Thank you so much, Sweetie!’
Esia na mekpɔa dzidzɔ be mete ŋu wɔ nu nyui aɖe na dada kple papa. "​ Casey.
It always makes me feel good to do something nice like that for my mom and dad. "​ Casey.
"Dzinyelawo kpena ɖe ŋunye ɣesiaɣi, wowɔa nu sia nu si mehiã la nam.
"My parents have always supported me, providing me with everything I need.
Eya ta esi woƒe ʋu gblẽ le ƒe si va yi me la, meɖe ga le gadzraɖoƒe be woatsɔ adzra ʋua ɖo, togbɔ be esia nye ga si le gadzraɖoƒe nam ƒe akpa gã aɖe hã.
So when they had a major problem with the car last year, I wrote a check to have it repaired, even though it was a large part of my savings.
Togbɔ be wogbe be yewomaxɔ kpekpeɖeŋua o hã la, nye hã mebe ɖeko mele ewɔ ge na wo.
Of course, they tried to refuse my offer, but I wouldn’t take no for an answer.
Kpekpeɖeŋu ma mede naneke o ne metsɔe sɔ kple nu si wòhiã be mawɔ na dzinyelawo.
My parents deserve so much more than even that.
Mese vivi be menyo dɔme hekpe ɖe wo ŋu. "​ Holly.
And it felt great to be generous and give them something. "​ Holly.
Ènyaa?
Did you know?
Sɔhɛ siwo nye Yehowa Ðasefowo dometɔ geɖe kpɔa dzidzɔ le esi wole kpekpem ɖe amewo ŋu to Biblia-fiafiadɔ dzi ta.
Many young people among Jehovah’s Witnesses have experienced the joy of helping others through their Bible education work.
Wo dometɔ aɖewo ʋu yi dutanyigbawo dzi afi si hiahiã le be woafia Biblia amewo.
Some have even moved to a foreign land where there is a need for Bible teachers.
"Meʋu tso United States yi Mexico be mafia Biblia amewo.
"I moved from the United States to Mexico to help teach the Bible.
Ɣeaɖewoɣi la, nyemetea ŋu naa gakpekpeɖeŋu alo ŋutilãmekpekpeɖeŋu amewo o elabena nu mede dzinye o.
Sometimes it’s difficult to be generous with money or things because I don’t really have much to give.
Gake mede dzesii be ne mezã nye ɣeyiɣi kple ŋusẽ le gbeƒãɖeɖedɔa me la, amewo kpɔa ŋudzedze ɖe eŋu wu ŋutilãmekpekpeɖeŋu dzro si mana wo. "​ Evan.
But I’ve found that when I give of my time and energy in the ministry, that’s more appreciated than just giving materially. "​ Evan.
Aleke makpe ɖe amewo ŋue?
How can I help others?
Àdi be yeakpɔ dzidzɔ si le kpekpe ɖe amewo ŋu mea?
Would you like to experience the joy that comes from helping others?
Mɔ siwo dzi nàto awɔ esia la dometɔ ʋɛ aɖewoe nye esiawo.
Here are just a few suggestions.
Kpekpe ɖe ƒowòmetɔwo ŋu:
To help your family:
Kplɔ aƒea me, klɔ agbawo, tutu míaƒe xɔ me ne womebiae tso asiwò o hã la
Vacuum, do the dishes, or clean a room​ without being asked
Ða nu
Cook a meal
Ŋlɔ akpedagbalẽ na dziwòlawo
Write a card of appreciation to your parents
Kpe ɖe nɔviwò ŋu wòawɔ eƒe sukudɔdeasi
Help a sibling with his or her schoolwork
Kpekpe ɖe ame siwo menye ƒowòmetɔwo o ŋu:
To help those outside your family:
Ðo nyuidinamegbalẽ ɖe ame aɖe si ƒe lãme gblẽ
Send a card to someone who is not well
Yi ɖadzra aƒe me ɖo na ame tsitsi aɖe
Do yard work for an elderly neighbor
Yi ɖasrã ame si tsi teƒe ɖeka la kpɔ
Visit someone who is housebound
Tsɔ nunana aɖe yi na ame si le nɔnɔme sesẽwo me tom
Buy a gift for someone who is going through a difficult time
Aɖaŋuɖoɖo: Wò ŋutɔ hã bu nu bubu siwo nàte ŋu awɔ la ŋu.
Tip: Try to come up with a few ideas of your own.
Eyome ɖoe nàkpe ɖe ame aɖe ŋu le kwasiɖa sia me.
Then make it your goal to help out one person this week.
Dzidzɔ si nàkpɔ le esia wɔwɔ vɔ megbe la, awu gbɔgblɔ na wò!
You might be surprised how good you will feel!
"Ne èkpe ɖe amewo ŋu la, ana nàkpɔ dzidzɔ.
"When you help others, you end up happy.
Ana nàse le ɖokuiwò me be yeɖo taɖodzinu aɖe gbɔ eye amewo akpɔ ŋudzedze ɖe ŋuwò.
You feel that you really accomplished something, and you see that others appreciate it.
Togbɔ be le gɔmedzedzea me la kpekpe ɖe ame bubuwo ŋu sesẽ na wò hã la, anɔ eme be èva le vivi sem na esia wɔwɔ.
You may have had fun doing it​ although at first you didn’t think you would.
Nu siwo nàtsɔ asa vɔe be nàna kpekpeɖeŋu ame bubuwo la made nu si gbegbe nàkpɔ tso esia wɔwɔ me ŋu o. "​ Alana.
What you did may not even feel like a sacrifice, because in the end you gained so much. "​ Alana.
Nu Ka Tae Wòle Be Manye Anukwareɖila?
Why Be Honest?
Nu si ta ame aɖewo meɖia anukware o
Why some people are dishonest
Nu si ta anukwareɖiɖi ɖea vi
Why honesty pays
Nya siwo hawòtiwo gblɔ
What your peers say
Nu si ta ame aɖewo meɖia anukware o
Why some people are dishonest
Le egbexexea me la, ewɔna na ame aɖewo be anukwareɖiɖi gblẽa nu le ame ŋu.
In today’s world, honesty could seem to be a disadvantage.
Wo dometɔ aɖewo gblɔna be:
After all, some might reason:
Ne nyemeble dzinyelawo o la, womaɖe mɔ nam o.’
‘If I don’t lie to my parents, I could get grounded.’
‘Ne nyemefi dɔ kpɔ le dodokpɔ sia me o la, mage..’
‘If I don’t cheat on this test, I might fail it.’
‘Ne nyemefi nu sia o la, ava hiã be nye ŋutɔ madzra ga ɖo aƒlee.’
‘If I don’t steal this item, I’ll have to save up for it.’
Ame bubuwo hã abia be: ‘Ðe wòhiã be míatsi dzi ɖe nya sia ŋu fũua?
‘Besides, what’s the big deal?’ some might ask.
Menye ame sia ame koe le alakpa dam oa?’
‘Isn’t everyone dishonest?’
Nyabiase ma ƒe ŋuɖoɖoe nye ao.
The answer to that question is no.
Ame gbogbo aɖewo, siwo dometɔ aɖewo nye sɔhɛwo, ka ɖe edzi be anukwareɖiɖi ɖea vi, eye kpeɖodzi hã le eŋu.
Many people​ including a large number of young people​ believe that honesty pays, and for good reason.
Biblia gblɔ be: "Nu si ame ƒãna la, esia kee wòaŋe. "
"Whatever a person is sowing, this he will also reap, " says the Bible.
(Galatiatɔwo 6:7) Ne míagblɔe kpuie la, míekpɔa míaƒe nuwɔnawo me tsonuwo godoo​ eɖanye nyuia alo vɔ̃a o.
(Galatians 6:7) In other words, our actions always have consequences​ whether for good or for bad.
Na míakpɔ ale si alakpadada gblẽ nu le ame aɖewo ŋu la ɖa.
Consider, for example, some bad consequences people have reaped from lying.
"Meɖoa dze kple ŋutsuvi aɖe, gake esi Dada biam la, meda alakpa nɛ.
"I lied to my mom about talking to a certain boy.
Enya nyuie be alakpa dam mele.
She had clear evidence that I wasn’t telling the truth.
Gake esi megable Dada zi etɔ̃lia la, edo dziku ɖe ŋunye vevie.
After the third time I lied about this, Mom had had enough.
Exe mɔ nam be nyemegado go o kwasiɖa eve sɔŋ, eye nyemekpɔ mɔ azã nye asitelefon alo akpɔ television o ɣleti ɖeka sɔŋ.
I was grounded for two weeks and could not use my cell phone or watch TV for a month.
Tso ema dzi la, nyemegada alakpa na dzinyelawo kpɔ o! "​ Anita.
I never lied to my parents again! "​ Anita.
Bu nya sia ŋu: Nu ka tae eteƒe adidi hafi Anita nɔ agava ka ɖe edzi?
To think about: Why might it take some time for Anita to regain her mom’s trust?
Biblia gblɔ be: "Azɔ la, mia dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe nato nyateƒe na ehavi. " Efesotɔwo 4:25.
The Bible says: "Now that you have put away deceit, each one of you speak truth with his neighbor. "​ Ephesians 4:25.
"Meble dzinyelawo eye mesusui be womanya gbeɖe o va se ɖe esime wobia tso asinye be magbugbɔ gblɔ ale si nua dzɔe.
"I lied to my parents and thought I got away with it until later when they made me recount what I said had happened.
Esi wònye be nyateƒe kui ɖeka pɛ hã mele nye si megblɔ va yi me o ta la, nyemegate ŋu ɖo ŋku nya siwo tututu megblɔ na wo va yi la dzi o.
It was so far from the truth that I couldn’t even remember the details of my story.
Ne èto nyateƒe le gɔmedzedzea la, nu sia tɔgbi madzɔ ɖe dziwò o! "​ Anthony.
When you tell the truth to begin with, you don’t have that problem! "​ Anthony.
Bu nya sia ŋu: Aleke Anthony awɔ aƒo asa na ŋukpedoameɖokui sia hafi?
To think about: How could Anthony have avoided that embarrassing situation?
Biblia gblɔ be: "Yehowa nyɔa ŋu alakpanuyiwo, ke ame siwo wɔa nuteƒe la ƒe nu dzea eŋu. " Lododowo 12:22.
The Bible says: "Lying lips are detestable to Jehovah, but those acting faithfully bring pleasure to him. "​ Proverbs 12:22.
"Xɔ̃nye aɖe lɔ̃a amiɖeɖe ɖe eƒe nyawo.
"I have a friend who embellishes her stories.
Ekpaa nya kpea eƒe nyawo eye wòvivia nu me ŋutɔ.
She exaggerates and takes things out of context.
Eƒe nu dzɔa dzi nam, eye medzea agbagba be nyemagake ŋku ɖe eƒe nyawo me fũu akpa o.
I love her and I try not to read too much into it.
Gake eƒe amiɖeɖe ɖe nya wɔe be esesẽna nam be maka ɖe edzi alo axɔ eƒe nyawo dzi ase. "​ Yvonne.
But it’s really hard to believe her or trust her. "​ Yvonne.
Bu nya sia ŋu: Aleke amiɖeɖe ɖe nya kple alakpa "suesuewo " ate ŋu ana be womagaka ɖe Yvonne ƒe xɔlɔ̃ sia dzi o?
To think about: How might exaggerations and "small " untruths affect the reputation of Yvonne’s friend?
Biblia gblɔ be: "Míedina be míaɖi anukware le nuwo katã me. " Hebritɔwo 13:18.
The Bible says: "We wish to conduct ourselves honestly in all things. "​ Hebrews 13:18.
Xɔ aɖe si ƒe gɔmeɖoanyiwo ɖe abi
A brick building with a cracked foundation
Abe ale si ko ne xɔ ƒe gɔmeɖoanyi ɖe abi ene la, xɔ bliboa megalia ke tututu o la, nenema ke anukwaremaɖimaɖi ate ŋu awɔe be amewo magaka ɖe dziwò o
A cracked foundation can weaken an entire structure; in the same way, dishonesty can undermine your good reputation
Nu si ta anukwareɖiɖi ɖea vi
Why honesty pays
Azɔ na míakpɔ nu nyui siwo dona tso anukwareɖiɖi me la dometɔ aɖewo ɖa.
Now consider some of the good consequences you can reap by being honest.
"Nyɔnu aɖe si nɔ zɔzɔm le ŋgɔnye la ƒe ga ge.
"A woman walking ahead of me had dropped some money.
Meyɔe tsɔ ga la nɛ.
I called out to her and returned her money.
Eda akpe nam kaka.
She was so thankful.
Egblɔ be: ‘Èdze agbagba ŋutɔ.
She said: ‘That was very nice of you.
Ame geɖe mate ŋu awɔ nu alea o.’
Not many people are honest enough to do that.’
Edzɔ dzi nam ŋutɔ be wode dzesii be mewɔ nu nyui! "​ Vivian.
It felt good to be noticed for doing the right thing! "​ Vivian.
Bu nya sia ŋu: Nu ka tae Vivian ƒe anukwareɖiɖi sia wɔ nuku na nyɔnua?
To think about: Why might the woman have been surprised to see such honesty?
Vi kae anukwareɖiɖi ɖe na Vivian?
How did being honest benefit Vivian?
Biblia gblɔ be: "Dzidzɔtɔwoe nye ame siwo . . . wɔa nu dzɔdzɔe ɣeawokatãɣi. "
The Bible says: "Happy are those who . . . always do what is right. "​ Psalm 106:3.
Psalmo 106:3. "Míaƒe ƒomea dzraa dɔwɔxɔ me ɖo na amewo, eye ɣeaɖewoɣi ne míele xɔawo me dzram ɖo la, míekpɔa gakuwo le anyigba.
"As a family, we work in the janitorial business, and sometimes while we’re cleaning an office, we’ll see a coin lying on the floor.
Ne edzɔ alea la, míetsɔa gaa dana ɖe dɔwɔkplɔ̃ si ŋu wòte ɖo la dzi.
When that happens, we put the coin on the nearest desk.
Dɔwɔla ɖeka kpɔ dziku ɖe mía ŋu le míaƒe anukwareɖiɖi alea ta. Egblɔ be: ‘Ga sue aɖe koe nye emae!’
One employee was almost annoyed that we were so honest​ ‘It’s just a dime!’ she said.
Gake ènya?
But you know what?
Dɔwɔla sia kana ɖe mía dzi ɣesiaɣi. "​ Julia.
We always had her confidence. "​ Julia.
Bu nya sia ŋu: Vi kae ale si wonya Julia be eɖia anukware aɖe nɛ ne ehiã be dɔwɔƒe si wòle naŋlɔ ɖaseɖigbalẽ tso eŋu na dɔwɔƒe bubu aɖe si wòdi be yeayi aɖawɔ dɔ le?
To think about: How might Julia’s reputation for honesty pay off when she needs a character reference for another job?
Biblia gblɔ be: "Wɔ wò ŋutete ɖe sia ɖe nàɖe ɖokuiwò afia Mawu abe ame si dze eŋu, dɔwɔla si ƒe dɔ mekpea ŋu nɛ le mɔ aɖeke nu o. " 2 Timoteo 2:15.
The Bible says: "Do your utmost to present yourself approved to God, a workman with nothing to be ashamed of. "​ 2 Timothy 2:​15.
"Míaƒe dɔwɔƒea xe gaƒoƒo 80 ƒe fe nam le esi teƒe be wòaxe gaƒoƒo 64 boŋ ƒe fe nam.
"I received a paycheck for 80 hours of work instead of 64.
Togbɔ be ade dzinye ŋutɔ ne mezi kpi ɖe edzi hã la, nyemate ŋu awɔ nu ma gbeɖe o.
Although it would have been nice to keep it, I just couldn’t do that.
Megblɔe na míaƒe dɔwɔƒea ƒe gadzikpɔla, eye wòda akpe nam kakaka.
I pointed it out to the accounting manager, and she was very grateful.
Ga le dɔwɔƒea si zã, gake nyemate ŋu awɔ nu si anye gafifi o. "​ Bethany.
The company is successful, but I wasn’t about to keep what would have felt like stolen money. "​ Bethany.
Bu nya sia ŋu: Ðe dɔwɔƒe ƒe ga fifi megblẽ boo abe ame ɖekaɖekawo ƒe ga fifi ene oa?
To think about: Is stealing from a corporation any less dishonest than stealing from a person?
Biblia gblɔ be: "Yehowa nyɔa ŋu ameflula, ke tsi metoa Eya kple nu dzɔdzɔe wɔlawo dome o. " Lododowo 3:32.
The Bible says: "Jehovah detests a devious person, but His close friendship is with the upright. "​ Proverbs 3:32.
Nya siwo hawòtiwo gblɔ
What your peers say
Tobi
Tobi
TOBI
TOBI
Ale si gbegbe sukuviwo dzea agbagba hafi fia dɔwo kpɔna le dodokpɔ me la, menye nu vi kura o.
The amount of scheming that goes into cheating at school is incredible.
Ne ɖe wodzea agbagba ma ƒe afã teti tsɔ srɔ̃a nu la, woakpɔ dzidzedze le dodokpɔa me!
If people put only half the effort into studying that they put into cheating, they would pass the test!

AUSTIN
Mebiaa ɖokuinye be, ‘Ðe magblẽ nu le ŋunye ŋutɔ ne meda alakpa oa?’
I ask myself, ‘What’s the worst trouble I could get into for telling the truth?’
Eyome metsɔa nu si gbegbe alakpadada agblẽ le ŋunyea sɔna kple viɖe si wòahe vɛ nam.
Then I weigh that against the trouble I could get into for lying.
Nu si wòagblẽ le ŋunyea ŋu bubu kpena ɖe ŋunye meƒoa asa na anukwaremaɖimaɖi.
Thinking about the consequences can help me avoid being dishonest.

Many people lie if they think that telling the truth will cause them pain.
Gake enyo be woato nyateƒe woahe to na wo wu be woada alakpa eye woƒe dzitsinya nanɔ fɔ bum wo.

Aleke Nye Dzedzeme Le?

Because clothes make a statement.

Awudodo ƒe atsyãwo ƒe vodada gã etɔ̃ kple ale si nàwɔ aƒo asa na wo
Three big fashion mistakes and how to avoid them
Nu si hawòtiwo gblɔ
What your peers say
Awudodo ƒe atsyãwo ƒe vodada gã etɔ̃ kple ale si nàwɔ aƒo asa na wo
Three big fashion mistakes and how to avoid them
Vodada #1: Mɔɖeɖe be nyakakamɔnuwo naɖo awu si nàdo la na wò.
Mistake #1: Letting the media dictate how you should look.
Sɔhɛ aɖe si ŋkɔe nye Theresa gblɔ be: "Ɣeaɖewoɣi la, awu siwo le tsia dzi fifia dzɔa dzi nam, elabena wole boblo dom wo vevie.
"Sometimes I’m attracted to a trend because I’ve seen so many ads about it, " says a teenager named Theresa.
Ne awu ƒe atsyã siwo dom ame geɖewo le va xɔ susu me na wò la, anɔ bɔbɔe be nàdze wo yome. "
"When your brain is pumped full of images of people wearing a certain item, it can be hard not to follow along. "
Menye nyɔnuviwo dzi koe boblododowo kpɔa ŋusẽ ɖo o.
Girls aren’t the only ones who are affected by advertising.
Agbalẽ aɖe (The Everything Guide to Raising Adolescent Boys) gblɔ be: "Ŋutsuviwo hã tsia dzi ɖe awudodo ƒe atsyãwo ŋu.
"Boys are just as susceptible to fashion trends, " says the book The Everything Guide to Raising Adolescent Boys.
Wometsina hafi asitsalawo dzea woƒe susu hehe yi asitsanuwo dzi o. "
"They don’t go far in life without seeing something aimed at them from a marketing perspective. "
Mɔ Nyuitɔ: Biblia gblɔ be: "Ðekemanyala xɔa nya sia nya dzi sena, ke aɖaŋudzela léa ŋku ɖe eƒe afɔɖeɖewo katã ŋu. "
A better route: The Bible says: "The naive person believes every word, but the shrewd one ponders each step. "
(Lododowo 14:15) Le ɖekawɔwɔ me kple Biblia me mɔfiame ma la, da awudodo ƒe atsyã siwo dzena le boblododowo me la kpɔ nyuie.
(Proverbs 14:15) In harmony with that principle, learn to scrutinize what you see in ads.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, ne wole boblo dom awu ƒe atsyã aɖe eye wogblɔ le eŋu be awua nana ame ƒe nu léa dzi na ame alo be edodo ana amewo naku ɖe dziwò la, ke bia ɖokuiwò be:
For example, when you see ads for clothes that are touted as "sassy, " "hot, " or "sexy, " ask yourself:
‘Ame ka tututue wòɖea vi na ne mele awu ƒe atsyã mawo yome?’
‘Who really profits if I follow that trend?’
‘Agbe ka ƒomevi nɔlae wòana amewo nabum?’
‘What lifestyle would it associate me with?’
‘Ðe agbe ma ƒomevi ɖɔ ame si menye kple nu si dzi mexɔ se ŋutɔŋutɔa?’
‘Does that lifestyle really define me and what I stand for?’
Aɖaŋuɖoɖo: Lé ŋku ɖe awuwo ƒe atsyã siwo wodoa bobloe kple nyakakamɔnu siwo hea susu yia awu mawo dzi la ŋu kwasiɖa ɖeka ko.
Fashion tip: For a week, look closely at clothing ads and other media that focus on fashion.
Agbenɔnɔ ka ƒomevi ƒe dzie wodea ƒo?
What lifestyle do they promote?
Ðe wòdzena le wo ŋu be woto ayemɔ aɖe dzi le didim be nàse le ɖokuiwò me be ehiã be wò awudodowo nanɔ atsyã ƒomevi aɖewo koŋ mea?
Are there subtle messages that are geared toward making you feel as if you need to follow a certain trend?
Sɔhɛ aɖe si ŋkɔe nye Karen gblɔ be: "Ame geɖewo le didim be yewoƒe dzedzeme, awudodowo kple nɔnɔme nade blibo. "
"There is huge pressure to look perfect, dress perfect, and show off your ‘perfect’ body, " says a teenager named Karen.
Boblodola siwo nya be didi sia le amewo me la tɔa ŋku sɔhɛwo, siwo nye ame siwo wotea ŋu léna bɔbɔe. "
"Advertisers who realize that have an easy target audience with young people. "
Vodada #2: Amewo yome dzedze.
Mistake #2: Adopting a popular look just to fit in.
"Sɔhɛ aɖe si ŋkɔe nye Manuel gblɔ be: "Ne awu aɖe va tsia dzi la, ke ame sia ame adi be yeado awu ƒe atsyã ma.
"If a certain type of clothing is in style, " says a teenager named Manuel, "then everyone is going to wear that style.
Ne mèdo awu ƒe atsyã ma o la, amewo ako wò. "
If you don’t wear it, people will judge you. "
Sɔhɛ aɖe si ŋkɔe nye Anna hã lɔ̃ ɖe nya sia dzi.
A teenager named Anna would agree.
Egblɔ be: "Menye atsyã la ŋutɔ ŋue nya ku ɖo o, ke ale si nàwɔ adze amewo ŋue nye nya. "
"It’s not so much about fashion as it is about fitting in, " she says.
Mɔ Nyuitɔ: Biblia gblɔ be: "Midzudzɔ agbenɔnɔ ɖe nuɖoanyi sia ƒe nɔnɔme nu. "
A better route: The Bible says: "Stop being molded by this system of things. "
(Romatɔwo 12:2) Le ɖekawɔwɔ me kple nuxlɔ̃ame sia la, lé ŋku ɖe wò awuwo ŋu eye nàbia ɖokuiwò be:
(Romans 12:2) In harmony with that advice, look through your wardrobe and ask yourself:
‘Nu kae nye nu vevitɔ si kpɔa ŋusẽ ɖe awu siwo tɔgbi medina be mado la dzi?’
‘Which factors primarily influence my clothing choices?’
‘Ðe ale asi adzɔha siwo wɔa awu siwo medona la xɔ ŋkɔe lae nɔa vevie nama?’
‘How important to me is having a brand-name label?’
‘Ðe medi be amewo nalɔ̃ nye nya le awu siwo medona ta?’
‘Am I trying to impress people with my clothing?’

Aɖaŋuɖoɖo: Le esi nàna susu eve ko nanɔ asiwò ku ɖe awudodo ŋu​ eyae nye be, ne yedo awu ƒe atsyã siwo le tsia dzi la amewo alɔ̃ yeƒe nya, gake ne yedo atsyã xoxowo la, amewo malɔ̃ yeƒe nya o ɖeɖe​ la, anyo be nàbu susu etɔ̃lia sia hã ŋu: ka ɖe ɖokuiwò dzi eye nàɖe dzi ɖi.
Fashion tip: Rather than seeing only two options​ trendy (and accepted) or out-of-style (and rejected)​ consider a third option: self-confident and secure.
Ne èdo awu heɖe dzi ɖi la, ana nàvo le ɖokuiwò me.
The more comfortable you are with yourself, the less anxious you will feel about fitting in.
Vodada #3: Bubu be ne yedo awu wònyɔ dzodzro ɖe amewo mee nye nyuitɔ.
Mistake #3: Thinking ‘the sexier, the better.’
Nyɔnuvi aɖe si ŋkɔe nye Jennifer gblɔ be: "Le nyateƒe me la, edzroam ɣeaɖewoɣi be mado awu si anyɔ dzodzro ɖe ame me.
"Honestly, sometimes it’s tempting to wear something a little edgy, as in too short or too tight or too skimpy, " admits a girl named Jennifer.

Mɔ Nyuitɔ: Biblia gblɔ be: "Migana miaƒe atsyɔ̃ɖoɖo nanye gota gome tɔ . . . o, ke boŋ mina wòanye dzi me ƒe ame ɣaɣla. " (1 Petro 3:3, 4) Le ɖekawɔwɔ me kple nuxlɔ̃ame sia la, nu kae ana ame ƒe nu nalé dzi na amewo wu​ gotagomenyonyo loo alo ememenyonyo ye?

A better route: The Bible says: "Do not let your adornment be external . . . but let it be the secret person of the heart. " (1 Peter 3:3, 4) In harmony with that advice, think about what’s more attractive​ eye-catching outfits or heart-touching traits.
Aɖaŋuɖoɖo: Wogblɔna be ‘atsyã si dzɔa dzi na wò wu’ lae sɔ na wò.
Fashion tip: Your best ‘fashion accessory’ is modesty.
Nyateƒeae nye be ame geɖewo megada asi ɖe nya ma dzi egbea o.
True, that’s not a popular word today.
Gake bu eŋu kpɔ:
But think of it this way:
Èɖo dze kple ame aɖe kpɔ eye eya ɖeka xɔ nya katã gblɔ eye wònɔ nu ƒom fũu tso eɖokui ŋua?
Have you ever had a conversation with someone who talks too much and only about himself or herself?
Nublanuitɔe la, amea ŋutɔ menya kura be yeƒe nuwɔna te ɖe dziwò o!
The sad thing is, that person probably has no clue that he or she is putting you off!
Sɔhɛ ŋutsuvi aɖe le susu hem yi awu si wòdo dzi eye esia ku dzi na sɔhɛ bubuawo
A teenage boy draws attention to what he is wearing while other teenagers look disgusted
Sɔhɛ ŋutsuvi aɖe le susu hem yi awu si wòdo dzi eye esia ku dzi na sɔhɛ bubuawo
Clothing, like conversation, can be so ‘me-focused’ that it repels those around you
Ne èdzrana ɖo ɖekematsɔlemetɔe la, ke àɖi ame ma.
When you dress immodestly, you become like that person.
Wò nudodowo ana amewo nasusui be ele gbɔgblɔm be, ‘Kpɔm ɖa,’ eye esia ana wò ŋutɔ nàdo kpo vovo le ɖokuiwò me alo wò susu katã nanɔ ɖokuiwò ŋu loo alo eve siaa.
Your attire sends out the message ‘look at me,’ and that can make you appear either insecure or self-absorbed​ or both.
Ana wòadze na amewo hã be èdi be ame sia ame ƒomevi ƒe susu nava ye dzi faa​ ame gblẽkuwo hã le eme.
It can also make you look desperate for any kind of attention​ even the wrong kind.
Le esi nànɔ boblo dom nane si dzram mèle o teƒe la, dzra ɖo nyuie.
Rather than advertising something you’re not selling, try modesty.
Sɔhɛ aɖe si ŋkɔe nye Monica gblɔ be: "Be nàdzra ɖo nyuie la, esia mele fiafiam be nàdzra ɖo abe mamawò ene o.
"Modesty doesn’t mean you have to dress like your grandmother, " says a teenager named Monica.
Nu si wòfia koe nye be nàdzra ɖo wòade bubu ɖokuiwò kple ame bubuwo ŋu. "
"It just means that you respect yourself and others around you. "
NYA SIWO HAWÒTIWO GBLƆ
WHAT YOUR PEERS SAY
Breanna
Breanna
"Meƒle awu siwo lolo wum vie, menye le esi mekpɔ lãme ta o, ke boŋ nyemedi be nye awuwo namiam kpaɖii o.
"I bought skirts that were a size larger than normal, not because I had gained weight but because I wanted to make sure my clothes weren’t clinging.
Gake màhase o ɖe, ɖe amewo va nɔ biayem boŋ be ɖe mele ku ɖim hã!
Guess what? People actually asked me if I had lost weight!
Ðe awudodo ɖe nɔnɔme nyui me nana ame ganya kpɔna ɖe edzi boŋ. "​ Breanna.
Dressing modestly makes you look better. "​ Breanna.
Keren
Keren
"Le nyateƒe me, ne medo awu ɖe nɔnɔme nyui me la, enana mevona le ɖokuinye me wu.
"I honestly feel more comfortable dressing modestly.

Awudodo ɖe nɔnɔme nyui me nana awua nya kpɔna le ŋunye, eye wònana hã be meɖea dzi ɖi le afi sia afi si meyi. Mate ŋu ana amewo nanya be Kristotɔe menye, eye nyemavɔ̃ be nye dzadzraɖo mesɔ ɖe nye dzixɔsewo nu o. "​ Keren.
Not only do my clothes fit better but I’m also at ease knowing that anywhere I go, I can tell people I’m a Christian and I don’t have to worry that my appearance doesn’t match my beliefs. "​ Keren.
Aleke Mawɔ Aɖe Nye Lolome Dzi Akpɔtɔ?
How Can I Lose Weight?
Ðe wòhiã ŋutɔŋutɔ be maɖe nye lolome dzi akpɔtɔa?
Do I really need to lose weight?
Mɔ kae nye nyuitɔ si dzi mato aɖe nye lolome dzi akpɔtɔ?
What’s the best way to lose weight?
Nu siwo nàwɔ
Action plan
Nya siwo hawòtiwo gblɔ
What your peers say
Ðe wòhiã ŋutɔŋutɔ be maɖe nye lolome dzi akpɔtɔa?
Do I really need to lose weight?
Sɔhɛ aɖewo gblɔna be yewodi be yewoaɖe yewoƒe lolome dzi akpɔtɔ.
Some teenagers say that they want to lose weight.
Gake . . .
However . . .
Ame geɖe tsia dzi ɖe woƒe dzedzeme ŋu wu woƒe lãmesẽ me nɔnɔ ŋu.
Many are more concerned about their appearance than their health.
Esi ame aɖewo di be yewoaɖe yewoƒe lolome dzi akpɔtɔ ta la, wozãa mɔnu siwo ana woaɖi ku kaba wu.
To shed pounds, some resort to quick fixes, like skipping meals or taking weight-loss pills.
Zi geɖe la, mɔnu siawo meɖea vi aɖeke o, eye wogblẽa nu le wo ŋu ɣeaɖewoɣi gɔ̃ hã.
Such methods usually prove futile and are sometimes even dangerous.
"Nyɔnuvi aɖewo tea nuɖuɖu wo ɖokuiwo kple susu be yewoaɖi ku kaba.
"Some girls starve themselves to get faster results.
Zi geɖe la, esia gblẽa nu le woƒe ŋutilã ŋu, eye exɔa ɣeyiɣi didi aɖe hafi woƒe ŋutilã gaɖɔna ɖo. "
This usually backfires, and then it takes a long time for their body to recover from the damage. "
Hailey.
Hailey.
Mehiã be ame siwo tsia dzi ɖe woƒe lolome ŋu la dometɔ geɖe natsi dzi hafi o.
Many who are concerned about their weight should not be.

Woƒe lolome megblẽ o, gake ɖewohĩ wosena le wo ɖokuiwo me be yewololo ne wotsɔ wo ɖokuiwo sɔ kple wo hatiwo alo ame tsralɛ siwo wokafuna le nyakakamɔnuwo abe magazinewo kple television dzi wɔnawo ene me.
Their weight is fine but perhaps they feel fat when they compare themselves with their peers or with the skinny "ideal " that the media promotes.
"Esi mexɔ ƒe 13 la, metsɔa ɖokuinye sɔna kple xɔ̃nyewo.
"When I was 13, I compared myself to my friends.
Ewɔna nam be woakpɔ ŋudzedze ɖe ŋunye geɖe wu ne mele abe woawo ke ene, eye esia abia be manɔ tsralɛ abe xakui ene. "
I thought they would like me more if I looked like them which meant that I had to be stick-thin. "
Paola.
Paola.
Gake ehiã be sɔhɛ aɖewo ya naɖe woƒe lolome dzi akpɔtɔ.
On the other hand, some young people really do need to lose weight.
Wogblɔ le Xexea Me Lãmesẽ Habɔbɔa ƒe nyatakaka aɖe me be . . .
According to a World Health Organization report . . .
Le xexea me godoo la, sɔhɛ miliɔn 340 siwo xɔ tso ƒe 5 va se ɖe ƒe 19 la lolo wu ale si wòle be woanɔ.
Globally, some 340 million youths between the ages of 5 and 19 are overweight.
Le 1975 me la, sɔhɛ siwo xɔ tso ƒe 5 va se ɖe ƒe 19 la dometɔ ene le alafa me koe lolo akpa.
In 1975 just 4 percent of those in the 5-19 age bracket were overweight.
Gake kaka ƒe 2016 naɖo la, xexlẽmea dzi ɖe edzi va ɖo 18 le alafa me.
By 2016 the figure had risen to 18 percent.
Le dukɔ akpa gãtɔ me la, ame siwo lolo wu ale si wòle be woanɔ la sɔ gbɔ wu ame siwo ɖi ku.
For most lands around the world, it is more common for people to be obese than to be underweight.
Le dukɔ dahewo hã me la, ebɔ be ame nalolo wu ale si dze, eye ele elea le aƒe siwo me ƒomea me tɔ aɖewo mekpɔa nu nyui ɖuna o la gɔ̃ hã me.
Obesity is also common in low-income countries, even in households where some members are undernourished.
Mɔ kae nye nyuitɔ si dzi mato aɖe nye lolome dzi akpɔtɔ?
What’s the best way to lose weight?
Mɔnu siawo dometɔ kae nàtia?
Which method would you choose?
Te nuɖuɖu ɖokuiwò ɣeaɖewoɣi.
Skip meals.
Ðu nu siwo me nunyiame le eye nànɔ kame dem.
Combine exercise with a balanced diet.
No atike siwo ana nàɖi ku.
Take weight-loss pills.
Ŋuɖoɖo nyuitɔ: Mɔnu 2 lia: Ðu nu siwo me nunyiame le eye nànɔ kame dem.
Correct answer: Method 2: Combine exercise with a balanced diet.
Ne ètea nuɖuɖu ɖokuiwò ɣeaɖewoɣi alo èɖe nuɖuɖu ƒe hatsotso aɖe ɖa le wò nuɖuɖu me la, ɖewohĩ àɖi ku kaba wu ya.
Skipping meals or cutting out a food group might get quick results.
Gake mɔnu mawo ate ŋu agblẽ nu le wò lãmesẽ ŋu, eye àgalolo ake ne ègate nu mawo ɖuɖu abe ale si nèwɔnɛ tsã ene.
But those methods may not be healthy, and you’ll likely regain the weight once you return to your usual eating habits.
Ke hã, ne enye wò taɖodzinu be yeanɔ lãmesẽ me la, àva kpɔe be yeƒe dzedzeme kple lãmesẽnyawo ganyo wu.
On the other hand, if you make it your goal to be healthy, you will look and feel your best.

Agbalẽnyalagã Michael Bradley gblɔ be: "Mɔnu si ana nànɔ dedie, si ade wò lãmesẽ dzi eteƒe nadidi lae nye be . . . nàwɔ tɔtrɔwo le ale si nènɔa agbee ŋu, eye tɔtrɔ siawo nanye esiwo me nàte ŋu alé ɖe asi le wò agbemeŋkeke mamlɛawo me. "
"The safest, healthiest, and most long-lasting results come from . . . altering your lifestyle in ways that you can maintain for the rest of your days, " writes Dr. Michael Bradley.
Nu kae esia fia?
The point?
Ne ehiã be nàɖe wò lolome dzi akpɔtɔ la, wò taɖodzinu meganye be nàte nuɖuɖu aɖewo ɖokuiwò o, ke boŋ nàwɔ tɔtrɔwo le ale si nènɔa agbee ŋu.
If you need to lose weight, don’t think in terms of following a diet but of adopting a lifestyle change.
Nu siwo nàwɔ
Action plan
Biblia gblɔ be ‘míada asɔ le nuwɔna me,’ eye esia lɔ nuɖuɖu hã ɖe eme.
The Bible tells us to be "moderate in habits " and that includes eating habits.
(1 Timoteo 3:11) Biblia gblɔe tẽe be míaƒo asa na nu tsu ɖuɖu.
(1 Timothy 3:11) It even specifically says to avoid overeating.
(Lododowo 23:20; Luka 21:34) Esi mɔfiame mawo le susu me na wò la, te aɖaŋuɖoɖo siawo kpɔ ale be nànɔ agbe si ade wò lãmesẽ dzi wu:
(Proverbs 23:20; Luke 21:34) With those principles in mind, try the following in order to adopt a healthier lifestyle:
Ŋutsuvi aɖe le ŋku lém ɖe nuɖuɖu aɖe ŋu tututu
A teenage boy looks closely at some food
Nya nu si wòfia be woaɖu nu siwo me nunyiame le.
Learn what healthy eating involves.
Mehiã be nànɔ kpaɖii akpa le nu siwo nàtia be yeaɖu gome o, gake ne ègasrɔ̃ nu vi aɖe tso nuɖuɖuwo ŋu la, esia ate ŋu awɔe be nàva nɔ nu siwo me nunyiame le ɖum.
You don’t have to become a fanatic, but a little knowledge about nutrition can go a long way in helping you to have a balanced diet.
Nu siwo me nunyiame le ɖuɖu nye mɔ nyuitɔ siwo dzi nàto ana wò lolome nada asɔ la dometɔ ɖeka.
And a balanced diet is one of the best ways to keep your weight on track.
Ŋutsuvi aɖe le zɔzɔm kabakaba
A teenage boy takes a brisk walk
Nɔ kame dem edziedzi.
Exercise regularly.
Bu nu siwo nànɔ wɔwɔm gbe sia gbe be nànɔ lãmesẽ me la ŋu.
Think of everyday things you can do to keep active.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, le esi nànɔ dziƒoxɔliamɔ̃ zãm teƒe la, zã atrakpuia boŋ.
For example, instead of taking the elevator, take the stairs.
Le esi nàtsɔ miniti 30 anɔ videodzifefewo ƒom teƒe la, zã ɣeyiɣi ma nàtsɔ azɔ azɔli afɔtsɔtsɔe le gota boŋ.
Trade a half hour of video gaming for a brisk walk outdoors.
Ŋutsuvi aɖe le numeɖenu si me nunyiame le tiam ɖe nuɖuɖu si me nunyiame mele o teƒe
A teenage boy selects healthy snacks instead of nonnutritious food
Ðu nu siwo me nunyiame le ɖe esiwo me nunyiame mele o la teƒe.
Replace junk food with healthy choices.
Ðetugbui aɖe si ŋkɔe nye Sophia gblɔ be: "Medzea agbagba be mana numeɖenu siwo dea lãmesẽ dzi, abe atikutsetsewo ene, nanɔ asitsɔƒe nam.
"I try to keep healthy snacks like fruits and vegetables around, " says a teenager named Sophia.
Ema nana wònɔa bɔbɔe nam be maƒo asa na nu siwo me amenyinu mele o la ɖuɖu. "
"That way I’m not tempted to eat a lot of nonnutritious food. "

Gbɔ dzi ɖi ne èle nu ɖum.
Eat slowly.
Ame aɖewo ɖua nu kabakaba ale gbegbe be ne woɖi ƒo gɔ̃ hã la, womedea dzesii kaba o!
Some people eat so fast that they don’t "hear " the body’s signal to stop! So slow down.
Eya ta gbɔ dzi ɖi ne èle nu ɖum.
Take a break before going for more food.
Ne èɖu nu si le agba me na wò vɔ la, lala vie hafi nàgaɖu bubu kpee.
You might find that you’re not as hungry as you think you are.
Ðewohĩ àkpɔe be dɔ mele wuwòm abe ale si nèsusui ene o.

Ŋutsuvi aɖe le nunyiame ŋuti nyatakaka si le nuɖuɖu ƒe go aɖe ŋu la xlẽm
Monitor your intake of calories.
Ðɔ ŋu ɖo le ŋutilãnyinu (calories) siwo nèɖuna ŋu.
Read nutrition labels to see how many calories are in your food.
Xlẽ nu siwo woŋlɔ ɖe nuɖuɖu ƒe gowo ŋu be nànya ŋutilãnyinu agbɔsɔsɔ si le wò nuɖuɖu me.
Clue: Sweetened soft drinks, fast food, and desserts can be a major source of calories and weight gain.
Ŋutsuvi aɖe ƒo bɔl vɔ eye wòle numeɖenu fafɛ aɖe nyim
A teenage boy enjoys an ice cream cone after playing ball
Mègatsi dzi ɖe wò lolome ŋu fũu akpa o.
Be balanced.

Sara, si xɔ ƒe 16, gblɔ be: "Ɣeaɖeɣi va yi la, metsia dzi ɖe ŋutilãnyinu ƒe agbɔsɔsɔ si le nye nuɖuɖu me ŋu ale gbegbe be ne mekpɔ nuɖuɖu le agba me la, ŋutilãnyinu agbɔsɔsɔme si le nuɖuɖua me ŋu koe nye susu nɔna! "
Sara, 16, says: "At one point I was so obsessed with counting calories that when I looked at a plate of food, all I could see were numbers! "
Mègawɔ ɖokuiwò "ŋutilãnyinuwo ŋuti kɔntabula o. "
Don’t become a "calorie accountant. "
Àte ŋu aɖu nu siwo vivia nuwò la ɣeaɖewoɣi ne ŋutilãnyinuwo sɔ gbɔ ɖe wo me gɔ̃ hã.
You can allow yourself an occasional treat.
Kpekpeɖeŋu: Gblɔ ale si nètsia dzi ɖe wò lolome ŋu na wò ɖɔkta.
Tip: Talk to your doctor about your weight concerns.
Nu si wò ɖɔktaa nya tso wò lãmesẽnyawo ŋu la ate ŋu akpe ɖe eŋu wòana mɔfiame siwo ana nànɔ agbe si ade wò lãmesẽ dzi wu la wò.
He or she can take your medical profile into consideration and help you adopt a lifestyle program that may work for you.

Don’t think in terms of following a diet, but of adopting a healthy lifestyle.

Exercise regularly.
