Ame siwo ƒoa nu alea la ate ŋu aɖe wo ɖokuiwo nu kple nya sia be, "Fefem ko menɔ! "
People who use sarcasm might say, "I was just joking! "
Gake menye nukonyae wònye be woagblɔ nya si ado ŋukpe ame o.
But humiliating others is no laughing matter.
Biblia gblɔ na mí be míaɖe ‘nya veame kple nu sia nu si gblẽa nu le ame ŋu la’ ɖa le mía dome. Efesotɔwo 4:31.
The Bible tells us to put away "abusive speech, as well as everything injurious. "​ Ephesians 4:​31.
"Le dzɔdzɔme nu la, melɔ̃a nya siwo ado nukokoe na ame la gbɔgblɔ, eye esia nana megblɔa gbɔɖiamenyawo, si wɔnɛ be mekpɔa nya zi geɖe. " Oksana.
"I tend to be very witty, and I like to be funny​ qualities that lead to sarcasm, which often gets me into trouble. "​ Oksana.
Ðekakpui aɖe le agbagba dzem be yeatutu numeklɔtike ade eƒe goea me
A young man tries to put toothpaste back into its tube
Ne nya aɖe nya do le nuwò ko la, edo xoxo, màgate ŋu agbugbɔe o, abe ale si ko màte ŋu agbugbɔ numeklɔtike ade eƒe goea me o ene
Once you say something, you can’t take it back any more than you can put toothpaste back into its tube
Ale si nàmla wò aɖe
Taming the tongue
Ate ŋu asesẽ be nàsrɔ̃ ale si nàɖu wò aɖe dzi, gake Biblia ƒe mɔfiamewo ate ŋu akpe ɖe ŋuwò.
Learning to control your tongue may not be easy, but Bible principles can help.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, bu mawunyakpukpui siwo gbɔna la ŋu kpɔ.
For example, consider the following.
"Migblɔ miaƒe nya le dzi me, . . . eye mizi kpi kpoo. " Psalmo 4:4.
"Have your say in your heart, . . . and keep silent. "​ Psalm 4:4.
Ɣeaɖewoɣi la, nu nyuitɔ si nàwɔe nye be nàzi ɖoɖoe.
Sometimes the best reply is no reply.
Ðetugbui aɖe si ŋkɔe nye Laura gblɔ be: "Ale si mese le ɖokuinye me esime medo dziku la ate ŋu atrɔ ne nye dzi va dze eme.
"The way I feel in the heat of the moment might not be the way I’ll feel later, " says a young woman named Laura.
Ne nye dzi dze eme la, edzɔa dzi nam be nyemegblɔ nya si meɖo be magblɔ hafi o. "
"After I calm down, I’m usually glad I didn’t say what I wanted to. "
Ðoɖoezizi sɛkɛnd ʋɛ aɖewo ko gɔ̃ hã ate ŋu ana be màgblɔ nya si mesɔ o.
Even pausing for just a few seconds can keep you from saying the wrong thing.
"Ðe to medoa nya kpɔna, abe ale si aɖe ɖɔa nu kpɔna ene oa? " Hiob 12:11.
"Does not the ear test out words as the tongue tastes food? "​ Job 12:11.
Àte ŋu aƒo asa na kuxi geɖe ne ètsɔ nyabiase siwo gbɔna la do nya siwo nèbe yeagblɔ la kpɔ hafi ƒo nu:
You can spare yourself much grief if you test out what you have in mind to say with these questions:
Nyateƒe yea?
Is it true?
Ðe wòanye ameŋububua?
Is it kind?
Ðe wòhiã kokoko be magblɔea? Romatɔwo 14:19.
Is it necessary?​ Romans 14:19.
Mateo 7:12. Ðe wòafia be mede bubu ame kemɛa ƒe susu ŋua?
How would I feel if someone said it to me?​ Matthew 7:​12.
Romatɔwo 12:10. Ðe wòsɔ be magblɔ nya sia le nɔnɔme sia mea?
Will it show respect for the other person’s viewpoint?​ Romans 12:10.
Nyagblɔla 3:7.
Is this the right setting in which to say it?​ Ecclesiastes 3:7.
"Mitsɔ ɖokuibɔbɔ bu ame bubuwo be wonye gã wu mi. " Filipitɔwo 2:3.
"With humility consider others superior to you. "​ Philippians 2:3.
Aɖaŋuɖoɖo sia ate ŋu akpe ɖe ŋuwò be nàbu susu nyuiwo ɖe ame bubuwo ŋu, eye esia akpe ɖe ŋuwò be nàɖu wò aɖe dzi ahabu nuwo ŋu nyuie hafi aƒo nu.
That advice will help you cultivate good thoughts toward others, which will in turn help you hold your tongue and think before you speak.
Ne nya veame aɖe ge le nuwò xoxo gɔ̃ hã la, ɖokuibɔbɔ akpe ɖe ŋuwò be nàɖe kuku, eye nàtso ɖe esia wɔwɔ ŋu kaba ale si wòanya wɔ!
Even if it’s too late and you have said something hurtful, humility will help you to apologize​ and to do so as quickly as possible!
(Mateo 5:23, 24) Eyome nàdze agbagba geɖe wu be nàmla wò aɖe.
(Matthew 5:​23, 24) Then resolve to do better at taming your tongue.
Nya siwo hawòtiwo gblɔ
What your peers say
Taylor
Taylor
"Ne mele vivi sem na dzeɖoɖo la, edzɔna be megblɔa nya siwo nyemeɖo be magblɔ hafi o.
"In the excitement of a conversation, I have a tendency to say things that I don’t mean.

Gake ne melala sɛkɛnd ewo teti hebu tame tso ale si nya si medi be magblɔ ana amewo nase le wo ɖokui me ŋu, alo mebu eŋu kpɔ be ɖe wòade dzi ƒo na ame hã la, metea ŋu ɖua nye aɖe dzi nyuie wu. " Taylor.

But if I wait just ten seconds to think about how my speech will affect others or whether it will really contribute something worthwhile to the conversation, I’m able to control my tongue much better. "​ Taylor.
Brandon
Brandon
"Ne ame aɖe gblɔ nya aɖe si ve wò la, anyo be nàbu nɔnɔme si me wògblɔe le la ŋu.
"When someone says something that disturbs you, it’s good to consider the circumstances.
Zi geɖe la, aɖea dzi maɖumaɖu gbɔ koe wòtsona, eye woate ŋu aŋe aɖaba aƒu edzi.
Often, it’s just wild talk, and it can be forgotten.
Ɣebubuɣiwo la, awɔ na wò be amea meƒo nu na wò nyuie o, gake ɖewohĩ nyateƒe aɖe le nya si wògblɔ la me.
At other times, what’s said can seem unfair from your perspective, but there may be some truth in it.
Nuƒoƒo tso eŋu kple amea tufafatɔe ate ŋu ana miakpɔ nya siawo tɔgbi gbɔ. " Brandon.
Good, calm communication is key in solving those situations. "​ Brandon.
Jessica
Jessica
"Ne nya veamewo mevaa susu me na mí o la, ke anɔ bɔbɔe hã be míagagblɔ wo o.
"It’s easier to avoid saying hurtful things if they don’t come to our mind in the first place.
Ɣeaɖewoɣi la, ehiãna be míawɔ asitɔtrɔ le ale si míebua nuwo ŋui kpakple nɔnɔme si le mía si ɖe amewo ŋu la ŋu.
Sometimes we need to work on our outlook on situations and our attitude toward people.
Ne míewɔnɛ alea la, anɔ bɔbɔe be míaƒo asa na nu si ave amewo la gbɔgblɔ. " Jessica.
If we do, then we’ll be less tempted to say something that could hurt them. "​ Jessica.
Sara nɔ agbe ƒe alafa ɖeka blaeve vɔ adre; esiae nye Sara ƒe agbenɔƒe.
And Sarah lived for 127 years; these were the years of Sarah’s life.
2 Eye Sara ku le Kiriat-Arba, si nye Hebron, le Kanaan-nyigba dzi. Abraham xa nu vevie eye wòfa Sara ŋutɔ.
2 So Sarah died in Kiriat-Arba, that is, Hebron, in the land of Canaan, and Abraham began to mourn and to weep over Sarah.
3 Eye Abraham tso le srɔ̃a kukua gbɔ yi ɖagblɔ na Het viwo be: 4 “Amedzro menye va tsi mia dome.
3 Then Abraham got up from before his dead wife and he said to the sons of Heth: 4 “I am a foreigner and settler among you.
Mina teƒem le mia gbɔ wòazu nye ameɖiƒe, ale be maɖi srɔ̃nye ɖe afi ma.” 5 Het viwo ɖo eŋu na Abraham be: 6 “Nye aƒetɔ, ɖo to mí.
Give me a property to serve as a burial place in your midst so that I may remove my dead for burial.” 5 At this the sons of Heth answered Abraham: 6 “Hear us, my lord.
Mawu ɖo wò amegã le mía dome.
You are a chieftain of God among us.
Àte ŋu aɖi srɔ̃wò ɖe míaƒe ameɖiƒe nyuitɔ faa.
You may bury your dead in the choicest of our burial places.
Mía dometɔ aɖeke magbe be nàgaɖi wò ame kuku la ɖe yeƒe ameɖiƒe o.”
None of us will hold back his burial place from you to prevent you from burying your dead.”

7 Eye Abraham tso eye wòbɔbɔ ɖe Het viwo, siwo nye dua me vidzidziwo, ŋkume 8 eye wògblɔ na wo be: “Ne mielɔ̃ ɖe edzi be maɖi srɔ̃nye la, ekema miɖo tom; miɖe kuku na Zohar vi Efron nam, 9 be wòadzra Makepela-gado si le eƒe anyigba ƒe liƒo dzi lɔƒo la nam.

7 So Abraham got up and bowed down to the people of the land, to the sons of Heth, 8 and said to them: “If you agree to let me remove my dead for burial, then listen to me and urge Ephron the son of Zohar 9 to sell me the cave of Machpelah, which belongs to him; it is at the edge of his field.
Nedzrae nam le mia ŋkume ɖe klosalo ale si nu wòaxɔ la nu, ne wòazu nye ameɖiƒe.”
Let him sell it to me in your presence for the full amount of silver so that I may have a property for a burial place.”
10 Ke Efron bɔbɔ nɔ Het viwo dome.
10 Now Ephron was sitting among the sons of Heth.
Eye Hititɔ Efron ɖo eŋu na Abraham le Het viwo kple ame siwo katã va dua ƒe agbo nu la ƒe to me be: 11 “Ao, nye aƒetɔ!
So Ephron the Hittite answered Abraham in the hearing of the sons of Heth, and before all who entered the gate of his city, saying: 11 “No, my lord!
Ðo tom.
Listen to me.
Metsɔ anyigba la kple agado si le edzi la siaa na wò.
I give you both the field and the cave that is in it.
Metsɔe na wò le nye dukɔ la me viwo ŋkume.
In the presence of the sons of my people, I give it to you.
Ði wò ame kukua faa.” 12 Eye Abraham bɔbɔ ɖe dua me viwo ŋkume, 13 eye wògblɔ na Efron, esi dua me viwo hã nɔ to dzi, be: “Ne èlɔ̃ la, ke ɖo tom!
Bury your dead.” 12 At that Abraham bowed down before the people of the land 13 and spoke to Ephron in the hearing of the people, saying: “Listen to me, if you will!
Matsɔ klosalo ale si nu anyigba la axɔ la ana wò.
I will give you the full amount of silver for the field.
Xɔe le asinye, ne maɖi srɔ̃nye ɖe afi ma.”
Take it from me, in order that I may bury my dead there.”
14 Eye Efron ɖo eŋu na Abraham be: 15 “Nye aƒetɔ, ɖo tom.
14 Then Ephron answered Abraham: 15 “My lord, listen to me.
Nu kae anyigba si ƒe home nye klosalo sekel alafa ene la nye le nye kpli wò dome?
This land is worth 400 silver shekels, but what is that between me and you?
Ði wò ame kukua faa.” 16 Abraham ɖo to Efron, eye Abraham da klosalo home si Efron yɔ Het viwo se la nɛ. Klosalo sekel alafa ene ɖe ale si asitsalawo danɛ nu.

So bury your dead.” 16 Abraham listened to Ephron, and Abraham weighed out to Ephron the amount of silver that he had mentioned in the hearing of the sons of Heth, 400 silver shekels according to the weight accepted by the merchants.

17 Ale woɖo kpe edzi be Efron ƒe anyigba si le Makepela le Mamre ŋgɔ, anyigba la kple agado si le edzi, kple ati siwo katã le anyigbaa dzi la 18 zu Abraham ƒe nunɔamesi si wòƒle le Het viwo kple ame siwo katã va dua ƒe agbo nu la ŋkume.

17 Thus the field of Ephron in Machpelah, which was in front of Mamre—the field and the cave in it and all the trees within the boundaries of the field—became confirmed as 18 Abraham’s purchased property in the presence of the sons of Heth, before all those entering the gate of his city.
19 Emegbe Abraham ɖi srɔ̃a Sara ɖe agado si le Makepela-nyigba dzi le Mamre ŋgɔ la me, le Hebron le Kanaan-nyigba dzi.
19 After that Abraham buried his wife Sarah in the cave of the field of Machpelah in front of Mamre, that is, Hebron, in the land of Canaan.
20 Ale Het viwo ɖe asi le anyigba la kple agado si le edzi la ŋu na Abraham wòzu eƒe ameɖiƒe.
20 Thus the field and the cave that was in it were transferred by the sons of Heth to Abraham as property for a burial place.
Emegbe Yakob yi eƒe mɔzɔzɔa dzi eye wòva ɖo Ɣedzeƒetɔwo ƒe anyigba dzi.
After that Jacob resumed his journey and traveled on to the land of the people of the East.
2 Eye wòkpɔ vudo aɖe le gbea dzi, eye alẽha etɔ̃ tsyɔ akɔ anyi ɖe afi ma le vudoa gbɔ, elabena vudo ma mee wokua tsi le na lãhawo wonona.
2 Now he saw a well in the field and three droves of sheep lying down next to it, because they usually watered the droves from that well.
Ke kpe gã aɖe le vudoa nu.
There was a large stone over the mouth of the well.
3 Ne woƒo lãhawo katã nu ƒu ɖe afi ma vɔ la, womlia kpe la ɖa le vudoa nu, eye wonaa tsi alẽhaawo, emegbe wogamlia kpe la ɖoa vudoa nu.

3 When all the droves had been gathered there, they rolled away the stone from the mouth of the well, and they watered the flocks, after which they returned the stone to its place over the mouth of the well.

4 Yakob bia wo be: “Nɔvinyewo, afi kae mietso?” Woɖo eŋu be: “Míetso Haran.” 5 Eye wòbia wo be: “Miedze si Laban, si nye Nahor ƒe tɔgbuiyɔvia?” Woɖo eŋu be: “Míedze sii.” 6 Eye wògabia wo be: “Eli sesĩea?”

4 So Jacob said to them: “My brothers, what place are you from?” to which they said: “We are from Haran.” 5 He said to them: “Do you know Laban the grandson of Nahor?” to which they said: “We know him.” 6 At this he said to them: “Is he well?”
Woɖo eŋu be: “Eli sesĩe.
They replied: “He is well.
Kpɔ ɖa, vianyɔnu Rahel ye nye ema kplɔ alẽwo gbɔnae!” 7 Eye wògagblɔ be: “Ɣeɖota koe nye esia.
And here is his daughter Rachel coming with the sheep!” 7 Then he said: “It is still the middle of the day.
Ɣeyiɣi mede haɖe be miaƒo lãhawo nu ƒu o ɖe!
It is not the time for gathering the herds.
Mina tsi alẽawo, emegbe miana woagaɖu gbe.” 8 Woɖo eŋu be: “Mɔɖeɖe meli be míawɔ esia o, va se ɖe esime woƒo lãhawo katã nu ƒu, eye womli kpe la ɖa le vudoa nu.
Water the sheep, and then go feed them.” 8 To this they said: “We are not allowed to do so until all the droves are gathered and they roll the stone away from the mouth of the well.
Ema megbe ko hafi míenaa tsi alẽawo.”
Then we water the sheep.”
9 Esi wògale nuƒoƒo dzi kpli wo la, Rahel kplɔ fofoa ƒe alẽwo vɛ, elabena alẽkplɔla wònye.
9 While he was yet speaking with them, Rachel came with her father’s sheep, for she was a shepherdess.
10 Esi Yakob kpɔ dadaa nɔvi Laban ƒe vi Rahel kple nyruia Laban ƒe alẽawo la, enumake Yakob te ɖe vudoa ŋu, mli kpea ɖa, eye wòna tsi nyruia Laban ƒe alẽawo wono.

10 When Jacob saw Rachel, the daughter of Laban his mother’s brother, and the sheep of Laban, Jacob immediately approached and rolled the stone away from the mouth of the well and watered the sheep of Laban his mother’s brother.
11 Eye Yakob gbugbɔ nu na Rahel, eye Yakob wó avi.
11 Then Jacob kissed Rachel and raised his voice and burst into tears.
12 Yakob gblɔ na Rahel be fofoa ƒe ƒometɔ yenye, eye be Rebeka ƒe vie yenye.
12 And Jacob began to tell Rachel that he was the relative of her father and that he was the son of Rebekah.
Eye nyɔnuvi la ƒu du yi ɖagblɔe na fofoa.
And she ran off and told her father.
13 Esi Laban nya se nyruiayɔvi Yakob ŋu nya ko la, eƒu du yi ɖakpee.
13 As soon as Laban heard the report about Jacob the son of his sister, he ran to meet him.
Eye wòkpla asi kɔ nɛ, gbugbɔ nu nɛ, eye wòkplɔe yi eƒe me.
He embraced him and kissed him and brought him into his house.
Eye wògblɔ nyaawo katã na Laban.
And he began to tell Laban all these things.
14 Laban gblɔ nɛ be: “Nyateƒee, nɔvinye kpamkpam nènye.”
14 Laban said to him: “You are indeed my bone and my flesh.”
Ale wònɔ egbɔ ɣleti ɖeka blibo.
So he stayed with him a full month.
15 Emegbe Laban gblɔ na Yakob be: “Esi nènye nye ƒometɔ tae nàsubɔm dzodzroa?
15 Laban then said to Jacob: “Just because you are my relative, should you serve me for nothing?
Gblɔe nam, nu kae anye wò fetu?” 16 Ke nyɔnuvi eve le Laban si.
Tell me, what are your wages to be?” 16 Now Laban had two daughters.
Tsitsitɔ ŋkɔe nye Lea, eye ɖevitɔ ŋkɔe nye Rahel.
The name of the older was Leah, and the name of the younger, Rachel.
17 Lea ƒe ŋkuwo le dɔ̃ɔ, ke Rahel ya dze tugbe, eye wònya kpɔ.
17 But the eyes of Leah had no luster, whereas Rachel had become a very attractive and beautiful woman.
18 Rahel ƒe nu lé dzi na Yakob, eya ta egblɔ be: “Melɔ̃ be masubɔ wò ƒe adre ɖe viwònyɔnu ɖevitɔ Rahel ta.” 19 Eye Laban gblɔ be: “Enyo be matsɔe ana wò wu be matsɔe ana ŋutsu bubu.

18 Jacob had fallen in love with Rachel, so he said: “I am willing to serve you seven years for your younger daughter Rachel.” 19 To this Laban said: “It is better for me to give her to you than to give her to another man.
Nɔ gbɔnye.” 20 Eye Yakob subɔ ƒe adre ɖe Rahel ta, ke wole abe ŋkeke ʋɛ aɖewo ko ene nɛ, elabena elɔ̃e ale gbegbe.
Keep dwelling with me.” 20 And Jacob served seven years for Rachel, but in his eyes they were like just a few days because of his love for her.
21 Emegbe Yakob gblɔ na Laban be: “Tsɔ srɔ̃nyea nam ne manɔ anyi kplii, elabena nye ŋkekewo de.” 22 Ale Laban ƒo afi ma ŋutsuwo katã nu ƒu, eye wòɖo kplɔ̃.
21 Then Jacob said to Laban: “Give over my wife because my days are up, and let me have relations with her.” 22 With that Laban gathered all the men of the place and made a feast.
23 Ke esi zã do la, ekplɔ via Lea boŋ yi nɛ, eye wòdɔ kplii.
23 But during the evening, he resorted to taking his daughter Leah and bringing her to him that he might have relations with her.
24 Laban tsɔ eƒe subɔvinyɔnu Zilpa hã na via Lea be wòasubɔe.
24 Laban also gave his female servant Zilpah to his daughter Leah as a servant.
25 Ke esi ŋu ke la, Yakob kpɔ be Lea boŋ ye!
25 In the morning Jacob saw that it was Leah!
Eya ta ebia Laban be: “Nu kae nye esi nèwɔ ɖe ŋunye?
So he said to Laban: “What have you done to me?
Alo menye Rahel tae mesubɔ wò ɖo oa?
Was it not for Rachel that I served you?
Ke nu ka tae nèflum?” 26 Laban ɖo eŋu be: “Womewɔnɛ alea le mía gbɔ be woatsɔ ɖetugbui ɖevitɔ la ana woaɖe do ŋgɔ na tsitsitɔ o.
Why have you tricked me?” 26 To this Laban said: “It is not our custom here to give the younger woman before the firstborn.
27 Ðu nyɔnu sia ƒe kwasiɖa la wu enu.
27 Celebrate the week of this woman.
Emegbe matsɔ nyɔnu kemɛa hã ana wò ale be nàgasubɔm ƒe adre ɖe eta.” 28 Yakob wɔe nenema, eye wòɖu nyɔnu sia ƒe kwasiɖa la wu enu, eye wòtsɔ vianyɔnu Rahel nɛ wòɖe.

After that you will also be given this other woman in exchange for serving me seven more years.” 28 Jacob did so and celebrated the week of this woman, after which he gave him his daughter Rachel as a wife.
29 Laban tsɔ eƒe subɔvinyɔnu Bilha hã na via Rahel, be wòasubɔe.
29 Besides, Laban gave his female servant Bilhah to his daughter Rachel as her servant.
30 Eye Yakob dɔ kple Rahel hã, ke elɔ̃ Rahel wu Lea, ale wògasubɔe ƒe adre bubu.
30 Then Jacob had relations also with Rachel, and he loved Rachel more than Leah, and he served him for another seven years.
31 Esi Yehowa kpɔe be womelɔ̃ Lea ƒe nya o la, ena wòfɔ fu, ke Rahel ya tsi ko.
31 When Jehovah saw that Leah was unloved, he then enabled her to become pregnant, but Rachel was barren.

32 Ale Lea fɔ fu dzi viŋutsuvi, eye wòna ŋkɔe be Ruben, elabena egblɔ be: “Esi Yehowa kpɔ xaxa si me mele la tae, eya ta srɔ̃nye alɔ̃m azɔ.” 33 Eye wògafɔ fu dzi viŋutsuvi eye wògblɔ be: “Esi Yehowa see be womelɔ̃m o tae wòtsɔ esia hã nam ɖo.”

32 So Leah became pregnant and gave birth to a son and named him Reuben, for she said: “It is because Jehovah has looked upon my affliction, for now my husband will begin to love me.” 33 And she again became pregnant and gave birth to a son and then said: “It is because Jehovah has listened, in that I was unloved, so he gave me this one also.”
Eya ta ena ŋkɔe be Simeon.
Then she named him Simeon.
34 Eye wògafɔ fu dzi viŋutsuvi eye wògblɔ be: “Fifia ya srɔ̃nye aku ɖe ŋunye, elabena medzi viŋutsu etɔ̃ nɛ.”
34 And she became pregnant yet again and gave birth to a son and then said: “Now this time my husband will join himself to me, because I have borne him three sons.”
Eye wòna ŋkɔe be Lewi.
Therefore, he was named Levi.
35 Eye wògafɔ fu ake dzi viŋutsuvi eye wògblɔ be: “Fifia ya makafu Yehowa.”
35 And she became pregnant once more and gave birth to a son and then said: “This time I will praise Jehovah.”
Eye wòna ŋkɔe be Yuda.
She therefore named him Judah.
Emegbe edzudzɔ vidzidzi.
After that she stopped giving birth.
Ɣemaɣi lɔƒo la, Yuda ʋu le nɔviawo gbɔ yi ɖatu eƒe agbadɔ ɖe ŋutsu aɖe si nye Adulamtɔ, si ŋkɔe nye Hira la gbɔ.
About that time Judah left his brothers and pitched his tent near an Adullamite man named Hirah.
2 Yuda kpɔ Kanaan ŋutsu aɖe si ŋkɔe nye Sua ƒe vinyɔnu le afi ma.
2 There Judah saw the daughter of a certain Canaanite named Shua.
Eye wòɖee, edɔ kplii, 3 eye wòfɔ fu.
So he took her and had relations with her, 3 and she became pregnant.
Emegbe edzi ŋutsuvi, eye Yuda na ŋkɔe be Er.
Later she bore a son, and he named him Er.
4 Eye wògafɔ fu dzi ŋutsuvi, eye wòna ŋkɔe be Onan.
4 Again she became pregnant and bore a son and named him Onan.
5 Egadzi viŋutsu bubu, eye wòna ŋkɔe be Sela.
5 Yet again she bore a son and named him Shelah.
Enɔ Akzib esime nyɔnua dzi ɖevi la.
He was in Achzib when she bore him.
6 Emegbe Yuda ɖe srɔ̃ na eƒe ŋgɔgbevi Er, eye nyɔnu la ŋkɔe nye Tamar.
6 In time Judah took a wife for Er his firstborn, and her name was Tamar.
7 Ke Yuda ƒe ŋgɔgbevi Er ƒe nu medze Yehowa ŋu o; eya ta Yehowa wui.
7 But Er, Judah’s firstborn, was displeasing to Jehovah; so Jehovah put him to death.
8 Esia ta Yuda gblɔ na Onan be: “Dɔ kple nɔviwòa srɔ̃, eye nàxɔ nɔviwò si ku la srɔ̃ aɖe, ne nàdzi vi na nɔviwòa.” 9 Ke Onan nyae be womabu ɖeviawo be wonye ye tɔ o.

8 In view of that, Judah said to Onan: “Have relations with your brother’s wife and perform brother-in-law marriage with her and raise up offspring for your brother.” 9 But Onan knew that the offspring would not be considered his.
Eya ta ne edɔ kple nɔvia srɔ̃a la, enana tsi la duduna ɖe anyigba, ale be wòagado ƒome ɖi na nɔvia o.
So when he did have relations with his brother’s wife, he wasted his semen on the ground so as not to give offspring to his brother.
10 Nu si wòwɔ la vɔ̃ɖi le Yehowa ŋkume, eya ta ewu eya hã.
10 What he did was bad in the eyes of Jehovah, so he also put him to death.
11 Yuda gblɔ na toyɔvia Tamar be: “Nɔ fofowò ƒe me, eye nànye ahosi va se ɖe esime vinye Sela tsi,” elabena egblɔ na eɖokui be: ‘Eya hã ava ku abe nɔviawo ke ene.’
11 Judah said to Tamar his daughter-in-law: “Dwell as a widow in the house of your father until my son Shelah grows up,” for he said to himself: ‘He too may die like his brothers.’
Eya ta Tamar yi ɖanɔ fofoa ƒe me.
So Tamar went and stayed in her own father’s house.
12 Le ɣeyiɣi aɖe megbe la, Yuda srɔ̃ si nye Sua vinyɔnu la ku.
12 Some time passed, and Judah’s wife, the daughter of Shua, died.
Esi Yuda wu konyifaɣi la nu vɔ la, eya kple eƒe zɔhɛ Adulamtɔ Hira, woyi ame siwo le fu kom na eƒe alẽwo la gbɔ le Timna.
Judah kept the mourning period, and then he went to his sheepshearers in Timnah with his companion Hirah the Adullamite.

13 Eye wova gblɔ na Tamar be: “Towò yina fu ko ge na eƒe alẽwo le Timna.” 14 Ale wòɖe eƒe ahovɔawo ɖi, tsɔ motsyɔnu tsyɔ mo, tsɔ kɔmevɔ tsyɔ, eye wòva bɔbɔ nɔ Enaim du si le Timna mɔ dzi la ƒe mɔnu, elabena ekpɔ be Sela tsi, ke wometsɔ ye nɛ wòɖe o.

13 Tamar was told: “Here your father-in-law is going up to Timnah to shear his sheep.” 14 With that she removed her widow’s clothing and veiled herself and covered herself with a shawl and sat down at the entrance of Enaim, which is on the road to Timnah, for she saw that Shelah had grown up and yet she had not been given to him as a wife.
15 Esi Yuda kpɔe la, enumake esusu be gboloe, elabena etsyɔ nu mo.
15 When Judah caught sight of her, he at once took her for a prostitute, because she had covered her face.
16 Eya ta edze yi egbɔ le mɔa to gblɔ be: “Meɖe kuku, na mamlɔ gbɔwò,” elabena menya be ye toyɔvi lae o.
16 So he turned aside to her by the road and said: “Allow me, please, to have relations with you,” for he did not know that she was his daughter-in-law.
Ke nyɔnua biae be: “Nu kae nànam hafi adɔ kplim?” 17 Eɖo eŋu be: “Malé gbɔ̃vi ɖeka tso nye lãha la me aɖo ɖe wò.”
However, she said: “What will you give me that you may have relations with me?” 17 To this he said: “I will send a young goat from my herd.”
Ke egblɔ be: “Nu kae nàtsɔ aɖo awɔba va se ɖe esime nèɖoe ɖa?” 18 Eye wòbia nyɔnua be: “Megbedanu kae matsɔ ana wò?”
But she said: “Will you give a security until you send it?” 18 He continued: “What security should I give you?” to which she said: “Your seal ring and your cord and your rod that is in your hand.”
Eɖo eŋu be: “Wò ŋkɔsigɛ, wò ka kple wò atikplɔ si le asiwò.”
Then he gave them to her and had relations with her, and she became pregnant by him.
Eya ta etsɔ wo nɛ eye wòdɔ kplii, eye wòfɔ fu nɛ. 19 Emegbe nyɔnua dzo, eye wòɖe eƒe kɔmevɔ la ɖi gatsɔ eƒe ahovɔawo ta.
19 After that she got up and went away and removed her shawl and clothed herself with her widow’s clothing.
20 Eye Yuda tsɔ gbɔ̃vi la de eƒe zɔhɛ Adulamtɔ la si ɖo ɖa, be wòaxɔ megbedanuawo le nyɔnua si vɛ, ke meke ɖe eŋu o.
20 And Judah sent the young goat by the hand of his companion the Adullamite, to get back the security from the hand of the woman, but he never found her.
21 Eya ta ebia ŋutsu siwo le teƒea be: “Afi kae gbedoxɔmegbolo si nɔa Enaim mɔ to la le?”
21 He inquired of the men of her place, saying: “Where is that temple prostitute in Enaim along the road?”

Ke woɖo eŋu nɛ be: “Gbedoxɔmegbolo aɖeke menɔ teƒe sia kpɔ o.” 22 Mlɔeba etrɔ yi Yuda gbɔ ɖagblɔ nɛ be: “Nyemeke ɖe eŋu o, eye azɔ hã ŋutsu siwo le teƒea gblɔ be, ‘Gbedoxɔmegbolo aɖeke menɔ teƒe sia kpɔ o.’” 23 Eya ta Yuda gblɔ be: “Netsɔ wo faa, ne míagadze vlododo me o.

But they said: “No temple prostitute has ever been in this place.” 22 Finally he returned to Judah and said: “I never found her, and besides, the men of the place said, ‘No temple prostitute has ever been in this place.’” 23 So Judah said: “Let her take them for herself, in order that we may not fall into contempt.
Alekee wòɖale o, nye ya meɖo gbɔ̃vi sia ɖa, eye wò hã ɖe mèke ɖe eŋu o.”
At any rate, I have sent this young goat, but you never found her.”
24 Ke anɔ ɣleti etɔ̃ megbe la, wova gblɔ na Yuda be: “Toyɔviwò Tamar wɔ gbolo, eye efɔ fu hã to eƒe gbolowɔwɔa me.”
24 However, about three months later, Judah was told: “Tamar your daughter-in-law has acted as a prostitute, and she is also pregnant by her prostitution.”
Eye Yuda gblɔ be: “Mikplɔe do goe ne miawui atɔ dzoe.” 25 Esi wokplɔe do gbɔna la, edɔ ame ɖe toa be: “Ŋutsu si ƒe nuwoe nye esiawo lae do fum.”
At that Judah said: “Bring her out and let her be burned.” 25 As she was being brought out, she sent word to her father-in-law: “I am pregnant by the man to whom these belong.”

Eye wòbe woagblɔ kpee be: “Meɖe kuku, lé ŋku ɖe nu siawo, ŋkɔsigɛ, ka kple atikplɔ la ŋu, be ame ka tɔe wonye hã.” 26 Eye Yuda lé ŋku ɖe wo ŋu hegblɔ be: “Etɔ dzɔ wu tɔnye, elabena nyemetsɔe na vinye Sela o.”

Then she added: “Please examine to whom these belong, the seal ring and the cord and the rod.” 26 Then Judah examined them and said: “She is more righteous than I am, because I did not give her to Shelah my son.”
Eye megadɔ kplii le ema megbe o.
And he had no further sexual relations with her after that.
27 Ke esime eƒe vidziɣi ɖo la, kpɔ ɖa, venɔviwo le dɔ me nɛ.
27 When the time came for her to give birth, there were twins in her womb.

28 Esime wòle vi dzim la, ɖeka do asi ɖa, eye enumake vixela la tsɔ ka dzĩ sa ɖe eƒe asi ŋu gblɔ be: “Ame siae do gbã.” 29 Gake esi wònya he asi yi ɖe eme ko la, nɔvia do, ale be vixela la do ɣli be: “Aleke nèfe mɔ na ɖokuiwò ale!”

28 As she was giving birth, one put out his hand, and the midwife immediately took a scarlet thread and tied it around his hand, saying: “This one came out first.” 29 But as soon as he drew back his hand, his brother came out, and she exclaimed: “What a breach you have made for yourself!”
Eya ta wona ŋkɔe be Perez.
So he was named Perez.
30 Emegbe nɔvia si ƒe asi ŋu wosa ka dzĩa ɖo la do, eye wona ŋkɔe be Zera.
30 Afterward his brother came out, around whose hand the scarlet thread was tied, and he was named Zerah.
Eye Yehowa gblɔ na Abram be: “Ʋu le mia de, eye nàdzo le wò ƒometɔwo gbɔ kple fofowò ƒe me, ne nàyi anyigba si mafia wò la dzi.
And Jehovah said to Abram: “Go out from your land and away from your relatives and from the house of your father to the land that I will show you.
2 Mana nàzu dukɔ gã aɖe, mayra wò, eye mana wò ŋkɔ nanyɔ; àva zu yayra na amewo.
2 I will make you a great nation, and I will bless you, and I will make your name great, and you will become a blessing.
3 Mayra ame siwo ayra wò, eye maƒo fi ade ame si ado ɖiŋu na wò la, eye woayra anyigbadziƒomeawo katã to dziwò.”
3 I will bless those who bless you, and I will curse him who calls down evil on you, and all the families of the ground will certainly be blessed by means of you.”
4 Eya ta Abram dze mɔ abe ale si tututu Yehowa gblɔ nɛ ene, eye Lot yi kplii.
4 So Abram went just as Jehovah had told him, and Lot went with him.
Abram xɔ ƒe blaadre vɔ atɔ̃ esime wòʋu tso Haran.
Abram was 75 years old when he left Haran.
5 Abram kplɔ srɔ̃a Sarai kple nɔviaŋutsu ƒe vi Lot; etsɔ nunɔamesi siwo le wo si, eye wòkplɔ ame siwo su wo si le Haran hedze mɔ ɖo ta Kanaan-nyigba dzi.
5 Abram took his wife Sarai and Lot the son of his brother and all the goods that they had accumulated and the people whom they had acquired in Haran, and they set out for the land of Canaan.
Esi wova ɖo Kanaan-nyigba dzi la, 6 Abram tsa le anyigba la dzi va ɖo keke Sekem ke, le More ƒe ati gãwo gbɔ.
When they reached the land of Canaan, 6 Abram traveled through the land as far as the site of Shechem, near the big trees of Moreh.
Ɣemaɣi la, Kanaantɔwo le anyigba la dzi.
At that time the Canaanites were in the land.
7 Yehowa ɖe eɖokui fia Abram eye wògblɔ nɛ be: “Wò dzidzimeviwoe matsɔ anyigba sia ana.”
7 Jehovah then appeared to Abram and said: “To your offspring I am going to give this land.”
Eya ta eɖi vɔsamlekpui ɖe afi ma na Yehowa, ame si ɖe eɖokui fiae la.
So he built an altar there to Jehovah, who had appeared to him.
8 Mlɔeba eʋu le afi ma yi tonuto la me le Betel ƒe ɣedzeƒe, eye wòtu eƒe agbadɔ ɖe afi ma, ale be Betel le ɣetoɖoƒe, eye Ai le ɣedzeƒe.
8 Later he moved from there to the mountainous region east of Bethel and pitched his tent with Bethel on the west and Ai on the east.
Eye wòɖi vɔsamlekpui ɖe afi ma na Yehowa heyɔ Yehowa ƒe ŋkɔ.
There he built an altar to Jehovah and began to call on the name of Jehovah.
9 Emegbe Abram ʋu, eye wònɔ eƒe agbadɔ hom nɔ tutum tso teƒe yi teƒe ɖo ta Negeb.
9 Afterward, Abram broke camp and journeyed toward the Negeb, moving his camp from one place to another.
10 Ke dɔ to le anyigba la dzi, eye Abram ɖo ta Egipte be yeaɖanɔ afi ma vie, elabena dɔwuame la nu sẽ le anyigba la dzi.
10 Now a famine arose in the land, and Abram went down toward Egypt to reside there for a while, because the famine in the land was severe.
11 Esi wòsusɔ vie wòaɖo Egipte la, egblɔ na srɔ̃a Sarai be: “Meɖe kuku ɖo tom!
11 As he was about to enter Egypt, he said to his wife Sarai: “Please listen!
Menyae nyuie be nyɔnu dzetugbee nènye.
I know what a beautiful woman you are.
12 Ne Egiptetɔwo kpɔ wò la, woagblɔ godoo be, ‘Srɔ̃ae nye esia.’
12 So when the Egyptians see you, they will surely say, ‘This is his wife.’
Eye woawum, ke woana wò ya nàtsi agbe.
Then they will kill me but keep you alive.
13 Meɖe kuku, gblɔ be nɔvinyee yenye, ne eme nanyo nam le tawò, ne matsi agbe.”
13 Please say you are my sister, so that it may go well with me because of you, and my life will be spared.”
14 Esi Abram nya ɖo afɔ Egipte ko la, Egiptetɔwo kpɔ be nyɔnua dze tugbe ale gbegbe.
14 As soon as Abram entered Egypt, the Egyptians noticed that the woman was very beautiful.
15 Eye Farao ƒe amegãwo hã kpɔe, eye wokafui na Farao, ale be wokplɔ nyɔnu la va Farao ƒe aƒe me.
15 And the princes of Pharaoh also saw her, and they began praising her to Pharaoh, so that the woman was taken to the house of Pharaoh.
16 Ewɔ nu ɖe Abram ŋu nyuie le nyɔnua ta, eye alẽwo, nyiwo, tedziwo, subɔviŋutsuwo, subɔvinyɔnuwo, tedzinɔwo kple kposɔwo va su esi.
16 He treated Abram well because of her, and he acquired sheep, cattle, male and female donkeys, male and female servants, and camels.
17 Ke Yehowa he fuwɔame sesẽwo va Farao kple eƒe aƒe la dzi le Abram srɔ̃ Sarai ta.
17 Then Jehovah struck Pharaoh and his household with severe plagues because of Sarai, Abram’s wife.
18 Ale Farao yɔ Abram vɛ hegblɔ nɛ be: “Nu kae nye esi nèwɔ ɖe ŋunye?
18 So Pharaoh called Abram and said: “What is this you have done to me?
Nu ka tae mègblɔ nam be ye srɔ̃e o? 19 Nu ka tae nègblɔ be, ‘Nɔvinyee,’ ale be meɖee kloe?
Why did you not tell me that she was your wife? 19 Why did you say, ‘She is my sister,’ so that I was about to take her as my wife?
Kpɔ ɖa, srɔ̃wò lae nye esi.
Here is your wife.
Kplɔe nàdzo!” 20 Eye Farao ɖe gbe na eƒe amewo be woana eya kple srɔ̃a nadzo kple woƒe nunɔamesiwo katã.
Take her and go!” 20 So Pharaoh gave his men orders concerning him, and they sent him away with his wife and all that he had.
Azɔ Yakob fɔ mo dzi, eye wòkpɔ Esau gbɔna, eye ŋutsu alafa ene le eŋu.
Now Jacob raised his eyes and saw Esau coming, and 400 men were with him.
Eya ta ema ɖeviawo na Lea kple Rahel kpakple subɔvinyɔnu eveawo.
So he divided the children among Leah, Rachel, and the two female servants.
2 Etsɔ subɔvinyɔnuawo kple wo viwo ɖo ŋgɔ, Lea kple viawo le wo yome, eye Rahel kple Yosef le wo megbe.
2 He put the female servants and their children in front, Leah and her children after them, and Rachel and Joseph behind them.
3 Eya ŋutɔ dze wo ŋgɔ, eye wòtsyɔ mo anyi zi adre va se ɖe esime wògogo nɔvia.
3 Then he himself went ahead of them and bowed down to the earth seven times as he came near to his brother.
4 Ke Esau ƒu du yi ɖakpee, ekpla asi kɔ nɛ hegbugbɔ nu nɛ, eye wowó avi.
4 But Esau ran to meet him, and he embraced him and kissed him, and they burst into tears.

5 Esi wòfɔ mo dzi kpɔ nyɔnuawo kple ɖeviawo la, ebiae be: “Ame kawoe nye esiawo le ŋuwò?” Eɖo eŋu be: “Vi siwo Mawu ve wò dɔla nu henae lae.” 6 Eye subɔvinyɔnuawo kple wo viwo te va hetsyɔ mo anyi, 7 eye Lea hã kple viawo te va hetsyɔ mo anyi.

5 When he raised his eyes and saw the women and the children, he said: “Who are these with you?” to which he said: “The children with whom God has favored your servant.” 6 At that the female servants came forward with their children and bowed down, 7 and Leah too came forward with her children, and they bowed down.
Eye Yosef kple Rahel te va, eye wotsyɔ mo anyi.
Then Joseph came forward with Rachel, and they bowed down.
8 Eye Esau biae be: “Mɔzɔlawo ƒe ha gã ka gbegbee nye esi va kpem?”
8 Esau said: “What is the purpose of all this camp of travelers that I have met?”
Eye wòɖo eŋu be: “Be nye aƒetɔ nave nunye tae.” 9 Eye Esau gblɔ be: “Nɔvinye, nu geɖe le asinye xoxo.
He replied: “In order to find favor in the eyes of my lord.” 9 Then Esau said: “I have a great many possessions, my brother.
Wò nuwo nenɔ anyi na wò ko.” 10 Ke Yakob gblɔ be: “Gbeɖe, meɖe kuku.
Keep what is yours.” 10 However, Jacob said: “No, please.
Ne ève nunye la, ekema xɔ nye nunana la, elabena ɖe metsɔe vɛ ne mate ŋu akpɔ wò mo.
If I have found favor in your eyes, you must take my gift from my hand, because I brought it so that I could see your face.
Eye mekpɔ wò mo abe Mawu ƒe moe mekpɔ ene, elabena èxɔm kple dzidzɔ.
And I have seen your face as though seeing God’s face, in that you received me with pleasure.
11 Meɖe kuku, xɔ nye yayranunana sia si wotsɔ vɛ na wò la dzro, elabena Mawu ve nunye, eye nu sia nu si hiãm la su asinye.”
11 Take, please, the gift conveying my blessing that was brought to you, for God has favored me and I have everything I need.”
Eyi edzi nɔ eƒom ɖe enu va se ɖe esime wòxɔe.
And he continued to urge him, so that he took it.
12 Emegbe Esau gblɔ be: “Na míaho adzo, eye madze ŋgɔ na wò.” 13 Ke egblɔ nɛ be: “Nye aƒetɔ nyae be ŋusẽ mele ɖeviawo ŋu o, eye ele be makpɔ alẽawo kple nyi siwo le no nam wo viwo la hã gbɔ.

12 Later Esau said: “Let us move out and go, and let me go in advance of you.” 13 But he said to him: “My lord is aware that the children are delicate and that in my care are sheep and cattle nursing their young.
Ne woakplɔ wo kple du ŋkeke ɖeka la, ekema lãha blibo la katã aku.
If they are driven too quickly for one day, then the whole flock will die.

14 Meɖe kuku, nye aƒetɔ nedze eƒe dɔla ŋgɔ, ke nye ŋutɔ mayi mɔzɔzɔa dzi ɖɔɖɔɖɔ le ale si nye lãha la kple ɖeviawo ate ŋui la nu, va se ɖe esime meɖo nye aƒetɔ gbɔ le Seir.” 15 Eye Esau gblɔ be: “Na magblẽ nye ameawo dometɔ aɖewo ɖe gbɔwò.”

14 Let my lord, please, go on ahead of his servant, but I will continue the journey more slowly at the pace of my livestock and of the children until I come to my lord at Seir.” 15 Then Esau said: “Please, let me leave some of my people with you.”
Eye Yakob gblɔ be: “Nu ka ŋuti nàwɔe alea?
To this he said: “Why do this?
Nye aƒetɔ neve nunye ko.” 16 Ale Esau gatrɔ yi Seir gbe ma gbe.
Just let me find favor in the eyes of my lord.” 16 So that day Esau went on his way back to Seir.
17 Eye Yakob dze mɔ va Sukot, eye wòtso aƒe na eɖokui hetu agbadɔwo na eƒe lãha la.
17 And Jacob journeyed to Succoth, and he built a house for himself and he made shelters for his herd.
Esia tae wòna ŋkɔ teƒea be Sukot.
That was why he named the place Succoth.
18 Esi Yakob ʋu tso Padan-Aram la, eva ɖo Sekem si le Kanaan-nyigba dzi dedie, eye wòtu agbadɔ ɖe dua xa.
18 After journeying from Paddanaram, Jacob arrived safely at the city of Shechem in the land of Canaan, and he set up his camp near the city.
19 Eye wòtsɔ klosalogaku alafa ɖeka ƒle anyigba si dzi wòtu eƒe agbadɔ ɖo la le Sekem fofo Hamor ƒe viwo si.
19 Then he acquired a portion of the field where he pitched his tent from the sons of Hamor, the father of Shechem, for 100 pieces of money.
20 Eɖi vɔsamlekpui ɖe afi ma, eye wòyɔe be Mawu, Israel ƒe Mawu.
20 There he set up an altar and called it God, the God of Israel.
Ke esi Isak tsi, eye eƒe ŋkuwo dzi tsyɔ, ale be megakpɔa nu o la, eyɔ viaŋutsu tsitsitɔ Esau be: “Vinye!”
Now when Isaac was old and his eyes were too weak to see, he called Esau his older son to him and said: “My son!”
Etɔ be: “Nyee nye esi!” 2 Eye wògblɔ nɛ be: “Fifia metsi.
He replied: “Here I am!” 2 And he went on to say: “I have now grown old.
Nyemenya gbe si gbe maku o.
I do not know the day of my death.
3 Eya ta meɖe kuku, tsɔ wò adedanuwo, wò daku kple wò dati, nàyi gbe me aɖawu lã vɛ nam.
3 So at this time take, please, your weapons, your quiver and your bow, and go out to the field and hunt some wild game for me.
4 Emegbe nàɖa nuɖuɖu si vivia nunye la nam maɖu, ne mayra wò hafi maku.”
4 Then make the kind of tasty dish that I am fond of and bring it to me.
5 Ke Rebeka see esime Isak ƒo nu kple via Esau.
5 However, Rebekah was listening while Isaac spoke to Esau his son.
Eye Esau dzo yi adegbe be yeaɖawu lã aɖe vɛ.
And Esau went out into the field to hunt game and to bring it in.

6 Eye Rebeka gblɔ na via Yakob be: “Kpɔ ɖa, fifi laa ko mesee fofowò gblɔ na nɔviwò Esau be, 7 ‘Di adelã vɛ nam, eye nàɖa nuɖuɖu si vivia nunye la nam maɖu, ne mayra wò le Yehowa ŋkume hafi maku.’ 8 Eya ta vinye, ɖo to nyuie nàwɔ nu si gblɔ ge mala na wò.

6 And Rebekah said to Jacob her son: “I just heard your father speaking to your brother Esau, saying, 7 ‘Bring me some game and make me a tasty dish. Then let me eat so that I may bless you before Jehovah before my death.’ 8 And now, my son, listen carefully and do what I am instructing you.
9 Yi lãhawo dome nàlé gbɔ̃vi nyuitɔ eve vɛ nam ne matsɔ aɖa nu vivi si tɔgbi dzɔa dzi na fofowò la nɛ.
9 Go, please, to the herd and get me two of the best young goats from there so that I may prepare from them a tasty dish for your father, just the way he likes it.
10 Emegbe nàtsɔe ayi na fofowò wòaɖu, ne wòayra wò hafi aku.”
10 Then take it to your father to eat, in order that he may bless you before his death.”
11 Yakob gblɔ na dadaa Rebeka be: “Fumee nɔvinye Esau nye, ke nye ya ŋutinye zrɔ̃.
11 Jacob said to his mother Rebekah: “But Esau my brother is a hairy man, and my skin is smooth.
12 Ne fofonye li asi ŋunye ɖe?
12 What if my father feels me?
Ekema abum be ɖe mele fewu ɖum le ye ŋu, eye esia ana mahe fiƒode ava ɖokuinye dzi, ke menye yayra o.” 13 Dadaa gblɔ nɛ be: “Vinye, fi si woaƒo ade wò la naɖi ŋunye.
Then I will certainly appear to be mocking him, and I will bring upon myself a curse rather than a blessing.” 13 At this his mother said to him: “Upon me be the curse meant for you, my son.
Wò ya wɔ nu si gblɔm mele na wò la ko, eye nàyi aɖalé gbɔ̃viawo vɛ nam.” 14 Ale wòyi ɖalé wo vɛ na dadaa, eye dadaa ɖa nuɖuɖu si vivia fofoa nu vevie.
Just do as I say and go, get them for me.” 14 So he went and got them and brought them to his mother, and his mother made a tasty dish, just the way his father liked it.
15 Emegbe Rebeka tsɔ via tsitsitɔ Esau ƒe awu nyuitɔ siwo le egbɔ le aƒea me la do na via ɖevitɔ Yakob.
15 After that Rebekah took her older son Esau’s finest garments, which she had in the house, and put them on her younger son Jacob.
16 Eye wòtsɔ gbɔ̃viawo ƒe agbalẽ bla ɖe eƒe asiwo kple eƒe kɔ ƒe akpa siwo fu mele o la ŋu.
16 She also put the skins of the young goats on his hands and on the hairless part of his neck.
17 Eye wòtsɔ nuɖuɖu vivi la kple abolo si ŋu wòtrɔ asi le la de via Yakob si.
17 Then she handed the tasty dish and the bread that she had made to her son Jacob.
18 Ale wòyi fofoa gbɔ gblɔ be: “Fofonye!” Etɔ be: “Nyee nye esi!
18 So he went in to his father and said: “My father!” to which he said: “Here I am!
Wò ame kae, vinye?” 19 Yakob gblɔ na fofoa be: “Nye Esau, wò ŋgɔgbevi lae.
Who are you, my son?” 19 Jacob said to his father: “I am Esau your firstborn.
Mewɔ abe ale si nègblɔ nam ene.
I have done just as you told me.
Meɖe kuku, fɔ ne nàɖu nye adelã la ƒe ɖe, ne nàyram.” 20 Eye Isak gblɔ na via be: “Vinye, aleke wɔ nèkpɔe kaba alea?”
Sit up, please, and eat some of my game, so that you may bless me.” 20 At that Isaac said to his son: “How were you so quick in finding it, my son?”

Eɖo eŋu be: “Elabena Yehowa wò Mawu lae kplɔe vɛ nam.” 21 Eye Isak gblɔ na Yakob be: “Meɖe kuku, vinye, te va ne mali asi ŋuwò kpɔ, ne manya ne vinye Esau nènye loo alo menye eyae o.” 22 Yakob te ɖe fofoa Isak ŋu, eye wòli asi eŋu hegblɔ be: “Gbe la nye Yakob ƒe gbe, ke asiawo nye Esau ƒe asiwo.” 23 Eye medze sii o, elabena fu le eƒe asiwo ŋu abe nɔvia Esau ƒe asiwo ene.

He replied: “Because Jehovah your God brought it to me.” 21 Then Isaac said to Jacob: “Come near, please, that I may feel you, my son, to know whether you are really my son Esau or not.” 22 So Jacob came near to his father Isaac, and he felt him, after which he said: “The voice is the voice of Jacob, but the hands are the hands of Esau.” 23 He did not recognize him because his hands were hairy like the hands of his brother Esau.
Eye wòyrae.
So he blessed him.
24 Emegbe ebiae be: “Wòe nye vinye Esau nyateƒea?” Eɖo eŋu be: “Ɛ̃, nyee.” 25 Eye wògblɔ be: “Vinye, tsɔ adelã la vɛ nam maɖu ne mayra wò.”
24 After that he asked: “Are you really my son Esau?” to which he replied: “I am.” 25 Then he said: “Bring me some of the wild game for me to eat, my son, then I will bless you.”
Eye wòtsɔe te ɖe eŋu wòɖu, eye wòtsɔ wain vɛ nɛ wòno.
With that he brought it to him and he ate, and he brought him wine and he drank.
26 Emegbe fofoa Isak gblɔ nɛ be: “Vinye, meɖe kuku te ɖe ŋunye, ne nàgbugbɔ nu nam.” 27 Eye wòte va hegbugbɔ nu nɛ, eye wòse eƒe awuawo ƒe ʋeʋẽ.
26 Then Isaac his father said to him: “Come near, please, and kiss me, my son.” 27 So he came near and kissed him, and he could smell the scent of his garments.
Eye wòyrae gblɔ be:
Then he blessed him and said:
“Kpɔ ɖa, vinye ƒe ʋeʋẽ le abe gbe si Yehowa yra ƒe ʋeʋẽ ene.
“See, the scent of my son is like the scent of the field that Jehovah has blessed.
28 Mawu vavã la nena dziƒozãmu kple anyigba wɔnuwo kpakple agblemenuku kple wain yeye geɖe wò.
28 May the true God give you the dews of the heavens and the fertile soils of the earth and an abundance of grain and new wine.
29 Amehawo nasubɔ wò, eye dukɔwo nabɔbɔ na wò.
29 Let peoples serve you, and let nations bow low to you.
Àɖu aƒetɔ ɖe nɔviwòwo dzi, eye dawò ƒe viwo abɔbɔ na wò.
Be master over your brothers, and let the sons of your mother bow low to you.
Woaƒo fi ade ame sia ame si aƒo fi ade wò, eye woayra ame sia ame si ayra wò.”
Cursed be everyone who curses you, and blessed be everyone who blesses you.”
30 Ke esi Isak yra Yakob vɔ eye Yakob dzo le fofoa Isak ŋkume teti ko la, nɔvia Esau gbɔ tso adegbea.
30 Now Isaac had just finished blessing Jacob, and Jacob had barely left the presence of his father Isaac when his brother Esau came back from his hunting.

31 Eya hã ɖa nu vivi aɖe eye wòtsɔe vɛ na fofoa eye wògblɔ nɛ be: “Fofonye, meɖe kuku fɔ nàɖu viwò ƒe adelã la ƒe ɖe, ne nàyram.” 32 Eye fofoa Isak biae be: “Wò ame kae?” Eye wògblɔ be: “Nye, viwò, wò ŋgɔgbevi Esau ye.” 33 Ale Isak de asi ƒoƒo me kpakpakpa hegblɔ be: “Ekema ame kae da ade wu lã vɛ nam?

31 He too prepared a tasty dish and brought it to his father, and he said to his father: “Let my father get up and eat some of his son’s game, in order that you may bless me.” 32 At this his father Isaac said to him: “Who are you?” to which he said: “I am your son, your firstborn, Esau.” 33 And Isaac began to tremble violently, so he said: “Who was it, then, who hunted for game and brought it to me?
Meɖui vɔ hafi nèva, eye meyrae, ɛ̃, eya tɔe yayra la anye godoo!”
I already ate it before you arrived, and I blessed him—and he will surely be blessed!”

34 Esi Esau se fofoa ƒe nyawo la, edo ɣli sesĩe kple vevesese gblɔ na fofoa be: “Fofonye, yram, yra nye hã!” 35 Ke egblɔ be: “Nɔviwò va flum eye wòxɔ wò yayra la xoxo.” 36 Eye wògblɔ be: “Ðe eƒe ŋkɔ Yakob meɖi eŋu si na wòtrɔm to eme zi eve sɔŋ oa?

34 On hearing his father’s words, Esau began to cry out in an extremely loud and bitter manner and to say to his father: “Bless me, yes, me too, my father!” 35 But he said: “Your brother came deceitfully so that he might get the blessing meant for you.” 36 At this he said: “Is he not rightly named Jacob, that he might supplant me these two times?
Exɔ nye ŋgɔgbevinyenye xoxo, eye wògaxɔ nye yayra fifia hã!”
My birthright he has already taken, and now he has taken my blessing!”

Eye wòbiae be: “Mèsusɔ yayra aɖeke ɖi nam oa?” 37 Ke Isak ɖo eŋu na Esau be: “Kpɔ ɖa, meɖoe aƒetɔ ɖe dziwò, metsɔ nɔviawo katã wɔ eƒe subɔlawoe, eye metsɔ agblemenuku kple wain yeye yrae be wòanɔ agbe ɖe enu.

Then he added: “Have you not reserved a blessing for me?” 37 But Isaac answered Esau: “Here I have appointed him master over you, and I have given him all his brothers as servants, and I have bestowed grain and new wine for his support.
Azɔ nu kae gali mawɔ na wò, vinye?”
What is left that I can do for you, my son?”
38 Esau gblɔ na fofoa be: “Fofonye, yayra ɖeka pɛ koe le asiwòa?
38 Esau said to his father: “Is there just one blessing that you have, my father?
Fofonye, yram, ɛ̃ yra nye hã!”
Bless me, yes, me too, my father!”
Ale Esau do ɣli hegba avi doo.
With that Esau cried loudly and burst into tears.
39 Eye fofoa Isak gblɔ nɛ be:
39 So his father Isaac answered him:
“Kpɔ ɖa, nɔwòƒe adidi tso anyigba wɔnuwo gbɔ, tso dziƒozãmu gbɔ.
“See, away from the fertile soils of the earth your dwelling will be, and away from the dew of the heavens above.
40 Wò yi nue nànɔ agbe ɖo, eye àsubɔ nɔviwò.
40 And by your sword you will live, and you will serve your brother.
Ke ne ède vovo ge do kpoe la, àŋe eƒe kɔkuti la ɖa le wò kɔ.”
But when you grow restless, you will indeed break his yoke off your neck.”
41 Esau lé Yakob ɖe dɔme le esi fofoa yrae ta, eye Esau nɔ gbɔgblɔm le eƒe dzi me be: “Ŋkeke siwo míafa fofonye la le gogom.
41 However, Esau harbored animosity against Jacob because of the blessing his father had given him, and Esau kept saying in his heart: “The days of mourning for my father are getting closer.

Le esia megbe la, mele nɔvinye Yakob wu ge.” 42 Esi Rebeka va se via tsitsitɔ Esau ƒe nyawo la, enumake edɔ woyi ɖayɔ via ɖevitɔ Yakob vɛ, eye wògblɔ nɛ be: “Kpɔ ɖa, nɔviwò Esau ɖoe be yeabia hlɔ̃ awu wò.

After that I am going to kill Jacob my brother.” 42 When the words of her older son Esau were told to Rebekah, she at once sent for her younger son Jacob and said to him: “Look! Your brother Esau is planning to take revenge by killing you.
43 Eya ta vinye, ɖo to nye gbe.
43 Now, my son, do as I say.
Tso nàsi ayi nɔvinye Laban gbɔ le Haran.
Get up and run away to my brother Laban at Haran.
44 Nɔ egbɔ ŋkeke aɖewo, va se ɖe esime nɔviwò ƒe dɔmedzoe la nu nafa, 45 va se ɖe esime dzi si le nɔviwò kum ɖe ŋuwò la nu nafa, eye wòaŋlɔ nu si nèwɔ ɖe eŋu la be.
44 Dwell with him for a while until your brother’s rage calms down, 45 until your brother’s anger toward you subsides and he forgets what you have done to him.
Ekema madɔ ame woakplɔ wò tso afi ma agbɔe.
Then I will send for you from there.
Nu ka tae mi ame evea siaa miabú ɖem gbe ɖeka?”
Why should I lose both of you in one day?”
46 Esia megbe la, Rebeka gblɔna na Isak be: “Nye agbe va le ŋu nyɔm nam le Het vinyɔnuawo ta.
46 After that Rebekah kept saying to Isaac: “I am disgusted with my life because of the daughters of Heth.
Ne Yakob hã aɖe Het vinyɔnu aɖe le anyigba sia dzi abe nyɔnu siawo ke ene ɖe, ekema nu ka ŋuti megale agbe ɖo?”
If Jacob ever takes a wife from the daughters of Heth, like these daughters of the land, what good is my life?”
Mawudɔla eveawo va ɖo Sodom le fiẽ me, eye Lot bɔbɔ nɔ Sodom dua ƒe agbo nu.
The two angels arrived at Sodom by evening, and Lot was sitting in the gate of Sodom.
Esi Lot kpɔ wo la, etso be yeaɖakpe wo, eye wòbɔbɔ tsyɔ mo anyi.
When Lot saw them, he got up to meet them and bowed down with his face to the earth.
2 Eye wògblɔ be: “Meɖe kuku, nye aƒetɔwo, miva dze miaƒe subɔla ƒe aƒe me ne miatsi adɔ, eye woaklɔ afɔ na mi.
2 And he said: “Please, my lords, turn aside, please, into the house of your servant and stay overnight and have your feet washed.
Ne miafɔ ŋdi kanya ayi miaƒe mɔzɔzɔa dzi.”
Then you may get up early and travel on your way.”
Ke woɖo eŋu be: “Ao, míatsi ablɔ dzi boŋ adɔ.” 3 Ke eƒoe ɖe wo nu vevie va se ɖe esime woyi eƒe aƒe me.
To this they said: “No, we will stay overnight in the public square.” 3 But he was so insistent with them that they went with him to his house.
Eye wòtsɔ amɔwɔ maʋamaʋã mè abolo tsɔ ɖo kplɔ̃ na wo, eye woɖu nu.
Then he made a feast for them, and he baked unleavened bread, and they ate.
4 Ke womekpɔ mlɔ anyi hafi dua me ŋutsuwo, Sodom ŋutsuwo katã, lɔ hoo va ƒo xlã aƒea, tso ŋutsuviwo dzi va se ɖe amegãɖeɖiwo dzi o.
4 Before they could lie down to sleep, the men of the city—the men of Sodom from boy to old man, all of them—surrounded the house in one mob.
5 Eye wonɔ Lot yɔm kple ɣli nɔ gbɔgblɔm be: “Afi kae ŋutsu siwo va gbɔwò zã sia la le?
5 And they kept calling out to Lot and saying to him: “Where are the men who came in to you tonight?
Kplɔ wo do goe na mí, ne míadɔ kpli wo.”
Bring them out to us so that we may have sex with them.”
6 Mlɔeba Lot do go yi wo gbɔ le mɔa nu, eye wòdo ʋɔa.
6 Then Lot went out to them to the doorway, and he shut the door behind him.
7 Eye wògblɔ na wo be: “Meɖe kuku na mi, nɔvinyewo, migawɔ nu vɔ̃ɖi sia o.
7 He said: “Please, my brothers, do not act wickedly.
8 Meɖe kuku, mikpɔ ɖa, vinyɔnu eve le asinye, siwo medɔ kple ŋutsu kpɔ o.
8 Please, here I have two daughters who have never had sexual relations with a man.
Meɖe kuku, makplɔ wo vɛ na mi ne miawɔ nu si dze mia ŋu la ɖe wo ŋu.
Please, let me bring them out to you for you to do to them whatever seems good to you.
Ðeko migawɔ naneke ŋutsu siawo ya o, elabena esia tae mena wova dze aƒenyeme ɖo.” 9 Ke wogblɔ nɛ be: “Te ɖa le afi sia!”
But do not do anything to these men, for they have come under the shelter of my roof.” 9 At this they said: “Stand back!”
Eye wogagblɔ be: “Wò amedzro ɖeka hɔ̃ sia si va tsi afi sia, mɔ ka nèkpɔ adrɔ̃ ʋɔnu mí!
And they added: “This lone foreigner came to live here, and yet he dares to judge us!
Azɔ míatu nu kpli wò wu woawo.”
Now we are going to do worse to you than to them.”
Eye wolũ ɖe Lot dzi bibibi be yewoagbã ʋɔa.
And they crowded in on Lot and moved forward to break down the door.
10 Eya ta ŋutsuawo do asi ɖa he Lot va wo ɖokui gbɔ le aƒea me, eye wodo ʋɔa.
10 So the men reached out their hands and brought Lot into the house with them, and they shut the door.
11 Ke wona ŋutsu siwo le ʋɔtrua nu la ƒe ŋkuwo tsi, tso ɖeviwo dzi va se ɖe tsitsiawo dzi, ale be wodi mɔa nu ʋuu keke ɖeɖi koe te wo ŋu.
11 But they struck the men who were at the entrance of the house with blindness, from the least to the greatest, so that they wore themselves out trying to find the doorway.
12 Eye ŋutsuawo gblɔ na Lot be: “Ame aɖe gale asiwò le afi sia?
12 Then the men said to Lot: “Do you have anyone else here?

Kplɔ towòyɔviwo, viwòŋutsuwo, viwònyɔnuwo kple ame siwo katã nye tɔwò le dua me la doe le teƒe sia! 13 Míele teƒe sia tsrɔ̃ ge, elabena konyifaɣli si le ɖiɖim ɖe wo ta la nu sẽ le Yehowa ŋkume, eya ta Yehowa dɔ mí be míava tsrɔ̃ dua.” 14 Ale Lot do go yi, eye wòƒo nu na toyɔviawo, ame siwo gbɔna vianyɔnuawo ɖe ge la, nɔ gbɔgblɔm be: “Mitso!

Sons-in-law, your sons, your daughters, and all your people in the city, bring out of this place! 13 For we are going to destroy this place, because the outcry against them has indeed grown great before Jehovah, so that Jehovah sent us to destroy the city.” 14 So Lot went out and began to speak to his sons-in-law who were to marry his daughters, and he kept saying: “Get up!
Mido go le teƒe sia, elabena Yehowa le dua tsrɔ̃ ge!”
Get out of this place, because Jehovah will destroy the city!”
Ke ɖeko toyɔviawo bui fefenyae.
But to his sons-in-law, he seemed to be joking.
15 Esi agu le dzedzem la, mawudɔlaawo ƒoe ɖe Lot nu vevie be: “Tso!
15 As dawn was breaking, the angels became urgent with Lot, saying: “Get up!

Kplɔ srɔ̃wò kple viwònyɔnu eve siwo le afi sia kpli wò, ne woagatsrɔ̃ mi le dua ƒe vodada ta o!” 16 Esi wòle hehem ɖe megbe la, Yehowa ve enu ale be ŋutsuawo lé eya kple srɔ̃a kpakple vianyɔnu eveawo ƒe alɔnu hekplɔ wo yi dua godo.

Take your wife and your two daughters who are here with you, so that you will not be swept away in the error of the city!” 16 When he kept lingering, then because of Jehovah’s compassion for him, the men seized hold of his hand and the hand of his wife and the hands of his two daughters, and they brought him out and stationed him outside the city.
17 Esi wokplɔ wo do goe teti la, wo dometɔ ɖeka gblɔ be: “Wò afɔ netsɔ nàɖe wò agbe!
17 As soon as they had brought them to the outskirts, he said: “Escape for your life!
Mègakpɔ megbe o, eye mègatɔ ɖe afi aɖeke le nuto bliboa katã me o!
Do not look behind you and do not stand still in any part of the district!
Si yi tonuto la me, ne woagatsrɔ̃ wò o!”
Escape to the mountainous region so that you may not be swept away!”

18 Lot gblɔ na wo be: “Yehowa, meɖe kuku, meganye afi ma o! 19 Meɖe kuku, ève wò subɔla nu, eye ènyo dɔme nam geɖe be nèxɔm ɖe agbe. Gake nyemate ŋu asi ayi tonuto la me o, elabena mele vɔvɔ̃m be vɔ̃ ava tum eye maku.

18 Then Lot said to them: “Not there, please, Jehovah! 19 Please, now, your servant has found favor in your eyes and you are showing great kindness to me by preserving me alive, but I am not able to flee to the mountainous region because I am afraid that disaster may overtake me and I will die.
20 Meɖe kuku, du sia tsɔ ɖe gbɔnye, na masi ayi afi ma; eye du sue aɖe ko wònye.
20 Please, now, this town is nearby and I can flee there; it is only a small place.
Meɖe kuku, àɖe mɔ nam be masi ayi afi ma?
May I, please, escape there?
Du sue aɖe ko wònye.
It is only a small place.
Ne matsi agbe.” 21 Eye wògblɔ nɛ be: “Enyo! Maɖo to wò le esia hã me, be nyematsrɔ̃ du si ŋu nèƒo nu le la o.
Then I will survive.” 21 So he said to him: “Very well, I will also show you consideration by not overthrowing the town you speak of.
22 Wɔ kaba!
22 Hurry!
Si yi afi ma, elabena nyemawɔ naneke o va se ɖe esime nèɖo afi ma hafi!”
Escape there, because I cannot do anything until you arrive there!”
Esia tae wòtsɔ ŋkɔ na dua be Zoar.
That is why he named the town Zoar.
23 Ɣe dze esime Lot ɖo Zoar.
23 The sun had risen over the land when Lot arrived at Zoar.
24 Azɔ Yehowa na dzokpe kple dzo dza tso dziƒo, tso Yehowa gbɔ, ɖe Sodom kple Gomora dzi.
24 Then Jehovah made it rain sulfur and fire on Sodom and Gomorrah—it came from Jehovah, from the heavens.
25 Ale wòtsrɔ̃ du siawo, ɛ̃, nuto blibo la, kple ame siwo katã le duawo me kpakple nu miemie siwo katã le anyigba la dzi.
25 So he overthrew these cities, yes, the entire district, including all the inhabitants of the cities and the plants of the ground.
26 Ke srɔ̃a si nɔ eyome la, nyè kɔ kpɔ megbe, eye wòtrɔ zu dzekɔ.
26 But Lot’s wife, who was behind him, began to look back, and she became a pillar of salt.
27 Abraham fɔ ŋdi kanya yi teƒe si wòtsi tre ɖe Yehowa ŋkume le tsã la.
27 Now Abraham got up early in the morning and went to the place where he had stood before Jehovah.
28 Eye wòkpɔ Sodom kple Gomora kpakple nuto blibo la godoo le abu me ɖaa, eye wòkpɔ be nane le dzɔdzɔm.
28 When he looked down toward Sodom and Gomorrah and all the land of the district, he saw quite a sight.

Kpɔ ɖa, dzudzɔ babla kɔtɔɔ le dzi dem tso anyigba la dzi abe kpodzo me dzudzɔ babla ene! 29 Esi Mawu tsrɔ̃ du siwo le nutoa me la, Mawu ɖo ŋku Abraham dzi, eye wòɖe Lot do goe le du si me wònɔ la me esi wòtrɔ dua bu anyi.

There was dense smoke rising from the land like the dense smoke of a kiln! 29 So when God destroyed the cities of the district, God kept Abraham in mind by sending Lot out from the cities he overthrew, the cities where Lot had been dwelling.
30 Emegbe Lot ʋu le Zoar, eye eya kple vianyɔnu eveawo yi ɖanɔ tonuto la me, elabena ele Zoar nɔnɔ vɔ̃m.
30 Later Lot went up from Zoar with his two daughters and began living in the mountainous region, because he was afraid to live in Zoar.
Eya ta eya kple vianyɔnu eveawo yi ɖanɔ agado aɖe me.
So he began living in a cave with his two daughters.
31 Eye via tsitsitɔ gblɔ na ɖevitɔ be: “Mía fofo tsi, eye ŋutsu aɖeke mele anyigba sia dzi aɖe mí abe ale si wòle kɔnua nu le anyigba bliboa katã dzi ene o.
31 And the firstborn said to the younger: “Our father is old, and there is not a man in the land to have relations with us according to the custom of the whole earth.
32 Va míana wain mía fofo wòano, eye míamlɔ egbɔ, ne míana dzidzimeviwo nanɔ mía fofo si.”
32 Come, let us give our father wine to drink, and let us lie down with him and preserve offspring from our father.”
33 Ale wona wain geɖe wo fofo wòno zã ma; eye tsitsitɔa yi ɖamlɔ fofoa gbɔ, ke fofoa menya ɣeyiɣi si me wòva mlɔ egbɔ kple ɣeyiɣi si me wòfɔ dzo o.
33 So that night they kept giving their father wine to drink; then the firstborn went in and lay down with her father, but he did not know when she lay down and when she got up.
34 Esi ŋu ke la, tsitsitɔ gblɔ na ɖevitɔ la be: “Kpɔ ɖa, memlɔ fofonye gbɔ le zã si va yi me.
34 Then on the next day, the firstborn said to the younger: “Here I lay down with my father last night.
Na míagana wain mía fofo wòano zã sia hã.
Let us give him wine to drink tonight also.

Ekema wò hã nàyi aɖamlɔ egbɔ, ne míana dzidzimeviwo nanɔ mía fofo si.” 35 Ale wona wain geɖe wo fofo wòno le zã ma hã me; eye ɖevitɔ la yi ɖamlɔ egbɔ, ke menya ɣeyiɣi si me wòva mlɔ egbɔ kple ɣeyiɣi si me wòfɔ dzo o.

Then you go in and lie down with him, and let us preserve offspring from our father.” 35 So that night also, they repeatedly gave their father wine to drink; then the younger went and lay down with him, but he did not know when she lay down and when she got up.
36 Ale Lot vinyɔnu eveawo siaa fɔ fu na wo fofo.
36 So both daughters of Lot became pregnant by their father.
37 Emegbe tsitsitɔa dzi ŋutsuvi, eye wòtsɔ ŋkɔ nɛ be Moab.
37 The firstborn gave birth to a son and named him Moab.
Eyae nye Moabtɔwo fofo va se ɖe egbe sia.
He is the father of the Moabites of today.
38 Ke ɖevitɔ hã dzi ŋutsuvi, eye wòtsɔ ŋkɔ nɛ be Ben-Ami.
38 The younger also gave birth to a son, and she named him Ben-ammi.
Eyae nye Amonitɔwo fofo va se ɖe egbe sia.
He is the father of the Ammonites of today.
Ke Dina, Yakob vinyɔnu si Lea dzi nɛ la dona yia dua me ɖetugbuiwo gbɔ.
Now Dinah, Jacob’s daughter by Leah, used to go out to spend time with the young women of the land.
2 Esi Hivitɔ Hamor, si nye amegãwo dometɔ ɖeka le anyigba ma dzi ƒe vi Sekem kpɔe la, elée dɔ egbɔ hegblẽe.
2 When Shechem, the son of Hamor the Hivite, a chieftain of the land, saw her, he took her and lay down with her and violated her.
3 Eye Yakob vinyɔnu Dina ƒe nu lé dzi nɛ vevie, eye wòlɔ̃ ɖetugbui la, eye wònɔa enu blem.
3 And he became very attached to Dinah, the daughter of Jacob, and he fell in love with the young woman and spoke persuasively to her.
4 Mlɔeba Sekem gblɔ na fofoa Hamor be: “Ðe ɖetugbui sia nam.”
4 Finally Shechem said to Hamor his father: “Get me this young woman to be my wife.”
5 Esime Yakob se be egblẽ ye vinyɔnu Dina la, viaŋutsuawo ya nɔ eƒe lãha la gbɔ le gbedzi.
5 When Jacob heard that he had defiled Dinah his daughter, his sons were with his herd in the field.
Gake Yakob mekɔ nu le nya la dzi o va se ɖe esime wogbɔ.
So Jacob kept silent until they returned.
6 Emegbe Hamor, Sekem fofo, yi Yakob gbɔ be yeaƒo nu kplii.
6 Later Hamor, Shechem’s father, went out to speak with Jacob.
7 Gake Yakob viŋutsuawo see, eye wogbɔ tso gbea dzi enumake.
7 But the sons of Jacob heard about it and returned from the field right away.
Nya la ve wo ŋutɔ, eye dzi ku wo vevie, elabena ewɔ ŋukpenanu ɖe Israel ŋu esi wòdɔ kple Yakob vinyɔnu, evɔ mele be woawɔ nu sia tɔgbi kura o hafi.
They were offended and very angry because he had disgraced Israel by lying down with Jacob’s daughter, something that should not be done.
8 Eye Hamor gblɔ na wo be: “Mia vinyɔnu la ƒe nu lé dzi na vinye Sekem.
8 Hamor spoke with them, saying: “My son Shechem longs for your daughter.
Meɖe kuku, mitsɔe nɛ wòaɖe, 9 eye mina srɔ̃ɖekadodo nanɔ mía kpli mi dome.
Please give her to him as his wife, 9 and form marriage alliances with us.
Mitsɔ mia vinyɔnuwo na mí, eye míawo hã míatsɔ mía vinyɔnuwo ana mi.
Give us your daughters, and take our daughters for yourselves.
10 Miate ŋu anɔ mía gbɔ, eye anyigba la li faa na mi.
10 You may dwell with us, and the land will become available for you.
Minɔ edzi, mitsa asi le edzi, eye miatsi edzi.” 11 Sekem gblɔ na Dina fofo kple nɔviaŋutsuawo be: “Mive nunye, eye nu sia nu si miabia tso asinye la, manae.
Dwell and carry on trade in it and settle in it.” 11 Then Shechem said to her father and to her brothers: “Let me find favor in your eyes, and I will give you whatever you ask me.
12 Miate ŋu abia tabianu kple nunana gbogbo aɖewo tso asinye faa.
12 You can demand from me a very high bride price and gift.
Melɔ̃ be mana nu sia nu si miabia tso asinye.
I am willing to give whatever you may say to me.
Mitsɔ ɖetugbui la nam maɖe ko.”
Just give me the young woman as a wife.”
13 Eye Yakob viŋutsuawo ɖo eŋu na Sekem kple fofoa Hamor ayetɔe, elabena egblẽ wo nɔvinyɔnu Dina.
13 And Jacob’s sons answered Shechem and Hamor his father deceitfully because he had defiled Dinah their sister.
14 Eye wogblɔ na wo be: “Míate ŋu awɔ nu sia tɔgbi, be míatsɔ mía nɔvinyɔnu ana ŋutsu aʋamatsomatsotɔ o, elabena ema nye ŋukpe na mí.
14 They said to them: “We cannot possibly do such a thing, to give our sister to a man who is not circumcised, for that is a disgrace to us.
15 Ne miewɔ nu sia ko hafi míalɔ̃ ɖe edzi na mi; eyae nye be miatso aʋa na miaƒe ŋutsuwo katã anɔ abe míawo ke ene.
15 We can only consent on this condition: that you become like us and circumcise all your males.
16 Ekema míatsɔ mía vinyɔnuwo ana mi, eye míaɖe mia vinyɔnuwo, míanɔ mia gbɔ, eye míazu dukɔ ɖeka.
16 Then we will give our daughters to you, and we will take your daughters for ourselves, and we will dwell with you and become one people.
17 Ke ne mieɖo to mí hetso aʋa o la, ekema míakplɔ mía vinyɔnu la adzoe.”
17 But if you do not listen to us and get circumcised, then we will take our daughter and go.”
18 Eye woƒe nyawo dze Hamor kple viaŋutsu Sekem ŋu.
18 Their words pleased Hamor and Shechem, Hamor’s son.
19 Ðekakpui la mehe ɖe megbe le nu si wobia la wɔwɔ me o, elabena Yakob vinyɔnu la ƒe nu nyo eŋu ŋutɔ, eye eyae nye ɖekakpui si ŋu bubu le wu le fofoa ƒe aƒe blibo la katã me.
19 The young man did not delay in doing what they asked, because he found delight in Jacob’s daughter, and he was the most honorable of the whole house of his father.
20 Eya ta Hamor kple via Sekem yi woƒe du la ƒe agbo nu hegblɔ na dua me ŋutsuwo be: 21 “Ŋutsu siawo di be yewoanɔ ŋutifafa me kpli mí.
20 So Hamor and his son Shechem went to the city gate and spoke to the men of their city, saying: 21 “These men wish to be at peace with us.
Eya ta mina woanɔ anyigba la dzi, ne woatsa asi le edzi, elabena anyigba la lolo woawo hã woate ŋu anɔ edzi.
Let them dwell in the land and carry on trade in it, for the land is large enough to accommodate them.
Míate ŋu aɖe wo vinyɔnuwo, eye míate ŋu atsɔ mía vinyɔnuwo ana wo woaɖe.
We can take their daughters as wives, and our daughters we can give to them.
22 Ne míewɔ nu ɖeka sia ko hafi ŋutsuawo alɔ̃ anɔ mía gbɔ, ne míazu dukɔ ɖeka: eyae nye be míaƒe ŋutsuwo katã natso aʋa abe ale si ko woawo hã wotso aʋae ene.
22 Only on this one condition will the men consent to dwell with us in order to become one people: that every male among us be circumcised just the way they are circumcised.
23 Ekema ɖe woƒe nunɔamesiwo kple woƒe kesinɔnuwo kple woƒe lãhawo katã mazu mía tɔ oa?
23 Then, will not their possessions, their wealth, and all their livestock be ours?

Eya ta mina míalɔ̃ ɖe edzi na wo, ne woanɔ mía gbɔ.” 24 Ale ame siwo katã va ƒo ƒu ɖe dua ƒe agbo nu la ɖo to Hamor kple via Sekem, eye wotso aʋa na ŋutsuawo katã, wo ame siwo katã va ƒo ƒu ɖe dua ƒe agbo nu.

So let us give them our consent that they may dwell with us.” 24 All those going out by the gate of his city listened to Hamor and to his son Shechem, and all the males got circumcised, all those going out of the city gate.

25 Ke le ŋkeke etɔ̃a gbe, esime abia le wo vem vevie la, Yakob viŋutsu eve, Simeon kple Lewi, siwo nye Dina nɔviwo tsɔ woƒe yiwo, eye woge ɖe du, sia si me tɔwo menya be woɖo vɔ̃ ɖe yewo ŋu o la me, eye wowu ŋutsuwo katã.
25 However, on the third day, when they were still in pain, two sons of Jacob, Simeon and Levi, Dinah’s brothers, each took his sword and went into the unsuspecting city and killed every male.
26 Wowu Hamor kple via Sekem kple yi, eye wokplɔ Dina tso Sekem ƒe aƒe me dzoe.
26 They killed Hamor and his son Shechem with the sword and then took Dinah from Shechem’s house and left.
27 Yakob viŋutsu bubuawo va ɖe nu le ame kukuawo ŋu, eye woha dua, elabena wogblẽ wo nɔvinyɔnu.
27 Jacob’s other sons came upon the slain men and plundered the city because they had defiled their sister.
28 Woha woƒe alẽwo, nyiwo, tedziwo kple nu siwo katã le dua me kple gbedzi.
28 They took their flocks, their herds, their donkeys, and whatever was in the city and in the field.
29 Wolɔ woƒe nuwo katã, eye woɖe aboyo wo viwo kple wo srɔ̃wo, eye woha nu siwo katã le aƒewo me.
29 They also took all their possessions, captured all their little children and their wives, and plundered everything in the houses.
30 Eye Yakob gblɔ na Simeon kple Lewi be: “Miehe vɔ̃ gã aɖe va dzinye, elabena miena mele ʋeʋẽm ɖe anyigba la dzi nɔla siwo nye Kanaantɔwo kple Perizitɔwo.
30 At this Jacob said to Simeon and to Levi: “You have brought great trouble on me in making me a stench to the inhabitants of the land, to the Canaanites and the Perizzites.
Evɔ nyemede ha o; eye woawɔ ɖeka ava dze dzinye ahatsrɔ̃ nye kple nye aƒe ɖa gbidii.” 31 Gake woɖo eŋu be: “Ðe ame aɖe kpɔ mɔ awɔ nu ɖe mía nɔvinyɔnu ŋu abe gboloe wònye enea?”
I am few in number, and they will certainly gather together to attack me and I will be annihilated, I and my house.” 31 But they said: “Should anyone treat our sister like a prostitute?”
Esi Yakob se be nuɖuɖu le Egipte la, egblɔ na viawo be: “Nu ka tae mienɔ anyi ɖi le mia nɔewo kpɔm?” 2 Egblɔ kpee be: “Kpɔ ɖa, mese be nuɖuɖu le Egipte.
When Jacob learned that there was grain in Egypt, he said to his sons: “Why do you just keep looking at one another?” 2 He added: “I have heard that there is grain in Egypt.
Miyi afi ma miaƒle ɖe vɛ na mí, ne míatsi agbe, ale be míagaku o.” 3 Eya ta Yosef nɔviŋutsu ewo dze mɔ be yewoayi aɖaƒle nuɖuɖu le Egipte.
Go down there and buy some for us, so that we may stay alive and not die.” 3 So ten of Joseph’s brothers went down to buy grain from Egypt.
4 Ke Yakob mena Yosef nɔvi Benyamin yi kple nɔviawo o, elabena egblɔ be: “Ðewohĩ nu vevi aɖe ava wɔe wòaku.”
4 But Jacob did not send Benjamin, Joseph’s brother, with his other brothers, for he said: “Perhaps a fatal accident may befall him.”
5 Eye Israel viŋutsuwo zɔ kple ame bubu siwo yina nu ƒle ge la, elabena dɔtoto la va ɖo keke Kanaan-nyigba dzi ke.
5 So Israel’s sons came along with the others who were coming to buy, because the famine had extended to the land of Canaan.
6 Yosef ye nye anyigba la dzi ɖula, eye eyae dzraa nuɖuɖu na anyigbadzitɔwo katã.
6 Joseph was the man in authority over the land, and he was the one who sold grain to all the people of the earth.
Eya ta Yosef nɔviŋutsuwo va, eye wobɔbɔ hetsyɔ mo anyi ɖe eŋkume.
So Joseph’s brothers came and bowed low to him with their faces to the ground.
7 Esi Yosef kpɔ nɔviawo la, ekpɔ wo dze sii enumake, ke eya mena wokpɔe dze sii o.
7 When Joseph saw his brothers, he immediately recognized them, but he concealed his identity from them.
Eye wòbia wo adãtɔe be: “Afi kae mietso?” Eye woɖo eŋu be: “Kanaan-nyigba dzie míetso va be míaƒle nuɖuɖu.”
So he spoke harshly with them and said: “Where have you come from?” to which they said: “From the land of Canaan to buy food.”
8 Ale Yosef kpɔ nɔviawo dze sii, ke woawo ya womekpɔe dze sii o.
8 Thus Joseph recognized his brothers, but they did not recognize him.
9 Enumake Yosef ɖo ŋku drɔ̃e siwo wòku tso wo ŋu la dzi, eye wògblɔ na wo be: “Ŋkutsalawoe mienye!
9 Joseph immediately remembered the dreams that he had dreamed about them, and he said to them: “You are spies!
Ðe mieva mɔnu di ge le anyigba la ŋu!” 10 Wogblɔ nɛ be: “Ao, nye aƒetɔ, ke boŋ nuɖuɖu ƒle gee wò dɔlawo va.
You have come to see the vulnerable areas of the land!” 10 Then they said to him: “No, my lord, but your servants have come to buy food.
11 Ŋutsu ɖeka ƒe viwoe mí katã míenye.
11 We are all sons of but one man.
Nuteƒewɔlawoe míenye.
We are upright men.
Menye ŋkutsalawoe wò dɔlawo nye o.” 12 Ke egblɔ na wo be: “Kpao!
Your servants do not act as spies.” 12 But he said to them: “Not so!
Mɔnu di gee mieva le anyigba la ŋu!” 13 Woɖo eŋu be: “Nɔvi wuievee wò dɔlawo nye.
You have come to see the vulnerable areas of the land!” 13 At this they said: “Your servants are 12 brothers.
Ŋutsu ɖeka ƒe viwo míenye le Kanaan-nyigba dzi, eye ɖevitɔ la le mía fofo gbɔ, ke ame kemɛa ya megali o.”
We are the sons of but one man in the land of Canaan, and the youngest is now with our father, whereas the other one is no more.”

14 Ke Yosef gblɔ na wo be: “Megblɔe na mi xoxo be, ‘Ŋkutsalawoe mienye!’ 15 Esiae woatsɔ ado mi kpɔ: Zi ale si Farao le agbe la, miadzo le afi sia o, va se ɖe esime mia nɔvi ɖevitɔ la va afi sia hafi.

14 However, Joseph said to them: “It is just as I said to you—‘You are spies!’ 15 By this you will be tested: As surely as Pharaoh lives, you will not leave this place until your youngest brother comes here.
16 Midɔ mia dometɔ ɖeka wòayi aɖakplɔ mia nɔvi la vɛ, eye miawo ya mianɔ ga me.
16 Send one of you to bring your brother while you remain in bondage.
Woatsɔ esia ado mi kpɔ be nyateƒe tom miele hã.
In this way, your words may be tested out to see if you are telling the truth.
Ke ne menye nyateƒee o la, ekema zi ale si Farao le agbe la, ŋkutsalawoe mienye.” 17 Ale wòlé wo de ga ŋkeke etɔ̃.
And if not, then, as surely as Pharaoh lives, you are spies.” 17 With that he put them together in custody for three days.
18 Yosef gblɔ na wo le ŋkeke etɔ̃a gbe be: “Miwɔ esia ne mianɔ agbe, elabena mevɔ̃a Mawu.
18 Joseph said to them on the third day: “Do this and live, for I fear God.
19 Ne nuteƒewɔlawoe mienye la, ekema mia nɔvi ɖeka nanɔ ga me le afi sia, ke mi ame susɔeawo miate ŋu adzo, eye mitsɔ nuɖuɖu ne miatsɔ atsi dɔwuamea nu.
19 If you are upright, let one of your brothers remain in bondage in your house of custody, but the rest of you may go and take grain to alleviate the famine in your households.
20 Eye ne miekplɔ mia nɔvi ɖevitɔ la vɛ nam la, ekema nyateƒee mieto, eye miaku o.”
20 Then bring your youngest brother to me, so that your words will be found trustworthy and you will not die.”
Eye wowɔ nenema.
And they did so.
21 Eye wogblɔ na wo nɔewo be: “Nyateƒee, wole to hem na mí le mía nɔvi la ta, elabena míekpɔ xaxa si me wòto, esime wòƒo koko na mí be míaƒe dɔme natrɔ ɖe ye ŋu, gake míeɖo toe o.
21 And they said to one another: “We are surely being punished on account of our brother, because we saw his distress when he begged us to show compassion, but we did not listen.
Esia tae xaxa sia va mía dzi ɖo.” 22 Ruben ɖo eŋu na wo be: “Ðe nyemegblɔe na mi be, ‘Migawɔ vɔ̃ aɖeke ɖevi la oa?’ Gake miegbe esese.
That is why this distress has come upon us.” 22 Then Reuben answered them: “Did I not say to you, ‘Do not sin against the child,’ but you would not listen?
Eƒe ʋu kokokoe nye esia biam wole tso mía si.” 23 Ke womenya be Yosef le nya la gɔme sem o, elabena gbegɔmeɖela le eya kpli wo dome.
Now his blood is certainly being asked back.” 23 But they did not know that Joseph understood, for there was an interpreter between them.
24 Eya ta edzo le wo gbɔ yi ɖafa avi.
24 So he turned away from them and began to weep.
Esi wòtrɔ va wo gbɔ la, egaƒo nu kpli wo, eye wòkplɔ Simeon le wo dome heblae le wo ŋkume.
When he returned and spoke to them again, he took Simeon from them and bound him before their eyes.
25 Eye Yosef ɖe gbe be woade nuɖuɖu woƒe kotokuwo me taŋ, egblɔ hã be woatrɔ ŋutsuawo ƒe ga ade wo dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe ƒe kotoku me, eye woana mɔdzinuɖuɖu hã wo.
25 Joseph then gave the command to fill up their bags with grain and to return each man’s money to his own sack and to give them provisions for the journey.
Eye wowɔe na wo nenema.
This was done for them.
26 Ale wodo nuɖuɖugbawo na woƒe tedziwo, eye wodze mɔ.
26 So they loaded their grain on their donkeys and left from there.
27 Esi wo dometɔ ɖeka ʋu eƒe kotoku be yeana nuɖuɖu yeƒe tedzi le afi si wodze la, ekpɔ eƒe ga le kotokua nu.
27 When one of them opened his sack to give fodder to his donkey at the lodging place, he saw his money there in the mouth of his bag.
28 Eye wògblɔ na nɔviawo be: “Wogbugbɔ nye ga la nam, eyae nye esi le nye kotokua me!”
28 At that he said to his brothers: “My money has been returned, and now here it is in my bag!”
Eye woƒe dzi lã kpo, ale be wodzo nyanyanya hetrɔ ɖe wo nɔewo ŋu gblɔ be: “Nu kae nye esi Mawu wɔ ɖe mía ŋu?”
Then their hearts sank, and trembling, they turned to one another and said: “What is this that God has done to us?”

29 Mlɔeba wova wo fofo Yakob gbɔ le Kanaan-nyigba dzi, eye wogblɔ nu siwo katã dzɔ ɖe wo dzi la nɛ be: 30 “Ŋutsu si nye dukɔa dzi kpɔla la ƒo nu kpli mí adãtɔe, eye wòtso mía nu be ŋku tsa gee míeva le dukɔa me.

29 When they came to Jacob their father in the land of Canaan, they told him all the things that had befallen them, saying: 30 “The man who is the lord of the country spoke harshly with us and accused us of spying on the country.
31 Ke míegblɔ nɛ be: ‘Nuteƒewɔlawoe míenye.
31 But we said to him, ‘We are upright men.
Menye ŋkutsalawoe míenye o.
We are not spies.
32 Nɔvi wuieve míenye, tɔ ɖeka viwoe míenye.
32 We are 12 brothers, the sons of our father.
Ðeka megali o, eye ɖevitɔ le mía fofo gbɔ le Kanaan-nyigba dzi.’ 33 Ke ŋutsu si nye dukɔa dzi kpɔlaa gblɔ na mí be, ‘Esia mee manyae le be nuteƒewɔlawoe mienye: Mina mia nɔvi ɖeka natsi gbɔnye.

One is no more, and the youngest is now with our father in the land of Canaan.’ 33 But the man who is the lord of the country said to us, ‘By this I will know that you are upright: Leave one of your brothers with me.
Azɔ mitsɔ nu siwo miatsɔ atsi dɔwuamea nu na miaƒe aƒemetɔwo la ne miadzo.
Then take something to alleviate the famine in your households and go.
34 Eye mikplɔ mia nɔvi ɖevitɔ la vɛ nam, ne manya be menye ŋkutsalawoe mienye o, ke boŋ nuteƒewɔlawoe mienye.
34 And bring your youngest brother to me, so that I may know that you are not spies but upright men.
Ekema maɖe asi le mia nɔvi la ŋu na mi, eye miate ŋu ava nɔ nu ƒlem le anyigba la dzi faa.’”
I will then give your brother back to you, and you may carry on trade in the land.’”
35 Esime wole woƒe nuwo trɔm le woƒe kotokuawo me la, kpɔ ɖa, ame sia ame ƒe ga le eƒe kotokua me.
35 As they were emptying their sacks, here was each one’s bag of money in his sack.
Esi woawo kple wo fofo siaa kpɔ woƒe ga siwo le babla la, vɔvɔ̃ ɖo wo.
When they and their father saw their bags of money, they became afraid.
36 Eye wo fofo Yakob do ɣli gblɔ na wo be: “Miena vinyewo bu vɔ!
36 Jacob their father exclaimed to them: “It is I you have bereaved!
Yosef megali o, Simeon hã megali o, eye Benyamin hã kplɔ ge miegalea?
Joseph is no more, and Simeon is no more, and you are going to take Benjamin!
Dzinyee nu siawo katã dzɔ ɖo!” 37 Ke Ruben gblɔ na fofoa be: “Ne nyemekplɔe gbɔe na wò o la, ekema wu vinyeŋutsu eveawo.
It is upon me that all these things have come!” 37 But Reuben said to his father: “You may put to death my own two sons if I do not bring him back to you.
Tsɔe de asi nam, eye makplɔe agbɔe na wò.” 38 Ke egblɔ be: “Vinyea mayi kpli mi o, elabena nɔvia ku, eye eya ɖeka koe susɔ.
Give him over to my care, and I will return him to you.” 38 However, he said: “My son will not go down with you, because his brother is dead and he alone is left.
Ne nu vevi aɖe wɔe wòku le mɔzɔzɔa me la, ekema miana matsɔ nye ta ƒowɔ ayi Tsiẽƒe kple nuxaxa.”
If a fatal accident should befall him on the journey you would make, then you would certainly bring down my gray hairs to the Grave in grief.”
Emegbe ede se na eƒe aƒedzikpɔla la be: “De nuɖuɖu ŋutsuawo ƒe kotokuwo me ale si nu woate ŋu atsɔ, eye nàtsɔ wo dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe ƒe ga de eƒe kotokua me.
Later he commanded the man who was over his house: “Fill the bags of the men with as much food as they can carry, and place the money of each one in the mouth of his bag.
2 Ke nàtsɔ nye kplu, nye klosalokplu la, de ɖevitɔ ƒe kotoku me hekpe ɖe eƒe nuɖuɖuƒlegaa ŋu.”
2 But you must place my cup, the silver cup, in the mouth of the bag of the youngest, along with the money for his grain.”
Eye wòwɔ nya si Yosef gblɔ nɛ la dzi.
So he did as Joseph had instructed.
3 Le ŋdi, esi xexea me kɔ la, wodo mɔ ŋutsuawo wodzo kple woƒe tedziwo.
3 In the morning when it had become light, the men were sent away with their donkeys.
4 Esi wodo go le dua me la, womekpɔ ɖo afi aɖeke hafi Yosef gblɔ na eƒe aƒedzikpɔlaa be: “Tso!
4 They had not gone far from the city when Joseph said to the man who was over his house: “Get up!
Dze ŋutsuawo yome!
Chase after the men!
Ne èxe wo la, gblɔ na wo be, ‘Nu ka tae mietsɔ vɔ̃ ɖo nyui teƒe? 5 Ðe mienya be kplu sia mee nye aƒetɔ noa nu le, eye eyae wòzãna tsɔ kaa nu oa?
When you overtake them, say to them, ‘Why have you repaid bad for good? 5 Is not this what my master drinks from and uses to read omens expertly?
Nu vɔ̃ɖie wònye miewɔ.’”
It is a wicked thing you have done.’”
6 Eya ta eva xe wo, eye wògblɔ nya siawo na wo.
6 So he overtook them and spoke these words to them.
7 Ke wogblɔ nɛ be: “Nu ka tae nye aƒetɔ le nu ƒom alea?
7 But they said to him: “Why does my lord say such a thing?
Nu sia wɔwɔ nede megbe xaa tso wò dɔlawo gbɔ.
It is unthinkable that your servants would do anything like this.
8 Kpɔ ɖa, ga si míekpɔ le míaƒe kotokuawo me la, míetsɔe tso Kanaan-nyigba dzi gbugbɔ vɛ na wò.
8 Why, the money that we found in the mouth of our bags we brought back to you from the land of Canaan.

Ekema aleke wɔ míahayi klosalo alo sika fi ge le wò aƒetɔ ƒe me? 9 Wo kluviwo dometɔ si gbɔ woakpɔe le la naku, eye mí ame mamlɛawo hã míazu kluviwo na nye aƒetɔ.” 10 Eye wògblɔ be: “Míawɔe abe ale si miegblɔe ene: ame si gbɔ woakpɔe le la azu nye kluvi, ke mi ame mamlɛawo ya miaɖi fɔ o.” 11 Ale wo dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe ɖiɖi eƒe kotoku la ɖe anyi enumake heʋu enu.

How, then, could we steal silver or gold from the house of your master? 9 If it is found with one of your slaves, let him die, and the rest of us will also become slaves to my master.” 10 So he said: “Let it be as you say: The one with whom it is found will become my slave, but the rest of you will be innocent.” 11 With that each one quickly lowered his bag to the ground and opened it.
12 Eye wòde asi edidi me tsitotsito, edze egɔme tso tsitsitɔ dzi va wu enu ɖe ɖevitɔ dzi.
12 He searched carefully, starting with the oldest and finishing with the youngest.
Mlɔeba wokpɔ kplu la le Benyamin ƒe kotoku me.
Finally the cup was found in Benjamin’s bag.
13 Eye wodze woƒe awuwo, eye wo dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe gatsɔ eƒe agba ɖo eƒe tedzi dzi, eye wotrɔ yi dua me.
