13 Then they ripped their garments apart, and each of them lifted his load back onto his donkey and returned to the city.
14 Esi Yuda kple nɔviawo trɔ yi Yosef ƒe me la, egakpɔtɔ nɔ aƒea me ɣemaɣi, eye wobɔbɔ tsyɔ mo anyi ɖe eŋkume.
14 When Judah and his brothers went into Joseph’s house, he was still there; and they fell to the ground before him.
15 Eye Yosef gblɔ na wo be: “Nu kae nye esi miewɔ?
15 Joseph said to them: “What is this deed that you have done?
Ðe mienyae be ɖe mebi ɖe nukaka me ŋutɔ oa?” 16 Yuda ɖo eŋu be: “Nya kae míagate ŋu agblɔ na nye aƒetɔ?
Did you not know that a man like me can expertly read omens?” 16 At this Judah replied: “What can we say to my master?
Nya ka gblɔ ge míala?
What can we speak?
Eye aleke míawɔ ana wòanya be nuteƒewɔlawoe míenye?
And how can we prove ourselves righteous?
Mawu vavã la ʋu go wò kluviwo ƒe vodada.
The true God has found out the error of your slaves.
Azɔ mía kple ame si si wokpɔ kplua le la siaa míezu nye aƒetɔ ƒe kluviwo!” 17 Ke egblɔ be: “Nede megbe xaa tso gbɔnye be mawɔ nu sia!
We are now slaves to my master, both we and the one in whose hand the cup was found!” 17 However, he said: “It is unthinkable for me to do this!
Ame si si wokpɔ kplua le lae azu nye kluvi.
The man in whose hand the cup was found is the one who will become a slave to me.
Ke mi ame mamlɛawo ya migbugbɔ yi mia fofo gbɔ le ŋutifafa me.”
As for the rest of you, go up in peace to your father.”
18 Eye Yuda te ɖe eŋu gblɔ nɛ be: “Meɖe kuku na wò, nye aƒetɔ, meɖe kuku, na wò kluvi nagblɔ nya aɖe na nye aƒetɔ, eye mègana wò dziku nafla ɖe wò kluvi la ŋu o, elabena ɖeko nèle abe Farao ŋutɔ ene.
18 Judah now approached him and said: “I beg you, my master, please let your slave speak a word in my master’s ears, and do not become angry with your slave, for you are like Pharaoh himself.
19 Nye aƒetɔ bia eƒe kluviwo be: ‘Fofo alo nɔvi aɖe le mia sia?’ 20 Eya ta míeɖo eŋu na nye aƒetɔ be: ‘Mía fofo si nye amegãɖeɖi kple via si wòdzi le eƒe amegãkuku me, ame si nye eƒe dɔmlɔea li.
19 My master asked his slaves, ‘Do you have a father or a brother?’ 20 So we said to my master, ‘We do have an aged father and a child of his old age, the youngest.

Ke nɔvia ku, ale be eya koe nye dadaa ƒe vi si susɔ, eye fofoa lɔ̃nɛ vevie.’ 21 Emegbe ègblɔ na wò kluviwo be: ‘Mikplɔe vɛ nam, ne makpɔ.’ 22 Ke míegblɔ na nye aƒetɔ be: ‘Ðevi la mate ŋu adzo le fofoa gbɔ o.

But his brother is dead, so he is the only remaining son of his mother, and his father loves him.’ 21 After that you said to your slaves, ‘Bring him down to me so that I may see him.’ 22 But we said to my master, ‘The boy is not able to leave his father.
Ne edzo le fofoa gbɔ la, fofoa aku godoo.’ 23 Ke ègblɔ na wò kluviwo be: ‘Ne mia nɔvi ɖevitɔ la meva kpli mi o la, ekema migava ŋkunyeme azɔ o.’
If he did leave him, his father would certainly die.’ 23 Then you said to your slaves, ‘Unless your youngest brother comes down with you, you may not see my face anymore.’
24 “Ale míetrɔ yi wò kluvi, mía fofo gbɔ, eye míegblɔ nye aƒetɔ ƒe nyawo nɛ.
24 “So we went up to your slave my father and told him the words of my master.
25 Emegbe mía fofo gblɔ be: ‘Mitrɔ yi ɖaƒle nuɖuɖu vi aɖe vɛ na mí.’ 26 Ke míegblɔ be: ‘Míate ŋu ayi o.
25 Later our father said, ‘Return and buy a little food for us.’ 26 But we said, ‘We are not able to go down.

Ne mía nɔvi ɖevitɔ kpe ɖe mía ŋu ko hafi míayi, elabena míate ŋu ado ɖe ŋutsua ŋkume ne mía nɔvi ɖevitɔ mekpe ɖe mía ŋu o.’ 27 Eye wò kluvi, mía fofo, gblɔ na mí be, ‘Miawo ŋutɔ mienyae nyuie be ŋutsuvi eve koe srɔ̃nye dzi nam.

If our youngest brother is with us we will go down, for we cannot see the man’s face unless our youngest brother is with us.’ 27 Then your slave my father said to us, ‘You well know that my wife bore but two sons to me.
28 Gake ɖeka dzo le gbɔnye, eye medo ɣli gblɔ be: “Lã aɖe kokokoe anya vuvui!” Eye nyemegakpɔe o va se ɖe egbe.
28 But one of them left me and I said: “He must surely have been torn to pieces!” and I have not seen him until now.
29 Ne miekplɔ ame sia hã dzoe le gbɔnye, eye nu vevi aɖe wɔe wòku la, ekema miana matsɔ nye ta ƒowɔ ayi Tsiẽƒe kple nuxaxa.’
29 If you were to take this one also out of my sight and a fatal accident were to befall him, you would certainly bring down my gray hairs to the Grave with calamity.’

30 “Azɔ ne metrɔ yi wò kluvi fofonye gbɔ, evɔ ɖevi la mekpe ɖe mía ŋu o, eye esi wònye be eƒe agbe ku ɖe ɖevia ƒe agbe ŋu ta la, 31 ne enya kpɔ mí, eye ɖevi la mele mía ŋu o ko la, aku godoo; eye wò kluviwo ana wò kluvi, mía fofo, natsɔ ta ƒowɔ ayi Tsiẽƒe kple nuxaxa.

30 “And now if I return to your slave my father without the boy along with us, since his own life is bound up with this one’s life, 31 then as soon as he sees that the boy is not there, he will die, and your slaves will indeed bring down the gray hairs of your slave our father to the Grave in grief.

32 Hafi míadze mɔ la, wò kluvi da megbe na ɖevia gblɔ na fofonye be: ‘Ne nyemekplɔe gbɔe na wò o la, ekema mewɔ nu vɔ̃ ɖe fofonye ŋu tegbee.’ 33 Eya ta meɖe kuku, na nye, wò kluvi boŋ mazu nye aƒetɔ ƒe kluvi ɖe ɖevi la teƒe, ne ɖevi la nagbugbɔ ayi kple nɔviawo.

32 Your slave gave a guarantee to my father for the boy, saying, ‘If I fail to bring him back to you, then I will have sinned against my father forever.’ 33 So now, please, let your slave stay instead of the boy as my master’s slave, in order that the boy may return with his brothers.
34 Aleke mawɔ ayi fofonye gbɔ ne ɖevi la mele ŋunye o?
34 How can I return to my father without the boy along with me?
Nyemate ŋu akpɔ vɔ̃ si adzɔ ɖe fofonye dzi la teƒe o!”
I could not bear looking on when this calamity befalls my father!”
Ale Isak yɔ Yakob vɛ eye wòyrae hegblɔ nɛ be: “Mègaɖe Kanaan-nyɔnu o.
So Isaac called Jacob and blessed him and commanded him, saying: “You must not take a wife from the daughters of Canaan.
2 Yi Padan-Aram le dawò fofo Betuel ƒe me, ne nàɖe nyruiwò Laban ƒe vinyɔnuwo dometɔ ɖeka.
2 Go away to Paddanaram to the house of Bethuel, your mother’s father, and from there take for yourself a wife from the daughters of Laban, your mother’s brother.
3 Mawu Ŋusẽkatãtɔ la nayra wò, wòana nàdzi ɖe edzi ahasɔ gbɔ ɖe edzi, eye àva zu dukɔ gã aɖe.
3 God Almighty will bless you and make you fruitful and multiply you, and you will certainly become a congregation of peoples.
4 Nena Abraham ƒe yayra nava wò kple wò dzidzimeviwo dzi, ne nàxɔ anyigba si Mawu tsɔ na Abraham, si dzi nènye amedzro le la, wòazu tɔwò.”

4 And he will give to you the blessing of Abraham, to you and to your offspring with you, so that you may take possession of the land where you have been living as a foreigner, which God has given to Abraham.”
5 Ale Isak do mɔ Yakob, eye wòdze mɔ yina ɖe Aramtɔ Betuel ƒe vi Laban gbɔ le Padan-Aram. Laban nye Yakob kple Esau dada Rebeka nɔvi.
5 So Isaac sent Jacob away, and he departed for Paddanaram, to Laban the son of Bethuel the Aramaean, the brother of Rebekah, the mother of Jacob and Esau.

6 Esau kpɔ be Isak yra Yakob, eye wòɖoe ɖe Padan-Aram be wòaɖe srɔ̃ le afi ma, eye esi wònɔ eyram la, ede se nɛ be, “Mègaɖe Kanaan-nyɔnu o,” 7 eye Yakob ɖo to fofoa kple dadaa, eye wòdze Padan-Aram mɔ.

6 Esau saw that Isaac had blessed Jacob and had sent him away to Paddanaram to take a wife from there and that when he blessed him, he commanded him, “Do not take a wife from the daughters of Canaan,” 7 and that Jacob obeyed his father and his mother and departed for Paddanaram.

8 Esau va kpɔe dze sii be Kanaan-nyɔnuwo ƒe nu medze ye fofo Isak ŋu o. 9 Eya ta Esau yi Ismael gbɔ, eye wòɖe Mahalat, si nye Abraham vi Ismael ƒe vinyɔnu, si nye Nebayot nɔvinyɔnu, kpe ɖe srɔ̃a bubuawo ŋu.

8 Esau then realized that the daughters of Canaan were displeasing to his father Isaac, 9 so Esau went to Ishmael and took as wife Mahalath the daughter of Abraham’s son Ishmael, the sister of NebAioth, in addition to the other wives he already had.
10 Ke Yakob dze mɔ tso Beer-Seba ɖo ta Haran.
10 Jacob departed from Beer-sheba and kept going toward Haran.
11 Le ɣeyiɣi aɖe megbe la, eva ɖo teƒe aɖe, eye wòɖoe be yeatsi afi ma adɔ, elabena ɣe ɖo to xoxo.
11 In time he came to a place and prepared to spend the night there because the sun had set.
Ale wòtsɔ kpe aɖe le afi ma ziɔ tae, eye wòmlɔ anyi ɖe afi ma.
So he took one of the stones of that place and set it to rest his head on and lay down there.
12 Eku drɔ̃e, eye kpɔ ɖa, woda atrakpui aɖe ɖe anyigba, si ƒe tame ɖatɔ dziƒo; eye Mawu ƒe dɔlawo le eliam le dzi yim gale ɖiɖim.
12 Then he had a dream, and look! there was a stairway set on the earth, and its top reached up to the heavens; and there were God’s angels ascending and descending on it.
13 Eye kpɔ ɖa, Yehowa ye nye ema le etame, eye wògblɔ be:
13 And look! there was Jehovah stationed above it, and he said:
“Nyee nye Yehowa, fofowò Abraham ƒe Mawu kple Isak ƒe Mawu.
“I am Jehovah the God of Abraham your father and Manasseh he God of Isaac.
Matsɔ anyigba si dzi nèmlɔ anyi ɖo la ana wò kple wò dzidzimeviwo.
The land on which you are lying, to you I am going to give it and to your offspring.
14 Wò dzidzimeviwo asɔ gbɔ abe kekuiwo ene, eye àkeke ta ɖo ɖe ɣetoɖoƒe, ɣedzeƒe, dziehe kple anyiehe gome, eye woayra anyigbadziƒomewo katã to wò kple wò dzidzimeviwo dzi.

14 And your offspring will certainly become like the dust particles of the earth, and you will spread abroad to the west and to the east and to the north and to the south, and by means of you and by means of your offspring all the families of the ground will certainly be blessed.
15 Meli kpli wò, makpɔ tawò le afi sia afi si nàyi, eye mana nàgatrɔ ava anyigba sia dzi.
15 I am with you, and I will safeguard you wherever you go, and I will return you to this land.
Nyemagblẽ wò ɖi o, va se ɖe esime mewɔ ŋugbe si medo na wò la dzi.”
I will not leave you until I have done what I have promised you.”
16 Eye Yakob nyɔ tso alɔ̃ me gblɔ be: “Nyateƒee, Yehowa le afi sia, gake nyemenya o.” 17 Eye vɔvɔ̃ ɖoe wògblɔ be: “Teƒe dziŋɔ ka gbegbee nye esi!
16 Then Jacob awoke from his sleep and said: “Truly Jehovah is in this place, and I did not know it.” 17 And he grew fearful and added: “How awe-inspiring this place is!
Mawu ƒe aƒe kokokoe nye esia, eye dziƒowo ƒe agboe nye esia.” 18 Eya ta esi Yakob fɔ ŋdi kanya la, etsɔ kpe si wòziɔ le afi ma la ɖi ŋkuɖodzikpee, eye wòkɔ ami ɖe edzi.

This can only be the house of God, and this is the gate of the heavens.” 18 So Jacob got up early in the morning and took the stone on which he had rested his head and set it up as a pillar and poured oil on top of it.
19 Eye wòna ŋkɔ teƒe ma be Betel, gake Luz ye woyɔna na dua tsã.
19 So he named that place Bethel, but previously the city’s name was Luz.

20 Eye Yakob ɖe adzɔgbe be: “Ne Mawu anɔ kplim, eye wòakpɔ tanye le nye mɔzɔzɔa me, eye wòana abolom maɖu kple awum mado, 21 eye magatrɔ ava fofonye ƒe me le ŋutifafa me la, ekema Yehowa ɖee fiam vavã be yenye nye Mawu.

20 Jacob then made a vow, saying: “If God will continue with me and will protect me on my journey and will give me bread to eat and garments to wear 21 and I return in peace to the house of my father, then Jehovah will certainly have proved to be my God.
22 Eye kpe sia si metsɔ ɖi ŋkuɖodzikpee la azu Mawu ƒe aƒe, eye matsɔ nu sia nu si nànam la ƒe ewolia ana wò godoo.”
22 And this stone that I have set up as a pillar will become a house of God, and without fail I will give you a tenth of everything you give to me.”
Le nu siawo megbe la, wova gblɔ na Yosef be: “Kpɔ ɖa, fofowò le gbɔdzɔgbɔdzɔm.”
After these things, Joseph was told: “Look, your father is getting weak.”
Eya ta Yosef kplɔ via eveawo, Manase kple Efrayim, ɖe asi yi egbɔ.
At that he took his two sons and Ephraim with him.
2 Eye wogblɔ na Yakob be: “Kpɔ ɖa, viwò Yosef va gbɔwò.”
2 Then Jacob was told: “Here your son Joseph has come to you.”
Eya ta Israel do ŋusẽ nu fɔ hebɔbɔ nɔ abati la dzi.
So Israel gathered his strength and sat up on his bed.
3 Eye Yakob gblɔ na Yosef be:
3 And Jacob said to Joseph:
“Mawu Ŋusẽkatãtɔ la ɖe eɖokui fiam le Luz le Kanaan-nyigba dzi eye wòyram.
“God Almighty appeared to me at Luz in the land of Canaan and blessed me.

4 Eye wògblɔ nam be, ‘Mena nèle dzidzim, mana nàsɔ gbɔ, mana nàzu ameha gã aɖe, eye matsɔ anyigba sia ana wò dzidzimevi siwo ava ɖe yowòme be wòanye wo tɔ ɖaa.’ 5 Azɔ ŋutsuvi siwo wodzi na wò le Egipte-nyigba dzi hafi meva gbɔwò le Egipte la zu tɔnyewo.

4 And he said to me, ‘I am making you fruitful, and I will make you many, and I will transform you into a congregation of peoples, and I will give this land to your offspring after you as a lasting possession.’ 5 Now your two sons who were born to you in the land of Egypt before I came to you in Egypt are mine.
Efrayim kple Manase azu vinyewo, abe Ruben kple Simeon ene.
Ephraim and Manasseh will become mine just as Reuben and Simeon are mine.
6 Ke vi siwo woava dzi na wò ɖe wo yome la azu tɔwò.
6 But the children born to you after them will become yours.
Woayɔ wo nɔvi eve siawo ƒe ŋkɔwo ɖe wo ŋu eye woanyi dome tso wo gbɔ.
They will be called by the name of their brothers in their inheritance.
7 Esime metso Padan gbɔna la, Rahel ku le gbɔnye le Kanaan-nyigba dzi.
7 As for me, when I was coming from Paddan, Rachel died alongside me in the land of Canaan, while there was yet a good stretch of land before coming to Ephrath.
Eye esi mɔ didi aɖe gale ŋgɔnye hafi maɖo Efrat ta la, meɖii esi menɔ mɔ dzi yina Efrat, si nye Betlehem.”
So I buried her there on the way to Ephrath, that is, Bethlehem.”
8 Esi Israel kpɔ Yosef viwo la, ebia be: “Ame kawoe nye esiawo?” 9 Yosef ɖo eŋu na fofoa be: “Woawoe nye vi siwo Mawu nam le teƒe sia.”
8 Then Israel saw Joseph’s sons and asked: “Who are these?” 9 So Joseph said to his father: “They are my sons whom God has given me in this place.”
Eye wògblɔ be: “Meɖe kuku, kplɔ wo vɛ nam, ne mayra wo.” 10 Ke Israel ƒe ŋkuwo dzi tsyɔ le tsitsi ta, eye megatea ŋu kpɔa nu o.
At this he said: “Bring them to me, please, so that I may bless them.” 10 Now the eyes of Israel were failing from age, and he was unable to see.
Esia ta Yosef kplɔ wo te ɖe eŋu, eye wògbugbɔ nu na wo hekpla asi kɔ na wo.
So Joseph brought them close to him, and he kissed them and embraced them.
11 Israel gblɔ na Yosef be: “Nyemebui kpɔ be magakpɔ wò ŋkume o, ke azɔ Mawu na mekpɔ viwòwo gɔ̃ hã.” 12 Emegbe Yosef ɖe wo le Israel ƒe atame, eye wòbɔbɔ tsyɔ mo anyi.

11 Israel said to Joseph: “I never imagined I would see your face, but here God has also let me see your offspring.” 12 Joseph then removed them from Israel’s knees, and he bowed down with his face to the ground.
13 Eye Yosef kplɔ wo ame evea, eye wòtsɔ eƒe nuɖusi lé Efrayim ɖo Israel ƒe miame, hetsɔ eƒe miasi lé Manase ɖo Israel ƒe ɖusime, eye wòkplɔ wo te ɖe eŋu.
13 Joseph now took the two of them, Ephraim with his right hand to Israel’s left and Manasseh with his left hand to Israel’s right, and brought them close to him.
14 Ke Israel tsɔ eƒe nuɖusi ɖo Efrayim ƒe tame, evɔ eyae nye ɖevitɔ hafi, eye wòtsɔ eƒe miasi ɖo Manase ƒe tame.
14 However, Israel put out his right hand and placed it on Ephraim’s head, although he was the younger, and he placed his left hand on Manasseh’s head.
Ðe wòɖoe koŋ da eƒe asiwo ɖe wo dzi nenema, elabena Manase ye nye ŋgɔgbevia.
He purposely laid his hands this way, since Manasseh was the firstborn.
15 Eye wòyra Yosef gblɔ be:
15 Then he blessed Joseph and said:
“Mawu vavã si ŋkume fofonye Abraham kple Isak zɔ le,
“The true God before whom my fathers Abraham and Isaac walked,
Mawu vavã si kplɔm le nye agbe me katã va se ɖe egbe,
The true God who has been shepherding me during all my life until this day,
16 Mawudɔla si ɖeam tso vɔ̃wo katã me, nayra ɖeviawo.
16 The angel who has been recovering me from all calamity, bless the boys.
Na woayɔ nye ŋkɔ ɖe wo ŋu, eye woayɔ fofonye Abraham kple Isak ƒe ŋkɔ ɖe wo ŋu,
Let my name be called upon them and the name of my fathers, Abraham and Isaac,
Eye na woadzi azu ameha gã aɖe le anyigba la dzi.”
Let them increase to a multitude in the earth.”
17 Esi Yosef kpɔ be ye fofo ƒe nuɖusi kpɔtɔ le Efrayim ƒe tame la, medzɔ dzi nɛ o, eya ta elé fofoa ƒe asi be yeaɖee ɖa le Efrayim ƒe tame ada ɖe Manase ƒe tame.

17 When Joseph saw that his father kept his right hand placed on Ephraim’s head, it was displeasing to him, so he tried to take hold of his father’s hand to move it from Ephraim’s head to Manasseh’s head.
18 Yosef gblɔ na fofoa be: “Fofonye, mègawɔe nenema o, elabena ame siae nye ŋgɔgbevi la.
18 Joseph said to his father: “Not so, my father, because this is the firstborn.
Tsɔ wò nuɖusi da ɖe eƒe tame.” 19 Ke fofoa gbe hegblɔ be: “Menya, vinye, menya.
Put your right hand on his head.” 19 But his father kept refusing and said: “I know it, my son, I know it.
Eya hã ava zu dukɔ, eye eya hã ava zu gã.
He too will become a people, and he too will become great.
Gake nɔvia ɖevitɔ la ava zu gã wui, eye eƒe dzidzimeviwo ava sɔ gbɔ ade dukɔwo nu.” 20 Eye wòyra wo gbe ma gbe gblɔ be:
Nevertheless, his younger brother will become greater than he will, and his offspring will become the full equivalent of nations.” 20 So he continued to bless them on that day, saying:
“Israel-viwo atsɔ wò ŋkɔ anɔ wo nɔewo yram agblɔ be:
“Let Israel mention you when they pronounce blessings, saying,
‘Mawu nawɔ wò nànɔ abe Efrayim kple Manase ene.’”
‘May God make you like Ephraim and like Manasseh.’”
Ale wòtsɔ Efrayim ɖo ŋgɔ na Manase.
Thus he kept putting Ephraim before Manasseh.
21 Eye Israel gblɔ na Yosef be: “Kpɔ ɖa, mele kukum, ke Mawu anɔ kpli mi, eye wòana miatrɔ ayi mia tɔgbuiwo ƒe anyigba dzi.
21 Then Israel said to Joseph: “Look, I am dying, but God will certainly continue with you and return you to the land of your forefathers.
22 Metsɔ anyigba aɖe, si metsɔ nye yi kple nye dati xɔ le Amoritɔwo si la na wò, be tɔwò nawu nɔviwòwo tɔ.”
22 As for me, I do give you one portion of land more than to your brothers, which I took from the hand of the Amorites with my sword and my bow.
Emegbe Abram fɔ eƒe nuwo katã, eye eya kple srɔ̃a woʋu le Egipte yi Negeb, eye Lot hã yi kpli wo.
Abram then went up out of Egypt to the Negeb, he and his wife and all that he had, together with Lot.
2 Eye lãhawo, klosalo kple sika va bɔ ɖe Abram si fũu.
2 Abram was very rich in livestock, silver, and gold.
3 Eʋu tso Negeb ɖo ta Betel, eye wònɔ eƒe agbadɔ hom nɔ tutum tso teƒe yi teƒe va ɖo afi si wòtu eƒe agbadɔ ɖo va yi, le Betel kple Ai dome, 4 le teƒe si wòɖi vɔsamlekpui ɖo tsã.

3 He camped in one place after another as he traveled from the Negeb to Bethel, until he arrived at the place where his tent had been between Bethel and Ai, 4 to the place where he had previously built an altar.
Eye Abram yɔ Yehowa ƒe ŋkɔ le afi ma.
There Abram called on the name of Jehovah.
5 Ke alẽwo kple nyiwo kpakple agbadɔwo va nɔ Lot, ame si kplɔ Abram ɖo le yiyim la, hã si.
5 Now Lot, who was traveling with Abram, also owned sheep, cattle, and tents.
6 Eye anyigba la mede wo nu be wo katã nanɔ teƒe ɖeka o, elabena woƒe nunɔamesiwo va sɔ gbɔ ale gbegbe be womagate ŋu anɔ teƒe ɖeka o.
6 So the land did not allow for all of them to stay in the same place; their goods had become so many that they could no longer dwell together.
7 Eya ta dzre dzɔ ɖe Abram ƒe lãkplɔviwo kple Lot ƒe lãkplɔviwo dome.
7 As a result, a quarrel arose between the herders of Abram’s livestock and the herders of Lot’s livestock.

(Ɣemaɣi la, Kanaantɔwo kple Perizitɔwo nɔ anyigba la dzi.) 8 Eya ta Abram gblɔ na Lot be: “Meɖe kuku, mègana dzre nanɔ nye kpli wò kpakple nye lãkplɔviwo kple wò lãkplɔviwo dome o, elabena nɔviwo míenye.

(At that time the Canaanites and the Perizzites were dwelling in the land.) 8 So Abram said to Lot: “Please, there should be no quarreling between me and you and between my herdsmen and your herdsmen, for we are brothers.
9 Alo menye anyigba blibo lae nye esi le ŋkuwòme oa?
9 Is not the whole land available to you?
Meɖe kuku, klã ɖa tso gbɔnye.
Please, separate from me.

Ne èyi miame la, ekema mayi ɖusime; ke ne èyi ɖusime la, ekema mayi miame.” 10 Eya ta Lot fɔ mo dzi eye wòkpɔ be Yordan nuto blibo la katã va se ɖe keke Zoar ke nye nuto si me tsi bɔ ɖo, ele abe Yehowa ƒe abɔ ene, abe Egipte-nyigba ene (ɣemaɣi la, Yehowa metsrɔ̃ Sodom kple Gomora haɖe o).

If you go to the left, then I will go to the right; but if you go to the right, then I will go to the left.” 10 So Lot raised his eyes and saw that the whole district of the Jordan was a well-watered region (before Jehovah destroyed Sodom and Gomorrah), like the garden of Jehovah, like the land of Egypt, as far as Zoar.
11 Eye Lot tia Yordan nuto bliboa na eɖokui, eye Lot ho eƒe agbadɔ yi ɖatu ɖe ɣedzeƒe gome.
11 Then Lot chose for himself the whole district of the Jordan, and Lot moved his camp to the east.
Ale woklã ɖa tso wo nɔewo gbɔ.
So they separated from each other.
12 Abram nɔ Kanaan-nyigba dzi, ke Lot ya nɔ nuto ma ƒe duwo me.
12 Abram lived in the land of Canaan, but Lot lived among the cities of the district.
Mlɔeba eva tu eƒe agbadɔ ɖe Sodom gbɔ.
Finally he set up his tent near Sodom.
13 Sodom ŋutsuwo nye ame vɔ̃ɖiwo, eye wowɔa nu vɔ̃ gãwo ɖe Yehowa ŋu.
13 Now the men of Sodom were wicked, gross sinners against Jehovah.

14 Esi Lot klã ɖa tso Abram gbɔ megbe la, Yehowa gblɔ na Abram be: “Meɖe kuku, fɔ mo dzi nàtsa ŋku tso afi si nèle, eye nàkpɔ dziehe, anyiehe, ɣedzeƒe kple ɣetoɖoƒe gome, 15 elabena anyigba blibo si kpɔm nèle la, wò kple wò dzidzimeviwoe mele etsɔ ge ana tegbee.

14 Jehovah said to Abram, after Lot had separated from him: “Raise your eyes, please, and look from the place where you are, to the north and south, east and west, 15 because all the land that you see, I will give to you and your offspring as a lasting possession.
16 Mana wò dzidzimeviwo nasɔ gbɔ abe kekuiwo ene, ale be ne ame aɖe ate ŋu axlẽ anyigbadzikekuiwo la, eya ko hafi wòate ŋu axlẽ wò dzidzimeviwo hã.
16 And I will make your offspring like the dust particles of the earth, so that if anyone could count the dust particles of the earth, then your offspring could be counted.
17 Tso nàtsa le anyigba la dzi nàkpɔ eƒe didime kple eƒe kekeme, elabena wòe matsɔe ana.” 18 Eye Abram yi edzi nɔ agbadɔ me.
17 Get up, travel through the length and breadth of the land, for to you I am going to give it.” 18 So Abram continued to live in tents.
Emegbe eva nɔ Mamre ƒe ati gã siwo le Hebron la te; eye wòɖi vɔsamlekpui ɖe afi ma na Yehowa.
Later he came and dwelled among the big trees of Mamre, which are in Hebron, and there he built an altar to Jehovah.
Yakob yi edzi nɔ Kanaan-nyigba si dzi fofoa nye amedzro le kpɔ la dzi.
Jacob continued to dwell in the land of Canaan, where his father had lived as a foreigner.
2 Esiae nye Yakob ƒe ŋutinya.
2 This is the history of Jacob.
Esi Yosef xɔ ƒe wuiadre la, ekpena ɖe Bilha kple Zilpa, siwo nye fofoa srɔ̃wo, ƒe viŋutsuwo ŋu wonɔa alẽwo kplɔm.
When Joseph was 17 years old, the young man was tending the flock with the sons of Bilhah and the sons of Zilpah, the wives of his father.
Eye Yosef va gblɔ nu gbegblẽ siwo wowɔ la na wo fofo.
And Joseph brought a bad report about them to their father.
3 Israel lɔ̃a Yosef wu via bubuawo katã, elabena edzii le eƒe amegãkuku me, eye wòna wotɔ awu ʋlaya tɔxɛ aɖe nɛ.
3 Now Israel loved Joseph more than all his other sons because he was the son of his old age, and he had a special robe made for him.
4 Esi nɔviawo kpɔe be yewo fofo lɔ̃nɛ wu yewo katã la, wolé fui, eye womeƒoa nu nɛ tufafatɔe o.
4 When his brothers saw that their father loved him more than all his brothers, they began to hate him, and they could not speak peaceably to him.
5 Emegbe Yosef ku drɔ̃e, eye wòlĩi na nɔviawo, ale be wogakpɔ susu bubu si ta woagalé fui ɖo.
5 Later Joseph had a dream and told it to his brothers, and they found further reason to hate him.
6 Egblɔ na wo be: “Meɖe kuku, mise drɔ̃e sia si meku la ɖa.
6 He said to them: “Please listen to this dream that I had.

7 Míele lu blam tatata le agble me, eye nye lu babla la tso hedzɔ kã, eye miaƒe lu bablawo va ƒo xlã nye lu babla la hede ta agu nɛ.” 8 Nɔviawo biae be: “Ðe nèdi be yeanye fia ɖe mía dzi ahaɖu mía dzia?”

7 There we were binding sheaves in the middle of the field when my sheaf got up and stood erect and your sheaves encircled and bowed down to my sheaf.” 8 His brothers said to him: “Are you really going to make yourself king over us and dominate us?”
Ale wogakpɔ susu bubu si ta woagalé fui ɖo le eƒe drɔ̃eawo kple nya si wògblɔ la ta.
So they found another reason to hate him, because of his dreams and what he said.
9 Ema megbe egaku drɔ̃e bubu, eye wòlĩi na nɔviawo be: “Megaku drɔ̃e bubu.
9 After that he had still another dream, and he related it to his brothers: “I have had another dream.
Fifia ya la, ɣe kple ɣleti kpakple ɣletivi wuiɖekɛ va de ta agu nam.” 10 Eye wòlĩi na fofoa kple nɔviawo siaa, eye fofoa ka mo nɛ hegblɔ nɛ be: “Drɔ̃e sia si nèku la gɔme ɖe?

This time the sun and the moon and 11 stars were bowing down to me.” 10 Then he related it to his father as well as his brothers, and his father rebuked him and said to him: “What is the meaning of this dream of yours?
Ðe nye kple dawò kpakple nɔviwòwo míava de ta agu na wòa?” 11 Eye nɔviawo ʋã ŋui, ke fofoa lé nya la ɖe susu me.
Am I as well as your mother and your brothers really going to come and bow down to the earth to you?” 11 And his brothers grew jealous of him, but his father kept the saying in mind.
12 Ke nɔviawo kplɔ wo fofo ƒe lãha la yi gbeɖuƒe le Sekem lɔƒo.
12 His brothers now went to pasture their father’s flock near Shechem.
13 Emegbe Israel gblɔ na Yosef be: “Ènya be nɔviwòwo le lãhawo kplɔm le Sekem lɔƒo ɖe?
13 Israel later said to Joseph: “Your brothers are tending flocks near Shechem, are they not?
Va madɔ wò ɖe wo gbɔ.”
Come, and let me send you to them.”
Eye wògblɔ be: “Yoo, mayi!” 14 Eye wògblɔ nɛ be: “Meɖe kuku, yi ɖakpɔ ɖa be nɔviwòwo li nyuie hã.
At this he said to him: “I am ready!” 14 So he said to him: “Go, please, and see whether your brothers are well.
Lé ŋku ɖe lãha la hã ŋu, eye nàva gblɔe nam.”
See how the flock is, and bring word back to me.”
Ale wòdɔe tso Hebron Bali la me, eye wòdze mɔ ɖo ta Sekem.
With that he sent him away from the valley of Hebron, and he went on toward Shechem.
15 Emegbe ŋutsu aɖe kpɔe wòle tsatsam le gbea dzi.
15 Later a man found him as he was wandering in a field.
Eye ŋutsua biae be: “Nu ka dim nèle?” 16 Eɖo eŋu be: “Nɔvinyewo dim mele.
The man asked him: “What are you looking for?” 16 To this he said: “I am looking for my brothers.
Meɖe kuku, afi kae wole lãhawo kplɔm le?” 17 Ŋutsua gblɔ be: “Woho dzo le afi sia. Mese wogblɔ be: ‘Mina míayi Dotan.’”
Please tell me, where are they tending flocks?” 17 The man continued: “They have pulled away from here, for I heard them saying, ‘Let us go to DOthan.’”
Eya ta Yosef ti nɔviawo yome, eye wòva tu wo le Dotan.
So Joseph went after his brothers and found them at DOthan.
18 Ke wokpɔe ɖaa le adzɔge, eye hafi wòate tu wo la, wode asi nugbeɖoɖo me ɖe eŋu be yewoawui.
18 Now they caught sight of him from a distance, and before he reached them, they began plotting against him to put him to death.
19 Eya ta wogblɔ na wo nɔewo be: “Kpɔ ɖa!
19 So they said to one another: “Look!
Drɔ̃ekulae nye ema gbɔna.
Here comes that dreamer.
20 Azɔ mina míawui, eye míakɔe aƒu gbe ɖe tsidoawo dometɔ ɖeka me, eye míagblɔ be lã wɔadã aɖee vuvui.
20 Come, now, let us kill him and pitch him into one of the waterpits, and we will say that a vicious wild animal devoured him.
Ekema míakpɔ nu si eƒe drɔ̃eawo ava zu ɖa.” 21 Esi Ruben se nya sia la, edze agbagba be yeaɖee le wo si me.
Then let us see what will become of his dreams.” 21 When Reuben heard this, he tried to rescue him from them.
Eya ta egblɔ be: “Migana míaɖe eƒe agbe ɖa o.” 22 Ruben gagblɔ na wo be: “Migakɔ ʋu ɖi o.
So he said: “Let us not take his life.” 22 Reuben said to them: “Do not shed blood.
Mikɔe ƒu gbe ɖe tsido sia si le gbea dzi la me, gake migawɔ nu vevii o.”
Throw him into this waterpit in the wilderness, but do not harm him.”
Eɖoe be yeaɖee le wo si me, ne yeagbugbɔe aɖo ɖe fofoa.
His purpose was to rescue him from them in order to return him to his father.
23 Esi Yosef nya ɖo nɔviawo gbɔ teti ko la, woɖe eƒe awu ʋlaya, awu ʋlaya tɔxɛ si wòdo la, le eŋu, 24 eye wokɔe ƒu gbe ɖe tsido la me.
23 So as soon as Joseph came to his brothers, they stripped Joseph of his robe, the special robe that he wore, 24 and they took him and threw him into the waterpit.
Ɣemaɣi la, do la le ƒuƒlu eye tsi mele eme o.
At the time the pit was empty; there was no water in it.
25 Azɔ wonɔ anyi be yewoaɖu nu.
25 Then they sat down to eat.
Esi wofɔ mo dzi la, wokpɔ Ismaeltɔ mɔzɔlawo ƒe ha aɖe tso Gilead gbɔna.
When they looked up, there was a caravan of Ishmaelites coming from Gilead.
Woƒe kposɔwo tsɔ labdano-ŋe kple balsam-mi kpakple aŋetikpa yina Egipte.
Their camels were carrying labdanum gum, balsam, and resinous bark, and they were on their way down to Egypt.
26 Eye Yuda gblɔ na nɔviawo be: “Viɖe kae wòanye ne míewu mía nɔvia hemia nu ɖe edzi? 27 Mina míadzrae na Ismaeltɔwo, eye migana míaka asi eŋu o.

26 At this Judah said to his brothers: “What profit would there be if we killed our brother and covered over his blood? 27 Come, now, let us sell him to the Ishmaelites, and do not let our hand be upon him.
Elabena mía nɔvie, míaƒe ŋutilãe.”
After all, he is our brother, our flesh.”
Eya ta woɖo to wo nɔvia.
So they listened to their brother.
28 Eye esi ŋutsu siwo nye Midiantɔ asitsalawo tso eme va yina la, woɖe Yosef le tsido la me, eye wodzrae na Ismaeltɔwo klosalo blaeve.
28 And when the Midianite merchants were passing by, they lifted Joseph up out of the waterpit and sold him to the Ishmaelites for 20 pieces of silver.
Ŋutsu siawo kplɔ Yosef yi Egipte.
These men took Joseph into Egypt.
29 Emegbe esi Ruben trɔ yi tsido la gbɔ, eye mekpɔ Yosef le tsidoa me o la, edze eƒe awuwo.
29 Later when Reuben returned to the waterpit and saw that Joseph was not in the waterpit, he ripped his garments apart.
30 Esi wòtrɔ yi nɔviawo gbɔ la, edo ɣli be: “Ðevi la megali o!
30 When he returned to his brothers, he exclaimed: “The child is gone!
Nu ka wɔ gee mala?”
And I—what am I going to do?”
31 Ke wotsɔ Yosef ƒe awu ʋlaya la, eye wowu gbɔ̃tsu hetsɔ awu ʋlaya la nyrɔ ɖe ʋua me.
31 So they took Joseph’s robe and slaughtered a male goat and dipped the robe in the blood.
32 Emegbe woɖo awu ʋlaya tɔxɛ la ɖe wo fofo gblɔ be: “Nu sia ŋue míeke ɖo.
32 After that they sent the special robe to their father and said: “This is what we found.
Míeɖe kuku, lé ŋku ɖe eŋu kpɔ be viwò ƒe awu ʋlaya lae loo alo menye eyae o hã.” 33 Eye wòlé ŋku ɖe eŋu hedo ɣli be: “Vinye ƒe awu ʋlaya lae!
Please examine whether this is your son’s robe or not.” 33 Then he examined it and exclaimed: “It is my son’s robe!
Lã wɔadã aɖee anya vuvui!
A vicious wild animal must have devoured him!
Oo, evuvu Yosef vavã!” 34 Eye Yakob dze eƒe awuwo, ta akpanya, eye wòfa konyi le via ƒe ku ta ŋkeke geɖe.
Joseph is surely torn to pieces!” 34 With that Jacob ripped his garments apart and put sackcloth around his waist and mourned his son for many days.
35 Eye viaŋutsuwo kple vianyɔnuwo katã fa akɔ nɛ ʋuu do kpoe, ke melɔ̃na wofaa akɔ nɛ o, ke boŋ egblɔna be: “Matsɔ konyifafa ayi vinyea gbɔ le Tsiẽƒe!”
35 And all his sons and all his daughters kept trying to comfort him, but he kept refusing to take comfort, saying: “I will go down into the Grave mourning my son!”
Eye fofoa fae vevie.
And his father continued weeping for him.
36 Ke Midiantɔwo yi ɖadzra Yosef le Egipte na Potifar, si nye Farao ŋu mewo dometɔ ɖeka, si nye fiaŋudzɔlawo ƒe amegã.
36 Now the Midianites sold him in Egypt to Potiphar, a court official of Pharaoh and the chief of the guard.

Le Sinar-fia Amrafel, Elasar-fia Ariok, Elam-fia Kedorlaomer kple Goim-fia Tidal ŋɔli la, 2 aʋa dzɔ ɖe fia siawo kpakple Sodom-fia Bera, Gomora-fia Birsa, Adma-fia Sinab, Zeboyim-fia Semeber kple Bela, si wogayɔna be Zoar ƒe fia dome.

Now in the days of Amraphel king of Shinar, Arioch king of Ellasar, Chedorlaomer king of Elam, and Tidal king of Goiim, 2 these made war with Bera king of Sodom, Birsha king of Gomorrah, Shinab king of Admah, Shemeber king of Zeboiim, and the king of Bela, that is, Zoar.
3 Ame siawo katã wɔ ɖeka ho yi Sidim Bali la me, si nye Dzeƒu la nu.
3 All of these joined forces at the Valley of Siddim, that is, the Salt Sea.
4 Ƒe wuieve sɔŋ wosubɔ Kedorlaomer, ke le ƒe wuietɔ̃lia me la, wodze aglã.
4 They had served Chedorlaomer for 12 years, but they rebelled in the 13th year.

5 Eye le ƒe wuienelia me la, Kedorlaomer kple fia siwo le eŋu la va si Refaimtɔwo le Asterot-Karnayim, Zuzitɔwo le Ham, Emitɔwo le Save-Kiriatayim, 6 kple Horitɔwo le woƒe to Seir dzi, va se ɖe El-Paran, si gogo gbegbe la.

5 So in the 14th year, Chedorlaomer and the kings who were with him came and defeated the Rephaim in Ashteroth-karnAim, the Zuzim in Ham, the Emim in Shaveh-kiriathAim, 6 and the Horites in their mountain of Seir down to El-paran, which is at the wilderness.
7 Eye wotrɔ heva En-Mispat si nye Kades, eye wosi Amalektɔwo ƒe nuto bliboa katã kple Amoritɔ siwo le Hazazon-Tamar hã.
7 Then they turned back and came to En-mishpat, that is, Kadesh, and conquered the whole territory of the Amalekites and also the Amorites who were dwelling in Hazazon-Tamar.

8 Eye Sodom-fia, Gomora-fia, Adma-fia, Zeboyim-fia kple Bela, si wogayɔna be Zoar ƒe fia ho le aʋalɔgowo me, eye wodze aʋa ɖe wo ŋu le Sidim Bali la me, 9 ɖe Elam-fia Kedorlaomer, Goim-fia Tidal, Sinar-fia Amrafel, kple Elasar-fia Ariok ŋu; fia ene ɖe fia atɔ̃awo ŋu.

8 At this point, the king of Sodom went on the march, and also the king of Gomorrah, the king of Admah, the king of Zeboiim, and the king of Bela, that is, Zoar, and they drew up in battle formation against them in the Valley of Siddim, 9 against Chedorlaomer king of Elam, Tidal king of Goiim, Amraphel king of Shinar, and Arioch king of Ellasar —four kings against the five.
10 Ke aŋɔʋe geɖewo le Sidim Bali la me, eye esi Sodom kple Gomora-fiawo si yina la, woge dze aŋɔʋeawo me, eye ame susɔeawo si yi tonuto la me.
10 Now the Valley of Siddim was full of bitumen pits, and the kings of Sodom and Gomorrah tried to escape and fell into them, and those who remained fled to the mountainous region.
11 Eye aʋadziɖulawo lɔ Sodom kple Gomora ƒe nuwo katã kple woƒe nuɖuɖuwo katã dzoe.
11 Then the victors took all the goods of Sodom and Gomorrah and all their food and went on their way.
12 Wokplɔ Abram nɔviŋutsu ƒe vi Lot si nɔ Sodom ɣemaɣi la hã dzoe, eye wolɔ eƒe nunɔamesiwo.
12 They also took Lot, the son of Abram’s brother who was dwelling in Sodom, as well as his goods, and they continued on their way.
13 Emegbe ŋutsu aɖe sí va gblɔ nu si dzɔ la na Hebritɔ Abram.
13 After that a man who had escaped came and told Abram the Hebrew.
Ɣemaɣi la, etu eƒe agbadɔ ɖe Amoritɔ Mamre ƒe ati gãwo te. Mamre nye Eskol kple Aner nɔvi.
He was then dwelling among the big trees of Mamre the Amorite, the brother of Eshcol and Aner.
Ame siawo bla nu kple Abram.
These men were allies of Abram.
14 Ale Abram se be woɖe aboyo ye nɔvi.
14 Thus Abram heard that his relative had been taken captive.
Eye wòƒo eƒe subɔviŋutsu xɔhehe siwo wodzi le eƒe aƒe me la nu ƒu; wole ame alafa etɔ̃ wuienyi, eye wòti wo yome yi keke Dan ke.
With that he mobilized his trained men, 318 servants born in his household, and went in pursuit up to Dan.
15 Eye le zã me la, ema eƒe aʋawɔlawo me, eye eya kple eƒe subɔviwo dze wo dzi hesi wo.
15 During the night, he divided his forces, and he and his servants attacked and defeated them.
Eye wòti wo yome yi keke Hoba si le Damasko ƒe dziehe ke.
And he pursued them up to HObah, which is north of Damascus.
16 Eye wòxɔ nuawo katã; exɔ nɔvia Lot kple eƒe nunɔamesiwo, nyɔnuawo kple ame bubuawo hã.
16 He recovered all the goods, and he also recovered Lot his relative, his goods, the women, and the other people.
17 Esi Abram ɖu Kedorlaomer kple fia siwo le eŋu dzi hetrɔ gbɔna la, Sodom-fia yi ɖakpee le Save Bali, si woyɔna be Fiabali la me.
17 After Abram returned from defeating Chedorlaomer and the kings who were with him, the king of Sodom went out to meet Abram at the Valley of ShAveh, that is, the Valley of the King.
18 Eye Salem-fia Melkizedek tsɔ abolo kple wain vɛ; ame sia nye Mawu Dziƒoʋĩtɔ la ƒe nunɔla.
18 And Melchizedek king of SAlem brought out bread and wine; he was priest of the Most High God.
19 Eye wòyrae gblɔ be:
19 Then he blessed him and said:
“Mawu Dziƒoʋĩtɔ la, Ame si wɔ dziƒo kple anyigba,
“Blessed be Abram by the Most High God,
Nayra Abram;
Maker of heaven and earth;
20 Woakafu Mawu Dziƒoʋĩtɔ la,
20 And praised be the Most High God,
Ame si tsɔ wò futɔwo de asi na wò!”
Who has handed your oppressors over to you!”
Eye Abram tsɔ nuawo katã ƒe ewolia nɛ.
And Abram gave him a tenth of everything.

21 Emegbe Sodom-fia gblɔ na Abram be: “Tsɔ ameawo nam, ne wò ŋutɔ nàtsɔ nuawo.” 22 Ke Abram gblɔ na Sodom-fia be: “Mekɔ nye asi dzi le atam kam na Yehowa, Mawu Dziƒoʋĩtɔ la, Ame si wɔ dziƒo kple anyigba, 23 be nyemaxɔ wò naneke o, nyemaxɔ ka ʋuu keke ahayi afɔkpaka xɔ ge o, ne nàva gblɔ be, ‘Nyee na Abram zu kesinɔtɔ o.’ 24 Nyemaxɔ naneke o, negbe nu si ɖekakpuiawo ɖu xoxo la ko.

21 After that the king of Sodom said to Abram: “Give me the people, but take the goods for yourself.” 22 But Abram said to the king of Sodom: “I raise my hand in an oath to Jehovah the Most High God, Maker of heaven and earth, 23 that I will not take anything that is yours, from a thread to a sandal lace, so that you may not say, ‘I made Abram rich.’ 24 I will take nothing except what the young men have already eaten.
Ke tsɔ Aner, Eskol kple Mamre, ame siwo yi kplim la, tɔ gome na wo.”
As for the share of the men who went with me, Aner, Eshcol, and Mamre —let them take their share.”
Le esia megbe la, Yehowa ƒe gbe va na Abram le ŋutega me be: “Abram, mègavɔ̃ o.
After this the word of Jehovah came to Abram in a vision, saying: “Do not fear, Abram.
Nyee nye wò akpoxɔnu.
I am a shield for you.

Wò fetu asɔ gbɔ ŋutɔ.” 2 Abram ɖo eŋu be: “Aƒetɔ Dziɖulagã Yehowa, esi vi mele asinye o, eye Eliezer, Damaskotɔ lae ava nyi nye dome ɖe, ke nu ka na ge nèlem?” 3 Eye Abram gblɔ kpee be: “Mèna vi aɖekem o, eye aƒenyemetɔ aɖee ava nyi nye dome.” 4 Yehowa ɖo eŋu nɛ be, “Ame sia manyi wò dome o, ke boŋ wò ŋutɔ viwòe anyi wò dome.”

Your reward will be very great.” 2 Abram replied: “Sovereign Lord Jehovah, what will you give me, seeing that I continue childless and the one who will inherit my house is a man of Damascus, eliezer?” 3 Abram added: “You have given me no offspring, and a member of my household is succeeding me as heir.” 4 But look! Jehovah’s word in reply to him was, “This man will not succeed you as heir, but your own son will succeed you as heir.”
5 Eye wòkplɔe do goe gblɔ nɛ be: “Meɖe kuku, fɔ mo dzi nàkpɔ dziƒo, eye ne àte ŋu axlẽ ɣletiviwo la, ekema xlẽ wo.”
5 He now brought him outside and said: “Look up, please, to the heavens and count the stars, if you are able to do so.”
Eye wògagblɔ nɛ be: “Aleae wò dzidzimeviwo ava nɔ.” 6 Abram xɔ Yehowa dzi se, eye Mawu bui dzɔdzɔenyenye nɛ.
Then he said to him: “So your offspring will become.” 6 And he put faith in Jehovah, and He counted it to him as righteousness.

7 Eye wògblɔ kpee be: “Nyee nye Yehowa, ame si kplɔ wò tso Ur, le Kaldea-nyigba dzi, be matsɔ anyigba sia ana wò wòazu tɔwò.” 8 Eye wòbia be: “Aƒetɔ Dziɖulagã Yehowa, aleke mawɔ anya be ava zu tɔnye?” 9 Eɖo eŋu nɛ be: “Tsɔ nyinɔ si xɔ ƒe etɔ̃, gbɔ̃nɔ si xɔ ƒe etɔ̃, agbo si xɔ ƒe etɔ̃, akpakpa ɖeka kple ahɔnɛvi ɖeka vɛ nam.” 10 Eye wòtsɔ lã siawo katã hefe wo me ɖe eve, eye wòtsɔ ɖe sia ɖe ƒe akpa ɖeka ɖo evelia ŋu wòsɔ ɖe enu, ke mefe xeawo ya me o.

7 Then he added: “I am Jehovah, who brought you out of Ur of the Chaldeans to give you this land as your possession.” 8 To this he said: “Sovereign Lord Jehovah, how will I know that I will take possession of it?” 9 He replied to him: “Take for me a three-year-old heifer, a three-year-old female goat, a three-year-old ram, a turtledove, and a young pigeon.” 10 So he took all of these and cut them in two and put each part opposite the other, but he did not cut up the birds.
11 Eye xe ƒonuwo va le dzedzem ɖe lã kukuawo dzi, ke Abram nɔ wo nyam.
11 Then the birds of prey began to descend on the carcasses, but Abram kept driving them away.
12 Esi wòsusɔ vie ɣe naɖo to la, Abram dɔ alɔ̃ yi eme ʋĩi, eye viviti tsiɖitsiɖi dziŋɔ aɖe do ɖee.
12 When the sun was about to set, a deep sleep fell upon Abram and a great and frightening darkness descended on him.
13 Eye Mawu gblɔ na Abram be: “Nyae kɔtɛe be, wò dzidzimeviwo ava zu amedzrowo le dzronyigba dzi, anyigba ma dzi tɔwo awɔ wo kluviwoe eye woawɔ fu wo ƒe alafa ene sɔŋ.
13 Then He said to Abram: “Know for certain that your offspring will be foreigners in a land not theirs and that the people there will enslave them and afflict them for 400 years.
14 Gake madrɔ̃ ʋɔnu dukɔ si woasubɔ la, eye emegbe woatsɔ nunɔamesi geɖewo adzoe.
14 But I will judge the nation they will serve, and after that they will go out with many goods.
15 Ke wò la, ànɔ agbe atsi nyuie, àku le ŋutifafa me, eye woatsɔ wò akpe ɖe tɔgbuiwòwo ŋu.
15 As for you, you will go to your forefathers in peace; you will be buried at a good old age.
16 Ke ne eɖo dzidzime enelia dzi la, woagatrɔ ava afi sia, elabena Amoritɔwo ƒe vodadawo mesɔ gbɔ haɖe na tohehe o.”
16 But they will return here in the fourth generation, because the error of the Amorites has not yet reached its full measure.”
17 Azɔ esi ɣe ɖo to, eye viviti tsiɖitsiɖi aɖe do la, kpo si me dzudzɔ le tutum le kɔlikɔli kple akakati si le bibim la va to lã fefeawo dome.
17 When the sun had set and it had become very dark, a smoking furnace appeared, and a fiery torch passed between the pieces.

18 Gbe ma gbee Yehowa bla nu kple Abram gblɔ be: “Wò dzidzimeviwoe matsɔ anyigba sia ana, tso Egipte-tɔsisi la nu va ɖo tɔsisi gã, si nye Frat-tɔsisi la nu: 19 Kenitɔwo, Kenizitɔwo, Kadmonitɔwo, 20 Hititɔwo, Perizitɔwo, Refaimtɔwo, 21 Amoritɔwo, Kanaantɔwo, Girgasitɔwo kple Yebusitɔwo ƒe anyigba.”

18 On that day Jehovah made with Abram a covenant, saying: “To your offspring I will give this land, from the river of Egypt to the great river, the river EuphrAtes: 19 the land of the Kenites, the Kenizzites, the Kadmonites, 20 the Hittites, the Perizzites, the RephAim, 21 the Amorites, the Canaanites, the GirgAshites, and the Jebusites.” At this Joseph could no longer control himself before all his attendants.
Ale Israel tsɔ nu siwo katã le esi la eye wòdze mɔ.
So he cried out: “Have everyone leave me!”
Esi wòva ɖo Beer-Seba la, esa vɔ na fofoa Isak ƒe Mawu la.
No one else stayed with him while Joseph made himself known to his brothers.
2 Eye Mawu yɔ Israel le ŋutega me le zã me be: “Yakob, Yakob!”
2 Then he began to weep so loudly that the Egyptians heard it and Pharaoh’s house heard it.
Etɔ be: “Nyee nye esi!” 3 Eye wògblɔ nɛ be: “Nyee nye Mawu vavã la, fofowò ƒe Mawu la.
3 Finally Joseph said to his brothers: “I am Joseph. Is my father still alive?”
Mègavɔ̃ Egipte yiyi o, elabena mana nàzu dukɔ gã aɖe le afi ma.
But his brothers were unable to answer him at all, because they were astonished on account of him.
4 Nye ŋutɔ mayi Egipte kpli wò, eye nye ŋutɔ magakplɔ wò tso afi ma agbɔe, eye Yosef ƒe asie amia wò ŋkuwo.”
4 So Joseph said to his brothers: “Come close to me, please.” With that they came close to him.
5 Ema megbe Yakob dzo le Beer-Seba, eye Israel viŋutsuwo kɔ wo fofo Yakob kple wo viwo kpakple wo srɔ̃wo ɖe tasiaɖam siwo Farao ɖo ɖa be woatsɔ akɔ woe la me.

Then he said: “I am Joseph your brother, whom you sold into Egypt. 5 But now do not be upset and do not reproach one another because you sold me here; because God has sent me ahead of you for the preservation of life.
6 Wokplɔ woƒe lãhawo hã, eye wotsɔ nu siwo su wo si le Kanaan-nyigba dzi la dzoe. Ale Yakob kple viawo katã va Egipte.
6 This is the second year of the famine in the land, and there are yet five years in which there will be no plowing or harvest.
7 Ekplɔ viaŋutsuwo kple eƒe tɔgbuiyɔviŋutsuwo kple vianyɔnuwo kple eƒe tɔgbuiyɔvinyɔnuwo yi Egipte; ekplɔ eƒe dzidzimeviwo katã yii.
7 But God sent me ahead of you in order to preserve for you a remnant on the earth and to keep you alive by a great deliverance.
8 Ke Israel, si wogayɔna be Yakob, ƒe viŋutsu siwo va Egipte la ƒe ŋkɔwoe nye esi: Yakob ƒe ŋgɔgbevie nye Ruben.
8 So, then, it was not you who sent me here, but it was the true God, in order to appoint me as chief adviser to Pharaoh and lord for all his house and ruler over all the land of Egypt.
9 Ruben viŋutsuwoe nye Hanok, Palu, Hezron kple Karmi.
9 “Return quickly to my father, and you must say to him, ‘This is what your son Joseph has said: “God has appointed me lord over all Egypt. Come down to me. Do not delay.
10 Simeon viŋutsuwoe nye Yemuel, Yamin, Ohad, Yakin, Zohar, kple Saul, si Kanaan nyɔnu aɖe dzi.
10 You must dwell in the land of GOshen, where you will be near me—you, your sons, your grandsons, your flocks, your herds, and everything you have.
11 Lewi viŋutsuwoe nye Gerson, Kohat kple Merari.
11 I will supply you with food there, for there are yet five years of famine.
12 Yuda viŋutsuwoe nye Er, Onan, Sela, Perez kple Zera. Ke Er kple Onan ku le Kanaan-nyigba dzi. Perez viŋutsuwoe nye Hezron kple Hamul.
Otherwise, you and your house and everything you have will come to poverty.”’ 12 You and my brother Benjamin can now see with your own eyes that I am really the one speaking to you.
13 Isakar viŋutsuwoe nye Tola, Puwa, Yob kple Simron.
13 So you must tell my father about all my glory in Egypt and everything you have seen.
14 Zebulon viŋutsuwoe nye Sered, Elon kple Yahlel.
14 Then he embraced his brother Benjamin and gave way to weeping, and Benjamin wept with his arms around his neck.
15 Ame siawoe nye Lea viŋutsu siwo wòdzi na Yakob le Padan-Aram hekpe ɖe vianyɔnu Dina ŋu.
15 And he kissed all his brothers and wept over them, and after that his brothers spoke with him.
16 Gad viŋutsuwoe nye Zifion, Hagi, Suni, Ezbon, Eri, Arodi kple Areli.
16 The news reached the house of Pharaoh: “Joseph’s brothers have come!”
Beria viŋutsuwoe nye Heber kple Malkiel.
It was good in the eyes of Pharaoh and his servants.
18 Ame siawoe nye Zilpa, si Laban tsɔ na via Lea la, ƒe viŋutsuwo. Ame siawoe wòdzi na Yakob: wole ame wuiade.
17 So Pharaoh said to Joseph: “Tell your brothers, ‘Do this: Load your beasts of burden and go to the land of Canaan, 18 and take your father and your households and come here to me.
19 Yakob srɔ̃ Rahel viŋutsuwoe nye Yosef kple Benyamin.

I will give you the good things of the land of Egypt, and you will eat the richest part of the land.’ 19 And you are commanded to tell them: ‘Do this: Take wagons from the land of Egypt for your children and your wives, and you must bring your father on one of them and come here.
20 Wodzi Manase kple Efrayim na Yosef le Egipte-nyigba dzi; ame siawoe On nunɔla Potifera ƒe vi Asenat dzi nɛ.
20 Do not worry about your belongings, for the best of all the land of Egypt is yours.’”
21 Benyamin viŋutsuwoe nye Bela, Beker, Asbel, Gera, Naaman, Ehi, Ros, Mupim, Hupim kple Ard.
21 And the sons of Israel did so, and Joseph gave them wagons according to Pharaoh’s orders, and he gave them provisions for the journey.
22 Esiawoe nye viŋutsu siwo Rahel dzi na Yakob: wo katã le ame wuiene.
22 To each of them he gave individual changes of clothing, but to Benjamin he gave 300 silver pieces and five changes of clothing.
23 Dan viŋutsue nye Husim.
23 And to his father he sent the following: ten donkeys carrying good things of Egypt and ten female donkeys carrying grain and bread and sustenance for his father for the journey.
24 Naftali viŋutsuwoe nye Yahzel, Guni, Yezer, kple Silem.
24 So he sent his brothers off, and as they departed, he said to them: “Do not become upset with one another on the way.”
25 Ame siawoe nye Bilha, si Laban tsɔ na via Rahel la, ƒe viŋutsuwo. Ame siawoe wòdzi na Yakob: wo katã le ame adre.
25 Then they went up from Egypt and came into the land of Canaan to their father Jacob.
26 Ame siwo katã wodzi na Yakob, siwo katã ʋu kplii yi Egipte, ne woɖe viaŋutsuwo srɔ̃wo le eme la, le blaade vɔ ade.
26 Then they reported to him: “Joseph is still alive, and he is the ruler over all the land of Egypt!” But his heart grew numb because he did not believe them.
27 Viŋutsu siwo wodzi na Yosef le Egipte la le ame eve. Ame siwo katã tso Yakob ƒe me va Egipte la le blaadre.
27 When they went on telling him all the words that Joseph had spoken to them and when he saw the wagons that Joseph had sent to carry him, the spirit of their father Jacob began to revive.
28 Yakob dɔ Yuda ɖe eŋgɔ ɖe Yosef gbɔ, be wòagblɔ nɛ be yele mɔ dzi ɖo ta Gosen.
28 Israel exclaimed: “It is enough!
Esi wòkpɔe la, enumake ekpla asi kɔ nɛ hefa avi ʋuu.
My son Joseph is still alive!
30 Eye Israel gblɔ na Yosef be: “Azɔ mate ŋu aku faa; mekpɔ wò ŋkume, eye menya be ègale agbe.”
I must go and see him before I die!”
Eye Yakob hã gayi eƒe mɔzɔzɔa dzi, eye Mawu ƒe dɔlawo va do goe.
Jacob then went on his way, and the angels of God met up with him.
2 Esi Yakob kpɔ wo la, egblɔ enumake be: “Mawu ƒe asaɖae nye esia!”
2 As soon as he saw them, Jacob said: “This is the camp of God!”
Eya ta ena ŋkɔ teƒe ma be Mahanayim.
So he named that place MAhAnAim.

3 Eye Yakob dɔ amewo ɖo ɖe eŋgɔ ɖe nɔvia Esau gbɔ le Seir-nyigba, si nye Edom-nyigba la dzi, 4 eye wòde se na wo be: “Ale miagblɔ na nye aƒetɔ Esau ye nye esi, ‘Ale wò dɔla Yakob gblɔe nye esi: “Menɔ Laban gbɔ ʋuu va se ɖe fifia.

3 Then Jacob sent messengers ahead of him to his brother Esau in the land of Seir, the territory of Edom, 4 and he commanded them: “This is what you will say to my lord, to Esau, ‘This is what your servant Jacob says: “I have resided with Laban for a long time until now.
5 Nyiwo kple tedziwo, alẽwo kple subɔviŋutsuwo kpakple subɔvinyɔnuwo va su asinye, eye medɔ ame be woava gblɔe na nye aƒetɔ be nàve nunye.”’”
5 And I have acquired bulls, donkeys, sheep, and male and female servants, and I send this message to inform my lord, in order to find favor in your eyes.”’”
6 Emegbe ame dɔdɔawo gbugbɔ va Yakob gbɔ gblɔ be: “Míedo go nɔviwò Esau, eye edze mɔ gbɔna kpe wò ge, eye ŋutsu alafa ene le eŋu.” 7 Eye Yakob vɔ̃ ŋutɔ hetsi dzodzodzoe.
6 In time the messengers returned to Jacob, saying: “We met your brother Esau, and he is now on his way to meet you, and there are 400 men with him.” 7 And Jacob became very frightened and anxious.
Eya ta ema eƒe amewo kple alẽhawo kple nyiawo kpakple kposɔawo ɖe hatsotso eve me.
So he divided the people who were with him, as well as the flocks, the cattle, and the camels, into two camps.
8 Eye wògblɔ be: “Ne Esau dze hatsotso ɖeka dzi la, ekema hatsotso evelia asi adzo.”
8 He said: “If Esau attacks the one camp, then the other camp will be able to escape.”

9 Emegbe Yakob gblɔ be: “Oo, fofonye Abraham ƒe Mawu kple fofonye Isak ƒe Mawu, Oo Yehowa, wò, ame si gblɔ nam be, ‘Trɔ yi wò anyigba dzi kple ƒowòmeawo gbɔ, eye mawɔ nyui na wò,’ 10 nyemedze na lɔlɔ̃ gã si nèɖe fiam kple ale si gbegbe nèwɔ nuteƒe na wò subɔla la o, elabena nye atizɔti koe nɔ asinye esi metso Yordan, ke azɔ meva zu hatsotso eve.

9 After that Jacob said: “O God of my father Abraham and God of my father Isaac, O Jehovah, you who are saying to me, ‘Return to your land and to your relatives, and I will deal well with you,’ 10 I am unworthy of all the loyal love and of all the faithfulness that you have shown toward your servant, for with only my staff I crossed this Jordan and now I have become two camps.
11 Meɖe kuku, ɖem tso nɔvinye Esau si me, elabena mele vɔvɔ̃m be ava dze nye kple vinɔawo kple wo viwo siaa dzi.
11 Save me, I pray you, from the hand of my brother Esau, for I am afraid of him that he may come and attack me, as well as the mothers and their children.
12 Evɔ wò ŋutɔ ègblɔ be: ‘Mawɔ nyui na wò godoo, eye mana wò dzidzimeviwo nanɔ abe ƒutake, si sɔ gbɔ ale gbegbe be womate ŋu axlẽe o la ene.’”
12 And you have said: ‘I will certainly deal well with you, and I will make your offspring like the grains of sand of the sea, which are too numerous to count.’”
13 Eye wòtsi afi ma dɔ.
13 And he spent the night there.

Eye wòɖe nunana tso nu siwo su esi la me ɖo ɖe nɔvia Esau: 14 gbɔ̃nɔ alafa eve kple gbɔ̃tsu blaeve, alẽnɔ alafa eve kple agbo blaeve, 15 kposɔ blaetɔ̃ siwo le no nam wo viwo, nyinɔ blaene kple nyitsu ewo, tedzinɔ blaeve kple tedzitsu ewo.

Then he took some of his possessions as a gift for Esau his brother: 14 200 female goats, 20 male goats, 200 female sheep, 20 rams, 15 30 camels nursing their young, 40 cows, 10 bulls, 20 female donkeys and 10 full-grown male donkeys.

16 Eye wòtsɔ lãha vovovoawo de asi na eƒe subɔviwo hatsotso hatsotso, eye wògblɔ na eƒe subɔviawo be: “Midze ŋgɔnye miayi aɖatso tɔa, eye mina dometsotso nanɔ lãha kple lãha dome.” 17 Ede se hã na gbãtɔ be: “Ne nɔvinye Esau do go wò, eye wòbia wò be, ‘Ame ka ƒe amee nènye, afi ka yim nèle, eye ame ka ƒe nuwoe nye esiawo le ŋgɔwò?’ hã la, 18 ekema nàgblɔ be: ‘Wò dɔla Yakob tɔe.

16 He handed them over to his servants, one drove after another, and he said to his servants: “Cross over ahead of me, and you are to set a space between one drove and the next.” 17 He also commanded the first one: “In case Esau my brother should meet you and ask, ‘To whom do you belong, and where are you going, and to whom do these ahead of you belong?’ 18 then you should say, ‘To your servant Jacob.

Nunanae wònye wòɖo ɖe nye aƒetɔ Esau, eye kpɔ ɖa, eya ŋutɔ hã le mía megbe gbɔna.’” 19 Eye wòde se na evelia, na etɔ̃lia, kple ame siwo katã dze lãhaawo yome hã be: “Alea tututu miagblɔ na Esau ne miedo goe.

It is a gift sent to my lord, to Esau, and look! he himself is also behind us.’” 19 And he commanded also the second, the third, and all those following the droves: “According to this word, you are to speak to Esau when you meet him.
20 Eye migblɔ hã be, ‘Wò dɔla Yakob le mía megbe gbɔna.’”
20 And you should also say, ‘Here is your servant Jacob behind us.’”
Elabena egblɔ be: ‘Ne metsɔ nunanawo do ŋgɔ ɖo ɖee tsɔ kpatae, eye meva kpɔe emegbe la, ɖewohĩ axɔm nyuie.’ 21 Ale wotsɔ nunana la tso tɔa dze eŋgɔ, ke eya ŋutɔ tsi asaɖa la me dɔ le zã ma me.

For he said to himself: ‘If I appease him by sending a gift ahead of me, then afterward when I see him, he may give me a kindly reception.’ 21 So the gift crossed over ahead of him, but he himself spent the night in the camp.
22 Emegbe efɔ le zã ma me, eye wòkplɔ srɔ̃a eveawo kple eƒe subɔvinyɔnu eveawo hekpe ɖe viaŋutsuvi wuiɖekɛawo ŋu, eye wòtso tɔa le Yabok tɔtsoƒe la.
22 Later during that night, he rose and took his two wives and his two female servants and his 11 young sons and crossed over the ford of Jabbok.
23 Eye wòkplɔ wo hekpe ɖe nu siwo le esi la ŋu tso tɔ la.
23 So he took them and brought them across the stream, and he brought over everything else he had.
24 Mlɔeba Yakob ɖeka susɔ.
24 Finally Jacob was left by himself.
Eye ŋutsu aɖe va te kame kplii ʋuu, va se ɖe esime agu dze.
Then a man began to wrestle with him until the dawn broke.
25 Esi ŋutsu la kpɔ be yemete ŋu kpe edzi o la, etɔ asi eƒe aligokpeƒe; eye Yakob ƒe aligokpeƒe gli esi wòle kame tem kplii.
25 When he saw that he had not prevailed over him, he touched the socket of his hip; and the socket of Jacob’s hip was dislocated during his wrestling with him.
26 Emegbe egblɔ be: “Ðe asi le ŋunye madzo, elabena agu le dzedzem.”
26 After that he said: “Let me go, for the dawn is breaking.”

Eɖo eŋu be: “Nyemele asi ɖe ge le ŋuwò nàdzo o, va se ɖe esime nèyram hafi.” 27 Eya ta ebiae be: “Ŋkɔwò ɖe?” Eɖo eŋu be: “Yakob.” 28 Eye wògblɔ be: “Womagayɔ wò be Yakob azɔ o, ke boŋ Israel, elabena ète kame kple Mawu kpakple amegbetɔ, eye nète ŋui.” 29 Eye Yakob hã biae be: “Meɖe kuku, ŋkɔwò ɖe?”

To this he said: “I am not going to let you go until you bless me.” 27 So he said to him: “What is your name?” to which he said: “Jacob.” 28 Then he said: “Your name will no longer be Jacob but Israel, for you have contended with God and with men and you have at last prevailed.” 29 In turn Jacob inquired: “Tell me, please, your name.”
Ke egblɔ be: “Nu ka tae nèle nye ŋkɔ ta biam?”
However, he said: “Why is it that you ask my name?”
Eye wòyrae le afi ma.
With that he blessed him there.
30 Eya ta Yakob na ŋkɔ teƒea be Peniel, elabena egblɔ be: “Mekpɔ Mawu ŋkume kple ŋkume, gake metsi agbe.”
30 So Jacob named the place Peniel, for he said, “I have seen God face-to-face, yet my life was preserved.”
31 Ke esi wòɖe Penuel ɖe megbe teti la, ɣe dze ɖee, gake enɔ tɔtɔm le eƒe alia ta.
31 And the sun rose upon him as soon as he passed by Penuel, but he was limping because of his hip.
32 Esia tae Israel-viwo meɖua ka titri si le lãwo ƒe aligokpeƒe la o va se ɖe egbe, elabena etɔ asi ka titri si le Yakob ƒe aligokpeƒe. Le nu siawo megbe la, Mawu vavã la do Abraham kpɔ.

32 That is why to this day the sons of Israel are not accustomed to eat the thigh sinew, which is on the socket of the hip joint, because he touched the socket of Jacob’s hip joint by the thigh sinew.

Eyɔe be: “Abraham!” Eye wòtɔ be: “Nyee nye esi!” 2 Egblɔ be: “Meɖe kuku, kplɔ viwò, wò tenuvi Isak, si nèlɔ̃ vevie la, nàyi Moriya-nyigba dzi, eye nàtsɔe asa numevɔ le afi ma le toawo dometɔ ɖeka si mafia wò la dzi.”

Now after this the true God put Abraham to the test, and he said to him: “Abraham!” to which he replied: “Here I am!” 2 Then he said: “Take, please, your son, your only son whom you so love, Isaac, and travel to the land of MOriah and offer him up there as a burnt offering on one of the mountains that I will designate to you.”
3 Eya ta Abraham fɔ ŋdi kanya, bla akpa na eƒe tedzi, eye wòkplɔ eƒe subɔvi eve kple via Isak kpe ɖe eɖokui ŋu.
3 So Abraham got up early in the morning and saddled his donkey and took two of his servants along with him and his son Isaac.
Edze nake ɖe numevɔsa la ŋu, eye wòtso hedze mɔ yi teƒe si Mawu vavã la fiae la.
He split the wood for the burnt offering, and then he rose and traveled to the place that the true God indicated to him.
4 Esi Abraham fɔ mo dzi le ŋkeke etɔ̃a gbe la, ekpɔ teƒe la le adzɔge ɖaa.
4 On the third day, Abraham looked up and saw the place from a distance.
5 Eye Abraham gblɔ na eƒe subɔviawo be: “Minɔ afi sia kple tedzi la, ke nye kple ɖevi la míayi ŋgɔ vie aɖade ta agu atrɔ ava mia gbɔ.”
5 Abraham now said to his servants: “You stay here with the donkey, but the boy and I will go over there and worship and return to you.”
6 Eya ta Abraham tsɔ numevɔsa ƒe nake la ɖo ta na via Isak.
6 So Abraham took the wood for the burnt offering and put it on his son Isaac.
Etsɔ dzo kple hɛ ɖe asi, eye wo kple evea woyi azɔlia dzi.
Then he took in his hands the fire and the knife, and the two of them walked on together.
7 Eye Isak yɔ fofoa Abraham be: “Fofonye!”
7 Then Isaac said to his father Abraham: “My father!”
Etɔ be: “Nyee nye esi, vinye!”
He replied: “Yes, my son!”
Eye wòbiae be: “Dzo kple nakee nye esi, ke afi kae alẽ si míatsɔ asa numevɔae la le?” 8 Abraham ɖo eŋu be: “Vinye, Mawu ŋutɔ ana alẽ si míatsɔ asa numevɔ lae mí.”
So he continued: “Here are the fire and the wood, but where is the sheep for the burnt offering?” 8 To this Abraham said: “God himself will provide the sheep for the burnt offering, my son.”
Ale wo ame evea wogayi mɔzɔzɔa dzi.
And both of them walked on together.
9 Mlɔeba wova ɖo teƒe si Mawu vavã la fiae la, eye Abraham ɖi vɔsamlekpui ɖe afi ma eye wòɖo nakea ɖe edzi.
9 Finally they reached the place that the true God had indicated to him, and Abraham built an altar there and arranged the wood on it.
Ebla via Isak ƒe asiwo kple afɔwo eye wòtsɔe ɖo nakea dzi le vɔsamlekpuia dzi.
He bound his son Isaac hand and foot and put him on the altar on top of the wood.
10 Eyome Abraham do asi ɖa tsɔ hɛ la be yeawu ye via.
10 Then Abraham reached out his hand and took the knife to kill his son.

11 Ke Yehowa ƒe dɔla yɔe tso dziƒo be: “Abraham, Abraham!” Etɔ be: “Nyee nye esi!” 12 Eye wògblɔ be: “Mègaka asi ɖevi la ŋu o, eye mègawɔ nanekee o, elabena menyae azɔ be mawuvɔ̃lae nènye, elabena mète viwò, wò tenuvi lam o.” 13 Eye Abraham fɔ mo dzi, eye kaka wòakpɔ la, agbo aɖee nye ema si ƒe dzowo ku avekawo le eŋgɔ.

11 But Jehovah’s angel called to him from the heavens and said: “Abraham, Abraham!” to which he answered: “Here I am!” 12 Then he said: “Do not harm the boy, and do not do anything at all to him, for now I do know that you are God-fearing because you have not withheld your son, your only one, from me.” 13 At that Abraham looked up, and there just beyond him was a ram caught by its horns in a thicket.
Eye Abraham yi ɖalé agbo la tsɔ sa numevɔ ɖe via teƒe.
So Abraham went and took the ram and offered it up as a burnt offering in place of his son.
14 Eye Abraham na ŋkɔ teƒe ma be Yehowa-Yire.
14 And Abraham named that place JehOvah-jireh.
Esia tae wogblɔna va se ɖe egbegbe be: “Woana le Yehowa ƒe to la dzi.”
This is why it is still said today: “In the mountain of Jehovah it will be provided.”

15 Eye Yehowa ƒe dɔla yɔ Abraham zi evelia tso dziƒo 16 gblɔ be: “Yehowa be, ‘Metà ɖokuinye be, esi nèwɔ esia, be mète viwò, wò tenuvi, lam o ta la, 17 mayra wò godoo, eye mana wò dzidzimevi nasɔ gbɔ abe dziƒoɣletiviwo kple ƒutake ene; wò dzidzimevi axɔ eƒe futɔwo ƒe duwo woazu etɔ.

15 And Jehovah’s angel called to Abraham a second time from the heavens, 16 saying: “‘By myself I swear,’ declares Jehovah, ‘that because you have done this and you have not withheld your son, your only one, 17 I will surely bless you and I will surely multiply your offspring like the stars of the heavens and like the grains of sand on the seashore, and your offspring will take possession of the gate of his enemies.
18 Eye anyigbadziƒomeawo katã axɔ yayra to wò dzidzimevi la dzi, elabena èɖo to nye gbe.’”
18 And by means of your offspring all nations of the earth will obtain a blessing for themselves because you have listened to my voice.’”
19 Emegbe Abraham trɔ va eƒe subɔviawo gbɔ; ale wotso, eye wo katã wotrɔ yi Beer-Seba; eye Abraham yi edzi nɔ Beer-Seba.
19 After that Abraham returned to his servants, and they got up and went back together to Beer-sheba; and Abraham continued to dwell at Beer-sheba.

20 Emegbe wova ka eta na Abraham be: “Kpɔ ɖa, Milka hã dzi viwo na nɔviwò Nahor: 21 eƒe ŋgɔgbevie nye Uz, nɔviae nye Buz kple Kemuel, si nye Aram fofo, 22 Kesed, Hazo, Pildas, Yidlaf kple Betuel.” 23 Betuel dzi Rebeka.

20 After this it was reported to Abraham: “Here Milcah has also borne sons to Nahor your brother: 21 Uz his firstborn, Buz his brother, Kemuel the father of Aram, 22 Chesed, HAzo, Pildash, Jidlaph, and Bethuel.” 23 Bethuel became the father of Rebekah.
Ame enyi siawoe Milka dzi na Abraham nɔvi Nahor.
Milcah bore these eight to Nahor the brother of Abraham.
24 Srɔ̃a evelia, si ŋkɔe nye Reuma, hã dzi Teba, Gaham, Tahas kple Maaka nɛ.
24 His concubine, whose name was Reumah, also bore sons: Tebah, GAham, TAhash, and MAAcah.
Eye Abraham ʋu tso afi ma yi Negeb, eva nɔ Kades kple Sur dome, eye wònɔ Gerar hã vie.
Now Abraham moved his camp from there to the land of the Negeb and began dwelling between KAdesh and Shur.
2 Abraham gblɔna tso srɔ̃a Sara ŋu enuenu be: “Nɔvinyee.”
While he was residing at Gerar, 2 Abraham repeated concerning his wife Sarah: “She is my sister.”
Esia ta Gerar-fia Abimelek dɔ woyi ɖakplɔ Sara vɛ nɛ.
So Abimelech king of Gerar sent for Sarah and took her.
3 Emegbe Mawu va Abimelek gbɔ le drɔ̃eƒe le zã me hegblɔ nɛ be: “Kpɔ ɖa, èku vɔ, le nyɔnu si nèxɔ la ta, elabena ame srɔ̃e wònye.” 4 Ke Abimelek mede asi eŋu o.

3 Afterward, God came by night to Abimelech in a dream and said to him: “Here you are as good as dead because of the woman whom you have taken, since she is married and belongs to another man.” 4 However, Abimelech had not gone near her.
Eye wògblɔ be: “Yehowa, dukɔ maɖifɔ hãe nàtsrɔ̃a? 5 Menye ɖe wògblɔ nam be, ‘Nɔvinyenyɔnue’ oa? Eye ɖe nyɔnua ŋutɔ hã megblɔ be, ‘Nɔvinyeŋutsue’ oa?
So he said: “Jehovah, will you kill a nation that is really innocent? 5 Did he not say to me, ‘She is my sister,’ and did she too not say, ‘He is my brother’?
Nye dzi me kɔ, eye nye asi me dza le nya sia me.” 6 Eye Mawu vavã la gblɔ nɛ le drɔ̃e me be: “Menyae be wò dzi me kɔ le nu sia wɔwɔ me, eya tae mexe mɔ na wò be nàgawɔ nu vɔ̃ ɖe ŋunye o.
I did this with an honest heart and innocent hands.” 6 Then the true God said to him in the dream: “I know that you did this with an honest heart, so I held you back from sinning against me.
Esia tae nyemeɖe mɔ na wò nèka asi eŋu o ɖo.
That is why I did not allow you to touch her.
7 Azɔ gbugbɔ ŋutsua srɔ̃ ɖo ɖee, elabena nyagblɔɖila wònye, ne wòaƒo koko ɖe tawò be nàtsi agbe.
7 Now return the man’s wife, for he is a prophet, and he will make supplication for you and you will keep living.
Ke ne mègbugbɔ nyɔnua ɖo ɖee o la, nyae be ku kee nàku, wò ŋutɔ kple wò amewo katã.”
But if you are not returning her, know that you will surely die, you and all who are yours.”
8 Abimelek fɔ ŋdi kanya, yɔ eƒe subɔviwo katã, eye wògblɔ nya siawo katã na wo. Eye ameawo vɔ̃ ŋutɔ.
8 Abimelech got up early in the morning and called all his servants and told them all these things, and they became very frightened.
9 Eyome Abimelek yɔ Abraham biae be: “Nu kae nye esi nèwɔ ɖe mía ŋu?
9 Then Abimelech called Abraham and said to him: “What have you done to us?
Nu vɔ̃ kae mewɔ ɖe ŋuwò be nèhe vɔ̃ gã sia va nye kple nye fiaɖuƒe la dzi?
What sin have I committed against you that you would bring upon me and my kingdom such a great sin?

Mèwɔ nu ɖe ŋunye nyuie kura o.” 10 Eye Abimelek gabia Abraham be: “Nu kae nèɖo ɖe tame hafi wɔ nu sia?” 11 Abraham gblɔ be: “Esi mebu be, ‘Ame aɖeke mevɔ̃a Mawu le afi sia o, eye woawum axɔ srɔ̃nye’ tae. 12 Gake nɔvinyee wònye vavã, fofonye ƒe vie wònye meɖe, gake menye danye ƒe vie o.

What you have done to me was not right.” 10 And Abimelech went on to say to Abraham: “What were your intentions when you did this thing?” 11 Abraham said: “It was because I said to myself, ‘Surely there is no fear of God in this place, and they will kill me because of my wife.’ 12 And besides, she really is my sister, the daughter of my father but not the daughter of my mother, and she became my wife.
13 Esi Mawu na míeʋu tso fofonye ƒe me hele tsatsam la, megblɔ nɛ be, ‘Ale si nàve nunyee nye esi: Afi sia afi si míayi la, gblɔ tso ŋunye be: “Nɔvinyee.”’”
13 So when God caused me to wander from the house of my father, I said to her: ‘Let this be how you show loyal love to me: Everywhere we go, say of me, “He is my brother.”’”
14 Eye Abimelek tsɔ alẽwo, nyiwo, subɔviŋutsuwo kple subɔvinyɔnuwo na Abraham, eye wòɖe asi le srɔ̃a Sara hã ŋu nɛ.
14 Abimelech then took sheep and cattle and male and female servants and gave them to Abraham, and he returned his wife Sarah to him.
15 Eye Abimelek gblɔ be: “Kpɔ ɖa, nye anyigbae nye esi.
15 Abimelech also said: “Here my land is available to you.
Nɔ afi sia afi si nyo ŋuwò.” 16 Eye wògblɔ na Sara be: “Kpɔ ɖa, metsɔ klosalo akpe ɖeka na nɔviwòa.
Dwell wherever you please.” 16 And to Sarah he said: “Here I give 1,000 pieces of silver to your brother.

Esiae metsɔ kpata wò le ame siwo katã le ŋuwò kpakple ame bubuwo katã ŋkume be, ŋutiwò kɔ tso vlododo me.” 17 Ale Abraham ƒo koko na Mawu vavã la; eye Mawu yɔ dɔ Abimelek kple srɔ̃a kpakple eƒe kosiwo, ale be wote ŋu dzi vi, 18 elabena Yehowa xe nyɔnu siwo katã le Abimelek ƒe aƒe me la ƒe vidzidɔ keŋkeŋ le Abraham srɔ̃ Sara ta.

It is a sign of your innocence to all who are with you and before everybody, and you are cleared of reproach.” 17 And Abraham began to make supplication to the true God, and God healed Abimelech and his wife and his slave girls, and they began having children; 18 for Jehovah had made all the women of the house of Abimelech barren because of Sarah, Abraham’s wife.

Le ɣeyiɣi aɖe megbe la, Yakob se nya siwo gblɔm Laban viwo nɔ be: “Yakob xɔ mía fofo ƒe nuwo katã, eye mía fofo ƒe nuwo dzie wòto ƒo kesinɔnu gbogbo siawo nu ƒu.” 2 Ne Yakob kpɔ Laban la, edea dzesii be megakɔa mo ɖe ye abe tsã ene o.

In time he heard what the sons of Laban were saying: “Jacob has taken everything that belonged to our father, and from what belonged to our father, he has amassed all this wealth.” 2 When Jacob would look at the face of Laban, he saw that his attitude toward him was not what it used to be.

3 Mlɔeba Yehowa gblɔ na Yakob be: “Gbugbɔ yi fofowòwo ƒe anyigba dzi kple ƒowòmeawo gbɔ, eye manɔ kpli wò.” 4 Eye Yakob ɖo du ɖe Rahel kple Lea be woava gbedzi le yeƒe lãha la gbɔ, 5 eye wògblɔ na wo be:

3 Finally Jehovah said to Jacob: “Return to the land of your fathers and to your relatives, and I will continue with you.” 4 Then Jacob sent a message to Rachel and Leah to come out to the field to his flock, 5 and he said to them:
“Mekpɔe be mia fofo megakɔa mo ɖem o; gake fofonye ƒe Mawu la li kplim.
“I have seen that your father’s attitude toward me has changed, but the God of my father has been with me.
6 Miawo ŋutɔ mienyae nyuie be, nye ŋusẽ katãe metsɔ subɔ mia fofo.
6 You yourselves certainly know that I have served your father with all my power.
7 Ke mia fofo dze agbagba be yeabam, eye wòtrɔ nye fetu zi ewo sɔŋ, gake Mawu meɖe mɔ nɛ be wòawɔ vɔ̃ ɖe ŋunye o.
7 And your father has tried to cheat me and has changed my wages ten times; but God has not allowed him to do me harm.

8 Ne egblɔ be, ‘Ŋɔtaŋɔtaawoe azu wò fetu’ la, ekema lãha blibo la katã dzia vi siwo le ŋɔtaŋɔta; eye ne egblɔ be, ‘Esiwo ŋu fli le lae azu wò fetu’ la, ekema lãha blibo la katã dzia vi siwo ŋu fli le.

8 If on the one hand he would say, ‘The speckled ones will be your wages,’ then the whole flock produced speckled ones; but if on the other hand he would say, ‘The striped ones will be your wages,’ then the whole flock produced striped ones.
9 Ale Mawu nɔa mia fofo ƒe lãha la xɔm tsɔ nɔa nayem.
9 So God kept taking your father’s livestock away from him and giving it to me.
10 Gbe ɖeka esi lãha la nɔ asi yɔm la, mekpɔ nane le drɔ̃e me, eye kpɔ ɖa, gbɔ̃tsu siwo le asi yɔm gbɔ̃nɔawo la nye esiwo ŋu fli le, esiwo le ŋɔtaŋɔta kple esiwo tso kpɔ.
10 Once when the flock got into heat, I raised my eyes and saw in a dream that the he-goats mating with the flock were striped, speckled, and spotty.

11 Eye Mawu vavã la ƒe dɔla yɔm le drɔ̃ea me be: ‘Yakob!’ Eye metɔ be: ‘Nyee nye esi.’ 12 Eye wògblɔ be: ‘Meɖe kuku, fɔ mo dzi nàkpɔ, àkpɔe be gbɔ̃tsu siwo katã le asi yɔm gbɔ̃nɔawo la nye esiwo ŋu fli le, esiwo le ŋɔtaŋɔta kple esiwo tso kpɔ, elabena mekpɔ nu siwo katã wɔm Laban le ɖe ŋuwò.

11 Then the angel of the true God said to me in the dream, ‘Jacob!’ to which I said, ‘Here I am.’ 12 And he continued, ‘Raise your eyes, please, and see that all the he-goats mating with the flock are striped, speckled, and spotty, for I have seen all that Laban is doing to you.
13 Nyee nye Mawu vavã si ɖe eɖokui fia wò le Betel, afi si nèkɔ ami ɖe ŋkuɖodzikpe aɖe dzi le, eye nèɖe adzɔgbe nam le la.
13 I am the true God of Bethel, where you anointed a pillar and where you made a vow to me.
Azɔ tso, ʋu le anyigba sia dzi, eye nàtrɔ ayi anyigba si dzi wodzi wò ɖo la dzi.’”
Now get up, go out of this land, and return to the land of your birth.’”

14 Eye Rahel kple Lea ɖo eŋu nɛ be: “Ðe domenyinu aɖe gali na mí le mía fofo ƒe mea? 15 Ðe mebu mí amedzrowoe le esi wòtsɔ mí dzra hele ga si wona ɖe mía ta la ɖuɖu dzi oa? 16 Kesinɔnu siwo katã Mawu xɔ le mía fofo si la zu míawo ŋutɔwo kple mía viwo tɔ.

14 At this Rachel and Leah answered him: “Is there any share left for us to inherit in our father’s house? 15 Does he not consider us as foreigners, since he has sold us and has been using up the money given for us? 16 All the riches that God has taken away from our father are ours and our children’s.
Eya ta wɔ nu sia nu si Mawu gblɔ na wò be nàwɔ la.”
So, then, do everything that God has told you to do.”

17 Eye Yakob tso hekɔ viawo kple srɔ̃awo ɖo kposɔwo dzi; 18 eye wòkplɔ eƒe lãha blibo la hetsɔ nunɔamesi siwo katã nu wòƒo ƒu, lãha siwo su esi le Padan-Aram la, eye wòdze mɔ ɖo ta fofoa Isak gbɔ le Kanaan-nyigba dzi.

17 Then Jacob got up and lifted his children and his wives on the camels, 18 and he began driving all his herd and all the goods that he had accumulated, the livestock in his possession that he had accumulated in Paddanaram, to go to Isaac his father in the land of Canaan.
19 Ɣemaɣi la, Laban yi fu ko ge na eƒe alẽwo, eye Rahel fi fofoa ƒe terafim legbawo.
19 Now Laban had gone to shear his sheep, and Rachel stole the teraphim statues that belonged to her father.
20 Gakpe ɖe eŋu la, Yakob flu Aramtɔ Laban, elabena meklãe hafi dzo o.
20 Moreover, Jacob outwitted Laban the Aramaean, for he had not told him that he was running away.
21 Ale wòsi yi ɖatso Tɔsisi la kple nu siwo katã le esi la.
21 And he ran away and crossed the River, he and all he had.
Emegbe eɖo ta Gilead tonuto la me.
Then he headed toward the mountainous region of Gilead.
22 Eye le ŋkeke etɔ̃a gbe la, wova gblɔ na Laban be Yakob si.
22 On the third day, Laban was told that Jacob had run away.
23 Ale wòkplɔ nɔviawo kpe ɖe eɖokui ŋu heti eyome ŋkeke adre hafi va tui le Gilead tonuto la me.
23 So he took his brothers with him and pursued him for a journey of seven days and caught up with him in the mountainous region of Gilead.
24 Eye Mawu va Aramtɔ Laban gbɔ le drɔ̃e me le zã me gblɔ nɛ be: “Kpɔ nyuie le nu si nàgblɔ na Yakob la ŋuti, eɖanye nyui alo vɔ̃ o.”
24 Then God came to Laban the Aramaean in a dream by night and said to him: “Be careful about what you say to Jacob, either good or bad.”
25 Eye Laban te ɖe Yakob ŋu, esime Yakob tu eƒe agbadɔ ɖe to la dzi, eye Laban na nɔviawo ƒu asaɖa anyi ɖe Gilead tonuto la me.
25 So Laban approached Jacob, as Jacob had pitched his tent in the mountain and Laban had encamped with his brothers in the mountainous region of Gilead.
26 Eye Laban gblɔ na Yakob be: “Nu kae nye esi nèwɔ?
26 Then Laban said to Jacob: “What have you done?
Nu ka tae nèflum hekplɔ vinyenyɔnuawo dzoe abe ame siwo wotsɔ yi ɖe aboyoe ene? 27 Nu ka tae nèflum hesi dzaa, eye mèklãm o?
Why have you resorted to outwitting me and carrying my daughters off like captives taken by the sword? 27 Why did you run away secretly and outwit me and not tell me?
Ne ɖe nèklãm la, anye ne matsɔ aseyetsotso, hadzidzi, axatsɛ kple saŋku ado mɔ wò.
If you had told me, I could have sent you away with rejoicing and with songs, with tambourine and with harp.
28 Evɔ mèna mɔnukpɔkpɔm be magbugbɔ nu na tɔgbuiyɔvinyewo kple vinyenyɔnuawo o.
28 But you did not give me a chance to kiss my grandchildren and my daughters.
Èwɔ bometsinu.
You have acted foolishly.

29 Mate ŋu awɔ nu vevi mi hafi, gake fofowò ƒe Mawu la ƒo nu nam etsɔ zã me be, ‘Kpɔ nyuie le nu si nàgblɔ na Yakob la ŋuti, eɖanye nyui alo vɔ̃ o.’ 30 Ðewohĩ esi nèdi vevie be yeatrɔ ayi fofowò ƒe aƒe me tae nèdzo, ke nu ka tae nèfi nye mawuawo?”

29 It is in my power to do harm to you, but the God of your father spoke to me last night, saying, ‘Be careful about what you say to Jacob, either good or bad.’ 30 Now you have gone because you have been longing to return to the house of your father, but why have you stolen my gods?”
31 Yakob ɖo eŋu na Laban be: “Esi mele vɔvɔ̃m tae. Elabena mebu be, ‘Ðewohĩ àxɔ viwònyɔnuawo le asinye sesẽe.’ 32 Ame si gbɔ nàkpɔ wò mawuawo le la, manɔ agbe o.
31 Jacob answered Laban: “It was because I was afraid, for I said to myself, ‘You might take your daughters away from me by force.’ 32 Anyone with whom you find your gods will not live.
Wò ŋutɔ ka nu siwo le gbɔnye la me le mía nɔviawo ŋkume, eye nàtsɔ nu siwo nye tɔwò.”
Before our brothers, examine what I have, and take what is yours.”
Ke Yakob menya be Rahel fi wo o.
But Jacob did not know that Rachel had stolen them.
33 Eye Laban yi Yakob ƒe agbadɔ kple Lea ƒe agbadɔ kpakple kosi eveawo ƒe agbadɔ me, ke mekpɔ wo o.
33 So Laban went into the tent of Jacob and into the tent of Leah and into the tent of the two slave girls, but did not find them.
Eye wòdo go le Lea ƒe agbadɔ me yi Rahel ƒe agbadɔ me.
Then he came out of Leah’s tent and went into Rachel’s tent.
34 Ke Rahel tsɔ terafim legba siwo wòtsɔ la de nyɔnuwo ƒe sɔkpaŋukotoku si wodana ɖe kposɔ dzi la me, eye wòbɔbɔ nɔ wo dzi.
34 Meanwhile, Rachel had taken the teraphim statues and put them in the woman’s saddle basket of the camel, and she was sitting on them.
Eye Laban yi ɖaka agbadɔ blibo la katã me, ke mekpɔ wo o.
So Laban searched through the whole tent but did not find them.
35 Eye Rahel gblɔ na fofoa be: “Nye aƒetɔ, mègado dziku le esi nyemate ŋu atsi tsitre le ŋkuwòme o ta o, elabena nu si dzɔna ɖe nyɔnuwo dzi la dzɔ ɖe dzinye.”
35 Then she said to her father: “Do not be angry, my lord, because I am not able to get up before you, for the customary thing with women is upon me.”
Ale wòdi terafim legba siawo ʋuu do kpoe.
So he searched on carefully but did not find the teraphim statues.
36 Eye Yakob do dziku, eye wòhe nya ɖe Laban ŋu.
36 At that Jacob became angry and began to criticize Laban.
Eye Yakob bia Laban be: “Agɔ kae medze, eye nu vɔ̃ kae mewɔ, si tae nèti yonyeme kple ŋkubiã alea? 37 Fifia esi nèka nye nuwo katã me ɖe, wò aƒemenuwo dometɔ ka ŋue nèke ɖo?
Jacob then said to Laban: “What is my offense, and for what sin are you hotly pursuing me? 37 Now that you have searched through all my goods, what have you found that belongs to your house?
Tsɔe da ɖe afi sia, le nɔvinyewo kple nɔviwòwo ŋkume, ne woadrɔ̃e le mí ame evea dome.
Put it here in front of my brothers and your brothers, and let them decide between the two of us.
38 Le ƒe blaeve siwo menɔ gbɔwò me la, fu mege le wò alẽwo kple wò gbɔ̃wo ƒo kpɔ o, eye nyemeɖu agbo aɖeke le wò lãha la me kpɔ o.
38 During these 20 years that I have been with you, your sheep and your goats never miscarried, and I never ate the rams of your flock.
39 Nyemetsɔ lã aɖeke si lã lénu aɖe vuvu la vɛ na wò kpɔ o.
39 I did not bring you any animal torn by wild beasts.
Nye ŋutɔe ɖoa eteƒe.
I would stand the loss of it myself.
Eɖanye ŋkeke mee wofi lãa loo alo zã mee o, ènana meɖoa eteƒe na wò.
Whether the animal was stolen by day or was stolen by night, you would demand compensation from me.
40 Ŋdɔ ɖuam le ŋkeke me, vuvɔ wɔam le zã me, eye alɔ̃ búna ɖe nye ŋkuwo.
40 By day the heat consumed me, and the cold by night, and sleep would flee from my eyes.
41 Ƒe blaevee nye esia mele aƒewò me.
41 This makes 20 years for me in your house.
Mesubɔ wò ƒe wuiene ɖe viwònyɔnu eveawo ta, ƒe ade ɖe wò lãha la ta, eye nètrɔ nye fetu zi ewo sɔŋ.
I have served you 14 years for your two daughters and 6 years for your flock, and you kept changing my wages ten times.
42 Ðe menye fofonye ƒe Mawu kple Abraham ƒe Mawu, Ame si Isak vɔ̃na lae le dzinye o la, anye ne asi ƒuƒlue nàdo mɔm fifia.
42 If the God of my father, the God of Abraham and the One whom Isaac fears, had not been on my side, you would now have sent me away empty-handed.
Mawu kpɔ nye fukpekpewo kple dɔ siwo metsɔ nye asiwo wɔ kutrikukutɔe, eye esia tae wògbe nya na wò etsɔ zã me ɖo.”
God has seen my affliction and the toil of my hands, and that is why he reproved you last night.”
43 Eye Laban ɖo eŋu na Yakob be: “Nyɔnuawo la, vinyewoe, ɖeviawo la, tɔgbuiyɔvinyewoe, lãhaa hã, nye lãhae, eye nu sia nu si kpɔm nèle la, nye kple vinyenyɔnuawo tɔe.
43 Then Laban answered Jacob: “The daughters are my daughters and the children my children and the flock my flock, and everything you are looking at is mine and my daughters’.
Nu kae mate ŋu awɔ ame siawo alo wo vi siwo wodzi la egbea? 44 Azɔ va ne nye kpli wò míabla nu, ne wòanye ɖase le mía dome.” 45 Eya ta Yakob tsɔ kpe ɖi ŋkuɖodzikpee.
