What can I do today against these or against their children whom they have borne? 44 Now come, let us make a covenant, you and I, and it will serve as a witness between us.” 45 So Jacob took a stone and set it up as a pillar.
46 Eye Yakob gblɔ na nɔviawo be: “Mifɔ kpewo vɛ!”
46 Then Jacob said to his brothers: “Pick up stones!”
Eye wofɔ kpewo li kɔe.
And they took stones and made a pile.
Emegbe woɖu nu le afi ma le kpekɔ la dzi.
After that they ate there on the pile of stones.
47 Eye Laban yɔe be Yegar-Sahaduta, ke Yakob ya yɔe be Galed.
47 And Laban began calling it Jegar-sahadutha, but Jacob called it Galeed.
48 Eye Laban gblɔ be: “Kpekɔ siae nye ɖase le nye kpli wò dome egbea.”
48 Laban then said: “This pile of stones is a witness between me and you today.”
Esia tae wòna ŋkɔe be Galed, 49 kple Gbetakpɔxɔ, elabena egblɔ be: “Yehowa nenɔ nye kpli wò dome ŋu dzɔm ne míeva le teƒe si míegale mía nɔewo kpɔm le o.
That is why he named it Galeed, 49 and the Watchtower, for he said: “Let Jehovah keep watch between you and me when we are out of each other’s sight.

50 Ne èwɔ fu vinyenyɔnuawo, eye nèva ɖe nyɔnu bubuwo kpe ɖe vinyenyɔnuawo ŋu la, ɖo ŋku edzi be ne ame aɖeke mekpɔe o hã la, Mawu ame si nye míaƒe ɖasefo la ya akpɔe.” 51 Eye Laban gagblɔ na Yakob be: “Kpekɔ sia kple ŋkuɖodzikpe si meɖi le nye kpli wò dome lae nye esi.

50 If you mistreat my daughters and if you start taking wives in addition to my daughters, though there is no man with us, remember that God will be a witness between you and me.” 51 Laban went on to say to Jacob: “Here is this pile of stones, and here is the pillar that I have erected between you and me.
52 Kpekɔ sia nye ɖase, eye ŋkuɖodzikpe la nye nu si le ɖase ɖim, be nyemato kpekɔ sia ŋu aho ɖe ŋuwò ava wɔ nu vevi wò o, eye be wò hã màto kpekɔ sia kple ŋkuɖodzikpe sia ŋu ava wɔ nu vevim o.

52 This pile of stones is a witness, and the pillar is something that bears witness, that I will not pass beyond this pile of stones to bring harm to you and you will not pass beyond this pile of stones and this pillar to bring harm to me.
53 Abraham ƒe Mawu, Nahor ƒe Mawu, kple wo fofo ƒe Mawu la, nadrɔ̃e le mía dome.”
53 Let the God of Abraham and the God of Nahor, the God of their father, judge between us.”
Eye Yakob tsɔ Ame si fofoa Isak vɔ̃na la ka atam.
And Jacob swore by the One whom his father Isaac fears.
54 Emegbe Yakob sa vɔ le to la dzi, eye wòkpe nɔviawo be woava ɖu nu.
54 After that Jacob offered a sacrifice in the mountain and invited his brothers to eat bread.
Ale woɖu nu, eye wotsi to la dzi dɔ.
So they ate and spent the night in the mountain.
55 Ke Laban fɔ ŋdi kanya, eye wògbugbɔ nu na tɔgbuiyɔviawo kple vianyɔnuawo, eye wòyra wo.
55 However, Laban got up early in the morning and kissed his grandchildren and his daughters and blessed them.
Emegbe Laban trɔ yi aƒe.
Then Laban departed and returned home.
Emegbe Mawu gblɔ na Yakob be: “Tso nàyi Betel, eye nànɔ afi ma, eye nàɖi vɔsamlekpui na Mawu vavã si ɖe eɖokui fia wò esime nèle sisim le nɔviwò Esau nu la ɖe afi ma.”
After that God said to Jacob: “Rise, go up to Bethel and dwell there, and make an altar there to the true God, who appeared to you when you were running away from Esau your brother.”
2 Eye Yakob gblɔ na eƒemetɔwo kple eŋumewo katã be: “Miɖe dutamawu siwo katã le mia dome la ɖa, mikɔ mia ɖokuiwo ŋu, eye miɖɔli miaƒe awuwo, 3 eye mina míatso ayi Betel.

2 Then Jacob said to his household and to all who were with him: “Get rid of the foreign gods that are in your midst, and cleanse yourselves and change your garments, 3 and let us rise and go up to Bethel.

Maɖi vɔsamlekpui ɖe afi ma na Mawu vavã, ame si tɔ nam le nye xaxagbe henɔ kplim le afi sia afi si meyi la.” 4 Eya ta wotsɔ dutamawu siwo katã le wo si kple togɛ siwo le to na wo la na Yakob, eye Yakob ɖi wo ɖe ati gã si gogo Sekem dua la te.

There I will make an altar to the true God, who answered me in the day of my distress and who has been with me wherever I have gone.” 4 So they gave Jacob all the foreign gods they had and the earrings that were in their ears, and Jacob buried them under the big tree that was close to Shechem.
5 Esi wodze mɔ yina la, Mawu ƒe ŋɔdzi lé du siwo ƒo xlã wo godoo la, ale be wometi Yakob viwo yome o.
5 When they traveled on, the terror of God struck the cities around them, so they did not chase after the sons of Jacob.
6 Mlɔeba Yakob kple ame siwo katã le eŋu la va ɖo Luz, si wogayɔna be Betel, le Kanaan-nyigba dzi.
6 Jacob eventually came to Luz, that is, Bethel, in the land of Canaan, he and all the people with him.
7 Eye wòɖi vɔsamlekpui ɖe afi ma heyɔ teƒe la be El-Betel, elabena afi mae Mawu vavã la ɖe eɖokui fiae le esime wòsi le nɔvia nu.
7 There he built an altar and called the place El-Bethel, because there the true God had revealed himself to him when he had run away from his brother.
8 Emegbe Debora, ame si na no Rebeka la ku, eye woɖii ɖe Betel lɔƒo le logoti aɖe te.
8 Later DebOrah, Rebekah’s nurse, died and was buried at the foot of Bethel under an oak.
Eya ta ena ŋkɔe be Alon-Bakut.
So he named it Allon-bacuth.
9 Mawu gaɖe eɖokui fia Yakob esime wòtrɔ tso Padan-Aram gbɔna, eye wòyrae.
9 God appeared to Jacob once again while he was coming from Paddanaram and blessed him.
10 Eye Mawu gblɔ nɛ be: “Ŋkɔwòe nye Yakob.
10 God said to him: “Your name is Jacob.
Womagayɔ wò be Yakob azɔ o, ke boŋ wò ŋkɔ anye Israel.”
Your name will no longer be Jacob, but Israel will be your name.”
Eye wòde asi eyɔyɔ me be Israel.
And he began to call him Israel.
11 Eye Mawu gagblɔ nɛ be: “Nyee nye Mawu Ŋusẽkatãtɔ.
11 God further said to him: “I am God Almighty.
Dzi nàsɔ gbɔ.
Be fruitful and become many.
Dukɔwo kple dukɔwo ƒe ha gã aɖe ado tso mewò, eye fiawo ado tso mewò.
Nations and a congregation of nations will come from you, and kings will descend from you.
12 Matsɔ anyigba si metsɔ na Abraham kple Isak la ana wò, eye matsɔ anyigba la ana wò dzidzimevi siwo ava ɖe yowòme.” 13 Eye Mawu dzo le egbɔ le afi si wòƒo nu kplii le la heyi dzi.

12 As for the land that I have given to Abraham and to Isaac, to you I will give it, and to your offspring after you I will give the land.” 13 Then God went up from him at the place where he had spoken with him.
14 Eya ta Yakob ɖi dzesikpe, si nye ŋkuɖodzikpe, ɖe afi si wòƒo nu kplii le, eye wòkɔ nunovɔsa ɖe edzi hekɔ ami ɖe edzi.
14 So Jacob set up a pillar in the place where he had spoken with him, a pillar of stone, and he poured a drink offering on it and poured oil on it.
15 Eye Yakob yɔa teƒe si Mawu ƒo nu kplii le la be Betel.
15 And Jacob continued to call the place where God had spoken with him Bethel.
16 Azɔ woho tso Betel.
16 Then they pulled away from Bethel.
Eye esi woɖo teƒe aɖe si didi tso Efrat gbɔ la, Rahel de asi kuléle me, ke via dzidzi sesẽ nɛ ŋutɔ.
And while they were still some distance from Ephrath, Rachel began to give birth, and her labor was very difficult.

17 Esi via dzidzi nɔ sesẽm nɛ la, vixela la gblɔ nɛ be: “Mègavɔ̃ o, elabena ŋutsuvi dzi gee nègale.” 18 Esime eƒe agbe nu nɔ tsotsom la (elabena enɔ kukum), ena ŋkɔe be Ben-Oni, ke fofoa yɔe be Benyamin.

17 But while she was struggling to deliver the child, the midwife said to her: “Do not be afraid, for you will have this son also.” 18 Just as her life was slipping away (for she was dying), she named him Ben-Oni, but his father called him Benjamin.
19 Ale Rahel ku, eye woɖii esime wole mɔ dzi yina Efrat, si wogayɔna be Betlehem.
19 So Rachel died and was buried on the way to Ephrath, that is, Bethlehem.
20 Eye Yakob tu dzesikpe ɖe eƒe yɔdo dzi, esiae nye dzesikpe si le Rahel ƒe yɔdo dzi va se ɖe egbe.
20 Jacob set up a pillar over her grave; it is the pillar of Rachel’s grave to this day.
21 Ema megbe Israel ho, eye wòva tu eƒe agbadɔ ɖe Eder mɔ́a godo.
21 After that Israel pulled away and pitched his tent a distance beyond the tower of eder.
22 Gbe ɖeka esime Israel le avɔgbadɔ me le anyigba ma dzi la, Ruben yi ɖadɔ fofoa ƒe ahiã Bilha gbɔ, eye Israel see.
22 Once while Israel was dwelling in that land, Reuben went and lay down with Bilhah his father’s concubine, and Israel heard about it.
Ke viŋutsu wuieve le Yakob si.
So there were 12 sons of Jacob.
23 Lea viŋutsuwoe nye Ruben, si nye Yakob ƒe ŋgɔgbevi, eyome Simeon, Lewi, Yuda, Isakar kple Zebulon.
23 The sons by Leah were Jacob’s firstborn Reuben, then Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, and Zebulun.
24 Rahel viŋutsuwoe nye Yosef kple Benyamin.
24 The sons by Rachel were Joseph and Benjamin.
25 Rahel ƒe subɔvi Bilha viŋutsuwoe nye Dan kple Naftali.
25 And the sons by Bilhah, Rachel’s servant, were Dan and Naphtali.
26 Eye Lea ƒe subɔvi Zilpa viŋutsuwoe nye Gad kple Aser.
26 And the sons by Zilpah, Leah’s servant, were Gad and Asher.
Ame siawoe nye Yakob viŋutsu siwo wodzi nɛ le Padan-Aram.
These are Jacob’s sons, who were born to him in Paddanaram.
27 Mlɔeba Yakob va fofoa Isak gbɔ le Mamre le Kiriat-Arba si wogayɔna be Hebron, afi si Abraham kple Isak nye amedzro le kpɔ.
27 Jacob eventually came to where his father Isaac was at Mamre, to Kiriat-Arba, that is, Hebron, where Abraham and also Isaac had resided as foreigners.
28 Eye Isak nɔ agbe ƒe alafa ɖeka blaenyi.
28 Isaac lived to be 180 years old.
29 Emegbe Isak ƒe gbɔgbɔ nu tso eye wòku, eye wotsɔe kpe ɖe eƒe amewo ŋu, etsi, eye agbenɔnɔ ɖi kɔ nɛ; eye via Esau kple Yakob ɖii.
29 Then Isaac breathed his last and died and was gathered to his people, after a long and satisfying life; and his sons Esau and Jacob buried him.
Yehowa trɔ susu ɖe Sara ŋu abe ale si tututu wògblɔe ene, eye Yehowa wɔ ɖe ŋugbe si wòdo na Sara la dzi.
Jehovah turned his attention to Sarah just as he had said, and Jehovah did for Sarah what he had promised.
2 Ale Sara fɔ fu dzi viŋutsuvi na Abraham le eƒe amegãkuku me, le ɣeyiɣi si tututu ƒe ŋugbe Mawu do nɛ la dzi.
2 So Sarah became pregnant and then bore a son to Abraham in his old age at the appointed time God had promised him.
3 Eye Abraham tsɔ ŋkɔ na vi si Sara dzi nɛ la be Isak.
3 Abraham named his newborn son, whom Sarah bore to him, Isaac.
4 Abraham tso aʋa na via Isak esi wòxɔ ŋkeke enyi, abe ale si Mawu de se nɛ ene.
4 And Abraham circumcised his son Isaac when he was eight days old, just as God had commanded him.
5 Abraham xɔ ƒe alafa ɖeka esime wodzi Isak nɛ.
5 Abraham was 100 years old when his son Isaac was born to him.
6 Eye Sara gblɔ be: “Mawu do nukokoe nam; ame sia ame si asee la ako nu kplim.” 7 Eye wògblɔ kpee be: “Ame kae agblɔ na Abraham be, ‘Sara ana no vi hafi?
6 Then Sarah said: “God has brought me laughter; everybody hearing of it will laugh with me.” 7 And she added: “Who would have said to Abraham, ‘Sarah will certainly nurse children’?
Ke hã, medzi viŋutsuvi nɛ le eƒe amegãkuku me.”
Yet, I have given birth to a son for him in his old age.”
8 Ke ɖevi la tsi, eye wotso no nɛ, eye Abraham ɖo kplɔ̃ gã aɖe le gbe si gbe wotso no na Isak.
8 Now the child grew and was weaned, and Abraham prepared a big feast on the day that Isaac was weaned.
9 Ke Sara de dzesii be Egiptetɔ Hagar ƒe vi si wòdzi na Abraham la lɔ̃a fewuɖuɖu le Isak ŋu.
9 But Sarah kept noticing that the son of HAgar the Egyptian, whom she had borne to Abraham, was mocking Isaac.
10 Eya ta egblɔ na Abraham be: “Nya kosi sia kple via ɖa, elabena kosi sia ƒe vi manyi dome kple vinye Isak o!” 11 Ke nya si wògblɔ tso via ŋu la medzɔ dzi na Abraham kura o.

10 So she said to Abraham: “Drive out this slave girl and her son, for the son of this slave girl is not going to be an heir along with my son, with Isaac!” 11 But what she said about his son was very displeasing to Abraham.
12 Eye Mawu gblɔ na Abraham be: “Mègana nya siwo gblɔm Sara le na wò le ŋutsuvi la kple kosi la ŋu nave wò o.
12 Then God said to Abraham: “Do not be displeased by what Sarah is saying to you about the boy and about your slave girl.
Ðo toe, elabena ame si woayɔ be wò dzidzimevi la adzɔ tso Isak me.
Listen to her, for what will be called your offspring will be through Isaac.
13 Ke mana kosi la ƒe vi hã nazu dukɔ, elabena viwòe eya hã nye.”
13 As for the son of the slave girl, I will also make a nation out of him, because he is your offspring.”
14 Eye Abraham fɔ ŋdi kanya, eye wòtsɔ abolo kple lãgbalẽgolo si me tsi le la na Hagar.
14 So Abraham got up early in the morning and took bread and a skin bottle of water and gave it to HAgar.
Etsɔe ɖo abɔta nɛ, eye wòdo mɔ eya kple ɖevi la.
He set these on her shoulder and then sent her away along with the boy.
Ale wòdzo yi ɖale tsaglãla tsam le Beer-Seba gbedzi.
So she departed and wandered about in the wilderness of Beer-sheba.
15 Mlɔeba tsia va vɔ le lãgbalẽgolo la me, eye wòɖe asi le ɖevi la ŋu da ɖe ati dodoe aɖe te.
15 Finally the water in the skin bottle was used up, and she pushed the boy under one of the bushes.
16 Eye wòdzo yi ɖabɔbɔ nɔ adzɔge; wo dome didi abe afi si woada aŋutrɔ wòadze ene, elabena egblɔ be: “Nyemate ŋu anɔ ɖevi la kpɔm wòaku o.”
16 Then she went on and sat down by herself, about the distance of a bowshot away, because she said: “I do not want to watch the boy die.”
Eya tae wòyi ɖabɔbɔ nɔ adzɔge, eye wòfa avi hehehe.
So she sat down at a distance and began to cry aloud and to weep.
17 Mawu se ŋutsuvi la ƒe gbe, eye Mawu ƒe dɔla yɔ Hagar tso dziƒo gblɔ nɛ be: “Hagar, nu kae le wɔwòm?
17 At that God heard the voice of the boy, and God’s angel called to HAgar from the heavens and said to her: “What is the matter with you, HAgar?
Mègavɔ̃ o, elabena Mawu se ɖevi la ƒe gbe le afi si wòle.
Do not be afraid, for God has heard the voice of the boy there where he is.
18 Tso nàyi aɖalé ɖevi la wòatso, elabena mana wòazu dukɔ gã aɖe.” 19 Ale Mawu ʋu eƒe ŋkuwo wòkpɔ vudo aɖe; eye wòyi ɖaku tsi ɖe lãgbalẽgolo la me hena tsi ŋutsuvi la wòno.

18 Get up, lift the boy and take hold of him with your hand, for I will make him a great nation.” 19 Then God opened her eyes and she saw a well of water, and she went and filled the skin bottle with water and gave the boy a drink.
20 Eye Mawu nɔ kple ɖevi la esi wònɔ tsitsim.
20 And God was with the boy as he grew up.
Enɔ gbedzi, eye wòva zu aŋutrɔdala.
He lived in the wilderness and became an archer.
21 Eva nɔ Paran gbedzi, eye dadaa ɖe srɔ̃ nɛ tso Egipte-nyigba dzi.
21 He took up dwelling in the wilderness of PAran, and his mother took a wife for him from the land of Egypt.
22 Le ɣeyiɣi mawo me la, Abimelek kple eƒe aʋafia Pikol gblɔ na Abraham be: “Mawu li kpli wò le nu sia nu si nèwɔna la me.
22 At that time Abimelech together with Phicol the chief of his army said to Abraham: “God is with you in everything you are doing.

23 Eya ta tsɔ Mawu ka atam nam be màwɔ vɔ̃ aɖeke nye kple vinyewo kpakple nye dzidzimeviwo o; be lɔlɔ̃ vavã si meɖe fia wò la kee wò hã nàɖe afia nye kple anyigba si dzi nèva le la.” 24 Eya ta Abraham gblɔ be: “Maka atam ɖe nya sia dzi.”

23 So now swear to me here by God that you will not deal falsely with me and with my offspring and with my descendants, and that you will deal with me and with the land where you have been residing with the same loyal love that I have shown you.” 24 So Abraham said: “I swear to this.”
25 Ke hã, Abraham na nutsotso Abimelek le vudo si Abimelek ƒe subɔviwo sẽ ŋuta xɔ le wo si la ta.
25 However, Abraham complained to Abimelech about the well of water that the servants of Abimelech had violently seized.

26 Abimelek gblɔ be: “Nyemenya ame si wɔ nu sia o, wò ŋutɔ hã mègblɔe nam o, eye nyemesee kpɔ abe ale si nèle egblɔm nam egbea ene o.” 27 Ale Abraham tsɔ alẽwo kple nyiwo na Abimelek, eye wo ame evea wobla nu.

26 Abimelech replied: “I do not know who did this; you did not tell me about it, and I heard nothing about it until today.” 27 At that Abraham took sheep and cattle and gave them to Abimelech, and the two of them made a covenant.

28 Esi Abraham ɖe alẽnɔe adre tso alẽha la dome ɖe vovo la, 29 Abimelek bia Abraham be: “Nu ka tae nèɖe alẽnɔe adre siawo ɖe vovo?” 30 Eɖo eŋu be: “Xɔ alẽnɔe adre siawo le asinye, be wòanye kpeɖodzi be nyee ɖe vudo sia.” 31 Ema tae wòtsɔ ŋkɔ na teƒe ma be Beer-Seba, elabena afi mae wo ame evea woka atam le.

28 When Abraham set seven female lambs apart from the flock by themselves, 29 Abimelech said to Abraham: “Why have you set these seven female lambs here by themselves?” 30 Then he said: “You are to accept the seven female lambs from my hand as a witness that I dug this well.” 31 That is why he called that place Beer-sheba, because there both of them had taken an oath.
32 Ale wobla nu le Beer-Seba; emegbe Abimelek kple eƒe aʋafia Pikol tso, eye wogbugbɔ yi Filistitɔwo ƒe anyigba dzi.
32 So they made a covenant at Beer-sheba, after which Abimelech got up together with Phicol the chief of his army, and they returned to the land of the Philistines.
33 Emegbe Abraham do tamarisk-ti aɖe ɖe Beer-Seba, eye wòyɔ Yehowa, Mawu si li tso mavɔ me yi mavɔ me la, ƒe ŋkɔ le afi ma.
33 After that he planted a tamarisk tree at Beer-sheba, and there he called on the name of Jehovah, the everlasting God.
34 Eye Abraham nɔ Filistitɔwo ƒe anyigba dzi eteƒe didi.
34 And Abraham stayed in the land of the Philistines for a long time.
Eye Yosef dze fofoa dzi, eye wòfa avi ɖe edzi hegbugbɔ nu nɛ.
Joseph then threw himself on his father and wept over him and kissed him.
2 Emegbe Yosef de se na eƒe subɔvi siwo nye atikewɔlawo be woasi atike na ye fofo.
2 After that Joseph commanded his servants, the physicians, to embalm his father.
Eya ta atikewɔlawo si atike na Israel; 3 ŋkeke blaene sɔŋ wozã ɖe eŋu, elabena ŋkeke siawoe wotsɔna sia atike na ame kukui, eye Egiptetɔwo fae ŋkeke blaadre.
So the physicians embalmed Israel, 3 and they took the full 40 days for him, for this is the full period for the embalming, and the Egyptians continued to shed tears for him 70 days.
4 Esi ŋkeke siwo wofae la va yi la, Yosef gblɔ na Farao ƒe fiasãmetɔwo be: “Ne mieve nunye la, ekema migblɔ na Farao be, 5 ‘Fofonye na meka atam, eye wògblɔ be: “Kpɔ ɖa, mele kukum.

4 When the days of mourning for him passed, Joseph spoke to Pharaoh’s court, saying: “If I have found favor in your eyes, give this message to Pharaoh: 5 ‘My father made me swear, saying: “Look! I am dying.
Yɔdo si meɖe ɖe Kanaan-nyigba dzi la mee nàɖim ɖo.”
You are to bury me in my burial place, which I have excavated in the land of Canaan.”
Eya ta meɖe kuku, na mayi aɖaɖi fofonye, emegbe magatrɔ agbɔ.’” 6 Farao ɖo eŋu be: “Yi nàɖaɖi fofowò, abe ale si tututu wòna nèka atam ene.”
Please, let me go up and bury my father, after which I will return.’” 6 Pharaoh replied: “Go and bury your father just as he made you swear.”

7 Eya ta Yosef yi ɖaɖi fofoa, eye Farao ƒe subɔviwo katã, ametsitsi siwo le eƒe fiasã me kpakple Egipte-nyigba la dzi ametsitsiwo katã yi kplii 8 hekpe ɖe Yosef ƒemetɔwo katã kple nɔviawo kpakple fofoa ƒemetɔwo katã ŋu.

7 So Joseph went up to bury his father, and all of Pharaoh’s servants went with him, the elders of his court and all the elders of the land of Egypt 8 and all of Joseph’s household and his brothers and the household of his father.
Negbe wo vi suewo, woƒe alẽhawo kple woƒe nyihawo koe wogblẽ ɖe Gosen-nyigba dzi.
Only their little children and their flocks and their herds they left in the land of GOshen.
9 Tasiaɖamwo kple sɔdolawo hã yi kplii, wonye ameha gã aɖe ŋutɔ.
9 Chariots and horsemen also went up with him, and the camp was very numerous.
10 Eye wova ɖo Atad ƒe nukuƒoƒe le Yordan nuto me, eye wofa konyi vevie le afi ma eteƒe mekɔ o, Yosef fa fofoa ŋkeke adre.
10 Then they came to the threshing floor of Atad, which is in the region of the Jordan, and there they carried on a very great and bitter mourning, and he kept mourning for his father seven days.
11 Eye anyigba la dzi nɔlawo, siwo nye Kanaantɔwo, kpɔ ale si wofa konyi le Atad ƒe nukuƒoƒe la, eye wodo ɣli be: “Egiptetɔwo ƒe konyifafa sia teƒe mekɔ o!”
11 The inhabitants of the land, the Canaanites, saw them mourning at the threshing floor of Atad, and they exclaimed: “This is a great mourning for the Egyptians!”
Esia tae wona ŋkɔ teƒea be Abel-Mizrayim, ele Yordan nuto la me.
That is why it was named Abel-mizrAim, which is in the region of the Jordan.
12 Eye viawo wɔ pɛpɛpɛ abe ale si wòde se na woe ene.
12 So his sons did for him exactly as he had instructed them.
13 Ale viawo kɔe yi Kanaan-nyigba dzi, eye woɖii ɖe agado si le Makepela-nyigba dzi la me; anyigba mae Abraham ƒle le Hititɔ Efron si, le Mamre ŋgɔ be wòazu yeƒe ameɖiƒe.

13 His sons carried him into the land of Canaan and buried him in the cave of the field of Machpelah, the field in front of Mamre that Abraham had purchased from Ephron the Hittite as property for a burial place.
14 Esi Yosef ɖi fofoa vɔ la, eya kple nɔviawo kpakple ame siwo katã yi kplii woɖaɖi fofoa la trɔ gbɔ va Egipte.
14 After he buried his father, Joseph returned to Egypt with his brothers and all those who had gone with him to bury his father.

15 Esi Yosef nɔviwo kpɔ be yewo fofo ku la, wogblɔ be: “Ðewohĩ Yosef lé mí ɖe dɔme, eye wòaɖo vɔ̃ siwo katã míewɔ ɖe eŋu la teƒe na mí.” 16 Eya ta wodɔ woyi ɖagblɔ na Yosef be: “Hafi fofowò naku la, ede se na mí be, 17 ‘Ale miagblɔ na Yosef ye nye esi: “Meɖe kuku na wò, tsɔ agɔ si nɔviwòwo dze, kple nu vɔ̃ si wowɔ hena nèkpe fu la ke dzro.”’

15 When Joseph’s brothers saw that their father was dead, they said: “It may be that Joseph is harboring animosity against us and that he will repay us for all the evil that we did to him.” 16 So they sent a message to Joseph in these words: “Your father gave this command before his death: 17 ‘This is what you are to say to Joseph: “I beg you, please pardon the transgression of your brothers and the sin they committed in bringing such harm to you.”’
Eya ta míeɖe kuku, tsɔ agɔ si fofowò ƒe Mawu la ƒe subɔlawo dze la ke.”
Now, please, pardon the transgression of the servants of your father’s God.”
Eye esi wogblɔ nya sia na Yosef la, ewó avi.
And Joseph wept when they spoke to him.

18 Eye nɔviawo hã va tsyɔ mo anyi ɖe eŋkume gblɔ be: “Míawoe nye esi; míezu wò kluviwo!” 19 Yosef gblɔ na wo be: “Migavɔ̃ o, Mawu teƒee melea? 20 Miawo miedi vɔ̃ nam, ke Mawu ya trɔe wòzu nyui, abe ale si wòle egbe sia ene, ale be wòaxɔ ame geɖewo ɖe agbe.

18 Then his brothers also came and fell down before him and said: “Here we are as slaves to you!” 19 Joseph said to them: “Do not be afraid. Am I in the place of God? 20 Although you meant to harm me, God intended it to turn out well and to preserve many people alive, as he is doing today.
21 Eya ta migavɔ̃ o.
21 So now do not be afraid.
Manɔ nuɖuɖu nam mia kple mia viwo.”
I will keep supplying you and your little children with food.”
Ale wòfa akɔ na wo, eye wòde dzi ƒo na wo.
Thus he comforted them and spoke reassuringly to them.
22 Yosef kple fofoa ƒe aƒemetɔwo nɔ Egipte, eye Yosef nɔ agbe ƒe alafa ɖeka kple ewo.
22 And Joseph continued to dwell in Egypt, he and the household of his father, and Joseph lived for 110 years.
23 Yosef kpɔ Efrayim ƒe viwo, va se ɖe dzidzime etɔ̃lia, eye wòkpɔ Manase vi Makir ƒe viwo hã.
23 Joseph saw the third generation of Ephraim’s sons, also the sons of MAchir, Manasseh’s son.
Yosef ƒe ata tae wodzi wo ɖo.
They were born upon Joseph’s knees.

24 Mlɔeba Yosef gblɔ na nɔviawo be: “Nye kuɣi ɖo, gake Mawu atrɔ susu ɖe mia ŋu godoo, eye wòakplɔ mi tso anyigba sia dzi ayi anyigba si ŋu wòka atam ɖo na Abraham, Isak kple Yakob la dzi.” 25 Eya ta Yosef na Israel ƒe viwo ka atam be: “Mawu atrɔ susu ɖe mia ŋu godoo.

24 At length Joseph said to his brothers: “I am dying, but God will without fail turn his attention to you, and he will certainly bring you up out of this land to the land about which he swore to Abraham, to Isaac, and to Jacob.” 25 So Joseph made the sons of Israel swear, saying: “God will without fail turn his attention to you.
Eya ta mitsɔ nye ƒuwo tso afi sia yii.” 26 Yosef ku esi wòxɔ ƒe alafa ɖeka kple ewo, eye wosi atike nɛ hedee aɖaka le Egipte.
You must take my bones up out of here.” 26 And Joseph died at the age of 110, and they had him embalmed, and he was put in a coffin in Egypt.

Eya ta Yosef yi ɖagblɔ na Farao be: “Fofonye kple nɔvinyewo tso Kanaan-nyigba dzi va kple woƒe alẽhawo kple nyihawo kpakple nu siwo katã le wo si, eye wole Gosen-nyigba dzi.” 2 Ekplɔ nɔviaŋutsu atɔ̃ ɖe asi, eye wòɖe wo fia Farao.

So Joseph went and reported to Pharaoh: “My father and my brothers and their flocks and their herds and all that they possess have come from the land of Canaan, and they are in the land of GOshen.” 2 He took five of his brothers and presented them to Pharaoh.
3 Eye Farao bia nɔviawo be: “Dɔ ka wɔlawo mienye?”
3 Pharaoh said to his brothers: “What is your occupation?”

Eye woɖo eŋu na Farao be: “Alẽkplɔlawoe wò dɔlawo nye, mía kple mía tɔgbuiwo siaa.” 4 Wogblɔ na Farao be: “Míeva be míanye amedzro le anyigba la dzi, elabena gbeɖuƒe aɖeke megali na wò dɔlawo ƒe lãhawo o, elabena dɔtoto la nu sẽ le Kanaan-nyigba dzi.

They replied to Pharaoh: “Your servants are herders of sheep, both we and our forefathers.” 4 Then they said to Pharaoh: “We have come to reside as foreigners in the land because there are no pastures for the flock of your servants, for the famine is severe in the land of Canaan.
Eya ta míeɖe kuku, na wò dɔlawo nanɔ Gosen-nyigba dzi.” 5 Eye Farao gblɔ na Yosef be: “Fofowò kple nɔviwòwo va gbɔwò le afi sia.
So please let your servants dwell in the land of GOshen.” 5 At that Pharaoh said to Joseph: “Your father and your brothers have come here to you.
6 Egipte-nyigba la le asiwò me.
6 The land of Egypt is at your disposal.
Na fofowò kple nɔviwòwo nanɔ anyigba la ƒe teƒe nyuitɔ.
Have your father and your brothers dwell in the very best part of the land.
Na woanɔ Gosen-nyigba dzi, eye ne èkpɔ ŋutsu zazɛ̃ aɖewo le wo dome la, ɖo wo be woakpɔ nye lãhawo dzi.”
Let them dwell in the land of GOshen, and if you know of any capable men among them, put them in charge of my livestock.”
7 Emegbe Yosef kplɔ fofoa Yakob vɛ heɖee fia Farao, eye Yakob yra Farao.
7 Then Joseph brought in Jacob his father and presented him to Pharaoh, and Jacob blessed Pharaoh.
8 Eye Farao bia Yakob be: “Ƒe nenie nèxɔ?” 9 Yakob gblɔ na Farao be: “Mexɔ ƒe alafa ɖeka blaetɔ̃, eye ƒe siawoe metsɔ nɔ tsatsam.
8 Pharaoh asked Jacob: “How old are you?” 9 Jacob said to Pharaoh: “The years of my wanderings are 130.
Nye agbenɔƒewo le ʋɛe, eye mekpe hiã geɖe le wo me, eye womede tɔgbuinyewo ƒe agbenɔƒe siwo wotsɔ tsae la nu o.” 10 Esia megbe la, Yakob yra Farao, eye wòdzo le egbɔ.

Few and distressing the years of my life have been, and they are not as long as the years of the lives of my forefathers during their wanderings.” 10 After that Jacob blessed Pharaoh and went out from before him.
11 Ale Yosef na fofoa kple nɔviawo va nɔ Egipte-nyigba dzi, eye wòna wonɔ anyigba la ƒe teƒe nyuitɔ, le Ramses, abe ale si tututu Farao de see ene.
11 So Joseph settled his father and his brothers, and he gave them a possession in the land of Egypt, in the very best part of the land, in the land of Rameses, just as Pharaoh had commanded.
12 Eye Yosef naa nuɖuɖu fofoa kple nɔviawo kpakple fofoa ƒemetɔwo katã, le wo viwo ƒe xexlẽme nu.
12 And Joseph kept supplying his father and his brothers and the entire household of his father with food according to the number of their children.
13 Ke nuɖuɖu aɖeke mele anyigba blibo la katã dzi o, elabena dɔtoto la nu sẽ ŋutɔ, eye nu te Egipte-nyigba kple Kanaan-nyigba dzi nɔlawo ŋu le dɔtoto la ta.
13 Now there was no food in all the land, because the famine was very severe, and the land of Egypt and the land of Canaan became exhausted as a result of the famine.
14 Eye Yosef nɔa ga siwo katã Egipte-nyigba kple Kanaan-nyigba dzi tɔwo tsɔ nɔa nuɖuɖuwo ƒlem la nu ƒom ƒu, eye Yosef tsɔa ga la vaa Farao ƒe me.

14 Joseph was collecting all the money that was to be found in the land of Egypt and in the land of Canaan for the grain that people were buying, and Joseph kept bringing the money into Pharaoh’s house.
15 Le ɣeyiɣi aɖe megbe la, ga siwo katã le Egipte-nyigba kple Kanaan-nyigba dzi la vɔ, eye Egiptetɔwo katã vaa Yosef gbɔ va gblɔna be: “Na nuɖuɖu mí!
15 In time the money from the land of Egypt and the land of Canaan was spent, and all the Egyptians began coming to Joseph, saying: “Give us food!

Nu ka tae míaku le ŋkuwòme le esi ga vɔ le mía si ta?” 16 Yosef gblɔ be: “Ne ga vɔ le mia si la, ekema mikplɔ miaƒe lãhawo vɛ, ne mana nuɖuɖu mi ɖe miaƒe lãhawo teƒe.” 17 Eye wokplɔa woƒe lãhawo vanɛ na Yosef, eye Yosef naa nuɖuɖu wo ɖe woƒe sɔwo kple alẽhawo kple nyihawo kpakple tedziwo teƒe, eye wòxɔ woƒe lãhawo katã hena nuɖuɖu wo ɖe eteƒe le ƒe ma me.

Why should we die before your very eyes because our money has run out?” 16 Then Joseph said: “If your money has run out, hand over your livestock, and I will give you food in exchange for your livestock.” 17 So they began bringing their livestock to Joseph, and Joseph kept giving them food in exchange for their horses, the livestock of the flock and of the herd, and the donkeys, and he kept providing them with food in exchange for all their livestock during that year.
18 Esi ƒe ma va wu enu la, wova egbɔ le ƒe si kplɔe ɖo me va gblɔ be: “Míele nya sia ɣla ge ɖe mía aƒetɔ o, nya lae nye be míetsɔ míaƒe ga kple míaƒe aƒemelãwo katã na mía aƒetɔ xoxo.

18 When that year came to its close, they began coming to him the next year and saying: “We will not hide from my lord that the money and the stock of domestic animals have already been given to my lord.
Naneke megakpɔtɔ le mía si míatsɔ ana mía aƒetɔ o, negbe míawo ŋutɔwo kple míaƒe anyigbawo ko.
We have nothing left for my lord but our bodies and our land.
19 Nu ka ta míaku le ŋkuwòme, eye míaƒe anyigbawo naɖi gbɔlo?
19 Why should we die before your eyes, both we and our land?
Ƒle míawo kple míaƒe anyigbawo ɖe nuɖuɖu teƒe, eye míawo ŋutɔwo míazu kluviwo na Farao, eye míaƒe anyigbawo nazu etɔ.
Buy us and our land in exchange for food, and we together with our land will become slaves to Pharaoh.

Na nuku mí, ne míanɔ agbe, eye míagaku, ne míaƒe anyigbawo nagaɖi gbɔlo o.” 20 Ale Yosef ƒle Egiptetɔwo ƒe anyigbawo katã na Farao, elabena Egiptetɔ ɖe sia ɖe dzra eƒe anyigba le esi dɔtoto la nu sẽ ŋutɔ ta; eye anyigba la katã va zu Farao tɔ.

Give us seed so that we may live and not die and that our land may not become desolate.” 20 Joseph then bought all the land of the Egyptians for Pharaoh because every Egyptian sold his field, for the famine was very severe; and the land became Pharaoh’s.
21 Ke ena ameawo ʋu tso Egipte nutoawo ƒe go ɖe sia ɖe me yi dugãwo me.
21 Then he moved the people into cities, from one end of the territory of Egypt to its other end.
22 Negbe nunɔlawo ƒe anyigbawo koe meƒle o, elabena Farao gbɔe nunɔlawo xɔa nuɖuɖu tso.
22 Only the land of the priests he did not buy, because the rations for the priests were from Pharaoh and they lived on their rations that Pharaoh gave them.
Esia tae womedzra woƒe anyigba o.
That is why they did not sell their land.
23 Eye Yosef gblɔ na ameawo be: “Kpɔ ɖa, meƒle mia kple miaƒe anyigbawo na Farao egbe.
23 Then Joseph said to the people: “See, I have today bought you and your land for Pharaoh.
Kpɔ ɖa, mixɔ nuku ne miaƒã ɖe anyigba la dzi.
Here is seed for you, and you must sow the land with it.

24 Ne nukuawo wɔ la, ekema miatsɔ eƒe me mama atɔ̃ ƒe ɖeka ana Farao, ke akpa ene nanye mia tɔ, miaƒã eƒe ɖe ɖe agble me, eye ɖe nanye nuɖuɖu na mia kple miaƒe aƒemetɔwo kpakple mia viwo.” 25 Eya ta wogblɔ be: “Èkpɔ míaƒe agbe ta.

24 When it produces, give a fifth to Pharaoh, but four parts will be yours as seed for the field and as food for you and for those in your houses and for your children to eat.” 25 So they said: “You have preserved our lives.
Mía aƒetɔ neve mía nu ko, eye míazu Farao ƒe kluviwo.” 26 Eya ta Yosef na wòzu se va se ɖe egbe sia be Farao naxɔ agblemenuwo ƒe me mama atɔ̃ ƒe ɖeka le Egipte-nyigba la dzi.
Let us find favor in the eyes of my lord, and we will become slaves to Pharaoh.” 26 Then Joseph made it a decree, which is valid until today over the land of Egypt, that a fifth belongs to Pharaoh.
Negbe nunɔlawo ƒe anyigbawo koe mezu Farao tɔ o.
It was only the land of the priests that did not become Pharaoh’s.
27 Israel-viwo nɔ Gosen le Egipte-nyigba dzi; wotsi afi ma, eye wodzi heva sɔ gbɔ ŋutɔ.
27 Israel continued to dwell in the land of Egypt, in the land of GOshen, and they settled in it and were fruitful and increased greatly.
28 Ke Yakob nɔ Egipte-nyigba la dzi ƒe wuiadre, eye Yakob ƒe agbenɔƒewo va le ƒe alafa ɖeka blaene vɔ adre.
28 And Jacob lived on in the land of Egypt for 17 years, so that the days of Jacob’s life came to be 147 years.
29 Esi Israel kpɔ be yeƒe kuɣi nɔ ɖoɖom la, eyɔ via Yosef, eye wògblɔ nɛ be: “Ne ève nunye la, ekema meɖe kuku, tsɔ wò asi de nye ata te nàka atam nam be yeave nunye ahawɔ nuteƒe nam.

29 The time was approaching for Israel to die, so he called his son Joseph and said: “If, now, I have found favor in your eyes, place your hand, please, under my thigh, and show loyal love and faithfulness to me.
Meɖe kuku, mègaɖim ɖe Egipte o.
Please, do not bury me in Egypt.
30 Ne meku la, ekema nàkɔm adzoe le Egipte aɖaɖi ɖe tɔgbuinyewo ɖiƒe.”
30 When I die, you must carry me out of Egypt and bury me in the grave of my forefathers.”
Eye wòɖo eŋu be: “Mawɔe abe ale si tututu nègblɔe ene.” 31 Eye wògblɔ be: “Ka atam nam.”
Accordingly, he said: “I will do just as you say.” 31 Then he said: “Swear to me.”
Ale wòka atam nɛ.
So he swore to him.
Eye Israel tsyɔ mo anyi ɖe abati la ƒe tade.
At that Israel bowed down at the head of his bed.
Ke dɔ to le anyigba la dzi, esia to vovo na dɔ si to va yi le Abraham ŋɔli; eya ta Isak yi Filistitɔwo ƒe fia Abimelek gbɔ le Gerar.
Now there was a famine in the land, in addition to the first famine that occurred in the days of Abraham, so that Isaac went to Abimelech king of the Philistines, in Gerar.
2 Yehowa ɖe eɖokui fiae gblɔ be: “Mègayi Egipte o.
2 Then Jehovah appeared to him and said: “Do not go down to Egypt.
Nɔ anyigba si matia na wò la dzi.
Dwell in the land that I designate to you.

3 Nɔ anyigba sia dzi nànye amedzro le edzi, manɔ kpli wò, eye mayra wò, elabena wò kple wò dzidzimeviwoe matsɔ anyigba siawo katã ana, eye mawɔ atam si meka na fofowò Abraham la dzi, 4 ‘Mana wò dzidzimeviwo nasɔ gbɔ abe dziƒoɣletiviwo ene, eye matsɔ anyigba siawo katã ana wò dzidzimeviwo; eye anyigbadzidukɔwo katã axɔ yayra to wò dzidzimeviwo dzi,’ 5 elabena Abraham ɖo to nye gbe, eye wòyi edzi wɔ nye didiwo, nye mɔfiamewo, nye ɖoɖowo kple nye sewo dzi.” 6 Ale Isak yi edzi nɔ Gerar.

3 Reside as a foreigner in this land, and I will continue with you and bless you because to you and to your offspring I will give all these lands, and I will carry out the oath that I swore to your father Abraham: 4 ‘I will multiply your offspring like the stars of the heavens; and I will give to your offspring all these lands; and by means of your offspring, all nations of the earth will obtain a blessing for themselves,’ 5 on account of the fact that Abraham listened to my voice and continued to keep my requirements, my commands, my statutes, and my laws.” 6 So Isaac continued to dwell in Gerar.
7 Ne ŋutsu siwo le afi ma la bia nyae tso srɔ̃a ŋu la, egblɔna be: “Nɔvinyee.”
7 When the men of the place kept asking about his wife, he would say: “She is my sister.”
Ele vɔvɔ̃m be yeagblɔ be “Srɔ̃nyee,” elabena egblɔ be: “Afi ma ŋutsuwo ava wum le Rebeka ta”; elabena edze tugbe.
He was afraid to say, “She is my wife,” for he said, “The men of the place might kill me because of Rebekah,” for she was beautiful in appearance.
8 Le ɣeyiɣi aɖe megbe la, Filistitɔwo ƒe fia Abimelek nɔ nu kpɔm to fesre nu, eye wòkpɔ be Isak ye nye ema le fefem kple srɔ̃a Rebeka lɔlɔ̃tɔe.
8 After some time had passed, Abimelech king of the Philistines was looking out of the window, and he saw Isaac displaying affection for Rebekah his wife.
9 Enumake Abimelek yɔ Isak gblɔ nɛ be: “Srɔ̃wòe wònye tso!
9 At once Abimelech called Isaac and said: “She is actually your wife!
Ke nu ka tae nègblɔ be: ‘Nɔvinyee’?”
Why did you say, ‘She is my sister’?”
Isak gblɔ nɛ be: “Megblɔe nenema, elabena mele vɔvɔ̃m be woava wum le eta.” 10 Ke Abimelek gblɔ be: “Nu kae nye esi nèwɔ ɖe mía ŋu?
At this Isaac said to him: “I said it for fear I should die because of her.” 10 But Abimelech continued: “What have you done to us?
Anye ne nye ameawo dometɔ ɖeka ate ŋu ade asi srɔ̃wòa ŋu bɔbɔe; eye àna míaɖi fɔ!” 11 Eye Abimelek de se na ameawo katã be: “Ame sia ame si aka asi ŋutsu sia kple srɔ̃a ŋu la, woawui!”

One of the people could easily have lain down with your wife, and you would have brought guilt upon us!” 11 Then Abimelech commanded all the people, saying: “Anybody touching this man and his wife will surely be put to death!”
12 Isak ƒã nu ɖe anyigba ma dzi, eye wòkpɔ nu si wòƒã la ƒe teƒe alafa ɖeka le ƒe ma me, elabena Yehowa yrae.
12 And Isaac began to sow seed in that land, and in that year he reaped 100 times what he sowed, for Jehovah was blessing him.
13 Ale ŋutsu la va zu kesinɔtɔ, eye nuwo nɔ edzi dzem nɛ va se ɖe esime wòzu kesinɔtɔ gã aɖe.
13 The man became wealthy, and he continued to prosper until he became very wealthy.
14 Alẽhawo kple nyihawo kpakple subɔviwo ƒe ha gã aɖe va su esi, eye Filistitɔwo va nɔ ŋu biãmee.
14 He acquired flocks of sheep and herds of cattle and a large body of servants, and the Philistines began to envy him.
15 Eya ta Filistitɔwo lɔ ke tsɔ xe vudo siwo katã fofoa ƒe subɔviwo ɖe le Abraham ŋɔli la keŋ.
15 So the Philistines took soil and stopped up all the wells that his father’s servants had dug in the days of Abraham.
16 Abimelek gblɔ na Isak be: “Dzo le míaƒe nutoa me, elabena èva kpɔ ŋusẽ geɖe wu mí.” 17 Eya ta Isak dzo le afi ma, eye wòyi ɖatu eƒe agbadɔ ɖe Gerar Bali la me henɔ afi ma.
16 Abimelech then said to Isaac: “Move from our neighborhood, for you have grown far stronger than we are.” 17 So Isaac moved from there and encamped in the valley of Gerar and began dwelling there.
18 Eye Isak gbugbɔ vudo siwo woɖe le fofoa Abraham ŋɔli siwo Filistitɔwo va xe le Abraham ƒe ku megbe la ɖe, eye wògbugbɔ ŋkɔ siwo fofoa na wo la tsɔ na wo.

18 And Isaac again dug the wells that had been dug in the days of his father Abraham but that the Philistines had stopped up after Abraham’s death, and he called them by the names that his father had given them.
19 Esi Isak ƒe subɔviwo nɔ bali la me kum la, wova ke ɖe vudo aɖe si me tsi nyui le ŋu.
19 When the servants of Isaac were digging in the valley, they found a well of fresh water.
20 Eye Gerar lãkplɔviwo de asi dzrewɔwɔ me kple Isak ƒe lãkplɔviwo hegblɔ be: “Mía tɔe vudo sia nye!”
20 And the shepherds of Gerar began quarreling with the shepherds of Isaac, saying: “The water is ours!”
Eya ta ena ŋkɔ vudo la be Esek, elabena wowɔ dzre kplii.
So he named the well esek, because they had quarreled with him.
21 Eye wogadze vudo bubu ɖeɖe gɔme, ke wogade asi dzrewɔwɔ me ɖe eya hã ta.
21 And they started digging another well, and they began quarreling over it also.
Eya ta ena ŋkɔe be Sitna.
So he named it Sitnah.
22 Emegbe edzo le afi ma yi ɖaɖe vudo bubu, gake womewɔ dzre ɖe ema ya ta o.
22 Later he moved away from there and dug another well, but they did not quarrel over it.
Ale wòna ŋkɔe be Rehobot hegblɔ be: “Elabena Yehowa na teƒe gã aɖe mí, eye wòna míesɔ gbɔ ɖe anyigba la dzi.”
So he named it RehOboth and said: “It is because now Jehovah has given us ample room and has made us fruitful in the land.”
23 Emegbe edzo le afi ma yi Beer-Seba.
23 Then he went up from there to Beer-sheba.
24 Yehowa ɖe eɖokui fiae le zã ma me gblɔ be: “Nyee nye fofowò Abraham ƒe Mawu.
24 That night Jehovah appeared to him and said: “I am the God of your father Abraham.
Mègavɔ̃ o, elabena meli kpli wò, mayra wò eye mana wò dzidzimeviwo nasɔ gbɔ le nye subɔla Abraham ta.” 25 Eya ta eɖi vɔsamlekpui ɖe afi ma heyɔ Yehowa ŋkɔ.
Do not be afraid, for I am with you, and I will bless you and multiply your offspring on account of Abraham my servant.” 25 So he built an altar there and called on the name of Jehovah.
Eye Isak tu eƒe agbadɔ ɖe afi ma, eye eƒe subɔviwo ɖe vudo ɖe afi ma.
And Isaac pitched his tent there, and his servants dug a well there.
26 Emegbe Abimelek tso Gerar va egbɔ, eya kple eƒe aɖaŋuɖola Ahuzat kpakple eƒe aʋafia Pikol.
26 Later Abimelech came to him from Gerar with Ahuzzath his personal adviser and Phicol the chief of his army.
27 Eye Isak gblɔ na wo be: “Esi mielé fum, eye mienyam le miaƒe nutoa me ɖe, nu ka tae mieva gbɔnye?” 28 Woɖo eŋu nɛ be: “Míekpɔe dze sii be Yehowa li kpli wò.
27 At this Isaac said to them: “Why have you come to me, seeing that you hated me and sent me away from your neighborhood?” 28 To this they said: “We have clearly seen that Jehovah has been with you.

Eya ta ‘Míeɖe kuku, na míaka atam na mía nɔewo, ne míabla nu kpli wò, 29 be màwɔ vɔ̃ aɖeke mí o, abe ale si ko míawo hã míewɔ nu vevi aɖeke wò o, ke boŋ míewɔ nyui ɖeɖe sɔŋ na wò hedo mɔ wò le ŋutifafa me ene.

So we said, ‘Let there, please, be an oath of obligation between us and you, and let us make a covenant with you 29 that you will do nothing bad to us just as we have not harmed you, seeing that we have done only good to you in that we sent you away in peace.
Fifia Yehowa ƒe ame yayrae nènye.’” 30 Emegbe eɖo kplɔ̃ na wo, eye woɖu nu no nu.
You now are the blessed of Jehovah.’” 30 Then he made a feast for them, and they ate and drank.
31 Wofɔ ŋdi kanya, eye woka atam na wo nɔewo.
31 In the morning they got up early and swore an oath to each other.
Eyome Isak do mɔ wo, eye wodzo le egbɔ le ŋutifafa me.
After that Isaac sent them away, and they went from him in peace.
32 Gbe ma gbe la, Isak ƒe subɔviwo va gblɔ vudo si woɖe la ŋu nya nɛ be: “Míeke ɖe tsi ŋu!” 33 Eya ta ena ŋkɔe be Siba.
32 On that day the servants of Isaac came and reported to him about the well that they had dug, and they told him: “We have found water!” 33 So he named it Shibah.
Esia tae woyɔ du la be Beer-Seba va se ɖe egbe sia.
That is why the name of the city is Beer-sheba to this day.
34 Esi Esau xɔ ƒe blaene la, eɖe Hititɔ Beeri vinyɔnu Yudit kple Hititɔ Elon vinyɔnu Basemat.
34 When Esau was 40 years old, he took as wife Judith the daughter of Beeri the Hittite and also Basemath the daughter of Elon the Hittite.
35 Eye nyɔnu siawo zu nuxaxa gã aɖe na Isak kple Rebeka.
35 They were a source of great grief to Isaac and Rebekah.
Eye Yakob yɔ viaŋutsuwo gblɔ bena: “Miƒo ƒu, ne magblɔ nu si gbɔna dzɔdzɔ ge ɖe mia dzi le ɣeyiɣi siwo gbɔna me la na mi.
And Jacob called his sons and said: “Gather yourselves together that I may tell you what will happen to you in the final part of the days.
2 Mi Yakob viwo, miƒo ƒu, eye miɖo to, ɛ̃, miɖo to mia fofo Israel.
2 Assemble yourselves and listen, you sons of Jacob, yes, listen to Israel your father.
3 “Ruben, wòe nye nye ŋgɔgbevi, nye ŋusẽ kple nye vidziŋusẽ ƒe gɔmedzedze, bubu nyuitɔ kple ŋusẽ nyuitɔ.
3 “Reuben, you are my firstborn, my vigor and the beginning of my procreative power, the excellence of dignity and the excellence of strength.
4 Esi mèdzea akɔ anyi o abe tɔ dzeagbowo ene ta la, màƒo nɔviwòwo ta o, elabena ède fofowò ƒe aba dzi.
4 With recklessness like turbulent waters, you will not excel, because you have gone up to your father’s bed.
Ɣemaɣi èƒo ɖi nye aba.
At that time you defiled my bed.
Ɛ̃, ede edzi!
He actually went on to it!
5 “Nɔviwoe Simeon kple Lewi nye.
5 “Simeon and Levi are brothers.
Wotsɔ woƒe lãnuwo wɔ ŋutasẽnuwoe.
Instruments of violence are their slaughter weapons.
6 Oo, nye luʋɔ, mègade ha kpli wo o.
6 Into their company do not come, O my soul.
Oo, nye bubu, mègawɔ ɖeka kple woƒe ha o, elabena dziku mee wowu amewo le, eye wotso agbeka na nyitsuwo tsɔ do dzidzɔ na wo ɖokuiwo.
With their assembly do not join, O my honor, because in their anger they killed men, and for their pleasure they hamstrung bulls.
7 Aɖi woƒe dziku ŋu, elabena evɔ̃ɖi akpa, kple woƒe dɔmedzoe ŋu, elabena enu sẽ akpa.
7 Cursed be their anger, because it is cruel, and their fury, because it is harsh.
Makaka wo ɖe Yakob me, eye mana woaka hlẽ ɖe Israel.
Let me disperse them in Jacob, and let me scatter them in Israel.
8 “Ke wò, Yuda, nɔviwòwo akafu wò.
8 “As for you, Judah, your brothers will praise you.
Wò asi anɔ wò futɔwo ƒe ve dzi.
Your hand will be on the neck of your enemies.
Fofowò ƒe viwo abɔbɔ ɖe ŋkuwòme.
The sons of your father will bow down before you.
9 Dzatavie Yuda nye.
9 Judah is a lion cub.
Vinye, àɖu wò nuléle ahatso adzo.
From the prey, my son, you will certainly go up.
Emlɔ anyi hedra ɖi abe dzata ene, eye ame kae ake atse aʋuʋui? 10 Fiatikplɔ la mate ɖa le Yuda gbɔ o, eye gbeɖela ƒe atikplɔ hã mate ɖa le ekɔme o, va se ɖe esime Silo nava, eyae dukɔwo aɖo toe.

He has crouched down and stretched himself out like a lion, and like a lion, who dares rouse him? 10 The scepter will not depart from Judah, neither the commander’s staff from between his feet, until Shiloh comes, and to him the obedience of the peoples will belong.
11 Ede ka eƒe tedzi ɖe wainka ŋu, kple eya ŋutɔ ƒe tedzivi ɖe wainka nyui aɖe ŋu; anya eƒe avɔ ɖe wain me kple eƒe awu ɖe waintsetse me tsi me.
11 Tying his donkey to a vine and his donkey’s colt to a choice vine, he will wash his clothing in wine and his garment in the blood of grapes.
12 Wain na eƒe ŋkuwo biã, eye notsi na eƒe aɖuwo fu tititi.
12 Dark red are his eyes from wine, and his teeth are white from milk.
13 “Zebulon anɔ ƒuta, eye wòanɔ ƒuta afi si wodea seke tɔdziʋuwo ɖo, eye eƒe mlɔenu kekeake anɔ Sidon lɔƒo.
13 “Zebulun will reside by the seashore, by the shore where the ships lie anchored, and his remote border will be toward Sidon.
14 “Isakar nye tedzi si ƒu sesẽwo le lãme na, eye wòmlɔ anyi ɖe sɔkpaŋukotoku eveawo dome.
14 “Issachar is a strong-boned donkey, lying down between the two saddlebags.
15 Akpɔe be gbɔɖemeƒe la nyo, eye be anyigba la nyo ŋutɔ.
15 And he will see that the resting-place is good and that the land is pleasant.
Abɔbɔ atsɔ agba ɖe eƒe abɔta, eye wòazu dzizizidɔwɔla.
He will bend his shoulder to bear the burden and will submit to forced labor.
16 “Dan anye Israel-toawo dometɔ ɖeka ahadrɔ̃ ʋɔnu dukɔ la.
16 “Dan will judge his people as one of the tribes of Israel.
17 Dan nenɔ abe da si le mɔ to, dzakpata si le afɔmɔ to, eye wòɖua afɔkpodzi na sɔ, ale be edola dzea anyi megbemegbee la ene.
17 Let Dan be a serpent by the roadside, a horned snake beside the path, that bites the heels of the horse so that its rider falls backward.
18 Oo Yehowa, manɔ wò xɔname lalam.
18 I will wait for salvation from you, O Jehovah.
19 “Ke adzohawo adze Gad dzi, gake eya hã ayɔ wo ɖe enu.
19 “As for Gad, a marauder band will raid him, but he will raid at their heels.
20 “Aser ƒe nuɖuɖu ado agbogbo, eye ana nuɖuɖu vivi siwo dze fiawo.
20 “Asher’s bread will be abundant, and he will provide food fit for a king.
21 “Naftali nye zinɔ tsralɛ.
21 “Naphtali is a slender doe.
Nya viviwo le esi wògblɔna.
He is speaking words of elegance.
22 “Yosef nye ati tseku ƒe dzeɖexɛ, ati tseku si le tsidzɔƒe, eɖe eƒe alɔwo wògbɔ gli ta.
22 “Joseph is the offshoot of a fruitful tree, a fruitful tree by a spring, whose branches extend over the wall.
23 Ke aŋutrɔdalawo le fu ɖem nɛ vevie, wotee kple da, eye wolé fui.
23 But the archers kept harassing him and shot at him and kept harboring animosity against him.
24 Gake eƒe dati le enɔƒe, eƒe asi tsɔna eye ŋusẽ le eŋu.
24 And yet his bow remained in place, and his hands stayed strong and agile.
Esia tso Yakob ƒe ŋusẽtɔ la, alẽkplɔla la, Israel ƒe kpe la gbɔ.
This was from the hands of the powerful one of Jacob, from the shepherd, the stone of Israel.
25 Eya tso fofowò ƒe Mawu la gbɔ, eyae akpe ɖe ŋuwò, ele Ŋusẽkatãtɔ la gbɔ, eyae atsɔ yayra siwo tso dziƒo kple yayra siwo tso agume kpakple no kple vidzidɔ ayra wò.

25 He is from the God of your father, and he will help you, and he is with the Almighty, and he will bless you with the blessings of the heavens above, with the blessings of the deep below, with the blessings of the breasts and womb.
26 Fofowò ƒe yayrawo agbɔ to siwo li tegbee la ƒe yayrawo kple togbɛ siwo li ɖaa la ƒe nu veviwo ŋu.
26 The blessings of your father will be superior to the blessings of the eternal mountains, to the desirable things of the enduring hills.
Woanɔ Yosef ƒe ta dzi, ame si woɖe ɖe vovo tso nɔviawo dome la ƒe dzodome.
They will continue upon the head of Joseph, upon the crown of the head of the one singled out from his brothers.
27 “Benyamin anɔ nu vuvum abe amegãxi ene.
27 “Benjamin will keep on tearing like a wolf.
Ŋdi la aɖu eƒe nuléle, eye wòama aboyonu le fiẽ.”
In the morning he will eat the prey, and in the evening he will divide spoil.”
28 Ame siawo mee Israel-to wuieveawo dzɔ tso, eye nya siawoe wo fofo gblɔ na wo esime wòle wo yram.
28 All of these are the 12 tribes of Israel, and this is what their father said to them when he was blessing them.
Ale wòyra wo dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe wotɔwotɔe.
He gave each of them an appropriate blessing.
29 Emegbe ede se siawo na wo be: “Wole tsɔ ye ge akpe ɖe nye amewo ŋu.
29 After that he gave these commands to them: “I am being gathered to my people.

Miɖim ɖe fofonyewo gbɔ le agado si le Hititɔ Efron ƒe anyigba dzi la me, 30 le agado si le Makepela-nyigba dzi le Mamre ŋgɔ, le Kanaan-nyigba dzi la me; eyae nye anyigba si Abraham ƒle le Hititɔ Efron si wòzu eƒe ameɖiƒe.

Bury me with my fathers in the cave that is in the field of Ephron the Hittite, 30 the cave in the field of Machpelah in front of Mamre in the land of Canaan, the field that Abraham purchased from Ephron the Hittite as a property for a burial place.
31 Afi mae woɖi Abraham kple srɔ̃a Sara ɖo.
31 There they buried Abraham and his wife Sarah.
Afi mae woɖi Isak kple srɔ̃a Rebeka ɖo, eye afi mae meɖi Lea ɖo.
There they buried Isaac and his wife Rebekah, and there I buried Leah.
32 Het viwo sie woƒle anyigba la kple agado si le edzi la le.”
32 The field and the cave that is in it were purchased from the sons of Heth.”
33 Ale Yakob wu nya siwo le esi na viawo la nu.
33 Thus Jacob finished giving these instructions to his sons.
Eye wòkɔ afɔ da ɖe abati la dzi, eye eƒe gbɔgbɔ nu tso, eye wotsɔe kpe ɖe eƒe amewo ŋu.
Then he drew his feet up onto the bed and breathed his last and was gathered to his people.
Azɔ dɔwuame la nu sẽ ŋutɔ le anyigba la dzi.
Now the famine was severe in the land.

2 Eya ta esi woɖu nuɖuɖu si wotsɔ tso Egipte gbɔe vɔ la, wo fofo gblɔ na wo be: “Migbugbɔ yi ɖaƒle nuɖuɖu vi aɖe vɛ na mí.” 3 Yuda gblɔ nɛ be: “Ŋutsu la na eme kɔ na mí nyuie be, ‘Migava ŋkunyeme azɔ o, negbe ɖe mia nɔvi la le mia ŋu hafi.’ 4 Ne èna mía nɔvi la yi kpli mí la, ekema míayi aɖaƒle nuɖuɖu na wò.

2 So when they had finished eating the grain they had brought from Egypt, their father said to them: “Return and buy a little food for us.” 3 Then Judah said to him: “The man clearly warned us, ‘You must not see my face again unless your brother is with you.’ 4 If you send our brother with us, we will go down and buy food for you.

5 Ke ne màna wòayi kpli mí o la, ekema míayi o, elabena ŋutsu la gblɔ na mí be: ‘Migava ŋkunyeme azɔ o, negbe ɖe mia nɔvi la le mia ŋu hafi.’” 6 Eye Israel bia be: “Nu ka tae miehe vɔ̃ sia va dzinye, be miegblɔ na ŋutsua be nɔvi bubu gale yewo si?” 7 Woɖo eŋu be: “Ŋutsu la bia nya mí tẽe tso míawo ŋutɔwo kple míaƒe ƒometɔwo ŋu be, ‘Mia fofo gale agbea?

5 But if you do not send him, we will not go down, for the man said to us, ‘You must not see my face again unless your brother is with you.’” 6 And Israel asked: “Why did you have to bring this trouble on me by telling the man that you had another brother?” 7 They replied: “The man directly inquired concerning us and our relatives, saying, ‘Is your father still alive?
Nɔvi bubu aɖe gale mia sia?’ Eye míegblɔ nya siawo katã nɛ.
Do you have another brother?’ and we told him these facts.
Aleke míawɔ anya be agblɔ na mí be, ‘Mikplɔ mia nɔvi la vɛ’?”
How could we possibly know that he would say, ‘Bring your brother down’?”
8 Yuda ɖe kuku na fofoa Israel vevie be: “Ðe asi le ɖevi la ŋu nam, ne míadze mɔ ayi, ne mía kpli wò kpakple mía viwo míatsi agbe, ale be míagaku o.
8 Judah then urged Israel his father: “Send the boy with me, and let us go on our way so that we may live and not die —we and you and our children.
9 Makpɔ egbɔ be ele dedie.
9 I will be a guarantee for his safety.
Àte ŋu abiae tso asinye.
You may hold me responsible.
Ne nyemekplɔe gbɔe na wò o la, ekema mewɔ nu vɔ̃ ɖe ŋuwò tegbee.
If I fail to return him to you and present him to you, I will have sinned against you for all time.
10 Gake ne menye ɖe míele hehem ɖe megbe o la, anye ne míede afi ma trɔ gbɔ zi eve xoxo.”
10 But if we had not delayed, we could have been there and back twice by now.”

11 Eya ta wo fofo Israel gblɔ na wo be: “Ne nenemae la, ekema miwɔ ale: Mitsɔ anyigba la dzi nu nyuitɔwo de miaƒe kotokuwo me yi ɖana ŋutsua: balsam-mi vi aɖe, anyitsi vi aɖe, labdano-ŋe kple aŋetikpa, newo kple yevuziwo.

11 So Israel their father said to them: “If it must be so, then do this: Take the finest products of the land in your bags and carry them down to the man as a gift: a little balsam, a little honey, labdanum, resinous bark, pistachio nuts, and almonds.
12 Mitsɔ ga la hã ƒe teƒe eve ɖe asi; eye mitsɔ ga si wotrɔ de miaƒe kotokuawo me la hã ɖe asi yii.
12 Take double the money with you; and also take back the money that was returned in the mouth of your bags.
Ðewohĩ ɖe woɖe ŋu ɖi.
Maybe it was a mistake.
13 Mikplɔ mia nɔvia, eye mitrɔ yi ŋutsua gbɔ.
13 Take your brother and go, return to the man.
14 Mawu Ŋusẽkatãtɔ la nena ŋutsua nave mia nu, ne wòaɖe asi le mia nɔvi kemɛa kple Benyamin ŋu na mi.
14 May God Almighty grant you pity from the man, so that he may release to you your other brother and Benjamin.
Ke nye la, ne ɖeko viwo anɔ bubum nam la, wonenɔ bubum ko!”
But as for me, if I must be bereaved, I will be bereaved!”
15 Ale ŋutsuawo tsɔ nunana siawo kple ga la ƒe teƒe eve ɖe asi, eye wokplɔ Benyamin hã ɖe asi.
15 So the men took this gift, and they took double the money in their hand and Benjamin.
Wotso dze mɔ yi Egipte, eye wova do ɖe Yosef ŋkume.
Then they rose and went on their way down to Egypt and again stood before Joseph.

16 Esi Yosef kpɔ Benyamin le wo dome la, enumake egblɔ na eƒe aƒedzikpɔla la be: “Kplɔ ŋutsuawo yi aƒe me, eye nàwu lã aɖa nu, elabena ame siawo aɖu nu kplim ŋdɔ sia.” 17 Enumake ŋutsu la wɔ abe ale si tututu Yosef gblɔ ene, eye wòkplɔ wo yi Yosef ƒe me.

16 When Joseph saw Benjamin with them, he at once said to the man who was over his house: “Take the men to the house and slaughter animals and prepare the meal, for the men are to eat with me at noon.” 17 Immediately the man did just as Joseph had said, and he took them to Joseph’s house.
18 Ke ŋutsuawo vɔ̃ esi wokplɔ wo yi Yosef ƒe me, eye wonɔ gbɔgblɔm be: “Ga si wotrɔ de míaƒe kotokuawo me esi míeva zi gbãtɔ la tae wokplɔ mí va afi sia ɖo.
18 But the men became afraid when they were taken to Joseph’s house, and they began to say: “It is because of the money that was returned in our bags the last time that we are being brought here.
Azɔ wole mía dzi dze ge ahawɔ mí kluviwoe, eye woaxɔ míaƒe tedziwo!”
Now they will attack us and make us slaves and take our donkeys!”
19 Eya ta wote ɖe Yosef ƒe aƒedzikpɔla la ŋu le aƒea ƒe mɔnu heƒo nu kplii.
19 So they approached the man who was over Joseph’s house and spoke to him at the entrance of the house.
20 Wogblɔ nɛ be: “Nye aƒetɔ, míeɖe kuku!
20 They said: “Pardon us, my lord!
Míeva afi sia zi gbãtɔ va ƒle nuɖuɖu.
We did come down the first time to buy food.
21 Ke esi míeva ɖo dzeƒe, eye míeʋu míaƒe kotokuawo la, kpɔ ɖa, mía dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe ƒe gae nye esi le eƒe kotokua nu, míaƒe ga la katã.
21 But when we arrived at our lodging place and began opening our bags, why, here was the money of each one in the mouth of his bag, our money in full weight.
Eya ta míawo ŋutɔwo míegatrɔe vɛ.
So we would like to return it personally.
22 Míetsɔ ga bubu ɖe asi be míaƒle nuɖuɖu.
22 And we have brought more money to buy food.
Míenya ame si tsɔ míaƒe ga la de míaƒe kotokuawo me o.” 23 Egblɔ na wo be: “Enyo.
We do not know who placed our money in our bags.” 23 Then he said: “It is all right.
Migavɔ̃ o.
Do not be afraid.
Mia Mawu kple mia fofo ƒe Mawue tsɔ kesinɔnuwo de miaƒe kotokuawo me.
Your God and the God of your father put treasure in your bags.
Miaƒe ga la va ɖo gbɔnye.”
Your money came first to me.”
Emegbe ekplɔ Simeon do go va wo gbɔ.
After that he brought out Simeon to them.
24 Eye ŋutsu la kplɔ wo yi Yosef ƒe me, eye wòna tsi wo be woatsɔ aklɔ woƒe afɔwo eye wòna nuɖuɖu woƒe tedziwo.
24 Then the man brought them into Joseph’s house and gave them water for washing their feet, and he gave fodder for their donkeys.
25 Eye wodzra nunana la ɖo nyuie be ne Yosef va le ŋdɔ me la yewoatsɔe anae, elabena wose be yewole nu ɖu ge le afi ma.
25 And they prepared the gift for Joseph’s coming at noon, for they had heard that they were going to eat a meal there.
26 Esi Yosef va aƒea me la, wotsɔ nunana si le wo si la nɛ le aƒea me, eye wobɔbɔ de ta agu nɛ.
26 When Joseph went into the house, they brought their gift to him into the house and prostrated themselves to him to the ground.
27 Le esia megbe la, ebia woƒe agbe ta se, eye wògblɔ be: “Mia fofo tsitsi si ŋu nya miegblɔ nam la li nyuiea?
27 After this he inquired about their welfare and said: “How is your aged father of whom you have spoken?
Egale agbea?” 28 Woɖo eŋu be: “Wò dɔla, mía fofo, li nyuie.
Is he still alive?” 28 To this they said: “Your servant our father is well.
Egale agbe.”
He is still alive.”
Eye wobɔbɔ tsyɔ mo anyi.
Then they bowed down and prostrated themselves.
29 Esi wòfɔ mo dzi kpɔ nɔvia Benyamin, si nye dadaa ƒe vi la, ebia be: “Mia nɔvi ɖevitɔ si ŋu nya miegblɔ nam lae nye esia?”
29 When he looked up and saw Benjamin his brother, the son of his mother, he said: “Is this your brother, the youngest one of whom you have spoken to me?”
Eye wògblɔ kpee be: “Vinye, Mawu neve nuwò.” 30 Yosef megate ŋu lé eɖokui o le nɔvia ta, eye wòwɔ kaba do be yeadi teƒe aɖe afa avi.
He added: “May God show you his favor, my son.” 30 Joseph then hurried out, because he was overcome with emotion for his brother, and he looked for a place to weep.
Ale wòyi ɖe xɔ aɖe me ɖafa avi.
So he went into a private room and gave way to tears there.

31 Emegbe efu mo, eye wòdo go, eye wòlé eɖokui gblɔ be: “Mitsɔ nuɖuɖua vɛ.” 32 Wotsɔ etɔ nɛ ɖe vovo, eye wotsɔ woawo hã tɔ na wo ɖe vovo, eye Egiptetɔ siwo le afi ma kplii la hã ɖu wo tɔ ɖe vovo; Egiptetɔwo meɖua nu kple Hebritɔwo o, elabena Egiptetɔwo bunɛ ŋunyɔnui.

31 After that he washed his face and went out, now in control of himself, and he said: “Serve the meal.” 32 They served him by himself and them by themselves, and the Egyptians with him ate by themselves, for the Egyptians could not eat a meal with the Hebrews, because that is a detestable thing to the Egyptians.
33 Wona nɔviawo nɔ anyi ɖe eŋgɔ, tso ŋgɔgbevi la dzi va se ɖe ɖevitɔ dzi ɖe woƒe tsitsime nu; eye wòwɔ nuku na ŋutsuawo wonɔ wo nɔewo ƒe ŋkume kpɔm.
33 The brothers were seated before him, the firstborn according to his right as firstborn and the youngest according to his youth, and they kept looking at one another in amazement.
34 Eye wònana wokaa nuɖuɖu si le eƒe kplɔ̃ dzi la yina na wo, ke enana Benyamin tɔ sɔa gbɔ wu wo katã tɔ zi gbɔ zi atɔ̃.
34 He kept sending portions of food from his table to theirs, but he increased Benjamin’s portion five times the size of the portions of all the others.
Ale woɖu nu no nu kplii va se ɖe esime woɖi ƒo.
So they continued banqueting and drinking with him to the full.
Le nu siawo megbe la, Egipte-fia ƒe ahakulawo ƒe amegã kple abolomelawo ƒe amegã wɔ nu vɔ̃ ɖe woƒe aƒetɔ Egipte-fia la ŋu.
After these things, the chief cupbearer of the king of Egypt and the chief baker sinned against their lord, the king of Egypt.

2 Eya ta Farao do dziku ɖe eƒe dɔwɔla eve siwo nye ahakulawo ƒe amegã kple abolomelawo ƒe amegã la ŋu, 3 eye wòtsɔ wo de gaxɔ si le fiaŋudzɔlawo ƒe amegã la ƒe aƒe me la me, le afi si Yosef nye gamenɔla le.

2 So Pharaoh grew indignant at his two officers, the chief cupbearer and the chief baker, 3 and he committed them to the jail of the house of the chief of the guard, to the place where Joseph was a prisoner.
4 Eye fiaŋudzɔlawo ƒe amegã la tsɔ wo de Yosef si be wòakpɔ wo dzi, eye wonɔ gaxɔ me hena ɣeyiɣi aɖe.
4 Then the chief of the guard assigned Joseph to be with them and to take care of them, and they remained in jail for some time.
5 Eye Egipte-fia ƒe ahakula kple abolomela, siwo wode gaxɔ me la ku drɔ̃e le zã ɖeka me, eye drɔ̃eawo dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe ƒe gɔmeɖeɖe le vovo.
5 The cupbearer and the baker of the king of Egypt, who were confined in the prison, each had a dream on the same night, and each dream had its own interpretation.
6 Esi Yosef va wo gbɔ le ŋufɔke ƒe ŋdi la, ekpɔe be wolé blanui.
6 The next morning, when Joseph came in and saw them, they looked dejected.

7 Eya ta ebia Farao ƒe dɔwɔlawo ƒe amegã siwo le egbɔ le gaxɔa me le eƒe aƒetɔ ƒe me la be: “Nu ka tae mielé blanui egbea ale?” 8 Eye woɖo eŋu nɛ be: “Mí ame evea siaa míeku drɔ̃e, gake ame aɖeke meli aɖe egɔme na mí o.”

7 So he asked the officers of Pharaoh who were in custody with him in his master’s house: “Why are your faces gloomy today?” 8 At this they said to him: “We each had a dream, but there is no interpreter with us.”
Eye Yosef gblɔ na wo be: “Ðe menye Mawue ɖea nyawo gɔme oa?
Joseph said to them: “Do not interpretations belong to God?
Meɖe kuku, milĩi nam.”
Relate it to me, please.”
9 Eya ta ahakulawo ƒe amegã la lĩ eƒe drɔ̃e la na Yosef be: “Le nye drɔ̃ea me la, wainka aɖe nɔ ŋkunyeme.
9 So the chief cupbearer related his dream to Joseph, saying to him: “In my dream, there was a vine before me.
10 Alɔ etɔ̃ nɔ wainka la ŋu, esi wònɔ alɔ yeyewo tom la, eƒo se, eye eƒe tsetsewo ɖi.
10 And on the vine, there were three twigs, and as it was sprouting shoots, it blossomed, and its clusters ripened into grapes.
11 Farao ƒe kplu le asinye, eye metsɔ waintsetseawo hefiã wo kɔ ɖe Farao ƒe kplua me.
11 And Pharaoh’s cup was in my hand, and I took the grapes and squeezed them out into Pharaoh’s cup.
Emegbe metsɔ kplu la de asi na Farao.” 12 Eye Yosef gblɔ nɛ be: “Drɔ̃e la gɔmee nye esi: Alɔ etɔ̃awo nye ŋkeke etɔ̃.
After that I put the cup in Pharaoh’s hand.” 12 Then Joseph said to him: “This is its interpretation: The three twigs are three days.
13 Le ŋkeke etɔ̃ megbe la, Farao aɖe wò le gaxɔ me, eye wòagatsɔ wò aɖo wò dɔ nu, eye àgatsɔ Farao ƒe kplu ade esi, abe ale si nèwɔnɛ tsã esime nènye eƒe ahakula ene.
13 Three days from now, Pharaoh will bring you out, restoring you to your office, and you will put Pharaoh’s cup into his hand as you did before when you were his cupbearer.
14 Gake ne eme va nyo na wò la, ɖo ŋku dzinye.
14 Nevertheless, you must remember me when things go well with you.
Meɖe kuku, ve nunye, eye nàgblɔ nye nya na Farao ale be woaɖem le gaxɔ sia me.
Please show me loyal love and mention me to Pharaoh, in order to get me out of this place.
15 Elabena le nyateƒe me la, ɖe wofim tso Hebritɔwo ƒe anyigba dzi, eye le afi sia hã nyemewɔ naneke si ta woadem gaxɔ me hafi o.”
15 I was, in fact, kidnapped from the land of the Hebrews, and I have not done anything here for which they should put me in prison.”

16 Esi abolomelawo ƒe amegã la kpɔ be drɔ̃e la ƒe gɔmeɖeɖe nyo la, eya hã gblɔ na Yosef be: “Nye hã meku drɔ̃e, eye kpɔ ɖa, kusi etɔ̃ siwo me abolo ɣiwo le la le tanye, 17 eye le kusi etametɔa me la, abolo vovovo siwo womè la le eme na Farao, eye xewo va le wo ɖum le kusia me le tanye.” 18 Eye Yosef ɖo eŋu nɛ be, “Drɔ̃e la gɔmee nye esi: Kusi etɔ̃awo nye ŋkeke etɔ̃.

16 When the chief baker saw that Joseph had interpreted something good, he said to him: “I too was in my dream, and there were three baskets of white bread on my head, 17 and in the top basket, there were all sorts of baked goods for Pharaoh, and there were birds eating them out of the basket on top of my head.” 18 Then Joseph answered, “This is its interpretation: The three baskets are three days.
19 Le ŋkeke etɔ̃ megbe la, Farao aɖe ta le nuwò, eye wòahe wò ɖe ati ŋu, eye xewo aɖu wò ŋutilã.”
19 Three days from now, Pharaoh will behead you and will hang you on a stake, and the birds will eat your flesh from you.”
20 Ke ŋkeke etɔ̃a gbe dze Farao ƒe dzigbe dzi, eye wòɖo kplɔ̃ na eŋumewo katã, eye wòɖe ahakulawo ƒe amegã kple abolomelawo ƒe amegã le gaxɔ me le eŋumewo ŋkume.
20 Now the third day was Pharaoh’s birthday, and he made a feast for all his servants, and he brought out both the chief cupbearer and the chief baker in the presence of his servants.
21 Eye wògbugbɔ ahakulawo ƒe amegã la ɖo eƒe ahakudɔ la nu, eye wògatsɔa kplu dea Farao si.
21 And he returned the chief cupbearer to his post of cupbearer, and he continued to hand the cup to Pharaoh.
22 Ke ehe abolomelawo ƒe amegã ya ɖe ati ŋu, abe ale si tututu Yosef ɖe drɔ̃ea gɔme na woe ene.
22 But he hanged the chief baker, just as Joseph had interpreted to them.
23 Gake ahakulawo ƒe amegã la meɖo ŋku Yosef dzi o, eŋlɔe be.
23 However, the chief cupbearer did not remember Joseph; he kept forgetting him.
Ke wokplɔ Yosef yi Egipte, eye Egiptetɔ Potifar, si nye Farao ŋu mewo dometɔ ɖeka, kple fiaŋudzɔlawo ƒe amegã la ƒlee le Ismaeltɔ siwo kplɔe va afi ma la si.
Now Joseph was taken down to Egypt, and an Egyptian named Potiphar, a court official of Pharaoh and chief of the guard, bought him from the Ishmaelites who had taken him down there.
2 Ke Yehowa nɔ kple Yosef.
2 But Jehovah was with Joseph.
Eye esia na wòkpɔ dzidzedze, eye wotsɔe ɖo eƒe aƒetɔ si nye Egiptetɔ la ƒe aƒe nu.
As a result, he became successful and was put over the house of his master, the Egyptian.
3 Eye eƒe aƒetɔ kpɔe be Yehowa li kplii, eye be Yehowa nana nu sia nu si wòwɔna la dzea edzi nɛ.
3 And his master saw that Jehovah was with him and that Jehovah was making everything that he did successful.
4 Eye wòkpɔa ŋudzedze ɖe Yosef ŋu eye wòna wòzu eƒe subɔvi.
4 Joseph kept finding favor in his eyes, and he became his personal attendant.
Eye wòɖoe eƒe aƒe la nu hetsɔ eƒe nuwo katã dzi kpɔkpɔ de esi.
So he appointed him over his house, and he put him in charge of all that was his.

5 Tso esime wòtsɔe ɖo eƒe aƒea nu, eye wòtsɔ eƒe nuwo katã dzi kpɔkpɔ de esi la, Yehowa nɔ Egiptetɔ la ƒe aƒe la yram le Yosef ta, eye Yehowa ƒe yayra nɔ eƒe nu siwo katã le aƒea me kple gbedzi la dzi.

5 From the time he appointed him over his house and in charge of all that was his, Jehovah kept blessing the house of the Egyptian because of Joseph, and Jehovah’s blessing came to be on all that he had in the house and in the field.
6 Mlɔeba etsɔ eƒe nuwo katã de Yosef si; eye megatsia dzi ɖe nu siwo le esi la ŋu kura o, negbe eƒe nuɖuɖu ko.
6 He eventually left everything that was his in Joseph’s care, and he gave no thought to anything except the food he was eating.
Gawu la, Yosef va nya kpɔ hedze ɖeka ale gbegbe.
Moreover, Joseph grew to be well-built and handsome.

7 Ke le nu siawo megbe la, Yosef ƒe aƒetɔ srɔ̃ va nɔa ahiãmo ɖom nɛ hegblɔna nɛ be: “Va mlɔ gbɔnye.” 8 Ke egbe, eye wògblɔ na eƒe aƒetɔ srɔ̃ la be: “Kpɔ ɖa, nye aƒetɔ megatsia dzi ɖe nu siwo le gbɔnye le aƒea me ŋu o, eye wòtsɔ eƒe nuwo katã de asi nam.

7 Now after these things, the wife of his master began to cast her eyes on Joseph and say: “Lie down with me.” 8 But he refused and said to his master’s wife: “Here my master does not know what is with me in the house, and he has entrusted everything he has into my care.
9 Ame aɖeke menye gã wum le aƒe sia me o, eye mete nanekem o, negbe wò ko, elabena srɔ̃ae nènye.
9 There is no one greater in this house than I am, and he has not withheld from me anything at all except you, because you are his wife.
Aleke gɔ̃ mawɔ vɔ̃ gã sia gbegbe ahawɔ nu vɔ̃ ɖe Mawu ŋu?”
So how could I commit this great badness and actually sin against God?”
10 Eye wònɔa nya sia gblɔm na Yosef ŋkeke sia ŋkeke, ke melɔ̃ be yeamlɔ egbɔ alo anɔ egbɔ o.
10 So day after day she spoke to Joseph, but he never consented to lie with her or to remain with her.
11 Gake gbe ɖeka, esi wòyi aƒea me be yeawɔ yeƒe dɔwo la, aƒea me subɔvi aɖeke menɔ aƒea me o.
11 But on one of the days when he went into the house to do his work, none of the household servants were in the house.
12 Eye nyɔnua lé eƒe awu gblɔ be: “Va mlɔ gbɔnye!”
12 Then she grabbed hold of him by his garment and said: “Lie down with me!”
Ke egblẽ eƒe awu la ɖe esi me hesi do go.
But he left his garment in her hand and fled outside.
13 Ke esi wòkpɔ be egblẽ eƒe awua ɖe ye si me hesi do go la, 14 edo ɣli yɔ eƒemetɔwo gblɔ na wo be: “Kpɔ ɖa!
13 As soon as she saw that he had left his garment in her hand and had fled outside, 14 she began to cry out to the men of her house and to say to them: “Look!
Ekplɔ Hebri ŋutsu sia va mía gbɔ be wòava ɖi gbɔ mí.
He brought to us this Hebrew man to make us a laughingstock.
Eva gbɔnye be yeamlɔ gbɔnye, ke mede asi ɣlidodo me sesĩe.
He came to me to lie down with me, but I began to cry out at the top of my voice.
15 Esi wònya kpɔ be mete ɣlidodo sesĩe ko la, egblẽ eƒe awu la ɖe gbɔnye hesi do go.” 16 Emegbe etsɔ awu la da ɖe eɖokui gbɔ va se ɖe esime Yosef ƒe aƒetɔ gbɔ va aƒea me.
15 Then as soon as he heard me raising my voice and screaming, he left his garment beside me and fled outside.” 16 After that she laid his garment beside her until his master came to his house.
17 Eye wògblɔ nya mawo ke nɛ be: “Hebri subɔvi si nèkplɔ vɛ na mí la, va be yeaɖi gbɔm.
17 Then she told him the same thing, saying: “The Hebrew servant whom you brought to us came to me to make me a laughingstock.
18 Gake esi menya do ɣli sesĩe ko la, egblẽ eƒe awu la ɖe gbɔnye hesi do go.” 19 Esi eƒe aƒetɔa se srɔ̃a ƒe nya siwo wògblɔ nɛ be, “Ale kple ale wò subɔvia wɔ ɖe ŋunye” ko la, dzi kui vevie.

18 But as soon as I raised my voice and began to scream, he left his garment beside me and fled outside.” 19 As soon as his master heard the words his wife spoke to him, saying: “These are the things your servant did to me,” his anger blazed.
20 Eye Yosef ƒe aƒetɔ lée de gaxɔ me, le afi si fia ƒe gamenɔlawo nɔna, eye wònɔ afi ma le gaxɔa me.
20 So Joseph’s master took him and gave him over to the prison, the place where the prisoners of the king were kept under arrest, and he remained there in the prison.
21 Ke Yehowa nɔ kple Yosef, eye wònyoa dɔme nɛ hevea enu, eye wòna gaxɔdzikpɔlawo ƒe amegã la hã ve enu.
21 But Jehovah continued with Joseph and kept showing loyal love to him and granting him favor in the eyes of the chief officer of the prison.
22 Ale gaxɔdzikpɔlawo ƒe amegã la tsɔ gamenɔla siwo katã le gaxɔa me la de asi na Yosef, eye nu sia nu si wowɔna le afi ma la, eyae nana wowɔa wo.
22 So the chief officer of the prison put Joseph in charge of all the prisoners in the prison, and everything that they were doing there, he was the one having it done.
23 Gaxɔdzikpɔlawo ƒe amegã la megatsia dzi ɖe nu siwo le Yosef ƒe dzikpɔkpɔ te la dometɔ aɖeke ŋu o, elabena Yehowa nɔ kple Yosef, eye nu sia nu si wòwɔna la, Yehowa nana wòdzea edzi.
23 The chief officer of the prison was looking after absolutely nothing that was in Joseph’s care, for Jehovah was with Joseph and Jehovah made whatever he did successful.
Esi Abram xɔ ƒe blaasieke vɔ asieke la, Yehowa ɖe eɖokui fiae eye wògblɔ nɛ be: “Nyee nye Mawu Ŋusẽkatãtɔ la.
When Abram was 99 years old, Jehovah appeared to Abram and said to him: “I am God Almighty.
Zɔ le ŋkunyeme, eye kpɔtsɔtsɔ aɖeke meganɔ ŋuwò o.
Walk before me and prove yourself faultless.
2 Mabla nu kpli wò, eye mana nàsɔ gbɔ agasɔ gbɔ ɖe edzi.”
2 I will establish my covenant between me and you, and I will multiply you very, very much.”
3 Ale Abram tsyɔ mo anyi, eye Mawu gaƒo nu kplii be: 4 “Ke nye la, kpɔ ɖa, mebla nu kpli wò be àva zu dukɔ geɖewo fofo.
3 At this Abram fell facedown, and God continued to speak with him, saying: 4 “As for me, look! my covenant is with you, and you will certainly become a father of many nations.
5 Womagayɔ wò be Abram azɔ o, ke boŋ Abraham anye wò ŋkɔ, elabena mawɔ wò nàzu dukɔ geɖewo fofo.
5 Your name will no longer be Abram; your name will become Abraham, for I will make you a father of many nations.
6 Mana nàdzi asɔ gbɔ agasɔ gbɔ ɖe edzi ava zu dukɔ geɖe, eye fiawo adzɔ tso mewò.
6 I will make you very, very fruitful and will make you become nations, and kings will come from you.
7 “Mawɔ nubabla si le nye kpli wò kpakple megbewòviwo dome la dzi le woƒe dzidzimeawo katã me, nubabla mavɔe wòanye, be manye Mawu na wò kple megbewòviwo.
7 “And I will keep my covenant between me and you and your offspring after you throughout their generations for an everlasting covenant, to be God to you and to your offspring after you.
8 Matsɔ anyigba si dzi nènye amedzro le, ɛ̃, Kanaan-nyigba blibo la katã ana wò kple megbewòviwo, ne wòanye mia tɔ ɖaa, eye manye woƒe Mawu.”
8 And I will give to you and to your offspring after you the land in which you lived as a foreigner —the entire land of Canaan—for a lasting possession, and I will be their God.”
9 Mawu gagblɔ na Abraham be: “Ke wò la, lé nye nubabla la me ɖe asi, wò ŋutɔ kple megbewòviwo siaa le woƒe dzidzimeawo katã me.
9 God said further to Abraham: “As for you, you are to keep my covenant, you and your offspring after you throughout their generations.
10 Esia anye nubabla si le nye kpli mi dome, si me wò kple megbewòviwo mialé ɖe asi: Miaƒe ŋutsuwo katã natso aʋa.
10 This is my covenant between me and you, that you and your offspring after you will keep: Every male among you must get circumcised.
11 Woaɖe miaƒe aʋanuyiwo ɖa, ne wòanye nubabla si le nye kpli mi dome la ƒe dzesi.
11 You must circumcise the flesh of your foreskins, and it will serve as a sign of the covenant between me and you.
12 Le miaƒe dzidzimewo katã me la, woatso aʋa na mia viŋutsu ɖe sia ɖe si xɔ ŋkeke enyi; eɖanye ame si wodzi le aƒea me alo ame si menye wò dzidzimevi o, si woƒle kple ga le amedzro aɖe si.

12 Throughout your generations, every male among you eight days old must be circumcised, anyone who is born in the house and anyone who is not one of your offspring and who was purchased with money from a foreigner.
13 Ŋutsu siwo katã wodzi le aƒewò me kple ŋutsu siwo katã woƒle kple wò ga la, natso aʋa; eye nubabla si ƒe dzesi le miaƒe ŋutilã ŋu la nanye nubabla mavɔ.
13 Every man born in your house and every man purchased with your money must be circumcised, and my covenant in your flesh must serve as a lasting covenant.
14 Ne ŋutsu aɖe mena wotso aʋa nɛ o, mena woɖe eƒe aʋanuyi ɖa o la, woatsrɔ̃ ame ma ɖa le eƒe dukɔ la dome.
14 If any uncircumcised male will not circumcise the flesh of his foreskin, that person must be cut off from his people.
Etu nye nubabla la.”
He has broken my covenant.”
15 Mawu gagblɔ na Abraham be: “Mègayɔ srɔ̃wò Sarai be Sarai azɔ o, elabena Sara anye eŋkɔ.
15 Then God said to Abraham: “As for your wife Sarai, you must not call her Sarai, because Sarah will become her name.

16 Mayrae, eye mana wòadzi ŋutsuvi na wò; ɛ̃, mayrae, eye wòazu dukɔ geɖewo dada; dukɔwo ƒe fiawo adzɔ tso eme.” 17 Ale Abraham tsyɔ mo anyi, eye wòde asi nukoko me hegblɔ le eƒe dzi me be: “Ðe woadzi vi na ŋutsu si xɔ ƒe alafa ɖeka laa, eye ɖe Sara, nyɔnu si xɔ ƒe blaasieke la adzi vi nyateƒea?”

16 I will bless her and also give you a son by her; I will bless her and she will become nations; kings of peoples will come from her.” 17 At this Abraham fell facedown and began to laugh and to say in his heart: “Will a man 100 years old have a child born to him, and will Sarah, a woman 90 years old, give birth?”
18 Ale Abraham gblɔ na Mawu vavã la be: “Oo, yra Ismael wòatsi agbe nam ko!” 19 Eye Mawu ɖo eŋu be: “Nyateƒee, srɔ̃wò Sara le ŋutsuvi dzi ge na wò godoo, eye nàna ŋkɔe be Isak.
18 So Abraham said to the true God: “O that Ishmael might live before you!” 19 To this God said: “Your wife Sarah will definitely bear you a son, and you must name him Isaac.
Maɖo nye nubabla anyi kplii, si anye nubabla mavɔ na emegbeviwo.
And I will establish my covenant with him for an everlasting covenant to his offspring after him.
20 Ke mese nya si nègblɔ le Ismael ŋu la hã.
20 But as regards Ishmael, I have heard you. Look!
Kpɔ ɖa, mayrae, mana wòadzi, eye mana wòasɔ gbɔ agasɔ gbɔ ɖe edzi.
I will bless him and will make him fruitful and will multiply him very, very much.
Adzi amegã wuieve, eye mana wòazu dukɔ gã aɖe.
He will produce 12 chieftains, and I will make him become a great nation.
21 Gake mabla nu kple Isak, si Sara adzi na wò le ƒe si gbɔna ƒe ɣealewoɣi.”
21 However, I will establish my covenant with Isaac, whom Sarah will bear to you at this appointed time next year.”
22 Esi Mawu gblɔ nya siawo na Abraham vɔ la, edzo le egbɔ yi dzi.
22 When God finished speaking with him, he went up from Abraham.

23 Gbe ma gbe ke Abraham tso aʋa na via Ismael kple ame siwo katã wodzi le eƒe aƒe me, kpakple ame siwo katã woƒle kple eƒe ga; wotso aʋa na ŋutsu siwo katã le eƒe aƒe me la abe ale si tututu Mawu gblɔ nɛ ene.

23 Abraham then took Ishmael his son and all the men born in his house and everyone he had purchased with money, every male in the household of Abraham, and he circumcised the flesh of their foreskins on that very day, just as God had spoken with him.
24 Abraham xɔ ƒe blaasieke vɔ asieke esime wòna wotso aʋa nɛ.
24 Abraham was 99 years old when he had the flesh of his foreskin circumcised.
25 Eye via Ismael xɔ ƒe wuietɔ̃ esime wotso aʋa nɛ.
25 And Ishmael his son was 13 years old when he had the flesh of his foreskin circumcised.
26 Gbe ma gbe ke Abraham na wotso aʋa na eya kple via Ismael.
26 On that very day, Abraham was circumcised and also his son Ishmael.
27 Ŋutsu siwo katã le eƒe aƒe me, ame siwo katã wodzi le aƒea me kple ame siwo katã wòƒle kple ga le amedzrowo si la hã tso aʋa.
27 All the men of his household, anyone born in the house and anyone purchased with money from a foreigner, were also circumcised with him.
Ke anyigba blibo la katã doa gbe ɖeka, eye nya ɖeka tɔgbi le nu na wo.
Now all the earth continued to be of one language and of one set of words.
2 Esi wozɔ mɔ ɖo ta ɣedzeƒe gome la, wova ke ɖe gbadzaƒe aɖe ŋu le bali aɖe me le Sinar-nyigba dzi, eye wonɔ afi ma.
2 As they traveled eastward, they discovered a valley plain in the land of Shinar, and they began dwelling there.
3 Azɔ wogblɔ na wo nɔewo be: “Miva, ne míatso anyikpe, eye míamèe.”
3 Then they said to one another: “Come! Let us make bricks and bake them with fire.”
Ale wozã anyikpe ɖe kpe teƒe, kple aŋɔ yibɔ ɖe ba teƒe.
So they used bricks instead of stone, and bitumen as mortar.
4 Eye wogblɔ be: “Miva, ne míatso du, eye míatu mɔ́ aɖe si tame atɔ dziƒo, ale be míawɔ ŋkɔ gã aɖe na mía ɖokui, be míagakaka ɖe anyigba blibo la dzi o.”

4 They now said: “Come! Let us build a city for ourselves and a tower with its top in the heavens, and let us make a celebrated name for ourselves, so that we will not be scattered over the entire face of the earth.”
5 Eya ta Yehowa ɖi va be yeakpɔ du la kple mɔ́ si tum amegbetɔviwo le la ɖa.
5 Then Jehovah went down to see the city and the tower that the sons of men had built.
6 Eye Yehowa gblɔ be: “Kpɔ ɖa!
6 Jehovah then said: “Look!
Dukɔ ɖeka wonye, eye wo katã wodoa gbe ɖeka, eye nu si wode asi wɔwɔ mee nye esia.
They are one people with one language, and this is what they have started to do.
Azɔ naneke meli si woaɖo tame be yewoawɔ, si woado kpoe o.
Now there is nothing that they may have in mind to do that will be impossible for them.
7 Va!
7 Come!
Na míaɖi ayi afi ma aɖatɔtɔ gbe na wo, ale be woagase wo nɔewo ƒe gbegbɔgblɔ gɔme o.” 8 Ale Yehowa ka wo hlẽ tso afi ma ɖe anyigba blibo la katã dzi; eye wodzudzɔ du la tsotso.

Let us go down there and confuse their language in order that they may not understand one another’s language.” 8 So Jehovah scattered them from there over the entire face of the earth, and they gradually left off building the city.
