9 Esia tae wona ŋkɔe be Babel, elabena afi mae Yehowa tɔtɔ anyigba blibo la katã ƒe gbe le, eye Yehowa ka wo hlẽ tso afi ma ɖe anyigba blibo la katã dzi.
9 That is why it was named BAbel, because there Jehovah confused the language of all the earth, and Jehovah scattered them from there over the entire face of the earth.
10 Sem ƒe ŋutinyae nye esi.
10 This is the history of Shem.
Ƒe eve le Tsiɖɔɖɔ la megbe, esime Sem xɔ ƒe alafa ɖeka la, edzi Arpaksad.
Shem was 100 years old when he became father to Arpachshad two years after the Flood.
11 Esi Sem dzi Arpaksad megbe la, eganɔ agbe ƒe alafa atɔ̃.
11 After becoming father to Arpachshad, Shem continued to live 500 years.
Eye wòdzi ŋutsuwo kple nyɔnuwo.
And he became father to sons and daughters.
12 Esi Arpaksad xɔ ƒe blaetɔ̃ vɔ atɔ̃ la, edzi Sela.
12 Arpachshad lived for 35 years and then became father to Shelah.
13 Esi Arpaksad dzi Sela megbe la, eganɔ agbe ƒe alafa ene kple etɔ̃.
13 After becoming father to Shelah, Arpachshad continued to live 403 years.
Eye wòdzi ŋutsuwo kple nyɔnuwo.
And he became father to sons and daughters.
14 Esi Sela xɔ ƒe blaetɔ̃ la, edzi Eber.
14 Shelah lived for 30 years and then became father to eber.
15 Esi Sela dzi Eber megbe la, eganɔ agbe ƒe alafa ene kple etɔ̃.
15 After becoming father to eber, Shelah continued to live 403 years.
Eye wòdzi ŋutsuwo kple nyɔnuwo.
And he became father to sons and daughters.
16 Esi Eber xɔ ƒe blaetɔ̃ vɔ ene la, edzi Peleg.
16 eber lived for 34 years and then became father to Peleg.
17 Esi Eber dzi Peleg megbe la, eganɔ agbe ƒe alafa ene blaetɔ̃.
17 After becoming father to Peleg, eber continued to live 430 years.
Eye wòdzi ŋutsuwo kple nyɔnuwo.
And he became father to sons and daughters.
18 Esi Peleg xɔ ƒe blaetɔ̃ la, edzi Reu.
18 Peleg lived for 30 years and then became father to Reu.
19 Esi Peleg dzi Reu megbe la, eganɔ agbe ƒe alafa eve kple asieke.
19 After becoming father to Reu, Peleg continued to live 209 years.
Eye wòdzi ŋutsuwo kple nyɔnuwo.
And he became father to sons and daughters.
20 Esi Reu xɔ ƒe blaetɔ̃ vɔ eve la, edzi Serug.
20 Reu lived for 32 years and then became father to Serug.
21 Esi Reu dzi Serug megbe la, eganɔ agbe ƒe alafa eve kple adre.
21 After becoming father to Serug, Reu continued to live 207 years.
Eye wòdzi ŋutsuwo kple nyɔnuwo.
And he became father to sons and daughters.
22 Esi Serug xɔ ƒe blaetɔ̃ la, edzi Nahor.
22 Serug lived for 30 years and then became father to Nahor.
23 Esi Serug dzi Nahor megbe la, eganɔ agbe ƒe alafa eve.
23 After becoming father to Nahor, Serug continued to live 200 years.
Eye wòdzi ŋutsuwo kple nyɔnuwo.
And he became father to sons and daughters.
24 Esi Nahor xɔ ƒe blaeve vɔ asieke la, edzi Tera.
24 Nahor lived for 29 years and then became father to Terah.
25 Esi Nahor dzi Tera megbe la, eganɔ agbe ƒe alafa ɖeka wuiasieke.
25 After becoming father to Terah, Nahor continued to live 119 years.
Eye wòdzi ŋutsuwo kple nyɔnuwo.
And he became father to sons and daughters.
26 Esi Tera xɔ ƒe blaadre la, edzi Abram, Nahor kple Haran.
26 Terah lived for 70 years, after which he became father to Abram, Nahor, and Haran.
27 Tera ƒe ŋutinyae nye esi.
27 This is the history of Terah.
Tera dzi Abram, Nahor kple Haran; Haran dzi Lot.
Terah became father to Abram, Nahor, and Haran; and Haran became father to Lot.
28 Emegbe Haran ku le wo de Ur, le Kaldea-nyigba dzi esime fofoa Tera gale agbe.
28 While his father Terah was still alive, Haran died in the land of his birth, in Ur of the Chaldeans.
29 Abram kple Nahor ɖe srɔ̃.
29 Abram and Nahor took wives for themselves.
Abram srɔ̃ ŋkɔe nye Sarai, eye Nahor srɔ̃ ŋkɔe nye Milka, ame si nye Haran vinyɔnu. Haran nye Milka kple Yiska fofo.
The name of Abram’s wife was Sarai, and the name of Nahor’s wife was Milcah, the daughter of Haran, the father of Milcah and Iscah.
30 Ke Sarai tsi ko; medzi vi o.
30 Now Sarai was barren; she had no child.
31 Emegbe Tera kplɔ via Abram kple tɔgbuiyɔvia Lot, ame si nye Haran vi, kple lɔ̃xoyɔvia Sarai, ame si nye via Abram srɔ̃, eye woʋu kplii tso Ur le Kaldea-nyigba dzi be yewoayi Kanaan-nyigba dzi.

31 Terah then took Abram his son and Lot his grandson, the son of Haran, and Sarai his daughter-in-law, the wife of Abram his son, and they went with him out of Ur of the Chaldeans to go to the land of Canaan.
Emegbe wova Haran, eye wonɔ afi ma.
In time they came to Haran and began dwelling there.
32 Tera nɔ agbe ƒe alafa eve kple atɔ̃.
32 The days of Terah were 205 years.
Eye Tera ku le Haran.
Then Terah died in Haran.
Esiae nye Esau, si wogayɔna be Edom, ƒe ŋutinya.
This is the history of Esau, that is, Edom.
2 Esau ɖe Kanaan-nyɔnuviwo, woawoe nye: Hititɔ Elon vinyɔnu Ada, kple Hivitɔ Zibeon ƒe tɔgbuiyɔvi Ana ƒe vi Oholibama, 3 kple Ismael vi Basemat, si nye Nebayot nɔvinyɔnu.

2 Esau took his wives from the daughters of Canaan: Adah the daughter of Elon the Hittite; and Oholibamah the daughter of Anah, the granddaughter of Zibeon the Hivite; 3 and Basemath, Ishmael’s daughter, the sister of NebAioth.
4 Ada dzi Elifaz na Esau, Basemat dzi Reuel, 5 eye Oholibama dzi Yeus, Yalam kple Kora.
4 And Adah bore Eliphaz to Esau, and Basemath bore Reuel, 5 and Oholibamah bore Jeush, Jalam, and Korah.
Esiawoe nye Esau vi siwo wodzi nɛ le Kanaan-nyigba dzi.
These are the sons of Esau, who were born to him in the land of Canaan.

6 Emegbe Esau kplɔ srɔ̃awo, viaŋutsuwo kple vianyɔnuwo, ame siwo katã le eƒe me, eƒe alẽha kple eƒe lãha bubuawo katã kpe ɖe kesinɔnu siwo katã su esi le Kanaan-nyigba dzi la ŋu, eye wòdzo yi anyigba bubu aɖe si didi tso nɔvia Yakob gbɔ la dzi.

6 After that Esau took his wives, his sons, his daughters, all the members of his household, his herd and all his other beasts, and all the wealth he had accumulated in the land of Canaan and he went to another land some distance away from Jacob his brother.
7 Elabena woƒe nuwo va sɔ gbɔ ale gbegbe be, womagate ŋu anɔ teƒe ɖeka o, eye anyigba si dzi wonɔ la megava le wo nu dem o le woƒe lãhawo ta.
7 For their goods had become too many for them to dwell together, and the land where they were residing was not able to sustain them because of their herds.
8 Eya ta Esau va nɔ Seir tonuto la me.
8 So Esau took up dwelling in the mountainous region of Seir.
Esau ye wogayɔna be Edom.
Esau is Edom.
9 Esiae nye Edomtɔwo fofo Esau si nɔ Seir tonuto me la ƒe ŋutinya.
9 And this is the history of Esau the father of Edom in the mountainous region of Seir.
10 Esiawoe nye Esau viŋutsuwo ŋkɔwo: Esau srɔ̃ Ada viŋutsue nye Elifaz, eye Esau srɔ̃ Basemat viŋutsue nye Reuel.
10 These are the names of the sons of Esau: Eliphaz the son of Adah, Esau’s wife; Reuel the son of Basemath, Esau’s wife.
11 Elifaz viŋutsuwoe nye Teman, Omar, Zefo, Gatam kple Kenaz.
11 The sons of Eliphaz were Teman, Omar, Zepho, GAtam, and Kenaz.
12 Eye Timna va zu Esau vi Elifaz ƒe ahiã.
12 Timna became the concubine of Eliphaz, Esau’s son.
Emegbe edzi Amalek na Elifaz.
In time she bore to Eliphaz, AmAlek.
Woawoe nye Esau srɔ̃ Ada ƒe viwo.
These are the sons of Adah, Esau’s wife.
13 Reuel viŋutsuwoe nye: Nahat kple Zera, Sama kple Miza.
13 These are the sons of Reuel: NAhath, Zerah, Shammah, and Mizzah.
Ame siawoe nye Esau srɔ̃ Basemat ƒe viwo.
These were the sons of Basemath, Esau’s wife.
14 Ame siawoe nye Esau srɔ̃ Oholibama, si nye Ana vinyɔnu, eye wònye Zibeon ƒe tɔgbuiyɔvi la, ƒe viwo; eyae dzi Yeus, Yalam kple Kora na Esau.
14 These were the sons of Oholibamah the daughter of Anah, the granddaughter of Zibeon, Esau’s wife, whom she bore to Esau: Jeush, Jalam, and Korah.
15 Ame siawoe nye Esau viwo ƒe amegãwo: Esau ƒe ŋgɔgbevi Elifaz viwoe nye: Amegã Teman, Amegã Omar, Amegã Zefo, Amegã Kenaz, 16 Amegã Kora, Amegã Gatam, Amegã Amalek.
15 These are the sheikhs of the sons of Esau: The sons of Eliphaz, Esau’s firstborn: Sheikh Teman, Sheikh Omar, Sheikh Zepho, Sheikh Kenaz, 16 Sheikh Korah, Sheikh GAtam, and Sheikh AmAlek.
Ame siawoe nye amegã siwo dzɔ tso Elifaz me le Edom-nyigba dzi.
These are the sheikhs of Eliphaz in the land of Edom.
Woawoe nye Ada viwo.
These are the sons by Adah.
17 Esau vi Reuel viŋutsuwoe nye: Amegã Nahat, Amegã Zera, Amegã Sama, Amegã Miza.
17 These are the sons of Reuel, Esau’s son: Sheikh NAhath, Sheikh Zerah, Sheikh Shammah, and Sheikh Mizzah.
Ame siawoe nye amegã siwo dzɔ tso Reuel me le Edom-nyigba dzi.
These are the sheikhs of Reuel in the land of Edom.
Woawoe nye Esau srɔ̃ Basemat ƒe viwo.
These are the sons by Basemath, Esau’s wife.
18 Eye Esau srɔ̃ Oholibama viŋutsuwoe nye: Amegã Yeus, Amegã Yalam, Amegã Kora.
18 Finally these are the sons of Oholibamah, Esau’s wife: Sheikh Jeush, Sheikh Jalam, and Sheikh Korah.
Ame siawoe nye amegã siwo dzɔ tso Esau srɔ̃ Oholibama, si nye Ana vinyɔnu la me.
These are the sheikhs of Oholibamah the daughter of Anah, Esau’s wife.
19 Ame siawoe nye Esau, si wogayɔna be Edom, ƒe viwo, eye woawoe nye woƒe amegãwo.
19 These are the sons of Esau, and these are their sheikhs. He is Edom.
20 Horitɔ Seir viŋutsu siwo nɔ anyigba la dzie nye : Lotan, Sobal, Zibeon, Ana, 21 Dison, Ezer kple Disan.
20 These are the sons of Seir the Horite, the inhabitants of the land: LOtan, ShObal, Zibeon, Anah, 21 Dishon, ezer, and Dishan.
Ame siawoe nye amegã siwo dzɔ tso Horitɔwo me, eye wonye Seir viwo, le Edom-nyigba la dzi.
These are the sheikhs of the Horites, the sons of Seir, in the land of Edom.
22 Lotan viŋutsuwoe nye Hori kple Hemam, eye Lotan nɔvinyɔnue nye Timna.
22 The sons of LOtan were HOri and Hemam, and LOtan’s sister was Timna.
23 Sobal viŋutsuwoe nye: Alvan, Manahat, Ebal, Sefo kple Onam.
23 These are the sons of ShObal: Alvan, ManAhath, ebal, Shepho, and Onam.
24 Zibeon viŋutsuwoe nye: Aya kple Ana.
24 These are the sons of Zibeon: Aiah and Anah.
Ame siae nye Ana si ke ɖe tsi xɔdzo dziƒe siwo le gbedzi la ŋu esime wòle fofoa Zibeon ƒe tedziwo kplɔm.
This is the Anah who found the hot springs in the wilderness while he was tending the donkeys for Zibeon his father.
25 Ana viwoe nye: Dison kple Ana vinyɔnu Oholibama.
25 These are the children of Anah: Dishon and Oholibamah the daughter of Anah.
26 Dison viŋutsuwoe nye: Hemdan, Esban, Yitran kple Keran.
26 These are the sons of Dishon: Hemdan, Eshban, Ithran, and Cheran.
27 Ezer viŋutsuwoe nye: Bilhan, Zaavan kple Akan.
27 These are the sons of ezer: Bilhan, ZAAvan, and Akan.
28 Disan viŋutsuwoe nye: Uz kple Aran.
28 These are the sons of Dishan: Uz and Aran.
29 Ame siawoe nye Horitɔwo ƒe amegãwo: Amegã Lotan, Amegã Sobal, Amegã Zibeon, Amegã Ana, 30 Amegã Dison, Amegã Ezer, Amegã Disan.
29 These are the sheikhs of the Horites: Sheikh LOtan, Sheikh ShObal, Sheikh Zibeon, Sheikh Anah, 30 Sheikh Dishon, Sheikh ezer, and Sheikh Dishan.
Ame siawoe nye Horitɔwo ƒe amegãwo le Seir-nyigba dzi.
These are the sheikhs of the Horites according to their sheikhs in the land of Seir.
31 Ke fia siawoe ɖu dzi le Edom-nyigba dzi hafi fia va ɖu Israel-viwo dzi.
31 Now these are the kings who reigned in the land of Edom before any king reigned over the Israelites.
32 Bela, Beor vi ɖu Edom dzi, eye eƒe du la ŋkɔe nye Dinhaba.
32 Bela son of Beor reigned in Edom, and the name of his city was DinhAbah.
33 Esi Bela ku la, Zera, si tso Bozra, ƒe vi Yobab zu fia ɖe eteƒe.
33 When Bela died, JObab son of Zerah from Bozrah began to reign in his place.
34 Esi Yobab ku la, Husam si tso Temantɔwo ƒe anyigba dzi la zu fia ɖe eteƒe.
34 When JObab died, Husham from the land of the Temanites began to reign in his place.
35 Esi Husam ku la, Hadad, Bedad vi, ame si ɖu Midiantɔwo dzi le Moab-nyigba dzi la zu fia ɖe eteƒe, eye eƒe du la ŋkɔe nye Avit.
35 When Husham died, HAdad son of Bedad, who defeated the Midianites in the territory of Moab, began to reign in his place, and the name of his city was Avith.
36 Esi Hadad ku la, Samla si tso Masreka zu fia ɖe eteƒe.
36 When HAdad died, Samlah from Masrekah began to reign in his place.
37 Esi Samla ku la, Saul si tso Rehobot le Tɔsisi la to zu fia ɖe eteƒe.
37 When Samlah died, Shaul from RehOboth by the River began to reign in his place.
38 Esi Saul ku la, Baal-Hanan, Akbor vi zu fia ɖe eteƒe.
38 When Shaul died, BAal-hAnan the son of Achbor began to reign in his place.
39 Esi Baal-Hanan, Akbor vi ku la, Hadar zu fia ɖe eteƒe, eƒe du la ŋkɔe nye Pau, eye srɔ̃a ŋkɔe nye Mehetabel, ame si nye Mezahab vinyɔnu Matred vi.
39 When BAal-hAnan the son of Achbor died, HAdar began to reign in his place. The name of his city was PAu, and the name of his wife was MehetAbel the daughter of MAtred the daughter of MezAhab.

40 Ame siawoe nye amegã siwo dzɔ tso Esau me la ƒe ŋkɔwo le woƒe ƒomewo, woƒe nutowo, kple woƒe ŋkɔwo nu: Amegã Timna, Amegã Alva, Amegã Yetet, 41 Amegã Oholibama, Amegã Ela, Amegã Pinon, 42 Amegã Kenaz, Amegã Teman, Amegã Mibzar, 43 Amegã Magdiel, kple Amegã Iram.

40 So these are the names of the sheikhs of Esau according to their families, according to their places, by their names: Sheikh Timna, Sheikh Alvah, Sheikh Jetheth, 41 Sheikh Oholibamah, Sheikh elah, Sheikh Pinon, 42 Sheikh Kenaz, Sheikh Teman, Sheikh Mibzar, 43 Sheikh Magdiel, and Sheikh iram.
Ame siawoe nye amegã siwo dzɔ tso Edom me le wo nɔƒewo le anyigba si woxɔ wòzu wo tɔ la dzi.
These are the sheikhs of Edom according to their settlements in the land of their possession.
Ame siae nye Edomtɔwo fofo Esau.
This is Esau the father of Edom.
Emegbe Abraham gaɖe srɔ̃, si ŋkɔe nye Ketura.
Abraham was now old, advanced in years, and Jehovah had blessed Abraham in everything.
2 Le ɣeyiɣi aɖe megbe la, Ketura dzi Zimran, Yoksan, Medan, Midian, Yisbak kple Sua nɛ. 3 Yoksan dzi Seba kple Dedan. Asurim viwo, Letusim viwo kple Leumim viwo dzɔ tso Dedan me.

2 Abraham said to his servant, the oldest one of his household, who was managing all he had: “Please put your hand under my thigh, 3 and I will make you swear by Jehovah, the God of the heavens and the God of the earth, that you will not take a wife for my son from the daughters of the Canaanites, among whom I am dwelling.
4 Midian viwoe nye Efa, Efer, Hanok, Abida kple Eldaa. Ame siawo katã dzɔ tso Ketura me.
4 You must go instead to my country and to my relatives and take a wife for my son, for Isaac.”
5 Emegbe Abraham tsɔ eƒe nuwo katã na Isak, 6 ke Abraham na nu eƒe ahiãwo ƒe viwo hã.
5 However, the servant said to him: “What if the woman is not willing to come with me to this land?
Eye le eƒe agbenɔɣi la, eɖe wo ɖa le via Isak ŋu heɖo wo ɖe ɣedzeƒe gome le Ɣedzeƒenyigba dzi.
Must I then return your son to the land from which you came?” 6 At this Abraham said to him: “See that you do not take my son there.
7 Abraham ƒe agbenɔƒewo va le ƒe alafa ɖeka blaadre vɔ atɔ̃.

7 Jehovah the God of the heavens, who took me from my father’s house and from the land of my relatives and who spoke with me and swore to me: ‘To your offspring I am going to give this land,’ he will send his angel ahead of you, and you will certainly take a wife for my son from there.
8 Eye Abraham ƒe gbɔgbɔ nu tso; enɔ agbe tsi nyuie, etsi ku amegã eye agbenɔnɔ ɖi kɔ nɛ hafi wòku, eye wotsɔe kpe ɖe eƒe amewo ŋu.
8 But if the woman is unwilling to come with you, you will be free from this oath.
9 Eye via Isak kple Ismael ɖii ɖe Makepela-gado la me le Hititɔ Zohar vi Efron ƒe anyigba si dze ŋgɔ Mamre la dzi; 10 eyae nye anyigba si Abraham ƒle le Het viwo si.
But you must not take my son there.” 9 With that the servant put his hand under the thigh of Abraham his master and swore to him concerning this matter.
Afi mae woɖi Abraham kple srɔ̃a Sara ɖo.
Then he went on his way to MesOpOtAmia, to the city of Nahor.
11 Le Abraham ƒe ku megbe la, Mawu yra via Isak, eye Isak nɔ afi si gogo Beer-Lahai-Roi.
11 He had the camels kneel down at a well of water outside the city. It was about evening, the time when the women would go out to draw water.
12 Esiae nye Abraham vi Ismael, ame si Sara ƒe kosi Hagar, Egipte nyɔnu la, dzi na Abraham la ƒe ŋutinya.
12 Then he said: “Jehovah the God of my master Abraham, please grant me success this day, and show your loyal love to my master Abraham.

13 Esiawoe nye Ismael viwo ƒe ŋkɔwo, le ƒome siwo me wodzɔ tso la nu: Ismael ƒe ŋgɔgbevie nye Nebayot, eyome edzi Kedar, Adbeel, Mibsam, 14 Misma, Duma, Masa, 15 Hadad, Tema, Yetur, Nafis kple Kedema.
15 Even before he finished speaking, Rebekah, who was the daughter of Bethuel the son of Milcah the wife of Nahor, Abraham’s brother, came out with her water jar on her shoulder.
16 Ame siawoe nye Ismael viwo, eye esiawoe nye woƒe ŋkɔwo le woƒe duwo kple woƒe aƒewo nu: wole amegã wuieve le woƒe towo nu.
16 Now the young woman was very beautiful, a virgin; no man had had sexual relations with her.
17 Ismael nɔ agbe ƒe alafa ɖeka blaetɔ̃ vɔ adre.
She went down to the spring, filled her water jar, and then came back up.
Eƒe gbɔgbɔ nu tso, eye wotsɔe kpe ɖe eƒe amewo ŋu. 18 Woƒe nɔƒewo tso Havila, si gogo Sur le Egipte gbɔ lɔƒo, va se ɖe keke Asiria ke.
17 At once the servant ran to meet her and said: “Please give me a little sip of water from your jar.” 18 In turn she said: “Drink, my lord.”
Eye wonɔ wo nɔviwo katã xa. 19 Esiae nye Abraham vi Isak ƒe ŋutinya.
With that she quickly lowered her jar upon her hand and gave him a drink.
Abraham dzi Isak. 20 Isak xɔ ƒe blaene esime wòɖe Aramtɔ Betuel si tso Padan-Aram ƒe vi Rebeka, si nye Aramtɔ Laban nɔvinyɔnu.

19 When she finished giving him a drink, she said: “I will also draw water for your camels until they are done drinking.” 20 So she quickly emptied her jar into the drinking trough and ran again and again to the well to draw water, and she kept drawing water for all his camels.
21 Ke Isak nɔ kuku ɖem na Yehowa vevie ɖe srɔ̃a ta, elabena etsi ko; eye Yehowa se eƒe kukuɖeɖe la, ale be srɔ̃a Rebeka fɔ fu.
21 The whole time the man silently stared at her in amazement, wondering whether Jehovah had made his trip successful or not.
Eye wòyi ɖabia Yehowa se. 23 Yehowa gblɔ nɛ be: “Dukɔ evee le wò dɔ me, eye dukɔ eveawo siwo ado tso mewò la ama; dukɔ ɖeka asesẽ wu ɖeka, eye tsitsitɔ asubɔ ɖevitɔ.”

22 When the camels had finished drinking, the man took out for her a gold nose ring weighing a half shekel and two bracelets of gold weighing ten shekels, 23 and he said: “Please tell me, whose daughter are you?

24 Esi eƒe vidziɣi ɖo la, kpɔ ɖa, venɔviwoe le eƒe dɔ me. 25 Esi gbãtɔ do la, fu hɛ̃ le eŋu kedzekedze abe lãfuwu ene; eya ta wona ŋkɔe be Esau. 26 Emegbe nɔvia do, eye wòlé Esau ƒe afɔkpodzi ɖe asi; eya ta wona ŋkɔe be Yakob. Isak xɔ ƒe blaade esime Rebeka dzi ɖeviawo.

Is there any room at your father’s house for us to spend the night?” 24 At that she said to him: “I am the daughter of Bethuel the son of Milcah, whom she bore to Nahor.” 25 And she added: “We have both straw and much fodder and also a place to spend the night.” 26 Then the man bowed down and prostrated himself before Jehovah 27 and said: “May Jehovah be praised, the God of my master Abraham, for he has not abandoned his loyal love and his faithfulness toward my master.
27 Esi ŋutsuviawo tsi la, Esau va zu adela bibi, eye wòlɔ̃a gbe me nɔnɔ, ke Yakob ya nye ame fafa, eye wòlɔ̃a agbadɔ me nɔnɔ.
Jehovah has guided me to the house of the brothers of my master.”
28 Isak lɔ̃ Esau, elabena edea adelã nu me nɛ, ke Rebeka ya lɔ̃ Yakob.
28 And the young woman ran to tell her mother’s household about these things.
29 Gbe ɖeka Yakob nɔ atadi wɔm esime Esau gbɔ tso gbe me eye nu te eŋu vevie.
29 Now Rebekah had a brother whose name was Laban. So Laban ran to the man who was outside at the spring.
30 Eya ta Esau gblɔ na Yakob be: “Meɖe kuku, na atadi ma, nu dzĩ ma, ƒe ɖem maɖu; netsɔ, elabena nu te ŋunye vevie!”

30 When he saw the nose ring and the bracelets on the hands of his sister and heard the words of his sister Rebekah, who was saying, “This is the way the man spoke to me,” he came to meet the man, who was still there standing by the camels at the spring. 31 At once he said: “Come, you who are blessed by Jehovah.
Esia tae wona ŋkɔe be Edom.
Why do you keep standing out here?
31 Eye Yakob gblɔ be: “Tsɔ wò ŋgɔgbevinyenye dzra nam gbã gbɔ!” 32 Esau gblɔ be: “Kpɔ ɖa, kukumee nye esia mele!

I have made the house ready and a place for the camels.” 32 With that the man came into the house, and he unharnessed the camels and gave straw and fodder to the camels and water to wash his feet and the feet of the men who were with him.
Vi ka gɔ̃e ŋgɔgbevinyenye aɖe nam?” 33 Eye Yakob gagblɔ be: “Ka atam nam gbã gbɔ!”
33 However, when something to eat was set before him, he said: “I will not eat until I have told you what I have to say.”
Eye wòka atam nɛ, ale wòdzra eƒe ŋgɔgbevinyenye na Yakob.
So Laban said: “Speak!”
34 Eye Yakob tsɔ abolo kple ayitadi la na Esau, eye wòɖu nu no nu, emegbe wòtso dzo.
34 Then he said: “I am Abraham’s servant.
Ale Esau do vlo eƒe ŋgɔgbevinyenye la.
This will release you from your oath.’
Emegbe Yehowa ɖe eɖokui fiae esi wòbɔbɔ nɔ eƒe agbadɔ nu le Mamre ƒe ati gãwo te, le ŋdɔkutsu dzatsɛ.
Afterward, Jehovah appeared to him among the big trees of Mamre while he was sitting at the entrance of the tent during the hottest part of the day.
2 Esi wòfɔ mo dzi la, ekpɔ ŋutsu etɔ̃ le tsitre ɖe adzɔge vie tso egbɔ.
2 He looked up and saw three men standing some distance from him.
Esi wòkpɔ wo la, eƒu du tso agbadɔ la nu yi ɖakpe wo, eye wòbɔbɔ tsyɔ mo anyi.
When he saw them, he ran from the entrance of the tent to meet them, and he bowed down to the ground.
3 Eye wògblɔ be: “Yehowa, ne ève nunye la, ekema meɖe kuku, mègato wò subɔla ŋu yi o.
3 Then he said: “Jehovah, if I have found favor in your eyes, please do not pass by your servant.
4 Meɖe kuku, na woaku tsi vi aɖe vɛ ne woaklɔ afɔ na mi. Emegbe miaɖi ɖe eme vie le atia te.
4 Please, let a little water be brought and have your feet washed; then recline under the tree.
5 Esi mieva to miaƒe subɔla gbɔ ta la, matsɔ abolo vi aɖe vɛ na mi miaɖu wòado ŋusẽ mi.
5 Seeing that you have come here to your servant, let me bring a piece of bread so that you may refresh yourselves.
Emegbe miate ŋu ayi miaƒe mɔzɔzɔa dzi.”
Then you may go on your way.”
Ale wogblɔ be: “Enyo.
At this they said: “All right.
Wɔ abe ale si nègblɔ ene.”
You may do as you have spoken.”
6 Eya ta Abraham wɔ kaba yi agbadɔ la me le Sara gbɔ gblɔ nɛ be: “Netsɔ!
6 So Abraham hurried to the tent to Sarah and said: “Quick!
Ku wɔ memee seya etɔ̃, blui eye nàtsɔe amè aboloe.” 7 Emegbe Abraham ƒu du yi nyiwo dome, eye wòlé nyitsui nyui aɖe.
Get three measures of fine flour, knead the dough, and make loaves of bread.” 7 Next Abraham ran to the herd and chose a tender and good young bull.
Etsɔe na subɔvi la, eye wòwɔ kaba yi ɖatrɔ asi le eŋu.
He gave it to the attendant, who hurried to prepare it.
8 Eye wòtsɔ notsi kpekẽ kple notsi tsrolo kpakple nyitsui si ŋu wòtrɔ asi le la ɖo wo kɔme.
8 He then took butter and milk and the young bull that he had prepared and set the food before them.
Ke etɔ ɖe wo gbɔ le atia te esi wonɔ nua ɖum.
Then he stood by them under the tree as they were eating.
9 Eye wobiae be: “Afi kae srɔ̃wò Sara le?”
9 They said to him: “Where is your wife Sarah?”
Eɖo eŋu be: “Ele agbadɔa me le afii.” 10 Eye wo dometɔ ɖeka gblɔ be: “Magatrɔ ava gbɔwò le ƒe si gbɔna ƒe ɣealewoɣi, eye kpɔ ɖa, viŋutsuvi anɔ srɔ̃wò Sara si.”
He replied: “Here in the tent.” 10 So one of them continued: “I will surely return to you next year at this time, and look! your wife Sarah will have a son.”
Ke Sara le agbadɔ si le ŋutsua megbe la nu nɔ to ɖom.
Now Sarah was listening at the tent entrance, which was behind the man.
11 Abraham kple Sara tsi xɔ ƒe geɖe.
11 Abraham and Sarah were old, being advanced in years.
Sara tsi gbɔ vidzidzi ŋu.
Sarah was past the age of childbearing.

12 Eya ta Sara ko nu le dzi me gblɔ be: “Esi wɔna vɔ le ŋunye, eye nye aƒetɔ hã tsi ku amegã ɖe, ɖe magate ŋu akpɔ dzidzɔ sia nyateƒea?” 13 Eye Yehowa gblɔ na Abraham be: “Nu ka tae Sara ko nu gblɔ be, ‘Esi metsi alea ɖe, nyateƒe ŋutɔŋutɔ wònye be madzi via?’ 14 Ðe nane sesẽ na Yehowaa?

12 So Sarah began to laugh to herself, saying: “After I am worn out and my lord is old, will I really have this pleasure?” 13 Then Jehovah said to Abraham: “Why did Sarah laugh and say, ‘Am I really going to give birth even though I am old?’ 14 Is anything too extraordinary for Jehovah?
Magatrɔ ava gbɔwò le ƒe si gbɔna ƒe ɣealewoɣi, eye viŋutsuvi anɔ Sara si.” 15 Ke Sara sẽ nu gblɔ be: “Nyemeko nu o lo!” elabena ele vɔvɔ̃m.
I will return to you next year at this appointed time, and Sarah will have a son.” 15 But Sarah denied it, saying, “I did not laugh!” for she was afraid.
Ke egblɔ be: “Ao!
At this he said: “Yes!
Èko nu.”
You did laugh.”
16 Esime ŋutsuawo tso le afi ma dze mɔ, eye wole Sodom kpɔm le abu me ɖaa la, Abraham zɔ kpli wo be yeaɖo wo ɖa.
16 When the men got up to leave and looked down toward Sodom, Abraham was walking with them to escort them.
17 Yehowa gblɔ be: “Ðe maɣla nu si wɔ ge mala la ɖe Abraham mahã? 18 Kpɔ ɖa, Abraham ava zu dukɔ gã sẽŋu aɖe, eye woayra anyigbadzidukɔwo katã to edzi.

17 Jehovah said: “Am I keeping hidden from Abraham what I am going to do? 18 Why, Abraham is surely going to become a great and mighty nation, and all the nations of the earth will be blessed by means of him.

19 Elabena meva nya eya amea nyuie be ade se na viawo kple eƒemetɔ siwo ava ɖe eyome, be woayi edzi anɔ Yehowa ƒe mɔ dzi, ne woawɔ nu dzɔdzɔe kple nu si le eteƒe; ale be Yehowa nana nya si wògblɔ ku ɖe Abraham ŋu la nava eme.”

19 For I have come to know him in order that he may command his sons and his household after him to keep Jehovah’s way by doing what is right and just, so that Jehovah may bring about what he has promised concerning Abraham.”
20 Eye Yehowa gblɔ be: “Konyifaɣli si le ɖiɖim ɖe Sodom kple Gomora ta la nu sẽ, eye woƒe nu vɔ̃ la kpe ŋutɔ.
20 Then Jehovah said: “The outcry against Sodom and Gomorrah is indeed great, and their sin is very heavy.
21 Maɖi ayi be makpɔe ɖa be ɣli si le ɖiɖim le wo ta la le eme hã, eye ne mele nenema o la, ne manya.”
21 I will go down to see whether they are acting according to the outcry that has reached me. And if not, I can get to know it.”
22 Azɔ ŋutsuawo dzo le afi ma heɖo ta Sodom; gake Yehowa tsi Abraham gbɔ.
22 Then the men left from there and went toward Sodom, but Jehovah remained with Abraham.

23 Eye Abraham te ɖe eŋu gblɔ be: “Ðe nàtsrɔ̃ ame dzɔdzɔewo kpe ɖe ame vɔ̃ɖiwo ŋua? 24 Tsɔe be ame dzɔdzɔe blaatɔ̃ le dua me; ɖe nàtsrɔ̃ woa, eye màtsɔ ake teƒe sia le ame dzɔdzɔe blaatɔ̃ siwo le eme la ta oa? 25 Meka ɖe edzi be màwɔ nu ma, awu ame dzɔdzɔe kple ame vɔ̃ɖi siaa, ale be wòanɔ na ame dzɔdzɔe abe ale si wòanɔ na ame vɔ̃ɖi ene gbeɖe o!

23 Then Abraham approached and said: “Will you really sweep away the righteous with the wicked? 24 Suppose there are 50 righteous men within the city. Will you, then, sweep them away and not pardon the place for the sake of the 50 righteous who are inside it? 25 It is unthinkable that you would act in this manner by putting the righteous man to death with the wicked one so that the outcome for the righteous man and the wicked is the same!
Màwɔ esia akpɔ o.
It is unthinkable of you.

Ðe anyigba blibo la ƒe Ʋɔnudrɔ̃la la mawɔ nu dzɔdzɔe oa?” 26 Eye Yehowa gblɔ be: “Ne makpɔ ame dzɔdzɔe blaatɔ̃ le Sodom dua me la, matsɔe ake teƒe blibo la le wo ta.” 27 Ke Abraham gblɔ be: “Meɖe kuku, togbɔ be anyi kple afi menye hã, meɖoe ɖokuinye dzi be maƒo nu kple Yehowa.

Will the Judge of all the earth not do what is right?” 26 Then Jehovah said: “If I find in Sodom 50 righteous men in the city, I will pardon the whole place for their sake.” 27 But Abraham again responded: “Please, here I have presumed to speak to Jehovah, whereas I am dust and ashes.
28 Tsɔe be ame atɔ̃ to le ame dzɔdzɔe blaatɔ̃a me.
28 Suppose the 50 righteous should lack five.
Ðe nàxa ɖe ame atɔ̃ la ta atsrɔ̃ dua?”
Because of the five will you destroy the whole city?”
Eɖo eŋu be: “Ne mekpɔ ame blaene vɔ atɔ̃ le eme la, nyematsrɔ̃e o.”
To this he said: “I will not destroy it if I find there 45.”
29 Ke egagblɔ nɛ be: “Tsɔe be wokpɔ ame blaene le eme.”
29 But yet again he spoke to him and said: “Suppose 40 are found there.”
Eɖo eŋu be: “Nyematsrɔ̃e o le ame blaene la ta.” 30 Ke eyi edzi be: “Yehowa, meɖe kuku mègabi dzi o, na magaƒo nu ake: Tsɔe be wokpɔ ame blaetɔ̃ ko le eme.”
He answered: “I will not do it for the sake of the 40.” 30 But he continued: “Jehovah, please, do not become hot with anger, but let me go on speaking: Suppose only 30 are found there.”
Eɖo eŋu be: “Ne makpɔ ame blaetɔ̃ le eme la, nyematsrɔ̃e o.” 31 Ke egayi edzi be: “Meɖe kuku, meɖoe ɖokuinye dzi be maƒo nu kple Yehowa: Tsɔe be wokpɔ ame blaeve ko le eme.”
He answered: “I will not do it if I find 30 there.” 31 But he continued: “Please, here I have presumed to speak to Jehovah: Suppose only 20 are found there.”
Eɖo eŋu be: “Nyematsrɔ̃e o le ame blaeve la ta.” 32 Mlɔeba egblɔ be: “Yehowa, meɖe kuku mègabi dzi o lo, na magaƒo nu zi ɖeka pɛ sia ko: Tsɔe be wokpɔ ame ewo pɛ ko le eme.”
He answered: “I will not destroy it for the sake of the 20.” 32 Finally he said: “Jehovah, please, do not become hot with anger, but let me speak just once more: Suppose only ten are found there.”
Eɖo eŋu be: “Nyematsrɔ̃e o le ame ewo la ta.” 33 Esi Yehowa ƒo nu kple Abraham vɔ la, edzo, eye Abraham trɔ yi enɔƒe.
He answered: “I will not destroy it for the sake of the ten.” 33 When Jehovah finished speaking to Abraham, he went his way and Abraham returned to his place.
Fifia Abraham tsi xɔ ƒe geɖe, eye Yehowa yrae le nuwo katã me.
Abraham was now old, advanced in years, and Jehovah had blessed Abraham in everything.

2 Abraham gblɔ na eƒe subɔvi tsitsitɔ si kpɔa eƒe aƒemenuwo katã dzi la be: “Meɖe kuku, tsɔ wò asi de nye ata te, 3 eye nàtsɔ Yehowa, dziƒowo kple anyigba ƒe Mawu, aka atam nam be, màɖe srɔ̃ na vinye tso Kanaantɔ siwo dome mele la ƒe vinyɔnuwo dome o.

2 Abraham said to his servant, the oldest one of his household, who was managing all he had: “Please put your hand under my thigh, 3 and I will make you swear by Jehovah, the God of the heavens and the God of the earth, that you will not take a wife for my son from the daughters of the Canaanites, among whom I am dwelling.
4 Ke boŋ àyi nye dukɔ kple ƒonyemeawo gbɔ aɖaɖe srɔ̃ na vinye Isak.”
4 You must go instead to my country and to my relatives and take a wife for my son, for Isaac.”
5 Ke subɔvi la gblɔ nɛ be: “Ke ne nyɔnu la melɔ̃ be yeakplɔm ɖo ava anyigba sia dzi o ɖe?
5 However, the servant said to him: “What if the woman is not willing to come with me to this land?
Ðe magbugbɔ viwò la ayi anyigba si dzi nèʋu le la dzia?” 6 Abraham gblɔ nɛ be: “Kpɔ nyuie be nàgagbugbɔ vinye la ayi afi ma o.
Must I then return your son to the land from which you came?” 6 At this Abraham said to him: “See that you do not take my son there.

7 Yehowa, dziƒowo ƒe Mawu, ame si kplɔm tso fofonye ƒe me kple ƒonyemeawo ƒe anyigba dzi, eye wòƒo nu kplim heka atam nam be, ‘Wò dzidzimeviwoe matsɔ anyigba sia ana’ la, ŋutɔ adɔ eƒe dɔla ɖe ŋgɔwò, eye nàɖe srɔ̃ na vinye la tso afi ma.

7 Jehovah the God of the heavens, who took me from my father’s house and from the land of my relatives and who spoke with me and swore to me: ‘To your offspring I am going to give this land,’ he will send his angel ahead of you, and you will certainly take a wife for my son from there.
8 Ke ne nyɔnu la melɔ̃ be yeakplɔ wò ɖo ava o la, ekema atam si nèka la magabla wò o.
8 But if the woman is unwilling to come with you, you will be free from this oath.
Ðeko mègana vinye la nagbugbɔ ayi afi ma o.” 9 Ale subɔvi la tsɔ eƒe asi de eƒe aƒetɔ Abraham ƒe ata te, eye wòka atam nɛ ɖe nya sia dzi.
But you must not take my son there.” 9 With that the servant put his hand under the thigh of Abraham his master and swore to him concerning this matter.
10 Eye subɔvi la ɖe eƒe aƒetɔ ƒe kposɔ ewo eye wòtsɔ eƒe aƒetɔ ƒe nu nyui vovovowo ɖe asi hedze mɔ.
10 So the servant took ten of his master’s camels and departed, taking along all sorts of good things from his master.
Eye wòɖo ta Mesopotamia, yina ɖe Nahor ƒe du la me.
Then he went on his way to MesOpOtAmia, to the city of Nahor.
11 Ena kposɔawo va tsyɔ akɔ anyi ɖe vudo aɖe to le dua godo.
11 He had the camels kneel down at a well of water outside the city.
Enye fiẽ me lɔƒo, le nyɔnuwo ƒe tɔmedeɣi.
It was about evening, the time when the women would go out to draw water.
12 Eye wògblɔ be: “Yehowa, nye aƒetɔ Abraham ƒe Mawu, meɖe kuku, na wòadze edzi nam egbe sia dzro, eye nàve nye aƒetɔ Abraham nu.
12 Then he said: “Jehovah the God of my master Abraham, please grant me success this day, and show your loyal love to my master Abraham.
13 Kpɔ ɖa, metɔ ɖe tsiduƒe, eye dua me nyɔnuviwo gbɔna tsi du ge.
13 Here I am standing at a spring of water, and the daughters of the men of the city are coming out to draw water.

14 Na wòava eme be ɖetugbui si magblɔ na be, ‘Meɖe kuku, dro wò tsize la ne nàna tsi vi aɖem mano,’ eye wòaɖo eŋu nam be, ‘Noe, eye mana tsi wò kposɔwo hã’ la, eya nanye ame si nètia na wò dɔla Isak; eye na manyae to esia me be ève nye aƒetɔ nu.”

14 May it happen that the young woman to whom I say, ‘Please let down your water jar so that I may take a drink,’ and who replies, ‘Take a drink, and I will also water your camels,’ let this be the one you choose for your servant Isaac; and by this let me know that you have shown your loyal love to my master.”
15 Ke esi mekpɔ ɖe nu le nya la me o la, kpɔ ɖa, Rebeka si wodzi na Betuel, ame si nye Abraham nɔvi Nahor srɔ̃ Milka ƒe vi, lae nye esi lé tsize ɖe abɔta gbɔna.
15 Even before he finished speaking, Rebekah, who was the daughter of Bethuel the son of Milcah the wife of Nahor, Abraham’s brother, came out with her water jar on her shoulder.
16 Ðetugbui la dze tugbe ŋutɔ, enye ɖetugbui leaƒe; eye ŋutsu aɖeke medɔ egbɔ kpɔ o.
16 Now the young woman was very beautiful, a virgin; no man had had sexual relations with her.
Eɖi abu yi tsiduƒea ɖaku tsi ɖe eƒe ze la me, emegbe wòdo go.
She went down to the spring, filled her water jar, and then came back up.
17 Enumake subɔvi la ƒu du yi ɖakpee gblɔ be: “Meɖe kuku, na wò ze la me tsi vi aɖem mano.” 18 Ke eɖo eŋu nɛ be: “Nye aƒetɔ, noe faa.”
17 At once the servant ran to meet her and said: “Please give me a little sip of water from your jar.” 18 In turn she said: “Drink, my lord.”
Eye wòɖiɖi eƒe ze la ɖe asi, eye wòna ɖee wòno.
With that she quickly lowered her jar upon her hand and gave him a drink.

19 Esi wòna tsii vɔ la, egblɔ be: “Madu tsi na wò kposɔwo hã, va se ɖe esime wòaɖi kɔ na wo.” 20 Ale wòtrɔ tsi si le eƒe zea me la kɔ ɖe lãwo ƒe tsinonu la me, eye wòle du dzi le vudoa to yim le gbɔgbɔm hele tsi dum na eƒe kposɔawo katã.

19 When she finished giving him a drink, she said: “I will also draw water for your camels until they are done drinking.” 20 So she quickly emptied her jar into the drinking trough and ran again and again to the well to draw water, and she kept drawing water for all his camels.
21 Le ɣeyiɣi sia katã me la, ŋutsua nɔ ekpɔm dũu, eƒe nu ku, eye wòzi kpi le ekpɔm ɖa be ɖe Yehowa na yeƒe mɔzɔzɔa dze edzi loo alo medze edzi o hã.
21 The whole time the man silently stared at her in amazement, wondering whether Jehovah had made his trip successful or not.
22 Esi kposɔawo no tsi vɔ la, ŋutsua tsɔ sikaŋɔtigɛ si da sekel afã kple alɔnugɛ eve, siwo da sika sekel ewo la nɛ be wòado, 23 eye wòbiae be: “Meɖe kuku gblɔe nam, ame ka ƒe vie nènye?

22 When the camels had finished drinking, the man took out for her a gold nose ring weighing a half shekel and two bracelets of gold weighing ten shekels, 23 and he said: “Please tell me, whose daughter are you?

Míakpɔ dzeƒe le fofowò ƒe aƒe me atsi adɔa?” 24 Eye wògblɔ nɛ be: “Fofonyee nye Betuel, ame si Milka dzi na Nahor.” 25 Eye wògagblɔ nɛ be: “Gbe kple nuɖuɖu geɖe le mía si na miaƒe lãwo, eye teƒe hã li miatsi adɔ.” 26 Eye ŋutsu la bɔbɔ hetsyɔ mo anyi ɖe Yehowa ŋkume 27 gblɔ be: “Woakafu Yehowa, nye aƒetɔ Abraham ƒe Mawu, ame si ve nye aƒetɔ nu hewɔ nuteƒe nɛ.

Is there any room at your father’s house for us to spend the night?” 24 At that she said to him: “I am the daughter of Bethuel the son of Milcah, whom she bore to Nahor.” 25 And she added: “We have both straw and much fodder and also a place to spend the night.” 26 Then the man bowed down and prostrated himself before Jehovah 27 and said: “May Jehovah be praised, the God of my master Abraham, for he has not abandoned his loyal love and his faithfulness toward my master.
Yehowa fia mɔm hekplɔm va nye aƒetɔ nɔviwo ƒe me.”
Jehovah has guided me to the house of the brothers of my master.”
28 Eye ɖetugbui la ƒu du yi ɖagblɔ nya siawo na dadaa ƒemetɔwo.
28 And the young woman ran to tell her mother’s household about these things.
29 Ke nɔviŋutsu aɖe le Rebeka si, eŋkɔe nye Laban.
29 Now Rebekah had a brother whose name was Laban.
Laban ƒu du yi ŋutsua gbɔ le tsiduƒea.
So Laban ran to the man who was outside at the spring.

30 Esi wòkpɔ ŋɔtigɛ la kple alɔnugɛawo le nɔvianyɔnu ƒe alɔ, eye wòse nɔvianyɔnu Rebeka ƒe nyawo be, “Ale kple ale ŋutsua gblɔ nam” la, eyi ɖakpe ŋutsua, ame si kpɔtɔ le tsitre ɖe kposɔawo gbɔ le tsiduƒea.

30 When he saw the nose ring and the bracelets on the hands of his sister and heard the words of his sister Rebekah, who was saying, “This is the way the man spoke to me,” he came to meet the man, who was still there standing by the camels at the spring.
31 Enumake egblɔ be: “Va, wò ame si Yehowa yra.
31 At once he said: “Come, you who are blessed by Jehovah.
Nu ka tae nèkpɔtɔ le tsitre ɖe afi sia?
Why do you keep standing out here?

Medzra aƒea me ɖo, eye medi teƒe na kposɔawo.” 32 Ale ŋutsu la va aƒea me, eye wòɖe akpa na kposɔawo, ena gbe kple nuɖuɖu kposɔawo, eye wòku tsi be woatsɔ aklɔ afɔ na eya kple ŋutsu siwo kpe ɖe eŋu la.

I have made the house ready and a place for the camels.” 32 With that the man came into the house, and he unharnessed the camels and gave straw and fodder to the camels and water to wash his feet and the feet of the men who were with him.
33 Esi wotsɔ nuɖuɖu ɖo ekɔme la, egblɔ be: “Nyemaɖu nu o, va se ɖe esime megblɔ nya si le asinye vɔ hafi.”
33 However, when something to eat was set before him, he said: “I will not eat until I have told you what I have to say.”
Eya ta Laban gblɔ be: “Ƒo nu!”
So Laban said: “Speak!”
34 Eye wògblɔ be: “Abraham ƒe subɔvie menye.
34 Then he said: “I am Abraham’s servant.
35 Yehowa yra nye aƒetɔ geɖe hena wòzu kesinɔtɔ gã aɖe, eye wòna alẽwo kple nyiwo, klosalo kple sika, subɔviŋutsuwo kple subɔvinyɔnuwo, kposɔwo kple tedziwo su esi.
35 And Jehovah has blessed my master very much, and he has made him very wealthy by giving him sheep and cattle, silver and gold, male and female servants, and camels and donkeys.
36 Nye aƒetɔ srɔ̃ Sara hã dzi vi nɛ le eƒe nyagãkuku me, eye nye aƒetɔ atsɔ eƒe nuwo katã ana via.
36 Further, Sarah the wife of my master bore a son to my master after she grew old, and he will give him everything he has.
37 Eya ta nye aƒetɔ na meka atam ɖe nya sia dzi be: ‘Mègaɖe srɔ̃ na vinye la tso Kanaantɔ siwo ƒe anyigba dzi mele la ƒe vinyɔnuwo dome o.
37 So my master made me swear, saying: ‘You must not take a wife for my son from the daughters of the Canaanites, in whose land I am dwelling.

38 Ao, ke boŋ yi fofonye ƒe me kple ƒonyemeawo gbɔ nàɖe srɔ̃ na vinyea.’ 39 Megblɔ na nye aƒetɔ be: ‘Ke ne nyɔnu la melɔ̃ be yeava kplim o ɖe?’ 40 Egblɔ nam be: ‘Yehowa, ame si ŋkume mezɔ le la, adɔ eƒe dɔla wòayi kpli wò, eye wòana mɔzɔzɔ la nadze edzi na wò, eye nàɖe srɔ̃ na vinye tso ƒonyemeawo gbɔ kple fofonye ƒe aƒe me.

38 No, but you will go to the house of my father and to my family, and you must take a wife for my son.’ 39 But I said to my master: ‘What if the woman is unwilling to come with me?’ 40 He said to me: ‘Jehovah, before whom I have walked, will send his angel with you and will certainly give success to your journey, and you must take a wife for my son from my family and from the house of my father.
41 Ne èɖo ƒonyemeawo gbɔ eye wometsɔ nyɔnu la na wò o la, ekema atam si nèka nam la megabla wò o.
41 You will be released from your oath to me if you go to my family and they will not give her to you.
Esia koe ana nàvo tso atam si nèka nam la me.’
This will release you from your oath.’
42 “Esi meva ɖo tsiduƒea egbea la, megblɔ be: ‘Yehowa, nye aƒetɔ Abraham ƒe Mawu, ne àna be nye mɔzɔzɔa nadze edzi nam la, 43 ekema kpɔ ɖa, mele tsitre ɖe tsiduƒe.
42 “When I got to the spring today, I said: ‘Jehovah the God of my master Abraham, if you will make my journey successful, 43 here I am standing at a spring.

Nu si dim mele ye nye be, ne ɖetugbui aɖe va tsi du ge la, magblɔ nɛ be, “Meɖe kuku, na wò ze la me tsi vi aɖem mano,” 44 eye ne eɖo eŋu nam be, “Noe, eye madu tsi na wò kposɔwo hã” la, ekema eyae anye nyɔnu si Yehowa tia na nye aƒetɔ ƒe vi la.’

What must take place is that when a young woman comes out to draw water, I will say, “Please, let me drink a little water from your jar,” 44 and she will say to me, “You take a drink, and I will also draw water for your camels.” Let that woman be the one whom Jehovah has chosen for the son of my master.’
45 “Nyemekpɔ wu nya la nu le nye dzi me o, kasia Rebekae nye ema lé ze ɖe abɔta gbɔna, eye wòyi tsiduƒea ɖaku tsi.
45 “Before I was finished speaking in my heart, there was Rebekah coming out with her jar on her shoulder, and she made her way down to the spring and began to draw water.
Megblɔ nɛ be: ‘Meɖe kuku, na tsim mano.’ 46 Eye wòɖiɖi eƒe ze la tso abɔta gblɔ be, ‘Noe, eye madu tsi na wò kposɔawo hã.’
Then I said to her: ‘Give me a drink, please.’ 46 So she quickly lowered her jar from her shoulder and said: ‘Take a drink, and I will also water your camels.’
Eye menoe, eye wòdu tsi na kposɔawo hã wono.
Then I took a drink, and she also watered the camels.
47 Emegbe mebiae be, ‘Ame ka ƒe vie nènye?’ Eɖo eŋu nam be, ‘Fofonyee nye Betuel, ame si Milka dzi na Nahor.’
47 After that I asked her, ‘Whose daughter are you?’ to which she replied, ‘The daughter of Bethuel the son of Nahor, whom Milcah bore to him.’
Ale metsɔ sikaŋɔtigɛ de ŋɔti nɛ kple alɔnugɛwo de alɔ nɛ.
So I put the ring on her nose and the bracelets on her hands.
48 Eye mebɔbɔ hetsyɔ mo anyi ɖe Yehowa ŋkume, eye mekafu Yehowa, nye aƒetɔ Abraham ƒe Mawu, ame si kplɔm to mɔ nyuitɔ dzi be maɖe nye aƒetɔ nɔvi ƒe vinyɔnu na via.

48 And I bowed down and prostrated myself before Jehovah and praised Jehovah the God of my master Abraham, who had led me on the right path to take the daughter of the brother of my master for his son.
49 Eya ta ne mianyo dɔme na nye aƒetɔ ahawɔ nuteƒe nɛ la, ekema migblɔe nam; ke ne menye nenema o hã, migblɔe nam, ne manya afi si maɖo tae.”
49 And now tell me if you wish to show loyal love and faithfulness toward my master; but if not, tell me, so that I may proceed one way or the other.”
50 Eye Laban kple Betuel ɖo eŋu nɛ be: “Yehowa gbɔe nu sia tso.
50 Then Laban and Bethuel answered: “This is from Jehovah.
Míate ŋu alɔ̃ alo agbe o.
We are not able to say yes or no to you.
51 Rebekae nye esi le ŋkuwòme.
51 Here is Rebekah before you.
Kplɔe yii ne wòazu wò aƒetɔ ƒe vi la srɔ̃, abe ale si tututu Yehowa gblɔe ene.” 52 Esi Abraham ƒe subɔvi la se woƒe nyawo la, etsyɔ mo anyi enumake le Yehowa ŋkume.
Take her and go, and let her become a wife to the son of your master, just as Jehovah has spoken.” 52 When Abraham’s servant heard their words, he at once bowed down on the ground before Jehovah.
53 Eye subɔvi la he klosalonuwo, sikanuwo kple awuwo ɖe go tsɔ na Rebeka; eye wòna nu xɔasiwo nɔviaŋutsua kple dadaa hã.
53 And the servant began to bring out articles of silver and of gold and garments and to give them to Rebekah, and he gave valuable things to her brother and to her mother.
54 Emegbe eya kple ŋutsu siwo le eŋu la ɖu nu no nu, eye wotsi afi ma dɔ.
54 After that he and the men with him ate and drank, and they spent the night there.
Esi wofɔ ŋdi la, egblɔ be: “Mido mɔm ne mayi nye aƒetɔ gbɔ.” 55 Eye nɔvia kple dadaa gblɔ be: “Na ɖetugbui la nanɔ mía gbɔ ŋkeke ewo ya teti.
When he got up in the morning, he said: “Send me off to my master.” 55 To this her brother and her mother said: “Let the young woman stay with us at least ten days.
Emegbe ate ŋu ayi.” 56 Ke egblɔ na wo be: “Migasikam ɖi o, elabena Yehowa na nye mɔzɔzɔ la dze edzi nam.
Then she can go.” 56 But he said to them: “Do not detain me, seeing that Jehovah has made my journey successful.
Mido mɔm ne mayi nye aƒetɔ gbɔ.” 57 Eye wogblɔ be: “Mina míayɔ ɖetugbui la ne míase eya ŋutɔ ƒe numegbe.” 58 Ale woyɔ Rebeka hebiae be: “Àyi kple ŋutsu sia?”
Send me off, in order that I may go to my master.” 57 So they said: “Let us call the young woman and inquire of her.” 58 They called Rebekah and said to her: “Will you go with this man?”
Eɖo eŋu be: “Ɛ̃, mayi.”
She replied: “I am willing to go.”
59 Eya ta wodo mɔ wo nɔvinyɔnu Rebeka kple ame si na noe kpakple Abraham ƒe subɔvi la kple eŋumeawo.
59 So they sent off their sister Rebekah and her nurse and Abraham’s servant and his men.

60 Eye woyra Rebeka gblɔ nɛ be: “Oo mía nɔvinyɔnu, dzi, ne nàzu ame akpe ewo teƒe akpewo dada, eye wò dzidzimeviwo naxɔ woƒe futɔwo ƒe duwo woazu wo tɔ.” 61 Eye Rebeka kple eƒe subɔvinyɔnuwo tso, eye wode kposɔwo dzi yi kple ŋutsu la.

60 And they blessed Rebekah and said to her: “Our sister, may you become thousands times ten thousand, and let your offspring take possession of the gate of those who hate them.” 61 Then Rebekah and her female attendants rose, got on the camels, and followed the man.
Ale subɔvi la kplɔ Rebeka hedze mɔ.
So the servant took Rebekah and went on his way.
62 Ke Isak trɔ tso Beer-Lahai-Roi mɔ dzi gbɔna, elabena enɔ Negeb-nyigba dzi.
62 Now Isaac had come from the direction of Beer-lAhai-roi, for he was dwelling in the land of the Negeb.
63 Isak do go yi ɖanɔ tsa ɖim le gbe me le fiẽ me lɔƒo nɔ ŋugble dem.
63 And Isaac was out walking in the field about nightfall to meditate.
Esi wòfɔ mo dzi la, ekpɔ kposɔwo gbɔna! 64 Esi Rebeka fɔ mo dzi la, ekpɔ Isak, eye wòɖi le kposɔ la dzi enumake.
When he looked up, why, he saw that camels were coming! 64 When Rebekah looked up, she caught sight of Isaac, and she quickly got down from the camel.
65 Eye wòbia subɔvi la be: “Ŋutsu kae nye ma le zɔzɔm le gbe me gbɔna mía kpe ge?”
65 Then she asked the servant: “Who is that man there walking in the field to meet us?”
Eye subɔvi la gblɔ be: “Nye aƒetɔe.”
And the servant said: “It is my master.”
Ale wòtsɔ motsyɔnu tsyɔ ŋkume.
So she took her veil to cover herself.
66 Eye subɔvi la gblɔ nu siwo katã wòwɔ la na Isak.
66 And the servant told Isaac all the things he had done.
67 Eye Isak kplɔ ɖetugbuia yi dadaa Sara ƒe agbadɔ me.
67 After that Isaac brought her into the tent of Sarah his mother.
Ale Rebeka zu srɔ̃a; Isak lɔ̃e ŋutɔ, eye Isak ƒe akɔ fa azɔ le dadaa si ku la ŋuti.
Thus he took Rebekah as his wife; and he fell in love with her, and Isaac found comfort after the loss of his mother.
Le ƒe eve megbe la, Farao ku drɔ̃e be yetɔ ɖe Nil-tɔsisi la to.
At the end of two full years, Pharaoh dreamed that he was standing by the Nile River.
2 Eye wòkpɔ nyinɔ adre siwo nya kpɔ heda ami la do tso tɔsisia me, eye wole gbe ɖum le Nil-tɔsisia to.
2 And there, coming up from the river, were seven fine-looking, fat cows, and they were feeding on the Nile grass.
3 Eye kpɔ ɖa, nyinɔ adre bubu do tso Nil-tɔsisia me ɖe wo yome, womenya kpɔ o, woɖi ku glãŋuu, eye wotɔ ɖe nyinɔ damiawo gbɔ le Nil-tɔsisia to.
3 There were seven other cows that looked ugly and thin coming up after them from the Nile, and they stood alongside the fat cows by the bank of the Nile.
4 Eye nyinɔ ɖiku siwo menya kpɔ o la de asi nyinɔ dami adre siwo nya kpɔ la mimi me.
4 Then the ugly, thin cows began to eat up the seven fine-looking, fat cows.
Ale Farao nyɔ.
At this Pharaoh woke up.
5 Ke egayi alɔ̃ me, eye wòku drɔ̃e zi evelia.
5 Then he went back to sleep and had a second dream.
Ekpɔ lutsetse adre wɔ ɖe ati ɖeka ŋu, woʋã hedo ku nyuie.
There were seven ears of grain coming up on one stalk, full and choice.
6 Eye lutsetse adre siwo le lɛe, eye ɣedzeƒeya xɔdzo na woyrɔ la, hã do ɖe wo yome.
6 And growing up after them were seven ears of grain that were thin and scorched by the east wind.
7 Eye lutsetse lɛawo de asi lutsetse adre siwo ʋã hedo ku la mimi me.
7 And the thin ears of grain began to swallow up the seven full and choice ears of grain.
Ale Farao nyɔ, eye wòkpɔe be drɔ̃e yeku.
At this Pharaoh woke up and realized that it was a dream.
8 Esi ŋu ke la, eƒe gbɔgbɔ tsi dzodzodzoe.
8 But in the morning, his spirit became agitated.
Eya ta edɔ woyi ɖayɔ eƒe akunyawɔla siwo katã le Egipte kple eƒe nunyalawo katã vɛ.
So he sent for all the magic-practicing priests of Egypt and all her wise men.
Eye Farao lĩ eƒe drɔ̃eawo na wo, ke wo dometɔ aɖeke mete ŋu ɖe wo gɔme na Farao o.
Pharaoh related his dreams to them, but there was no one who could interpret them for Pharaoh.
9 Enumake ahakulawo ƒe amegã la gblɔ na Farao be: “Maʋu nye nu vɔ̃wo me egbea.
9 At that the chief cupbearer spoke with Pharaoh, saying: “I am confessing my sins today.
10 Farao do dziku ɖe eƒe subɔviwo ŋu.
10 Pharaoh was indignant at his servants.
Ale wòde nye kple abolomelawo ƒe amegã siaa fiaŋudzɔlawo ƒe amegã ƒe gaxɔ me.
So he committed me to the jail of the house of the chief of the guard, both me and the chief baker.
11 Emegbe mía dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe ku drɔ̃e le zã ɖeka me.
11 After that we each had a dream on the same night.
Ke mía dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe ku eƒe drɔ̃e, eye eƒe gɔmeɖeɖe to vovo.
He and I each had a dream with its own interpretation.
12 Hebri ɖekakpui aɖe, si nye fiaŋudzɔlawo ƒe amegã ƒe subɔvi la, nɔ mía gbɔ le gaxɔa me.
12 And there with us was a young Hebrew man, a servant of the chief of the guard.
Esi míelĩ míaƒe drɔ̃eawo nɛ la, eɖe mía dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe ƒe drɔ̃ea gɔme nɛ.
When we related them to him, he interpreted for us the meaning of each dream.
13 Eva eme pɛpɛpɛ abe ale si tututu wòɖe wo gɔme na mí ene.
13 It happened exactly as he had interpreted to us.
Wogatsɔm ɖo nye dɔ nu, ke wohe ame kemɛa ɖe ati ŋu.”
I was restored to my office, but the other man was hanged.”
14 Eye Farao dɔ be woayi aɖakplɔ Yosef vɛ, eye wokplɔe tso gaxɔ la me vɛ enumake.
14 So Pharaoh sent for Joseph, and they brought him quickly from the prison.
Eya ta elũ ge, ɖɔli eƒe awuwo, eye wòyi Farao gbɔ.
He shaved and changed his clothes and went in to Pharaoh.
15 Eye Farao gblɔ na Yosef be: “Meku drɔ̃e, ke ame aɖeke meli aɖe egɔme nam o.
15 Then Pharaoh said to Joseph: “I had a dream, but there is no one to interpret it.
Gake wogblɔ le ŋuwò mese be, ne èse drɔ̃e la, ètea ŋu ɖea egɔme.” 16 Yosef ɖo eŋu na Farao be: “Menye nyee o!
Now I have heard it said about you that you can hear a dream and interpret it.” 16 At this Joseph answered Pharaoh: “I need not be considered!
Mawue agblɔ nya si nyo la na Farao.”
God will speak concerning Pharaoh’s welfare.”
17 Farao gagblɔ na Yosef be: “Meku drɔ̃e, eye kpɔ ɖa, mele tsitre ɖe Nil-tɔsisia to.
17 Pharaoh went on to say to Joseph: “In my dream I was standing on the bank of the Nile River.
18 Eye mekpɔ nyinɔ dami adre siwo nya kpɔ la do tso Nil-tɔsisia me, eye wole gbe ɖum le Nil-tɔsisia to.
18 And there, coming up from the Nile, were seven fine-looking, fat cows, and they began to feed on the Nile grass.
19 Eye kpɔ ɖa, nyinɔ adre bubu do ɖe wo yome, woƒe dzedzeme vlo, womenya kpɔ kura o, eye woɖi ku glãŋuu.
19 And there were seven other cows coming up after them, poor and very bad-looking and thin.
Nyemekpɔ nyinɔ vloe siawo tɔgbi le Egipte-nyigba blibo la katã dzi kpɔ o.
I have never seen such bad-looking cows in all the land of Egypt.
20 Eye nyinɔ ɖiku siwo menya kpɔ o la de asi nyinɔ dami adre gbãtɔawo mimi me.
20 And the skinny, bad cows began to eat up the first seven fat cows.
21 Gake esi womi wo hã la, mànya gɔ̃ hã be womi naneke o, elabena woƒe dzedzeme gavloe abe ale si wonɔ tsã ene.
21 But when they had consumed them, no one could have known that they had done so, since their appearance was just as bad as at the start.
Eye menyɔ.
At that I woke up.
22 “Emegbe megaku drɔ̃e, eye mekpɔ lutsetse adre wɔ ɖe luti ɖeka ŋu, woʋã hedo ku nyuie.
22 “After that I saw in my dream seven ears of grain coming up on one stalk, full and choice.
23 Eye lutsetse adre siwo mia sũu hele lɛe, eye ɣedzeƒeya xɔdzo na woyrɔ la hã do ɖe wo yome.
23 Growing up after them were seven ears of shriveled grain, thin and scorched by the east wind.
24 Eye lutsetse lɛawo de asi lutsetse adre siwo ʋã la mimi me.
24 Then the thin ears of grain began to swallow up the seven choice ears of grain.
Melĩ drɔ̃ea na akunyawɔlawo, gake wo dometɔ aɖeke mete ŋu ɖe egɔme nam o.”
So I told it to the magic-practicing priests, but there was no one who could explain it to me.”
25 Eye Yosef gblɔ na Farao be: “Gɔmeɖeɖe ɖekae le Farao ƒe drɔ̃eawo ŋu.
25 Then Joseph said to Pharaoh: “The dreams of Pharaoh are one and the same.
Nu si wɔ ge Mawu vavã la le lae wògblɔ na Farao.
The true God has told to Pharaoh what He will do.
26 Nyinɔ dami adreawo nye ƒe adre.
26 The seven good cows are seven years.
Nenema kee lutsetse ʋaʋã adreawo nye ƒe adre.
Likewise, the seven good ears of grain are seven years.
Gɔmeɖeɖe ɖekae le drɔ̃eawo ŋu.
The dreams are one and the same.
27 Nyinɔ ɖiku adre siwo vloe ŋutɔ, siwo do ɖe wo yome la, nye ƒe adre, eye lutsetse adre siwo medo ku o, eye ɣedzeƒeya xɔdzo na woyrɔ la, nye ƒe adre si me dɔ ato le.
27 The seven skinny and bad cows that came up after them are seven years, and the seven empty ears of grain, scorched by the east wind, will prove to be seven years of famine.
28 Ðeko wòle abe ale si tututu megblɔe na Farao ene be: Nu si wɔ ge Mawu vavã la le lae wòna Farao kpɔ.
28 This is just as I told to Pharaoh: The true God has caused Pharaoh to see what He will do.
29 “Ƒe adre gbɔna, esime nuɖuɖu ado agbogbo ɖe Egipte-nyigba blibo la katã dzi.
29 “There are to be seven years of great abundance in all the land of Egypt.
30 Ke eyome dɔ ato ƒe adre, eye woaŋlɔ nuɖuɖu si do agbogbo ɖe Egipte-nyigba dzi va yi la be keŋkeŋ, elabena dɔ si ato la agblẽ nu le anyigba la ŋu.
30 But seven years of famine will certainly arise after them, and all the abundance in the land of Egypt will certainly be forgotten, and the famine will exhaust the land.
31 Womagaɖo ŋku ale si nuɖuɖu bɔ ɖe anyigba la dzi va yi la dzi o, le dɔ si to ɖe eyome la ta, elabena enu asẽ ŋutɔ.
31 And the previous abundance in the land will not be remembered because of the famine afterward, for it will be very severe.
32 Eye esi Farao ku drɔ̃ea zi eve la, efia be Mawu vavã la ɖoe kplikpaa, eye Mawu vavã la le ewɔ ge kpuie.
32 The dream was given twice to Pharaoh because the matter has been firmly established by the true God, and the true God will soon carry it out.
33 “Eya ta Farao nedi ŋutsu dzeaɖaŋu nyanu aɖe ne wòatsɔe aɖo Egipte-nyigba la nu.
33 “So now let Pharaoh look for a man who is discreet and wise and place him over the land of Egypt.
34 Farao neɖo dzikpɔlawo ɖe anyigba la nu, eye wòaƒo agblemenuku siwo wɔ le Egipte-nyigba dzi la ƒe me mama ɖe atɔ̃ ƒe ɖeka nu ƒu le ƒe adre siwo me nuɖuɖu abɔ le la me.
34 Let Pharaoh take action and appoint overseers in the land, and he should collect one fifth of the produce of Egypt during the seven years of abundance.
35 Nena woaƒo nuɖuɖu siwo awɔ le ƒe nyui siawo siwo gbɔna me la nu ƒu, eye woaƒo nukuwo nu ƒu le Farao ƒe ŋusẽ te wòanye nuɖuɖu le duwo me, eye woadzra wo ɖo ɖe afi mawo.
35 And let them collect all the food during these coming good years, and let them stockpile grain under Pharaoh’s authority as food to be stored in the cities and safeguarded there.
36 Eye woazã nuɖuɖuawo le ƒe adre siwo dɔ ato le Egipte-nyigba dzi la me, ale be dɔtoto la nagatsrɔ̃ anyigba la o.”
36 The food should serve as a supply for the land for the seven years of famine that will occur in the land of Egypt, so that the land may not perish in the famine.”
37 Ke nya la dze Farao kple eŋumewo katã ŋu.
37 This proposal seemed good to Pharaoh and all his servants.

38 Eya ta Farao gblɔ na eŋumewo be: “Ðe woagate ŋu akpɔ ŋutsu bubu si le abe ame sia ene, si me Mawu ƒe gbɔgbɔ lea?” 39 Eye Farao gblɔ na Yosef be: “Esi Mawu na nènya nu siawo katã ta la, ame aɖeke meli si dze aɖaŋu henya nu de nuwò o.

38 So Pharaoh said to his servants: “Can another man be found like this one in whom there is the spirit of God?” 39 Pharaoh then said to Joseph: “Since God has caused you to know all of this, there is no one as discreet and wise as you.
40 Wòe anɔ nye aƒe la nu, eye nye dukɔ blibo la aɖo to wò le nu sia nu me.
40 You will personally be over my house, and all my people will obey you implicitly.

Negbe nye, fia la, koe anye gã wu wò.” 41 Eye Farao gagblɔ na Yosef be: “Kpɔ ɖa, metsɔ wò ɖo Egipte-nyigba blibo la katã nu.” 42 Farao ɖe eƒe ŋkɔsigɛ le asi tsɔ do na Yosef, eye wòdo aklala biɖibiɖi wu nɛ, eye wòtsɔ sikakɔsɔkɔsɔ de kɔ nɛ.

Only in my role as king will I be greater than you.” 41 And Pharaoh added to Joseph: “See, I am putting you over all the land of Egypt.” 42 Then Pharaoh removed his signet ring from his own hand and put it on Joseph’s hand and clothed him with garments of fine linen and placed a necklace of gold around his neck.
43 Azɔ hã, ena wòdo fia ƒe tasiaɖam evelia, eye wòna wonɔ ɣli dom le eŋgɔ be: “Avrek!”
43 Moreover, he had him ride in the second chariot of honor that he had, and they would call out ahead of him, “Avrékh!”
Ale wòtsɔe ɖo Egipte-nyigba blibo la katã nu.
Thus he put him over all the land of Egypt.

44 Eye Farao gagblɔ na Yosef be: “Nyee nye Farao, gake ne mèɖe mɔ o la, ame aɖeke mate ŋu awɔ naneke le Egipte-nyigba blibo la katã dzi o.” 45 Emegbe Farao na ŋkɔ Yosef be Zafenat-Panea, eye wòtsɔ On nunɔla Potifera ƒe vi Asenat nɛ wòɖe.

44 Pharaoh further said to Joseph: “I am Pharaoh, but without your authorization, no man may do a single thing in all the land of Egypt.” 45 After that Pharaoh gave Joseph the name Zaphenath-pAneah and gave him Asenath the daughter of Potiphera the priest of On as a wife.
Eye Yosef zu Egipte-nyigba la dzi kpɔla.
And Joseph began to oversee the land of Egypt.
46 Yosef xɔ ƒe blaetɔ̃ esime wòtsi tsitre ɖe Egipte-fia Farao ŋkume.
46 Joseph was 30 years old when he stood before Pharaoh king of Egypt.
Eye Yosef dzo le Farao ŋkume yi ɖatsa le Egipte-nyigba blibo la katã dzi.
Then Joseph went out from before Pharaoh and traveled throughout all the land of Egypt.
47 Anyigba la wɔ nu ŋutɔ le ƒe adre siwo me nuɖuɖu do agbogbo la me.
47 And during the seven years of abundance, the land went on producing plentifully.
48 Eye wònɔ agblemenuku siwo katã wɔ le ƒe adreawo me le Egipte-nyigba dzi la nu ƒom ƒu; eƒoa nuɖuɖuawo nu ƒu ɖe duawo me.
48 And he kept collecting all the food of the seven years from the land of Egypt, and he would stockpile the food in the cities.
Le du sia du me la, eƒoa nuku siwo katã wɔ le agble siwo ƒo xlãe me la nu ƒu ɖe dua me.
In each city he would store the food from the fields around it.
49 Eye Yosef nɔ kɔ lim nuku ɖi gleglegle, wosɔ gbɔ abe ƒutake ene, va se ɖe esime womegaxa dzidzea wo o, le esi womagate ŋu adzidze wo o ta.
49 Joseph continued stockpiling grain in very great quantity, like the sand of the sea, until finally they gave up measuring it because it could not be measured.
50 Hafi dɔŋɔliƒeawo nadze egɔme la, On nunɔla Potifera ƒe vi Asenat dzi viŋutsu eve na Yosef.
50 Before the year of the famine arrived, two sons were born to Joseph, whom Asenath the daughter of Potiphera the priest of On bore to him.

51 Yosef na ŋkɔ eƒe ŋgɔgbevi la be Manase, elabena egblɔ be: “Mawu na meŋlɔ nye fukpekpewo katã kple fofonye ƒe aƒe la katã be.” 52 Eye wòna ŋkɔ evelia be Efrayim, elabena egblɔ be: “Mawu na medzi ɖe edzi le anyigba si dzi mekpe fu le la dzi.”

51 Joseph named the firstborn Manasseh, for he said, “God has made me forget all my trouble and all the house of my father.” 52 And he named the second one Ephraim, for he said, “God has made me fruitful in the land of my affliction.”
53 Eye ƒe adre siwo me nuɖuɖu do agbogbo ɖe Egipte-nyigba dzi la va wu enu, 54 eye dɔŋɔliƒe adreawo dze egɔme, abe ale si tututu Yosef gblɔe ene.
53 Then the seven years of abundance in the land of Egypt ended, 54 and the seven years of famine began, just as Joseph had said.
Dɔ to le dukɔwo katã me, gake nuɖuɖu le Egipte-nyigba blibo la katã ya dzi.
The famine developed in all the lands, but in all the land of Egypt there was bread.
55 Mlɔeba dɔ va to le Egipte-nyigba blibo la hã dzi, eye dukɔ la de asi ɣlidodo me na Farao be wòana nuɖuɖu yewo.
55 Eventually, all the land of Egypt suffered from the famine, and the people began to cry to Pharaoh for bread.
Eye Farao gblɔ na Egiptetɔwo katã be: “Miyi Yosef gbɔ, eye nu sia nu si wòagblɔ na mi la, miwɔe.” 56 Eye dɔ to le anyigba blibo la katã dzi.
Then Pharaoh said to all the Egyptians: “Go to Joseph, and do whatever he tells you.” 56 The famine continued over all the surface of the earth.
Eye Yosef ʋu nuɖuɖudzraɖoƒeawo katã, eye wòdzraa nuɖuɖu na Egiptetɔwo, elabena dɔwuame la nu sẽ ɖe edzi le Egipte-nyigba dzi.
Then Joseph began to open up all the granaries that were among them and to sell to the Egyptians, as the famine had a strong grip on the land of Egypt.
57 Eye anyigbadzinɔlawo katã vaa Egipte be woaƒle nuɖuɖu le Yosef gbɔ, elabena dɔwuame la nu sẽ ŋutɔ le anyigba blibo la katã dzi.
57 Moreover, people of all the earth came to Egypt to buy from Joseph, because the famine had a strong grip on all the earth.
Ale Israel tsɔ nu siwo katã le esi la eye wòdze mɔ.
So Israel took all that he had and departed.
Esi wòva ɖo Beer-Seba la, esa vɔ na fofoa Isak ƒe Mawu la.
When he arrived at Beer-sheba, he offered sacrifices to the God of his father Isaac.
2 Eye Mawu yɔ Israel le ŋutega me le zã me be: “Yakob, Yakob!” Etɔ be: “Nyee nye esi!” 3 Eye wògblɔ nɛ be: “Nyee nye Mawu vavã la, fofowò ƒe Mawu la.
2 Then God spoke to Israel in a vision by night and said: “Jacob, Jacob!” to which he said: “Here I am!” 3 He said: “I am the true God, the God of your father.
Mègavɔ̃ Egipte yiyi o, elabena mana nàzu dukɔ gã aɖe le afi ma.
Do not be afraid to go down to Egypt, for there I will make you into a great nation.
4 Nye ŋutɔ mayi Egipte kpli wò, eye nye ŋutɔ magakplɔ wò tso afi ma agbɔe, eye Yosef ƒe asie amia wò ŋkuwo.”
4 I myself will go down with you to Egypt, and I myself will also bring you back from there, and Joseph will lay his hand on your eyes.”
5 Ema megbe Yakob dzo le Beer-Seba, eye Israel viŋutsuwo kɔ wo fofo Yakob kple wo viwo kpakple wo srɔ̃wo ɖe tasiaɖam siwo Farao ɖo ɖa be woatsɔ akɔ woe la me.
5 After that Jacob departed from Beer-sheba, and the sons of Israel transported Jacob their father and their children and their wives in the wagons that Pharaoh had sent to transport him.
6 Wokplɔ woƒe lãhawo hã, eye wotsɔ nu siwo su wo si le Kanaan-nyigba dzi la dzoe.
6 They took along their herds and their goods, which they had accumulated in the land of Canaan.
Ale Yakob kple viawo katã va Egipte.
And so they came into Egypt, Jacob and all his offspring with him.
7 Ekplɔ viaŋutsuwo kple eƒe tɔgbuiyɔviŋutsuwo kple vianyɔnuwo kple eƒe tɔgbuiyɔvinyɔnuwo yi Egipte; ekplɔ eƒe dzidzimeviwo katã yii.
7 He brought with him into Egypt his sons and his grandsons, his daughters and his granddaughters—all his offspring.
8 Ke Israel, si wogayɔna be Yakob, ƒe viŋutsu siwo va Egipte la ƒe ŋkɔwoe nye esi: Yakob ƒe ŋgɔgbevie nye Ruben.
8 Now these are the names of Israel’s sons who came into Egypt, Jacob and his sons: Jacob’s firstborn was Reuben.
9 Ruben viŋutsuwoe nye Hanok, Palu, Hezron kple Karmi.
9 The sons of Reuben were Hanoch, Pallu, Hezron, and Carmi.
10 Simeon viŋutsuwoe nye Yemuel, Yamin, Ohad, Yakin, Zohar, kple Saul, si Kanaan nyɔnu aɖe dzi.
10 The sons of Simeon were Jemuel, Jamin, Ohad, Jachin, Zohar, and Shaul the son of a Canaanite woman.
11 Lewi viŋutsuwoe nye Gerson, Kohat kple Merari.
11 The sons of Levi were Gershon, Kohath, and Merari.
12 Yuda viŋutsuwoe nye Er, Onan, Sela, Perez kple Zera.
12 The sons of Judah were Er, Onan, Shelah, Perez, and Zerah.
Ke Er kple Onan ku le Kanaan-nyigba dzi.
However, Er and Onan died in the land of Canaan.
Perez viŋutsuwoe nye Hezron kple Hamul.
The sons of Perez came to be Hezron and Hamul.
13 Isakar viŋutsuwoe nye Tola, Puwa, Yob kple Simron.
13 The sons of Issachar were Tola, Puvah, Iob, and Shimron.
14 Zebulon viŋutsuwoe nye Sered, Elon kple Yahlel.
14 The sons of Zebulun were Sered, Elon, and Jahleel.
15 Ame siawoe nye Lea viŋutsu siwo wòdzi na Yakob le Padan-Aram hekpe ɖe vianyɔnu Dina ŋu.
15 These are the sons of Leah, whom she bore to Jacob in Paddanaram, together with his daughter Dinah.
Viaŋutsuwo kple vianyɔnuwo katã le blaetɔ̃ vɔ etɔ̃.
All his sons and his daughters numbered 33.
16 Gad viŋutsuwoe nye Zifion, Hagi, Suni, Ezbon, Eri, Arodi kple Areli.
16 The sons of Gad were Ziphion, Haggi, Shuni, Ezbon, Eri, Arodi, and Areli.
17 Aser viŋutsuwoe nye Yimna, Yiswa, Yiswi, kple Beria, kpakple wo nɔvinyɔnu Sera.
17 The sons of Asher were Imnah, Ishvah, Ishvi, and Beriah, and their sister was Serah.
Beria viŋutsuwoe nye Heber kple Malkiel.
The sons of Beriah were Heber and Malchiel.
18 Ame siawoe nye Zilpa, si Laban tsɔ na via Lea la, ƒe viŋutsuwo.
18 These are the sons of Zilpah, whom Laban gave to his daughter Leah.
Ame siawoe wòdzi na Yakob: wole ame wuiade.
She bore these to Jacob: 16 persons in all.
19 Yakob srɔ̃ Rahel viŋutsuwoe nye Yosef kple Benyamin.
19 The sons of Jacob’s wife Rachel were Joseph and Benjamin.
20 Wodzi Manase kple Efrayim na Yosef le Egipte-nyigba dzi; ame siawoe On nunɔla Potifera ƒe vi Asenat dzi nɛ.
20 There were born to Joseph in the land of Egypt Manasseh and Ephraim, whom Asenath the daughter of Potiphera the priest of On bore to him.
21 Benyamin viŋutsuwoe nye Bela, Beker, Asbel, Gera, Naaman, Ehi, Ros, Mupim, Hupim kple Ard.
21 The sons of Benjamin were Bela, Becher, Ashbel, Gera, Naaman, Ehi, Rosh, Muppim, Huppim, and Ard.
22 Esiawoe nye viŋutsu siwo Rahel dzi na Yakob: wo katã le ame wuiene.
22 These are the sons of Rachel who were born to Jacob: 14 persons in all.
23 Dan viŋutsue nye Husim.
23 The son of Dan was Hushim.
24 Naftali viŋutsuwoe nye Yahzel, Guni, Yezer, kple Silem.
24 The sons of Naphtali were Jahzeel, Guni, Jezer, and Shillem.
25 Ame siawoe nye Bilha, si Laban tsɔ na via Rahel la, ƒe viŋutsuwo.
25 These are the sons of Bilhah, whom Laban gave to his daughter Rachel.
Ame siawoe wòdzi na Yakob: wo katã le ame adre.
She bore these to Jacob: seven persons in all.
26 Ame siwo katã wodzi na Yakob, siwo katã ʋu kplii yi Egipte, ne woɖe viaŋutsuwo srɔ̃wo le eme la, le blaade vɔ ade.
26 All those who descended from Jacob and went into Egypt with him, aside from the wives of Jacob’s sons, were 66.
27 Viŋutsu siwo wodzi na Yosef le Egipte la le ame eve.
27 Joseph’s sons who were born to him in Egypt were two.
Ame siwo katã tso Yakob ƒe me va Egipte la le blaadre.
All the people of the house of Jacob who came into Egypt were 70.
28 Yakob dɔ Yuda ɖe eŋgɔ ɖe Yosef gbɔ, be wòagblɔ nɛ be yele mɔ dzi ɖo ta Gosen.
28 Jacob sent Judah ahead to tell Joseph that he was on the way to GOshen.
Esi wova ɖo Gosen-nyigba dzi la, 29 Yosef na wodzra eƒe tasiaɖam ɖo, eye wòyi ɖado go fofoa Israel le Gosen.
When they came into the land of GOshen, 29 Joseph had his chariot prepared and went up to meet Israel his father at GOshen.
Esi wòkpɔe la, enumake ekpla asi kɔ nɛ hefa avi ʋuu.
When he presented himself to him, he at once embraced him and wept for some time.
30 Eye Israel gblɔ na Yosef be: “Azɔ mate ŋu aku faa; mekpɔ wò ŋkume, eye menya be ègale agbe.”
30 Then Israel said to Joseph: “Now I am ready to die; I have seen your face and know that you are still alive.”
31 Eye Yosef gblɔ na nɔviawo kple fofoa ƒemetɔwo be: “Mina mayi Farao gbɔ aɖagblɔ nɛ be, ‘Nɔvinyewo kple fofonye ƒemetɔ siwo le Kanaan-nyigba dzi la va gbɔnye afi sia.

31 Joseph then said to his brothers and to his father’s household: “Let me go up and report to Pharaoh and tell him, ‘My brothers and my father’s household who were in the land of Canaan have come here to me.

32 Lãnyilawoe ame siawo nye, eye lãhawo le wo si; wova kple woƒe alẽhawo kple nyihawo kpakple nu siwo katã le wo si.’ 33 Ne Farao yɔ mi eye wòbia mi be, ‘Dɔ ka wɔlawo mienye?’ hã la, 34 migblɔ be, ‘Lãnyilawoe wò dɔlawo nye tso míaƒe ɖevime, mía kple mía tɔgbuiwo siaa,’ ale be mianɔ Gosen-nyigba la dzi, elabena Egiptetɔwo nyɔa ŋu alẽkplɔlawo.”

32 The men are shepherds, and they raise livestock, and they have brought their flocks and their herds and all that they have.’ 33 When Pharaoh calls you and asks, ‘What is your occupation?’ 34 you must say, ‘Your servants have raised livestock from our youth until now, both we and our forefathers,’ so that you may dwell in the land of GOshen, for every herder of sheep is detestable to the Egyptians.”

Esi Rahel kpɔe be yemedzi vi aɖeke na Yakob o la, eʋã ŋu nɔvianyɔnua, eye wògblɔ na Yakob be: “Na vim, ne menye nenema o la, maku.” 2 Ale Yakob do dziku ɖe Rahel ŋu vevie eye wògblɔ be: “Nyee nye Mawu, ame si mena vi wò nèdzi oa?” 3 Eya ta egblɔ be: “Nye kosi Bilha ye nye esi.

When Rachel saw that she had borne no children to Jacob, she became jealous of her sister and began to say to Jacob: “Give me children or else I will die.” 2 At this Jacob’s anger flared up against Rachel, and he said: “Am I in the place of God, who has prevented you from having children?” 3 So she said: “Here is my slave girl Bilhah.
Dɔ kplii, ne wòadzi vi nam, ale be vi nasu nye hã asinye to edzi.” 4 Eye wòtsɔ eƒe kosi Bilha nɛ wòɖe, eye Yakob dɔ kplii.

Have relations with her in order that she may bear children for me and that through her, I too may have children.” 4 With that she gave him her servant Bilhah as a wife, and Jacob had relations with her.
5 Bilha fɔ fu, eye wòdzi ŋutsuvi na Yakob.
5 Bilhah became pregnant and in time bore Jacob a son.
6 Eye Rahel gblɔ be: “Mawu drɔ̃ nye nya nam, eye wòse nye gbe hã, ale be wòna viŋutsuvim.”
6 Then Rachel said: “God has acted as my judge and has also listened to my voice, so that he gave me a son.”
Esia tae wòna ŋkɔe be Dan.
That is why she named him Dan.
7 Eye Rahel ƒe kosi Bilha gafɔ fu ake, eye wòdzi viŋutsuvi evelia na Yakob.
7 Bilhah, Rachel’s servant, became pregnant once more and in time bore Jacob a second son.
8 Eye Rahel gblɔ be: “Ʋiʋli sesẽe meʋli kple nɔvinyenyɔnua.
8 Then Rachel said: “With strenuous wrestlings I have wrestled with my sister.
Meɖu dzi hã!”
I have also come off the winner!”
Eya ta ena ŋkɔe be Naftali.
So she named him Naphtali.
9 Esi Lea kpɔ be yemegale vi dzim o la, etsɔ eƒe kosi Zilpa na Yakob wòɖe.
9 When Leah saw that she had stopped having children, she took her servant Zilpah and gave her to Jacob as a wife.
10 Eye Lea ƒe kosi Zilpa dzi viŋutsuvi na Yakob.
10 And Leah’s servant Zilpah bore a son to Jacob.
11 Eye Lea gblɔ be: “Eme nyo nam!”
11 Then Leah said: “With good fortune!”
Eya ta ena ŋkɔe be Gad.
So she named him Gad.
12 Emegbe Lea ƒe kosi Zilpa dzi viŋutsuvi evelia na Yakob.
12 After that Zilpah, Leah’s servant, bore a second son to Jacob.
13 Eye Lea gblɔ be: “Dzidzɔ ka gbegbee nye esi!
13 Then Leah said: “With my happiness!
Elabena nyɔnuwo ayɔm be dzidzɔtɔ.”
For the daughters will certainly pronounce me happy.”
Eya ta ena ŋkɔe be Aser.
So she named him Asher.
14 Ke Ruben nɔ tsa ɖim le luxaɣi eye wòkpɔ agbitsawo le gbe me.
14 Now Reuben was walking in the days of the wheat harvest, and he found mandrakes in the field.
Egbe wo tsɔ vɛ na dadaa Lea.
So he brought them to his mother Leah.
Eye Rahel gblɔ na Lea be: “Meɖe kuku, na viwò ƒe agbitsa ƒe ɖem.” 15 Eye Lea gblɔ nɛ be: “Nu tsɛ wònye be nèxɔ srɔ̃nye tso, eye nègale didim be yeaxɔ vinye ƒe agbitsawo hã?”
Then Rachel said to Leah: “Give me, please, some of your son’s mandrakes.” 15 At this she said to her: “Is it a small matter that you took my husband? Would you now take my son’s mandrakes also?”
Eya ta Rahel gblɔ be: “Enyo.
So Rachel said: “Very well.
Gbɔwòe wòamlɔ zã sia ɖe viwò ƒe agbitsawo nu.”
He will lie down with you tonight in exchange for your son’s mandrakes.”
16 Esi Yakob tso agble gbɔna le fiẽ me la, Lea do go yi ɖakpee gblɔ be: “Gbɔnye dɔ gee nèle, elabena metsɔ vinye ƒe agbitsawo xe fe ɖe tawò.”
16 When Jacob was coming from the field in the evening, Leah went out to meet him and said: “It is with me you are going to have relations, because I have hired you outright with my son’s mandrakes.”
Ale wòdɔ egbɔ zã ma.
So he lay down with her that night.
17 Eye Mawu tɔ na Lea, eye wòfɔ fu dzi viŋutsuvi atɔ̃lia na Yakob.
17 And God heard and answered Leah, and she became pregnant and in time bore to Jacob a fifth son.
18 Eye Lea gblɔ be: “Mawu ɖo eteƒe nam, elabena metsɔ nye kosi na srɔ̃nye.”
18 Then Leah said: “God has given me my wages because I have given my servant to my husband.”
Eya ta ena ŋkɔe be Isakar.
So she named him Issachar.
19 Eye Lea gafɔ fu, eye wòdzi ŋutsuvi adelia na Yakob.
19 And Leah became pregnant once more and in time bore a sixth son to Jacob.
20 Eye Lea gblɔ be: “Mawu na num, ɛ̃, ena nu nyui aɖem.
20 Then Leah said: “God has endowed me, yes, me, with a good endowment.
Srɔ̃nye alɔ̃ nye nya azɔ, elabena medzi viŋutsu ade nɛ.”
At last, my husband will tolerate me, for I have borne him six sons.”
Eya ta ena ŋkɔe be Zebulon.
So she named him Zebulun.
21 Emegbe edzi nyɔnuvi, eye wòna ŋkɔe be Dina.
21 Afterward she bore a daughter and named her Dinah.
22 Mlɔeba Mawu ɖo ŋku Rahel dzi, eye Mawu tɔ nɛ eye wòna wòfɔ fu.
22 Finally God remembered Rachel, and God heard and answered her by enabling her to become pregnant.
23 Efɔ fu dzi viŋutsuvi.
23 And she became pregnant and gave birth to a son.
Eye wògblɔ be: “Mawu ɖe nye ŋukpe ɖa!” 24 Eya ta ena ŋkɔe be Yosef eye wògblɔ be: “Yehowa tsɔ ŋutsuvi bubu kpee nam.”
Then she said: “God has taken away my reproach!” 24 So she named him Joseph, saying: “Jehovah is adding another son to me.”
25 Esi Rahel dzi Yosef megbe la, Yakob gblɔ na Laban be: “Do mɔm, ne mayi nɔnyeƒe kple nye anyigba dzi.
25 After Rachel had given birth to Joseph, Jacob immediately said to Laban: “Send me away so that I may go to my place and to my land.

26 Tsɔ srɔ̃nyewo kple vinyewo, ame siwo ta mesubɔ wò ɖo la, nam ne madzo, elabena wò ŋutɔ ènya ale si mesubɔ wòe la nyuie.” 27 Eye Laban gblɔ nɛ be: “Ve nunye dzro! Dzesiawo na mekpɔe be tawòe Yehowa le yrayem ɖo.” 28 Eye wògblɔ kpee be: “Gblɔ fetu si nàxɔ la nam, ne mana wò.” 29 Eye Yakob gblɔ nɛ be: “Wò ŋutɔ ènya ale si mesubɔ wòe, kple ale si wò lãhawo le dedie le gbɔnye; 30 nu sue aɖe koe nɔ asiwò hafi meva, ke wò lãhawo dzi ɖe edzi va sɔ gbɔ taŋtaŋ, eye Yehowa le yrawòm tso esime meva gbɔwò.

26 Give over my wives and my children, for whom I have served with you, that I may go, for you well know how I have served you.” 27 Then Laban said to him: “If I have found favor in your eyes,—I have understood by the omens that Jehovah is blessing me because of you.” 28 And he added: “Stipulate your wages to me, and I will give them.” 29 So Jacob said to him: “You know how I have served you and how your herd has fared with me; 30 you had little before my coming, but your herd has increased and multiplied, and Jehovah has blessed you since I arrived.
Ke ɣekaɣie nye ŋutɔ mawɔ nane na nye ƒomea?”
So when will I do something for my own house?”
31 Eye wògblɔ be: “Nu kae mana wò?”
31 Then he said: “What should I give you?”
Yakob ɖo eŋu be: “Nyemaxɔ naneke o!
And Jacob said: “You will give me nothing whatsoever!
Ke ne àwɔ nu ɖeka sia ko nam la, ekema mayi edzi akplɔ wò lãha la ahakpɔ wo ta.
If you will do this one thing for me, I will resume shepherding your flock and guarding it.
32 Matsa le wò lãha blibo la dome egbea.
32 I will pass through your whole flock today.
Ðe alẽ siwo katã le ŋɔtaŋɔta alo tso kpɔ, alẽtsuiawo dometɔ siwo katã nyɔ, kple gbɔ̃nɔawo dometɔ siwo katã le ŋɔtaŋɔta alo tso kpɔ la ɖe vovo.
You set aside from there every sheep speckled and with color patches and every dark-brown sheep among the young rams and any color-patched and speckled one among the she-goats.
Esiawoe anye nye fetu tso fifia.
From now on, these must become my wages.
33 Eye gbe si gbe nàva be yealé ŋku ɖe nye fetua ŋu la, nye anukwareɖiɖi adze ƒãa; ne èkpɔ gbɔ̃nɔ aɖe si mele ŋɔtaŋɔta alo tso kpɔ o, alo alẽtsui aɖe si menyɔ o le gbɔnye la, ekema ɖe mefii.”

33 And my righteousness must speak for me on a future day when you come to look over my wages; every one that is not speckled and color-patched among the she-goats and dark brown among the young rams will be considered stolen if it is with me.”
34 Laban ɖo eŋu be: “Enyo!
34 To this Laban said: “That is fine!

Nenɔ abe ale si nègblɔe ene.” 35 Eye Laban ɖe gbɔ̃tsu siwo ŋu fli le alo tso kpɔ, gbɔ̃nɔ siwo katã le ŋɔtaŋɔta alo tso kpɔ, kple alẽtsui siwo katã ŋu fli ɣi le kple esiwo katã nyɔ la ɖe vovo le ŋkeke ma dzi, eye wòtsɔ wo de viaŋutsuwo si.

Let it be according to your word.” 35 Then on that day, he set aside the he-goats striped and color-patched and all the she-goats speckled and color-patched, every one in which there was any white and every one dark brown among the young rams, and gave them into the care of his sons.
36 Emegbe ena wokplɔ eƒe lãhawo yi teƒe didi aɖe si anɔ ŋkeke etɔ̃ ƒe mɔzɔzɔ tso Yakob gbɔ, eye Yakob nɔ Laban ƒe lãha siwo susɔ la kplɔm.
36 After that he set a distance of three days’ journey between himself and Jacob, and Jacob was shepherding the flocks of Laban that remained over.
37 Eye Yakob tsɔ storax-ti kple yevuziti kpakple armon-ti mumuwo wɔ kpowo, eye wòɖe tsro le kpoawo ƒe teƒe aɖewo ŋu be woƒe teƒe siwo le ɣie la nadze.
37 Jacob then took freshly cut staffs of the storax, almond, and plane trees, and he peeled white spots in them by exposing the white wood of the staffs.
38 Eye wòtsɔ kpo siawo siwo ŋu wòɖe tsro le la da ɖe tsiʋe siwo me lãhawo noa tsi le la me le lãawo ŋgɔ, ale be woayɔ asi le wo ŋgɔ ne wova tsi no ge.

38 Then he placed the staffs that he had peeled in front of the flock, in the gutters, in the drinking troughs, where the flocks would come to drink, that they might get into heat in front of them when they came to drink.
39 Eya ta lãhawo yɔa asi le kpoawo ŋgɔ, eye lãhawo dzia vi siwo ŋu fli le, esiwo le ŋɔtaŋɔta, kple esiwo tso kpɔ.
39 So the flocks would get into heat in front of the staffs, and the flocks would produce striped, speckled, and color-patched offspring.
40 Eye Yakob ɖe alẽtsuiawo ɖe vovo, eye wòna Laban ƒe lãhawo dze ŋgɔ lã siwo ŋu fli le kple esiwo katã nyɔ la.
40 Then Jacob separated the young rams and turned the flocks to face the striped ones and all the dark-brown ones among the flocks of Laban.
Azɔ enɔ eya ŋutɔ ƒe lãhawo ɖem ɖe vovo, eye metsɔa wo kpena ɖe Laban ƒe lãhawo ŋu o.
Then he separated his own flocks and did not mix them with Laban’s flocks.
41 Eye ɣesiaɣi si lã sesẽwo le asi yɔm la, Yakob tsɔa kpoawo dana ɖe tsiʋeawo me le lãhawo ŋgɔ, eye woyɔa asi le kpoawo gbɔ.
41 And whenever the robust animals would get into heat, Jacob would place the staffs in the gutters before the eyes of the flocks, that they might get into heat by the staffs.
42 Ke ne lã beliwoe la, metsɔa kpoawo dana ɖe afi ma o.
42 But when the animals were weak, he would not place the staffs there.
Ale lã beliawo katã zua Laban tɔ ɣesiaɣi, ke lã sesẽawo ya nyea Yakob tɔ.
So the weak ones always came to be Laban’s, but the robust ones became Jacob’s.
43 Eye nuwo nɔ edzi dzem na Yakob, eye lãha gbogbowo, subɔvinyɔnuwo, subɔviŋutsuwo, kposɔwo kple tedziwo va su esi.
43 And the man grew very prosperous, and he acquired great flocks and male and female servants and camels and donkeys.
Ke Abram srɔ̃ Sarai medzi vi aɖeke nɛ o, gake kosi aɖe le Sarai si, si nye Egiptetɔ, eŋkɔe nye Hagar.
Now Abram’s wife Sarai had borne him no children, but she had an Egyptian servant whose name was HAgar.
2 Eya ta Sarai gblɔ na Abram be: “Yehowa xe nye vidzidɔ.
2 So Sarai said to Abram: “Please now! Jehovah has prevented me from bearing children.
Meɖe kuku, dɔ kple nye kosi la.
Please, have relations with my servant.
Ðewohĩ adzi viwo nam.”
