Perhaps I can have children by means of her.”
Eya ta Abram ɖo to Sarai ƒe gbe.
So Abram listened to what Sarai said.
3 Esi Abram nɔ Kanaan-nyigba dzi ƒe ewo megbe la, Abram srɔ̃ Sarai tsɔ eƒe kosi Egiptetɔ Hagar na srɔ̃a wòɖe.
3 After Abram had lived for ten years in the land of Canaan, Abram’s wife Sarai took her Egyptian servant HAgar and gave her to her husband Abram as his wife.
4 Ale Abram dɔ kple Hagar eye wòfɔ fu.
4 So he had relations with HAgar, and she became pregnant.
Ke esi wòkpɔ be yefɔ fu ko la, megabua eƒe aƒenɔ ɖe ɖeke me o.
When she realized that she was pregnant, she began to despise her mistress.
5 Eye Sarai gblɔ na Abram be: “Vevesese si dom wole nam la tso gbɔwò.
5 At this Sarai said to Abram: “The injury done to me is your fault.
Nye ŋutɔe ɖe asi le nye kosi la ŋu na wò, ke esi wòkpɔ be yefɔ fu ko la, megabuam ɖe ɖeke me o.
I was the one who put my servant in your arms, but when she realized that she was pregnant, she began to despise me.
Yehowa nadrɔ̃e le nye kpli wò dome.” 6 Eye Abram gblɔ na Sarai be: “Kpɔ ɖa!
May Jehovah judge between me and you.” 6 So Abram said to Sarai: “Look!
Wò kosi la le asiwò me.
Your servant is under your authority.
Wɔ nu si nyo ŋuwò la ɖe eŋu.”
Do to her whatever you think is best.”
Ale Sarai bɔbɔe ɖe anyi, eye kosi la si le egbɔ.
Then Sarai humiliated her, and she ran away from her.
7 Emegbe Yehowa ƒe dɔla kpɔe le vudo aɖe si le gbedzi le Sur mɔ dzi la to.
7 Later Jehovah’s angel found her at a spring of waters in the wilderness, the spring on the way to Shur.
8 Eye wòbiae be: “Sarai ƒe kosi Hagar, afi kae nètso, eye afi ka yim nèle?”
8 And he said: “HAgar, servant of Sarai, where have you come from and where are you going?”

Eɖo eŋu be: “Nye aƒenɔ Sarai nue mele sisim le.” 9 Eye Yehowa ƒe dɔla la gblɔ nɛ be: “Trɔ yi wò aƒenɔ la gbɔ, eye nàbɔbɔ ɖokuiwò ɖe ete.” 10 Yehowa ƒe dɔla la gagblɔ nɛ be: “Mana wò dzidzimeviwo nasɔ gbɔ kpaŋkpaŋ, woasɔ gbɔ ale gbegbe be womate ŋu axlẽ wo o.” 11 Yehowa ƒe dɔla la gblɔ kpee be: “Kpɔ ɖa! Èfɔ fu, àdzi ŋutsuvi, eye nàna ŋkɔe be Ismael; elabena Yehowa se konyi si fam nèle le wò fukpekpe la ŋuti.

To this she said: “I am running away from my mistress Sarai.” 9 Jehovah’s angel then said to her: “Return to your mistress and humble yourself under her hand.” 10 Then Jehovah’s angel said: “I will greatly multiply your offspring, so that they will be too numerous to count.” 11 Jehovah’s angel added: “Here you are pregnant, and you will give birth to a son, and you must name him Ishmael, for Jehovah has heard your affliction.
12 Ŋutsuvi la anɔ abe gbetedzi ene.
12 He will be a wild donkey of a man.
Akɔ asi dzi ɖe ame sia ame ŋu, eye ame sia ame akɔ asi dzi ɖe eya hã ŋu; eye wòanɔ teƒe si dze ŋgɔ nɔviawo katã.”
His hand will be against everyone, and everyone’s hand will be against him, and he will dwell opposite all his brothers.”
13 Eye wòyɔ Yehowa, Ame si le nu ƒom nɛ la, ƒe ŋkɔ gblɔ be: “Mawu si kpɔa nue nènye,” elabena egblɔ be: “Ame si le kpɔyem lae mekpɔ le afi sia?” 14 Esia tae woyɔ vudo la be Beer-Lahai-Roi.

13 Then she called on the name of Jehovah, who was speaking to her: “You are a God of sight,” for she said: “Have I here actually looked upon the one who sees me?” 14 That is why the well was called Beer-lAhai-roi.
(Ele Kades kple Bered dome.) 15 Eye Hagar dzi ŋutsuvi na Abram, eye Abram na ŋkɔ vi si Hagar dzi la be Ismael.
(It is between KAdesh and Bered.) 15 So HAgar bore to Abram a son, and Abram named his son, whom HAgar bore, Ishmael.
16 Abram xɔ ƒe blaenyi vɔ ade esime Hagar dzi Ismael nɛ.
16 Abram was 86 years old when HAgar bore Ishmael to him.
“Mèganɔ alakpanya kakam o.
“You must not spread a report that is not true.
Mègawɔ ɖeka kple ame vlo ahanye ɖasefo vɔ̃ɖi ɖe hawòvi ŋu o.
Do not cooperate with a wicked one by becoming a malicious witness.
2 Mègadze amehawo yome le nu vɔ̃ɖi wɔwɔ me o, eye mègatrɔ gbo nya dzɔdzɔe to ɖaseɖiɖi atsɔ ade amehawo ƒe nya dzi me o.
2 You must not follow after the crowd to do evil, and you must not pervert justice by giving testimony to go along with the crowd.
3 Mègade ame dahe dzi le nyaʋiʋli me o.
3 You must show impartiality in the dispute of a poor person.
4 “Ne èkpɔ wò futɔ ƒe nyi alo eƒe tedzi wòtra mɔ la, kplɔe yi nɛ.
4 “If you come upon your enemy’s bull or his donkey straying, you must return it to him.
5 Ne agba nɔ wò futɔ ƒe tedzi dzi wòtsi anyigba nèkpɔ la, mègato eŋu yi o.
5 If you see that the donkey of someone who hates you has fallen under its load, you must not ignore it and leave.
Kpe ɖe eŋu miatu agbaa le lãa dzi.
You must help him release the animal.
6 “Mègatrɔ gbo ame dahe si le dowòme la ƒe nya dzɔdzɔe le ʋɔnu o.
6 “You are not to pervert the judgment of the poor one among you in his legal case.
7 “Mègakpɔ gome le aʋatsonutsotso me o, eye mègawu ame maɖifɔ kple ame dzɔdzɔe o, elabena nyematso afia na ame vɔ̃ɖi be etɔ dzɔ o.
7 “Have nothing to do with a false accusation, and do not kill the innocent and the righteous, for I will not declare the wicked one righteous.
8 “Mègaxɔ zãnu o, elabena zãnu ɖe wògbãa ŋku na ame siwo kpɔa nu nyuie gɔ̃ hã, eye wòtea ŋu trɔa gbo ame dzɔdzɔe ƒe nya.
8 “You must not accept a bribe, for the bribe blinds clear-sighted men and can distort the words of righteous men.
9 “Mègate amedzro ɖe anyi o.
9 “You must not oppress a foreign resident.
Mienya ale si wònɔna na amedzrowo, elabena mienye amedzrowo kpɔ le Egipte-nyigba dzi.
You know how it feels to be a foreigner, because you were foreign residents in the land of Egypt.
10 “Ƒe ade nàƒã nu ɖe wò anyigba dzi, eye nàƒo wò agblemenuwo nu ƒu.
10 “You are to sow your land with seed and gather its produce for six years.
11 Ke mègade agble ɖe edzi le ƒe adrelia me o, ke boŋ na wòagbɔ ɖe eme, eye wò dukɔ la ƒe ame dahewo naɖu edzinuwo, eye nu siwo woawo hã gblẽ ɖi la, gbemelãwo naɖui.
11 But the seventh year you should leave it uncultivated and let it lie fallow, and the poor among your people will eat of it, and what they leave, the wild animals of the field will eat.
Aleae nàwɔ wò waingble kple wò amitibɔwo hã.
That is what you should do with your vineyard and your olive grove.
12 “Ŋkeke ade nàwɔ wò dɔ; ke mègawɔ dɔ le ŋkeke adrelia dzi o, ale be wò nyi kple wò tedzi naɖi ɖe eme, eye wò kosi ƒe viŋutsu kple amedzro la nagbɔ ɖe eme.

12 “Six days you are to do your work; but on the seventh day, you are to cease from your labor, in order that your bull and your donkey may rest and the son of your slave girl and the foreign resident may refresh themselves.
13 “Mikpɔ egbɔ be miewɔ nya siwo katã megblɔ na mi la dzi, eye migayɔ mawu bubuwo ŋkɔ o; woagase wo ŋkɔ le mia nu o.
13 “You must be careful to do all that I have said to you, and you must not mention the names of other gods; they should not be heard on your lips.
14 “Zi etɔ̃ nàɖu ŋkekenyui nam le ƒe ɖeka me.
14 “Three times a year you are to celebrate a festival to me.
15 Nàɖu Amɔwɔ Maʋamaʋã Bolo Ŋkekenyui.
15 You will observe the Festival of Unleavened Bread.
Ðui ŋkeke adre le ɣeyiɣi ɖoɖi la dzi le ɣleti Abib me, abe ale si tututu mede se na wò ene, elabena ɣemaɣie nèʋu tso Egipte.
You will eat unleavened bread for seven days, just as I have commanded you, at the appointed time in the month of Abib, for at that time you came out of Egypt.
Ame aɖeke megado ɖe ŋkunyeme asi gbɔlo o.
No one is to appear before me empty-handed.
16 Eye nàɖu Nuŋeŋeŋkekenyui; si nye nu siwo nèƒã ɖe agble me la ƒe kutsetse gbãtɔwo, eye ne èƒo nu siwo nèƒã ɖe wò agble me la nu ƒu le ƒea ƒe nuwuwu la, ekema nàɖu Nukuƒoƒoƒu Ŋkekenyui hã.

16 Also, you are to observe the Festival of Harvest of the first ripe fruits of your labors, of what you sow in the field; and the Festival of Ingathering at the end of the year, when you gather in from the field the results of your labors.
17 Wò ŋutsuwo katã nado ɖe Aƒetɔ vavã, Yehowa, ŋkume zi etɔ̃ ƒe sia ƒe.
17 Three times a year all your men are to appear before the true Lord, Jehovah.
18 “Mègatsɔ nu ʋaʋã kpe ɖe nye vɔsalã ƒe ʋu ŋu asa vɔe o.
18 “You must not offer the blood of my sacrifice with anything leavened.
Eye vɔsalã ƒe ami si wotsɔ saa vɔ le nye ŋkekenyuiwo dzi la megatsi anyi ŋu nake ɖe edzi o.
And the sacrifices of fat offered at my festivals should not stay overnight until the morning.
19 “Tsɔ wò anyigbadzikutsetse gbãtɔwo ƒe nyuitɔwo va Yehowa wò Mawu ƒe me.
19 “You are to bring the best of the first ripe fruits of your ground to the house of Jehovah your God.
“Mègaɖa gbɔ̃vi le dadaa ƒe notsi me o.
“You must not boil a young goat in its mother’s milk.
20 “Mele mawudɔla aɖe dɔm ɖe ŋgɔwò, be wòadzɔ ŋuwò le mɔa dzi, eye wòakplɔ wò ava teƒe si medzra ɖo la.
20 “I am sending an angel ahead of you to guard you on the way and to bring you into the place that I have prepared.
21 Ðo toe, eye nàwɔ eƒe gbe dzi.
21 Pay attention to him, and obey his voice.
Mègadze aglã ɖe eŋu o, elabena matsɔ miaƒe vodadawo ake mi o, elabena nye ŋkɔ le eya amea ŋu.
Do not rebel against him, for he will not pardon your transgressions, because my name is in him.
22 Ne èwɔ eƒe gbe dzi pɛpɛpɛ, eye nèwɔ nu siwo katã megblɔ la, ekema malé fu wò ketɔwo, eye matsi tsitre ɖe ame siwo tsia tsitre ɖe ŋuwò la ŋu.
22 However, if you strictly obey his voice and do all that I say, I will show hostility to your enemies and oppose those who oppose you.
23 Elabena nye dɔla adze ŋgɔwò, eye wòakplɔ wò ayi Amoritɔwo, Hititɔwo, Perizitɔwo, Kanaantɔwo, Hivitɔwo kple Yebusitɔwo ƒe anyigba dzi, eye matsrɔ̃ wo keŋkeŋ.
23 For my angel will go ahead of you and will bring you to the Amorites, the Hittites, the Perizzites, the Canaanites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites, and I will annihilate them.
24 Mègade ta agu na woƒe mawuwo alo asubɔ wo o, eye mègasrɔ̃ woƒe nuwɔnawo o.
24 You must not bow down to their gods or be persuaded to serve them, and you must not imitate their practices.
Ke boŋ nàgblẽ wo, eye nàkaka woƒe trɔ̃sɔtiwo.
Instead, you must demolish them and smash their sacred pillars.
25 Misubɔ Yehowa mia Mawu la, ekema ayra wò abolo kple wò tsi.
25 You must serve Jehovah your God, and he will bless your bread and your water.
Maɖe dɔlélewo ɖa le dowòme.
I will remove sickness from among you.
26 Fu mage le nyɔnuwo ƒo alo woatsi ko le wò anyigba dzi o. Mana nànɔ agbe wòade edeƒe.
26 The women in your land will not suffer a miscarriage or be barren, and I will give you a full life span.
27 “Mana vɔvɔ̃ si le ŋunye la nadze ŋgɔwò, made tɔtɔ dukɔ siwo katã nàkpe kplii la dome, eye mana wò futɔwo katã nasi le nuwò.
27 “I will send the fear of me ahead of you, and I will throw into confusion all the people you encounter, and I will cause all your enemies to flee from you in defeat.
28 Madɔ dziɖeleameƒo ɖe ŋgɔwò; eye wòanya Hivitɔwo, Kanaantɔwo kple Hititɔwo ɖa le ŋgɔwò.
28 I will send the feeling of dejection ahead of you, and it will drive the Hivites, the Canaanites, and the Hittites out from before you.
29 Nyemanya wo ɖa le ŋgɔwò le ƒe ɖeka me o, ne anyigba la nagaɖi gbɔlo, eye lã wɔadãwo nadzi ɖe edzi awɔ nu vevi wò o.
29 I will not drive them out from before you in one year, so that the land does not become desolate and the wild animals of the field multiply against you.
30 Manya wo ɖa le ŋgɔwò vivivi, va se ɖe esime nàdzi ɖe edzi asɔ gbɔ ahaxɔ anyigba la wòazu tɔwò.
30 Little by little I will drive them out from before you, until you become fruitful and take possession of the land.
31 “Mana wò liƒo natso Ƒudzĩ la nu va se ɖe Filistitɔwo ƒe ƒu la nu, tso gbea dzi va se ɖe Tɔsisi la nu; elabena matsɔ anyigba la dzi nɔlawo ade asi na mi, eye ànya wo ɖa le ŋgɔwò.

31 “I will set your boundary from the Red Sea to the sea of the Philistines and from the wilderness to the River; for I will give the inhabitants of the land into your hand, and you will drive them out from before you.
32 Mègabla nu kple woawo ŋutɔwo loo alo woƒe mawuwo o.
32 You must not make a covenant with them or their gods.
33 Womeganɔ wò anyigba dzi o, be woagana nàwɔ nu vɔ̃ ɖe ŋunye o.
33 They should not dwell in your land, so that they may not cause you to sin against me.
Ne èsubɔ woƒe mawuwo la, azu mɔ̃ aɖe wò.”
If you should serve their gods, it would surely become a snare to you.”

“Nu si nàwɔ atsɔ akɔ wo ŋu ne woazu nunɔlawo asubɔm lae nye esi: Lé nyitsui ɖeka kple agbo eve siwo sɔ blibo, 2 eye nàtsɔ luwɔ si me nyuie aƒo amɔwɔ maʋamaʋã bolo, amɔwɔ maʋamaʋã bolo kotoe si wode amii, kple amɔwɔ maʋamaʋã kpɔnɔ si ŋu wosisi ami ɖo.

“This is what you are to do to sanctify them to serve as priests to me: Take a young bull, two unblemished rams, 2 unleavened bread, unleavened ring-shaped loaves mixed with oil, and unleavened wafers spread with oil.
3 Tsɔ wo de kusi me nàtsɔ wo kple kusia vɛ, eye nàkplɔ nyi la kple agbo eveawo hã vɛ.
You are to make them with fine wheat flour 3 and put them in a basket and present them in the basket, along with the bull and the two rams.
4 “Eyome nàkplɔ Aron kple viaŋutsuwo va takpegbadɔ la nu, eye nàna woale tsi.
4 “You will present Aaron and his sons at the entrance of the tent of meeting and wash them with water.
5 Tsɔ awuawo vɛ, eye nàdo awu ʋlaya la, awu ʋlaya si ŋu abɔ mele o, kɔmewu la kple akɔtaɖonu la na Aron, eye nàsa kɔmewu la dzi blanu ɖe edzi nɛ.

5 Then you are to take the garments and clothe Aaron with the robe, the sleeveless coat of the ephod, the ephod, and the breastpiece, and you are to tie the woven belt of the ephod securely around his waist.
6 Tsɔ tablanu la ɖɔ ɖe ta nɛ, eye nàtsɔ adzɔgbeɖeɖe ƒe dzesi kɔkɔe la ɖo tablanu la ŋu; 7 eye nàkɔ ami kɔkɔe la ɖe tame nɛ atsɔ asi ami nɛ.
6 You will put the turban on his head and put the holy sign of dedication on the turban; 7 and take the anointing oil and pour it on his head and anoint him.

8 “Azɔ nàna viaŋutsuwo nate va, eye nàdo awu ʋlayaawo na wo. 9 Tsɔ alidziblanuwo bla ali dzi na wo, Aron kple viaŋutsuwo siaa, eye nàtsɔ tablavɔ la abla ta na wo, ale be nunɔlanyenye la nazu wo tɔ le se nu tegbee.

8 “Then bring his sons forward and clothe them with the robes 9 and wrap the sashes around them, Aaron as well as his sons, and put on their headgear; and the priesthood will become theirs as a permanent statute.
Aleae nàwɔ aɖo Aron kple viaŋutsuwo nunɔlawoe.
This is how you should install Aaron and his sons to serve as priests.
10 “Azɔ nàkplɔ nyi la ava takpegbadɔ la ŋgɔ, eye Aron kple viaŋutsuwo natsɔ woƒe asiwo aɖo nyi la ƒe tame.
10 “You are now to present the bull before the tent of meeting, and Aaron and his sons will lay their hands on the bull’s head.
11 Eye nàwu nyi la le Yehowa ŋkume le takpegbadɔa nu.
11 Slaughter the bull before Jehovah, at the entrance of the tent of meeting.
12 Eye nàtsɔ wò asibidɛ ade nyi la ƒe ʋu la me asisi ɖe vɔsamlekpui la ƒe dzoawo ŋu, eye nàkɔ ʋu si susɔ la katã ɖe vɔsamlekpuia te.
12 Take some of the bull’s blood on your finger and put it on the horns of the altar, and pour out all the rest of the blood at the base of the altar.
13 Azɔ nàɖe ami siwo katã le dɔkaviawo ŋu, aklã ŋu miwo, ayiku eveawo kple ami si le wo ŋu la atsɔ ado dzudzɔ le vɔsamlekpui la dzi.
13 Then take all the fat that covers the intestines, the appendage on the liver, and the two kidneys and the fat that is on them, and burn them so that they smoke on the altar.
14 Gake nàtɔ dzo nyilã la kple eƒe agbalẽ kpakple eƒe dɔmemĩ le asaɖa la godo.
14 But the bull’s flesh and its skin and its dung, you will burn with fire outside the camp.
Nuvɔ̃vɔsa wònye.
It is a sin offering.
15 “Emegbe nàtsɔ agboawo dometɔ ɖeka, eye Aron kple viaŋutsuwo natsɔ woƒe asiwo aɖo agbo la ƒe tame.
15 “Then take the one ram, and Aaron and his sons are to lay their hands on the ram’s head.
16 Wu agbo la nàhlẽ eƒe ʋu ɖe vɔsamlekpuia ŋu godoo va kpe.
16 Slaughter the ram and take its blood and sprinkle it on all sides of the altar.
17 Fli agbo la ɖe eƒe ƒunuɖeƒewo, eye nàkpala eƒe dɔmenuwo kple eƒe afɔwo, eye nàgbugbɔ aɖo lãkɔawo kple eƒe ta ɖe ɖoɖo nu.
17 Cut the ram into its pieces, and wash its intestines and its shanks, and arrange the pieces together with its head.
18 Tsɔ agbo blibo la do dzudzɔ le vɔsamlekpui la dzi.
18 You must burn the entire ram, making it smoke on the altar.
Enye numevɔsa si ʋẽna lilili na Yehowa; dzovɔsa wònye na Yehowa.
It is a burnt offering to Jehovah, a pleasing aroma. It is an offering made by fire to Jehovah.
19 “Eyome nàtsɔ agbo evelia, eye Aron kple viaŋutsuwo natsɔ woƒe asiwo aɖo agbo la ƒe tame.
19 “Next you are to take the other ram, and Aaron and his sons are to lay their hands on the ram’s head.

20 Eye nàwu agbo la asisi eƒe ʋu la ƒe ɖe ɖe Aron ƒe ɖusitogboe kple viaŋutsuwo ƒe ɖusitogboewo kple woƒe nuɖusidegblefetsuwo kpakple woƒe ɖusifɔdegblefetsuwo ŋu, eye nàhlẽ ʋu la ɖe vɔsamlekpui la ŋu godoo va kpe.

20 Slaughter the ram and take some of its blood and put it on Aaron’s right earlobe and on his sons’ right earlobe and on the thumb of their right hand and the big toe of their right foot, and sprinkle the blood on all sides of the altar.

21 Eye nàtsɔ ʋu si le vɔsamlekpuia dzi la ƒe ɖe kple ami kɔkɔe la ƒe ɖe ahlẽ ɖe Aron kple eƒe awuwo kpakple viaŋutsuwo kple woƒe awuwo ŋu, ale be eya ŋutɔ kple eƒe awuwo, kpakple viaŋutsuwo kple woƒe awuwo nanɔ kɔkɔe.

21 Then take some of the blood that is on the altar and some of the anointing oil and spatter it on Aaron and his garments and on his sons and his sons’ garments, so that he and his garments and his sons and their garments may be holy.
22 “Eye nàɖe ami si le agbo la ŋu, asike dami la, ami si le dɔkaviawo ŋu, aklã ŋu miwo, ayiku eveawo kple ami si le wo ŋu, kpakple ɖusita la, elabena nunɔlaɖoɖo ƒe agbo ye wònye.

22 “Then take from the ram the fat, the fat tail, the fat that covers the intestines, the appendage of the liver, the two kidneys and the fat that is on them, and the right leg, for it is a ram of installation.
23 Eyome nàtsɔ abolo nogoe ɖeka, abolo kotoe si wode amii la ɖeka kple akpɔnɔ vivi ɖeka le kusi si me amɔwɔ maʋamaʋã boloawo le le Yehowa ŋkume la me.
23 Take also a round loaf of bread and a ring-shaped loaf of oiled bread and a wafer out of the basket of unleavened bread that is before Jehovah.
24 Eye nàtsɔ wo katã ade Aron kple viaŋutsuwo si, eye nànyè nuawo woazu nunyèvɔsa le Yehowa ŋkume.
24 You must place them all in the hands of Aaron and in the hands of his sons, and you are to wave them back and forth as a wave offering before Jehovah.
25 Emegbe nàxɔ nuawo le wo si ada ɖe numevɔsalã la dzi le vɔsamlekpuia dzi atsɔ ado dzudzɔ ʋeʋĩ na Yehowa; dzovɔsa wònye na Yehowa.
25 Then you will take them out of their hands and burn them on the altar, on top of the burnt offering, as a pleasing aroma before Jehovah. It is an offering made by fire to Jehovah.
26 “Eyome nàtsɔ nunɔlaɖoɖo ƒe agbo si wotsɔ ɖo Aron la ƒe akɔ, eye nànyèe wòazu nunyèvɔsa le Yehowa ŋkume, emegbe wòazu tɔwò.
26 “Then take the breast of the ram of installation, which is offered in behalf of Aaron, and wave it back and forth as a wave offering before Jehovah, and it will become your portion.
27 Eye nàtsɔ lã si ƒe akɔ wonyè, kple agbo si wowu hena Aron kple viaŋutsuwo ɖoɖo la ƒe ata si wonyè, si nye gome kɔkɔe la, ne nàkɔ wo ŋu.

27 You are to sanctify the breast of the wave offering and the leg of the sacred portion that was waved and that was taken from the ram of installation, from what was offered for Aaron and for his sons.
28 Esia azu Aron kple viaŋutsuwo tɔ, eye wòanye ɖoɖo si dzi Israel-viwo awɔ ɖo ɖaa, elabena gome kɔkɔe si Israel-viwo atsɔ ana ye wònye.
28 It is to become Aaron’s and his sons’ by a permanent regulation to be carried out by the Israelites, for it is a sacred portion, and it will become a sacred portion to be given by the Israelites.
Azu gome kɔkɔe si woatsɔ ana Yehowa tso woƒe ŋutifafavɔsawo me.
It is their sacred portion for Jehovah from their communion sacrifices.
29 “Aron ƒe awu kɔkɔeawo nazu emegbevi siwo axɔ ɖe eteƒe la tɔ, eye woadoe ne wosi ami na wo heɖo wo nunɔlawoe.
29 “The holy garments that belong to Aaron will be used by his sons after him when they are anointed and installed as priests.
30 Viaŋutsuwo dometɔ si azu nunɔla ɖe eteƒe, si ayi takpegbadɔa me be yeasubɔ le kɔkɔeƒea la, nado awuawo ŋkeke adre.
30 The priest from among his sons who succeeds him and who comes into the tent of meeting to minister in the holy place will wear them for seven days.
31 “Azɔ nàtsɔ nunɔlaɖoɖo ƒe agbo la, eye nàɖa lã la le teƒe kɔkɔe.
31 “You will take the ram of installation and boil its flesh in a holy place.
32 Aron kple viaŋutsuwo naɖu agbolã la kple abolo siwo le kusi me la le takpegbadɔa nu.
32 Aaron and his sons will eat the flesh of the ram and the bread that is in the basket at the entrance of the tent of meeting.
33 Woaɖu nu siwo wotsɔ lé avu esi woɖo wo nunɔlawoe hekɔ wo ŋu la.
33 They are to eat the things with which atonement was made to install them as priests and to sanctify them.
Gake ame bubu aɖeke mekpɔ mɔ aɖu wo o, elabena nu kɔkɔe wonye.
But an unauthorized person may not eat them, for they are something holy.
34 Ne nunɔlaɖoɖo ƒe vɔsalã kple abolo la ƒe ɖe tsi anyi ŋu ke ɖe edzi la, ekema woatɔ dzoe.
34 If any of the flesh of the installation sacrifice and of the bread is left over until the morning, then you must burn what is left with fire.
Womaɖui o, elabena nu kɔkɔe wònye.
It must not be eaten, for it is something holy.
35 “Ale si mede se na wò la, nenema tututu nàwɔ na Aron kple viaŋutsuawoe.
35 “You are to do this way to Aaron and his sons, according to all that I have commanded you.
Ŋkeke adre nàtsɔ aɖo wo nunɔlawoe.
You will take seven days to install them as priests.
36 Tsɔ nyitsu ɖeka sa nuvɔ̃vɔe gbe sia gbe, ne wòanye avuléle; eye nàlé avu ɖe vɔsamlekpui la ta atsɔ aɖe nu vɔ̃ ɖa le eŋu, eye nàsi ami nɛ atsɔ akɔ eŋu.
36 You will offer the bull of the sin offering daily for an atonement, and you are to purify the altar from sin by making atonement for it, and you must anoint it to sanctify it.
37 Ŋkeke adre nàtsɔ alé avu ɖe vɔsamlekpui la ta, eye nàkɔ eŋu ne wòazu vɔsamlekpui kɔkɔetɔ.
37 You will take seven days to make atonement for the altar, and you must sanctify it so that it may become a most holy altar.
Ame sia ame si aka asi vɔsamlekpuia ŋu la nanɔ kɔkɔe.
Anyone who touches the altar is to be holy.
38 “Tsɔ alẽtsui eve siwo dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe xɔ ƒe ɖeka la sa vɔe le vɔsamlekpuia dzi gbe sia gbe, eye nànɔ ewɔm nenema ɖaa.
38 “This is what you will offer on the altar: two one-year-old rams each day, continually.
39 Tsɔ alẽtsui ɖeka sa vɔe le ŋdi, eye nàtsɔ alẽtsui evelia sa vɔe le anyinutsyɔɣi.
39 Offer the one young ram in the morning and the other ram at twilight.

40 Eye nàtsɔ wɔ memee efa me mama ɖe ewo ƒe akpa ɖeka, si wotsɔ amititsetse ƒe ami nyuitɔ hin me mama ɖe ene ƒe akpa ɖeka dzabae, kple nunovɔsa ƒe wain hin me mama ɖe ene ƒe akpa ɖeka akpe ɖe alẽtsui gbãtɔa ŋu.
40 A tenth part of an ephah measure of fine flour mixed with a fourth of a hin of beaten oil, and a drink offering of a fourth of a hin of wine, will go for the first young ram.
41 Tsɔ alẽtsui evelia sa vɔe le anyinutsyɔɣi, eye nàsa nuɖuvɔ kple nunovɔ akpe ɖe eŋu abe ŋdi me tɔa ke ene.
41 You will offer the second young ram at twilight, along with the same grain and drink offerings as in the morning.
Anye dzovɔsa si aʋẽ lilili na Yehowa.
You will render it as a pleasing aroma, an offering made by fire to Jehovah.
42 Esia anye numevɔsa si miawɔ ɖaa tso dzidzime yi dzidzime le takpegbadɔ la nu le Yehowa ŋkume, afi si maɖe ɖokuinye afia mi le, aƒo nu kpli wò le.
42 It is to be a regular burnt offering throughout your generations at the entrance of the tent of meeting before Jehovah, where I will present myself to you to speak to you there.
43 “Maɖe ɖokuinye afia Israel-viwo le afi ma, eye nye ŋutikɔkɔe ana teƒea nanɔ kɔkɔe.
43 “I will present myself there to the Israelites, and it will be sanctified by my glory.
44 Makɔ takpegbadɔ la kple vɔsamlekpui la ŋu, eye makɔ Aron kple viaŋutsuwo ŋu, ne woazu nunɔlawo asubɔm.
44 I will sanctify the tent of meeting and the altar, and I will sanctify Aaron and his sons so that they may serve as priests to me.
45 Manɔ Israel-viwo dome, eye manye woƒe Mawu.
45 I will reside among the people of Israel, and I will be their God.
46 Eye woadze sii be nyee nye Yehowa woƒe Mawu, ame si kplɔ wo tso Egipte-nyigba dzi, be manɔ wo dome.
46 And they will certainly know that I am Jehovah their God, who brought them out of the land of Egypt so that I may reside among them.
Nyee nye Yehowa woƒe Mawu.
I am Jehovah their God.
Ɣemaɣi la, ŋutsu aɖe si tso Lewi-toa me ɖe Lewi nyɔnu aɖe.
About that time, a certain man of the house of Levi married a daughter of Levi.
2 Eye nyɔnu la fɔ fu dzi ŋutsuvi.
2 And the woman became pregnant and gave birth to a son.
Esi wòkpɔ be edze ɖeka ŋutɔ la, eɣlae dzinu etɔ̃ sɔŋ.
When she saw how beautiful he was, she kept him concealed for three months.
3 Esi megate ŋu le eɣlam o la, etsɔ kusi si wolɔ̃ kple aƒla, eye wòtsɔ aŋɔ kple aŋe tree keŋ, eye wòtsɔ ɖevi la de eme hetsɔe yi ɖada ɖe aɖawo dome le Nil-tɔsisia to.
3 When she was no longer able to conceal him, she took a papyrus basket and coated it with bitumen and pitch and put the child in it and placed it among the reeds by the bank of the Nile River.
4 Ke nɔvianyɔnu tɔ ɖe adzɔge be yeakpɔ nu si ava dzɔ ɖe edzi.
4 But his sister stood at a distance to see what would happen to him.
5 Ke Farao vinyɔnu va tsi le ge le Nil-tɔsisia me, eye eƒe subɔvinyɔnuwo le tsa ɖim le Nil-tɔsisia to.
5 When Pharaoh’s daughter came down to bathe in the Nile, her female attendants were walking by the side of the Nile.
Kasia Farao vinyɔnua kpɔ kusi la le aɖawo dome.
And she caught sight of the basket in the middle of the reeds.
Enumake edɔ eƒe kosi ɖa be wòayi aɖatsɔe vɛ.
She immediately sent her slave girl to get it.
6 Esi wòʋui la, ekpɔ ɖevi la le eme, eye ɖevia le avi fam.
6 When she opened it, she saw the child, and the boy was crying.

Eƒe nu wɔ nublanui nɛ, gake egblɔ be, “Hebritɔwo ƒe viwo dometɔ ɖekae nye esia.” 7 Eye ɖevia nɔvinyɔnu bia Farao vinyɔnu la be: “Mayi aɖayɔ vinɔ aɖe tso Hebri nyɔnuwo dome ne wòana no ɖevia ahakpɔ edzi na wòa?” 8 Farao vinyɔnu la gblɔ nɛ be: “Heyi!”

She felt compassion for him, but she said: “This is one of the children of the Hebrews.” 7 Then his sister said to Pharaoh’s daughter: “Shall I go and call a nursing woman from the Hebrews to nurse the child for you?” 8 Pharaoh’s daughter said to her: “Go!”
Enumake nyɔnuvi la yi ɖayɔ ɖevia dada vɛ.
At once the girl went and called the child’s mother.
9 Eye Farao vinyɔnu la gblɔ nɛ be: “Xɔ ɖevi sia nàna noe ahakpɔ edzi nam, eye maxe fe na wò.”
9 Pharaoh’s daughter then said to her: “Take this child with you and nurse him for me, and I will pay you.”
Ale nyɔnu la kɔ ɖevia, eye wòna noe hekpɔ edzi.
So the woman took the child and nursed him.
10 Esi ɖevia tsi la, ekplɔe yi na Farao vinyɔnu la, eye wòzu via.
10 When the child grew older, she brought him to Pharaoh’s daughter, and he became a son to her.
Ena ŋkɔe be Mose elabena egblɔ be: “Tsi mee meɖee tsoe.”
She named him Moses and said: “It is because I have drawn him out of the water.”
11 Le ŋkeke mawo me esi Mose tsi la, edo go yi nɔviawo gbɔ be yeakpɔ dɔ sesẽ siwo wɔm wole la ɖa, eye wòkpɔ Egiptetɔ aɖe wòle nɔvia Hebritɔ aɖe ƒom.
11 Now in those days, after Moses had become an adult, he went out to his brothers to look at the burdens they were bearing, and he caught sight of an Egyptian beating a Hebrew, one of his brothers.
12 Esi wòtsa ŋku mlamlamla, eye mekpɔ ame aɖeke o la, ewu Egiptetɔ la eye wòɖii ɖe ke me.
12 So he looked this way and that, and seeing no one, he killed the Egyptian and hid him in the sand.
13 Le ŋufɔke la, egado go eye wòkpɔ Hebritɔ eve wole avu wɔm.
13 But he went out on the following day, and there were two Hebrew men fighting with each other.
Eya ta ebia ame si tɔ medzɔ o la be: “Nu ka tae nèle nɔviwò ƒom?” 14 Ke eya ɖo eŋu be: “Ame kae ɖo wò amegã kple ʋɔnudrɔ̃la ɖe mía nu?
So he said to the one in the wrong: “Why do you strike your companion?” 14 At this he said: “Who appointed you as a prince and a judge over us?
Ðe nèdi be yeawu nye hã abe ale si nèwu Egiptetɔ la enea?”
Are you planning to kill me just as you killed the Egyptian?”
Ale vɔvɔ̃ ɖo Mose wògblɔ na eɖokui be: “Ei, nya la ɖi wose!”
Moses now was afraid and said: “Surely the matter has become known!”
15 Azɔ Farao se nya la, eye wòdi be yeawu Mose; ke Mose si le Farao nu yi ɖanɔ Midian-nyigba dzi, eye wòva bɔbɔ nɔ vudo aɖe to.
15 Then Pharaoh heard about it, and he attempted to kill Moses; but Moses ran away from Pharaoh and went to dwell in the land of Midian, and he sat down by a well.
16 Ke nyɔnuvi adre le Midian nunɔla si, eye wova be yewoadu tsi akɔ ɖe lãwo ƒe tsinonuwo me na wo fofo ƒe alẽwo.
16 Now the priest of Midian had seven daughters, and these came to draw water and to fill the troughs to water their father’s flock.
17 Eye alẽkplɔlawo va nya wo ɖa, abe ale si wowɔnɛ ɣesiaɣi ene.
17 But as usual, the shepherds came and drove them away.
Ale Mose tso va kpe ɖe nyɔnuawo ŋu, eye wòna tsi woƒe alẽawo.
At this Moses got up and helped the women and watered their flock.

18 Esi wogbɔ va wo fofo Reuel gbɔ la, edo ɣli be: “Aleke wɔ miegbɔ egbea kaba ale?” 19 Woɖo eŋu be: “Egiptetɔ aɖee ɖe mí tso alẽkplɔlaawo si me, eye wòdu tsi gɔ̃ hã na mí eye wòna tsi míaƒe alẽawo wono.” 20 Ale wòbia vianyɔnuawo be: “Afi kae ŋutsu la le?

18 When they came home to their father Reuel, he exclaimed: “How is it that you have come home so quickly today?” 19 They replied: “A certain Egyptian rescued us from the shepherds, and he even drew water for us and watered the flock.” 20 He said to his daughters: “But where is he?
Nu ka tae miegblẽe ɖe afi ma?
Why did you leave the man behind?
Miyi ɖayɔe vɛ ne wòaɖu nu kpli mí.” 21 Eye Mose lɔ̃ be yeanɔ ŋutsu la gbɔ, eye wòtsɔ via Zipora na Mose wòɖe.
Call him, so that he may eat with us.” 21 After that Moses consented to stay with the man, and he gave his daughter ZippOrah to Moses in marriage.
22 Emegbe edzi ŋutsuvi, eye wòtsɔ ŋkɔ nɛ be Gersom, elabena egblɔ be: “Amedzroe menye le dzronyigba dzi.”
22 Later she bore a son, and he named him Gershom, for he said, “I have become a foreign resident in a foreign land.”
23 Le ƒe geɖe megbe la, Egipte-fia la ku, gake Israel-viwo gakpɔtɔ le hũ ɖem le kluvinyenye la ta, wole konyi fam, eye woƒe ɣlidodo be woaxɔ na yewo le kluvinyenyea ta la nɔ Mawu vavã la gbɔ ɖom.

23 After a long time, the king of Egypt died, but the Israelites continued to groan because of the slavery and to cry out in complaint, and their cry for help because of the slavery kept going up to the true God.
24 Le ɣeyiɣi aɖe megbe la, Mawu se woƒe hũɖeɖe la, eye Mawu ɖo ŋku nu, si wòbla kple Abraham, Isak kple Yakob la dzi.
24 In time God heard their groaning, and God remembered his covenant with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.
25 Ale Mawu kpɔ Israel-viwo ɖa, eye wòtrɔ susu ɖe woƒe nɔnɔmea ŋu.
25 So God looked on the Israelites; and God took notice.
Emegbe etsɔ akasiati kpa numevɔsamlekpui la.
He made the altar of burnt offering out of acacia wood.
Edidi abɔklugui atɔ̃, ekeke abɔklugui atɔ̃, ele dzogoe ene me, eye wòkɔ abɔklugui etɔ̃.
It was square, five cubits long, five cubits wide, and three cubits high.
2 Eyome ewɔ dzowo ɖe eƒe dzogoe eneawo dzi wònye nu ɖeka.
2 Then he made its horns on its four corners. Its horns were one piece with it.
Eye wòfa akɔbli ɖe eŋu.
Next he overlaid it with copper.
3 Emegbe ewɔ vɔsamlekpui la ŋu nuwo katã: tɔkpowo, sofiwo, agba goboewo, gaflowo kple dzoɖenuwo.
3 After that he made all the utensils of the altar, the buckets, the shovels, the bowls, the forks, and the fire holders.
Akɔbli wòtsɔ wɔ eŋu nuawo katãe.
All its utensils he made of copper.
4 Etsɔ akɔbli wɔ gaɖɔ ɖe vɔsamlekpui la ƒe titina lɔƒo, le eƒe to la ƒe anyime.
4 He also made a grating for the altar, a network of copper, under its rim, down toward its center.
5 Ewɔ akɔblisigɛ ene ɖe eƒe dzogoe eneawo dzi le klosalogaɖɔ la gbɔ lɔƒo, be woaƒo kpowo ɖe wo me atsɔ akɔe.
5 He cast four rings on the four corners near the grating of copper, as holders for the poles.
6 Emegbe etsɔ akasiati kpa kpowo eye wòfa akɔbli ɖe wo ŋu.
6 After that he made the poles of acacia wood and overlaid them with copper.
7 Azɔ eƒo kpoawo ɖe asigɛawo me, le vɔsamlekpui la ƒe axawo ne woatsɔ akɔe.
7 He inserted the poles into the rings on the sides of the altar for carrying it.
Etsɔ ʋuƒowo wɔ vɔsamlekpui la wòle abe aɖaka ene.
He made the altar in the form of a hollow chest of planks.
8 Emegbe etsɔ akɔbli wɔ ze la kple eƒe zɔ; nyɔnu siwo wode dɔ asi na be woasubɔ le takpegbadɔa nu la ƒe gahuhɔ̃ewoe wòtsɔ wɔ woe.
8 Then he made the basin of copper and its copper stand; he used the mirrors of the women who were organized to serve at the entrance of the tent of meeting.
9 Eye wòwɔ xɔxɔnu la.
9 Then he made the courtyard.
Etsɔ avɔ siwo wotsɔ ɖeti ɣi biɖibiɖi dada lɔ̃ la tɔ kpɔ ɖe xɔxɔnu la ƒe axa si trɔ ɖe anyiehe gome wòdidi abɔklugui alafa ɖeka.
For the south side of the courtyard, facing south, he made the hanging curtains of fine twisted linen, for 100 cubits.
10 Etsɔ akɔbli wɔ eƒe kpɔti blaeveawo kple woƒe anyinɔ blaeveawo. Eye wòtsɔ klosalo wɔ kpɔtiawo ƒe nulénuwo kple woƒe kpeƒe ƒe gaviwo.
10 There were 20 pillars and 20 socket pedestals of copper, and the hooks of the pillars and their connectors were of silver.
11 Avɔ si wòtsɔ tɔ kpɔ ɖe dziehekpa dzi la hã didi abɔklugui alafa ɖeka.
11 Also, for the north side, there were 100 cubits of hanging curtains.
Etsɔ akɔbli wɔ eƒe kpɔti blaeveawo kple woƒe anyinɔ blaeveawo.
Their 20 pillars and their 20 socket pedestals were of copper.
Eye wòtsɔ klosalo wɔ kpɔtiawo ƒe nulénuwo kple woƒe kpeƒe ƒe gaviwo.
The hooks of the pillars and their connectors were of silver.
12 Ke avɔ si wòtsɔ tɔ kpɔ ɖe eƒe ɣetoɖoƒekpa dzi ya keke abɔklugui blaatɔ̃.
12 But for the west side, the hanging curtains were for 50 cubits.
Woƒe kpɔtiwo le ewo, eye woƒe anyinɔwo le ewo. Klosalo wòtsɔ wɔ kpɔtiawo ƒe nulénuwo kple woƒe kpeƒe ƒe gaviwo.
There were ten pillars and ten socket pedestals, and the hooks of the pillars and their connectors were of silver.
13 Avɔ si wòtsɔ tɔ kpɔ ɖe ɣedzeƒekpa dzi la keke abɔklugui blaatɔ̃.
13 The width of the east side, toward the sunrising, was 50 cubits.
14 Avɔ si wòtsɔ tɔ kpɔ ɖe xɔxɔnua ƒe mɔnu ƒe akpa ɖeka la keke abɔklugui wuiatɔ̃, woƒe kpɔtiwo le etɔ̃, eye woƒe anyinɔwo le etɔ̃.
14 There were 15 cubits of hanging curtains on the one wing, with three pillars and three socket pedestals.
15 Eye avɔ si wòtsɔ tɔ kpɔ ɖe xɔxɔnua ƒe mɔnu ƒe akpa evelia la keke abɔklugui wuiatɔ̃, abe akpa kemɛa ke ene. Woƒe kpɔtiwo le etɔ̃, eye woƒe anyinɔwo le etɔ̃.
15 And for the other wing on the other side of the entrance of the courtyard, there were hanging curtains for 15 cubits, with three pillars and three socket pedestals.
16 Ðeti ɣi biɖibiɖi dada wòtsɔ lɔ̃ avɔ siwo katã wotsɔ tɔ kpɔ ɖe xɔxɔnua ŋu godoo va kpe.
16 All the hanging curtains around the courtyard were of fine twisted linen.
17 Etsɔ akɔbli wɔ kpɔtiawo ƒe anyinɔwo, etsɔ klosalo wɔ kpɔtiawo ƒe nulénuwo kple wo kpeƒe ƒe gaviwo, efa klosalo ɖe kpɔtiawo tame, eye wòtsɔ klosalo wɔ xɔxɔnu la ƒe sɔtiawo katã ƒe kpeƒelénuwo.

17 The socket pedestals for the pillars were of copper, the hooks of the pillars and their connectors were of silver, the tops were overlaid with silver, and there were silver fasteners for all the pillars of the courtyard.
18 Eyome etsɔ ka blɔtɔ, alẽfuka si wode ama aɖabɛ dzĩtɔe, ka dzĩ kple ɖeti ɣi biɖibiɖi dada lɔ̃ xɔxɔnu la ƒe mɔnuvɔ la.
18 The screen of the entrance of the courtyard was woven of blue thread, purple wool, scarlet material, and fine twisted linen.
Edidi abɔklugui blaeve, eye wòkɔ abɔklugui atɔ̃, abe avɔ si wotsɔ tɔ kpɔ ɖe xɔxɔnu la ke ene.
It was 20 cubits long and 5 cubits high, the same height as the hanging curtains of the courtyard.
19 Etsɔ akɔbli wɔ woƒe kpɔti eneawo kple woƒe anyinɔ eneawo.
19 Their four pillars and their four socket pedestals were made of copper.
Etsɔ klosalo wɔ woƒe nulénuwo kple wo kpeƒe ƒe gaviwo eye wòfa klosalo ɖe wo tame.
Their hooks and connectors were of silver, and their tops were overlaid with silver.
20 Avɔgbadɔ la kple xɔxɔnu la ƒe tsyotiwo katã nye akɔbli.
20 All the tent pins for the tabernacle and around the courtyard were of copper.
21 Esiawoe nye avɔgbadɔ la, si nye Ðaseɖiɖigbadɔ la, ŋuti nuŋlɔɖi si Mose na Lewi viwo wɔ le nunɔla Itamar, Aron vi ƒe dzikpɔkpɔ te.

21 The following is the inventory of the tabernacle, the tabernacle of the Testimony, which was inventoried at the command of Moses, as the responsibility of the Levites under the direction of Ithamar the son of Aaron the priest.
22 Bezalel, si nye Uri vi, Hur vi, tso Yuda-to la me, wɔ nu siawo katã abe ale si Yehowa de se na Mose ene.
22 Bezalel the son of uri the son of Hur of the tribe of Judah did all that Jehovah had commanded Moses.

23 Eye Oholiab, si nye Ahisamak si tso Dan-to la me ƒe viŋutsu kpe ɖe eŋu. Enye aɖaŋudɔwɔla, elɔ̃a nu ɖe avɔ me, eye wònya ale si wotsɔa ka blɔtɔ kple alẽfuka si wode ama aɖabɛ dzĩtɔe, ka dzĩ kple ɖeti ɣi biɖibiɖi lɔ̃a nui.
23 With him was OhOliab the son of AhisAmach of the tribe of Dan, a craftsman and an embroiderer and a weaver of the blue thread, the purple wool, the scarlet material, and the fine linen.
24 Sika si wodzɔ wònye nunyèvɔsa, si wozã le kɔkɔeƒe la ŋuti dɔ bliboa katã wɔwɔ me, la ƒe home le talento blaeve vɔ asieke kple sekel alafa adre blaetɔ̃, ne wobui ɖe teƒe kɔkɔe la ƒe sekel la nu.
24 All the gold that was used for all the work of the holy place equaled the amount of the gold of the wave offering, 29 talents and 730 shekels by the standard shekel of the holy place.
25 Klosalo si ameha la dometɔ siwo katã ƒe ŋkɔ woŋlɔ dzɔ la, le talento alafa ɖeka kple sekel akpe ɖeka alafa adre blaadre vɔ atɔ̃, ne wobui ɖe teƒe kɔkɔe la ƒe sekel la nu.
25 And the silver of the ones registered of the assembly was 100 talents and 1,775 shekels by the standard shekel of the holy place.
26 Ame siwo katã xɔ ƒe blaeve kple edzivɔ, siwo ƒe ŋkɔ woŋlɔ la na sekel afã, le teƒe kɔkɔe la ƒe sekel la nu, eye wo katã ƒe xexlẽme le ame akpe alafa ade kple etɔ̃ alafa atɔ̃ blaatɔ̃.
26 The half shekel for each individual was half a shekel by the standard shekel of the holy place for every man who was among those registered from 20 years of age and up, amounting to 603,550.
27 Etsɔ klosalo talento alafa ɖeka wɔ kɔkɔeƒe la ƒe anyinɔwo kple xɔmetsovɔ la ƒe anyinɔwo; talento alafa ɖeka wɔ anyinɔ alafa ɖeka; talento ɖeka wɔ anyinɔ ɖeka.

27 The casting of the socket pedestals of the holy place and the socket pedestals of the curtain amounted to 100 talents; 100 socket pedestals equaled 100 talents, one talent for each socket pedestal.
28 Etsɔ sekel akpe ɖeka alafa adre blaadre vɔ atɔ̃ wɔ sɔtiawo ƒe nulénuwo, efa klosalo ɖe sɔtiawo tame, eye wòkpe wo ɖekae.
28 From the 1,775 shekels, he made hooks for the pillars and overlaid their tops and joined them together.
29 Akɔbli si wodzɔ la le talento blaadre kple sekel akpe eve alafa ene.
29 The copper of the offering was 70 talents and 2,400 shekels.

30 Etsɔe wɔ anyinɔwo na sɔti siwo le takpegbadɔ la ƒe mɔnu, akɔblivɔsamlekpui la kple eƒe akɔbligaɖɔ la, vɔsamlekpui la ŋu nuwo katã, 31 kpɔti siwo le xɔxɔnua ƒe anyinɔwo katã, kpɔti siwo le xɔxɔnua ƒe mɔnu la ƒe anyinɔwo katã, avɔgbadɔ la ƒe tsyotiwo katã, kple xɔxɔnua ƒe tsyotiwo katã.

30 With this he made the socket pedestals of the entrance of the tent of meeting, the copper altar and its copper grating, all the utensils of the altar, 31 the socket pedestals around the courtyard, the socket pedestals of the entrance of the courtyard, and all the tent pins of the tabernacle and all the tent pins around the courtyard.
Eye Yehowa gblɔ na Mose kple Aron le Egipte-nyigba dzi be: 2 “Ɣleti sia anye miaƒe ɣletiwo ƒe gbãtɔ.
Jehovah now said to Moses and Aaron in the land of Egypt: 2 “This month will be the beginning of the months for you.
Eyae anye ɣleti gbãtɔ na mi le ƒea me.
It will be the first of the months of the year for you.
3 Gblɔ na Israel ƒe ha blibo la katã be: ‘Le ɣleti sia ƒe ŋkeke ewolia dzi la, ame sia ame nalé alẽ ɖeka ɖe fofoa ƒe aƒe nu, aƒe ɖeka alẽ ɖeka.
3 Speak to the entire assembly of Israel, saying, ‘On the tenth day of this month, they should each take for themselves a sheep for their father’s house, a sheep to a house.
4 Ke ne aƒea me tɔwo mesɔ gbɔ ate ŋu aɖu alẽ ɖeka o la, ekema woawo kple woƒe aƒelika si tsɔ wo gbɔ la namae le woƒe aƒe me le ameawo ƒe xexlẽme nu.
4 But if the household is too small for the sheep, they and their nearest neighbor should share it between themselves in their house according to the number of people.
Ne miele esia ŋu bum la, mibu lã ale si nu ame sia ame ate ŋu aɖu la ŋu.
When making the calculation, determine how much of the sheep each one will eat.
5 Lãtsui si sɔ blibo, eye wòxɔ ƒe ɖeka lae mialé.
5 Your sheep should be a sound, one-year-old male.
Mitiae le alẽtsuiwo alo gbɔ̃tsuiwo dome.
You may choose from the young rams or from the goats.
6 Mikpɔ edzi va se ɖe ɣleti sia ƒe ŋkeke wuienelia dzi, eye Israel-viwo ƒe ha blibo la nawui le anyinutsyɔɣi.
6 You must care for it until the 14th day of this month, and the whole congregation of the assembly of Israel must slaughter it at twilight.
7 Eye woatsɔ ʋu la ƒe ɖe asisi ɖe aƒe si me woaɖui le la ƒe ʋɔtruti eveawo kple ʋɔtruti etametɔ ŋu.
7 They must take some of the blood and splash it on the two doorposts and the upper part of the doorway of the houses in which they eat it.
8 “‘Woaɖu lã la le zã ma me.
8 “‘They must eat the meat on this night.
Woamèe le dzo nu, eye woatsɔ amɔwɔ maʋamaʋã bolo kple ama veve aɖui.
They should roast it over the fire and eat it along with unleavened bread and bitter greens.
9 Migaɖu eƒe ɖeke mumu alo aɖae le tsi me o, ke boŋ mimèe dɔ nogo le dzo nu; ta kple afɔwo kpakple dɔmenuwo nanɔ eŋu hafi miamèe.
9 Do not eat any of it raw or boiled, cooked in water, but roast it over the fire, its head together with its shanks and its inner parts.
10 Migagblẽ eƒe ɖeke ɖi ŋu nake ɖe edzi o; ne eƒe ɖe susɔ ŋu ke ɖe edzi la, mitɔ dzoe.
10 You must not save any of it until morning, but any of it left over until morning you should burn with fire.
11 Ale miaɖui nye esi: Mibla miaƒe aliwo dzi, mido afɔkpa, eye milé miaƒe atizɔtiwo ɖe asi; eye minɔ kplakplakpla dzi miaɖui.
11 And this is how you should eat it, with your belt fastened, sandals on your feet, and your staff in your hand; and you should eat it in a hurry.
Yehowa ƒe Ŋutitotoŋkekenyui wònye.
It is Jehovah’s Passover.
12 Elabena mato Egipte-nyigba la dzi le zã sia me ahawu ŋgɔgbeviwo katã, amegbetɔwo kple lãwo siaa, le Egipte-nyigba dzi; eye madrɔ̃ ʋɔnu Egipte mawuwo katã.
12 For I will pass through the land of Egypt on this night and strike every firstborn in the land of Egypt, from man to beast; and I will execute judgment on all the gods of Egypt.
Nyee nye Yehowa.
I am Jehovah.
13 Ʋu la nanye dzesi anɔ xɔ siwo me miele la ŋu; ale be ne mele nu gblẽm le Egipte-nyigba dzi, eye mekpɔ ʋua la, mato mia ŋu ayi, ale be fuwɔame la mava mia dzi ahagblẽ nu le mia ŋu o.
13 The blood will serve as your sign on the houses where you are; and I will see the blood and pass over you, and the plague will not come on you to destroy you when I strike the land of Egypt.
14 “‘Ŋkeke sia anye ŋkuɖodzi na mi, eye wòanye ŋkekenyui mianɔ ɖuɖum na Yehowa le miaƒe dzidzimewo katã me.
14 “‘This day will serve as a memorial for you, and you must celebrate it as a festival to Jehovah throughout your generations.
Wòanye ɖoɖo na mi, eye mianɔ eɖum ɖaa.
As a lasting statute, you should celebrate it.
15 Ŋkeke adre sɔŋ miaɖu amɔwɔ maʋamaʋã bolo.
15 Seven days you are to eat unleavened bread.
Ɛ̃, miaɖe amɔwɔ ʋaʋã ɖa le miaƒe aƒewo me le ŋkeke gbãtɔ dzi, elabena ame sia ame si aɖu nu ʋaʋã tso ŋkeke gbãtɔ dzi va se ɖe ŋkeke adrelia dzi la, woatsrɔ̃ ame ma ɖa le Israel.
Yes, on the first day you are to remove the sourdough from your houses, because anyone eating what is leavened from the first day down to the seventh, that person must be cut off from Israel.
16 Miwɔ takpekpe kɔkɔe le ŋkeke gbãtɔ dzi, eye migawɔ takpekpe kɔkɔe le ŋkeke adrelia hã dzi.
16 On the first day you will hold a holy convention, and on the seventh day, another holy convention.
Womawɔ dɔ aɖeke le ŋkeke siawo dzi o.
No work is to be done on these days.
Negbe nu si wòhiã be ame sia ame naɖu la koe miaɖa.
Only what every person needs to eat, that alone may be prepared for you.
17 “‘Miaɖu Amɔwɔ Maʋamaʋã Bolo Ŋkekenyui la, elabena ŋkeke sia tututu dzie makplɔ miaƒe amehawo adzoe le Egipte-nyigba dzi.
17 “‘You must keep the Festival of Unleavened Bread, for on this very day, I will bring your multitudes out of the land of Egypt.
Minɔ ŋkeke sia ɖum le miaƒe dzidzimewo katã me wòanye ɖoɖo na mi ɖaa.
And you must keep this day throughout your generations as a lasting statute.
18 Miɖu amɔwɔ maʋamaʋã bolo le ɣleti gbãtɔ ƒe ŋkeke wuienelia ƒe fiẽ va se ɖe ɣletia ƒe ŋkeke blaeve vɔ ɖekɛlia ƒe fiẽ.
18 In the first month, on the 14th day of the month, in the evening, you are to eat unleavened bread until the 21st day of the month, in the evening.
19 Ŋkeke adre sɔŋ womakpɔ amɔwɔ ʋaʋã le miaƒe aƒewo me o, elabena ame sia ame si aɖu nu ʋaʋã aɖe la, eɖanye amedzro alo Israel vidzidzi o, woatsrɔ̃ ame ma ɖa le Israel ƒe ha la dome.

19 No sourdough is to be found in your houses for seven days, because if anyone eats what is leavened, whether he is a foreigner or a native of the land, that person must be cut off from the assembly of Israel.
20 Migaɖu nu ʋaʋã aɖeke o.
20 You should not eat anything leavened.
Amɔwɔ maʋamaʋã bolo miaɖu le mia nɔƒewo katã.’”
In all your homes, you are to eat unleavened bread.’”
21 Enumake Mose yɔ Israel ƒe ametsitsiwo katã gblɔ na wo be: “Miyi ɖalé lãtsuiwo le miaƒe ƒomeawo nu, ne miawu Ŋutitotovɔsalã la.
21 Moses promptly called all the elders of Israel and said to them: “Go and select young animals for each of your families, and slaughter the Passover sacrifice.
22 Eye mianyrɔ isop gbe babla ɖe ʋu la me le agba me, eye miatsɔe asisi ɖe ʋɔtruti etametɔ kple ʋɔtruti eveawo ŋu; mia dometɔ aɖeke megado go le eƒe me o va se ɖe esime ŋu ke.

22 Then you must dip a bunch of hyssop into the blood that is in a basin and strike the upper part of the doorway and the two doorposts with the blood; and none of you should go out of the entrance of his house until morning.

23 Ekema ne Yehowa va to anyigba la dzi be yeawɔ fu Egiptetɔwo, eye wòkpɔ ʋu la le ʋɔtruti etametɔa kple ʋɔtruti eveawo ŋu la, ekema Yehowa ato miaƒe ʋɔtru la ŋuti, eye maɖe mɔ be gbegblẽ la nage ɖe miaƒe aƒewo me o.

23 Then when Jehovah passes through to plague the Egyptians and sees the blood on the upper part of the doorway and on the two doorposts, Jehovah will certainly pass over the entrance, and he will not allow the plague of death to enter into your houses.
24 “Mia kple mia viwo milé ɖoɖo sia me ɖe asi ɖaa.
24 “You must observe this event as a lasting regulation for you and your sons.
25 Eye ne mieva anyigba si Yehowa le mia na ge dzi, abe ale si wògblɔe ene la, milé wɔna sia me ɖe asi.
25 And when you come into the land that Jehovah will give you just as he has stated, you must keep this observance.

26 Eye ne mia viwo va bia mi be, ‘Nu kae wɔna sia fia na mi?’ hã la, 27 ekema miaɖo eŋu be: ‘Ŋutitoto ƒe vɔsae wònye na Yehowa, ame si to Israel-viwo ƒe aƒewo ŋu le Egipte esime wòhe fuwɔame va Egiptetɔwo dzi, ke ekpɔ míaƒe aƒewo ya ta.’”

26 And when your sons ask you, ‘What does this observance mean to you?’ 27 you must say, ‘It is the sacrifice of the Passover to Jehovah, who passed over the houses of the Israelites in Egypt when he plagued the Egyptians, but he spared our houses.’”
Eye dukɔ la bɔbɔ hede ta agu.
Then the people bowed low and prostrated themselves.
28 Ale Israel-viwo yi ɖawɔ abe ale si tututu Yehowa de se na Mose kple Aron ene.
28 So the Israelites went and did just as Jehovah had commanded Moses and Aaron.
Nenema pɛpɛpɛ wowɔ.
They did just so.

29 Eye le zã titina la, Yehowa wu ŋgɔgbeviwo katã le Egipte-nyigba dzi, tso Farao si bɔbɔ nɔ eƒe fiazikpui dzi la ƒe ŋgɔgbevi dzi va ɖo aboyome si le gaxɔ me ƒe ŋgɔgbevi dzi va se ɖe lãwo ƒe ŋgɔgbeviwo katã dzi.

29 Then at midnight, Jehovah struck down every firstborn in the land of Egypt, from the firstborn of Pharaoh who was sitting on his throne to the firstborn of the captive who was in the prison, and every firstborn of the animals.
30 Farao, eƒe subɔviwo katã kple Egiptetɔ bubuawo katã fɔ le zã me; eye avifafa de dzi bobobo le Egiptetɔwo dome, elabena aƒe aɖeke meli si me ame meku le o.
30 Pharaoh got up that night along with all his servants and all the other Egyptians, and there was a great outcry among the Egyptians, because there was not a house where someone was not dead.
31 Enumake Farao yɔ Mose kple Aron le zãa me gblɔ be: “Mitso, mia kple Israel-vi bubuawo midzo le nye dukɔ la me.
31 At once he called Moses and Aaron by night and said: “Get up, get out from among my people, both you and the other Israelites.
Miyi ɖasubɔ Yehowa abe ale si miegblɔe ene.
Go and serve Jehovah, just as you have said.
32 Mikplɔ miaƒe alẽhawo kple nyihawo hã yii abe ale si miegblɔe ene.
32 Take also your flocks and your herds and go, just as you have said.
Ke miyra nye hã.”
But you must also bless me.”

33 Eye Egiptetɔwo ƒo du ɖe dukɔ la nu be woadzo kaba le anyigba la dzi hegblɔ be: “Elabena mí katã míeku vɔ!” 34 Eya ta dukɔ la tsɔ woƒe amɔwɔ maʋamaʋã kpakple woƒe amɔwɔbluzewo bla ɖe woƒe avɔwo me tsɔ ɖo abɔta.

33 And the Egyptians began to urge the people to depart quickly out of the land “because,” as they said, “we are all as good as dead!” 34 So the people carried their flour dough before it was leavened, with their kneading troughs wrapped up in their clothing on their shoulder.
35 Eye Israel-viwo wɔ abe ale si Mose gblɔe ene, eye wobia klosalonuwo, sikanuwo kple awuwo Egiptetɔwo.
35 The Israelites did what Moses had told them and asked the Egyptians for articles of silver and of gold as well as clothing.
36 Yehowa na Egiptetɔwo ve dukɔ la nu, eye wotsɔ nu siwo wobia la na wo; ale woha Egiptetɔwo.
36 Jehovah gave the people favor in the eyes of the Egyptians, so that they gave them what they asked for, and they plundered the Egyptians.
37 Eye Israel-viwo dze mɔ tso Ramses ɖo ta Sukot; woade ŋutsu afɔzɔla akpe alafa ade, womexlẽ ɖeviwo o.
37 Then the Israelites departed from Rameses for Succoth, about 600,000 men on foot, besides children.
38 Eye ame vovovowo ƒe ha gã aɖe hã yi kpli wo, eye wokplɔ alẽwo kple nyiwo ɖe asi, wonye lãha gã aɖe ŋutɔ.
38 And a vast mixed company also went with them, as well as flocks and herds, a great number of livestock.
39 Le mɔa dzi la, wotsɔ amɔwɔ si wotsɔ tso Egipte la mè amɔwɔ maʋamaʋã bolo nogoewo.
39 They began to bake the dough that they brought from Egypt into round loaves of unleavened bread.
Amɔwɔ la meʋã o, elabena ɖe wonya wo le Egipte kpata, eye womekpɔ asinu ɖa nu ɖe asi o.
It was not leavened, because they had been driven out of Egypt so suddenly that they had not prepared any provisions for themselves.
40 Ɣeyiɣi si Israel-viwo, si nye dukɔ si nɔ Egipte, nɔ dzronyigba dzi la katã le ƒe alafa ene blaetɔ̃.
40 The dwelling of the Israelites, who had dwelled in Egypt, was 430 years.
41 Eye le ƒe alafa ene blaetɔ̃awo ƒe nuwuwu, le gbe ma gbe tututu la, Yehowa ƒe amehawo katã ʋu dzo le Egipte-nyigba dzi.
41 At the end of the 430 years, on this very day, all the multitudes of Jehovah went out of the land of Egypt.
42 Enye zã si woaɖu ale si Yehowa kplɔ wo dzoe le Egipte-nyigba dzi la ƒe ŋkekenyui.
42 It is a night on which they will celebrate Jehovah’s bringing them out of the land of Egypt.
Israel-viwo katã aɖo ŋku zã sia dzi atsɔ ade bubu Yehowa ŋu le woƒe dzidzimewo katã me.
This night is to be observed to Jehovah by all the people of Israel throughout their generations.
43 Eye Yehowa gblɔ na Mose kple Aron be, “Esiae nye Ŋutitotoŋkekenyui la ŋuti ɖoɖo: Amedzro aɖeke mekpɔ mɔ aɖui o.
43 Then Jehovah said to Moses and Aaron, “This is the statute of the Passover: No foreigner may eat of it.
44 Ke ne ame aɖe tsɔ ga ƒle kluvi aɖe la, ekema wòatso aʋa nɛ.
44 But if someone has a slave man who was purchased with money, you should circumcise him.
Ema ko hafi wòkpɔ mɔ aɖui.
Only then may he share in eating it.
45 Amedzro si va tsi mia gbɔ kple apadɔwɔla mekpɔ mɔ aɖui o.
45 A settler and a hired worker may not eat of it.
46 Miɖu alẽvi la le aƒe ɖeka me.
46 In one house it is to be eaten.
Migatsɔ lã la ƒe ɖeke do go le aƒea me yi xexe o. Eye migagbã eƒe ƒu aɖeke o.
You must not take any of the meat outside of the house, and you must not break any of its bones.
47 Israel ƒe ha blibo la katã naɖu ŋkekenyui la.
47 All the assembly of Israel are to celebrate it.
48 Ke ne amedzro si le gbɔwò di vevie be yeaɖu Ŋutitotoŋkekenyui na Yehowa la, ekema eƒe me ŋutsuwo katã natso aʋa.
48 If a foreigner resides with you and he wants to celebrate the Passover to Jehovah, every male of his must be circumcised.
Ema ko hafi wòate ŋu aɖui, eye wòazu abe Israel vidzidzi ene.
Then he may come near to celebrate it, and he will become like a native of the land.
Ke aʋamatsomatsotɔ aɖeke mekpɔ mɔ aɖui o.
But no uncircumcised man may eat of it.
49 Se ɖeka nakplɔ dumevi kple amedzro si le mia dome la siaa.”
49 One law will apply for the native and for the foreigner who is residing among you.”
50 Eye Israel-viwo katã wɔ abe ale si tututu Yehowa de se na Mose kple Aron ene.
50 So all the Israelites did just as Jehovah had commanded Moses and Aaron.
Nenema pɛpɛpɛ wowɔ.
They did just so.
51 Eye gbe ma gbe tututu la, Yehowa kplɔ Israel-viwo kple woƒe amehawo dzoe le Egipte-nyigba la dzi.
51 On this very day, Jehovah brought the Israelites along with their multitudes out of the land of Egypt.
Eye Yehowa gblɔ na Mose be: “Azɔ àkpɔ nu si mawɔ Farao.
So Jehovah said to Moses: “Now you will see what I will do to Pharaoh.
Nye alɔ sesẽ ana wòaɖe asi le wo ŋu, eye nye alɔ sesẽ ana wòanya wo le eƒe anyigba dzi.”
A mighty hand will force him to send them away, and a mighty hand will force him to drive them out of his land.”
2 Eye Mawu gagblɔ na Mose be: “Nyee nye Yehowa.
2 Then God said to Moses: “I am Jehovah.
3 Nyee ɖe ɖokuinye fia Abraham, Isak kple Yakob abe Mawu Ŋusẽkatãtɔ ene, ke le nye ŋkɔ Yehowa gome ya la, nyemeɖe ɖokuinye fia wo bliboe o.
3 And I used to appear to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob as God Almighty, but with regard to my name Jehovah I did not make myself known to them.
4 Mebla nu kpli wo hã be matsɔ Kanaan-nyigba, si dzi wonye amedzro le kpɔ la, ana wo.
4 I also established my covenant with them to give them the land of Canaan, the land in which they lived as foreigners.
5 Azɔ mese Israel-viwo, ame siwo Egiptetɔwo wɔ kluviwoe la ƒe hũɖeɖe, eye meɖo ŋku nye nubabla la dzi.
5 Now I myself have heard the groaning of the people of Israel, whom the Egyptians are enslaving, and I remember my covenant.
6 “Eya ta gblɔ na Israel-viwo be: ‘Nyee nye Yehowa; maɖe mi tso Egiptetɔwo ƒe kɔkuti te, maɖe mi tso kluvinyenye me, madrɔ̃ ʋɔnu sesẽe, eye matsɔ alɔ si medo ɖa aɖe mi.

6 “Therefore, say to the Israelites: ‘I am Jehovah, and I will bring you out from under the burdens of the Egyptians and rescue you from their slavery, and I will reclaim you with an outstretched arm and with great judgments.
7 Maxɔ mi mianye nye dukɔ, eye manye miaƒe Mawu; eye miadze sii be nyee nye Yehowa mia Mawu, ame si aɖe mi tso Egiptetɔwo ƒe kɔkuti te.
7 And I will take you in as my people, and I will be your God, and you will certainly know that I am Jehovah your God who is bringing you out from under the burdens of Egypt.
8 Makplɔ mi ayi anyigba si ŋu meka atam le be matsɔ ana Abraham, Isak kple Yakob la dzi; matsɔe ana mi wòanye mia tɔ.
8 And I will bring you into the land that I swore with an oath to give to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob; and I will give it to you as something to possess.
Nyee nye Yehowa.’”
I am Jehovah.’”
9 Emegbe Mose gblɔ nya siawo na Israel-viwo, ke womeɖo to Mose o le dziɖeleameƒo kple kluvidɔ sesẽ la ta.
9 Moses later gave this message to the Israelites, but they did not listen to Moses because of their discouragement and because of the harsh slavery.

10 Eye Yehowa gblɔ na Mose be: 11 “Yi Egipte-fia Farao gbɔ nàgblɔ nɛ be wòaɖe asi le Israel-viwo ŋu woadzo le eƒe anyigba dzi.” 12 Ke Mose gblɔ na Yehowa be: “Kpɔ ɖa, Israel-viwo meɖo tom o; ke aleke wɔ Farao aɖo to nye ame si nu menya ƒona na o la?” 13 Ke Yehowa gagblɔ nya si wòle be woagblɔ na Israel-viwo kple Egipte-fia Farao, ne woakplɔ Israel-viwo adzoe le Egipte-nyigba dzi la na Mose kple Aron.

10 Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying: 11 “Go in and tell Pharaoh, Egypt’s king, that he should send the Israelites away out of his land.” 12 However, Moses replied to Jehovah: “Look! The Israelites have not listened to me; how will Pharaoh ever listen to me, as I speak with difficulty?” 13 But Jehovah again told Moses and Aaron what commands to give to the Israelites and to Pharaoh, Egypt’s king, in order to bring the Israelites out of the land of Egypt.
14 Wo fofowo ƒe aƒekɔwo ƒe tatɔwoe nye: Ruben, si nye Israel ƒe ŋgɔgbevi la, eya ƒe viwoe nye Hanok, Palu, Hezron kple Karmi.
14 These are the heads of the house of their fathers: The sons of Reuben, Israel’s firstborn, were Hanoch, Pallu, Hezron, and Carmi.
Ame siawoe nye Ruben ƒomeawo.
These are the families of Reuben.
15 Simeon viwoe nye Yemuel, Yamin, Ohad, Yakin, Zohar kple Saul, ame si nye Kanaan nyɔnu aɖe ƒe vi.
15 The sons of Simeon were Jemuel, Jamin, Ohad, Jachin, Zohar, and Shaul, the son of a Canaanite woman.
Woawoe nye Simeon ƒomeawo.
These are the families of Simeon.
16 Lewi viwo ƒe ŋkɔwoe nye esi le woƒe ƒomeawo ƒe dzidzime nu: Gerson, Kohat kple Merari.
16 These are the names of the sons of Levi, according to their family descents: Gershon, Kohath, and Merari.
Lewi ƒe agbenɔƒewo le ƒe alafa ɖeka blaetɔ̃ vɔ adre.
The length of Levi’s life was 137 years.
17 Gerson viwoe nye Libni kple Simei le woƒe ƒomeawo nu.
17 The sons of Gershon were Libni and Shimei, according to their families.
18 Kohat viwoe nye Amram, Yizhar, Hebron kple Uziel.
18 The sons of Kohath were Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel.
Kohat ƒe agbenɔƒewo le ƒe alafa ɖeka blaetɔ̃ vɔ etɔ̃.
The length of Kohath’s life was 133 years.
19 Merari viwoe nye Mahli kple Musi.
19 The sons of Merari were Mahli and Mushi.
Esiawoe nye Lewi viwo ƒe ƒomewo le woƒe ƒomeawo ƒe dzidzime nu.
These were the families of the Levites, according to their family descents.
20 Ke Amram ɖe fofoa nɔvinyɔnu Yokebed.
20 Now Amram took Jochebed, his father’s sister, as his wife.
Eye wòdzi Aron kple Mose nɛ.
She bore him Aaron and Moses.
Amram ƒe agbenɔƒewo le ƒe alafa ɖeka blaetɔ̃ vɔ adre.
The length of Amram’s life was 137 years.
21 Yizhar viwoe nye Kora, Nefeg kple Zikri.
21 The sons of Izhar were Korah, Nepheg, and Zichri.
22 Uziel viwoe nye Misael, Elizafan kple Sitri.
22 The sons of Uzziel were Mishael, Elzaphan, and Sithri.
23 Ke Aron ɖe Aminadab vinyɔnu Eliseba, si nye Nahason nɔvinyɔnu.
23 Now Aaron took Elisheba, Amminadab’s daughter, the sister of Nahshon, as his wife.
Eye wòdzi Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar kple Itamar nɛ.
She bore him Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.
24 Kora viwoe nye Asir, Elkana kple Abiasaf.
24 The sons of Korah were Assir, Elkanah, and Abiasaph.
Esiawoe nye Kora viwo ƒe ƒomeawo.
These were the families of the Korahites.
25 Aron viŋutsu Eleazar ɖe Putiel vinyɔnuwo dometɔ ɖeka.
25 Elezar, Aaron’s son, took one of the daughters of Putiel as his wife.
Eye wòdzi Finehas nɛ.
She bore him Phinehas.
Ame siawoe nye Lewi viwo ƒe tatɔ siwo le wo fofowo ƒe aƒekɔwo nu le woƒe ƒomeawo nu.
These are the heads of the paternal houses of the Levites, according to their families.
26 Aron kple Mose siawoe Yehowa gblɔ na be: “Mikplɔ Israel dukɔa dzoe le Egipte-nyigba dzi hatsotso hatsotso.” 27 Woawoe ƒo nu kple Egipte-fia Farao be yewoakplɔ Israel dukɔa adzoe le Egipte.

26 This is the Aaron and Moses to whom Jehovah said: “Bring the people of Israel out of the land of Egypt, company by company.” 27 It was they who spoke to Pharaoh, Egypt’s king, to bring the people of Israel out of Egypt.
Ame siawoe nye Mose kple Aron.
It was this Moses and Aaron.
28 Eye gbe si gbe Yehowa ƒo nu kple Mose le Egipte-nyigba dzi la, 29 Yehowa gblɔ na Mose be: “Nyee nye Yehowa.
28 On that day when Jehovah spoke to Moses in the land of Egypt, 29 Jehovah told Moses: “I am Jehovah.
Gblɔ nya siwo katã gblɔm mele na wò la na Egipte-fia Farao.” 30 Eye Mose gblɔ na Yehowa be: “Kpɔ ɖa, nu menya ƒona nam o, aleke wɔ Farao aɖo tom?”
Speak to Pharaoh, king of Egypt, everything I am speaking to you.” 30 Then Moses said before Jehovah: “Look!
Yehowa gagblɔ na Mose be: “Kplɔ ame siwo nèkplɔ tso Egipte-nyigba dzi la miayi anyigba si ŋu meka atam ɖo na Abraham, Isak kple Yakob be, ‘Wò dzidzimeviwo matsɔe ana’ la dzi.
I speak with difficulty, so how will Pharaoh ever listen to me?” Jehovah said further to Moses: “Go on your way from here with the people whom you led up out of the land of Egypt.
2 Madɔ mawudɔla aɖe ɖe ŋgɔwò, eye manya Kanaantɔwo, Amoritɔwo, Hititɔwo, Perizitɔwo, Hivitɔwo kple Yebusitɔwo ɖa.

Journey to the land about which I swore to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, saying, ‘To your offspring I will give it.’ 2 I will send an angel ahead of you and drive out the Canaanites, the Amorites, the Hittites, the Perizzites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites.
3 Miyi anyigba si dzi notsi kple anyitsi le sisim le la dzi.
3 Go up to a land flowing with milk and honey.
Gake nyemanɔ mia dome ayi o, elabena dukɔ kɔlialiatɔ mienye, be magatsrɔ̃ mi ɖa keŋkeŋ le mɔa dzi o.”
But I will not go in the midst of you, for you are an obstinate people, and I might exterminate you on the way.”
4 Esi dukɔ la se nya vɔ̃ sia la, wode asi konyifafa me, eye wo dometɔ aɖeke meɖo atsyɔ̃ o.
4 When the people heard this harsh word, they began to mourn, and not one of them put on his ornaments.
5 Yehowa gagblɔ na Mose be: “Gblɔ na Israel-viwo be, ‘Dukɔ sẽdzime mienye.
5 Jehovah said to Moses: “Say to the Israelites, ‘You are an obstinate people.
Mate ŋu age ɖe mia dome atsrɔ̃ mi ɖa keŋkeŋ le aɖabaƒoƒo ɖeka me.
In one moment I could go through the midst of you and exterminate you.
Eya ta miɖe miaƒe atsyɔ̃ɖonuwo ɖi, ne makpɔ nu si mawɔ mi.’” 6 Eya ta Israel-viwo ɖe woƒe atsyɔ̃ɖonuwo ɖi tso ɣemaɣi le Horeb To la gbɔ.
So now keep your ornaments off while I consider what to do to you.’” 6 So from Mount Horeb onward, the Israelites refrained from wearing their ornaments.
7 Azɔ Mose yi ɖatu eƒe agbadɔ ɖe asaɖa la godo, le adzɔge tso asaɖa la gbɔ, eye wòyɔe be takpegbadɔ.
7 Now Moses took his tent and pitched it outside the camp, at some distance from the camp, and he called it a tent of meeting.
Ne ame aɖe di be yeabia nu Yehowa la, edona yia takpegbadɔ si le asaɖaa godo la gbɔ.
Everyone inquiring of Jehovah would go out to the tent of meeting, which was outside the camp.
8 Ne Mose yina agbadɔa me la, dukɔ blibo la katã tsona, eye wo dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe tɔna ɖe eƒe agbadɔ nu, eye wonɔa Mose yome kpɔm va se ɖe esime wòge ɖe agbadɔ la me.
8 As soon as Moses went out to the tent, all the people would rise and stand at the entrance of their own tents, and they would gaze after Moses until he entered into the tent.
9 Ne Mose nya ge ɖe agbadɔa me teti ko la, alilikpo dodo la ɖiɖina va nɔa agbadɔ la nu, eye Mawu ƒoa nu kple Mose.
9 As soon as Moses would go into the tent, the pillar of cloud would come down and stand at the entrance of the tent while God spoke with Moses.
10 Ne dukɔ la kpɔ alilikpo dodo la ɖiɖi va tɔ ɖe agbadɔa nu la, dukɔ blibo la katã tsona hedea ta agu, ame sia ame le eƒe agbadɔ nu.
10 When all the people saw the pillar of cloud standing at the entrance of the tent, each of them rose and bowed down at the entrance of his own tent.
11 Yehowa ƒoa nu kple Mose ŋkume kple ŋkume, abe ale si ko ame ƒoa nu kple ehavi ene.
11 Jehovah spoke to Moses face-to-face, just as one man would speak to another man.
Ne etrɔ yina asaɖaa me la, eƒe subɔvi Yosua, Nun vi, si nye eƒe kpeɖeŋutɔ la, ya medzona le agbadɔ la me o.
When he returned to the camp, Joshua the son of Nun, his minister and attendant, would not depart from the tent.
12 Eye Mose gblɔ na Yehowa be: “Ègblɔ nam be, ‘Kplɔ dukɔ sia miayi,’ gake mèna menya ame si nèɖe kpe ɖe ŋunye la o.
12 Now Moses said to Jehovah: “See, you are saying to me, ‘Lead this people up,’ but you have not let me know whom you will send with me.
Ègblɔ hã be, ‘Menya wò kple wò ŋkɔ, eye meve nuwò hã.’ 13 Meɖe kuku, ne ève nunye la, ekema na manya wò mɔwo, ale be manya wò, ne nàyi edzi ave nunye.

Moreover, you have said, ‘I know you by name, and you have also found favor in my eyes.’ 13 Please, if I have found favor in your eyes, make me know your ways, so that I may know you and continue to find favor in your eyes.
Eye ɖo ŋui be wò amewoe dukɔ sia nye.” 14 Eya ta egblɔ be: “Nye ŋutɔ mayi kpli wò, eye mana gbɔdzɔe wò.” 15 Mose ɖo eŋu be: “Ne wò ŋutɔ màyi kpli mí o la, ekema mègana míaho le afi sia o.

Consider, too, that this nation is your people.” 14 So he said: “I myself will go with you, and I will give you rest.” 15 Then Moses said to him: “If you yourself are not going along, do not lead us up from here.
16 Ne mèyi kpli mí o ɖe, aleke woawɔ anya be ève nunye, eye be ève nye kple wò dukɔ la nu?
16 How will it be known that I have found favor in your eyes, I and your people?
Ðe menye esiae ana nye kple wò dukɔ la míato vovo tso dukɔ bubu ɖe sia ɖe si le anyigba dzi la gbɔ oa?”
Is it not by your going along with us, so that I and your people will be distinguished from every other people on the face of the earth?”

17 Yehowa gagblɔ na Mose be: “Mawɔ nya sia si gblɔm nèle la hã dzi, elabena meve nuwò, eye menya wò kple wò ŋkɔ.” 18 Eye Mose gblɔ be: “Meɖe kuku, na makpɔ wò ŋutikɔkɔe.” 19 Gake egblɔ be: “Mana nàkpɔ nye nyuiwɔwɔ katã teƒe, eye maɖe gbeƒã nye ŋkɔ Yehowa le ŋgɔwò; mave ame si nu medi be mave la nu, eye makpɔ nublanui na ame si medi be makpɔ nublanui na la.” 20 Eye wògblɔ kpee be: “Màte ŋu akpɔ nye ŋkume o, elabena ame aɖeke mate ŋu akpɔm aganɔ agbe o.”

17 Jehovah went on to say to Moses: “I will also do this thing that you request, because you have found favor in my eyes and I know you by name.” 18 Then he said: “Please show me your glory.” 19 But he said: “I will make all my goodness pass before your face, and I will declare before you the name of Jehovah; and I will favor the one whom I favor, and I will show mercy to the one to whom I show mercy.” 20 But he added: “You cannot see my face, for no man can see me and live.”
21 Yehowa gagblɔ be: “Kpɔ ɖa, teƒe aɖe le gbɔnye afii; va tɔ ɖe agakpe la dzi.
21 Jehovah said further: “Here is a place near me. Station yourself on the rock.
22 Ne nye ŋutikɔkɔe tso eme va yina la, maɣla wò ɖe agado la me, eye matsɔ nye asi atsyɔ dziwò va se ɖe esime metso eme va yi.
22 When my glory is passing by, I will place you in a crevice of the rock, and I will shield you with my hand until I have passed by.
23 Emegbe maɖe nye asi ɖa, eye àkpɔ yonyeme.
23 After that I will take my hand away, and you will see my back.
Ke nye ŋkume ya, màte ŋu akpɔe o.”
But my face may not be seen.”
“Emegbe nàtsɔ akasiati akpa vɔsamlekpui la wòadidi abɔklugui atɔ̃, eye wòakeke abɔklugui atɔ̃.
“You will make the altar of acacia wood; it will be five cubits long and five cubits wide.
Vɔsamlekpui la nanɔ dzogoe ene me, eye wòakɔ abɔklugui etɔ̃.
The altar should be square and three cubits high.
2 Wɔ dzowo eye nàli wo ɖe vɔsamlekpui la ƒe dzogoe eneawo dzi woanye vɔsamlekpuia ƒe akpa aɖe, eye nàfa akɔbli ɖe eŋu.
2 You will make horns on its four corners; the horns will be part of the altar, and you will overlay the altar with copper.
3 Wɔ eƒe dzofilɔgbawo kple eƒe sofiwo, agba goboewo, gaflowo kple dzoɖenuwo, eye nàtsɔ akɔbli awɔ eŋu nuwo katã.
3 You will make buckets for clearing away its ashes, along with shovels, bowls, forks, and fire holders, and you will make all its utensils of copper.
4 Azɔ tsɔ akɔbligavi lɛlɛlɛwo wɔ eƒe gaɖɔ; eye nàwɔ akɔblisigɛ ene ɖe gaɖɔ la ƒe dzogoe eneawo dzi.
4 You will make a grating for the altar, a network of copper, and on the network four rings of copper at its four corners.
5 Tsɔ gaɖɔ la de vɔsamlekpui la me, le eƒe to la ƒe anyime, eye wòanɔ vɔsamlekpui la titina lɔƒo.
5 You will set it down below the rim of the altar, and the network will extend partway down into the altar.
6 Tsɔ akasiati kpa kpowo na vɔsamlekpui la, eye nàfa akɔbli ɖe wo ŋu.
6 You will make poles of acacia wood for the altar and overlay them with copper.
7 Woaƒo kpoawo ɖe asigɛawo me, ale be kpoawo nanɔ vɔsamlekpuia ƒe axa eveawo ne woatsɔ akɔe.
7 The poles will be inserted into the rings so that the poles are on the two sides of the altar when it is carried.
8 Ʋuƒoe nàtsɔ awɔ vɔsamlekpui la wòanɔ abe aɖaka ene.
8 You will make the altar in the form of a hollow chest of planks.
Wɔe abe ale si tututu wòɖee fia wò le toa dzi ene.
It should be made just as He showed you on the mountain.
9 “Eyome nàɖe xɔxɔnu ɖi na avɔgbadɔ la.
9 “You will make the courtyard of the tabernacle.
Na woatsɔ avɔ siwo wotsɔ ɖeti ɣi biɖibiɖi dada lɔ̃ la atɔ kpɔ ɖe eŋu, eye eƒe axa si trɔ ɖe anyiehe gome la nadidi abɔklugui alafa ɖeka.
For the south side, facing south, the courtyard will have hanging curtains of fine twisted linen, 100 cubits long for the one side.
10 Woatsɔ akɔbli awɔ eƒe kpɔti blaeveawo kple woƒe anyinɔ blaeveawo.
10 It will have 20 pillars with 20 copper socket pedestals.
Eye woatsɔ klosalo awɔ kpɔtiawo ƒe nulénuwo kple woƒe kpeƒe ƒe gaviwo.
The hooks of the pillars and their connectors are of silver.

11 Avɔ si woatsɔ atɔ kpɔ ɖe dziehekpa dzi la hã nadidi abɔklugui alafa ɖeka, woatsɔ akɔbli awɔ eƒe kpɔti blaeveawo kple woƒe anyinɔ blaeveawo, eye woatsɔ klosalo awɔ kpɔtiawo ƒe nulénuwo kple woƒe kpeƒe ƒe gaviwo.
11 The hanging curtains for the north side will also be 100 cubits long, along with its 20 pillars and their 20 copper socket pedestals, with silver hooks and connectors for the pillars.
12 Avɔ si woatsɔ atɔ kpɔ ɖe xɔxɔnu la ƒe ɣetoɖoƒekpa dzi nadidi abɔklugui blaatɔ̃; woƒe kpɔtiawo nanye ewo, eye woƒe anyinɔwo nanye ewo.
12 There are to be hanging curtains on the west side for 50 cubits across the width of the courtyard, with ten pillars and ten socket pedestals.
13 Xɔxɔnu la ƒe ɣedzeƒekpa dzi nakeke abɔklugui blaatɔ̃.
13 The width of the courtyard on the east side toward the sunrise is 50 cubits.
14 Eye avɔ si woatsɔ atɔ kpɔ ɖe kekeme sia ƒe akpa ɖeka la nadidi abɔklugui wuiatɔ̃, woƒe kpɔtiwo nanye etɔ̃, eye woƒe anyinɔwo nanye etɔ̃.
14 There will be 15 cubits of hanging curtains on the one side, with three pillars and three socket pedestals.
15 Avɔ si woatsɔ atɔ kpɔ ɖe kekemea ƒe akpa evelia nadidi abɔklugui wuiatɔ̃, woƒe kpɔtiwo nanye etɔ̃, eye woƒe anyinɔwo nanye etɔ̃.
15 And for the other side, there will be 15 cubits of hanging curtains, with three pillars and three socket pedestals.
16 “Na woatsɔ ka blɔtɔ, alẽfuka si wode ama aɖabɛ dzĩtɔe, ka dzĩ kple ɖeti ɣi biɖibiɖi dada alɔ̃ mɔnuvɔ na xɔxɔnu la, wòadidi abɔklugui blaeve; woƒe kpɔtiwo nanye ene, eye woƒe anyinɔwo nanye ene.

16 “The entrance of the courtyard should have a screen 20 cubits long made of blue thread, purple wool, scarlet material, and fine twisted linen woven together, with four pillars and their four socket pedestals.
17 Woafa klosalo ɖe kpɔti siwo wotsɔ tɔ kpɔ ɖe xɔxɔnua ŋu la ŋuti, eye woatsɔ klosalo awɔ woƒe kpeƒegaviwo kple nulénuwo, gake woatsɔ akɔbli awɔ woƒe anyinɔwoe.
17 All the pillars surrounding the courtyard will have silver fasteners and silver hooks, but their socket pedestals will be of copper.
18 Xɔxɔnukpɔ la nadidi abɔklugui alafa ɖeka, wòakeke abɔklugui blaatɔ̃, eye wòakɔ abɔklugui atɔ̃; woatsɔ ɖeti ɣi biɖibiɖi dada alɔ̃e, eye woatsɔ akɔbli awɔ eƒe anyinɔwoe.
18 The courtyard is to be 100 cubits long, 50 cubits wide, and 5 cubits high, made from fine twisted linen, and it should have copper socket pedestals.
19 Woatsɔ akɔbli awɔ nu siwo katã ŋu dɔ woawɔ le avɔgbadɔ la ŋu, kple eƒe agbadɔtsyotiwo katã kpakple xɔxɔnu la ƒe tsyotiwo katã.
19 All the utensils and the items used in the service of the tabernacle, as well as its tent pins and all the pins of the courtyard, are to be of copper.
20 “Gblɔ na Israel-viwo be woadi amititsetse ƒe ami nyuitɔ na akaɖi la, ale be woate ŋu asi akaɖigbɛawo ɣesiaɣi.
20 “You are to command the Israelites to bring you pure, beaten olive oil for the lighting, in order to keep the lamps burning constantly.
21 Aron kple viaŋutsuwo nakpɔ egbɔ be akaɖia le bibim ɖaa tso fiẽ va se ɖe ŋdi le Yehowa ŋkume le takpegbadɔ la me, le xɔmetsovɔ si le Ðaseɖinua gbɔ la ŋgɔ.
21 In the tent of meeting, outside the curtain that is near the Testimony, Aaron and his sons will arrange to keep the lamps lit from evening until morning before Jehovah.
Esia anye ɖoɖo na Israel-viwo ɖaa tso dzidzime yi dzidzime.
It is a lasting statute for all their generations to be carried out by the Israelites.
Le Israel-viwo ƒe ʋuʋu tso Egipte-nyigba dzi ƒe ɣleti etɔ̃lia megbe, le ŋkeke ma dzi tututu, wova ɖo Sinai gbedzi.
In the third month after the Israelites went out of the land of Egypt, on the same day, they came to the wilderness of Sinai.
2 Woho tso Refidim va Sinai gbedzi heƒu asaɖa anyi ɖe gbea dzi.
2 They pulled away from Rephidim and came to the wilderness of Sinai and camped in the wilderness.
Israel ƒu asaɖa anyi ɖe afi ma le to la ŋgɔ.
Israel camped there in front of the mountain.

3 Eye Mose lia to la yi Mawu vavã la gbɔ, eye Yehowa yɔe tso to la dzi gblɔ be: “Ale nàgblɔ na Yakob ƒe aƒe la, si nye Israel-viwoe nye esi: 4 ‘Miawo ŋutɔwo miekpɔ nu si mewɔ Egiptetɔwo ne matsɔ mi ɖe hɔ̃ ƒe aʋalawo dzi ava ɖokuinye gbɔe.

3 Then Moses went up to the true God, and Jehovah called to him from the mountain, saying: “This is what you are to say to the house of Jacob and to tell the Israelites, 4 ‘You have seen for yourselves what I did to the Egyptians, in order to carry you on wings of eagles and bring you to myself.
5 Azɔ ne mieɖo to nye gbe pɛpɛpɛ, eye mielé nye nubabla la me ɖe asi la, miazu nye nunɔamesi tɔxɛ le dukɔ bubuwo katã dome, elabena anyigba bliboa katã tɔnyee.
5 Now if you will strictly obey my voice and keep my covenant, you will certainly become my special property out of all peoples, for the whole earth belongs to me.
6 Miazu nunɔlawo ƒe fiaɖuƒe kple dukɔ kɔkɔe nam.’
6 You will become to me a kingdom of priests and a holy nation.’
Nya siawoe nàgblɔ na Israel-viwo.”
These are the words that you are to say to the Israelites.”
7 Eya ta Mose yi ɖayɔ dukɔ la ƒe ametsitsiwo hegblɔ nya siwo katã Yehowa gblɔ nɛ la na wo.
7 So Moses went and summoned the elders of the people and declared to them all these words that Jehovah had commanded him.
8 Emegbe dukɔ blibo la ɖo eŋu kple nu sɔsɔe be: “Nya siwo katã Yehowa gblɔ la, míawɔ wo dzi.”
8 After that all the people answered unanimously: “All that Jehovah has spoken, we are willing to do.”
Enumake Mose trɔ yi ɖagblɔ dukɔ la ƒe nyawo na Yehowa.
Moses immediately took the people’s response to Jehovah.
9 Eye Yehowa gblɔ na Mose be: “Kpɔ ɖa, megbɔna gbɔwò le alilikpo dodo me, ale be ne mele nu ƒom kpli wò la, dukɔ la nasee, ne woaxɔ wò hã dziwò ase ɣesiaɣi.”
9 And Jehovah said to Moses: “Look! I am coming to you in a dark cloud, so that the people may hear when I speak with you and so that they may always put faith in you as well.”
Eye Mose gblɔ dukɔ la ƒe nyawo na Yehowa.
Then Moses reported the words of the people to Jehovah.
10 Eye Yehowa gblɔ na Mose be: “Yi dukɔ la gbɔ, eye nàkɔ wo ŋu egbe kple etsɔ, eye woanya woƒe awuwo.
10 Then Jehovah said to Moses: “Go to the people and sanctify them today and tomorrow, and they must wash their clothing.
11 Woanɔ klalo le ŋkeke etɔ̃a gbe, elabena Yehowa aɖi va Sinai To la dzi le ŋkeke etɔ̃a gbe le dukɔ blibo la katã ŋkume.
11 And they must be ready for the third day, because on the third day Jehovah will come down upon Mount Sinai before the eyes of all the people.
12 Ðo liƒo ɖe to la ŋu godoo va kpe na dukɔ la, eye nàgblɔ na wo be, ‘Mikpɔ nyuie be miagalia to la, alo agogoe aka asi eŋu o.
12 You must set boundaries for the people all around it and tell them, ‘Beware of going up to the mountain or touching its border.
Ame si ka asi toa ŋu la, ku kee wòaku.
Anybody touching the mountain will surely be put to death.
13 Ame aɖeke maka asi ame ma ŋu o, ke boŋ woaƒu kpee alo woaƒo nu ɖee.
13 No hand is to touch him, but he will either be stoned or be shot through.
Eɖanye amegbetɔ alo lã o, mele be woanɔ agbe o.’
Whether beast or man, he will not live.’
Gake ne wose kpẽ ƒe ɖiɖi ko hafi woate ŋu ava to la gbɔ.”
But at the sound of the ram’s horn they may come up to the mountain.”
14 Eye Mose ɖi tso toa dzi va dukɔa gbɔ hekɔ wo ŋu, eye wonya woƒe awuwo.
14 Then Moses went down from the mountain to the people, and he began to sanctify the people, and they washed their clothing.
15 Eye wògblɔ na dukɔ la be: “Minɔ klalo le ŋkeke etɔ̃a gbe.
15 He said to the people: “Get ready for the third day.
Migadɔ nyɔnu gbɔ o.”
Abstain from sexual relations.”
16 Le ŋkeke etɔ̃a gbe ƒe ŋdi la, dzi le gbe ɖem hele dzo kem, alilikpo dodo aɖe va tsyɔ to la tame, eye kpẽ aɖe le ɖiɖim sesĩe, ale be dukɔ blibo si le asaɖaa me la le dzodzom nyanyanya.
16 On the morning of the third day, there was thunder and lightning, and there was a heavy cloud on the mountain and a very loud sound of a horn, and all the people in the camp began to tremble.
17 Eye Mose kplɔ dukɔ la do goe le asaɖa la me be woaɖado go Mawu vavã la, eye wotɔ ɖe to la gɔme.
17 Moses now brought the people out of the camp to meet the true God, and they took their place at the base of the mountain.
18 Eye Sinai To blibo la katã le dzudzɔ tum, elabena Yehowa ɖi va edzi le dzo me; eye eƒe dzudzɔ le dzi dem abe dzokpomedzudzɔ babla ene, eye to blibo la katã le ʋuʋum kpekpekpe.
18 Mount Sinai smoked all over, because Jehovah came down upon it in fire; and its smoke was rising like the smoke of a kiln, and the whole mountain was trembling violently.
19 Esi kpẽa ƒe ɖiɖi nu le sesẽm ɖe edzi la, Mose ƒo nu, eye Mawu vavã la ɖo eŋu kple gbe sesẽ aɖe.
19 As the sound of the horn grew louder and louder, Moses spoke, and the voice of the true God answered him.
20 Ale Yehowa ɖi va Sinai To la dzi.
20 So Jehovah came down upon Mount Sinai to the top of the mountain.
Eye Yehowa yɔ Mose be wòava toa tame, eye Mose liae yi.
Then Jehovah called Moses to the top of the mountain, and Moses went up.
21 Eye Yehowa gblɔ na Mose be: “Ði yi ɖaxlɔ̃ nu dukɔ la, be woagate kpɔ be yewoava kpɔ Yehowa o. Ne menye nenema o la, wo dometɔ geɖe aku.
21 Jehovah now said to Moses: “Go down and warn the people not to try to force their way through to look at Jehovah, or many of them will perish.

22 Eye na nunɔlawo, ame siwo tena vaa Yehowa gbɔ edziedzi la, nakɔ wo ɖokuiwo ŋu, ale be Yehowa nagahe to na wo o.” 23 Eye Mose gblɔ na Yehowa be: “Dukɔ la mate ŋu alia Sinai To la o, elabena wò ŋutɔ èxlɔ̃ nu mí esi nègblɔ nam be: ‘Ðo liƒo ɖe to la ŋu, eye nàwɔe kɔkɔe.’” 24 Gake Yehowa gblɔ nɛ be: “Ði yi, eye wò kple Aron miatrɔ va, ke nunɔlawo kple dukɔa ya megagbɔ liƒo la ŋu be yewoalia toa ava Yehowa gbɔ o, be magatu nu kpli wo o.” 25 Ale Mose ɖi yi dukɔ la gbɔ hegblɔe na wo.

22 And let the priests who regularly come near to Jehovah sanctify themselves, so that Jehovah may not strike them.” 23 Moses then said to Jehovah: “The people are not able to come up to Mount Sinai because you already warned us, saying, ‘Set boundaries around the mountain, and make it sacred.’” 24 However, Jehovah said to him: “Go, descend, and come back up, you and Aaron with you, but do not let the priests and the people force their way through to come up to Jehovah, so that he may not strike them.” 25 So Moses descended to the people and told them.
Eye Yehowa gblɔ na Mose be: “Kpɔ ɖa, mewɔ wò abe Mawu ene na Farao, eye nɔviwò Aron azu wò nyagblɔɖila.
Jehovah then said to Moses: “See, I have made you like God to Pharaoh, and Aaron your own brother will become your prophet.
