2 Gblɔ nya siwo katã magblɔ na wò la na nɔviwò Aron ne wòagblɔe na Farao, eye aɖe asi le Israel-viwo ŋu woadzo le eƒe anyigba dzi.
2 You are to repeat everything that I will command you, and Aaron your brother will speak to Pharaoh, and he will send the Israelites away from his land.
3 Maɖe mɔ Farao ƒe dzi me nasẽ, eye mawɔ dzesi kple nukunu geɖewo le Egipte-nyigba dzi.
3 As for me, I will allow Pharaoh’s heart to become obstinate, and I will multiply my signs and my miracles in the land of Egypt.
4 Ke Farao maɖo to mi o; eye mado nye asi ɖe Egipte dzi, madrɔ̃ ʋɔnu sesẽe ahakplɔ nye amehawo, nye dukɔ Israel, adzoe le Egipte-nyigba dzi.
4 But Pharaoh will not listen to you, and I will lay my hand upon Egypt and bring my multitudes, my people, the Israelites, out of the land of Egypt with great judgments.

5 Eye ne medo nye asi ɖe Egipte gbɔ la, ekema Egiptetɔwo adze sii be, nyee nye Yehowa, eye makplɔ Israel-viwo adzoe le wo dome.” 6 Eye Mose kple Aron wɔ abe ale si Yehowa de se na wo ene; nenema pɛpɛpɛ wowɔ.

5 And the Egyptians will certainly know that I am Jehovah when I stretch out my hand against Egypt and bring the Israelites out from among them.” 6 Moses and Aaron did what Jehovah had commanded them; they did just so.
7 Mose xɔ ƒe blaenyi, eye Aron xɔ ƒe blaenyi vɔ etɔ̃, esime woƒo nu kple Farao.
7 Moses was 80 years old and Aaron was 83 years old when they spoke to Pharaoh.
8 Eye Yehowa gblɔ na Mose kple Aron be: 9 “Ne Farao gblɔ na mi be, ‘Miwɔ nukunu aɖe’ la, ekema nàgblɔ na Aron be: ‘Tsɔ wò atikplɔ la ƒu gbe ɖe anyigba le Farao ŋkume.’
8 Jehovah now said to Moses and Aaron: 9 “If Pharaoh says to you, ‘Perform a miracle,’ then tell Aaron, ‘Take your rod and throw it down before Pharaoh.’
Atrɔ azu da gã aɖe.” 10 Eya ta Mose kple Aron yi Farao gbɔ, eye wowɔ pɛpɛpɛ abe ale si Yehowa de se ene.
It will become a big snake.” 10 So Moses and Aaron went in to Pharaoh and did exactly as Jehovah had commanded.
Aron tsɔ eƒe atikplɔ ƒu gbe ɖe anyigba le Farao kple eƒe subɔviwo ŋkume, eye wòtrɔ zu da gã aɖe.
Aaron threw his rod down before Pharaoh and his servants, and it became a big snake.
11 Gake Farao yɔ eƒe nunyalawo kple dzotɔwo vɛ, eye Egipte ƒe akunyawɔlawo hã wɔ nenema ke to woƒe akunyawɔwɔ me.
11 However, Pharaoh summoned the wise men and the sorcerers, and the magic-practicing priests of Egypt also did the same thing with their magic.
12 Wo dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe tsɔ eƒe atikplɔ ƒu gbe ɖe anyigba, eye wotrɔ zu da gãwo; ke Aron ƒe atikplɔ la mi woƒe atikplɔawo.
12 Each one threw down his rod, and they became big snakes; but Aaron’s rod swallowed up their rods.
13 Gake Farao gasẽ dzi me kokoko, eye meɖo to wo o, abe ale si tututu Yehowa gblɔe ene.
13 Still, Pharaoh’s heart became obstinate, and he did not listen to them, just as Jehovah had said.
14 Eye Yehowa gblɔ na Mose be: “Farao sẽ dzi me.
14 Then Jehovah said to Moses: “Pharaoh’s heart is unresponsive.
Egbe be yemaɖe asi le dukɔ la ŋu woadzo o.
He has refused to send the people away.
15 Yi Farao gbɔ ŋdi kanya; kpɔ ɖa, ayi tɔsisi la nu!
15 Go to Pharaoh in the morning. Look! He is going out to the water!
Tɔ ɖe Nil-tɔsisi la to be nàdo goe, eye nàtsɔ atikplɔ, si trɔ zu da va yi la, ɖe asi.
And you should station yourself to meet him by the edge of the Nile River; and take with you in your hand the rod that turned into a serpent.
16 Eye nàgblɔ nɛ be, ‘Yehowa, Hebritɔwo ƒe Mawu lae, dɔm ɖe gbɔwò be: “Ðe asi le nye amewo ŋu woayi aɖasubɔm le gbedzi,” gake ègbe toɖoɖo va se ɖe fifi.
16 And you must say to him, ‘Jehovah the God of the Hebrews has sent me to you, and he says: “Send my people away so that they may serve me in the wilderness,” but you have not obeyed until now.
17 Ale Yehowa gblɔe nye esi: “Esia mee nàdze sii le be nyee nye Yehowa.
17 This is what Jehovah says: “By this you will know that I am Jehovah.
Kpɔ ɖa, matsɔ nye atikplɔ aƒo Nil-tɔsisia me tsia dzi, eye wòatrɔ azu ʋu.
Here I am striking the water that is in the Nile River with the rod that is in my hand, and it will turn into blood.
18 Tɔmelã siwo le Nil-tɔsisia me la aku, Nil-tɔsisia aʋẽ kũu, eye Egiptetɔwo mate ŋu ano Nil-tɔsisia me tsi o.”’”
18 And the fish that are in the Nile will die, and the Nile will stink, and the Egyptians will find it impossible to drink water from the Nile.”’”
19 Eye Yehowa gblɔ na Mose be: “Gblɔ na Aron be: ‘Tsɔ wò atikplɔ la, eye nàdo asi ɖe Egipte tsiwo, tɔsisiwo, tɔʋuwo, tsiteƒewo kple woƒe tsi siwo woku da ɖi la katã dzi, ne woatrɔ azu ʋu.’

19 Then Jehovah said to Moses: “Say to Aaron, ‘Take your rod and stretch out your hand over the waters of Egypt, over its rivers, over its canals, over its marshes, and over all its reservoirs, that they may become blood.’
Ʋu anɔ Egipte-nyigba blibo la katã dzi, anɔ atigoewo kple kpezɔwo gɔ̃ hã me.” 20 Enumake Mose kple Aron wɔ abe ale si tututu Yehowa de see ene.
There will be blood in all the land of Egypt, even in the wooden and stone containers.” 20 Immediately Moses and Aaron did just as Jehovah had commanded.
Aron do atikplɔ la ɖe dzi ƒo Nil-tɔsisi la me tsi la dzi le Farao kple eƒe subɔviwo ŋkume, eye tɔsisi la me tsiwo katã trɔ zu ʋu.
He lifted up the rod and struck the water that was in the Nile River before the eyes of Pharaoh and his servants, and all the water that was in the river was turned into blood.
21 Ale tɔmelã siwo le tɔsisia me la ku, eye tɔsisi la de asi ʋeʋẽ me kũu, ale be Egiptetɔwo megate ŋu no Nil-tɔsisia me tsi o, eye ʋu xɔ afi sia afi le Egipte-nyigba blibo la dzi.
21 And the fish that were in the river died, and the river began to stink, and the Egyptians were unable to drink water from the Nile, and there was blood throughout the land of Egypt.
22 Ke Egipte ƒe akunyawɔlawo tsɔ woƒe ayemeɖaŋuwo wɔ nenema ke; ale be Farao gasẽ dzi me kokoko, eye meɖo to wo o, abe ale si tututu Yehowa gblɔe ene.

22 Nevertheless, the magic-practicing priests of Egypt did the same thing with their secret arts, so that Pharaoh’s heart continued to be obstinate, and he did not listen to them, just as Jehovah had said.
23 Ale Farao trɔ yi eƒe aƒe me, eye nu sia hã mede dzi gbɔ nɛ o.
23 Then Pharaoh returned to his house, and he did not take this to heart either.
24 Eya ta Egiptetɔwo katã ɖe do ɖe Nil-tɔsisia ŋu godoo be woakpɔ tsi ano, elabena womate ŋu ano Nil-tɔsisi la me tsi o.
24 So all the Egyptians were digging all around the Nile for water to drink, because they could not drink any water of the Nile.
25 Eye esi Yehowa ƒo Nil-tɔsisi la, exɔ ŋkeke adre sɔŋ.
25 And seven full days passed after Jehovah struck the Nile.
Eye Yehowa gblɔ na Mose be: “Kpa kpe gbadzɛ eve abe gbãtɔawo ene, ne maŋlɔ nya siwo le kpe gbadzɛ gbãtɔ siwo nègbã dzi la, ɖe wo dzi.
Then Jehovah said to Moses: “Carve out for yourself two tablets of stone like the first ones, and I will write on the tablets the words that appeared on the first tablets, which you shattered.
2 Dzra ɖo na etsɔ ŋdi, elabena àlia Sinai To la le ŋdi me ava gbɔnye le toa tame.
2 Get ready for the morning, as you will go up in the morning to Mount Sinai and station yourself before me there on the top of the mountain.
3 Ke ame aɖeke megayi kpli wò o. Azɔ hã, ame aɖeke meganɔ to bliboa ƒe afi aɖeke o.
3 But nobody may go up with you, and nobody else should be seen anywhere on the mountain.
Eye alẽ alo nyi aɖeke hã megava ɖu gbe le to ma gbɔ o.”
Not even the flocks or herds should graze in front of that mountain.”
4 Ale Mose kpa kpe gbadzɛ eve abe gbãtɔawo ene, eye wòfɔ ŋdi kanya helia Sinai To la, abe ale si tututu Yehowa de se nɛ ene, eye wòtsɔ kpe gbadzɛ eveawo ɖe asi.

4 So Moses carved out two tablets of stone like the first ones and got up early in the morning and went up Mount Sinai, just as Jehovah had commanded him, and he took the two tablets of stone in his hand.
5 Eye Yehowa ɖi va le alilikpo la me henɔ egbɔ le afi ma, eye wòɖe gbeƒã eƒe ŋkɔ Yehowa.
5 Then Jehovah came down in the cloud and stationed himself with him there and declared the name of Jehovah.

6 Eye Yehowa va to eŋu yi hele gbeƒã ɖem be: “Yehowa, Yehowa, Mawu nublanuikpɔla kple veveseɖeamenula, ame si medoa dziku kabakaba o, eye eƒe lɔlɔ̃ si nu metsina o kple eƒe nuteƒewɔwɔ sɔ gbɔ, 7 ame si ɖea lɔlɔ̃ si nu metsina o fiaa ame akpeakpewo, eye wòtsɔa vodada, dzidada kple nu vɔ̃ kena, ke megbea tohehe na fɔɖila o; ame si hea fofowo ƒe vodada ŋuti tohehe vaa viwo kple tɔgbuiyɔviwo dzi, vaa dzidzime etɔ̃lia kple dzidzime enelia dzi.”

6 Jehovah was passing before him and declaring: “Jehovah, Jehovah, a God merciful and compassionate, slow to anger and abundant in loyal love and truth, 7 showing loyal love to thousands, pardoning error and transgression and sin, but he will by no means leave the guilty unpunished, bringing punishment for the error of fathers upon sons and upon grandsons, upon the third generation and upon the fourth generation.”
8 Enumake Mose bɔbɔ hetsyɔ mo anyi.
8 Moses hurried to bow low to the earth and prostrate himself.

9 Eye wògblɔ be: “Oo Yehowa, azɔ ne ève nunye la, ekema Yehowa, togbɔ be míenye dukɔ sẽdzime hã, meɖe kuku, nɔ mía dome míayi, eye nàtsɔ míaƒe vodada kple míaƒe nu vɔ̃ ake ahaxɔ mí míazu tɔwò.” 10 Eɖo eŋu be: “Kpɔ ɖa, mele nu blam kpli mi. Mawɔ nukunu siwo tɔgbi womewɔ le anyigba blibo la dzi alo dukɔwo katã dome kpɔ o la le wò dukɔ blibo la ŋkume, eye dukɔ si dome nèle la katã akpɔ Yehowa ƒe dɔwɔwɔ, elabena nu si wɔ ge mala la adzi ŋɔ na mi.

9 Then he said: “If, now, I have found favor in your eyes, O Jehovah, then please, Jehovah, go along with us in our midst, although we are an obstinate people, and forgive our error and our sin, and take us as your own possession.” 10 In turn he said: “Here I am making a covenant: Before all your people, I will do wonderful things that have never been done in all the earth or among all the nations, and all the people among whom you live will see the work of Jehovah, for it is an awe-inspiring thing that I am doing with you.
11 “Lé se si dem mele na wò egbea la me ɖe asi.
11 “Pay attention to what I am commanding you today.
Kpɔ ɖa, manya Amoritɔwo, Kanaantɔwo, Hititɔwo, Perizitɔwo, Hivitɔwo kple Yebusitɔwo ɖa le ŋgɔwò.
Here I am driving out from before you the Amorites, the Canaanites, the Hittites, the Perizzites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites.
12 Kpɔ nyuie be nàgabla nu kple anyigba si dzi yim nèle la dzi nɔlawo o, ne wòagazu mɔ̃ na mi o.
12 Be careful that you do not make a covenant with the inhabitants of the land to which you are going, or it may prove to be a snare among you.
13 Ke boŋ mikaka woƒe vɔsamlekpuiwo, mimu woƒe trɔ̃sɔtiwo, eye milã woƒe Asera-tiwo ƒu anyi.
13 But you are to pull down their altars, you are to shatter their sacred pillars, and their sacred poles you are to cut down.
14 Mègade ta agu na mawu bubu aɖeke o, elabena Yehowa nye ame si biaa ɖokuitsɔtsɔna blibo.
14 You must not bow down to another god, for Jehovah is known for requiring exclusive devotion.
Ɛ̃, enye Mawu si biaa ɖokuitsɔtsɔna blibo.
Yes, he is a God who requires exclusive devotion.
15 Mègabla nu kple anyigba la dzi nɔlawo o, elabena ne wole ahasi wɔm kple woƒe mawuwo hele vɔ sam na woƒe mawuwo la, woakpe wò, eye nàva ɖu woƒe vɔsanu la ƒe ɖe.

15 Be careful not to make a covenant with the inhabitants of the land, because when they prostitute themselves to their gods and sacrifice to their gods, someone will invite you and you will eat from his sacrifice.
16 Ekema àva ɖe wo vinyɔnuwo na viwòŋutsuwo, eye wo vinyɔnuawo awɔ ahasi kple woƒe mawuwo ahana viwòŋutsuwo hã nava wɔ ahasi kple woƒe mawuawo.
16 Then you will surely take some of their daughters for your sons, and their daughters will prostitute themselves to their gods and cause your sons to prostitute themselves to their gods.
17 “Mègalólo ga tsɔ wɔ legba o.
17 “You must not make gods of cast metal.
18 “Nɔ Amɔwɔ Maʋamaʋã Bolo Ŋkekenyui la ɖum.
18 “You are to observe the Festival of Unleavened Bread.
Ŋkeke adre nàɖu amɔwɔ maʋamaʋã bolo la le ɣeyiɣi si woɖo la dzi le ɣleti si nye Abib me, abe ale si tututu mede se na wòe ene, elabena ɣleti si nye Abib mee nèʋu dzo le Egipte.
You will eat unleavened bread, just as I have commanded you; do this for seven days at the appointed time in the month of Abib, because it was in the month of Abib that you came out of Egypt.
19 “Viŋutsu sia viŋutsu si ʋu dɔ nu la, tɔnyee, eye nyi kple alẽ ƒe vi gbãtɔ siwo nye atsu le wò lãha la katã me la, tɔnyee.
19 “Every firstborn male is mine, including all your livestock, whether the first male bull or sheep.
20 Tsɔ alẽ ɖɔli tedzi ƒe ŋgɔgbevi.
20 The firstling of a donkey you are to redeem with a sheep.
Ke ne màɖɔlii o la, ekema nàŋe kɔ le enu.
But if you do not redeem it, then you must break its neck.
Gake ele be nàxe fe ɖe wò ŋgɔgbeviŋutsuwo katã ya ta.
You are to redeem every firstborn of your sons.
Mia dometɔ aɖeke nagava ŋkunyeme asi gbɔlo o.
No one may appear before me empty-handed.
21 “Ŋkeke ade nàwɔ dɔ, ke le ŋkeke adrelia dzi la, nàdzudzɔ.
21 “Six days you are to work, but on the seventh day you will rest.
Eɖanye agbleŋlɔɣi alo nuŋeɣi o, ele be nàɖi ɖe eme.
Even during plowing time and in harvest, you will rest.
22 “Ðu Kwasiɖawo Ƒe Ŋkekenyui la eye nàtsɔ luŋeŋe gbãtɔwo vɛ le eɖuɣi, eye nàɖu Nukuƒoƒoƒu Ŋkekenyui la hã le ƒea ƒe nuwuwu lɔƒo.
22 “And you will celebrate your Festival of Weeks with the first ripe fruits of the wheat harvest, and the Festival of Ingathering at the turn of the year.
23 “Wò ŋutsuwo katã nava Aƒetɔ vavã Yehowa, Israel ƒe Mawu la, ŋkume zi etɔ̃ le ƒea me.
23 “Three times a year, all your men are to appear before the true Lord, Jehovah, the God of Israel.
24 Elabena manya dukɔwo ɖa le ŋgɔwò, eye makeke wò liƒowo ɖe enu, ne èyi be yeado ɖe Yehowa wò Mawu ŋkume zi etɔ̃ le ƒea me la, wò anyigba mabiã ŋu na ame aɖeke o.

24 For I will drive the nations away from before you, and I will enlarge your territory, and nobody will desire your land while you are going up to see the face of Jehovah your God three times a year.
25 “Mègatsɔ nu ʋaʋã aɖeke kpe ɖe nye vɔsalã ƒe ʋu ŋu atsɔ asa vɔe o.
25 “You must not offer the blood of my sacrifice along with anything leavened.
Eye Ŋutitotoŋkekenyui ƒe vɔsalã la megatsi anyi ŋu nake ɖe edzi o.
The sacrifice of the festival of the Passover should not be kept overnight until the morning.
26 “Tsɔ wò anyigbadzikutsetse gbãtɔwo ƒe nyuitɔwo va Yehowa wò Mawu ƒe aƒe me.
26 “The best of the first ripe fruits of your soil you are to bring to the house of Jehovah your God.
“Mègaɖa gbɔ̃vi le dadaa ƒe notsi me o.”
“You must not boil a young goat in its mother’s milk.”
27 Yehowa gagblɔ na Mose be: “Ŋlɔ nya siawo ɖi, elabena nya siawo dzie nu, si blam mele kpli wò kpakple Israel la, nɔ te ɖo.” 28 Eye wònɔ Yehowa gbɔ le afi ma ŋkeke blaene kple zã blaene sɔŋ.

27 Jehovah went on to say to Moses: “You are to write down these words, because in accordance with these words, I am making a covenant with you and with Israel.” 28 And he remained there with Jehovah 40 days and 40 nights.
Meɖu nu o, eye meno tsi hã o.
He ate no bread and drank no water.
Eye wòŋlɔ nubabla la me nyawo, siwo nye Se Ewoawo, ɖe kpe gbadzɛawo dzi.
And He wrote on the tablets the words of the covenant, the Ten Commandments.
29 Azɔ Mose ɖi tso Sinai Toa dzi, eye wòlé Ðaseɖiɖikpe gbadzɛ eveawo ɖe asi.
29 Moses then came down from Mount Sinai, and the two tablets of the Testimony were in his hand.
Ke esi Mose ɖi tso toa dzi la, menya be esi yeƒo nu kple Mawu ta la, yeƒe mo nɔ keklẽm o.
When he came down from the mountain, Moses did not know that the skin of his face was emitting rays because he had been speaking with God.
30 Esi Aron kple Israel-viwo katã kpɔ Mose la, wokpɔ be eƒe mo nɔ keklẽm, eye wonɔ vɔvɔ̃m be yewoate ɖe eŋu.
30 When Aaron and all the Israelites saw Moses, they noticed that the skin of his face emitted rays and they were afraid to go near him.
31 Mose yɔ wo, eye Aron kple ha la ƒe tatɔwo katã trɔ va egbɔ, eye Mose ƒo nu kpli wo.
31 But Moses called to them, so Aaron and all the chieftains of the assembly came to him, and Moses spoke with them.
32 Ema megbe la, Israel-viwo katã te ɖe eŋu, eye wògblɔ se siwo katã Yehowa de le Sinai Toa dzi la na wo.
32 After that all the Israelites came near to him, and he gave them all the commands that Jehovah had given him on Mount Sinai.
33 Ne Mose ƒo nu kpli wo vɔ la, etsɔa motsyɔnu tsyɔa mo.
33 When Moses would finish speaking with them, he would put a veil over his face.
34 Gake ne Mose yina Yehowa ŋkume be yeaƒo nu kplii la, eɖea motsyɔnu la ɖa, va se ɖe esime wògado go.
34 But when Moses would go in before Jehovah to speak with him, he would take off the veil until he went out.
Eye wòva gblɔa se si wode nɛ la na Israel-viwo.
Then he went out and revealed to the Israelites the commands he had received.
35 Israel-viwo kpɔnɛ be Mose ƒe mo nɔa keklẽm; eye Mose gbugbɔa motsyɔnu la tsyɔa mo, va se ɖe esime wògage ɖe eme be yeaƒo nu kple Mawu.
35 And the Israelites saw that the skin of Moses’ face emitted rays; then Moses put the veil back over his face until he went in to speak with God.

Eye Yehowa gblɔ na Mose be: “Yi Farao gbɔ, elabena nyee ɖe mɔ eya ŋutɔ kple eƒe subɔviwo ƒe dzi me sẽ, bena mawɔ dzesi siawo le eŋkume, 2 ne nàgblɔ nu siwo gbegbe metu kple Egipte kple dzesi siwo mewɔ le wo dome la na viwòwo kple tɔgbuiyɔviwòwo; eye miadze sii be nyee nye Yehowa.”

Then Jehovah said to Moses: “Go in to Pharaoh, for I have allowed his heart and the hearts of his servants to become unresponsive, so that I may display these signs of mine right before him, 2 and in order that you may declare to your sons and your grandsons how severely I have dealt with Egypt and what signs I have performed among them; and you will certainly know that I am Jehovah.”
3 Eya ta Mose kple Aron yi Farao gbɔ ɖagblɔ nɛ be: “Ale Yehowa, Hebritɔwo ƒe Mawu la, gblɔe nye esi: ‘Va se ɖe ɣekaɣie nàgbe ɖokuiwò bɔbɔ ɖe tenye?
3 So Moses and Aaron went in to Pharaoh and said to him: “This is what Jehovah the God of the Hebrews has said, ‘How long will you refuse to submit to me?
Ðe asi le nye dukɔ ŋu woayi aɖasubɔm.
Send my people away so that they may serve me.
4 Elabena ne ègbe be yemaɖe asi le nye dukɔ la ŋu o la, ekema makplɔ ʋetsuviwo ava wò anyigba dzi etsɔ.
4 For if you keep refusing to send my people away, here I am bringing locusts within your boundaries tomorrow.
5 Woatsyɔ anyigba la dzi ale gbegbe be anyigba la magadze o.
5 And they will cover the surface of the earth, and it will not be possible to see the ground.
Woaɖu nu siwo susɔ, siwo kpetsi la gblẽ ɖi na mi kple miaƒe ati siwo katã le totom le gbe me la keŋkeŋ.
They will eat up what escaped the hail and was left for you, and they will eat all your trees that are growing in the field.
6 Eye woayɔ wò xɔwo, wò subɔviwo ƒe xɔwo kple Egiptetɔwo katã ƒe xɔwo me ale gbegbe be, anye nu si tɔgbi womekpɔ kpɔ tso esime mia fofowo kple mia tɔgbuiwo nɔ anyi va se ɖe egbe o.’”

6 They will fill your houses, the houses of all your servants, and the houses of all Egypt to an extent that your fathers and your grandfathers never saw from the time they have been in this land until today.’”
Eye wòtrɔ dzo le Farao gbɔ.
With that he turned and went out from Pharaoh.
7 Emegbe Farao ƒe subɔviwo gblɔ nɛ be: “Va se ɖe ɣekaɣie ŋutsu sia anye afɔku na mí?
7 Then Pharaoh’s servants said to him: “How long will this man continue to menace us?
Ðe asi le ameawo ŋu woayi aɖasubɔ Yehowa woƒe Mawu la.
Send the men away so that they may serve Jehovah their God.
Mèkpɔe be Egipte dome gblẽ keŋ oa?” 8 Eya ta wogbugbɔ yɔ Mose kple Aron va Farao gbɔ, eye wògblɔ na wo be: “Miheyi ɖasubɔ Yehowa mia Mawu la.
Do you not yet realize that Egypt has been ruined?” 8 So Moses and Aaron were brought back to Pharaoh, and he said to them: “Go, serve Jehovah your God.

Gake ame kawoe le yiyi ge?” 9 Mose ɖo eŋu be: “Mía kple míaƒe ɖekakpuiwo, ɖetugbuiwo, míaƒe ame tsitsiwo, mía viŋutsuwo kple mía vinyɔnuwo, míaƒe alẽwo kple míaƒe nyiwo míayi, elabena míeyina ŋkekenyui ɖu ge na Yehowa.” 10 Eɖo eŋu na wo be: “Ne meɖe asi le mia kple mia viwo ŋu miedzo la, ke Yehowa li kpli mi vavã!

But just who will be going?” 9 Then Moses said: “We will go with our young people, our old people, our sons, our daughters, our sheep, and our cattle, because we will hold a festival to Jehovah.” 10 He said to them: “If I ever send you and your children away, then Jehovah is indeed with you!
Edze ƒãa be tame vɔ̃e mieɖo.
It is clear that you intend to do something evil.
11 Kpao!
11 No!
Miaƒe ŋutsuwo ɖeɖe koe ayi aɖasubɔ Yehowa, elabena emae miebia.”
Only your men may go and serve Jehovah, for that is what you requested.”
Eye wonya wo ɖa le Farao ŋkume.
With that they were driven out from before Pharaoh.

12 Eye Yehowa gblɔ na Mose be: “Do wò asi ɖe Egipte-nyigba la dzi ne ʋetsuviwo nado ava Egipte-nyigba blibo la dzi ne woaɖu anyigba la dzi nu miemie siwo katã kpetsi la gblẽ ɖi la keŋkeŋ.” 13 Enumake Mose do eƒe atikplɔ la ɖe Egipte-nyigba la dzi, eye Yehowa na ɣedzeƒeya ƒo ɖe anyigba la dzi ŋkeke blibo la kple zã blibo la katã.

12 Jehovah now said to Moses: “Stretch out your hand over the land of Egypt for the locusts, so that they may come up over the land of Egypt and eat up all the vegetation of the land, everything that the hail has let remain.” 13 At once Moses stretched out his rod over the land of Egypt, and Jehovah caused an east wind to blow on the land all that day and all night.
Esi ŋu ke la, ɣedzeƒeya la lɔ ʋetsuviawo vɛ.
The morning came, and the east wind brought the locusts.
14 Ʋetsuviawo va ƒo ɖe Egipte-nyigba blibo la katã dzi, eye wodze ɖe Egipte-nyigba la ƒe afi sia afi taŋtaŋ.
14 And the locusts came up over all the land of Egypt and settled down on the whole territory of Egypt.
Menɔ bɔbɔe kura o; ʋetsuviwo meva alea gbegbe kpɔ o, eye wo tɔgbi aɖeke magava akpɔ o.
It was extremely severe; never before had there been so many locusts, nor would there ever be so many again.

15 Wotsyɔ anyigba blibo la katã dzi, eye anyigba la dzi do viviti; woɖu anyigba la dzi nu miemiewo katã kple atikutsetse siwo katã kpetsi la gblẽ ɖi; aŋgba mumu aɖeke megasusɔ ɖe atiwo dzi o, eye ɖeke megasusɔ ɖe nu miemie siwo le gbe me le Egipte-nyigba bliboa dzi la dzi o.

15 They covered the surface of the entire land, and the land grew dark with them; they devoured all the vegetation of the land and all the fruit of the trees that the hail had left; nothing green was left on the trees or on the vegetation of the field in all the land of Egypt.
16 Enumake Farao na woyɔ Mose kple Aron vɛ, eye wògblɔ na wo be: “Mewɔ nu vɔ̃ ɖe Yehowa mia Mawu la kple mia ŋu.
16 So Pharaoh quickly called Moses and Aaron and said: “I have sinned against Jehovah your God and against you.
17 Eya ta meɖe kuku, mitsɔ nye nu vɔ̃ kem zi mamlɛtɔ sia ko, eye miɖe kuku na Yehowa mia Mawu la be wòaɖe fuwɔame vɔ̃ɖi sia ɖa le dzinye.” 18 Ale wòdzo le Farao gbɔ yi ɖaɖe kuku na Yehowa.
17 Now, please, pardon my sin just this once, and plead with Jehovah your God that he just remove this deadly plague from upon me.” 18 So he went out from Pharaoh and pleaded with Jehovah.
19 Eye Yehowa na ya la trɔ zu ɣetoɖoƒeya sesẽ aɖe helɔ ʋetsuviawo dzoe yi ɖakɔ ɖe Ƒudzĩ la me.
19 Then Jehovah caused the wind to shift, and it became a very stiff west wind, and it carried the locusts away and drove them into the Red Sea.
Ʋetsuvi ɖeka pɛ hã mekpɔtɔ ɖe Egipte-nyigba blibo la ƒe afi aɖeke o.
Not a single locust remained in all the territory of Egypt.
20 Ke Yehowa ɖe mɔ Farao gasẽ dzi me, eye meɖe asi le Israel-viwo ŋu o.
20 However, Jehovah allowed Pharaoh’s heart to become obstinate, and he did not send the Israelites away.

21 Eye Yehowa gblɔ na Mose be: “Do wò asi ɖe dziƒo, ne viviti nado ɖe Egipte-nyigba la dzi, viviti la ado ale gbegbe be woate ŋu ali asi eŋu.” 22 Enumake Mose do eƒe asi ɖe dziƒo, eye viviti tsiɖitsiɖi do ɖe Egipte-nyigba blibo la katã dzi ŋkeke etɔ̃ sɔŋ.

21 Jehovah then said to Moses: “Stretch out your hand toward the heavens so that there may be darkness over the land of Egypt, a darkness so thick that it can be felt.” 22 Moses immediately stretched out his hand toward the heavens, and there was a dense darkness in all the land of Egypt for three days.
23 Ame aɖeke mete ŋu kpɔ nɔvia o, eye wo dometɔ aɖeke medzo le enɔƒe o ŋkeke etɔ̃ sɔŋ; ke kekeli le Israel-viwo katã ya ƒe nɔƒewo.
23 They did not see one another, and none of them got up from where they were for three days; but all the Israelites had light in their dwellings.
24 Emegbe Farao yɔ Mose gblɔ be: “Miheyi ɖasubɔ Yehowa.
24 Pharaoh then called Moses and said: “Go, serve Jehovah.
Negbe miaƒe alẽwo kple miaƒe nyiwo koe atsi anyi.
Only your sheep and your cattle will remain behind.
Miate ŋu akplɔ mia viwo gɔ̃ hã ayii.” 25 Ke Mose gblɔ be: “Wò ŋutɔe ana lã siwo míatsɔ asa vɔ kple esiwo míatsɔ asa numevɔ la mí, eye míatsɔ wo asa vɔ na Yehowa mía Mawu.
Even your children may go with you.” 25 But Moses said: “You yourself will also provide us with sacrifices and burnt offerings, and we will offer them to Jehovah our God.
26 Míaƒe lãhawo hã ayi kpli mí.
26 Our livestock will also go with us.

Míalɔ̃ be lã ɖeka teti natsi anyi o, elabena woƒe ɖe tsɔ ge míala asubɔ Yehowa mía Mawu la, eye míenya wo dometɔ siwo míatsɔ asubɔ Yehowa haɖe o, va se ɖe esime míeɖo afi ma hafi.” 27 Eya ta Yehowa ɖe mɔ Farao ƒe dzi me sẽ, eye melɔ̃ be yeaɖe asi le wo ŋu o.

Not an animal will be allowed to remain, because we will be using some of them to worship Jehovah our God, and we do not know what we will offer in worship to Jehovah until we arrive there.” 27 So Jehovah allowed Pharaoh’s heart to become obstinate, and he did not consent to send them away.
28 Farao gblɔ nɛ be: “Bu le nye ŋkuta!
28 Pharaoh said to him: “Get out of my sight!
Kpɔ ɖokuiwò dzi nyuie be màgakpɔ nye mo azɔ o, elabena gbe si gbe nàkpɔ nye mo la, ku kee nàku.” 29 Mose ɖo eŋu be: “Yoo, nyemagakpɔ wò mo azɔ o, abe ale si nègblɔ ene.”
Make sure that you do not try to see my face again, for on the day you see my face, you will die.” 29 To this Moses said: “Just as you have spoken, I will not try to see your face again.”

Emegbe Mose kple Aron yi Farao gbɔ ɖagblɔ nɛ be: “Ale Yehowa, Israel ƒe Mawu la, gblɔe nye esi: ‘Ðe asi le nye dukɔ la ŋu ne woayi aɖaɖu ŋkekenyui nam le gbedzi.’” 2 Ke Farao gblɔ be: “Ame kae nye Yehowa, ne maɖo to eƒe gbe ahaɖe asi le Israel ŋu wòayi?

Afterward, Moses and Aaron went in and said to Pharaoh: “This is what Jehovah the God of Israel says, ‘Send my people away so that they may celebrate a festival to me in the wilderness.’” 2 But Pharaoh said: “Who is Jehovah, that I should obey his voice to send Israel away?
Nyemenya Yehowa la o, eye nyemaɖe asi le Israel ŋu hã o.” 3 Ke wogblɔ be: “Hebritɔwo ƒe Mawu la ƒo nu kpli mí.
I do not know Jehovah at all, and what is more, I will not send Israel away.” 3 But they said: “The God of the Hebrews has communicated with us.

Míeɖe kuku, míedi be míazɔ mɔ ŋkeke etɔ̃ ayi gbedzi aɖasa vɔ na Yehowa mía Mawu la; ne menye nenema o la, atsɔ dɔvɔ̃ awu mí alo míatsi yi nu.” 4 Egipte-fia ɖo eŋu na wo be: “Mose kple Aron, nu ka tae miedi be miana dukɔ la nadzo le woƒe dɔwo gbɔ?

Please, we want to make a three-day journey into the wilderness and sacrifice to Jehovah our God; otherwise, he will strike us with disease or with the sword.” 4 The king of Egypt replied to them: “Why is it, Moses and Aaron, that you are taking the people away from their work?
Miyi miaƒe dɔwo dzi!” 5 Eye Farao gagblɔ be: “Mikpɔ ale si gbegbe dukɔ la sɔ gbɔe ɖa, hafi miebe yewoana woadzudzɔ woƒe dɔwo wɔwɔa!”
Return to your labor!” 5 And Pharaoh continued: “Look at how many people of the land there are, and you would have them rest from their labor.”
6 Gbe ma gbe ke Farao de se na dɔdzikpɔlawo kple woƒe dɔnunɔlawo be: 7 “Migadi gbe ƒuƒu na dukɔ la azɔ be woatsɔ amè anyikpewo o.
6 That same day, Pharaoh commanded the taskmasters and their foremen: 7 “You must no longer give straw to the people to make bricks.
Mina woawo ŋutɔwo nayi aɖadi gbe ƒuƒuawo.
Let them go and gather straw for themselves.
8 Gake mina woamè anyikpe agbɔsɔsɔme si woɖo na wo, si womèna tsã la.
8 But you must still impose on them the same quota of bricks as they made in the past.
Migaɖe ɖeke le edzi na wo o, elabena wole kuvia wɔm.
Do not reduce it for them, for they are relaxing.
Esia tae wole ɣli dom le gbɔgblɔm be: ‘Míedi be míadzo, míedi be míayi aɖasa vɔ na mía Mawu!’ 9 Mina woawɔ dɔ sesĩe wu tsã, eye woanɔ dɔwɔwɔ dzi, ne womagaɖo to alakpanyawo o.”
That is why they are crying out, ‘We want to go, we want to sacrifice to our God!’ 9 Make them work harder, and keep them busy so that they will not pay attention to lies.”
10 Eya ta dɔdzikpɔlawo kple woƒe dɔnunɔlawo yi ɖagblɔ na dukɔ la be: “Ale Farao gblɔe nye esi: ‘Nyemegale gbe ƒuƒu na ge mi azɔ o.
10 So the taskmasters and their foremen went out and said to the people: “Here is what Pharaoh has said, ‘I am giving you no more straw.

11 Miawo ŋutɔwo miyi ɖadi gbe ƒuƒu le afi sia afi si miakpɔe le, ke womaɖe miaƒe dɔwo dzi akpɔtɔ na mi o.’” 12 Ale dukɔ la kaka ɖe Egipte-nyigba blibo la katã dzi, be woaƒo ahɔ̃litiwo nu ƒu wòanye gbe ƒuƒu na wo.

11 Go and get your own straw for yourselves wherever you can find it, but your work will not be reduced at all.’” 12 Then the people scattered throughout all the land of Egypt to gather stubble for straw.

13 Eye dɔdzikpɔlawo ƒlɔ dzo ɖe wo te be: “Ele be mia dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe nawu eƒe dɔ nu gbe sia gbe, abe ale si ko wònɔ tsã esime wonaa gbe ƒuƒu mi ene.” 14 Azɔ woƒo Israel-viwo ƒe dɔnunɔlawo, ame siwo Farao ƒe dɔdzikpɔlawo ɖo wo nu la hebia wo be: “Nu ka tae miemè anyikpe agbɔsɔsɔme si woɖo na mi la wu enu etsɔ kple egbe siaa, abe ale si miewɔna tsã ene o?”

13 And the taskmasters kept urging them: “You must each finish your work every day, just as when straw was provided.” 14 Also the foremen of the Israelites, whom Pharaoh’s taskmasters had appointed over them, were beaten. They asked them: “Why did you not reach the quota of bricks that you used to make? It happened both yesterday and today.”
15 Eya ta Israel-viwo ƒe dɔnunɔlawo yi ɖafa konyi na Farao be: “Nu ka tae nèle nu wɔm ɖe wò subɔviwo ŋu alea? 16 Wometsɔ gbe ƒuƒu aɖeke na wò subɔviwo o, gake wole gbɔgblɔm na mí be: ‘Mimè anyikpe!’
15 So the foremen of the Israelites went in and complained to Pharaoh: “Why are you treating your servants this way? 16 No straw is given to your servants, yet they are saying to us, ‘Make bricks!’
Woƒo wò subɔviwo, evɔ wònye wò ŋutɔ wò amewo gbɔe vodada la tso hafi.” 17 Ke eɖo eŋu be: “Kuviatɔwo, kuviatɔwo mienye!
Your servants are beaten, but your own people are at fault.” 17 But he said: “You are relaxing, you are relaxing!
Esia tae miele gbɔgblɔm be: ‘Míedi be míayi aɖasa vɔ na Yehowa.’ 18 Miheyi ɖawɔ dɔa!
That is why you are saying, ‘We want to go, we want to sacrifice to Jehovah.’ 18 So now go, get back to work!
Womana gbe ƒuƒu mi o, gake miamè anyikpe agbɔsɔsɔme si woɖo na mi la pɛpɛpɛ.”
No straw will be given to you, but you must still produce your quota of bricks.”

19 Esi wòde se be, “Migaɖe anyikpe si miemèna gbe sia gbe la dzi vie gɔ̃ hã o” la, Israel-viwo ƒe dɔnunɔlawo kpɔe be yewoɖo xaxa gã aɖe me. 20 Esi wodzo le Farao gbɔ la, wodo go Mose kple Aron, ame siwo tɔ ɖe afi ma nɔ wo lalam.

19 Then the foremen of the Israelites saw that they were in serious trouble because of the order: “You must not reduce your daily quota of bricks at all.” 20 After that they met up with Moses and Aaron, who were standing there to meet them as they came out from Pharaoh.

21 Enumake wogblɔ na wo be: “Yehowa nekpɔ mi ne wòadrɔ̃e, elabena miena míezu ame nyɔŋuwo na Farao kple eƒe subɔviwo, eye miede yi wo si be woawu mí.” 22 Eye Mose trɔ ɖe Yehowa ŋu gblɔ be: “Yehowa, nu ka tae nèhe fukpekpe va dukɔ sia dzi?

21 At once they said to them: “May Jehovah look upon you and judge, since you have made Pharaoh and his servants despise us and you have put a sword in their hand to kill us.” 22 Then Moses turned to Jehovah and said: “Jehovah, why have you afflicted this people?
Nu ka tae nèdɔm? 23 Elabena tso esime meyi Farao ŋkume be maƒo nu le wò ŋkɔ me la, ɖeko wògale ŋuta sẽm le dukɔ sia ŋu wu, eye mèɖe wò dukɔ la kpɔ o.”
Why have you sent me? 23 From the time that I went in before Pharaoh to speak in your name, he has dealt worse with this people, and you have certainly not rescued your people.”
“Azɔ ɖe nɔviwò Aron kple viaŋutsu siwo nye Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar kple Itamar tso Israel-viwo dome, ne woazu nunɔlawo asubɔm.
“You are to summon from the Israelites your brother Aaron, along with his sons, so that he may serve as priest to me —Aaron, along with NAdab and Abihu, EleAzar and Ithamar, the sons of Aaron.
2 Eye nàtɔ awu kɔkɔewo na nɔviwò Aron, ne wòanye bubu kple atsyɔ̃ nɛ.
2 You are to make holy garments for Aaron your brother, for glory and beauty.
3 Ƒo nu kple aɖaŋudɔwɔla bibi siwo katã ƒe dzi me mede nunya ƒe gbɔgbɔe la be woatɔ Aron ƒe awuwo, ne woakɔ eŋu wòazu nunɔla asubɔm.
3 You are to speak to all those who are skillful, those whom I have filled with the spirit of wisdom, and they will make Aaron’s garments for his sanctification, so that he may serve as priest to me.

4 “Nu siwo woatɔ lae nye esi: akɔtaɖonu, kɔmewu, awu ʋlaya si ŋu abɔ mele o, awu ʋlaya si me wolɔ̃ atsyã siwo le dzogoe ene me ɖo, tablanu kple alidziblanu; woatɔ awu kɔkɔe siawo na nɔviwò Aron kple viawo be woazu nunɔlawo asubɔm.

4 “These are the garments that they will make: a breastpiece, an ephod, a sleeveless coat, a checkered robe, a turban, and a sash; they will make these holy garments for your brother Aaron and his sons, so that he may serve as priest to me.
5 Aɖaŋudɔwɔlaawo nazã sika, ka blɔtɔ, alẽfuka si wode ama aɖabɛ dzĩtɔe, ka dzĩ kple ɖeti ɣi biɖibiɖi atsɔ alɔ̃ woe.
5 The skilled workers will use the gold, the blue thread, the purple wool, the scarlet material, and the fine linen.
6 “Aɖaŋuvɔlɔ̃la natsɔ sika, ka blɔtɔ, alẽfuka si wode ama aɖabɛ dzĩtɔe, ka dzĩ kple ɖeti ɣi biɖibiɖi dada alɔ̃ kɔmewu la.
6 “They are to make the ephod of gold, blue thread, purple wool, scarlet material, and fine twisted linen, and it should be embroidered.
7 Woatɔ abɔtaɖonu ɖe kɔmewu la ƒe abɔta eveawo dzi atsɔ akpe wo ɖekae.
7 It is to have two attached shoulder pieces that join it at its two edges.
8 Eye woatsɔ nu mawo ke, siwo nye sika, ka blɔtɔ, alẽfuka si wode ama aɖabɛ dzĩtɔe, ka dzĩ kple ɖeti ɣi biɖibiɖi dada alɔ̃ alidziblanu si anɔ kɔmewu la dzi.
8 The woven belt, which is attached to the ephod for tying it securely in position, should be of the same materials: gold, blue thread, purple wool, scarlet material, and fine twisted linen.
9 “Eye nàtsɔ oniks-kpe eve, nàɖe Israel viŋutsuwo ƒe ŋkɔwo ɖe wo dzi; 10 ŋkɔ ade nanɔ kpe ɖeka dzi, eye ŋkɔ ade mamlɛawo nanɔ kpe evelia dzi le ɖoɖo si nu wodzi wo ɖo la nu.
9 “You are to take two onyx stones and engrave on them the names of the sons of Israel, 10 six names on the one stone and the six remaining names on the other stone, in the order of their births.
11 Na kpe xɔasi ŋudɔwɔla naɖe Israel viŋutsuwo ŋkɔwo ɖe kpe eveawo dzi abe ale si woɖea nu ɖe nutrenu dzi ene.
11 A stone engraver will engrave the names of the sons of Israel on the two stones as he would engrave a seal.
Nàtsɔ sika aɖo to na wo.
Then you are to have them mounted in gold settings.
12 Eye nàtsɔ kpe eveawo aɖo kɔmewu la ƒe abɔtaɖonuawo dzi wòanye ŋkuɖodzikpewo na Israel-viwo, ale be woƒe ŋkɔwo nanɔ Aron ŋu le Yehowa ŋkume le eƒe abɔtaɖonu eveawo dzi be wòanye ŋkuɖodzinu.

12 You are to put the two stones on the shoulder pieces of the ephod as memorial stones for the sons of Israel, and Aaron must carry their names before Jehovah on his two shoulder pieces as a memorial.
13 Eyome nàtsɔ sika aɖo to na wo, 14 eye nàtsɔ sika nyuitɔ awɔ kɔsɔkɔsɔ eve, nàgbi wo abe ka ene, eye nàku kɔsɔkɔsɔawo ɖe to si woɖo nɛ la ŋu.
13 You are to make settings of gold 14 and two chains of pure gold twisted like a cord, and you must attach the corded chains to the settings.
15 “Na aɖaŋuvɔlɔ̃la nalɔ̃ ʋɔnudrɔ̃kɔtaɖonu la.
15 “You are to have an embroiderer make the breastpiece of judgment.
Woatsɔ nu siwo wotsɔ lɔ̃ kɔmewu la ke alɔ̃e, siwo nye sika, ka blɔtɔ, alẽfuka si wode ama aɖabɛ dzĩtɔe, ka dzĩ kple ɖeti ɣi biɖibiɖi dada.
It should be made like the ephod, out of gold, blue thread, purple wool, scarlet material, and fine twisted linen.
16 Woawɔe ale be ne woŋe eme ɖe eve la, wòanɔ dzogoe ene me, wòadidi asi ɖeka, eye wòakeke asi ɖeka.
16 It should be square when doubled, a span long and a span wide.
17 Nàtsɔ kpe xɔasiwo aɖo eŋu, eye kpeawo nanɔ agbaka ene me.
17 You should set in it mounted stones, four rows of stones.
Agbaka gbãtɔ nanye rubi, topaz kple emerald.
The first row is ruby, topaz, and emerald.
18 Agbaka evelia nanye nofek, safir kple yaspis.
18 The second row is turquoise, sapphire, and jasper.
19 Agbaka etɔ̃lia nanye lesem, agat kple ametist.
19 The third row is leshem stone, agate, and amethyst.
20 Eye agbaka enelia nanye krisolit, oniks kple yasifi.
20 The fourth row is chrysOlite, onyx, and jade.
Woatsɔ sika aɖo to na wo.
They should be mounted in settings of gold.
21 Kpeawo nanɔ wuieve ɖe Israel viŋutsu wuieveawo ƒe ŋkɔwo nu.
21 The stones will correspond to the names of the 12 sons of Israel.
Woaɖe ŋkɔawo ɖe kpeawo dzi ɖekaɖeka, ŋkɔ ɖe sia ɖe le tsitre ɖi na to wuieveawo dometɔ ɖeka.
Each one should be engraved like a seal, each name representing one of the 12 tribes.
22 “Eye nàtsɔ sika nyuitɔ agbi ka wòanɔ abe kɔsɔkɔsɔ ene ɖe akɔtaɖonu la ŋu.
22 “You are to make wreathed chains on the breastpiece, like cords of pure gold.
23 Tsɔ sika wɔ asigɛ eve na akɔtaɖonu la, eye nàtsɔ asigɛ eveawo ade akɔtaɖonu la ƒe dzogoe eve dzi.
23 You are to make two rings of gold for the breastpiece and attach the two rings to the two ends of the breastpiece.
24 Emegbe nàtsɔ sikaka eveawo ade asigɛ eveawo me le akɔtaɖonu la ƒe dzogoeawo dzi.
24 You are to put the two cords of gold through the two rings at the ends of the breastpiece.
25 Tsɔ ka eveawo ƒe nugbɔ de asigɛ eveawo me, eye nàtsɔ wo aku kɔmewu la ƒe abɔtaɖonuawo le eƒe ŋgɔ.
25 You will put the two ends of the two cords through the two settings, and you must attach them to the shoulder pieces of the ephod, at the front.
26 Eye nàtsɔ sika awɔ asigɛ eve bubu atsɔ ade akɔtaɖonu la ƒe dzogoe eve mamlɛawo le eƒe akpa si le kɔmewua dzi, le eme gome.
26 You are to make two rings of gold and set them at the two ends on the inside edge of the breastpiece, facing the ephod.
27 Eye nàgatsɔ sika awɔ asigɛ eve ade kɔmewu la ŋgɔ le eƒe abɔtaɖonu eveawo ƒe anyime le ekpeƒe, wòanɔ alidziblanu la tame tututu le teƒe si wotɔe ɖe kɔmewu la dzi le.
27 You should make two more rings of gold on the front of the ephod, below the two shoulder pieces, close to where it is joined, above the woven belt of the ephod.
28 Woagbi ka blɔtɔ atsɔ ato akɔtaɖonu la ƒe asigɛawo me atsi ɖe kɔmewu la ƒe asigɛawo ŋu.
28 The breastpiece should be held in place by a blue cord, tying its rings to the rings of the ephod.
Esia alé akɔtaɖonu la ɖe kɔmewu la dzi le alidziblanu la tame, ale be maganɔ ʋaʋãm o.
This will keep the breastpiece in place on the ephod, above the woven belt.
29 “Israel viŋutsuwo ƒe ŋkɔwo nanɔ Aron ŋu le ʋɔnudrɔ̃kɔtaɖonu la dzi le eƒe dzi gbɔ ne eva Kɔkɔeƒe la, be wòanye ŋkuɖodzi le Yehowa ŋkume ɖaa.
29 “Aaron must carry the names of the sons of Israel on the breastpiece of judgment over his heart when he comes into the Holy as a constant memorial before Jehovah.
30 Eye nàtsɔ Urim kple Tumim la ade ʋɔnudrɔ̃kɔtaɖonu la me, ne woanɔ Aron ƒe dzi gbɔ ne eva Yehowa ŋkume, eye Israel-viwo ƒe ʋɔnudɔdrɔ̃wo nanɔ Aron ŋu le eƒe dzi gbɔ le Yehowa ŋkume ɖaa.

30 You will put the urim and the Thummim into the breastpiece of judgment, and they must be over Aaron’s heart when he comes in before Jehovah, and Aaron must carry the means for making judgments of the Israelites over his heart before Jehovah constantly.
31 “Emegbe na woatsɔ ka blɔtɔ ɖeɖe alɔ̃ awu ʋlaya si ŋu abɔ mele o.
31 “You are to make the sleeveless coat of the ephod entirely of blue thread.
32 Woalɔ̃e ahaɖe kɔme nɛ ɖe etitina.
32 There will be an opening at the top in the middle of it.
Avɔlɔ̃la naƒo to na kɔmea va kpe.
Its opening should have a border woven all around it by a loom worker.
Nenɔ abe gawu ƒe kɔme ene, be wòagavuvu o.
It should be like the opening of a coat of mail, so that it will not be torn.
33 Eye nàtsɔ ka blɔtɔ, alẽfuka si wode ama aɖabɛ dzĩtɔe, kple ka dzĩ alɔ̃ yevuboɖawo ɖe ete, eye woatsɔ sika awɔ nyawowoewo ɖe wo domee godoo va kpe.
33 You should make pomegranates of blue thread, purple wool, and scarlet material all around its hem, along with bells of gold in between them.
34 Sikanyawowoe ɖeka yevuboɖa ɖeka, sikanyawowoe ɖeka yevuboɖa ɖeka, le awu ʋlaya si ŋu abɔ mele o la toga le ete godoo va kpe.
34 You should alternate a bell of gold and a pomegranate, a bell of gold and a pomegranate, all around the hem of the sleeveless coat.
35 Aron nado awua ne ele subɔsubɔm, ale be ne eva kɔkɔeƒe la le Yehowa ŋkume alo wòdo go la, wòanɔ ɖiɖim le eŋu woase, be wòagaku o.
35 It must be worn by Aaron so that he may minister, and the sound from it must be heard when he goes into the sanctuary before Jehovah and when he comes out, so that he will not die.
36 “Tsɔ sika nyuitɔ wɔ ga falɛ keklẽ aɖe eye nàna ŋkɔɖelawo naɖe nuŋɔŋlɔ ɖe edzi be: ‘Kɔkɔenyenye nye Yehowa tɔ.’ 37 Eye nàgbi ka blɔtɔ atsɔ alée ɖe tablanu la dzi, ne wòanɔ tablanu la ŋgɔ.

36 “You are to make a shining plate of pure gold and engrave on it as one would engrave a seal: ‘Holiness belongs to Jehovah.’ 37 You must fasten it to the turban with a blue cord; it is to remain on the front of the turban.
38 Eye wòanɔ Aron ƒe ŋgonu, ale be ne Israel-viwo mewɔ nu kɔkɔewo ŋu dɔ nyuie o, eye wowɔ vodada le woƒe nunana kɔkɔe siwo wotsɔ vɛ na Mawu gome la, Aron naxɔ woƒe vodadawo ɖe akɔ.
38 It will be on Aaron’s forehead, and Aaron will bear responsibility when someone commits an error against the holy things, which the Israelites sanctify when they offer them as holy gifts.
Nenɔ eƒe ŋgonu ɣesiaɣi, be wòana Yehowa nakpɔ ŋudzedze ɖe wo ŋu.
It must always remain on his forehead, so that they may gain approval before Jehovah.
39 “Azɔ hã, nàlɔ̃ aklala biɖibiɖi wu ʋlaya si me atsyã siwo le dzogoe ene me la le, eye nàtsɔ ɖeti ɣi biɖibiɖi alɔ̃ tablanu kple alidziblanu.
39 “You are to weave the checkered robe of fine linen, make a turban of fine linen, and make a woven sash.
40 “Eyome nàlɔ̃ awu ʋlayawo, alidziblanuwo kple tablavɔwo na Aron viŋutsuwo, ne wòanye bubu kple atsyɔ̃ na wo.
40 “You will also make robes, sashes, and headgear for Aaron’s sons, for glory and beauty.
41 Eye nàdo awuawo na nɔviwò Aron kple viaŋutsuwo eye nàsi ami na wo, aɖo wo nunɔlawoe ahakɔ wo ŋu ne woasubɔm.
41 You will clothe your brother Aaron and his sons with him, and you are to anoint them and install them and sanctify them, and they will serve as priests to me.
42 Tsɔ aklala tɔ atakpuiwo na wo, be woatsɔ atsyɔ woƒe ama.
42 Also make linen shorts for them to cover their naked flesh.
Wòadidi tso woƒe alime va ɖo woƒe ata.
These are to extend from the hips to the thighs.
43 Aron kple viaŋutsuwo nadoe ne woyina takpegbadɔ la me alo ne woate ɖe vɔsamlekpui la ŋu be woasubɔ le kɔkɔeƒe la, ale be wòaganye vodada na wo ne woaku o.
43 These must be worn by Aaron and his sons when they come into the tent of meeting or when they approach the altar to minister in the holy place, so that they may not incur guilt and die.
Se wònye na eya kple emegbeviwo tegbee.
It is a permanent statute for him and his offspring after him.
Eye Yehowa gagblɔ na Mose be: 2 “Kɔ Israel-viwo ƒe ŋgɔgbeviŋutsu ɖe sia ɖe ŋu nam.
Jehovah spoke further to Moses, saying: 2 “Sanctify to me every firstborn male among the Israelites.
Amegbetɔwo ƒe ŋgɔgbeviŋutsuwo kple lãwo ƒe vi gbãtɔ siwo nye atsu la nye tɔnye.”
The first male to be born, of both human and animal, belongs to me.”
3 Eye Mose gblɔ na dukɔ la be: “Miɖo ŋku gbe si gbe mieʋu dzo le Egipte, afi si nye kluviwo ƒe me, la dzi, elabena asi sesẽe Yehowa tsɔ kplɔ mi tso afi sia.
3 Then Moses said to the people: “Remember this day on which you went out of Egypt, from the house of slavery, because with a mighty hand Jehovah brought you out of here.
Eya ta migaɖu naneke si me amɔwɔʋãnu le o.
So nothing leavened may be eaten.
4 Miele ʋuʋu ge egbe, le ɣleti si nye Abib me.
4 You are going out on this day, in the month of Abib.

5 Eye ne Yehowa kplɔ mi yi Kanaantɔwo, Hititɔwo, Amoritɔwo, Hivitɔwo kple Yebusitɔwo ƒe anyigba, si ŋu wòka atam ɖo na mia tɔgbuiwo be yeatsɔ ana mi, si nye anyigba si dzi notsi kple anyitsi le sisim le dzi la, ekema miaɖu azã sia le ɣleti sia me.

5 When Jehovah has brought you into the land of the Canaanites, the Hittites, the Amorites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites, which he swore to your forefathers to give you, a land flowing with milk and honey, then you must keep this observance in this month.
6 Ŋkeke adre sɔŋ miaɖu amɔwɔ maʋamaʋã bolo, eye ŋkeke adrelia nanye ŋkekenyui na Yehowa.
6 Seven days you are to eat unleavened bread, and on the seventh day, there will be a festival to Jehovah.
7 Amɔwɔ maʋamaʋã bolo nàɖu ŋkeke adreawo; womakpɔ nu ʋaʋã aɖeke le gbɔwò o, eye womakpɔ amɔwɔ ʋaʋã aɖeke le gbɔwò le wò anyigba katã dzi o.
7 Unleavened bread is to be eaten for the seven days; and nothing leavened is to be found with you, and no sourdough is to be found with you within all your territory.

8 Gbe ma gbe nàgblɔ na viwò be: ‘Nu si Yehowa wɔ nam esime meʋu dzo le Egipte la tae.’ 9 Ŋkekenyui sia anɔ na wò abe dzesi le wò asi ŋu kple ŋkuɖodzinu le wò ŋgonu ene, ne Yehowa ƒe se la nanɔ wò nu me; elabena asi sesẽ Yehowa tsɔ kplɔ wò tso Egipte.

8 And you must tell your son on that day, ‘It is because of what Jehovah did for me when I came out of Egypt.’ 9 And this will serve for you as a sign on your hand and as a memorial on your forehead, so that Jehovah’s law may be in your mouth, for with a mighty hand Jehovah brought you out of Egypt.
10 Eye nànɔ ɖoɖo sia dzi wɔm le eƒe ɣeyiɣi ɖoɖi dzi ƒe sia ƒe.
10 You must keep this statute at its appointed time from year to year.

11 “Ne Yehowa kplɔ wò yi Kanaantɔwo ƒe anyigba, si ŋu wòka atam na wò kple tɔgbuiwòwo be yeatsɔ ana mi dzi la, 12 ekema nàtsɔ ŋgɔgbeviŋutsu ɖe sia ɖe kple lãwo ƒe vi gbãtɔ siwo nye atsu siwo katã ava su asiwò la ana Yehowa.

11 “When Jehovah brings you into the land of the Canaanites, which he has sworn to you and to your forefathers to give to you, 12 you must devote to Jehovah every firstborn male, as well as every male firstling of the livestock that you acquire.
Ŋgɔgbeviŋutsuwo kple lãwo ƒe ŋgɔgbevi siwo nye atsu la nye Yehowa tɔ.
The males belong to Jehovah.
13 Tsɔ alẽ xe fe ɖe tedzi ƒe vi gbãtɔ ɖe sia ɖe ta, eye ne màxe fe ɖe eta o la, ekema nàŋe kɔ le enu.
13 Every firstling donkey you are to redeem with a sheep, and if you do not redeem it, then you must break its neck.
Xe fe ɖe wò ŋgɔgbeviŋutsuwo katã ta.
And every firstborn male of your sons you are to redeem.
14 “Eye ne viwò va bia wò emegbe be, ‘Nu sia gɔme ɖe?’ hã la, ekema nàɖo eŋu nɛ be: ‘Asi sesẽe Yehowa tsɔ kplɔ mí tso Egipte, afi si nye kluviwo ƒe me.
14 “In case your son should ask you later on, ‘What does this mean?’ then you should say to him, ‘With a mighty hand Jehovah brought us out of Egypt, from the house of slavery.
15 Esi Farao gbe dzimesesẽtɔe be yemaɖe asi le mía ŋu míadzo o la, Yehowa wu ŋgɔgbeviwo katã le Egipte-nyigba dzi, amewo ƒe ŋgɔgbeviwo kple lãwo ƒe vi gbãtɔwo siaa.
15 When Pharaoh stubbornly refused to send us away, Jehovah killed every firstborn in the land of Egypt, from the firstborn of man to the firstborn of beast.

Esia tae metsɔa lãwo ƒe vi gbãtɔ siwo nye atsu la katã saa vɔ na Yehowa, eye mexea fe ɖe nye ŋgɔgbeviŋutsuwo katã ta ɖo.’ 16 Esia nanɔ abe dzesi le wò asi ŋu kple ŋgoblanu le wò ŋgonu ene, elabena asi sesẽe Yehowa tsɔ kplɔ mí tso Egipte.”

That is why I am sacrificing to Jehovah all the firstborn males, and I redeem every firstborn of my sons.’ 16 This must serve as a sign on your hand and as a headband on your forehead, for with a mighty hand Jehovah brought us out of Egypt.”
17 Ke esi Farao ɖe asi le dukɔ la ŋu wodzo la, Mawu mekplɔ wo to mɔ si to Filistitɔwo ƒe anyigba dzi o, evɔ wònye mɔ mae nye kpuitɔ hafi.
17 Now when Pharaoh sent the people away, God did not lead them by the way of the land of the Philistines, although it was near.
Elabena Mawu gblɔ be: “Dukɔ la ava trɔ susu ne wokpe aʋa kpli wo, eye woatrɔ ayi Egipte.” 18 Eya ta Mawu na dukɔ la gɔdɔ̃ mɔ to Ƒudzĩ la ƒe gbedzimɔ.
For God said: “The people may change their minds when they are confronted by war and will return to Egypt.” 18 So God made the people go around by the way of the wilderness of the Red Sea.
Ke Israel-viwo dzo le Egipte-nyigba dzi le ɖoɖo nu abe asrafohawo ene.
But it was in battle formation that the Israelites went up out of the land of Egypt.

19 Azɔ hã Mose tsɔ Yosef ƒe ƒuwo ɖe asi, elabena Yosef na Israel-viwo ka atam nɛ, eye wògblɔ be: “Mawu atrɔ susu ɖe mia ŋu godoo, eye mitsɔ nye ƒuwo tso afi sia yii.” 20 Eye woho tso Sukot heva ƒu asaɖa anyi ɖe Etam, le gbegbe la nu.

19 Moses also took Joseph’s bones with him, because Joseph had made the sons of Israel solemnly swear: “God will not fail to turn his attention to you, and you must take my bones up out of here with you.” 20 They departed from Succoth and encamped at etham, at the edge of the wilderness.
21 Le ŋkeke me la, Yehowa nɔa wo ŋgɔ le alilikpo dodo aɖe me hekplɔa wo le mɔa dzi, eye le zã me la, eklẽna na wo le dzobibi aɖe me, ale wotea ŋu zɔa mɔ le ŋkeke me kple zã me siaa.
21 Now Jehovah was going ahead of them by day in a pillar of cloud to lead them along the way, and by night in a pillar of fire to give them light, so that they could travel by day and by night.
22 Alilikpo dodo la medzona le dukɔ la ŋgɔ le ŋkeke me o, eye dzobibi la medzona le zã me o.
22 The pillar of cloud would not move away from before the people during the day, nor the pillar of fire at night.
Azɔ Bezalel tsɔ akasiati kpa Aɖaka la.
Bezalel then made the Ark of acacia wood.
Edidi abɔklugui eve kple afã, ekeke abɔklugui ɖeka kple afã, eye wòkɔ abɔklugui ɖeka kple afã.
It was two and a half cubits long and a cubit and a half wide and a cubit and a half high.
2 Efa sika nyuitɔ ɖe eme kple ekɔgo siaa eye wòtsɔ sika ɖo to nɛ kpe ɖo.
2 He overlaid it with pure gold inside and outside and made a border of gold around it.
3 Emegbe ewɔ sikasigɛ ene ɖe eƒe dzogoewo dzi le afɔti eneawo gbɔ lɔƒo; asigɛ eve le eƒe axa si, eye asigɛ eve le eƒe axa kemɛ.
3 After that he cast four rings of gold for it, for above its four feet, with two rings on its one side and two rings on its other side.
4 Azɔ etsɔ akasiati kpa kpowo hefa sika ɖe wo ŋu.
4 He next made poles of acacia wood and overlaid them with gold.
5 Eye wòtsɔ kpoawo ƒo ɖe asigɛawo me le Aɖaka la ƒe axawo dzi be woatsɔ akɔ Aɖaka la.
5 Then he put the poles through the rings on the sides of the Ark for carrying the Ark.
6 Etsɔ sika nyuitɔ wɔ eƒe nutunu la.
6 He made the cover of pure gold.
Edidi abɔklugui eve kple afã, eye wòkeke abɔklugui ɖeka kple afã.
It was two and a half cubits long and a cubit and a half wide.
7 Ewɔ sikakerubi eve hã, eye wòtu wo ɖe nutunu la ƒe go eveawo dzi.
7 He then made two cherubs of hammered gold on both ends of the cover.
8 Kerubi ɖeka le akpa si, eye kerubi ɖeka le akpa kemɛ, le nutunu la ƒe go eveawo dzi.
8 One cherub was on one end, and the other cherub on the other end. He made the cherubs on both ends of the cover.
9 Kerubiawo ke woƒe aʋala eveawo me do ɖe dzi, ale be woƒe aʋalawo tsyɔ nutunu la dzi.
9 The two cherubs spread out their wings upward, overshadowing the cover with their wings.
Wodze ŋgɔ wo nɔewo hede mo to ɖe nutunu la dzi.
They were facing each other, and their faces were turned toward the cover.
10 Eyome etsɔ akasiati kpa kplɔ̃ la.
10 He then made the table of acacia wood.
Edidi abɔklugui eve, ekeke abɔklugui ɖeka, eye wòkɔ abɔklugui ɖeka kple afã.
It was two cubits long, a cubit wide, and a cubit and a half high.
11 Efa sika nyuitɔ ɖe eŋu, eye wòtsɔ sika do atsyã ɖe kplɔ̃ la toga kpe ɖo.
11 And he overlaid it with pure gold and made a border of gold around it.
12 Eyome eɖo to nɛ wòkeke asiƒome ɖeka, eye wòtsɔ sika do atsyã ɖe to la toga kpe ɖo.
12 Next he made a rim the width of a handbreadth to go around it and a border of gold to go around the rim.
13 Egawɔ sikasigɛ ene hã ɖe eŋu, eye wòtsɔ asigɛawo de afɔti eneawo ƒe dzogoe eneawo dzi le etame lɔƒo.
13 Further, he cast four rings of gold for it and placed the rings on the four corners where the four legs were attached.
14 Asigɛawo te ɖe to la ŋu be woate ŋu aƒo kpo ɖe wo me atsɔ akɔ kplɔ̃ lae.
14 The rings were near the rim, as holders for the poles used for carrying the table.
15 Azɔ etsɔ akasiati kpa kpoawo, eye wòfa sika ɖe wo ŋu, be woatsɔ akɔ kplɔ̃ lae.
15 Then he made the poles of acacia wood and overlaid them with gold for carrying the table.
16 Emegbe etsɔ sika nyuitɔ wɔ kplɔ̃ la dzi nu siwo nye agba gbadzɛwo, kpluwo, zewo, kple agba goboe siwo woatsɔ aƒo nunovɔsawo ɖi.
16 After that he made out of pure gold the utensils that went on the table—its dishes, its cups, and its bowls and pitchers from which drink offerings would be poured.
17 Azɔ etsɔ sika nyuitɔ tu akaɖiti la.
17 Then he made the lampstand of pure gold.
Ðe wòtu akaɖiti la ƒe titinati la kpakple eƒe alɔwo, eƒe kpluwo, eƒe kɔ́wo kple eƒe seƒoƒowo ɖekae.
He made the lampstand of hammered work. Its base, its stem, its cups, its knobs, and its blossoms were one piece.
18 Akaɖiti la dze alɔ ade; alɔ etɔ̃ le eƒe axa si, eye alɔ etɔ̃ le eƒe axa kemɛ.
18 Six branches were extending out from its stem, three branches of the lampstand from its one side and three branches from its other side.

19 Kplu etɔ̃ siwo wowɔ wole abe yevuziti ƒe seƒoƒo ene la le alɔawo dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe ŋu le axa si, eye kɔ́wo kple seƒoƒowo kplɔ kplu ɖe sia ɖe ɖo. Eye le eƒe axa kemɛ hã kplu etɔ̃ siwo wowɔ wole abe yevuziti ƒe seƒoƒowo ene la le alɔawo dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe ŋu, eye kɔ́wo kple seƒoƒowo kplɔ kplu ɖe sia ɖe ɖo.

19 Three cups shaped like almond flowers were on the one set of branches, with knobs and blossoms alternating, and three cups shaped like almond flowers were on the other set of branches, with knobs and blossoms alternating.
Aleae alɔ ade siwo le akaɖitia ŋu la le.
This was done for the six branches extending out from the stem of the lampstand.
20 Kplu ene le akaɖiti la ƒe titinatia ŋu, eye wole abe yevuziti ƒe seƒoƒo ene, eye kɔ́wo kple seƒoƒowo kplɔ kpluawo dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe ɖo le eŋu.
20 And on the stem of the lampstand were four cups shaped like almond flowers, with knobs and blossoms alternating.
21 Kɔ́ ɖeka le afi si alɔ eve gbãtɔwo dze le la te, kɔ́ ɖeka le afi si alɔ eve bubu siwo kplɔe ɖo dze le la te, eye kɔ́ ɖeka le afi si alɔ eve mamlɛawo dze le la hã te; wo katã le alɔ ade.

21 There was a knob under the first two branches that extended out of the stem and a knob under the next two branches and a knob under the next two branches, for the six branches extending out from the stem of the lampstand.
22 Etsɔ sika nyuitɔ tu kɔ́awo kple alɔawo ale be akaɖiti bliboa nye nu ɖeka.
22 The knobs and the branches and the whole lampstand were made to be one piece of pure, hammered gold.
23 Azɔ etsɔ sika nyuitɔ wɔ eƒe akaɖigbɛ adreawo, eƒe ɖovulãnuwo kple eƒe dzofilɔnuwo.
23 Then he made its seven lamps and its snuffers and its fire holders out of pure gold.
24 Sika nyuitɔ talento ɖeka wòtsɔ wɔ akaɖiti la kple eŋu nuwo katãe.
24 He made it, along with all its utensils, from a talent of pure gold.
25 Azɔ etsɔ akasiati wɔ dzudzɔdomlekpui la.
25 He now made the altar of incense out of acacia wood.
Edidi abɔklugui ɖeka, ekeke abɔklugui ɖeka, ele dzogoe ene me, eye wòkɔ abɔklugui eve.
It was square, a cubit long, a cubit wide, and two cubits high.
Eye wokpa dzoawo kplii wonye nu ɖeka.
Its horns were one piece with it.
26 Efa sika nyuitɔ ɖe eŋu, ɖe etame kple eƒe axawo dzi godoo va kpe, efae ɖe eƒe dzowo hã ŋu; eye wòtsɔ sika ɖo to nɛ kpe ɖo.
26 He overlaid it with pure gold, its top surface and its sides all around and its horns, and he made a border of gold around it.
27 Eye wòtsɔ sika wɔ asigɛ eve ɖe to la ŋu le eƒe axawo kple eve dzi, be woaƒo kpo siwo woatsɔ akɔe la ɖe wo me.
27 He made two rings of gold for it below its border on two opposite sides to hold the poles used for carrying it.
28 Emegbe etsɔ akasiati kpa kpoawo eye wòfa sika ɖe wo ŋu.
28 After that he made the poles of acacia wood and overlaid them with gold.
29 Azɔ hã ewɔ ameɖomi kɔkɔe la kple atike ʋeʋĩ nyuitɔ la, eye wòtsaka wo nyuie.
29 He also made the holy anointing oil and the pure, perfumed incense, skillfully blended.
Eye Yehowa gblɔ na Mose be: “Yi Farao gbɔ nàgblɔ nɛ be: ‘Ale Yehowa, Hebritɔwo ƒe Mawu la, gblɔe nye esi: “Ðe asi le nye dukɔ ŋu woayi aɖasubɔm.
So Jehovah said to Moses: “Go in to Pharaoh and say to him, ‘This is what Jehovah the God of the Hebrews has said: “Send my people away so that they may serve me.
2 Ke ne ègbe asiɖeɖe le wo ŋu, eye nègalé wo ɖi la, 3 ekema Yehowa ƒe asi ava wò lãha siwo le gbedzi la dzi.
2 But if you refuse to send them away and you keep holding them, 3 look! Jehovah’s hand will come against your livestock in the field.
Dɔvɔ̃ dziŋɔ aɖe adze sɔwo, tedziwo, kposɔwo, nyihawo kple alẽhawo dzi.
On the horses, the donkeys, the camels, the herd, and the flock, there will be a devastating plague.
4 Yehowa ade vovototo Israel-viwo ƒe lãhawo kple Egiptetɔwo ƒe lãhawo dome, eye Israel-viwo ƒe lã aɖeke maku o.”’” 5 Yehowa ɖo ɣeyiɣi hã gblɔ be: “Yehowa awɔ esia etsɔ le Egipte-nyigba la dzi.”

4 And Jehovah will certainly make a distinction between the livestock of Israel and the livestock of Egypt, and nothing that belongs to the Israelites will die.”’” 5 Moreover, Jehovah set an appointed time, saying: “Tomorrow Jehovah will do this in the land.”
6 Le ŋufɔke la, Yehowa wɔ esia, ale Egiptetɔwo ƒe lãhawo katã ku, ke Israel-viwo ƒe lã aɖeke meku o.
6 And Jehovah did this on the very next day, and all sorts of livestock of Egypt began to die, but not one of Israel’s livestock died.
7 Esi Farao bia la, kpɔ ɖa, Israel-viwo ƒe lã ɖeka pɛ hã meku o!
7 When Pharaoh inquired, look! not so much as one of Israel’s livestock had died.
Ke hã Farao gasẽ dzi me, eye meɖe asi le dukɔ la ŋu woyi o.
Nevertheless, Pharaoh’s heart continued to be unresponsive, and he did not send the people away.
8 Emegbe Yehowa gblɔ na Mose kple Aron be: “Miɖe kpomedzɔble ɖe miaƒe asiʋlowo me, eye Mose nahlẽe ɖo ɖe yame le Farao ŋkume.
8 Jehovah then said to Moses and Aaron: “Fill both of your hands with soot from a kiln, and Moses must throw it into the air in front of Pharaoh.
9 Azu ʋuʋudedi ɖe Egipte-nyigba blibo la dzi eye wòazu ƒoƒoe vɔ̃ ate amegbetɔwo kple lãwo siaa le Egipte-nyigba blibo la katã dzi.”
9 And it will become a fine dust on all the land of Egypt, and it will become festering boils on man and beast in all the land of Egypt.”
10 Ale woɖe kpomedzɔble, eye wova tɔ ɖe Farao ŋkume, eye Mose hlẽe ɖe yame, wòzu ƒoƒoe vɔ̃ te amegbetɔwo kple lãwo.
10 So they took soot from a kiln and stood before Pharaoh, and Moses tossed it into the air, and it became festering boils breaking out on man and beast.
11 Ke akunyawɔlawo mete ŋu tɔ ɖe Mose ŋkume o le ƒoƒoe si te akunyawɔlaawo kple Egiptetɔwo katã la ta.
11 The magic-practicing priests were unable to stand before Moses because of the boils, for they had developed on the magic-practicing priests and on all the Egyptians.
12 Ke Yehowa ɖe mɔ Farao ƒe dzi me sẽ, eye meɖo to wo o, abe ale si tututu Yehowa gblɔe na Mose ene.
12 But Jehovah allowed Pharaoh’s heart to become obstinate, and he did not listen to them, just as Jehovah had told Moses.
13 Eye Yehowa gblɔ na Mose be: “Fɔ ŋdi kanya nàyi aɖatɔ ɖe Farao ŋkume agblɔ nɛ be: ‘Ale Yehowa, Hebritɔwo ƒe Mawu la, gblɔe nye esi: “Ðe asi le nye dukɔ ŋu woayi aɖasubɔm.

13 Then Jehovah said to Moses: “Get up early in the morning and station yourself in front of Pharaoh, and say to him, ‘This is what Jehovah the God of the Hebrews has said: “Send my people away so that they may serve me.
14 Elabena mele nye fuwɔameawo katã lɔ ge atrɔ ɖe wò ŋutɔ, wò subɔviwo, kple wò dukɔ la dzi, ne nàdze sii be ame aɖeke mede nunye le anyigba blibo la katã dzi o.
14 For now I am directing all my blows to strike your heart, your servants, and your people, so that you may know that there is no one like me in all the earth.
15 Elabena mate ŋu ado nye asi ɖa atsɔ dɔvɔ̃ aƒo wò ŋutɔ kple wò dukɔ ale be nàtsrɔ̃ le anyigba la dzi xoxoxo hafi.
15 For by now I could have thrust my hand out to strike you and your people with a devastating plague, and you would have been wiped out from the earth.
16 Gake susu si tae mena nèle agbe ɖoe nye be, maɖe nye ŋusẽ afia wò, eye woaɖe gbeƒã nye ŋkɔ le anyigba blibo la dzi.
16 But for this very reason I have kept you in existence: to show you my power and to have my name declared in all the earth.

17 Ðe nègale ɖokuiwò dom ɖe dzi kokoko ɖe nye dukɔ la ŋu hegbe asiɖeɖe le wo ŋua? 18 Kpɔ ɖa, mana kpetsi gã aɖe nadza etsɔ ɣealewoɣi, kpetsi sia tɔgbi medza le Egipte kpɔ tso gbe si gbe woɖo egɔme anyi va se ɖe fifia o.

17 Are you still behaving arrogantly against my people by not sending them away? 18 Here I will cause a very great hail to rain down tomorrow about this time, such as has never occurred in Egypt from the day it was founded until now.
19 Eya ta dɔ woaɖakplɔ wò lãhawo katã kple wò nu sia nu si le gbedzi la ade xɔ.
19 Therefore, send word to bring all your livestock and all that is yours in the field under shelter.
Ame kple lã, siwo katã le gbedzi eye womekplɔ wo va aƒe me o la, kpetsi la adza ɖe wo dzi woaku.”’”
Every man and beast caught in the field and not brought into the house will die when the hail comes down on them.”’”

20 Farao ƒe subɔvi siwo Yehowa ƒe nya la tso dzika ƒo na la wɔ kaba yi ɖakplɔ woƒe subɔviwo kple woƒe lãhawo va aƒe me, 21 ke ame si mebu Yehowa ƒe nya la ɖe naneke me o la gblẽ eƒe subɔviwo kple eƒe lãhawo ɖe gbedzi.

20 Anyone among Pharaoh’s servants who feared Jehovah’s word quickly brought his own servants and his livestock into the houses, 21 but whoever did not take Jehovah’s word to heart left his servants and his livestock in the field.

22 Azɔ Yehowa gblɔ na Mose be: “Do wò asi ɖe dziƒo, ne kpetsi nadza ɖe Egipte-nyigba blibo la dzi, ɖe amegbetɔwo kple lãwo kpakple nu miemie siwo katã le gbedzi le Egipte-nyigba dzi la dzi.” 23 Eya ta Mose do eƒe atikplɔ la ɖe dziƒo, eye Yehowa na dzi ɖe gbe, kpetsi dza, eye dzo dza ɖe anyigba la dzi, ale Yehowa na kpetsi la dza ɖe Egipte-nyigba la dzi.

22 Jehovah now said to Moses: “Stretch out your hand toward the heavens, so that hail may come down on all the land of Egypt, on man and beast and all the vegetation of the field in the land of Egypt.” 23 So Moses stretched out his rod toward the heavens, and Jehovah sent thunder and hail, and fire fell down to the earth, and Jehovah kept making it rain down hail on the land of Egypt.
24 Kpetsi dza, eye dzi nɔ dzo kem le kpetsi la me miamiamia.
24 There was hail, and there was fire flashing in the midst of the hail.
Enu sẽ ale gbegbe; etɔgbi aɖeke medza ɖe Egipte-nyigba blibo la katã dzi kpɔ tso esime wòzu dukɔ o.
It was very heavy; there had never been any like it in the land since Egypt had become a nation.
25 Eye kpetsi la gblẽ nu sia nu si le gbedzi le Egipte-nyigba blibo la dzi, amegbetɔwo, lãwo, kple nu miemiewo katã, eye wòfe gbemetiwo katã.
25 The hail struck everything in the field throughout the land of Egypt, from man to beast, and it struck down all the vegetation and shattered all the trees of the field.
26 Negbe Gosen-nyigba dzi, afi si Israel-viwo le la, koe kpetsi aɖeke medza le o.
26 Only in the land of GOshen, where the Israelites were, there was no hail.
27 Eya ta Farao dɔ woɖayɔ Mose kple Aron vɛ, eye wògblɔ na wo be: “Fifia ya, mewɔ nu vɔ̃.
27 So Pharaoh sent for Moses and Aaron and said to them: “I have sinned this time.
Yehowa tɔ dzɔ, eye nye kple nye dukɔ la tɔ medzɔ o.
Jehovah is righteous, and I and my people are in the wrong.
28 Miɖe kuku na Yehowa, ne wòana dziɖegbe kple kpetsi la nu natso.
28 Plead with Jehovah that there may be an end to God’s thunder and hail.
Ekema maɖe asi le mia ŋu miadzo faa, eye miaganɔ afi sia azɔ o.” 29 Mose gblɔ nɛ be: “Ne menya do go le dua me ko la, make nye abɔwo me le Yehowa ŋkume.
Then I will be willing to send you away, and you will not stay any longer.” 29 So Moses said to him: “As soon as I go out of the city, I will spread out my hands before Jehovah.
Dziɖegbea atɔ te, eye kpetsi la nu atso, ne nàdze sii be Yehowa tɔe nye anyigba la.
The thunder will stop and the hail will not continue any longer, so that you may know that the earth belongs to Jehovah.
30 Ke menyae xoxo be, ne eva eme alea gɔ̃ hã la, wò kple wò subɔviwo miele Yehowa Mawu vɔ̃ ge o.”
30 But as for you and your servants, I know already that even then, you will not fear Jehovah God.”
31 Ke kpetsi la na ɖeti kple ƒo dome gblẽ, elabena ƒo ɖi, eye ɖeti hã ƒo se.
31 Now the flax and the barley had been struck down, because the barley was in the ear and the flax had flower buds.
32 Ke lu kple lu dzĩ ya dome megblẽ o, elabena woawo metse haɖe o.
32 But the wheat and the spelt had not been struck down, because they were later crops.
33 Eye Mose dzo le Farao gbɔ hedo le dua me, eye wòke eƒe abɔwo me le Yehowa ŋkume, ale dziɖegbea kple kpetsi la nu tso, eye tsia ke le anyigba la dzi.
33 Moses now went out of the city from Pharaoh and spread out his hands before Jehovah, and the thunder and the hail stopped and the rain quit pouring down on the earth.
34 Esi Farao kpɔ be tsia kple kpetsia kpakple dziɖegbea nu tso la, egawɔ nu vɔ̃, eya kple eƒe subɔviwo siaa gasẽ dzi me.
34 When Pharaoh saw that the rain, the hail, and the thunder had stopped, he sinned again and hardened his heart, he as well as his servants.
35 Ale Farao gasẽ dzi me kokoko, eye meɖe asi le Israel-viwo ŋu o, abe ale si tututu Yehowa gblɔe to Mose dzi ene.
35 And Pharaoh’s heart continued obstinate, and he did not send the Israelites away, just as Jehovah had stated through Moses.
Eye Yehowa gblɔ na Mose be: 2 “Gblɔ na Israel-viwo be woatrɔ ava ƒu asaɖa anyi ɖe Pihahirot ŋgɔ le Migdol kple atsiaƒu la dome, adze ŋgɔ Baal-Zefon.
Jehovah now said to Moses: 2 “Tell the Israelites that they should turn back and encamp before Pihahiroth, between Migdol and the sea, within view of Baal-Zephon.
Miƒu asaɖa anyi ɖe atsiaƒu la nu eye miadze ŋgɔ Baal-Zefon.
You are to encamp facing it by the sea.
3 Ekema Farao agblɔ le Israel-viwo ŋu be: ‘Wotɔtɔ hele tsaglãla tsam le anyigba la dzi.
3 Then Pharaoh will say about the Israelites, ‘They are wandering in confusion in the land.
Gbea dzi xaxa wo ɖo.’ 4 Maɖe mɔ Farao ƒe dzi me nasẽ wòati wo yome, eye mato Farao kple eƒe aʋakɔwo katã dzi akɔ ɖokuinye ŋu; ne Egiptetɔwo nadze sii be nyee nye Yehowa.”

The wilderness has closed in on them.’ 4 I will allow Pharaoh’s heart to become obstinate, and he will chase after them, and I will glorify myself by means of Pharaoh and all his army; and the Egyptians will certainly know that I am Jehovah.”
Eye Israel-viwo wɔ nenema.
So that is what they did.
5 Eye wova gblɔ na Egipte-fia la be dukɔ la si dzo.
5 Later it was reported to the king of Egypt that the people had run away.

Enumake Farao kple eƒe subɔviwo trɔ tame le dukɔ la ŋuti, eye wogblɔ be: “Nu kae nye esi míewɔ be míeɖe asi le Israel-viwo ŋu wodzo be woagasubɔ mí abe kluviwo ene azɔ o?” 6 Ale wòna wodzra eƒe aʋatasiaɖamwo ɖo, eye wòkplɔ eƒe aʋawɔlawo kpe ɖe eɖokui ŋu.

Immediately, Pharaoh and his servants had a change of heart regarding the people, and they said: “Why did we do this and release Israel from serving as slaves for us?” 6 So he made his war chariots ready, and he took his people with him.
7 Eye wòtsɔ tasiaɖam tɔxɛ alafa ade hekpe ɖe Egipte ƒe tasiaɖam bubuawo katã ŋu, eye aʋawɔlawo le wo dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe me.
7 He took 600 chosen chariots and all the other chariots of Egypt, with warriors on every one of them.
8 Ale Yehowa ɖe mɔ Egipte-fia Farao ƒe dzi me sẽ, eye wòti Israel-viwo yome, esime Israel-viwo nɔ azɔli dzi le dziɖeɖi me.
8 Thus Jehovah allowed the heart of Pharaoh king of Egypt to become obstinate, and he chased after the Israelites, while the Israelites were going out with confidence.
9 Egiptetɔwo ti wo yome, eye Farao kple eƒe sɔdolawo kpakple eƒe aʋakɔwo ƒe tasiaɖamwo le wo gogom esime woƒu asaɖa anyi ɖe atsiaƒu la nu, le Pihahirot gbɔ le Baal-Zefon ŋgɔ.

9 The Egyptians chased after them, and all the chariot horses of Pharaoh and his cavalrymen and his army were catching up with them while they were camping by the sea, by Pihahiroth, facing Baal-Zephon.
10 Esi Farao gogo wo, eye Israel-viwo fɔ kɔ dzi kpɔ Egiptetɔwo le wo yome gbɔna la, dzidzi ƒo Israel-viwo, eye wodo ɣli yɔ Yehowa.
10 When Pharaoh got closer, the Israelites raised their eyes and saw the Egyptians pursuing them. The Israelites became terrified and began to cry out to Jehovah.
11 Eye wobia Mose be: “Esi ameɖiƒe aɖeke mele Egipte o tae nèkplɔ mí va afi sia be míaku ɖe gbe sia dzia?
11 They said to Moses: “Is it because there are no burial places in Egypt that you have brought us here to die in the wilderness?
Nu kae nye esi nèwɔ ɖe mía ŋu be nèkplɔ mí tso Egipte? 12 Alo menye nya sia koe míegblɔ na wò le Egipte be, ‘Ðe asi le mía ŋu kpoo ne míasubɔ Egiptetɔwo’ oa?
What have you done to us by leading us out of Egypt? 12 Is this not the very thing we told you in Egypt when we said, ‘Let us alone, so that we may serve the Egyptians’?
Elabena enyo na mí be míasubɔ Egiptetɔwo wu be míaku ɖe gbedzi.” 13 Eye Mose gblɔ na dukɔ la bena: “Migavɔ̃ o.
For it is better for us to serve the Egyptians than to die in the wilderness.” 13 Then Moses said to the people: “Do not be afraid.
Minɔ te sesĩe, eye miakpɔ ale si Yehowa le xɔxɔ ge na mi egbe.
Stand firm and see the salvation of Jehovah that he will perform for you today.
Elabena Egiptetɔ siwo kpɔm miele egbea la, miegale wo kpɔ ge akpɔ gbeɖegbeɖe o.
For the Egyptians whom you see today, you will never ever see again.
14 Yehowa ŋutɔ awɔ aʋa na mi, ke miawo la miatɔ ɖi kpoo.”
14 Jehovah himself will fight for you, and you will keep silent.”
15 Eye Yehowa gblɔ na Mose be: “Nu ka ŋuti nèle ɣli dom nam?
15 Jehovah now said to Moses: “Why do you keep crying out to me?
Gblɔ na Israel-viwo be woaho.
Tell the Israelites that they should break camp.
16 Ke wò la, tsɔ wò atikplɔ la, eye nàdo wò asi ɖe atsiaƒu la dzi ne wòama ɖe eve, ale be Israel-viwo nazɔ to ƒuƒuiƒe le atsiaƒu la me.
16 As for you, lift up your rod and stretch out your hand over the sea and divide it, so that the Israelites may go through the midst of the sea on dry ground.
17 Nyee ɖe mɔ Egiptetɔwo ƒe dzi me sẽ, ne woadze wo yome age ɖe eme, ale be mato Farao kple eƒe aʋakɔwo katã, eƒe aʋatasiaɖamwo kple eƒe sɔdolawo dzi, akɔ ɖokuinye ŋu.

17 As for me, I am allowing the hearts of the Egyptians to become obstinate, so that they will go in after them; thus I will glorify myself by means of Pharaoh and all his army, his war chariots, and his cavalrymen.
18 Eye Egiptetɔwo adze sii be nyee nye Yehowa ne meto Farao, eƒe aʋatasiaɖamwo kple eƒe sɔdolawo dzi kɔ ɖokuinye ŋu.”
18 And the Egyptians will certainly know that I am Jehovah when I glorify myself by means of Pharaoh, his war chariots, and his cavalrymen.”
19 Eye Mawu vavã la ƒe dɔla si le Israel-viwo ŋgɔ la dzo yi wo megbe, eye alilikpo dodo si le wo ŋgɔ la dzo yi wo megbe.
19 Then the angel of the true God who was going ahead of the camp of Israel departed and went to their rear, and the pillar of cloud that was in front of them moved to the rear and stood behind them.
20 Eye wòva le Egiptetɔwo ƒe aʋakɔwo kple Israel-viwo dome.
20 So it came between the camp of the Egyptians and the camp of Israel.
Eye alilikpo la na viviti do ɖe akpa ɖeka.
On the one side, it was a dark cloud.
Ke le akpa kemɛ la, ena zã la me kɔ.
On the other side, it was lighting up the night.
Eye wo dometɔ aɖeke mete ɖe nɔvia ŋu zã blibo la katã o.
So the one camp did not come near the other camp all night long.
21 Azɔ Mose do eƒe asi ɖe atsiaƒu la dzi; ale Yehowa na ɣedzeƒeya sesẽ ƒo zã blibo la katã hetutu atsiaƒu la ɖe megbe, eye wòna atsiaƒu la gɔme zu ƒuƒuiƒe, eye tsi la me ma ɖe akpa eve.
21 Moses now stretched out his hand over the sea; and Jehovah drove the sea back with a strong east wind all night long, turning the sea basin into dry ground, and the waters divided.
22 Eye Israel-viwo zɔ to ƒuƒuiƒe le atsiaƒu la me, esime tsia zu abe gli ene le woƒe ɖusime kple miame.
22 So the Israelites went through the midst of the sea on dry ground, while the waters formed a wall on their right hand and on their left.
23 Egiptetɔwo ti wo yome, eye Farao ƒe sɔwo, eƒe aʋatasiaɖamwo kple eƒe sɔdolawo katã dze wo yome ge ɖe atsiaƒu la me.
23 The Egyptians pursued them, and all Pharaoh’s horses, his war chariots, and his cavalrymen began going after them into the midst of the sea.
24 Eye le ŋdiŋudzɔɣi la, Yehowa le dzobibi kple alilikpo dodo la me kpɔ Egiptetɔwo ƒe aʋakɔwo, eye wòde tɔtɔ Egiptetɔwo ƒe aʋakɔwo me.
24 During the morning watch, Jehovah looked at the camp of the Egyptians from within the pillar of fire and cloud, and he threw the camp of the Egyptians into confusion.
25 Eye wòna woƒe tasiaɖamfɔtiwo gli, ale be wo kuku zu dɔ na wo, eye Egiptetɔwo gblɔ be: “Mina míasi le Israel nu, elabena Yehowa le aʋa wɔm na wo ɖe Egiptetɔwo ŋu.”

25 He kept taking wheels off their chariots so that they were driving them with difficulty, and the Egyptians were saying: “Let us flee from any contact with Israel, because Jehovah is fighting for them against the Egyptians.”

26 Eye Yehowa gblɔ na Mose be: “Do asi ɖe atsiaƒu la dzi, ne tsia natrɔ ava ahatsyɔ Egiptetɔwo, woƒe aʋatasiaɖamwo kple woƒe sɔdolawo dzi.” 27 Enumake Mose do asi ɖe atsiaƒu la dzi, eye esi ŋu de asi keke me la, atsiaƒu la gaɖo eƒe nɔnɔme me.

26 Then Jehovah said to Moses: “Stretch out your hand over the sea so that the waters may come back over the Egyptians, their war chariots, and their cavalrymen.” 27 Moses at once stretched out his hand over the sea, and as morning approached, the sea returned to its normal condition.
Esi Egiptetɔwo le sisim le enu la, Yehowa tutu wo ƒu atsiaƒu la me.
As the Egyptians fled from it, Jehovah shook the Egyptians off into the midst of the sea.
28 Eye tsia nyè tsyɔ aʋatasiaɖamwo, sɔdolawo kple Farao ƒe aʋakɔ blibo, siwo ti wo yome va atsiaƒua me la dzi.
28 The returning waters covered the war chariots and the cavalrymen and all of Pharaoh’s army who had gone into the sea after them.
Wo dometɔ ɖeka hɔ̃ hã metsi agbe o.
Not so much as one among them was allowed to survive.
29 Ke Israel-viwo ya zɔ ƒuƒuiƒe to atsiaƒu la me, eye tsia zu abe gli ene le woƒe ɖusime kple miame.
29 But the Israelites walked on dry ground in the midst of the seabed, and the waters formed a wall on their right hand and on their left.
30 Ale Yehowa ɖe Israel tso Egiptetɔwo si me gbe ma gbe, eye Israel-viwo kpɔ Egiptetɔwo ƒe kukuawo le ƒua ta.
30 Thus Jehovah saved Israel on that day from the hand of the Egyptians, and Israel saw the Egyptians dead on the seashore.
31 Esi Israel-viwo kpɔ ŋusẽ gã si Yehowa ɖe fia ɖe Egiptetɔwo ŋu la, dukɔ la de asi Yehowa vɔvɔ̃ me, eye woxɔ Yehowa kple eƒe subɔla Mose dzi se.
31 Israel also saw the great power that Jehovah wielded against the Egyptians, and the people began to fear Jehovah and to put faith in Jehovah and in his servant Moses.
Ɣemaɣi la, Mose kple Israel-viwo dzi ha sia tsɔ kafu Yehowa be:
At that time Moses and the Israelites sang this song to Jehovah:
“Madzi ha na Yehowa, elabena eƒe ŋutikɔkɔe de dzi bobobo.
“Let me sing to Jehovah, for he has become highly exalted.
Etsɔ sɔ kple edola ƒu gbe ɖe atsiaƒu la me.
The horse and its rider he has hurled into the sea.
2 Nye ŋusẽ kple nye ŋutetee nye Yah, elabena eyae nye nye xɔname.
2 My strength and my might is Jah, since he has become my salvation.
Nye Mawue, eya ta makafui; fofonye ƒe Mawue, eya ta madoe ɖe dzi.
This is my God, and I will praise him; my father’s God, and I will exalt him.
3 Yehowa nye aʋakalẽtɔ.
3 Jehovah is a powerful warrior.
Eŋkɔe nye Yehowa.
Jehovah is his name.
4 Ede Farao ƒe tasiaɖamwo kple eƒe aʋakɔ la ƒu,
4 Pharaoh’s chariots and his army He has cast into the sea,
Eye eƒe aʋawɔla bibiwo nyrɔ ɖe Ƒudzĩ la me.
And his finest warriors have sunk into the Red Sea.
5 Tsi dzeagbowo nyè tsyɔ wo dzi; wodze to le atsiaƒu ƒe gogloƒewo abe kpe ene.
5 The surging waters covered them; down into the depths they sank like a stone.
6 Oo Yehowa, ŋusẽ le wò nuɖusibɔ ŋu ale gbegbe;
6 Your right hand, O Jehovah, is great in power;
Oo Yehowa, wò nuɖusibɔ ate ŋu aka futɔwo ahlẽ.
Your right hand, O Jehovah, can shatter an enemy.
7 Esi wò gãnyenye teƒe mekɔ o ta la, àte ŋu aƒo ame siwo tso ɖe ŋuwò la aƒu anyi;
7 In your great majesty you can throw down those who rise up against you;
Èdɔ wò dziku bibi la ɖa, eye wòfiã wo abe ahɔ̃liti ene.
You send out your burning anger, it eats them up like stubble.
8 Wò ŋɔtimegbɔgbɔ na tsiwo li kɔ ɖi;
8 By a breath from your nostrils waters massed together;
Wotɔ ɖi maʋamaʋãe abe tɔɖɔɖɔ si woxe mɔ na ene;
They stood still, holding back the floods;
Tsi dzeagbowo bla le atsiaƒu la titina.
The surging waters congealed in the heart of the sea.
9 Futɔ la be: ‘Mati wo yome!
9 The enemy said: ‘I will pursue!
Matu wo!
I will overtake!
Mama aboyonu va se ɖe esime meɖi ƒo!
I will divide spoil until I am satisfied!
Maɖe nye yi ɖe go!
I will draw my sword!
Nye asi akpe wo dzi!’
My hand will subdue them!’
10 Ƒuƒu ko nèɖo, eye atsiaƒu la tsyɔ wo dzi;
10 You blew with your breath, the sea covered them;
Wonyrɔ abe asabukpe ene ɖe tɔ gãwo me.
They sank like lead in majestic waters.
11 Oo Yehowa, mawu kae le abe wò ene le mawuwo dome?
11 Who among the gods is like you, O Jehovah?
Ame kae le abe wò, ame si ƒe kɔkɔenyenye teƒe mekɔ o la, ene?
Who is like you, showing yourself mighty in holiness?
Wò, Ame si woavɔ̃ ahadzi kafukafuhawo na, wò, Ame si le nukunuwo wɔm.
The One to be feared with songs of praise, the One doing wonders.
12 Èdo wò nuɖusi ɖa, eye anyigba mi wo.
12 You stretched out your right hand, and the earth swallowed them up.
13 Èkplɔ dukɔ si nèxɔ na la le wò amenuveve me;
13 In your loyal love you have led the people whom you have redeemed;
Àkplɔ wo ayi wò nɔƒe kɔkɔe la le wò ŋusẽ me.
In your strength you will guide them to your holy place of dwelling.
14 Dukɔwo asee; dzidzi aƒo wo;
14 Peoples must hear; they will shudder;
Filistitɔwo ase veve vevie.
Anguish will seize the inhabitants of Philistia.
15 Dzidzi aƒo Edom ƒe amegãwo ɣemaɣi;
15 At that time the sheikhs of Edom will be terrified,
Moab-megãwo hã adzo nyanyanya.
And trembling will take hold of the mighty rulers of Moab.
Dzi aɖe le Kanaantɔwo katã ƒo.
All the inhabitants of Canaan will be disheartened.
16 Vɔvɔ̃ kple ŋɔdzi alé wo.
16 Fear and dread will fall upon them.
Wò alɔ sesẽ ana woatsi maʋamaʋã abe kpe ene,
Because of the greatness of your arm they will be as motionless as a stone
Oo Yehowa, va se ɖe esime wò dukɔ la va yi,
Until your people pass by, O Jehovah,
Va se ɖe esime dukɔ si nèwɔ la tso eme va yi.
Until the people whom you produced pass by.
17 Àkplɔ wo vɛ, eye àdo wo ɖe to, si nye tɔwò la dzi,
17 You will bring them and plant them in the mountain of your inheritance,
Oo Yehowa, teƒe si nèdzra ɖo na ɖokuiwò be yeanɔ la,
The established place that you have prepared for yourself to inhabit, O Jehovah,
Oo Yehowa, kɔkɔeƒe si nètsɔ wò asiwo li kee la.
A sanctuary, O Jehovah, that your hands have established.
18 Yehowa aɖu fia ɖaa tegbetegbe.
18 Jehovah will rule as king forever and ever.
19 Esi Farao ƒe sɔwo kple eƒe aʋatasiaɖamwo kpakple eƒe sɔdolawo ge ɖe ƒua me la,
19 When Pharaoh’s horses with his war chariots and his cavalrymen went into the sea,
Yehowa na ƒu la nyè tsyɔ wo dzi,
Then Jehovah brought back the waters of the sea upon them,
Gake Israel-viwo zɔ ƒuƒuiƒe to ƒu la titina.”
