25 And they made bells of pure gold and put the bells in between the pomegranates all around the hem of the sleeveless coat, in between the pomegranates; 26 they alternated a bell and a pomegranate, a bell and a pomegranate, all around the hem of the sleeveless coat, which was used for ministering, just as Jehovah had commanded Moses.

27 Eyome avɔlɔ̃la tsɔ ɖeti ɣi biɖibiɖi lɔ̃ awu ʋlayawo na Aron kple viaŋutsuwo, 28 wotsɔ ɖeti ɣi biɖibiɖi lɔ̃ tablanu kple atsyɔ̃tablavɔwo, eye wotsɔ ɖeti ɣi biɖibiɖi dada lɔ̃ atakpui ɣiwo. 29 Eyome wotsɔ ɖeti ɣi biɖibiɖi, ka blɔtɔ, alẽfuka si wode ama aɖabɛ dzĩtɔe kple ka dzĩ lɔ̃ alidziblanu la; wowɔe abe ale si tututu Yehowa de se na Mose ene.

27 And they made the robes of fine linen, woven by a loom worker, for Aaron and his sons, 28 and the turban of fine linen, the ornamental headgear of fine linen, the linen shorts of fine twisted linen, 29 and the sash of fine twisted linen, blue thread, purple wool, and scarlet material woven together, just as Jehovah had commanded Moses.

30 Mlɔeba wotsɔ sika nyuitɔ wɔ ga falɛ keklẽ la, si nye adzɔgbeɖeɖe ƒe dzesi kɔkɔe la, eye wona ŋkɔɖelawo ɖe nuŋɔŋlɔ ɖe edzi be: “Kɔkɔenyenye nye Yehowa tɔ.” 31 Eye wogbi ka blɔtɔ tsɔ lée ɖe tablanu la dzi; wowɔe abe ale si tututu Yehowa de se na Mose ene.

30 Finally, they made the shining plate, the holy sign of dedication, out of pure gold and inscribed on it an inscription as one would engrave a seal: “Holiness belongs to Jehovah.” 31 They attached to it a cord made from blue thread in order to put it on the turban, just as Jehovah had commanded Moses.
32 Ale wowu avɔgbadɔ si nye takpegbadɔ la ƒe dɔ blibo la katã nu; Israel-viwo wɔe abe ale si tututu Yehowa de se na Mose ene.
32 So all the work for the tabernacle, the tent of meeting, was completed, and the Israelites did everything that Jehovah had commanded Moses.
Nenema pɛpɛpɛ wowɔe.
They did just so.

33 Eyome wofɔ avɔgbadɔ la ƒe nuwo katã va Mose gbɔ: agbadɔvɔ la kple eŋu nuwo katã, eƒe gaviwo, eƒe ʋuƒowo, eƒe xɔblatiwo, eƒe sɔtiwo kple eƒe anyinɔwo; 34 agbogbalẽ si wode ama dzĩ kple nyogbalẽ siwo woatsɔ agba edzi, xɔmetsovɔ la; 35 Ðaseɖiɖiɖaka la, eŋu kpowo kple nutunu la; 36 kplɔ̃ la, eŋu nuwo katã kple ŋkumeɖobolo la; 37 akaɖiti si wotsɔ sika nyuitɔ wɔ kple eƒe akaɖigbɛ siwo le agbaka me, eŋu nuwo katã kple ami si woade akaɖigbɛ la me; 38 sikavɔsamlekpui la, ami kɔkɔe la, atike ʋeʋĩ la, agbadɔ la ƒe mɔnuvɔ la; 39 akɔblivɔsamlekpui la, eƒe akɔbligaɖɔ la, eŋu kpowo kple eŋu nuwo katã, ze la kple eƒe zɔ; 40 xɔxɔnu la ŋu vɔwo, eƒe kpɔtiwo kple eƒe anyinɔwo, xɔxɔnu la ƒe mɔnuvɔ, eƒe kawo kple eƒe tsyotiwo, kple nu siwo katã woazã le avɔgbadɔ, si nye takpegbadɔ la, me dɔwo wɔwɔ me; 41 awu siwo wolɔ̃ nyuie be woatsɔ awɔ subɔsubɔdɔ le kɔkɔeƒe la, nunɔla Aron ƒe awu kɔkɔewo kple viaŋutsuwo ƒe awu siwo woado atsɔ awɔ nunɔladɔwo.

33 Then they brought the tabernacle to Moses, the tent and all its equipment: its clasps, its panel frames, its bars and its pillars and its socket pedestals; 34 its covering of ram skins dyed red, its covering of sealskins, the curtain for the screen; 35 the ark of the Testimony and its poles and the cover; 36 the table, all its utensils and the showbread; 37 the lampstand of pure gold, its lamps, the row of lamps, and all its utensils and the oil for lighting; 38 the altar of gold, the anointing oil, the perfumed incense, the screen for the entrance of the tent; 39 the altar of copper and its grating of copper, its poles, all its utensils, the basin and its stand; 40 the hanging curtains of the courtyard, its pillars and its socket pedestals, the screen for the entrance of the courtyard, its tent cords and its tent pins and all the utensils for the service of the tabernacle, for the tent of meeting; 41 the finely woven garments for ministering in the sanctuary, the holy garments for Aaron the priest, and the garments of his sons for serving as priests.
42 Israel-viwo wɔ dɔ blibo la katã abe ale si tututu Yehowa de se na Mose ene.
42 According to all that Jehovah had commanded Moses, that was how the Israelites did all the work.
43 Mose lé ŋku ɖe dɔ blibo la ŋu eye wòkpɔe be wowɔe abe ale si tututu Yehowa de see ene; eye Mose yra wo.
43 When Moses inspected all their work, he saw that they had done it just as Jehovah had commanded; and Moses blessed them.
Eye Israel-viwo ƒe ha blibo la ho tso Sin gbedzi heto teƒeteƒewo, abe ale si Yehowa de se na wo ene, eye wova ƒu asaɖa anyi ɖe Refidim.
The entire assembly of the Israelites departed from the wilderness of Sin by stages according to the order of Jehovah, and they camped at Rephidim.
Ke tsi aɖeke meli dukɔ la ano o.
But there was no water for the people to drink.
2 Eye dukɔ la wɔ dzre kple Mose, eye wogblɔ be: “Na tsi mí míano.”
2 So the people began quarreling with Moses and saying: “Give us water to drink.”
Ke Mose bia wo be: “Nu ka tae miele dzre wɔm kplim?
But Moses said to them: “Why are you quarreling with me?

Nu ka ŋuti miele Yehowa dom kpɔ?” 3 Tsikɔ wu dukɔ la vevie le afi ma, eye dukɔ la lĩ liʋiliʋĩ le Mose ŋu be: “Nu ka tae nèkplɔ mí tso Egipte be tsikɔ nawu mía kple mía viwo kpakple míaƒe lãhawo míaku?” 4 Ale Mose do ɣli na Yehowa be: “Nu kae mawɔ na dukɔ sia?

Why do you keep putting Jehovah to the test?” 3 But the people were very thirsty for water there, and they kept murmuring against Moses and saying: “Why have you brought us up out of Egypt to kill us and our sons and our livestock with thirst?” 4 Finally Moses cried out to Jehovah: “What should I do with this people?
Esusɔ vie ko woaƒu kpem!”
A little longer and they will stone me!”
5 Eye Yehowa gblɔ na Mose be: “Dze dukɔ la ŋgɔ, eye kplɔ Israel ƒe ametsitsi aɖewo kpe ɖe ɖokuiwò ŋu, eye nàtsɔ wò atikplɔ si nètsɔ ƒo Nil-tɔsisia dzi la ɖe asi ayii.
5 Then Jehovah said to Moses: “Go ahead of the people, and take with you some of the elders of Israel and your rod with which you struck the Nile River.
6 Kpɔ ɖa, manɔ tsitre ɖe ŋkuwòme le afi ma le agakpe la dzi le Horeb.
Take it in your hand and walk on. 6 Look!
Ƒo kpe la, ekema tsi ado tso eme be dukɔ la nano.”
I will be standing before you there on the rock in Horeb.
Eye Mose wɔe nenema le Israel ƒe ametsitsiawo ŋkume.
Moses did so before the eyes of the elders of Israel.
7 Eye wòna ŋkɔ teƒe la be Masa kple Meriba, elabena Israel-viwo wɔ dzre kple Mose le afi ma, eye wote Yehowa kpɔ gblɔ be: “Ðe Yehowa le mía dome loo alo meli o?”
7 So he named the place Massah and Meribah because of the quarreling of the Israelites and because they put Jehovah to the test by saying: “Is Jehovah in our midst or not?”
8 Esia megbe la, Amalektɔwo ho aʋa ɖe Israel ŋu le Refidim.
8 Then the Amalekites came and fought against Israel in Rephidim.
9 Eye Mose gblɔ na Yosua be: “Tia ŋutsuwo, eye nàyi aɖawɔ aʋa kple Amalektɔwo na mí.
9 At this Moses said to Joshua: “Choose men for us and go out to fight against the Amalekites.
Matɔ ɖe togbɛ la tame etsɔ, eye malé Mawu vavã la ƒe atikplɔ la ɖe asi.” 10 Eye Yosua wɔ abe ale si tututu Mose gblɔ nɛ ene, eye wòwɔ aʋa kple Amalektɔwo.
Tomorrow I will stand on top of the hill, with the rod of the true God in my hand.” 10 Then Joshua did just as Moses told him, and he fought against the Amalekites.
Eye Mose, Aron kple Hur lia togbɛ la yi etame.
And Moses, Aaron, and Hur went up to the top of the hill.
11 Eye ne Mose ƒe abɔwo le dzi la, Israel-viwo nɔa aʋa dzi ɖum, gake ne eɖiɖi eƒe abɔwo ko la, Amalektɔwo nɔa aʋa dzi ɖum.
11 As long as Moses kept his hands lifted up, the Israelites prevailed, but as soon as he would let down his hands, the Amalekites prevailed.
12 Esi abɔ nɔ Mose kum la, wotsɔ kpe de ete wòbɔbɔ nɔ edzi.
12 When the hands of Moses were heavy, they took a stone and put it under him, and he sat on it.
Eye Aron kple Hur lé eƒe abɔwo ɖe dzi, ame ɖeka le akpa si, eye evelia le akpa kemɛ, ale be eƒe abɔwo le dzi va se ɖe esime ɣe ɖo to.
Then Aaron and Hur, one on each side, supported his hands, so that his hands remained steady until the sun set.
13 Ale Yosua ɖu Amalektɔwo kple ame siwo kpe ɖe wo ŋu la dzi kple yi.
13 Thus Joshua defeated AmAlek and his people with the sword.

14 Eye Yehowa gblɔ na Mose be: “Ŋlɔ esia ɖe agbalẽ la me wòanye ŋkuɖodzi, eye nàkui ɖe to me na Yosua be: ‘Matsrɔ̃ Amalektɔwo ɖa keŋkeŋ le dziƒoa te, eye womagaɖo ŋku wo dzi o.’” 15 Eye Mose ɖi vɔsamlekpui hena ŋkɔe be Yehowa-Nisi, 16 hegblɔ be: “Esi Amalektɔwo kɔ woƒe asiwo ɖe dzi ɖe Yah ƒe fiazikpui ŋu ta la, Yehowa awɔ aʋa kpli wo tso dzidzime yi dzidzime.”

14 Jehovah now said to Moses: “Write this as a memorial in the book and repeat it to Joshua, ‘I will completely wipe out the memory of AmAlek from under the heavens.’” 15 Then Moses built an altar and named it JehOvah-nissi, 16 saying: “Because his hand is against the throne of Jah, Jehovah will have war with AmAlek from generation to generation.”

Yakob, si wogayɔna be Israel, ƒe viŋutsu siwo kpe ɖe eŋu va Egipte, ŋutsuawo katã va kple wo ƒemetɔwo, eye woƒe ŋkɔwoe nye esi: 2 Ruben, Simeon, Lewi kple Yuda; 3 Isakar, Zebulon kple Benyamin; 4 Dan kple Naftali; Gad kple Aser.

Now these are the names of Israel’s sons who came into Egypt with Jacob, each man who came with his household: 2 Reuben, Simeon, Levi, and Judah; 3 Issachar, Zebulun, and Benjamin; 4 Dan and Naphtali; Gad and Asher.
5 Ame siwo katã wodzi na Yakob la le ame blaadre, ke Yosef ya le Egipte xoxo.
5 And all those who were born to Jacob were 70 people, but Joseph was already in Egypt.
6 Emegbe Yosef ku, eye nɔviawo katã kple dzidzime ma katã hã ku.
6 Joseph eventually died, and also all his brothers and all that generation.
7 Eye Israel-viwo dzi hede asi agbɔsɔsɔ me, eye wova le agbɔ sɔm ɖe edzi hele ŋusẽ kpɔm ɖe edzi eteƒe mekɔ o, ale be woyɔ anyigba la dzi taŋ.
7 And the Israelites became fruitful and began to increase greatly, and they kept on multiplying and growing mightier at an extraordinary rate, so that the land became filled with them.
8 Emegbe fia yeye aɖe va ɖu Egipte dzi, si menya Yosef o.
8 In time there arose over Egypt a new king, one who did not know Joseph.
9 Ale wògblɔ na eƒe dukɔ la be: “Kpɔ ɖa!
9 So he said to his people: “Look!
Israel-viwo sɔ gbɔ, eye wosesẽ wu mí.
The people of Israel are more numerous and mightier than we are.
10 Mina míadze aye ɖe wo ŋu.
10 Let us deal shrewdly with them.
Ne menye nenema o la, ɖeko woanɔ agbɔ sɔm ɖe edzi, eye ne aʋa dzɔ la, woade míaƒe futɔwo dzi ahawɔ aʋa kpli mí, eye woaʋu adzo le dukɔa me.”
Otherwise, they will continue to multiply, and if a war breaks out, they will join our enemies and fight against us and leave the country.”
11 Ale woɖo dzizizidɔwɔlawo ƒe amegãwo wo nu ne woate wo ɖe anyi ahazi wo dzi woawɔ dɔ sesẽ, eye wotso nudzraɖoƒedu siwo nye Pitom kple Ramses na Farao.
11 So they appointed chiefs of forced labor over them to oppress them with hard labor, and they built storage cities for Pharaoh, namely, Pithom and Raamses.
12 Gake esi wole wo tem ɖe anyi hã la, dzidzim ko wole ɖe edzi, eye wole ta kekem, ale wode asi Israel-viwo vɔvɔ̃ me ŋutɔ.
12 But the more they would oppress them, the more they would multiply and the more they kept spreading out, so they felt sick with fear because of the Israelites.
13 Eya ta Egiptetɔwo zi Israel-viwo dzi wowɔ kluvidɔ sesẽ.
13 Consequently, the Egyptians forced the Israelites into harsh slavery.
14 Wona agbenɔnɔ sesẽ na wo to kluvidɔ sesẽ ɖoɖo na wo me, wona wonya anyi mè anyikpe, eye wowɔ kluvidɔ ɖe sia ɖe ƒomevi le agble me.
14 They made their life bitter with hard labor, as they worked with clay mortar and bricks and in every form of slavery in the field.
Ɛ̃, wona wokpe fu le nɔnɔme sesẽwo me le kluvidɔ ɖe sia ɖe ƒomevi wɔwɔ me.
Yes, they made them toil in harsh conditions in every form of slavery.

15 Emegbe Egipte-fia ƒo nu kple Hebri nyɔnu vixela siwo ŋkɔwoe nye Sifra kple Pua, 16 eye wògblɔ na wo be: “Ne miele vi xem na Hebri nyɔnuwo, eye miekpɔe le via dziƒe be ŋutsuvie la, ekema miwui; ke ne nyɔnuvie la, mina wòanɔ agbe.” 17 Ke vixelaawo vɔ̃ Mawu vavã la, eye womewɔ nu si Egipte-fia gblɔ na wo la o, ke boŋ woxɔa ŋutsuviawo ɖe agbe.

15 Later the king of Egypt spoke to the Hebrew midwives whose names were Shiphrah and Puah, 16 and he told them: “When you help the Hebrew women to give birth and you see them on the stool for childbirth, you must put the child to death if it is a son; but if it is a daughter, she must live.” 17 However, the midwives feared the true God, and they did not do what the king of Egypt told them. Instead, they would keep the male children alive.
18 Emegbe Egipte-fia yɔ vixelaawo, eye wòbia wo be: “Nu ka tae miena ŋutsuviawo tsi agbe?” 19 Vixelaawo ɖo eŋu na Farao be: “Hebri nyɔnuwo mele abe Egipte nyɔnuwo ene o.
18 In time the king of Egypt called the midwives and said to them: “Why have you kept the male children alive?” 19 The midwives said to Pharaoh: “The Hebrew women are not like the Egyptian women.
Ŋusẽ le wo ŋu, eya ta kaka vixelaa nava ɖo wo gbɔ la, wodzi via xoxo.”
They are lively and have already given birth before the midwife can come in to them.”
20 Eya ta Mawu wɔ nyui na vixelaawo, eye dukɔ la dzi ɖe edzi hekpɔ ŋusẽ ŋutɔ.
20 So God dealt well with the midwives, and the people kept increasing and becoming very mighty.
21 Eye esi vixelaawo vɔ̃ Mawu vavã la ta la, ena ƒome wo emegbe.
21 And because the midwives had feared the true God, he later gave them families.
22 Mlɔeba Farao de se na eƒe dukɔ blibo la katã be: “Mitsɔ ŋutsuvi ɖe sia ɖe si Hebritɔwo dzi la ƒu gbe ɖe Nil-tɔsisia me, ke mina nyɔnuviwo katã nanɔ agbe.”
22 Finally Pharaoh commanded all his people: “You are to throw every newborn son of the Hebrews into the Nile River, but you are to keep every daughter alive.”
Eye Yehowa gblɔ na Mose be: “Magahe fuwɔame ɖeka pɛ ko ava Farao kple Egiptetɔwo dzi.
Then Jehovah said to Moses: “One more plague I am going to bring upon Pharaoh and Egypt.
Emegbe aɖe asi le mia ŋu miadzo le afi sia.
After that he will send you away from here.
Ne ele asi ɖem le mia ŋu la, ɖe wòanya mi adzoe le afi sia.
When he does send you away, he will literally drive you out of here.
2 Azɔ gblɔ na dukɔ la be, ŋutsu sia ŋutsu kple nyɔnu sia nyɔnu nabia klosalonuwo kple sikanuwo ehavi.” 3 Ale Yehowa na Egiptetɔwo ve Israel-viwo nu.
2 Now tell the people that all the men and women should ask their neighbor for articles of silver and of gold.” 3 And Jehovah gave the people favor in the eyes of the Egyptians.
Eye Farao ƒe subɔviwo kple eƒe dukɔ la de bubu Mose ŋu ŋutɔ le Egipte-nyigba la dzi.
Moreover, Moses himself had become highly esteemed in the land of Egypt among Pharaoh’s servants and among the people.

4 Eye Mose gagblɔ be: “Ale Yehowa gblɔe nye esi: ‘Le zã titina lɔƒo la, mato Egipte-nyigba blibo la dzi, 5 eye ŋgɔgbeviwo katã aku le Egipte-nyigba dzi, tso Farao si bɔbɔ nɔ eƒe fiazikpui dzi la ƒe ŋgɔgbevi dzi va ɖo kosi si le téƒo ƒe ŋgɔgbevi dzi, va se ɖe lã ɖe sia ɖe ƒe ŋgɔgbevi dzi.

4 Moses then said: “This is what Jehovah has said, ‘About midnight I am going out into the midst of Egypt, 5 and every firstborn in the land of Egypt will die, from the firstborn of Pharaoh who is sitting on his throne to the firstborn of the slave girl who is working at the hand mill, and every firstborn of the livestock.
6 Eye konyifaɣli gã aɖe aɖi le Egipte-nyigba blibo la katã dzi, ɣli si tɔgbi meɖi kpɔ o, eye etɔgbi magaɖi akpɔ gbeɖe o.
6 Throughout all the land of Egypt, there will be a great outcry such as has never occurred nor will ever occur again.

7 Gake avu gɔ̃ hã mawó ɖe Israel-viwo ŋutɔwo loo alo woƒe lãwo ŋu o; ne miadze sii be Yehowa ate ŋu ade vovototo Egiptetɔwo kple Israel-viwo dome.’ 8 Eye wò subɔviwo katã ava gbɔnye ahabɔbɔ nam agblɔ be: ‘Wò ŋutɔ kple dukɔ si le ŋuwò la katã miheyi.’

7 But not even a dog will bark at the Israelites, at the men or their livestock, so that you may know that Jehovah can make a distinction between the Egyptians and the Israelites.’ 8 And all your servants will certainly come down to me and prostrate themselves to me, saying, ‘Go, you and all the people who follow you.’
Emegbe madzo.”
And after that I will go out.”
Ale wòdo dziku vevie hedzo le Farao gbɔ.
With that he went out from Pharaoh in the heat of anger.

9 Eye Yehowa gblɔ na Mose be: “Farao maɖo to mi o, bena nye nukunuwo nasɔ gbɔ le Egipte-nyigba la dzi.” 10 Eye Mose kple Aron wɔ nukunu siawo katã le Farao ŋkume; ke Yehowa ɖe mɔ Farao gasẽ dzi me, ale be meɖe asi le Israel-viwo ŋu wodzo le eƒe anyigba dzi o.

9 Jehovah then said to Moses: “Pharaoh will not listen to you, in order for my miracles to be multiplied in the land of Egypt.” 10 Moses and Aaron performed all these miracles before Pharaoh, but Jehovah allowed Pharaoh’s heart to become obstinate, so that he did not send the Israelites away from his land.

“Bezalel kple Oholiab kpakple ŋutsu siwo katã ƒe tagbɔ aɖaŋu le, ame siwo Yehowa na nunya kple gɔmesesee be woanya dɔ siwo katã ku ɖe subɔsubɔdɔ kɔkɔea ŋu la, nawɔ wo abe ale si tututu Yehowa de see ene.”
“Bezalel will work along with OhOliab and every skilled man to whom Jehovah has given wisdom and understanding so as to know how to do all the work of the holy service just as Jehovah has commanded.”
2 Eye Mose yɔ Bezalel kple Oholiab kpakple ŋutsu siwo katã ƒe tagbɔ aɖaŋu le, ame siwo ƒe dzi me Yehowa de nunyae, ame siwo katã ƒe dzi ʋã wo la, be woava wɔ dɔ la.
2 Moses then called Bezalel and OhOliab and every skilled man into whose heart Jehovah had put wisdom, everyone whose heart impelled him to volunteer to do the work.
3 Eye woxɔ nu siwo katã Israel-viwo dzɔ hena subɔsubɔ kɔkɔe la ƒe dɔwo wɔwɔ la le Mose si; ke amewo gatsɔa lɔlɔ̃nu faa nunanawo vana nɛ ŋdi sia ŋdi.
3 Then they took from Moses all the contribution that the Israelites had brought for the work of the holy service. However, these continued to bring him voluntary offerings, morning after morning.

4 Esi wodze dɔ kɔkɔea gɔme la, aɖaŋudɔnyala bibiawo dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe te va 5 Mose gbɔ va gblɔ nɛ be: “Nu si dukɔ la tsɔ le vavam la sɔ gbɔ wu esi hiã hena dɔ si Yehowa ɖo be woawɔ la wɔwɔ.” 6 Eya ta Mose na woɖe gbeƒã le asaɖa la me godoo be: “Ŋutsuwo kple nyɔnuwo, migatsɔ nudzɔdzɔ aɖeke vɛ azɔ na dɔ kɔkɔea wɔwɔ o.”

4 Then after they started the holy work, all the skilled workers were coming, one after another, 5 and they were telling Moses: “The people are bringing much more than what is required for the work that Jehovah has commanded to be done.” 6 So Moses commanded that an announcement be made throughout the camp, saying: “Men and women, do not bring any more goods for the holy contribution.”
Ale dukɔ la dzudzɔ nunanawo tsɔtsɔ vɛ.
With that the people were restrained from bringing in anything else.
7 Nuawo sɔ gbɔ na dɔ blibo la wɔwɔ; wode gbɔ edzi gɔ̃ hã.
7 The goods were enough for all the work to be done, and more than enough.
8 Eye aɖaŋudɔnyala bibiwo tsɔ ɖeti ɣi biɖibiɖi dada, ka blɔtɔ, alẽfuka si wode ama aɖabɛ dzĩtɔe kple ka dzĩ lɔ̃ avɔgbadɔ la ƒe agbadɔvɔwo; elɔ̃ kerubiwo ɖe eme aɖaŋutɔe.
8 So all the skilled workers made the tabernacle of ten tent cloths of fine twisted linen, blue thread, purple wool, and scarlet material; he made them with cherubs embroidered on them.
9 Agbadɔvɔ ɖe sia ɖe didi abɔklugui blaeve vɔ enyi, eye wòkeke abɔklugui ene.
9 Each tent cloth was 28 cubits long and 4 cubits wide.
Dzidze ɖekae li na agbadɔvɔ ewoawo katã.
All the tent cloths were the same size.
10 Azɔ etɔ agbadɔvɔ atɔ̃ tsiã ɖe wo nɔewo nu, eye wògatɔ agbadɔvɔ atɔ̃ bubuwo hã tsiã ɖe wo nɔewo nu.
10 Then he joined five of the tent cloths together, and the other five tent cloths he joined together.
11 Emegbe etsɔ ka blɔtɔ wɔ ka kotoewo ɖe agbadɔvɔ gbãtɔ siwo woatɔ atsiã la ƒe go ɖeka.
11 After that he made loops of blue thread on the edge of the one tent cloth where it would join.
Ewɔ alea ke ɖe agbadɔvɔ mamlɛtɔ hã ƒe go kemɛ, le afi si woakpe wo le.
He did the same on the edge of the outermost tent cloth at the corresponding place where it would join.
12 Ewɔ ka kotoe blaatɔ̃ ɖe agbadɔvɔ gbãtɔa ŋu, eye wòwɔ ka kotoe blaatɔ̃ ɖe agbadɔvɔ kemɛa hã ƒe go ɖeka, le afi si woakpe wo le, eye ka kotoeawo sɔ ɖe wo nɔewo nu.
12 He made 50 loops on the one tent cloth and 50 loops on the other edge of the tent cloth at the place where it would join so that the loops would be opposite one another.
13 Eyome etsɔ sika tu gavi blaatɔ̃, eye wòtsɔ gaviawo ku agbadɔvɔ eveawo, ale be wòzu agbadɔvɔ ɖeka na avɔgbadɔ la.
13 Finally, he made 50 gold clasps and joined the tent cloths together with the clasps, so that the tabernacle became one unit.
14 Emegbe etsɔ gbɔ̃fu lɔ̃ avɔwo be woatsɔ agba avɔgbadɔ la.
14 Then he made tent cloths of goat hair for the tent over the tabernacle.
Agbadɔgbavɔ wuiɖekɛ wòwɔ.
He made 11 tent cloths.
15 Agbadɔgbavɔ ɖe sia ɖe didi abɔklugui blaetɔ̃, eye wòkeke abɔklugui ene.
15 Each tent cloth was 30 cubits long and 4 cubits wide.
Dzidze ɖekae li na agbadɔgbavɔ wuiɖekɛawo.
The 11 tent cloths were the same size.
16 Azɔ etɔ agbadɔgbavɔ atɔ̃ tsiã ɖe wo nɔewo nu, eye wògatɔ agbadɔgbavɔ ade susɔeawo tsiã ɖe wo nɔewo nu ɖe vovo.
16 Then he joined five of the tent cloths together, and he joined the other six tent cloths together.
17 Emegbe etɔ ka kotoe blaatɔ̃ ɖe agbadɔgbavɔ siwo wotɔ tsiã la ƒe mamlɛtɔ ƒe nugbɔ, eye wògatɔ ka kotoe blaatɔ̃ ɖe agbadɔgbavɔ kemɛa hã ƒe nugbɔ le afi si woakpe wo le.
17 Next he made 50 loops along the edge of the outermost tent cloth where it joined, and he made 50 loops along the edge of the other tent cloth that joined with it.
18 Eye wòtsɔ akɔbli wɔ gavi blaatɔ̃, siwo woatsɔ aku agbadɔgbavɔ la, ne wòakpe azu ɖeka.
18 And he made 50 copper clasps for joining the tent together to become one unit.
19 Etsɔ agbogbalẽ si wode ama dzĩi la gba agbadɔ la, eye wògatsɔ nyogbalẽ hã gba edzi.
19 He made a covering for the tent out of ram skins dyed red and a covering out of sealskins to go over that.
20 Azɔ etsɔ akasiati kpa ʋuƒo siwo woatu na avɔgbadɔ la.
20 Then he made out of acacia wood the tabernacle’s panel frames, which stood upright.
21 Ʋuƒo ɖe sia ɖe kɔkɔ abɔklugui ewo, eye wòkeke abɔklugui ɖeka kple afã.
21 Each panel frame was ten cubits high and one and a half cubits wide.
22 Ekpa zɔvi eve ɖe ʋuƒo ɖe sia ɖe ƒe nugbɔ, eye wole akasa nu.
22 Each panel frame had two tenons joined to each other.
Aleae wòkpa avɔgbadɔ la ƒe ʋuƒoawo katãe.
That is how he made all the panel frames of the tabernacle.
23 Ekpa avɔgbadɔ la ƒe anyieheʋuƒoawo, ʋuƒo blaeve le eƒe axa si trɔ ɖe anyiehe.
23 Thus he made the panel frames for the south side of the tabernacle, 20 panel frames, facing south.
24 Eye wòtsɔ klosalo wɔ anyinɔ blaene ɖe ʋuƒo blaeveawo te; ewɔ anyinɔ eve ɖe ʋuƒo ɖe sia ɖe si ƒe nugbɔ zɔvi eveawo le la te, eye anyinɔ eve le ʋuƒo siwo katã kplɔe ɖo la hã ƒe zɔvi eveawo te.

24 Then he made 40 socket pedestals of silver to go under the 20 panel frames, two socket pedestals beneath one panel frame for its two tenons and two socket pedestals under each following panel frame for its two tenons.

25 Ekpa ʋuƒo blaeve na avɔgbadɔ la ƒe axa evelia, si nye dziehekpa dzi, 26 kple woƒe anyinɔ blaeneawo siwo wotsɔ klosalo wɔ. Anyinɔ eve le ʋuƒo ɖeka te, eye anyinɔ eve le ʋuƒo siwo kplɔe ɖo la hã dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe te.

25 For the other side of the tabernacle, the northern side, he made 20 panel frames 26 and their 40 socket pedestals of silver, two socket pedestals beneath the one panel frame and two socket pedestals beneath each of the other panel frames.
27 Eyome ekpa ʋuƒo ade na avɔgbadɔa megbe, si le ɣetoɖoƒekpa dzi.
27 For the rear section of the tabernacle to the west, he made six panel frames.
28 Ekpa ʋuƒo eve wonye avɔgbadɔ la ƒe dzogoedzitiwo, le eƒe megbekpa eveawo dzi.
28 He made two panel frames as corner posts of the tabernacle at the two rear corners.
29 Wonye ʋuƒo eve ƒokpli tso gɔme va se ɖe tame le gavi gbãtɔa gbɔ.
29 The posts were doubled from the bottom to the top, up to the first ring.
Aleae wòwɔe na dzogoedziti eveawo.
That is what he did with the two corner posts.
30 Ale wole ʋuƒo enyi, eye woƒe klosalo ƒe anyinɔwo le wuiade; anyinɔ eve le ʋuƒo ɖeka te, eye anyinɔ eve le ʋuƒo ɖe sia ɖe te.
30 So they amounted to eight panel frames along with their 16 socket pedestals of silver, two socket pedestals under each panel frame.

31 Etsɔ akasiati kpa xɔblati atɔ̃ na ʋuƒo siwo le avɔgbadɔ la ƒe axa ɖeka, 32 eye wòkpa xɔblati atɔ̃ na ʋuƒo siwo le avɔgbadɔ la ƒe axa evelia, kple xɔblati atɔ̃ na ʋuƒo siwo le avɔgbadɔ la ƒe megbekpa dzi le ɣetoɖoƒe gome.

31 Then he made bars of acacia wood, five bars for the panel frames of the one side of the tabernacle 32 and five bars for the panel frames of the other side of the tabernacle and five for the panel frames of the tabernacle for the rear section to the west.
33 Ekpa xɔblati domedometɔ, be wòato ʋuƒoawo titina tso eƒe go si dzi va se ɖe go kemɛ dzi.
33 He made the middle bar to extend along the middle of the panel frames from one end to the other.
34 Efa sika ɖe ʋuƒoawo ŋu eye wòtsɔ sika wɔ woƒe gaviwo be woalé xɔblatiawo, eye wòfa sika ɖe xɔblatiawo ŋu.
34 He overlaid the panel frames with gold, and he made their rings of gold as holders for the bars, and he overlaid the bars with gold.
35 Azɔ etsɔ ka blɔtɔ, alẽfuka si wode ama aɖabɛ dzĩtɔe, ka dzĩ kple ɖeti ɣi biɖibiɖi dada lɔ̃ xɔmetsovɔ la.
35 Then he made a curtain of blue thread, purple wool, scarlet material, and fine twisted linen.
Elɔ̃ kerubiwo ɖe avɔa me aɖaŋutɔe.
He made it with cherubs embroidered on it.
36 Etsɔ akasiati kpa sɔti ene siwo ŋu woatsii ɖo, eye wòfa sika ɖe sɔtiawo ŋu; etsɔ sika wɔ wo ŋuti nulénuawo, eye wòtsɔ klosalo wɔ anyinɔ ene ɖe wo te.
36 Then he made for it four acacia pillars and overlaid them with gold, along with hooks of gold, and cast four socket pedestals of silver for them.
37 Eye wòtsɔ ka blɔtɔ, alẽfuka si wode ama aɖabɛ dzĩtɔe, ka dzĩ kple ɖeti ɣi biɖibiɖi dada lɔ̃ agbadɔ la ƒe mɔnuvɔ, 38 eye wòwɔ sɔti atɔ̃ kple wo ŋuti nulénuawo.
37 Next he made a screen for the entrance of the tent out of blue thread, purple wool, scarlet material, and fine twisted linen woven together, 38 as well as its five pillars and their hooks.
Efa sika ɖe wo tame kple woƒe nulégaviwo ŋuti, eye wòtsɔ akɔbli wɔ sɔtiawo ƒe anyinɔ atɔ̃awo.
He overlaid their tops and their connectors with gold, but their five socket pedestals were of copper.
Yehowa gblɔ na Mose be: 2 “Gblɔ na Israel-viwo be woadzɔ nu nam; mixɔ nudzɔdzɔ le ame sia ame si ƒe dzi ʋãe la si nam.
Jehovah then said to Moses: 2 “Tell the people of Israel to take up a contribution for me; from every person whose heart moves him, you are to take up my contribution.

3 Nu siwo miadzɔ le wo sie nye: sika, klosalo, akɔbli, 4 ka blɔtɔ, alẽfuka si wode ama aɖabɛ dzĩtɔe, ka dzĩ, ɖeti ɣi biɖibiɖi, gbɔ̃fu, 5 agbogbalẽ si wode ama dzĩi, nyogbalẽ, akasiati, 6 ami si woade akaɖigbɛ la me, balsam-mi si woatsɔ awɔ ami kɔkɔe la kple atike ʋeʋĩ la, 7 kple oniks-kpe kpakple kpe xɔasi bubu siwo woaɖo ɖe kɔmewu la kple akɔtaɖonu la ŋu.

3 This is the contribution that you are to accept from them: gold, silver, copper, 4 blue thread, purple wool, scarlet material, fine linen, goat hair, 5 ram skins dyed red, sealskins, acacia wood, 6 oil for the lamps, balsam for the anointing oil and for the perfumed incense, 7 and onyx stones and other stones to be set in the ephod and the breastpiece.
8 Eye woawɔ nɔƒe kɔkɔe nam, ne manɔ wo dome.
8 They are to make a sanctuary for me, and I will reside among them.
9 Ale si maɖe avɔgbadɔ la kple eme nuwo katã ƒe nɔnɔme afia wòe la, nenema pɛpɛpɛ miawɔ woe.
9 You are to make it, the tabernacle and all its furnishings, following exactly the pattern that I am showing you.
10 “Woatsɔ akasiati akpa Aɖaka la: wòadidi abɔklugui eve kple afã, wòakeke abɔklugui ɖeka kple afã, eye wòakɔ abɔklugui ɖeka kple afã.
10 “They are to make an ark of acacia wood, two and a half cubits long and a cubit and a half wide and a cubit and a half high.
11 Fa sika nyuitɔ ɖe eŋu, ɖe eme kple ekɔgo siaa, eye nàtsɔ sika aɖo to nɛ kpe ɖo.
11 Then you will overlay it with pure gold. Inside and outside you are to overlay it, and you will make a border of gold all around it.
12 Wɔ sikasigɛ ene ɖe eŋu le eƒe dzogoewo dzi le afɔti eneawo gbɔ lɔƒo; asigɛ eve nanɔ eƒe axa si, eye asigɛ eve nanɔ eƒe axa kemɛ.
12 And you will cast four rings of gold for it and attach them above its four feet, with two rings on one side and two rings on the other side.
13 Tsɔ akasiati kpa kpowo eye nàfa sika ɖe wo ŋu.
13 And you will make poles of acacia wood and overlay them with gold.
14 Eye nàtsɔ kpoawo aƒo ɖe asigɛawo me le Aɖaka la ƒe axawo dzi, be woatsɔ akɔ Aɖaka lae.
14 You will put the poles through the rings on the sides of the Ark in order to carry the Ark with them.
15 Kpoawo natsi Aɖaka la ƒe asigɛawo me; womaɖe wo le eme o.
15 The poles will stay in the rings of the Ark; they are not to be removed from it.
16 Eye nàtsɔ Ðaseɖinu si matsɔ ana wò la ade Aɖaka la me.
16 You will place in the Ark the Testimony that I will give you.
17 “Tsɔ sika nyuitɔ wɔ nutunu la: wòadidi abɔklugui eve kple afã, eye wòakeke abɔklugui ɖeka kple afã.
17 “You will make a cover of pure gold, two and a half cubits long and a cubit and a half wide.
18 Eye nàwɔ sikakerubi eve. Nàtu wo ɖe nutunu la ƒe go eveawo dzi.
18 You are to make two cherubs of gold; you will make them of hammered work on the two ends of the cover.
19 Kerubiawo nanɔ nutunu la ƒe go eveawo dzi, kerubi ɖeka nanɔ akpa si, eye evelia nanɔ akpa kemɛ.
19 Make the cherubs on the two ends, one cherub on each end of the cover.
20 Kerubiawo nake woƒe aʋala eveawo me ado ɖe dzi, ale be woƒe aʋalawo natsyɔ nutunu la dzi, eye woadze ŋgɔ wo nɔewo.
20 The cherubs are to spread out their two wings upward, overshadowing the cover with their wings, and they will face each other.
Kerubiawo nade mo to ɖe nutunu la dzi.
The faces of the cherubs will be turned toward the cover.
21 Tsɔ nutunu la ɖo Aɖaka la nu, eye nàtsɔ Ðaseɖinu si matsɔ ana wò la ade Aɖaka la me.
21 You will put the cover on the Ark, and in the Ark you will place the Testimony that I will give you.
22 Maɖe ɖokuinye afia wò le afi ma aƒo nu kpli wò, eye magblɔ se siwo katã made na wò be nàgblɔ na Israel-viwo la tso nutunu la tame, le kerubi eve siwo le Ðaseɖiɖiɖakaa dzi la dome.

22 I will present myself to you there and speak with you from above the cover. From between the two cherubs that are on the ark of the Testimony, I will make known to you all that I will command you for the Israelites.
23 “Tsɔ akasiati kpa kplɔ̃: wòadidi abɔklugui eve, wòakeke abɔklugui ɖeka, eye wòakɔ abɔklugui ɖeka kple afã.
23 “You will also make a table of acacia wood, two cubits long and a cubit wide and a cubit and a half high.
24 Fa sika nyuitɔ ɖe eŋu eye nàtsɔ sika ado atsyã ɖe kplɔ̃ la toga kpe ɖo.
24 You will overlay it with pure gold and make a golden border around it.
25 Eye nàɖo to nɛ wòakeke asiƒome ɖeka, eye nàtsɔ sika ado atsyã ɖe to la toga kpe ɖo.
25 You will make a rim around it a handbreadth wide and a border of gold to go around the rim.
26 Wɔ sikasigɛ ene nàtsɔ asigɛawo ade afɔti eneawo ƒe dzogoe eneawo dzi le afi si afɔ eneawo kpe kplɔ̃a le.
26 You will make for it four rings of gold and place the rings on the four corners, where the four legs are attached.
27 Asigɛawo nate ɖe to la ŋu be woate ŋu aƒo kpo ɖe wo me atsɔ akɔ kplɔ̃ lae.
27 The rings are to be close to the rim as holders for the poles for carrying the table.
28 Tsɔ akasiati kpa kpoawo eye nàfa sika ɖe wo ŋu, ne woatsɔ akɔ kplɔ̃ lae.
28 You will make the poles of acacia wood and overlay them with gold and carry the table with them.
29 “Eyome nàtsɔ sika nyuitɔ awɔ edzi nu siwo nye agba gbadzɛwo, kpluwo, zewo kple agba goboe siwo woatsɔ aƒo nunovɔsawo ɖi.
29 “You will also make its dishes, its cups, and its pitchers and bowls from which they will pour drink offerings. You are to make them out of pure gold.
30 Eye nàtsɔ ŋkumeɖobolo la aɖo kplɔ̃ la dzi le ŋkunyeme ɖaa.
30 And you will put the showbread on the table before me constantly.
31 “Tsɔ sika nyuitɔ tu akaɖiti blibo lae.
31 “You will make a lampstand of pure gold.
Tu eƒe anyinɔ kple eƒe titinati la kpakple eƒe alɔwo ale be atsyã siwo nye kpluwo, kɔ́wo, kple seƒoƒowo katã nanye nu blibo ɖeka.
The lampstand is to be made of hammered work. Its base, its stem, its branches, its cups, its knobs, and its blossoms will be one piece.
32 Alɔ ade nanɔ akaɖiti la ŋu: alɔ etɔ̃ nanɔ akaɖiti la ƒe axa si, eye alɔ etɔ̃ nanɔ eƒe axa kemɛ.
32 And six branches will extend out from the sides of the lampstand, three branches from one side and three branches from the other side.

33 Kplu etɔ̃ siwo le abe yevuziti ƒe seƒoƒo ene la nanɔ alɔawo dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe ŋu le axa si, eye kɔ́awo kple seƒoƒoawo nakplɔ kplu ɖe sia ɖe ɖo. Eye le eƒe axa kemɛ hã kplu etɔ̃ siwo le abe yevuziti ƒe seƒoƒo ene la nanɔ alɔawo dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe ŋu, eye kɔ́awo kple seƒoƒoawo nakplɔ kplu ɖe sia ɖe ɖo.

33 Three cups shaped like almond flowers will be on the one set of branches, with knobs and blossoms alternating, and three cups shaped like almond flowers on the other set of branches, with knobs and blossoms alternating.
Aleae alɔ adeawo anɔ le titinati la ŋu.
This is how the six branches will extend out from the stem of the lampstand.
34 Kplu ene siwo le abe yevuziti ƒe seƒoƒo ene la nanɔ akaɖiti la ƒe titinatia ŋu, eye kɔ́awo kple seƒoƒoawo nakplɔ kpluawo dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe ɖo le eŋu.
34 On the stem of the lampstand are four cups shaped like almond flowers, with its knobs and its blossoms alternating.

35 Kɔ́ ɖeka nanɔ afi si alɔ eve gbãtɔawo dze le la te, kɔ́ ɖeka nanɔ afi si alɔ eve bubu siwo kplɔe ɖo la dze le la te, eye kɔ́ ɖeka nanɔ afi si alɔ eve mamlɛawo dze le la te. Aleae akaɖitia ƒe alɔ adeawo hã anɔ.

35 A knob will be under the first two branches that extend out of the stem and a knob under the next two branches and a knob under the next two branches, for the six branches extending out from the stem.
36 Woatsɔ sika nyuitɔ atu kɔ́awo kple alɔdzeawo be akaɖiti blibo la nanye nu ɖeka.
36 The knobs and the branches and the whole lampstand are to be one piece of pure, hammered gold.
37 Woawɔ akaɖigbɛ adre na akaɖiti la, eye ne wosi akaɖigbɛawo la, woaklẽ ɖo ɖe ŋgɔ.
37 You will make seven lamps for it, and when the lamps are lit, they will shine on the area in front of it.
38 Woatsɔ sika nyuitɔ awɔ eƒe ɖovulãnuwo kple eƒe dzofilɔnuwo.
38 Its snuffers and its fire holders are to be of pure gold.
39 Woatsɔ sika nyuitɔ talento ɖeka awɔ akaɖiti la kple eŋu nuwo katãe.
39 It should be made, along with these utensils, from a talent of pure gold.
40 Kpɔ egbɔ be yewɔ wo ɖe nɔnɔme si wotsɔ fia wò le toa dzi la nu pɛpɛpɛ.
40 See that you make them after their pattern that was shown to you on the mountain.
Ke Midian nunɔla Yetro, si nye Mose to la, se nu siwo katã Mawu wɔ na Mose kple eƒe dukɔ Israel, kpakple ale si Yehowa kplɔ Israel tso Egipte.
Now Jethro the priest of Midian, Moses’ father-in-law, heard about all that God had done for Moses and for his people Israel, how Jehovah had brought Israel out of Egypt.
2 Mose to Yetro xɔ Mose srɔ̃ Zipora wònɔ egbɔ, esime Mose ɖoe ɖe aƒe 3 hekpe ɖe viaŋutsu eveawo ŋu.
2 Jethro, Moses’ father-in-law, had taken in ZippOrah, Moses’ wife, when she was sent back to him, 3 along with her two sons.

Mose na ŋkɔ viawo dometɔ ɖeka be Gersom, elabena egblɔ be: “Mezu amedzro le dzronyigba dzi,” 4 eye wòna ŋkɔ evelia be Eliezer, elabena egblɔ be: “Fofonye ƒe Mawu lae nye nye kpeɖeŋutɔ, si ɖem tso Farao ƒe yi nu.”

One son was named Gershom, because Moses said, “I have become a foreign resident in a foreign land,” 4 and the other was named eliezer, because he said, “The God of my father is my helper, who rescued me from Pharaoh’s sword.”
5 Ale Mose to, Yetro, kple Mose viŋutsuawo kpakple srɔ̃a wova egbɔ le gbea dzi, afi si woƒu asaɖa anyi ɖo, le Mawu vavã la ƒe to la gbɔ.
5 So Jethro, Moses’ father-in-law, along with Moses’ sons and his wife, came to Moses into the wilderness where he was camping at the mountain of the true God.
6 Eye wòɖo du ɖe Mose be: “Nye towò Yetro kple srɔ̃wò kpakple viwòŋutsu eveawo míegbɔna gbɔwò.” 7 Enumake Mose do go yi ɖakpe toa, eye wòbɔbɔ tsyɔ mo anyi ɖe eŋkume, eye wògbugbɔ nu nɛ.
6 Then he sent word to Moses: “I, your father-in-law Jethro, am coming to you with your wife and her two sons.” 7 At once Moses went out to meet his father-in-law, and he bowed down and kissed him.
Wobia wo nɔewo ƒe agbe ta se, eye woyi agbadɔ la me.
Each of them asked about the other’s welfare, and then they went into the tent.
8 Eye Mose gblɔ nu siwo katã Yehowa tu kple Farao kple Egiptetɔwo le Israel ta, kple fu siwo katã wokpe le mɔzɔzɔa me kpakple ale si Yehowa ɖe wo la na toa.
8 Moses related to his father-in-law all that Jehovah had done to Pharaoh and Egypt in behalf of Israel, all the hardships that had befallen them along the way, and how Jehovah had delivered them.
9 Yetro kpɔ dzidzɔ le nu nyui siwo katã Yehowa wɔ na Israel be wòɖe wo tso Egiptetɔwo si me la ta.
9 Jethro rejoiced over all the good that Jehovah had done for Israel by rescuing them from Egypt.
10 Eye Yetro gblɔ be: “Woakafu Yehowa, ame si ɖe mi tso Egiptetɔwo kple Farao si me, eye wòɖe dukɔ la tso Egiptetɔwo ƒe ŋusẽ te.
10 Then Jethro said: “Praised be Jehovah, who rescued you from Egypt and from Pharaoh, and who rescued the people from under Egypt’s control.

11 Azɔ medze sii be Yehowa lolo wu mawu bubuawo katã le nu si wòtu kple ame siwo wɔ nu ɖe eƒe amewo ŋu dadatɔe la ta.” 12 Eye Mose to Yetro tsɔ numevɔ kple vɔsa bubuwo vɛ na Mawu, eye Aron kple Israel ƒe ametsitsiwo katã va ɖu nu kple Mose to le Mawu vavã la ŋkume.

11 Now I know that Jehovah is greater than all the other gods, because of what he did to those who acted arrogantly against his people.” 12 Then Jethro, Moses’ father-in-law, brought a burnt offering and sacrifices for God, and Aaron and all the elders of Israel came to eat a meal with Moses’ father-in-law before the true God.
13 Esi ŋu ke la, Mose bɔbɔ nɔ anyi abe ale si wòwɔna ene, be yeadrɔ̃ ʋɔnu dukɔ la, eye dukɔ la le Mose ŋkume tso ŋdi va se ɖe fiẽ.
13 On the next day, Moses sat down as usual to serve as judge for the people, and the people kept standing before Moses from morning until evening.
14 Esi Mose to kpɔ nu siwo katã wɔm wòle na dukɔa la, ebiae be: “Nu kae nye esi wɔm nèle na dukɔ la?
14 When Moses’ father-in-law saw all that he was doing for the people, he said: “What is this that you are doing for the people?
Nu ka tae wò ɖeka nèbɔbɔ nɔ anyi ɖe afi sia, eye dukɔ blibo la le tsitre ɖe ŋkuwòme tso ŋdi va se ɖe fiẽ?” 15 Mose ɖo eŋu na toa be: “Elabena dukɔ la vaa gbɔnye be woabia nu Mawu.
Why do you sit here alone with all the people standing before you from morning until evening?” 15 Moses said to his father-in-law: “Because the people keep coming to me to inquire of God.
16 Ne nya aɖe dzɔ la, wotsɔnɛ vaa gbɔnye, eye medrɔ̃a ame kple ehavi dome nya na wo, eye menana wonyaa Mawu vavã la ƒe nyametsotsowo kple eƒe sewo.”
16 When a case arises, it comes to me and I must judge between one person and the other, and I make known the decisions of the true God and his laws.”
17 Eye Mose to gblɔ nɛ be: “Nu si wɔm nèle la menyo o.
17 Moses’ father-in-law said to him: “What you are doing is not good.
18 Nu ati kɔ na wò kple dukɔ si le ŋuwò la siaa, elabena agba la kpe na wò akpa. Wò ɖeka màte ŋu atsɔe o.
18 You will surely wear out, both you and this people who are with you, because this is too big a load for you and you cannot carry it by yourself.
19 Azɔ ɖo tom.
19 Now listen to me.
Na maɖo aɖaŋu na wò, eye Mawu anɔ kpli wò.
I will give you advice, and God will be with you.
Nɔ dukɔ la teƒe le Mawu vavã la ŋkume, eye nàtsɔ nyaawo ayi Mawu vavã la gbɔ.
You serve as representative for the people before the true God, and you must bring the cases to the true God.
20 Fia ɖoɖoawo kple seawo wo, eye na woanya mɔ si woato kple dɔ si woawɔ.
20 You should warn them about what the regulations and the laws are and make known to them the way in which they should walk and the work that they should do.

21 Tia ŋutsu zazɛ̃wo le dukɔ la dome, ame siwo vɔ̃a Mawu, ŋutsu siwo dzi woate ŋu aka ɖo, siwo lé fu viɖe ƒoɖi, eye nàɖo wo tatɔwoe, ame aɖewo ɖe ame akpe nu, ame aɖewo ɖe ame alafa nu, ame aɖewo ɖe ame blaatɔ̃ nu, eye ame aɖewo ɖe ame ewo nu.

21 But you should select from the people capable men fearing God, trustworthy men hating dishonest profit, and appoint these over them as chiefs over thousands, chiefs over hundreds, chiefs over fifties, and chiefs over tens.
22 Woadrɔ̃ ʋɔnu na dukɔ la ɣesiaɣi si nya aɖe dzɔ, woawo nakpɔ nya suesuewo katã gbɔ, ke woatsɔ nya sesẽ ɖe sia ɖe ava gbɔwò.
22 They should judge the people when cases arise, and they will bring every difficult case to you, but every minor case they will decide.
Na woatsɔ agba la akpe wò be nuwo nanɔ bɔbɔe na wò.
Make it easier for yourself by letting them share the load along with you.
23 Ne èwɔe alea, eye wòsɔ ɖe Mawu ƒe se nu la, ekema àte ŋu anɔ te ɖe dɔ sesẽ la nu, eye ame sia ame atsɔ dzidzeme ayi aƒe me.”
23 If you do this, and God so commands you, you will be able to stand the strain, and everyone will go home satisfied.”
24 Enumake Mose ɖo to toa ƒe gbe eye wòwɔ nu siwo katã wògblɔ nɛ.
24 Moses immediately listened to his father-in-law and did all that he had said.
25 Mose tia ŋutsu zazɛ̃wo le Israel-viwo katã dome, eye wòɖo wo dukɔ la ƒe tatɔwoe, ame aɖewo ɖe ame akpe nu, ame aɖewo ɖe ame alafa nu, bubuwo ɖe ame blaatɔ̃ nu, eye ame aɖewo hã ɖe ame ewo nu.
25 Moses chose capable men out of all Israel and appointed them heads over the people, as chiefs of thousands, chiefs of hundreds, chiefs of fifties, and chiefs of tens.
26 Eya ta wodrɔ̃a ʋɔnu na dukɔ la ne nya aɖe dzɔ.
26 So they judged the people when cases arose.
Wotsɔa nya sesẽwo vaa Mose gbɔ, ke nya suesuewo katã la woawo ŋutɔwo drɔ̃nɛ.
A difficult case they would bring to Moses, but every minor case they would judge.
27 Emegbe Mose do mɔ toa, eye wòdzo yi eƒe anyigba dzi.
27 After that Moses saw his father-in-law off, and he went his way to his land.
Eye wògblɔ na Mose be: “Lia to la nàva Yehowa gbɔ, wò kple Aron, Nadab, Abihu kple Israel ƒe ametsitsiawo dometɔ blaadre, eye mianɔ adzɔge ade ta agu.
Then he said to Moses: “Go up to Jehovah, you and Aaron, NAdab and Abihu, and 70 of the elders of Israel, and bow down from a distance.
2 Mose ɖeɖe nate ɖe Yehowa ŋu; ame mamlɛawo megate va o, eye dukɔ la megalia toa kplii o.”
2 Moses should approach Jehovah by himself; but the others should not approach, and the people should not go up with him.”

3 Eye Mose va gblɔ Yehowa ƒe nyawo katã kple ʋɔnudrɔ̃ɖoɖowo katã na dukɔ la, eye dukɔ blibo la katã ɖo eŋu kple nu sɔsɔe be: “Nya siwo katã Yehowa gblɔ la, míawɔ wo dzi.” 4 Eye Mose ŋlɔ Yehowa ƒe nyawo katã ɖi.

3 Then Moses came and related to the people all the words of Jehovah and all the judicial decisions, and all the people answered with one voice: “All the words that Jehovah has spoken, we are willing to do.” 4 So Moses wrote down all the words of Jehovah.
Azɔ efɔ ŋdi kanya, eye wòɖi vɔsamlekpui kple ŋkuɖodzikpe wuieve ɖe Israel-to wuieveawo nu ɖe to la gɔme.
Then he got up early in the morning and built at the foot of the mountain an altar and 12 pillars corresponding to the 12 tribes of Israel.
5 Emegbe ena Israel-vi ɖekakpui aɖewo sa numevɔwo, eye wowu nyitsuwo tsɔ sa ŋutifafavɔwo, na Yehowa.
5 After that he sent young Israelite men, and they offered up burnt offerings and sacrificed bulls as communion sacrifices to Jehovah.
6 Eye Mose kɔ ʋu la ƒe afã ɖe agba goboewo me, eye wòhlẽ ʋu la ƒe afã ɖe vɔsamlekpui la ŋu.
6 Then Moses took half of the blood and put it in bowls, and half of the blood he sprinkled on the altar.
7 Azɔ etsɔ nubablagbalẽ la hexlẽe sesĩe ɖe dukɔ la ƒe to me.
7 Then he took the book of the covenant and read it aloud to the people.

Eye wogblɔ be: “Nya siwo katã Yehowa gblɔ la, míalé wo me ɖe asi, awɔ wo dzi.” 8 Eye Mose tsɔ ʋu la hlẽ ɖe dukɔ la ŋu gblɔ be: “Esiae nye ʋu si Yehowa tsɔ ɖo kpe nu, si wòbla kpli mi la me nyawo katã dzi.”

And they said: “All that Jehovah has spoken we are willing to do, and we will be obedient.” 8 So Moses took the blood and sprinkled it on the people and said: “This is the blood of the covenant that Jehovah has made with you in harmony with all these words.”
9 Eye Mose kple Aron, Nadab kple Abihu, kpakple Israel ƒe ametsitsiawo dometɔ blaadre lia to la, 10 eye wokpɔ Israel ƒe Mawu la.
9 Moses and Aaron, NAdab and Abihu, and 70 of the elders of Israel went up, 10 and they saw the God of Israel.
Nane le eƒe afɔ te abe safir-kpe gbadzawo ene, eye wòdza abe dziƒowo ene.
Under his feet was what seemed like a sapphire pavement, and it was as pure as the heavens themselves.
11 Mewɔ naneke Israel-viwo ƒe ame ŋkutaawo o, ke boŋ wokpɔ Mawu vavã la le ŋutega me, eye woɖu nu no nu.
11 He did not harm the distinguished men of Israel, and they saw a vision of the true God and ate and drank.
12 Eye Yehowa gblɔ na Mose be: “Lia to la nàva gbɔnye, eye nàlala le afi ma.
12 Jehovah now said to Moses: “Come up to me on the mountain and stay there.
Matsɔ kpe gbadzɛ siwo dzi maŋlɔ se la kple mɔfiameawo ɖo hena nufiafia wo la ana wò.” 13 Eya ta Mose kple eƒe subɔvi Yosua tso, eye Mose lia Mawu vavã la ƒe to la.

I will give you the stone tablets with the law and the commandment that I will write for their instruction.” 13 So Moses got up with his attendant Joshua, and Moses went up the mountain of the true God.
14 Ke egblɔ na ametsitsiawo be: “Milala mí le afi sia, va se ɖe esime míatrɔ agbɔ.
14 But to the elders he had said: “Wait here for us until we return to you.
Kpɔ ɖa, Aron kple Hur le mia gbɔ.
You have Aaron and Hur with you.
Ne ʋɔnunya aɖe le ame aɖe si la, netsɔe yi na wo.” 15 Ale Mose lia to la esime alilikpo tsyɔ to la tame.
Whoever has a legal case may go to them.” 15 Then Moses went up the mountain while the cloud was covering it.
16 Yehowa ƒe ŋutikɔkɔe xɔ Sinai To la dzi, eye alilikpo la tsyɔ edzi ŋkeke ade sɔŋ.
16 Jehovah’s glory remained on Mount Sinai, and the cloud covered it for six days.
Le ŋkeke adrea gbe la, eyɔ Mose tso alilikpoa me.
On the seventh day he called to Moses from the midst of the cloud.
17 Eye Israel-viwo nɔ Yehowa ƒe ŋutikɔkɔe kpɔm abe dzobibi ene le toa tame.
17 To the Israelites who were watching, the appearance of Jehovah’s glory was like a consuming fire on the mountaintop.
18 Mose ge ɖe alilikpoa me helia to la.
18 Moses then entered into the cloud and went up the mountain.
Eye Mose nɔ to la dzi ŋkeke blaene kple zã blaene
And Moses stayed on the mountain 40 days and 40 nights.
Ke Mose ɖo eŋu be: “Ne womexɔ dzinye se o, eye womeɖo to nye gbe o, eye wogblɔ nam be: ‘Yehowa meɖe eɖokui fia wò o ɖe?’” 2 Eye Yehowa biae be: “Nu kae nye ema le asiwò?”

However, Moses answered: “But suppose they do not believe me and do not listen to my voice, for they will say, ‘Jehovah did not appear to you.’” 2 Then Jehovah said to him: “What is that in your hand?”
Eɖo eŋu be: “Atikplɔ ye.” 3 Eye wògblɔ be: “Tsɔe ƒu gbe ɖe anyigba.”
He answered: “A rod.” 3 He said: “Throw it on the ground.”
Ale wòtsɔe ƒu gbe ɖe anyigba, eye wòtrɔ zu da; eye Mose si le enu.
So he threw it on the ground, and it became a serpent; and Moses fled from it.
4 Azɔ Yehowa gblɔ na Mose be: “Do asi ɖa nàlé eƒe asike.”
4 Jehovah now said to Moses: “Reach out your hand and seize it by the tail.”
Ale wòdo asi ɖa lée, eye wògatrɔ zu atikplɔ ɖe esi.
So he reached out and seized it, and it became a rod in his hand.
5 Eye Mawu gblɔ nɛ be: “Esia ana woaxɔe ase be Yehowa, wo tɔgbuiwo ƒe Mawu, Abraham ƒe Mawu, Isak ƒe Mawu kple Yakob ƒe Mawu la, ɖe eɖokui fia wò.”
5 God then said: “This is so that they may believe that Jehovah the God of their forefathers, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob, has appeared to you.”
6 Eye Yehowa gagblɔ nɛ be: “Meɖe kuku, ƒo asi ɖe wò awua ƒe akɔta.”
6 Jehovah said to him once more: “Put your hand, please, into the upper fold of your garment.”
Eye wòƒo asi ɖe eƒe awua ƒe akɔta.
So he put his hand into the fold of his garment.
Esi wòɖee la, anyi ƒo ɖe asi ŋuti nɛ wòfu kpii abe sno ene! 7 Emegbe egblɔ be: “Gbugbɔ wò asi la ƒo ɖe wò awua ƒe akɔta.”
When he drew it out, why, his hand was stricken with leprosy like snow! 7 Then he said: “Return your hand into the upper fold of your garment.”
Eya ta egbugbɔ eƒe asi ƒo ɖe eƒe awua ƒe akɔta.
So he returned his hand into his garment.
Esi wòɖee le awua me la, eɖɔ ɖo abe eƒe ŋutilã susɔea ene! 8 Eye wògblɔ be: “Ne womexɔ dziwò se o alo xɔ dzesi gbãtɔa dzi se o la, ekema woaxɔ evelia ya dzi ase.

When he drew it out of the garment, it was restored like the rest of his flesh! 8 He said: “If they will not believe you or pay attention to the first sign, then they will certainly heed the next sign.
9 Ke ne womexɔ dzesi eve siawo hã dzi se o, eye womese wò gbe o la, ekema nàku tsi le Nil-tɔsisi la me akɔ ɖe anyigba ƒuƒui dzi, eye tsi si nàku le Nil-tɔsisia me la atrɔ azu ʋu ɖe anyigba.”

9 Still, even if they will not believe these two signs and refuse to listen to your voice, you will take some water from the Nile River and pour it out on the dry land, and the water that you take from the Nile will become blood on the dry land.”

10 Eye Mose gblɔ na Yehowa be: “Yehowa, meɖe kuku, nu menya ƒona nam o, eye aleae wòle tso gbe aɖe gbe ke va se ɖe fifi si nèle nu ƒom kple wò subɔla, elabena nye nu metsɔna o, eye nye aɖe hã metrɔna ɖe nya ŋu kabakaba o.” 11 Yehowa biae be: “Ame kae wɔ nu na ame, alo ame kae nana ame zua aɖetututɔ, tokunɔ, nukpɔla alo ŋkuagbãtɔ?

10 Moses now said to Jehovah: “Pardon me, Jehovah, but I have never been a fluent speaker, neither in the past nor since you have spoken to your servant, for I am slow of speech and slow of tongue.” 11 Jehovah said to him: “Who made a mouth for man, or who makes them speechless, deaf, clear-sighted, or blind?

Alo menye nye Yehowa ye oa? 12 Eya ta heyi, eye nye ŋutɔ manɔ kpli wò ne èle nu ƒom, eye mafia nya si nàgblɔ la wò.” 13 Ke egblɔ be: “Yehowa, meɖe kuku, dɔ ame bubu.” 14 Ale Yehowa do dɔmedzoe ɖe Mose ŋu gblɔ be: “Menye nɔviwòe nye Lewi vi Aron oa?

Is it not I, Jehovah? 12 So go now, and I will be with you as you speak, and I will teach you what you should say.” 13 But he said: “Pardon me, Jehovah, please send anyone whom you want to send.” 14 Then Jehovah’s anger blazed against Moses, and he said: “What about your brother Aaron the Levite?
Menya be ate ŋu aƒo nu nyuie.
I know that he can speak very well.
Eye ele mɔ dzi gbɔna go do ge wò.
And he is now on his way here to meet you.
Ne ekpɔ wò la, eƒe dzi atso aseye.
When he sees you, his heart will rejoice.
15 Ekema nàƒo nu kplii, eye nàtsɔ nyaawo ade enu, eye manɔ kpli mi ne miele nu ƒom, eye mafia nu si miawɔ la mi.
15 So you must speak to him and put the words in his mouth, and I will be with you and him as you speak, and I will teach you men what to do.
16 Eya aƒo nu kple dukɔ la ɖe nuwò, eye wòanye wò nyanuɖela, ke wò la, ànɔ Mawu teƒe nɛ.
16 He will speak for you to the people, and he will be your spokesman, and you will serve as God to him.
17 Tsɔ atikplɔ sia ɖe asi, eye nàtsɔe awɔ dzesiwoe.”
17 And you will take this rod in your hand and perform the signs with it.”
18 Eya ta Mose gbugbɔ yi toa Yetro gbɔ gblɔ nɛ be: “Meɖe kuku, medi be madzo, ne magbugbɔ ayi nɔvinye siwo le Egipte la gbɔ aɖakpɔ ɖa be wogale agbe hã.”
18 So Moses went back to Jethro his father-in-law and said to him: “I want to go, please, and return to my brothers who are in Egypt to see whether they are still alive.”
Eye Yetro gblɔ na Mose be: “Heyi le ŋutifafa me.” 19 Emegbe Yehowa gblɔ na Mose le Midian be: “Heyi, gbugbɔ yi Egipte, elabena ame siwo katã le wò ku dim la ku.”
Jethro said to Moses: “Go in peace.” 19 After that Jehovah said to Moses in Midian: “Go, return to Egypt, because all the men who were seeking to kill you are dead.”
20 Ale Mose kplɔ srɔ̃a kple viawo, eye wòtsɔ wo ɖo tedzi dzi, eye wòtrɔ ɖo ta Egipte-nyigba dzi.
20 Then Moses took his wife and his sons and lifted them onto a donkey, and he started back to the land of Egypt.
Mose tsɔ Mawu vavã la ƒe atikplɔ la hã ɖe asi.
Moreover, Moses took the rod of the true God in his hand.
21 Yehowa gblɔ na Mose be: “Ne ètrɔ yi Egipte la, kpɔ egbɔ be yewɔ nukunu siwo katã mena ŋusẽ wò be nàwɔ la le Farao ŋkume.
21 Then Jehovah said to Moses: “After you have returned to Egypt, see that you perform before Pharaoh all the miracles that I have empowered you to do.
Gake maɖe mɔ eƒe dzi me nasẽ, eye malɔ̃ be yeaɖe asi le dukɔ la ŋu woadzo o.
But I will allow his heart to become obstinate, and he will not send the people away.
22 Gblɔ na Farao be: ‘Ale Yehowa gblɔe nye esi: “Israel la, vinyeŋutsue, nye ŋgɔgbevie.
22 You must say to Pharaoh, ‘This is what Jehovah says: “Israel is my son, my firstborn.
23 Mebe, Ðe asi le vinye la ŋu wòayi aɖasubɔm.
23 I say to you, Send my son away so that he may serve me.
Ke ne ègbe be yemaɖe asi le eŋu o la, mawu viwòŋutsu si nye wò ŋgɔgbevi la.”’”
But if you refuse to send him away, I am going to kill your son, your firstborn.”’”
24 Ke esi wole mɔa dzi va ɖo dzeƒe la, Yehowa va do goe, eye wòdi be yeawui.
24 Now on the road at the lodging place, Jehovah met him and was seeking to put him to death.
25 Mlɔeba Zipora tsɔ kpe ɖaɖɛ aɖe tso aʋa na via, eye wòtsɔ eƒe aʋanuyi la ka eƒe afɔwo ŋuti gblɔ be: “Esi nènye ʋuŋugbetɔsrɔ̃ nam ta.” 26 Ale wòɖe asi le eŋu.
25 Finally ZippOrah took a flint and circumcised her son and caused his foreskin to touch his feet and said: “It is because you are a bridegroom of blood to me.” 26 So He let him go.
Ɣemaɣi Zipora gblɔ be, “ʋuŋugbetɔsrɔ̃ nènye,” le aʋatsotso la ta.
At that time she said, “a bridegroom of blood,” because of the circumcision.
27 Eye Yehowa gblɔ na Aron be: “Yi ɖakpe Mose le gbea dzi.”
27 Then Jehovah said to Aaron: “Go into the wilderness to meet Moses.”
Ale wòyi ɖakpee le Mawu vavã la ƒe to la gbɔ, eye wògbugbɔ nu nɛ.
So he went and met him at the mountain of the true God and greeted him with a kiss.
28 Eye Mose gblɔ nya siwo katã Yehowa, ame si dɔe la, gblɔ kple dzesi siwo katã wògblɔ nɛ be wòawɔ la na Aron.
28 And Moses told Aaron all the words of Jehovah, who had sent him, and all the signs that He had commanded him to do.
29 Emegbe Mose kple Aron yi ɖaƒo Israel-viwo ƒe ametsitsiwo katã nu ƒu.
29 After that Moses and Aaron went and gathered all the elders of the Israelites.
30 Aron gblɔ nya siwo katã Yehowa gblɔ na Mose la na wo, eye wòwɔ dzesiawo le dukɔ la ŋkume.
30 Aaron told them all the words that Jehovah had spoken to Moses, and he performed the signs before the eyes of the people.
31 Ale dukɔ la xɔe se.
31 At this the people believed.
Esi wose be Yehowa trɔ susu ɖe Israel-viwo ŋu, eye wòkpɔ woƒe fukpekpea la, wobɔbɔ de ta agu.
When they heard that Jehovah had turned his attention to the Israelites and that he had seen their affliction, they bowed down and prostrated themselves.
“Tsɔ akasiati wɔ vɔsamlekpui si dzi woado dzudzɔ ʋeʋĩ ɖo.
“You are to make an altar as a place for burning incense; you will make it of acacia wood.
2 Nenɔ dzogoe ene me, wòadidi abɔklugui ɖeka, wòakeke abɔklugui ɖeka, eye wòakɔ abɔklugui eve.
2 It should be square, one cubit long, one cubit wide, and two cubits high.
Eye vɔsamlekpuia kple eƒe dzowo nanye nu blibo ɖeka.
Its horns will be one piece with it.
3 Fa sika nyuitɔ ɖe eŋu: ɖe etame kple eƒe axawo dzi godoo va kpe, eye nàfae ɖe eƒe dzowo hã ŋu; eye nàtsɔ sika aɖo to nɛ kpe ɖo.
3 You are to overlay it with pure gold: its top surface, its sides all around, and its horns; and you are to make a gold border around it.
4 Tsɔ sika wɔ asigɛ eve ɖe to la te le eƒe axawo kple eve dzi, ale be woaƒo kpowo ɖe wo me atsɔ akɔe.
4 You will also make two rings of gold for it below its border on two opposite sides, and these will hold the poles used to carry it.
5 Tsɔ akasiati kpa kpoawo eye nàfa sika ɖe wo ŋu.
5 Make the poles of acacia wood and overlay them with gold.
6 Eye nàtsɔe ada ɖe xɔmetsovɔ si le Ðaseɖiɖiɖakaa gbɔ la ŋgɔ, le Ðaseɖinu la ƒe nutunu la ŋgɔ, afi si maɖe ɖokuinye afia wò le.
6 You are to put it before the curtain that is near the ark of the Testimony, before the cover that is over the Testimony, where I will present myself to you.
7 “Aron natsɔ atike ʋeʋĩ ado dzudzɔ le edzi ŋdi sia ŋdi ne ele akaɖigbɛawo gbɔ kpɔm.
7 “Aaron will burn perfumed incense on it, making it smoke on the altar when he maintains the lamps each morning.
8 Azɔ hã, Aron nado dzudzɔ le edzi ne wòva be yeasi akaɖigbɛawo le anyinutsyɔɣi.
8 Also, when Aaron lights the lamps at twilight, he will burn the incense.
Esia anye dzudzɔ ʋeʋĩ si woado ɖaa le Yehowa ŋkume le miaƒe dzidzimewo katã me.
It is a regular incense offering before Jehovah throughout your generations.
9 Migado dzudzɔ ʋeʋĩ bubu aɖeke si ŋu womeɖe mɔ ɖo o la le edzi loo alo asa numevɔ alo nuɖuvɔ le edzi o, eye migakɔ nunovɔsa aɖeke hã ɖe edzi o.
9 You must not offer on it unauthorized incense or a burnt offering or a grain offering, and you must not pour a drink offering on it.
10 Aron natsɔ nuvɔ̃vɔsalã si wotsɔ lé avu la ƒe ʋu asisi ɖe vɔsamlekpuia ƒe dzowo ŋu atsɔ alé avu ɖe eta zi ɖeka le ƒe me.
10 Aaron must make atonement on its horns once a year.
Woawɔ esia le miaƒe dzidzimewo katã me elabena nu kɔkɔewo ƒe nu kɔkɔe wònye na Yehowa.”
With some of the blood of the sin offering of the atonement, he will make atonement for it once a year throughout your generations.

11 Eye Yehowa gagblɔ na Mose be: 12 “Ɣesiaɣi si nàxlẽ Israel-viwo be yeanya woƒe xexlẽme la, ele be wo dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe naxe fe ɖe eƒe agbe ta na Yehowa ne wole wo xlẽm, ale be dɔvɔ̃ aɖeke nagaɖo wo dome ne wole wo xlẽm o.

It is most holy to Jehovah.” 11 Then Jehovah said to Moses: 12 “Whenever you take a census and count the sons of Israel, each one must give a ransom for his life to Jehovah at the time of the census. This is so that no plague may be brought upon them when they are registered.
13 Nu si ame siwo katã woxlẽ la anae nye esi: sekel afã, le teƒe kɔkɔe la ƒe sekel la nu.
13 This is what all those who are registered will give: a half shekel by the standard shekel of the holy place.
Gera blaeve le sekel ɖeka.
Twenty gerahs equal a shekel.
Sekel afãe woadzɔ na Yehowa.
A half shekel is the contribution to Jehovah.
14 Ame siwo katã xɔ ƒe blaeve kple edzivɔ, siwo ƒe ŋkɔ woaŋlɔ la, adzɔ nu na Yehowa.
14 Everyone registered who is 20 years old and up will give Jehovah’s contribution.
15 Kesinɔtɔ megana wu o, eye ame dahe hã megana wòanɔ ʋɛe wu sekel afã la o; woadzɔe na Yehowa be woalé avu ɖe miaƒe agbewo ta.
15 The rich should not give more and the poor should not give less than the half shekel as a contribution to Jehovah to make atonement for your lives.
16 Xɔ ga si Israel-viwo atsɔ alé avu la le wo si nàtsɔ ana be woatsɔ akpɔ takpegbadɔ la ƒe subɔsubɔdɔwo gbɔ, ne wòanye ŋkuɖodzi le Yehowa ŋkume na Israel-viwo, be woalé avu ɖe miaƒe agbewo ta.”

16 You are to take the silver money of the atonement from the Israelites and give it in behalf of the service of the tent of meeting, that it may serve as a remembrance before Jehovah for the Israelites, to make atonement for your lives.”
17 Yehowa gagblɔ na Mose be: 18 “Tsɔ akɔbli wɔ ze kple eƒe zɔ; eye nàtsɔe ada ɖe takpegbadɔ la kple vɔsamlekpui la dome ahakɔ tsi ɖe eme na asi kple afɔ kɔklɔ.
17 Jehovah spoke further to Moses, saying: 18 “Make a copper basin and its stand for washing; then place it between the tent of meeting and the altar and put water into it.
19 Afi mae Aron kple viaŋutsuwo aklɔ woƒe asi kple afɔ le.
19 Aaron and his sons will wash their hands and their feet there.
20 Hafi woayi takpegbadɔa me alo ate ɖe vɔsamlekpuia ŋu awɔ subɔsubɔdɔ alo asa dzovɔ loo alo ado dzudzɔ na Yehowa la, ele be woaklɔ asi kple afɔ, be woagaku o.
20 When they go into the tent of meeting or when they approach the altar to minister and to make offerings of fire and smoke to Jehovah, they will wash with water so that they do not die.
21 Woakpɔ egbɔ be yewoklɔ asi kple afɔ, be woagaku o. Esia anye ɖoɖo na eya ŋutɔ kple eƒe dzidzimeviwo tegbee.”
21 They must wash their hands and their feet so that they may not die, and it must serve as a permanent regulation for them, for him and his offspring, throughout their generations.”

22 Yehowa gagblɔ na Mose be: 23 “Tsɔ atike ʋeʋĩ nyuitɔwo: mire babla dzidze alafa atɔ̃, sinamɔn ʋeʋĩ dzidze alafa eve kple blaatɔ̃, si nye ekemɛa ƒe afã, gbekee ʋeʋĩ dzidze alafa eve blaatɔ̃, 24 kasia dzidze alafa atɔ̃, le teƒe kɔkɔe la ƒe sekel la nu, kple amititsetse ƒe ami hin ɖeka.

22 Jehovah continued to speak to Moses: 23 “Next, take the choicest perfumes: 500 units of solidified myrrh, and half that amount, 250 units, of sweet cinnamon, 250 units of sweet calamus, 24 and 500 units of cassia, measured by the standard shekel of the holy place, along with a hin of olive oil.
25 Tsɔ wo wɔ ameɖomi kɔkɔe; woatsaka wo nyuie.
25 Then make out of it a holy anointing oil; it should be skillfully blended together.
Ameɖomi kɔkɔe wòanye.
It is to be a holy anointing oil.

26 “Eye nàsi ami na takpegbadɔ la kple Ðaseɖiɖiɖaka la, 27 kplɔ̃ la kple eŋu nuwo katã, akaɖiti la kple eŋu nuwo, dzudzɔdomlekpui la, 28 numevɔsamlekpui la kple eŋu nuwo katã, kpakple ze la kple eƒe zɔ.

26 “You are to anoint the tent of meeting and the ark of the Testimony with it, 27 as well as the table and all its utensils, the lampstand and its utensils, the altar of incense, 28 the altar of burnt offering and all its utensils, and the basin and its stand.
29 Eye nàkɔ wo ŋu, ne woazu nu kɔkɔewo ƒe nu kɔkɔe.
29 You must sanctify them that they may become most holy.
Ame sia ame si aka asi wo ŋu la nanɔ kɔkɔe.
Anyone touching them is to be holy.
30 Eye nàsi ami na Aron kple viaŋutsuwo ahakɔ wo ŋu be woazu nunɔlawo asubɔm.
30 And you will anoint Aaron and his sons and sanctify them to serve as priests to me.
31 “Gblɔ na Israel-viwo be: ‘Ameɖomi kɔkɔe wòanye le ŋkunyeme le miaƒe dzidzimewo katã me.
31 “You will speak to the Israelites, saying, ‘This is to continue as a holy anointing oil to me during your generations.
32 Ame aɖeke megasii ɖe ŋuti o, eye migawɔ etɔgbi aɖeke hã o.
32 It is not to be applied to the flesh of mankind, and you must not make anything with a composition like it.
Nu kɔkɔe wònye.
It is something holy.
Nenye nu kɔkɔe na mi ɖaa.
It is to continue as something holy for you.
33 Ame sia ame si awɔ ami ʋeʋĩ sia tɔgbi, eye wòasii na ame tutɔ aɖe la, woatsrɔ̃e ɖa le eƒe dukɔ la dome.’”
33 Anyone who makes an ointment like it and who puts some of it on an unauthorized person must be cut off from his people.’”
34 Eye Yehowa gagblɔ na Mose be: “Tsɔ atike ʋeʋĩ siwo nye nataf, onitsa, galbano ʋeʋĩ kple lifi nyuitɔ; wo katã ƒe dzidzeme nasɔ.
34 Then Jehovah said to Moses: “Take equal portions of these perfumes: stacte drops, onycha, perfumed galbanum, and pure frankincense.
35 Eye nàtsaka wo nyuie, ade dze eme, atsɔ wo awɔ dzudzɔdonu ʋeʋĩ, wòadza eye wòanɔ kɔkɔe.
35 Make it into an incense; the spice mixture should be skillfully blended, salted, pure, and holy.
36 Eyome nàto eƒe ɖe memie, eye nàtsɔ ɖe ada ɖe Ðaseɖinu la ŋgɔ le takpegbadɔa me, afi si maɖe ɖokuinye afia wò le.
36 You are to pound some of it into fine powder and put some of it before the Testimony in the tent of meeting, where I will present myself to you.
Nu kɔkɔewo ƒe nu kɔkɔe wòanye na mi.
It should be most holy to you.
37 Migawɔ dzudzɔdonu ʋeʋĩ sia tɔgbi na mia ɖokui o.
37 You must not make for your own use the incense that you make with this composition.
Mibui nu kɔkɔe na Yehowa ɣeawokatãɣi.
You are to regard it as something holy to Jehovah.
38 Ame sia ame si awɔ etɔgbi be wòaʋẽ ɖe ye lilili la, woatsrɔ̃e ɖa le eƒe dukɔ la dome.”
38 Whoever makes any like it to enjoy its smell must be cut off from his people.”
Esi Israel-viwo ƒe ha blibo la ho tso Elim la, wova ɖo Sin gbedzi le Elim kple Sinai dome, le woƒe ʋuʋu le Egipte-nyigba dzi ƒe ɣleti evelia ƒe ŋkeke wuiatɔ̃lia dzi.

After they departed from elim, the entire assembly of the Israelites eventually came to the wilderness of Sin, which is between elim and Sinai, on the 15th day of the second month after their departure from the land of Egypt.
2 Eye Israel-viwo ƒe ha blibo la lĩ liʋiliʋĩ le Mose kple Aron ŋu le gbea dzi.
2 Then the entire assembly of the Israelites began to murmur against Moses and Aaron in the wilderness.
3 Israel-viwo gblɔ na wo be: “Ne ɖe míeku le Yehowa si me le Egipte-nyigba dzi esime míebɔbɔ nɔa míaƒe lãzewo ŋu, eye míeɖua abolo ɖia ƒo la, ne enyo wu.
3 The Israelites kept saying to them: “If only we had died by Jehovah’s hand in the land of Egypt while we were sitting by the pots of meat, while we were eating bread to satisfaction.
Azɔ miekplɔ mí va gbe sia dzi be miana dɔ nawu ha blibo sia katã woaku.”
Now you have brought us out into this wilderness to put this whole congregation to death by famine.”
4 Eye Yehowa gblɔ na Mose be: “Kpɔ ɖa, mana abolo nadza tso dziƒo na mi; gbe sia gbe la, ame sia ame nayi aɖafɔ agbɔsɔsɔme si asu nɛ, ne mado wo kpɔ be woawɔ nye sewo dzi loo alo womawɔ wo dzi o hã.

4 Then Jehovah said to Moses: “Here I am raining down bread for you from the heavens, and each of the people should go out to gather his amount day by day, so that I may put them to the test to see whether they will walk in my law or not.
5 Gake nu si woafɔ aɖa le ŋkeke adelia dzi la, nanye nu si wofɔna gbe sia gbe la ƒe teƒe eve.”
5 But on the sixth day when they prepare what they have gathered, it is to be double the amount that they pick up on each of the other days.”
6 Eya ta Mose kple Aron gblɔ na Israel-viwo katã be: “Le fiẽ la, miadze sii be Yehowae kplɔ mi tso Egipte-nyigba dzi.
6 So Moses and Aaron said to all the Israelites: “In the evening you will certainly know that it is Jehovah who brought you out of the land of Egypt.
7 Eye ŋdi la, miakpɔ Yehowa ƒe ŋutikɔkɔe, elabena Yehowa se liʋiliʋĩ siwo lĩm miele le eŋu la.
7 In the morning you will see Jehovah’s glory, for he has heard your murmurings against Jehovah.

Ame kawoe míawo míenye be mialĩ mía ŋu?” 8 Eye Mose gagblɔ be: “Ne Yehowa na lã mi mieɖu le fiẽ, eye wòna abolo mi mieɖu ɖi ƒo le ŋdi la, miadze sii be Yehowa se miaƒe liʋiliʋĩ siwo lĩm miele le eŋu la.

Who are we that you should murmur against us?” 8 Moses continued: “When Jehovah gives you meat to eat in the evening and in the morning bread to satisfaction, you will see that Jehovah has heard your murmurings that you are murmuring against him.
Ke ame kawoe míawo míenye?
But who are we?
Menye mía ŋue miele liʋiliʋĩ lĩm le o, ke boŋ Yehowa ŋue.”
Your murmurings are not against us, but against Jehovah.”

9 Eye Mose gblɔ na Aron be: “Gblɔ na Israel-viwo ƒe ha blibo la be: ‘Mite va Yehowa ŋkume, elabena ese miaƒe liʋiliʋĩlilĩawo.’” 10 Eye esi Aron nya ƒo nu kple Israel-viwo ƒe ha blibo la vɔ teti ko la, wotrɔ dze ŋgɔ gbedzi lɔƒo, eye kpɔ ɖa, Yehowa ƒe ŋutikɔkɔe dze le alilikpo la me.

9 Then Moses said to Aaron: “Tell the entire assembly of the Israelites, ‘Come near before Jehovah, for he has heard your murmurings.’” 10 As soon as Aaron had spoken to the entire assembly of the Israelites, they turned and faced toward the wilderness, and look! Jehovah’s glory appeared in the cloud.
11 Eye Yehowa gagblɔ na Mose be: 12 “Mese Israel-viwo ƒe liʋiliʋĩlilĩawo.
11 Jehovah spoke further to Moses, saying: 12 “I have heard the murmurings of the Israelites.
Gblɔ na wo be: ‘Le anyinutsyɔɣi la, miaɖu lã, eye le ŋdi la, miaɖu abolo aɖi ƒo, eye miadze sii be nyee nye Yehowa mia Mawu.’”
Tell them, ‘At twilight you will eat meat, and in the morning you will be satisfied with bread, and you will certainly know that I am Jehovah your God.’”
13 Eya ta le fiẽ ma la, tegliwo va nyè tsyɔ asaɖa la, eye le ŋdi la, zãmu dza ƒo xlã asaɖa la.
13 So that evening quail came and covered the camp, and in the morning a layer of dew was all around the camp.
14 Esi zãmu la ƒu la, nu wɔliwɔli zɔzrɔ̃e aɖe le anyigba le gbea dzi abe kpetsi wluiwluiwo ene.
14 When the layer of dew evaporated, there was a fine, flaky substance on the surface of the wilderness, as fine as frost on the ground.
15 Esi Israel-viwo kpɔe la, wobia wo nɔewo be, “Nu kae nye esia?” elabena womenya nu si wònye o.
15 When the Israelites saw it, they began to say to one another, “What is it?” for they did not know what it was.
Eye Mose gblɔ na wo be: “Esiae nye abolo si Yehowa na mi be miaɖu.
Moses said to them: “It is the bread that Jehovah has given you for food.
16 Se si Yehowa dee nye esi: ‘Ame sia ame nefɔ esi nu wòate ŋu aɖu.
16 This is what Jehovah has commanded, ‘Each one should gather it according to how much he can eat.
Mifɔe ɖe ame siwo le mia dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe ƒe agbadɔ me la nu, ame ɖeka omer ɖeka.’” 17 Israel-viwo wɔe nenema; ame aɖewo fɔe fũu, eye ame aɖewo fɔe ʋɛe.

You are to take an omer measure for each individual according to the number of the people that each of you has in his tent.’” 17 The Israelites began to do so; they gathered it, some gathering much and some gathering little.
18 Esi wotsɔ omer la dzidzee la, ɖeke metsi ame si fɔe fũu la tɔ dzi o, eye ɖeke meto le ame si fɔe ʋɛe la hã tɔ me o.
18 When they would measure it by the omer, the one who had gathered much had no surplus and the one who had gathered little had no shortage.
Wo dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe fɔ esi nu wòate ŋu aɖu.
They each gathered it according to what they could eat.
19 Eye Mose gblɔ na wo be: “Ame aɖeke megagblẽ ɖeke ɖi ŋu nake ɖe edzi o.” 20 Ke womeɖo to Mose o.
19 Then Moses said to them: “Nobody should leave any of it until the morning.” 20 But they did not listen to Moses.
Wo dometɔ aɖewo gblẽ ɖe ɖi ŋu ke ɖe edzi, gake edze nyé henɔ ʋeʋẽm; eya ta Mose do dziku ɖe wo ŋu.
When some men left some of it until the morning, it bred worms and stank, and Moses became indignant at them.
21 Wofɔnɛ ŋdi sia ŋdi, ame sia ame ɖe eƒe ɖuɖu nu.
21 They would pick it up morning by morning, each one according to what he could eat.
Ne ŋdɔ ʋu la, elólona le anyigba.
When the sun got hot, it melted.
22 Eye le ŋkeke adelia dzi la, wofɔ abolo teƒe eve nu, ame ɖeka omer eve.
22 On the sixth day, they picked up twice as much bread, two omer measures for each person.
Eya ta ha la ƒe tatɔwo katã va gblɔe na Mose.
So all the chieftains of the assembly came and reported it to Moses.
23 Eye wògblɔ na wo be: “Nenemae Yehowa gblɔ.
23 At that he said to them: “It is what Jehovah has said.
Etsɔ la midzudzɔ bliboe, anye sabat kɔkɔe na Yehowa.
Tomorrow there will be a complete rest, a holy sabbath to Jehovah.
Mimè esi miate ŋu amè, eye miɖa esi miate ŋu aɖa, eye midzra esi asusɔ la ɖo na ŋufɔke.” 24 Eya ta wodzrae ɖo ŋu ke ɖe edzi, abe ale si tututu Mose de se ene; meʋẽ o, eye medze nyé hã o.

Bake what you need to bake, and boil what you need to boil; then save whatever is left over and keep it until the morning.” 24 So they saved it until the morning, just as Moses had commanded, and it did not stink nor were there maggots in it.
25 Eye Mose gblɔ be: “Miɖui egbea, elabena egbee nye sabat na Yehowa.
25 Then Moses said: “Eat it today, because today is a sabbath to Jehovah.
Miakpɔ ɖeke le anyigba egbea o.
Today you will not find it on the ground.
26 Ŋkeke adee miafɔe, ke ɖeke manɔ anyi le ŋkeke adrelia si nye Sabat la dzi o.” 27 Ke le ŋkeke adrelia dzi la, dukɔ la me tɔ aɖewo do go yi efɔ ge, gake womekpɔ ɖeke o.
26 You will pick it up for six days, but on the seventh day, the Sabbath, there will be none.” 27 However, some of the people did go out to pick it up on the seventh day, but they found nothing.
28 Eya ta Yehowa gblɔ na Mose be: “Ɣekaɣie miagbe toɖoɖo nye sewo kple nye mɔfiamewo ase ɖo? 29 Mide dzesii be esi Yehowa na Sabat la mi tae wòna ŋkeke eve ƒe abolo mi le ŋkeke adelia dzi ɖo.

28 So Jehovah said to Moses: “How long will you refuse to keep my commandments and my laws? 29 Take notice of the fact that Jehovah has given you the Sabbath. That is why he is giving you the bread for two days on the sixth day.
Ame sia ame nenɔ enɔƒe, ame aɖeke megadzo le enɔƒe le ŋkeke adrelia dzi o.” 30 Ale dukɔ la ɖu Sabat le ŋkeke adrelia dzi.
Everyone must stay where he is; nobody is to leave his locality on the seventh day.” 30 So the people observed the Sabbath on the seventh day.
31 Eye Israel ƒe aƒe la na ŋkɔ nuɖuɖu la be “mana.”
31 The house of Israel named the bread “manna.”
Ele abe nuku ɣi suesuesuewo ene, eye wòvivi abe abolo gbadzɛ si me wode anyitsii ene.
It was white like coriander seed, and its taste was like that of flat cakes with honey.

32 Eye Mose gblɔ be: “Se si Yehowa dee nye esi: ‘Midzra mana omer ɖeka ɖo hena miaƒe dzidzimewo katã, ne woakpɔ abolo si mena mieɖu le gbedzi esime mekplɔ mi tso Egipte-nyigba dzi.’” 33 Eya ta Mose gblɔ na Aron be: “Tsɔ ze nàku mana omer ɖeka ade eme atsɔ ada ɖe Yehowa ŋkume, eye miadzrae ɖo le miaƒe dzidzimewo katã me.” 34 Ale Aron tsɔe da ɖe Ðaseɖinu la ŋgɔ, be wòanɔ dedie, abe ale si tututu Yehowa de se na Mose ene.

32 Then Moses said: “This is what Jehovah has commanded, ‘Fill an omer measure of it as something to be kept throughout your generations, so that they may see the bread that I gave you to eat in the wilderness when I was bringing you out of the land of Egypt.’” 33 So Moses said to Aaron: “Take a jar and put in it an omer measure of manna and deposit it before Jehovah as something to be kept throughout your generations.” 34 Just as Jehovah commanded Moses, Aaron placed it before the Testimony so that it might be preserved.
35 Eye Israel-viwo ɖu mana ƒe blaene, va se ɖe esime wova anyigba si dzi amewo le la dzi.
35 The Israelites ate the manna for 40 years, until they came to a land that was inhabited.
Manae woɖu va se ɖe esime woɖo Kanaan-nyigba la ƒe liƒo dzi.
They ate the manna until they came to the frontier of the land of Canaan.
36 Ke omer ɖeka nye efa me mama ɖe ewo ƒe akpa ɖeka.
36 Now an omer is a tenth of an ephah measure.
Mose kplɔa toa Yetro, Midian nunɔla la, ƒe alẽha.
Moses became a shepherd of the flock of his father-in-law Jethro, the priest of Midian.
Esime wòkplɔ lãha la ɖo ta gbedzi le ɣetoɖoƒe gome la, eva ɖo Mawu vavã la ƒe to Horeb gbɔ.
While he was leading the flock to the west side of the wilderness, he eventually came to the mountain of the true God, to Horeb.
2 Eye Yehowa ƒe dɔla ɖe eɖokui fiae le dzoƒaɖe me le ŋuve aɖe me.
2 Then Jehovah’s angel appeared to him in a flame of fire in the midst of a thornbush.
Esi wòlé ŋku ɖe eŋu la, ekpɔ be ŋuve la le bibim, gake mele fiafiãm o.
As he kept looking, he saw that the thornbush was on fire, and yet the thornbush was not consumed.
3 Eye Mose gblɔ be: “Mayi aɖakpɔ nu wɔnuku sia, ne makpɔ nu si tae ŋuve la mele fiafiãm o.” 4 Esi Yehowa kpɔ be ete va be yeakpɔe ɖa la, Mawu yɔe tso ŋuve la me be: “Mose!

3 So Moses said: “I will go over to inspect this unusual sight to see why the thornbush does not burn up.” 4 When Jehovah saw that he went over to look, God called to him out of the thornbush and said: “Moses!
Mose!” Eye wòtɔ be: “Nyee nye esi!” 5 Egblɔ nɛ be: “Mègate va afi sia o.
Moses!” to which he said: “Here I am.” 5 Then he said: “Do not come any nearer.
Ðe wò afɔkpawo, elabena teƒe si nèle tsitre ɖo la, anyigba kɔkɔe wònye.”
Remove your sandals from your feet, because the place where you are standing is holy ground.”
6 Eye wògagblɔ be: “Nyee nye fofowò ƒe Mawu, Abraham ƒe Mawu, Isak ƒe Mawu kple Yakob ƒe Mawu.”
6 He went on to say: “I am the God of your father, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob.”
Enumake Mose ɣla eƒe ŋkume, elabena ele vɔvɔ̃m na Mawu vavã la kpɔkpɔ.
Then Moses hid his face, because he was afraid to look at the true God.
7 Yehowa gagblɔ be: “Mekpɔ nye dukɔ si le Egipte la ƒe fukpekpe la keŋ, eye mese ɣli si dom wole le ame siwo zia wo dzi be woawɔ dɔ la ta; menya fu siwo kpem wole la nyuie.
7 Jehovah added: “I have certainly seen the affliction of my people who are in Egypt, and I have heard their outcry because of those who force them to work; I well know the pains they suffer.

8 Eya ta maɖi ayi aɖaɖe wo tso Egiptetɔwo si me, eye makplɔ wo adzoe le anyigba ma dzi ayi anyigba nyui si keke la dzi, anyigba si dzi notsi kple anyitsi le sisim le, si nye Kanaantɔwo, Hititɔwo, Amoritɔwo, Perizitɔwo, Hivitɔwo kple Yebusitɔwo ƒe anyigba.

8 I will go down to rescue them out of the hand of the Egyptians and to bring them up out of that land to a land good and spacious, a land flowing with milk and honey, the territory of the Canaanites, the Hittites, the Amorites, the Perizzites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites.
9 Kpɔ ɖa!
9 Now look!
Israel-viwo ƒe ɣlidodo la va ɖo gbɔnye, eye mekpɔ ale si gbegbe Egiptetɔwo te wo ɖe anyi vevie la hã.
The outcry of the people of Israel has reached me, and I have seen also the harsh way that the Egyptians are oppressing them.
10 Eya ta va madɔ wò ɖe Farao gbɔ, ne nàkplɔ nye dukɔ Israel-viwo adzoe le Egipte.”
10 Now come, I will send you to Pharaoh, and you will bring my people the Israelites out of Egypt.”

11 Ke Mose gblɔ na Mawu vavã la be: “Ame kae menye, be mayi Farao gbɔ, eye makplɔ Israel-viwo adzoe tso Egipte?” 12 Eye wòɖo eŋu be: “Manɔ kpli wò, eye esiae anye dzesi na wò be nyee dɔ wò: Ne èkplɔ dukɔ la dzoe tso Egipte la, ekema miasubɔ Mawu vavã la le to sia dzi.”

11 However, Moses said to the true God: “Who am I that I should go to Pharaoh and bring the Israelites out of Egypt?” 12 To this he said: “I will prove to be with you, and this is the sign for you that it was I who sent you: After you have brought the people out of Egypt, you people will serve the true God on this mountain.”
13 Ke Mose gblɔ na Mawu vavã la be: “Tsɔe be meyi Israel-viwo gbɔ, eye megblɔ na wo be: ‘Mia tɔgbuiwo ƒe Mawu lae dɔm ɖe mia gbɔ,’ eye wobiam be: ‘Eŋkɔ ɖe hã la?’
13 But Moses said to the true God: “Suppose I go to the Israelites and say to them, ‘The God of your forefathers has sent me to you,’ and they say to me, ‘What is his name?’
Nya kae magblɔ na wo?” 14 Eye Mawu gblɔ na Mose be: “Mava Nye Nu Si Metia Be Manye.”
What should I say to them?” 14 So God said to Moses: “I Will Become What I Choose to Become.”
Eye wògblɔ kpee be: “Ale nàgblɔ na Israel-viwoe nye esi: ‘Mava Nye ye dɔm ɖe mia gbɔ.’” 15 Eye Mawu gagblɔ na Mose be:
And he added: “This is what you are to say to the Israelites, ‘I Will Become has sent me to you.’” 15 Then God said once more to Moses:
“Ale nàgblɔ na Israel-viwoe nye esi: ‘Yehowa, mia tɔgbuiwo ƒe Mawu, Abraham ƒe Mawu, Isak ƒe Mawu kple Yakob ƒe Mawu lae dɔm ɖe mia gbɔ.’
“This is what you are to say to the Israelites, ‘Jehovah the God of your forefathers, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob, has sent me to you.’
Esiae nye nye ŋkɔ tegbee, eye esiae woatsɔ aɖo ŋku dzinye tso dzidzime yi dzidzime.
This is my name forever, and this is how I am to be remembered from generation to generation.

16 Azɔ yi nàƒo Israel ƒe ametsitsiwo nu ƒu, eye nàgblɔ na wo be: ‘Yehowa, mia tɔgbuiwo ƒe Mawu, Abraham, Isak kple Yakob ƒe Mawu la, ɖe eɖokui fiam gblɔ be: “Nye ŋkuwo le mia ŋu, eye mekpɔ nu si wɔm wole ɖe mia ŋu le Egipte.

16 Now go, and gather the elders of Israel and say to them, ‘Jehovah the God of your forefathers has appeared to me, the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, and he said: “I have certainly taken notice of you and of what is being done to you in Egypt.

17 Esia ta mebe: Maɖe mi tso Egiptetɔwo ƒe fuwɔame la me, eye makplɔ mi ayi Kanaantɔwo, Hititɔwo, Amoritɔwo, Perizitɔwo, Hivitɔwo kple Yebusitɔwo ƒe anyigba dzi, anyigba si dzi notsi kple anyitsi le sisim le.”’

17 So I say, I will take you away from affliction at the hands of the Egyptians to the land of the Canaanites, the Hittites, the Amorites, the Perizzites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites, to a land flowing with milk and honey.”’

18 “Woaɖo to wò gbe; eye wò kple Israel ƒe ametsitsiwo miayi Egipte-fia gbɔ, eye miagblɔ nɛ be: ‘Yehowa, Hebritɔwo ƒe Mawu la, ƒo nu kpli mí; eya ta míeɖe kuku, míedi be míazɔ mɔ ŋkeke etɔ̃ ayi gbedzi aɖasa vɔ na Yehowa mía Mawu la.’ 19 Gake menyae nyuie be Egipte-fia maɖe mɔ na mi miadzo o, negbe ɖe asi sẽ ɖe edzi ko hafi.
