18 “They will certainly listen to your voice, and you will go, you and the elders of Israel, to the king of Egypt, and you men should say to him: ‘Jehovah the God of the Hebrews has communicated with us. So, please, let us make a three-day journey into the wilderness so that we may sacrifice to Jehovah our God.’ 19 But I myself well know that the king of Egypt will not give you permission to go unless a mighty hand compels him.
20 Eya ta mado nye asi ɖa, eye matsɔ nukunu siwo katã mawɔ le Egipte la atu nu kplii, eye emegbe la, ana miadzo.
20 So I will have to stretch out my hand and strike Egypt with all my extraordinary acts that I will do in it, and after that he will send you out.
21 Mana Egiptetɔwo nave dukɔ sia nu, eye ne miele dzodzom la, miadzo asi gbɔlo o.
21 And I will give this people favor in the eyes of the Egyptians, and when you go, you will by no means go empty-handed.
22 Nyɔnu sia nyɔnu nabia klosalonuwo, sikanuwo kple awuwo tso ehavi kple nyɔnu si le eƒe me la si, eye miado wo na mia viŋutsuwo kple mia vinyɔnuwo; eye miaha Egiptetɔwo.”

22 Each woman must ask her neighbor and the woman lodging in her house for articles of silver and of gold as well as clothing, and you will put them on your sons and your daughters; and you will plunder the Egyptians.”
Yehowa gagblɔ na Mose be: 2 “Gblɔ na Israel-viwo be, ‘Ŋkekenyui siwo Yehowa ɖo be miaɖu la nanye takpekpe kɔkɔewo.
Jehovah continued speaking to Moses, saying: 2 “Speak to the Israelites and tell them, ‘The seasonal festivals of Jehovah that you should proclaim are holy conventions.
Miɖe gbeƒã nye ŋkekenyui siawo:
These are my seasonal festivals:
3 “‘Miate ŋu awɔ dɔ ŋkeke ade, ke ŋkeke adrelia anye dzudzɔ blibo ƒe sabat; enye takpegbe kɔkɔe.
3 “‘Six days work may be done, but on the seventh day is a sabbath of complete rest, a holy convention.
Migawɔ dɔ aɖeke o.
You may not do any sort of work.
Sabat wònye na Yehowa le mia nɔƒewo katã.
It is to be a sabbath to Jehovah wherever you dwell.
4 “‘Esiawoe nye ŋkekenyui siwo Yehowa ɖo be miaɖu; takpegbe kɔkɔe siwo miaɖe gbeƒãe le woƒe ɣeyiɣiwo dzi: 5 Miɖu Ŋutitotoŋkekenyui na Yehowa le ɣleti gbãtɔ ƒe ŋkeke wuienelia dzi, le anyinutsyɔɣi.

4 “‘These are the seasonal festivals of Jehovah, holy conventions that you should proclaim at the times appointed for them: 5 In the first month, on the 14th day of the month, at twilight is the Passover to Jehovah.
6 “‘Eye le ɣleti sia ƒe ŋkeke wuiatɔ̃lia dzi la, miɖu Amɔwɔ Maʋamaʋã Bolo Ŋkekenyui na Yehowa.
6 “‘On the 15th day of this month is the Festival of Unleavened Bread to Jehovah.
Miɖu amɔwɔ maʋamaʋã bolo ŋkeke adre sɔŋ.
Seven days you should eat unleavened bread.
7 Ŋkeke gbãtɔ nanye takpegbe kɔkɔe.
7 On the first day, you will observe a holy convention.
Migawɔ dɔ sesẽ aɖeke o.
You should not do any hard work.
8 Ke misa dzovɔ na Yehowa ŋkeke adre sɔŋ.
8 But you are to present an offering made by fire to Jehovah for seven days.
Ŋkeke adrelia nanye takpegbe kɔkɔe.
There will be a holy convention on the seventh day.
Migawɔ dɔ sesẽ aɖeke o.’”
You should not do any hard work.’”

9 Yehowa gagblɔ na Mose be: 10 “Gblɔ na Israel-viwo be, ‘Ne mieva ɖo anyigba si metsɔ le mia na ge la dzi, eye mieŋe nu le edzi la, mitsɔ miaƒe nuŋeŋe gbãtɔawo ƒe babla ɖeka vɛ na nunɔla la, 11 ne wòanyè babla la le Yehowa ŋkume be miaƒe nu nadze eŋu.

9 Jehovah continued to speak to Moses, saying: 10 “Speak to the Israelites and tell them, ‘When you eventually come into the land that I am giving you and you have reaped its harvest, you must bring a sheaf of the firstfruits of your harvest to the priest. 11 And he will wave the sheaf back and forth before Jehovah to gain approval for you.
Nunɔla la nanyèe le Sabat ƒe ŋufɔke.
The priest should wave it on the day after the Sabbath.
12 Gbe si gbe mietsɔ nuŋeŋe la vɛ wonyè la, mitsɔ alẽtsui si xɔ ƒe ɖeka, si sɔ blibo la na be wòatsɔ asa numevɔ na Yehowa.
12 On the day you have the sheaf waved, you must offer a sound young ram in its first year, as a burnt offering to Jehovah.
13 Mitsɔ wɔ memee efa me mama ɖe ewo ƒe akpa eve si wotsɔ ami dzabae la kpe ɖe eŋu miatsɔ asa dzovɔ be wòaʋẽ lilili na Yehowa.
13 Its grain offering will be two tenths of an ephah of fine flour mixed with oil, as an offering made by fire to Jehovah, a pleasing aroma.
Eye miatsɔ wain hin me mama ɖe ene ƒe akpa ɖeka akpe ɖe eŋu atsɔ asa nunovɔ.
Its drink offering will be a fourth of a hin of wine.
14 Migaɖu nuku yeye aɖeke o, woɖatsɔe mè abolo alo tɔe o, va se ɖe ŋkeke sia si dzi miatsɔ mia Mawu ƒe nunana la avɛ.
14 You must not eat any bread, roasted grain, or new grain until this day, until you bring the offering of your God.
Se wònye na mi ɖaa le miaƒe dzidzimewo katã me le mia nɔƒewo katã.
It is a lasting statute for all your generations wherever you dwell.
15 “‘Miaxlẽ sabat adre tso Sabat la ƒe ŋufɔke, gbe si gbe wonyè nuŋeŋe siwo mietsɔ vɛ la.
15 “‘You are to count seven sabbaths from the day after the Sabbath, from the day that you bring the sheaf of the wave offering.
Mixlẽ kwasiɖaawo woade pɛpɛpɛ.
They should be complete weeks.
16 Mixlẽ ŋkeke blaatɔ̃, eye esia adze Sabat adrelia ƒe ŋufɔke dzi, eye miatsɔ nuku yeyewo asa nuɖuvɔ na Yehowa.
16 You will count off 50 days until the day after the seventh Sabbath, and then you should present a new grain offering to Jehovah.
17 Mitsɔ wɔ memee efa me mama ɖe ewo ƒe akpa eve si me wode amɔwɔʋãnui la mè abolo eve tso mia nɔƒewo vɛ be wòanye kutsetse gbãtɔwo ƒe vɔsa si wonyè na Yehowa.

17 You should bring from your dwelling places two loaves as a wave offering. These should be made of two tenths of an ephah of fine flour. They should be baked with leaven, as first ripe fruits to Jehovah.
18 Eye miatsɔ alẽtsui adre siwo sɔ blibo, siwo xɔ ƒe ɖekaɖeka kple nyitsui ɖeka kpakple agbo eve akpe ɖe aboloawo ŋu.
18 And you should present along with the loaves seven sound male lambs, each a year old, and one young bull and two rams.
Miatsɔ wo asa numevɔ na Yehowa, eye miatsɔ nuɖuvɔ kple nunovɔ akpe ɖe eŋu, wòanye dzovɔsa si aʋẽ lilili na Yehowa.
They will serve as a burnt offering to Jehovah along with the corresponding grain offering and drink offerings, as an offering made by fire, of a pleasing aroma to Jehovah.
19 Tsɔ gbɔ̃tsui ɖeka na woatsɔ asa nuvɔ̃vɔ kple alẽtsui eve siwo xɔ ƒe ɖekaɖeka la na woatsɔ asa ŋutifafavɔ.
19 And you must offer one young goat as a sin offering and two male lambs, each a year old, as a communion sacrifice.
20 Nunɔla la nanyè wo kple kutsetse gbãtɔawo ƒe aboloawo le Yehowa ŋkume hekpe ɖe alẽtsui eveawo ŋu, wòanye nunyèvɔsa.
20 The priest will wave them back and forth along with the loaves of the first ripe fruits, as a wave offering before Jehovah, together with the two male lambs.
Nu kɔkɔe woanye na Yehowa, eye woazu nunɔla la tɔ.
They should serve as something holy to Jehovah for the priest.
21 Miɖe gbeƒã gbe ma gbe be enye takpegbe kɔkɔe.
21 On this day you will make a proclamation for a holy convention for yourselves.
Migawɔ dɔ sesẽ aɖeke o.
You may not do any hard work.
Se wònye na mi ɖaa le miaƒe dzidzimewo katã me le mia nɔƒewo katã.
It is a lasting statute in all your dwelling places for all your generations.
22 “‘Ne mieŋe nukuwo le miaƒe anyigba dzi la, mègaŋe esiwo le wò bo to la keŋkeŋ o, eye mègafɔ wò nuku siwo tsi anyi la o.
22 “‘When you reap the harvest of your land, you must not reap the edge of your field completely and you should not pick up what is left from your harvest.
Gblẽ wo ɖi na ame dahewo kple amedzroviwo.
You should leave it for the poor and for the foreign resident.
Nyee nye Yehowa mia Mawu.’”
I am Jehovah your God.’”
23 Yehowa yi edzi gblɔ na Mose be: 24 “Gblɔ na Israel-viwo be, ‘Midzudzɔ mia ɖokuiwo bliboe le ɣleti adrelia ƒe ŋkeke gbãtɔ dzi. Anye miaƒe takpegbe kɔkɔe si dzi woaɖo ŋkui kple kpẽkuku.

23 Jehovah went on speaking to Moses, saying: 24 “Tell the Israelites, ‘In the seventh month, on the first of the month, you should observe a complete rest, a memorial signaled by a trumpet blast, a holy convention.
25 Migawɔ dɔ sesẽ aɖeke o; misa dzovɔ na Yehowa.’”
25 You may not do any hard work, and you will present an offering made by fire to Jehovah.’”
26 Yehowa gagblɔ na Mose be: 27 “Ɣleti adrelia ma ke ƒe ŋkeke ewolia nanye Avuléŋkeke.
26 Jehovah spoke further to Moses, saying: 27 “However, on the tenth of this seventh month is the Day of Atonement.
Anye takpegbe kɔkɔe, miawɔ fu mia ɖokui, eye miasa dzovɔ na Yehowa.
You should observe a holy convention, and you must afflict yourselves and present an offering made by fire to Jehovah.
28 Migawɔ dɔ aɖeke le ŋkeke sia dzi o, elabena avuléŋkeke si dzi woalé avu ɖe mia ta le Yehowa mia Mawu la ŋkumee wònye.
28 You are not to do any sort of work on this particular day because it is a day of atonement to make atonement for you before Jehovah your God.
29 Ame sia ame si mawɔ fu eɖokui le ŋkeke sia dzi o la, woatsrɔ̃e ɖa le eƒe dukɔ la dome.
29 Anyone who will not afflict himself on this day will be cut off from his people.
30 Matsrɔ̃ ame sia ame si awɔ dɔ aɖe le ŋkeke sia dzi la ɖa le eƒe dukɔ la dome.
30 And I will destroy from among his people every person who does any sort of work on this day.
31 Migawɔ dɔ aɖeke o.
31 You must not do any sort of work.
Se wònye na mi ɖaa le miaƒe dzidzimewo katã me le mia nɔƒewo katã.
It is a lasting statute for all your generations wherever you dwell.
32 Dzudzɔ blibo ƒe sabat wònye na mi; miawɔ fu mia ɖokui le ɣletia ƒe ŋkeke asiekelia dzi, le fiẽ.
32 It is a sabbath of complete rest for you, and you will afflict yourselves on the ninth of the month in the evening.
Miɖu sabat la tso fiẽ va se ɖe fiẽ.”
You should observe your sabbath from evening to evening.”
33 Yehowa yi edzi gblɔ na Mose be: 34 “Gblɔ na Israel-viwo be, ‘Tso ɣleti adrelia sia ƒe ŋkeke wuiatɔ̃lia dzi la, miaɖu Agbadɔŋkekenyui na Yehowa ŋkeke adre sɔŋ.
33 Jehovah continued speaking to Moses, saying: 34 “Tell the Israelites, ‘On the 15th day of this seventh month is the Festival of Booths for seven days to Jehovah.
35 Miwɔ takpekpe kɔkɔe le ŋkeke gbãtɔ dzi, eye migawɔ dɔ sesẽ aɖeke o.
35 There is to be a holy convention on the first day, and you should not do any hard work.
36 Ŋkeke adre miasa dzovɔ na Yehowa.
36 Seven days you must present an offering made by fire to Jehovah.
Miwɔ takpekpe kɔkɔe le ŋkeke enyia gbe, eye miasa dzovɔ na Yehowa.
On the eighth day, you should observe a holy convention, and you should present an offering made by fire to Jehovah.
Takpekpe tɔxɛ wònye.
It is a solemn assembly.
Migawɔ dɔ sesẽ aɖeke o.
You may not do any hard work.

37 “‘Esiawoe nye Yehowa ƒe ŋkekenyui siwo wòɖo na mi, siwo miaɖe gbeƒãe be wonye takpekpe kɔkɔewo, siwo dzi miasa numevɔ kple nuɖuvɔ kpakple nunovɔwo na Yehowa woanye dzovɔsawo le gbe sia gbe ɖoɖowɔɖia nu, 38 hekpe ɖe vɔ siwo miasa le Yehowa ƒe sabatwo dzi kpakple miaƒe nunanawo, miaƒe adzɔgbeɖenunanawo, kple miaƒe lɔlɔ̃nu faa nunana siwo katã miatsɔ ana Yehowa la ŋu.

37 “‘These are the seasonal festivals of Jehovah that you should proclaim as holy conventions for presenting an offering made by fire to Jehovah: the burnt offering and the grain offering of the sacrifice and the drink offerings according to the daily schedule. 38 These are in addition to what is offered on Jehovah’s sabbaths, and your gifts, your vow offerings, and your voluntary offerings, which you should give to Jehovah.
39 Ne mieƒo nu siwo anyigbaa wɔ la nu ƒu la, ekema miaɖu Yehowa ƒe ŋkekenyui la le ɣleti adrelia ƒe ŋkeke wuiatɔ̃lia dzi ŋkeke adre sɔŋ.
39 However, on the 15th day of the seventh month, when you have gathered the produce of the land, you should celebrate the festival of Jehovah for seven days.
Ŋkeke gbãtɔ nanye dzudzɔ blibo, eye ŋkeke enyilia hã nanye dzudzɔ blibo.
On the first day is a complete rest and on the eighth day is a complete rest.
40 Mitsɔ ati siwo nya kpɔ la dzi kutsetsewo, deʋayawo, ati siwo do nyuie la ƒe alɔwo kple amuti siwo le tɔʋu to la vɛ le ŋkeke gbãtɔ dzi, eye miakpɔ dzidzɔ le Yehowa mia Mawu ŋkume ŋkeke adre.

40 On the first day, you will take the fruit of majestic trees, the fronds of palm trees, the branches of leafy trees and poplars of the valley, and you will rejoice before Jehovah your God for seven days.
41 Eye wòanye ŋkekenyui miaɖu na Yehowa ŋkeke adre sɔŋ le ƒea me.
41 You will celebrate it as a festival to Jehovah for seven days in the year.
Miaɖui le ɣleti adrelia me; se wònye na mi ɖaa le miaƒe dzidzimewo katã me.
As a lasting statute during all your generations, you should celebrate it in the seventh month.
42 Minɔ agbadɔ me ŋkeke adre sɔŋ.
42 You should dwell in the booths for seven days.
Israel vidzidziwo katã nanɔ agbadɔ me, 43 ne miaƒe dzidzimewo nanyae be agbadɔ mee mena Israel-viwo nɔ esime mekplɔ wo tso Egipte-nyigba dzi.

All the natives in Israel should dwell in the booths, 43 so that your future generations may know that it was in the booths that I made the Israelites dwell when I was bringing them out of the land of Egypt.
Nyee nye Yehowa mia Mawu.’”
I am Jehovah your God.’”
44 Ale Mose gblɔ ŋkekenyui siwo Yehowa ɖo be woaɖu la na Israel-viwo.
44 So Moses spoke of the seasonal festivals of Jehovah to the Israelites.
“‘Ke ne ame aɖe di be yeasa nuɖuvɔ na Yehowa la, ekema wòatsɔ wɔ memee asa vɔ lae, wòakɔ ami ɖe edzi eye wòatsɔ lifi akpe ɖe eŋu.
“‘Now if someone presents a grain offering to Jehovah, his offering must be fine flour, and he should pour oil on it and put frankincense on it.

2 Eye wòatsɔe ava Aron viŋutsu siwo nye nunɔlawo gbɔ, eye nunɔla la naku wɔ memee la kple ami la kpakple lifi la katã asiʋlo ɖeka; eye wòatsɔe ado dzudzɔ ɖe vɔsamlekpui la dzi wòanye kpɔɖeŋuvɔsa, wòanye dzovɔsa si nye ʋeʋẽ lilili na Yehowa.

2 Then he will bring it to the sons of Aaron, the priests, and the priest will take a handful of the fine flour and oil and all its frankincense, and he will make it smoke as a token offering on the altar, an offering made by fire of a pleasing aroma to Jehovah.
3 Ke nuɖuvɔsa susɔea nanye Aron kple viaŋutsuwo tɔ, abe nu kɔkɔewo ƒe nu kɔkɔe tso Yehowa ƒe dzovɔsawo me ene.
3 Whatever is left of the grain offering belongs to Aaron and his sons as something most holy from Jehovah’s offerings made by fire.
4 “‘Eye ne èbe yeatsɔ nu si womè le kpo me asa nuɖuvɔe la, ekema wòanye esi wotsɔ wɔ memee si wotsɔ ami dzabae la mè, wòanye amɔwɔ maʋamaʋã bolo kotoe alo amɔwɔ maʋamaʋã kpɔnɔ si dzi wosisi ami ɖo.
4 “‘If you present a grain offering that has been baked in the oven, it should be of fine flour, unleavened ring-shaped loaves mixed with oil or unleavened wafers spread with oil.
5 “‘Eye ne èbe yeamè nu le agba me asa nuɖuvɔe la, ekema wòanye wɔ memee si wotsɔ ami dzabae, si me womede amɔwɔʋãnui o.
5 “‘If your offering is a grain offering from the griddle, it should be of fine, unleavened flour mixed with oil.
6 Woaflii kakɛkakɛe, eye nàkɔ ami ɖe edzi.
6 It should be broken into pieces, and you are to pour oil on it.
Nuɖuvɔsa wònye.
It is a grain offering.
7 “‘Eye ne èbe yeatsɔ nu si woɖana le ze me asa nuɖuvɔe la, ekema nàtsɔ wɔ memee kple ami aɖae.
7 “‘If your offering is a grain offering prepared in a pan, it should be made of fine flour with oil.
8 Eye nàtsɔ nuɖuvɔsa si wotsɔ nu siawo ɖae la vɛ na Yehowa, tsɔe yi na nunɔlaa, eye wòatsɔe ayi vɔsamlekpuia gbɔ.
8 You should bring the grain offering that was made of these to Jehovah, and it will be presented to the priest, who will bring it near to the altar.
9 Eye nunɔla la atsɔ nuɖuvɔsa la ƒe ɖe, wòanye kpɔɖeŋuvɔsa, eye wòatsɔe ado dzudzɔ ɖe vɔsamlekpui la dzi wòanye dzovɔsa si nye ʋeʋẽ lilili na Yehowa.
9 And the priest will lift off some of the grain offering as a token offering and make it smoke on the altar as an offering made by fire of a pleasing aroma to Jehovah.
10 Ke nuɖuvɔsa susɔea nanye Aron kple viaŋutsuwo tɔ, abe nu kɔkɔewo ƒe nu kɔkɔe tso Yehowa ƒe dzovɔsawo me ene.
10 What is left of the grain offering belongs to Aaron and his sons as something most holy of Jehovah’s offerings by fire.
11 “‘Migade nuʋãnu aɖeke nu siwo miatsɔ asa nuɖuvɔe na Yehowa la dometɔ aɖeke me o, elabena miekpɔ mɔ atsɔ amɔwɔ ʋaʋã aɖeke kple anyitsi aɖeke kura ado dzudzɔ wòanye dzovɔsa na Yehowa o.
11 “‘No grain offering that you present to Jehovah should be leavened, for you must not make any sourdough or honey smoke as an offering made by fire to Jehovah.
12 “‘Miate ŋu atsɔ wo vɛ na Yehowa abe kutsetse gbãtɔwo ene, ke womatɔ dzo wo le vɔsamlekpui la dzi wòanye ʋeʋẽ lilili o.
12 “‘You may present them to Jehovah as an offering of the firstfruits, but they must not be brought to the altar as a pleasing aroma.
13 “‘De dze wò nuɖuvɔsawo katã me; mègado kpo wò Mawu ƒe nubabla ƒe dze la dede wò nuɖuvɔsa me o.
13 “‘Every grain offering you make is to be seasoned with salt; and you must not allow the salt of the covenant of your God to be missing from your grain offering.
Dze nakpe ɖe wò nunanawo katã ŋu.
Along with every offering of yours, you will present salt.
14 “‘Ne èbe yeatsɔ kutsetse gbãtɔwo asa nuɖuvɔe na Yehowa la, ekema nàtsɔ nuku yeye siwo womè le dzo me, siwo nye nuku yeye siwo wogbã keŋ la vɛ wòanye wò kutsetse gbãtɔwo ƒe nuɖuvɔsa.

14 “‘If you present the grain offering of the first ripe fruits to Jehovah, you should present new grain roasted with fire, coarsely crushed new kernels, as the grain offering of your first ripe fruits.
15 Kɔ ami ɖe edzi, eye nàtsɔ lifi ada ɖe edzi.
15 You are to put oil on it and place frankincense on it.
Nuɖuvɔsa wònye.
It is a grain offering.
16 Eye nunɔla la natsɔ vɔsa la ƒe kpɔɖeŋuvɔsa, si nye nuku si wogbã la kpakple ami la ƒe ɖe hekpe ɖe eŋuti lifi la katã ŋu ado dzudzɔ wòanye dzovɔsa na Yehowa.
16 The priest will make it smoke as a token offering, that is, some of the coarse grain and oil along with all its frankincense, as an offering made by fire to Jehovah.
Yehowa gagblɔ na Mose be: 2 “Gblɔ na Israel-viwo be: ‘Ne nyɔnu aɖe fɔ fu, eye wòdzi ŋutsuvi la, ekema eŋu mekɔ o ŋkeke adre, abe ale si eŋu mekɔ o le ŋkeke siwo me wòɖo asi anyi lae ene.

Jehovah went on to say to Moses: 2 “Tell the Israelites, ‘If a woman becomes pregnant and gives birth to a male, she will be unclean for seven days, just as she is in the days of the impurity when she is menstruating.
3 Le ŋkeke enyia gbe la, woatso aʋa na ɖevia.
3 On the eighth day, the flesh of his foreskin will be circumcised.
4 Eye nyɔnu la agakɔ eɖokui ŋu tso eƒe ʋu la me ŋkeke blaetɔ̃ vɔ etɔ̃ kpee.
4 She will continue cleansing herself from the blood for the next 33 days.
Megaka asi nu kɔkɔe aɖeke ŋu o, eye megava kɔkɔeƒe la o, va se ɖe esime wòwu eŋukɔkɔ ƒe ŋkekeawo nu hafi.
She should not touch any holy thing, and she should not come into the holy place until she fulfills the days of her purification.
5 “‘Ke ne edzi nyɔnuvi la, ekema eŋu mekɔ o ŋkeke wuiene, abe ale si ko eŋu mekɔ o le eƒe asiɖoanyiɣi ene.
5 “‘If she should give birth to a female, she will then be unclean for 14 days, just as she would be during her menstruation.
Akpɔtɔ akɔ eɖokui ŋu tso ʋu la me ŋkeke blaade vɔ ade kpee.
She will continue cleansing herself from the blood for the next 66 days.

6 Ne ŋutsuvi alo nyɔnuvie wòdzi, eye eŋukɔkɔ ƒe ŋkekeawo wu enu la, ekema wòatsɔ alẽtsui si mexɔ wu ƒe ɖeka o vɛ na nunɔla le takpegbadɔa ƒe mɔnu be woatsɔ asa numevɔ, kple ahɔnɛvi ɖeka alo akpakpa ɖeka be woatsɔ asa nuvɔ̃vɔ.

6 When the days of her purification for a son or a daughter are completed, she will bring a young ram in its first year for a burnt offering and a young pigeon or a turtledove for a sin offering to the entrance of the tent of meeting, to the priest.
7 Nunɔla la natsɔe ava Yehowa ŋkume ahalé avu ɖe eta, eye eŋu akɔ tso ʋu si do le eŋu la me.
7 He will present it before Jehovah and make atonement for her, and she will be clean from her flow of blood.
Esiae nye nyɔnu si dzi ŋutsuvi alo nyɔnuvi la ŋuti se.
This is the law about the woman who gives birth to either a male or a female.
8 Ke ne mate ŋu ana alẽ o la, ekema wòatsɔ akpakpa eve alo ahɔnɛvi eve vɛ, woatsɔ ɖeka asa numevɔ, eye woatsɔ evelia asa nuvɔ̃vɔ, eye nunɔla la nalé avu ɖe eta, eye eŋu akɔ.’”

8 But if she cannot afford a sheep, she must then take two turtledoves or two young pigeons, one for a burnt offering and one for a sin offering, and the priest will make atonement for her, and she will be clean.’”

Yehowa gagblɔ na Mose be: 2 “Ne ame aɖe wɔ nu vɔ̃, ale be mewɔ nuteƒe na Yehowa o, eye wòble ehavi le nane si woda ɖe egbɔ, alo wobe nedzrae ɖo la me, alo wòfi ehavi alo tafae, 3 alo wòfɔ nane si bú eye wòsẽ nu, eye wòka aʋatso heta nu le nu vɔ̃ siawo dometɔ aɖe si wòwɔ me la, nu si wòawɔe nye esi: 4 Ne ewɔ nu vɔ̃ heɖi fɔ la, ekema wòatrɔ nu si wòfi alo nu si wòba ame xɔ alo nu si wòtafa ame xɔ, eɖanye nu ka kee woda ɖe egbɔ o, alo nu búbu, si wòfɔ, 5 alo nu sia nu si me wòda alakpa heta nu le la ayii, eye wòaɖo eteƒe bliboe ahatsɔ nua ƒe home me mama ɖe teƒe atɔ̃ ƒe ɖeka akpe ɖe eŋuti.

Jehovah went on to say to Moses: 2 “If someone sins and behaves unfaithfully toward Jehovah by deceiving his neighbor in connection with something entrusted to him, or something deposited with him, or he robs or defrauds his neighbor, 3 or he finds something lost and is deceptive about it, and if he swears falsely over any such sin he may commit, this is what he should do: 4 If he has sinned and is guilty, he must return what he stole, what he extorted, what he took by fraud, what was entrusted to him, or the lost thing that he found, 5 or anything about which he swore falsely, and he must make full compensation for it, and he will add to it a fifth of its value.
Wòatsɔe ana ame si tɔ wònye le gbe si gbe woɖo kpe edzi be eɖi fɔ.
He will give it to the owner on the day his guilt is proved.
6 Eye wòatsɔ fɔɖivɔsalã, si anye agbo si sɔ blibo, si asɔ ɖe home si woɖo la nu, ava nunɔla la gbɔ be woatsɔ asa fɔɖivɔ na Yehowa.
6 And he will bring to the priest as his guilt offering to Jehovah a sound ram from the flock according to the assessed value, for a guilt offering.
7 Eye nunɔla la nalé avu ɖe eta le Yehowa ŋkume, eye woatsɔ nu sia nu si wòwɔ heɖi fɔ la akee.”
7 The priest will make atonement for him before Jehovah, and he will be forgiven for anything he may have done resulting in his guilt.”

8 Yehowa gagblɔ na Mose be: 9 “De se na Aron kple viaŋutsuwo be: ‘Esiae nye numevɔsa la ŋuti se: Numevɔsa la nanɔ dzo si le vɔsamlekpuia me la dzi zã bliboa katã va se ɖe ŋdi, eye dzo nanɔ bibim ɖaa le vɔsamlekpuia me.

8 Jehovah continued to speak to Moses, saying: 9 “Command Aaron and his sons and say, ‘This is the law of the burnt offering: The burnt offering will remain on the hearth on the altar all night long until the morning, and the fire will be kept burning on the altar.
10 Nunɔla la nado eƒe nunɔlaklalawu, eye wòado aklalatakpui.
10 The priest will clothe himself with his official dress of linen, and he will put the linen shorts on over his flesh.
Azɔ wòalɔ numevɔsa siwo dzo la bi le vɔsamlekpuia dzi la ƒe dzofiwo akɔ ɖe vɔsamlekpuia xa.
Then he will remove the ashes of the burnt offering that the fire had consumed on the altar and place them beside the altar.
11 Emegbe wòaɖe eƒe awuwo ahado awu bubuwo, eye wòalɔ dzofiawo ayi teƒe dzadzɛ aɖe le asaɖa la godo.
11 Then he will take off his garments and put on other garments and take the ashes to a clean place outside the camp.
12 Dzo nanɔ bibim le vɔsamlekpuia me ɖaa.
12 The fire will be kept burning on the altar.
Dzo megatsi le eme o.
It must not go out.
Nunɔla la nanɔ nake dem eme ŋdi sia ŋdi, eye wòaɖo numevɔsalã la ɖe edzi ahatsɔ ŋutifafavɔsalãa ƒe amiwo ado dzudzɔ ɖe edzi.
The priest must burn wood on it each morning and arrange the burnt offering over it, and he will make the fat of the communion sacrifices smoke over it.
13 Dzo nanɔ bibim le vɔsamlekpuia me ɖaa.
13 Fire will be kept constantly burning on the altar.
Dzo megatsi le eme o.
It must not go out.
14 “‘Ke esiae nye nuɖuvɔsa ŋuti se: Mi Aron viŋutsuwo mitsɔe va Yehowa ŋkume le vɔsamlekpuia ŋgɔ.
14 “‘Now this is the law of the grain offering: You sons of Aaron are to present it before Jehovah in front of the altar.

15 Wo dometɔ ɖeka naku nuɖuvɔsa ƒe wɔ memee la kple eƒe ami la kpakple lifi si le nuɖuvɔsaa dzi la katã ƒe asiʋlo ɖeka atsɔ ado dzudzɔ ɖe vɔsamlekpuia dzi wòanye ʋeʋẽ lilili, si anye kpɔɖeŋuvɔsa na Yehowa.

15 One of them will take a handful from the fine flour of the grain offering and some of its oil and all the frankincense that is on the grain offering, and he will make it smoke on the altar as a pleasing aroma for a token offering to Jehovah.
16 Aron kple viaŋutsuwo naɖu susɔea.
16 Aaron and his sons will eat what is left of it.
Amɔwɔ maʋamaʋã bolo wòanye woaɖu le teƒe kɔkɔe la.
It will be eaten as unleavened bread in a holy place.
Woaɖui le takpegbadɔa ƒe xɔxɔnu.
They will eat it in the courtyard of the tent of meeting.
17 Womade nuʋãnu aɖeke eme hafi amèe o.
17 It should not be baked with anything leavened.
Nye dzovɔsawo me meɖee le na wo be wòanye wo tɔ.
I have given it as their share out of my offerings made by fire.
Nu kɔkɔewo ƒe nu kɔkɔe wònye abe nuvɔ̃vɔsa kple fɔɖivɔsa ke ene.
It is something most holy, like the sin offering and like the guilt offering.
18 Aron ƒe dzidzimevi ŋutsuwo katã kpɔ mɔ aɖui.
18 Every male among the sons of Aaron will eat it.
Anye woƒe gome ɖaa tso Yehowa ƒe dzovɔsawo me le miaƒe dzidzimewo katã me.
It is their permanent allowance throughout your generations from Jehovah’s offerings made by fire.
Nu sia nu si aka wo ŋu la azu nu kɔkɔe.’”
Everything that touches them will become holy.’”

19 Yehowa gagblɔ na Mose be: 20 “Esiae nye vɔ si Aron kple viaŋutsuwo asa na Yehowa le gbe si gbe woasi ami na wo dometɔ aɖe: woana wɔ memee efa me mama ewo ƒe akpa ɖeka be woatsɔ asa nuɖuvɔe, woatsɔ afã asa vɔe le ŋdi eye afã le fiẽ.

19 Jehovah spoke again to Moses: 20 “This is the offering that Aaron and his sons will present to Jehovah on the day he is anointed: the tenth of an ephah of fine flour as a regular grain offering, half of it in the morning and half of it in the evening.
21 Woatsɔ ami ablui ahamèe le agba me.
21 It will be made with oil on a griddle.
Nàblui kple ami nyuie amèe wòanye nuɖuvɔsanu eye nàflii hafi atsɔ asa vɔe be wòanye ʋeʋẽ lilili na Yehowa.
You will bring it well-mixed with oil and present it in pieces as a baked product of the grain offering as a pleasing aroma to Jehovah.
22 Eye nunɔla viŋutsu si wosi ami na be wòazu nunɔla ɖe eteƒe la nawɔe.
22 The anointed priest who succeeds him from among his sons will make it.
Ðoɖo wònye ɖaa: Woatsɔ vɔsa bliboa ado dzudzɔ na Yehowa.
It is a lasting regulation: As a whole offering it will be made to smoke to Jehovah.
23 Woatɔ dzo nunɔla ƒe nuɖuvɔsa ɖe sia ɖe keŋkeŋ.
23 Every grain offering of a priest should be a whole offering.
Womaɖui o.”
It must not be eaten.”
24 Eye Yehowa gagblɔ na Mose be: 25 “Gblɔ na Aron kple viaŋutsuwo be, ‘Esiae nye nuvɔ̃vɔsa la ŋuti se: Teƒe si wowua numevɔsalãa le la, teƒe ma kee woawu nuvɔ̃vɔsalãa hã ɖo le Yehowa ŋkume.

24 Jehovah spoke again to Moses and said: 25 “Tell Aaron and his sons, ‘This is the law of the sin offering: In the place where the burnt offering is slaughtered, the sin offering will also be slaughtered before Jehovah.
Nu kɔkɔewo ƒe nu kɔkɔe wònye.
It is a most holy thing.
26 Nunɔla si sa nuvɔ̃vɔ lae aɖui.
26 The priest who offers it for sin will eat it.
Teƒe kɔkɔe woaɖui le, le takpegbadɔa ƒe xɔxɔnu.
It will be eaten in a holy place, in the courtyard of the tent of meeting.
27 “‘Nu sia nu si aka nuvɔ̃vɔsalãa ŋu la azu nu kɔkɔe, eye ne ame aɖe le ʋua hlẽm eye wòhlẽ ɖe eƒe awu ŋu la, ekema mianya nu si ŋu ʋua hlẽ ɖo la le teƒe kɔkɔe.
27 “‘Everything that touches its flesh will become holy, and when anyone spatters some of its blood on his garment, you should wash what was spattered with blood in a holy place.
28 Woagbã ze si me woɖae le la.
28 The earthenware vessel in which it was boiled is to be shattered.
Ke ne akɔblize mee woɖae le la, ekema woaklɔ akɔblize la atsɔ tsi akpalae.
But if it was boiled in a copper vessel, then the vessel must be scoured and washed with water.
29 “‘Ŋutsu sia ŋutsu si nye nunɔla la kpɔ mɔ aɖui.
29 “‘Every male among the priests will eat it.
Nu kɔkɔewo ƒe nu kɔkɔe wònye.
It is something most holy.
30 Ke womaɖu nuvɔ̃vɔsalã la, nenye be wotsɔ eƒe ʋu ƒe ɖe yi takpegbadɔ la me be woalé avu le kɔkɔeƒea o.
30 However, no sin offering is to be eaten if some of its blood is brought into the tent of meeting to make atonement in the holy place.
Woatɔ dzoe.
It is to be burned with fire.

Yehowa gagblɔ na Mose be: 2 “Gblɔ na Israel-viwo be, ‘Ne ame aɖe ɖe adzɔgbe tɔxɛ be yeatsɔ ga home si woxena ɖe ame ta ana Yehowa la, 3 ne enye ŋutsu si le ƒe blaeve kple ƒe blaade domee la, ekema eƒe asi nanye klosalo sekel blaatɔ̃ le teƒe kɔkɔe la ƒe sekel la nu.

Jehovah continued to speak to Moses, saying: 2 “Speak to the Israelites and tell them, ‘If a man makes a special vow to offer the estimated value of a person to Jehovah, 3 the estimated value of a male from 20 to 60 years old will be 50 shekels of silver by the standard shekel of the holy place.
4 Ke ne nyɔnue la, ekema eƒe asi nanye sekel blaetɔ̃.
4 But if it is a female, the estimated value will be 30 shekels.
5 Ne ele ƒe atɔ̃ kple ƒe blaeve domee la, ekema ŋutsu ƒe asi nanye sekel blaeve, eye nyɔnu ƒe asi nanye sekel ewo.
5 If the age is from 5 to 20 years old, the estimated value of the male will be 20 shekels and 10 shekels for the female.
6 Eye ne ele ɣleti ɖeka kple ƒe atɔ̃ domee la, ekema ŋutsu ƒe asi nanye klosalo sekel atɔ̃, eye nyɔnu ƒe asi nanye klosalo sekel etɔ̃.
6 If the age is from one month up to five years old, the estimated value of the male will be five shekels of silver and three shekels of silver for the female.
7 “‘Ke ne exɔ ƒe blaade kple edzivɔ la, ekema ŋutsu ƒe asi nanye sekel wuiatɔ̃, eye nyɔnu ƒe asi nanye sekel ewo.
7 “‘If the age is 60 years and over, the estimated value will be 15 shekels for the male and 10 shekels for the female.
8 Ke ne eda ahe ale gbegbe be mate ŋu ana home ma o la, ekema woana amea nava nunɔla la gbɔ, eye nunɔla la nado asi ɖe eŋu.
8 But if he is too poor to pay the estimated value, the person will stand before the priest, and the priest will set a value on him.
Nunɔla la nado asi ɖe eŋu le adzɔgbeɖelaa ƒe ŋutete nu.
The priest will make the valuation according to what the one making the vow can afford.
9 “‘Ne lã siwo wotsɔna saa vɔ na Yehowa ƒe ɖee la, ekema nu sia nu si wòana Yehowa la nazu nu kɔkɔe.
9 “‘If the vow involves an animal that is suitable for offering to Jehovah, whatever may be given to Jehovah will become something holy.
10 Mate ŋu aɖɔlii o; matsɔ nyui aɖɔli manyomanyoa alo atsɔ manyomanyo aɖɔli nyuia o.
10 He may not replace it or exchange it with good for bad or with bad for good.
Ke ne ehiã be wòatsɔ lã aɖɔli esi wòtsɔ ɖe adzɔgbee godoo la, ekema esi woɖɔli kple esi wotsɔ ɖɔlii la siaa nazu nu kɔkɔe.
But if he should exchange it with one animal for another animal, the original and what is exchanged for it will both become holy.
11 Eye ne lã si ŋu mekɔ o, si womate ŋu atsɔ ava sa vɔ na Yehowa o ye la, ekema wòakplɔ lã la ava nunɔla la gbɔ.
11 If it is an unclean animal that may not be presented as an offering to Jehovah, he will then stand the animal before the priest.
12 Eye nunɔlaa nalé ŋku ɖe eŋu akpɔ be enyo loo alo menyo o, ne wòado asi ɖe eŋu.
12 The priest will then set its value, as to whether it is good or bad.
Asi si nunɔla la ado ɖe eŋu la, nenemae wòaxɔ.
The value estimated by the priest will stand.
13 Ke ne edi be yeagbugbɔe aƒle kokoko la, ekema wòaxe asi si wodo ɖe eŋu la ahatsɔ home ma me mama ɖe atɔ̃ ƒe akpa ɖeka akpee.
13 But if he ever wants to buy it back, he must then give a fifth of it in addition to the estimated value.
14 “‘Ne ame aɖe kɔ eƒe xɔ ŋu wòzu nu kɔkɔe na Yehowa la, ekema nunɔla la nakpɔe ɖa be enyo loo alo menyo o, eye wòado asi ɖe eŋu.
14 “‘Now if a man should sanctify his house as something holy to Jehovah, the priest will then set its value, whether it is good or bad.
Asi si nunɔlaa ado ɖe eŋu la, nenemae wòaxɔ.
According to the value that the priest sets, that is what it will cost.
15 Ke ne ame si kɔ xɔa ŋu di be yeagaxɔe aƒle la, ekema wòaxe asi si wodo ɖe eŋu la ahatsɔ home ma me mama ɖe atɔ̃ ƒe akpa ɖeka akpee, eye wòazu etɔ.
15 But if the one who sanctifies his house wants to buy it back, he must then give a fifth of the money of the estimated value in addition to it, and it will become his.
16 “‘Ne ame aɖe kɔ eƒe agble ƒe akpa aɖe ŋu na Yehowa la, ekema woado asi ɖe eŋu ɖe nuku agbɔsɔsɔ si woate ŋu aƒã ɖe edzi la nu. Ne ƒo homer ɖekae la, ekema eƒe home nanye klosalo sekel blaatɔ̃.
16 “‘If a man sanctifies to Jehovah some of the field that he possesses, the value will be estimated in proportion to the seed needed to sow it: a hOmer of barley seed will be 50 shekels of silver.
17 Ne ekɔ eƒe agble ŋu tso Ablɔɖeƒe la dzi la, ekema asi si wodo ɖe eŋu la, eyae anye eƒe home.
17 If he sanctifies his field from the year of Jubilee, the estimated value stands.
18 Ne Ablɔɖeƒe la megbee wòkɔ eƒe agble ŋu la, ekema nunɔla la nabu eƒe home la nɛ ɖe ƒe siwo susɔ hafi Ablɔɖeƒe bubu naɖo la nu, eye woaɖe asi si wodo ɖe eŋu la dzi.

18 If he sanctifies his field after the Jubilee, the priest will calculate for him the price in proportion to the years that are left until the next year of Jubilee, and a deduction should be made from the estimated value.
19 Ke ne ame si kɔ agblea ŋu la di be yeagaxɔe aƒle kokoko la, ekema wòaxe asi si wodo ɖe eŋu la ahatsɔ home ma me mama ɖe atɔ̃ ƒe akpa ɖeka akpee, ekema agblea agazu etɔ.
19 But if the one who sanctified it should ever buy the field back, he must then give a fifth of the money of the estimated value in addition to it, and it will remain his.
20 Ke ne mexɔ agblea ƒle o, eye wogadzrae na ame bubu la, ekema magate ŋu axɔe aƒle o.
20 Now if he should not buy the field back and the field is sold to another man, it may not be bought back again.
21 Ne agblea do le ame si le Ablɔɖeƒea me la, azu nu kɔkɔe na Yehowa, abe agble si wotsɔ ɖe adzɔgbe na Mawu ene.
21 When the field is released in the Jubilee, it will become something holy to Jehovah, as a field that is devoted to him.
Azu nunɔla la ƒe domenyinu.
It will become the property of the priests.
22 “‘Ne ame aɖe kɔ agble aɖe si wòƒle ŋu na Yehowa, eye agble la menye eƒe domenyinu o la, 23 ekema nunɔla la nabu asia nɛ ɖe ƒe siwo susɔ hafi Ablɔɖeƒea naɖo la nu, eye wòaxe ga home ma gbe ma gbe.

22 “‘If a man sanctifies to Jehovah a field he purchased that is not part of his hereditary property, 23 the priest will calculate for him the amount of the valuation up until the year of Jubilee, and he will give the estimated value on that day.
Ga la zu nu kɔkɔe na Yehowa.
It is something holy to Jehovah.
24 Ke agblea agatrɔ azu ame si si wòƒlee le, ame si ƒe domenyinu wònye, la tɔ le Ablɔɖeƒe la dzi.
24 In the year of Jubilee, the field will return to the one he bought it from, to the one the land belongs to.
25 “‘Woado asiawo katã ɖe teƒe kɔkɔe la ƒe sekel la nu.
25 “‘Every value should be estimated by the standard shekel of the holy place.
Sekel ɖeka nanye gera blaeve.
The shekel should amount to 20 gerahs.
26 “‘Gake womakɔ lãwo ƒe ŋgɔgbeviwo ya ŋu na Yehowa o, elabena etɔe wonye xoxo.
26 “‘However, no one should sanctify the firstborn of the animals, since it is born as the firstborn for Jehovah.
Eɖanye nyi alo alẽ o, Yehowa tɔe wònye.
Whether bull or sheep, it already belongs to Jehovah.
27 Ne lã si ŋu mekɔ o ye wònye la, ekema nua tɔ naxe ga home si woado ɖe eŋu la, eye wòatsɔ home ma me mama ɖe atɔ̃ ƒe akpa ɖeka akpee.
27 If it is among the unclean animals and he redeems it according to the estimated value, he should give a fifth of it in addition to it.
Gake ne maxe fea axɔe o la, ekema nunɔla la nadzrae ɖe asi si wòdo ɖe eŋu la nu.
But if it is not bought back, it will be sold according to the estimated value.
28 “‘Ne ame aɖe tsɔ eƒe domenyinu aɖe ɖe adzɔgbe na Yehowa ɖikaa la, eɖanye amegbetɔ, lã, alo agble si nye etɔ o, womadzrae o, eye womagbugbɔ axɔe aƒle o.
28 “‘But no devoted thing that a man devotes unconditionally to Jehovah from his belongings may be sold or bought back, whether from mankind or animals or the field he possesses.
Nu sia nu si wotsɔ ɖe adzɔgbe ɖikaa la, nu kɔkɔewo ƒe nu kɔkɔe wònye na Yehowa.
Every devoted thing is something most holy to Jehovah.
29 Ne wobu fɔ ame aɖe be edze na tsɔtsrɔ̃ la, womaxe fe ɖe eta axɔe o.
29 Furthermore, no condemned person who is set apart for destruction may be redeemed.
Ele be woawui godoo.
He should be put to death without fail.
30 ‘“Nu siwo katã anyigba wɔ, agblemenukuwo loo alo kutsetsewo me mama ewo ƒe akpa ɖeka nye Yehowa tɔ.
30 “‘Every tenth part of the land, whether from the produce of the field or the fruit of the trees, belongs to Jehovah.
Nu kɔkɔe wònye na Yehowa.
It is something holy to Jehovah.
31 Ne ame aɖe di be yeagbugbɔ axɔ yeƒe nuwo ƒe ewolia aƒle godoo la, ekema wòaxe ga home si wodo ɖe eŋu ahatsɔ home ma me mama ɖe atɔ̃ ƒe akpa ɖeka akpee.
31 If a man ever wants to buy any of his tenth part back, he should give a fifth of it in addition to it.
32 Nyi alo alẽ ƒe ewolia ɖe sia ɖe si ato lãkplɔti te esi wole wo xlẽm la azu nu kɔkɔe na Yehowa.
32 As for every tenth part of the herd and flock, everything that passes under the shepherd’s staff, the tenth animal should become something holy to Jehovah.
33 Malé ŋku ɖe eŋu akpɔe ɖa be enyo loo alo menyo o, eye maɖɔlii hã o.
33 He should not examine whether it is good or bad, neither should he exchange it.
Ke ne wodi be woaɖɔlii kokoko la, ekema esi woɖɔli kple esi wotsɔ ɖɔlii la siaa nazu nu kɔkɔe.
But if he would ever try to exchange it, both the original and what is exchanged for it should become something holy.
Womagbugbɔ axɔe aƒle o.’”
It may not be bought back.’”
34 Esiawoe nye se siwo Yehowa tsɔ na Mose le Sinai To la dzi be wòade na Israel-viwo.
34 These are the commandments that Jehovah gave to Moses for the Israelites on Mount Sinai.
Yehowa gagblɔ na Mose be: 2 “Gblɔ na Israel ƒe ha blibo la katã be, ‘Minɔ kɔkɔe, elabena nye, Yehowa mia Mawu la, mele kɔkɔe.
Jehovah spoke further to Moses, saying: 2 “Speak to the entire assembly of the Israelites and tell them, ‘You should be holy, because I, Jehovah your God, am holy.
3 “Mia dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe nade bubu dadaa kple fofoa ŋu, eye milé nye sabat ƒe seawo me ɖe asi.
3 “‘Each of you should respect his mother and his father, and you should keep my sabbaths.
Nyee nye Yehowa, mia Mawu.
I am Jehovah your God.
4 Migatrɔ ɖe mawu maɖinuwo ŋu o, eye migalólo ga tsɔ wɔ mawuwo na mia ɖokuiwo o.
4 Do not turn to worthless gods or make for yourselves gods of cast metal.
Nyee nye Yehowa, mia Mawu.
I am Jehovah your God.
5 “‘Ne miesa ŋutifafavɔ na Yehowa la, miwɔe le mɔ si ana miaƒe nu nadze eŋu nu.
5 “‘Now if you offer a communion sacrifice to Jehovah, you should sacrifice it in such a way that you gain approval for yourselves.
6 Miɖui le gbe si gbe miesa vɔa kple eƒe ŋufɔke, ke esi tsi anyi va se ɖe ŋkeke etɔ̃a gbe la, mitɔ dzoe.
6 It should be eaten on the day of your sacrifice and on the next day, but what is left over until the third day should be burned in the fire.
7 Gake ne mieɖui le ŋkeke etɔ̃a gbe la, ekema ezu nu makɔmakɔ, madze ŋunye o.
7 If, though, any of it is eaten on the third day, it is an offensive thing that will not be accepted with approval.
8 Ame si ɖui la, eɖi fɔ, elabena mede bubu Yehowa ƒe nu kɔkɔe ŋu o, woatsrɔ̃ ame ma ɖa le eƒe dukɔ la dome.
8 The one eating it will answer for his error because he has profaned a holy thing of Jehovah, and that person must be cut off from his people.
9 “‘Ne miele agblemenukuwo ŋem le miaƒe anyigba dzi la, mègaŋe esiwo le wò bo to la keŋkeŋ o, eye mègafɔ wò nuku siwo tsi anyi la o.
9 “‘When you reap the harvest of your land, you must not reap the edge of your field completely and you must not pick up the gleaning of your harvest.
10 Mègaxa wò waintsetsewo hã ƒiaƒiaƒia le wò agble me o, eye mègafɔ wò waintsetse siwo dudu ɖe anyi la o.
10 Also, you must not gather the leftovers of your vineyard or pick up the scattered grapes of your vineyard.
Gblẽ wo ɖi na ame dahewo kple amedzrowo.
You should leave them for the poor and the foreign resident.
Nyee nye Yehowa, mia Mawu.
I am Jehovah your God.
11 “‘Migafi fi o, migable ame o, eye mia dometɔ aɖeke megaflu ehavi o.
11 “‘You must not steal, you must not deceive, and you must not deal falsely with one another.
12 Mègatsɔ nye ŋkɔ ka atam ɖe alakpanya dzi o, be nàgaƒo ɖi wò Mawu ƒe ŋkɔ la o.
12 You must not swear to a lie in my name and thus profane the name of your God.
Nyee nye Yehowa.
I am Jehovah.
13 Mègatafa hawòvi o, eye mègada adzoe o.
13 You must not defraud your fellow man, and you must not rob.
Dɔwɔla ƒe fetu megatsi gbɔwò ŋu nake ɖe edzi o.
You should not withhold the wages of a hired worker all night until morning.
14 “‘Mègado ɖiŋu na tokunɔ o, eye mègada nu ɖe ŋkuagbãtɔ ŋgɔ wòakli o, vɔ̃ wò Mawu.
14 “‘You must not curse a deaf man or put an obstacle before a blind man, and you must be in fear of your God.
Nyee nye Yehowa.
I am Jehovah.
15 “‘Migadrɔ̃ ʋɔnu madzɔmadzɔ o.
15 “‘You must not be unjust in your judgment.
Mègate ame dahe ɖe to o, eye mègade kesinɔtɔ dzi o.
You must not show partiality to the poor or show preference to the rich.
Drɔ̃ ʋɔnu dzɔdzɔe na hawòvi.
With justice you should judge your fellow man.
16 “‘Mèganɔ ame ŋu gblẽm anɔ yiyim o.
16 “‘You must not go around spreading slander among your people.
Mègadi be woakɔ hawòvi ƒe ʋu ɖi o.
You must not stand up against the life of your fellow man.
Nyee nye Yehowa.
I am Jehovah.
17 “‘Mègalé fu nɔviwò le dzi me o.
17 “‘You must not hate your brother in your heart.
Gbe nya na hawòvi, ne eƒe nu vɔ̃ naganɔ wò kplii ƒe ta dzi o.
You should by all means reprove your fellow man, so that you will not bear sin along with him.
18 “‘Mègawɔ wɔɖenui alo alé wò dukɔmeviwo ɖe dɔme o, lɔ̃ hawòvi abe wò ŋutɔ ɖokuiwò ene.
18 “‘You must not take vengeance nor hold a grudge against the sons of your people, and you must love your fellow man as yourself.
Nyee nye Yehowa.
I am Jehovah.
19 “‘Milé nye sewo me ɖe asi: Mègana wò aƒemelã eve ƒomevi natsaka ayɔ asi wo nɔewo o.
19 “‘You should keep my statutes: You must not interbreed two sorts of your domestic animals.
Mègatsaka nuku eve ƒomevi aƒã ɖe wò agble me o, eye mègado awu si wotsɔ ka eve ƒomevi tsaka lɔ̃ la o.
You must not sow your field with two sorts of seed, and you must not wear a garment made with two sorts of thread mixed together.
20 “‘Ne ŋutsu aɖe dɔ subɔvinyɔnu aɖe si ŋugbe wodo na ŋutsu bubu gbɔ, evɔ womexɔ nyɔnua ƒle alo na ablɔɖee o la, ele be woahe to na wo.

20 “‘Now if a man lies down with a woman and has intercourse with her and she is a servant who is designated for another man, but she has not been redeemed or given her freedom, there should be a punishment.
Womawu wo o, elabena womena ablɔɖe nyɔnua haɖe o.
However, they should not be put to death, for she was not yet set free.
21 Ŋutsua natsɔ agbo ɖeka avɛ na Yehowa le takpegbadɔa nu be woatsɔ asa fɔɖivɔ.
21 He should bring his guilt offering to Jehovah to the entrance of the tent of meeting, a ram of guilt offering.
22 Nunɔla la natsɔ agbo la asa fɔɖivɔe atsɔ alé avu ɖe eta le Yehowa ŋkume le nu vɔ̃ si wòwɔ la ta, eye woatsɔ eƒe nu vɔ̃ la akee.
22 The priest will make atonement for him with the ram of the guilt offering before Jehovah for the sin that he committed, and he will be forgiven for the sin that he committed.
23 “‘Ne mieva ɖo anyigba la dzi eye miedo ati si ƒe tsetse woɖuna la, migaɖu eƒe tsetse o ƒe etɔ̃ sɔŋ; mibui le ɣeyiɣi mawo me abe ati makɔmakɔ kple ati maɖumaɖua ene.
23 “‘When you come into the land and you plant any tree for food, you must consider its fruitage impure and forbidden. For three years it will be forbidden to you.
24 Gake le ƒe enelia me la, eƒe tsetse la katã zu nu kɔkɔe si ŋu miatso aseye ɖo le Yehowa ŋkume.
It must not be eaten. 24 But in the fourth year, all its fruit will be holy for rejoicing before Jehovah.
25 Ke le ƒe atɔ̃lia me la, miekpɔ mɔ aɖu eƒe tsetse ale be miaƒe kutsetsewo nasɔ gbɔ ɖe edzi.
25 Then in the fifth year, you may eat its fruit in order to add its produce to your harvest.
Nyee nye Yehowa, mia Mawu.
I am Jehovah your God.
26 “‘Migaɖu naneke si me ʋu le o.
26 “‘You must eat nothing containing blood.
“‘Migaka afa o, eye migawɔ akunya o.
“‘You must not look for omens or practice magic.
27 “‘Migaƒlɔ miaƒe loglo o, eye migafɔ miaƒe ge dzi ɖewoɖewoe o.
27 “‘You must not shave the hair on the side of your head or disfigure the edges of your beard.
28 “‘Ne ame ku la, migasi ŋuti o, eye migatá nu ɖe ŋuti hã o.
28 “‘You must not make cuts in your flesh for a dead person, and you must not make tattoo markings on yourselves.
Nyee nye Yehowa.
I am Jehovah.
29 “‘Mègawɔ viwònyɔnu gbolo ahaklo bubu le eŋu o, ne anyigba la nagawɔ gbolo, ale be ŋukpenanuwɔwɔ naxɔ edzi o.
29 “‘Do not dishonor your daughter by making her a prostitute, so that the land may not commit prostitution and be filled with loose morals.
30 “‘Milé nye sabat ƒe sewo me ɖe asi, eye mide bubu nye kɔkɔeƒe la ŋu.
30 “‘You must keep my sabbaths, and you must show reverence for my sanctuary.
Nyee nye Yehowa.
I am Jehovah.
31 “‘Migayi ŋɔliyɔlawo gbɔ o, eye migabia nu ta se le nukalawo gbɔ o, ne miagazu ame makɔmakɔwo o.
31 “‘Do not turn to the spirit mediums, and do not consult fortune-tellers so as to become unclean by them.
Nyee nye Yehowa, mia Mawu.
I am Jehovah your God.
32 “‘Tso ɖe tsitrenu le ta ƒowɔ ŋkume, nàde bubu ame tsitsi ŋu, eye nàvɔ̃ wò Mawu.
32 “‘Before gray hair you should rise up, and you must show honor to an older man, and you must be in fear of your God.
Nyee nye Yehowa.
I am Jehovah.
33 “‘Ne amedzrovi aɖe le gbɔwò le miaƒe anyigba dzi la, mègawɔ ŋlɔmi le eŋu o.
33 “‘If a foreigner resides with you in your land, you must not mistreat him.
34 Amedzrovi si le mia gbɔ la nanɔ abe dumevidzidzi ke ene. Lɔ̃e abe ɖokuiwò ene, elabena miawo hã mienye amedzrowo kpɔ le Egipte-nyigba dzi.
34 The foreigner who resides with you should become to you like a native among you; and you must love him as yourself, for you were foreign residents in the land of Egypt.
Nyee nye Yehowa, mia Mawu.
I am Jehovah your God.
35 “‘Migatafa ame le ʋɔnudɔdrɔ̃ me o. Migazã nudzidzenu, nudanu, alo nudonu amebatɔ o.
35 “‘You must not use dishonest standards in measuring length, weight, or volume.
36 Nudanu siwo de pɛpɛpɛ, nudakpe siwo de pɛpɛpɛ, nudogba blibo, kple nudotre blibo nanɔ mia si.
36 You should use accurate scales, accurate weights, an accurate dry measure, and an accurate liquid measure.
Nyee nye Yehowa, mia Mawu, ame si kplɔ mi tso Egipte-nyigba dzi.
I am Jehovah your God, who brought you out of the land of Egypt.
37 Eya ta milé nye sewo kple nye ʋɔnudrɔ̃ɖoɖowo katã me ɖe asi, ne miawɔ wo dzi.
37 So you must keep all my statutes and all my judicial decisions, and you must follow them.
Nyee nye Yehowa.’”
I am Jehovah.’”
“‘Esiae nye fɔɖivɔsa ŋuti se: Nu kɔkɔewo ƒe nu kɔkɔe wònye.
“‘This is the law of the guilt offering: It is something most holy.
2 Teƒe si wowua numevɔsalã le la, teƒe ma kee woawu fɔɖivɔsalã hã ɖo, eye woahlẽ eƒe ʋua ɖe vɔsamlekpuia ƒe axawo katã ŋu.
2 They will slaughter the guilt offering in the place where they slaughter the burnt offerings, and its blood should be sprinkled on all sides of the altar.
3 Ke woatsɔ eƒe amiawo katã, asike dami la, ami si tsyɔ dɔkaviawo dzi, 4 ayiku eveawo kple ami siwo le wo ŋu le alia gbɔ asa vɔe.
3 He will present all its fat, including the fat tail, the fat that covers the intestines, 4 and the two kidneys with their fat that is near the loins.
Eye wòaɖe ami si le aklã ŋu kpe ɖe ayikuawo ŋu hã.
He will also remove the appendage of the liver along with the kidneys.
5 Eye nunɔla la natsɔ wo ado dzudzɔ ɖe vɔsamlekpuia dzi wòanye dzovɔsa na Yehowa.
5 The priest will make them smoke on the altar as an offering made by fire to Jehovah.
Fɔɖivɔsa wònye.
It is a guilt offering.
6 Ŋutsu sia ŋutsu si nye nunɔla la kpɔ mɔ aɖui, teƒe kɔkɔe lae woaɖui le.
6 Every male among the priests will eat it, and it should be eaten in a holy place.
Nu kɔkɔewo ƒe nu kɔkɔe wònye.
It is something most holy.
7 Se si le nuvɔ̃vɔsaa ŋu la kee anɔ fɔɖivɔsa la hã ŋu; anye nunɔla si tsɔe lé avui la tɔ.
7 The law regarding the sin offering applies to the guilt offering; it belongs to the priest who makes atonement with it.
8 “‘Ne nunɔla sa numevɔ na ame aɖe la, ekema numevɔsalã si wòtsɔ va nunɔlaa gbɔ la ƒe agbalẽ anye nunɔla la tɔ.
8 “‘When the priest presents the burnt offering for someone, the skin of the burnt offering that was presented to the priest will become his.
9 “‘Nuɖuvɔsa siwo katã womè le kpo me kple esiwo katã woɖa le ze me kple nutɔgba me la nye nunɔla si tsɔe sa vɔe la tɔ.
9 “‘Every grain offering that is baked in the oven or prepared in the pan or on the griddle belongs to the priest who presents it.
Azu etɔ.
It will become his.
10 Ke woama nuɖuvɔsa siwo woblu kple ami alo esiwo womede amii o la na Aron viŋutsuwo; wo katã woamae sɔsɔe.
10 But every grain offering that is mixed with oil or that is dry will be for all of Aaron’s sons; each will have an equal share.

11 “Ke esiae nye ŋutifafavɔ si ame aɖe asa na Yehowa la ŋuti se: 12 Ne akpedavɔe wòdi be yeasa la, ekema wòatsɔ amɔwɔ maʋamaʋã bolo kotoe siwo wode amii, kple amɔwɔ maʋamaʋã kpɔnɔ siwo dzi wosisi ami ɖo, kpakple wɔ memee si wodzaba kple ami nyuie ƒe abolo kotoe akpe ɖe akpedavɔsalãa ŋu.

11 “‘Now this is the law of the communion sacrifice that one may present to Jehovah: 12 If he presents it as an expression of thanksgiving, he will present along with the thanksgiving sacrifice unleavened ring-shaped loaves mixed with oil, unleavened wafers spread with oil, and ring-shaped loaves made with fine flour, well-mixed and blended with oil.
13 Eye wòatsɔ abolo kotoe siwo wotsɔ amɔwɔ ʋaʋã wɔ kple eƒe ŋutifafavɔsalã siwo wòtsɔ vɛ be woanye akpedavɔsa la akpe ɖe eƒe nunana la ŋu vɛ.
13 He will present his offering along with ring-shaped loaves of leavened bread and the thanksgiving sacrifice of his communion sacrifices.
14 Eye wòaɖe ɖeka le eƒe nunana ɖe sia ɖe ŋu vɛ wòanye gome kɔkɔe na Yehowa; azu nunɔla si hlẽ ŋutifafavɔsalã la ƒe ʋu ɖe vɔsamlekpuia ŋu la tɔ.
14 He is to present from it one of each offering as a sacred portion to Jehovah; it will belong to the priest who sprinkles the blood of the communion sacrifices.
15 Woaɖu eƒe ŋutifafavɔsalã siwo wòtsɔ sa akpedavɔe la le gbe si gbe wòsa vɔ la.
15 The flesh of the thanksgiving sacrifice of his communion sacrifices is to be eaten on the day he offers it.
Megagblẽ eƒe ɖeke ɖi ŋu nake ɖe edzi o.
He must not save any of it until morning.
16 “‘Ke ne nu si wòtsɔ va vɔ sa ge la nye adzɔgbeɖenunana alo lɔlɔ̃nu faa nunana la, ekema woaɖui le gbe si gbe wòsa vɔa, eye woate ŋu aɖu esi tsi anyi ŋu ke ɖe edzi hã.
16 “‘If the sacrifice of his offering is a vow or a voluntary offering, it is to be eaten on the day he presents his sacrifice, and what is left of it may also be eaten on the next day.
17 Vɔsalã, si tsi anyi va se ɖe ŋkeke etɔ̃a gbe la, woatɔ dzoe.
17 But whatever is left of the flesh of the sacrifice on the third day is to be burned with fire.
18 Ne woɖu eƒe ŋutifafavɔsalã ƒe ɖe le ŋkeke etɔ̃a gbe la, ekema womaxɔe na ame si tsɔe sa vɔ la o.
18 However, if any of the flesh of his communion sacrifice is eaten on the third day, the one presenting it will not be accepted with approval.
Womabui nɛ o; nu makɔmakɔ wònye, eye ame si ɖu eƒe ɖe la, woabia akɔntae le vo si wòda la ŋuti.
It will not be credited to him; it is an offensive thing, and the person who eats some of it will answer for his error.
19 Womaɖu lã si ka nu makɔmakɔ aɖe ŋu la o.
19 Flesh that touches anything unclean is not to be eaten.
Woatɔ dzoe.
It is to be burned with fire.
Ame sia ame si ŋu kɔ la ate ŋu aɖu lã si ŋu kɔ la.
Everyone who is clean may eat the clean flesh.
20 “‘Ame si ŋu mekɔ o, gake wòɖu ŋutifafavɔsalã si nye Yehowa tɔ la, woatsrɔ̃e ɖa le eƒe dukɔmeviwo dome.
20 “‘But any person who is unclean and eats the flesh of the communion sacrifice, which is for Jehovah, that person must be cut off from his people.

21 Eye ne ame aɖe ŋuti ka nu makɔmakɔ aɖe ŋu, eɖanye ame ƒe nu makɔmakɔ aɖe alo lã makɔmakɔ aɖe alo nu makɔmakɔ nyɔŋu aɖe o, eye wòɖu ŋutifafavɔsalã si nye Yehowa tɔ la ƒe ɖe la, woatsrɔ̃ ame ma ɖa le eƒe dukɔmeviwo dome.’”

21 If someone touches anything unclean, whether the uncleanness of a man or an unclean animal or any unclean disgusting thing, and eats some of the flesh of the communion sacrifice, which is for Jehovah, that person must be cut off from his people.’”
22 Eye Yehowa gagblɔ na Mose be: 23 “Gblɔ na Israel-viwo be: ‘Migaɖu nyi alo alẽ alo gbɔ̃ ƒe ami aɖeke o.
22 Jehovah continued to speak to Moses, saying: 23 “Tell the Israelites, ‘You must not eat any fat of a bull or a young ram or a goat.
24 Miate ŋu azã lã si ku le eɖokui si alo lã si lã bubu aɖe wu la ƒe ami na nu bubu ɖe sia ɖe wɔwɔ, gake migaɖui gbeɖegbeɖe o.
24 The fat of an animal found dead and the fat of an animal killed by another animal may be used for any other purpose, but you must never eat it.
25 Ame sia ame si aɖu lã si wòtsɔ sa dzovɔ na Yehowa ƒe ami la, woatsrɔ̃e ɖa le eƒe dukɔmeviwo dome.
25 For whoever eats fat from an animal that he presents as an offering made by fire to Jehovah must be cut off from his people.
26 “‘Migaɖu ʋu aɖeke le mia nɔƒewo katã o, eɖanye xe alo lã tɔ o.
26 “‘You must not eat any blood in any of your dwelling places, whether that of birds or that of animals.
27 Ame si aɖu ʋu la, woatsrɔ̃e ɖa le eƒe dukɔmeviwo dome.’”
27 Anyone who eats any blood must be cut off from his people.’”
28 Yehowa gagblɔ na Mose be: 29 “Gblɔ na Israel-viwo be: ‘Ame si sa ŋutifafavɔ na Yehowa la natsɔ eƒe ŋutifafavɔsalã la ƒe ɖe vɛ na Yehowa.
28 Jehovah went on to speak to Moses, saying: 29 “Tell the Israelites, ‘Whoever presents his communion sacrifice to Jehovah will bring part of the offering from his communion sacrifice to Jehovah.
30 Eya ŋutɔ natsɔ vɔsalã la ƒe ami kple eƒe akɔ la ava sa dzovɔ na Yehowa, eye wòanyè ami la kple akɔ la le Yehowa ŋkume, wòanye vɔsa si wonyè.
30 He will bring in his own hands the fat along with the breast as an offering made by fire to Jehovah, and he will wave it back and forth as a wave offering before Jehovah.
31 Nunɔla la natsɔ ami la ado dzudzɔ ɖe vɔsamlekpuia dzi, gake akɔa ya nanye Aron kple viaŋutsuwo tɔ.
31 The priest will make the fat smoke on the altar, but the breast will belong to Aaron and his sons.
32 “‘Eye miatsɔ miaƒe ŋutifafavɔsalãwo ƒe ɖusita ana nunɔla la wòanye eƒe gome kɔkɔe.
32 “‘You will give the right leg as a sacred portion to the priest from your communion sacrifices.
33 Ðusita la anye Aron viŋutsu si tsɔ ŋutifafavɔsalã ƒe ʋu kple ami sa vɔe la tɔ.
33 The son of Aaron who presents the blood of the communion sacrifices and the fat will have the right leg as his portion.
34 Elabena mexɔ akɔ si nye vɔsa si woanyè la kple ɖusita si nye gome kɔkɔe la tso Israel-viwo ƒe ŋutifafavɔsawo me tsɔ na nunɔla Aron kple viaŋutsuwo, be wòanye ɖoɖo mavɔ na Israel-viwo.

34 For I take the breast of the wave offering and the leg of the sacred portion from the communion sacrifices of the Israelites, and I give them to Aaron the priest and his sons as a lasting regulation for the Israelites.
35 “‘Esiae nye nunɔlawo ƒe gome, si Aron kple viaŋutsuwo axɔ le Yehowa ƒe dzovɔsawo me le gbe si gbe woɖo wo be woawɔ nunɔladɔ na Yehowa.
35 “‘This was the portion from Jehovah’s offerings made by fire to be set aside for the priests, for Aaron and his sons, on the day he presented them to serve as priests to Jehovah.
36 Yehowa de se be woaxɔ gome sia le Israel-viwo si na wo le gbe si gbe woasi ami na wo.
36 Jehovah commanded to give them this portion from the Israelites on the day he anointed them.
Ðoɖo mavɔ wònye na woƒe dzidzimewo.’”
It is a permanent statute for their generations.’”

37 Esiae nye numevɔsa, nuɖuvɔsa, nuvɔ̃vɔsa, fɔɖivɔsa, ameɖovɔsa kple ŋutifafavɔsa ŋuti se, 38 abe ale si tututu Yehowa de se na Mose le Sinai To la dzi le gbe si gbe wòde se na Israel-viwo be woatsɔ woƒe nunanawo vɛ na Yehowa le Sinai gbedzi la ene.

37 This is the law concerning the burnt offering, the grain offering, the sin offering, the guilt offering, the installation sacrifice, and the communion sacrifice, 38 just as Jehovah commanded Moses on Mount Sinai in the day he commanded the Israelites to present their offerings to Jehovah in the wilderness of Sinai.
Emegbe Nadab kple Abihu, siwo nye Aron viŋutsuwo la, dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe tsɔ eƒe dzudzɔdosonuwo, eye woɖe dzo ɖe wo me, tsɔ dzudzɔdonu ʋeʋĩ da ɖe edzi.
Later Aaron’s sons NAdab and Abihu each took his fire holder and put fire in it and placed incense on it.
Eye wodo dzo si ŋu Yehowa meɖe mɔ ɖo o, si meɖo na wo o la, le eŋkume.
Then they began offering before Jehovah unauthorized fire, which he had not commanded them to do.
2 Ale dzo do tso Yehowa gbɔ va fiã wo, eye woku le Yehowa ŋkume.
2 At this a fire came out from before Jehovah and consumed them, so that they died before Jehovah.
3 Eye Mose gblɔ na Aron be: “Nya si Yehowa gblɔe nye esi, ‘Woakɔ ŋunye le ame siwo te ɖe ŋunye la dome, eye woadom ɖe dzi le dukɔ blibo la katã ŋkume.’”
3 Then Moses said to Aaron: “This is what Jehovah has said, ‘I will be made holy among those near to me, and I will be glorified before all the people.’”
Ke Aron meke nu o.
And Aaron kept silent.

4 Eye Mose yɔ Misael kple Elizafan, Aron tɔɖia Uziel ƒe viŋutsuwo, gblɔ na wo be: “Miva kɔ mia nɔviawo dzoe le kɔkɔeƒea ŋgɔ yi asaɖa la godo.” 5 Ale wova kɔ Nadab kple Abihu, ame siwo ƒe awu ʋlayaawo gakpɔtɔ le wo ŋu la, yi asaɖa la godo, abe ale si Mose gblɔe ene.

4 So Moses called Mishael and Elzaphan, the sons of Uzziel, Aaron’s uncle, and said to them: “Come here, carry your brothers from in front of the holy place to a place outside the camp.” 5 So they came forward and carried the men away in their robes to a place outside the camp, just as Moses had told them.
6 Eye Mose gblɔ na Aron kple viaŋutsu bubu siwo nye Eleazar kple Itamar be: “Migagblẽ miaƒe ɖawo ɖi nyamaa alo adze miaƒe awuwo o, ne miagaku o, eye Mawu nagado dziku ɖe ha blibo la katã hã ŋu o.

6 Moses then said to Aaron and his other sons EleAzar and Ithamar: “Do not let your heads go ungroomed or tear your garments, so that you may not die and that God may not become indignant against all the assembly.
Mia nɔviwo, Israel ƒe aƒe blibo la, afa avi ɖe ame siwo Yehowa wu kple dzo la ta.
Your brothers of the whole house of Israel will weep over those whom Jehovah has killed by the fire.
7 Migadzo le takpegbadɔa ƒe mɔnu o, be miagaku o, elabena Yehowa ƒe ami kɔkɔe si wosi na mi la le mia ŋu.”
7 You must not go out from the entrance of the tent of meeting or you will die, for Jehovah’s anointing oil is upon you.”
Eye wowɔe abe ale si Mose gblɔe ene.
So they did according to Moses’ word.
8 Eye Yehowa gblɔ na Aron be: 9 “Ne miegbɔna takpegbadɔa me la, wò ŋutɔ kple viwòŋutsu siwo kpe ɖe ŋuwò siaa migano wain alo aha muame bubu aɖeke o, ne miagaku o.
8 Then Jehovah said to Aaron: 9 “Do not drink wine or other alcoholic beverages, you and your sons with you, when you come into the tent of meeting, so that you will not die.
Esia nanye ɖoɖo mavɔ na wò kple wò dzidzimeviwo.
It is a permanent statute for your generations.
10 Ne miade vovo nu kɔkɔe kple nu dzro dome, nu si medza o kple nu dzadzɛ dome, 11 eye miafia ɖoɖo siwo katã Yehowa gblɔ to Mose dzi la Israel-viwo.”

10 This is to distinguish between the holy thing and the profane and between the unclean thing and the clean, 11 and to teach the Israelites all the regulations that Jehovah has spoken to them through Moses.”

12 Eye Mose gblɔ na Aron kple viaŋutsu siwo susɔ, siwo nye Eleazar kple Itamar be: “Mitsɔ nuɖuvɔsa si susɔ tso Yehowa ƒe dzovɔsawo me, eye mitsɔe wɔ amɔwɔ maʋamaʋã boloe ne miaɖu le vɔsamlekpui la xa, elabena nu kɔkɔewo ƒe nu kɔkɔe wònye.

12 Then Moses spoke to Aaron and to EleAzar and Ithamar, his sons who were left: “Take what was left of the grain offering from Jehovah’s offerings made by fire and eat it as unleavened bread near the altar, because it is something most holy.
13 Miɖui le teƒe kɔkɔe, elabena wò gome kple viwòŋutsuwo ƒe gome wònye tso Yehowa ƒe dzovɔsawo me, eye se siae wode nam.
13 You must eat it in a holy place, because it is your allowance and the allowance of your sons from Jehovah’s offerings made by fire, for this is what I have been commanded.

14 Ke wò ŋutɔ kple viwòŋutsuwo kpakple viwònyɔnuwo miaɖu lã la ƒe akɔ si nye vɔsa si wonyè kple ɖusita si nye gome kɔkɔe la le teƒe dzadzɛ, elabena wò kple viwòwo ƒe gome wònye tso Israel-viwo ƒe ŋutifafavɔsawo me.

14 You will also eat the breast of the wave offering and the leg of the sacred portion in a clean place, you and your sons and your daughters with you, because these things have been given as your allowance and the allowance of your sons from the communion sacrifices of the Israelites.

15 Woatsɔ ɖusita si nye gome kɔkɔe la kple akɔ si nye vɔsa si woanyè la kpakple ami siwo wotsɔ sa dzovɔ vɛ ne woanye vɔsa si wonyè le Yehowa ŋkume; akɔ la kple ɖusita la nanye wò kple viwò siwo le ŋuwò la ƒe gome tegbee abe ale si Yehowa de se ene.”

15 They will bring the leg of the sacred portion and the breast of the wave offering along with the offerings of fat made by fire, in order to wave the wave offering back and forth before Jehovah; and it will serve as a permanent allowance for you and your sons with you, just as Jehovah has commanded.”
16 Eye Mose di nuvɔ̃vɔsagbɔ̃ la tsitotsito, eye wòkpɔe be wotɔ dzoe xoxo!
16 And Moses diligently searched for the goat of the sin offering, and he discovered that it had been burned up.

Ale wòdo dziku ɖe Eleazar kple Itamar, siwo nye Aron viŋutsu mamlɛawo ŋu gblɔ be: 17 “Nu ka ŋuti mieɖu nuvɔ̃vɔsalã la le teƒe kɔkɔe o, evɔ nu kɔkɔewo ƒe nu kɔkɔe si wòtsɔ na mi be miaxɔ ha la ƒe vodada ɖe akɔ, ne mialé avu ɖe wo ta le Yehowa ŋkume lae wònye? 18 Kpɔ ɖa!

So he grew indignant at EleAzar and Ithamar, Aaron’s sons who were left, and he said: 17 “Why did you not eat the sin offering in the holy place, since it is something most holy and he has given it to you so that you may answer for the error of the assembly and make atonement for them before Jehovah? 18 Look!
Wometsɔ eƒe ʋu la va kɔkɔeƒe la o.
Its blood has not been brought inside the holy place.
Ðe wòle be miaɖui le teƒe kɔkɔe la abe ale si wode se nam ene.” 19 Eye Aron ɖo eŋu na Mose be: “Kpɔ ɖa!
You certainly should have eaten it in the holy place, just as I was commanded.” 19 Aaron replied to Moses: “Look!
Egbee wosa woƒe nuvɔ̃vɔ kple woƒe numevɔ le Yehowa ŋkume, ke hã nu siawo dzɔ ɖe dzinye.
Today they presented their sin offering and their burnt offering before Jehovah, and yet these things happened to me.
Ne ɖe meɖu nuvɔ̃vɔsalã la egbea la, ɖe wòadze Yehowa ŋua?” 20 Esi Mose see la, edze eŋu.
If I had eaten the sin offering today, would that have been pleasing to Jehovah?” 20 When Moses heard that, he was satisfied.

“‘Ne ame aɖe wɔ nu vɔ̃, le esi wòsee woɖe gbeƒã le dutoƒo be woava aɖi ɖase le nu vɔ̃ wɔla aɖe ŋu, eye wònye ɖasefo le eŋu, alo wòkpɔ eteƒe alo nya nu tso eŋu, evɔ meva gblɔe o la, ekema woabia eƒe vodada la ŋuti kɔntae.
“‘If someone sins because he has heard a public call to testify and he is a witness or has seen or learned about it and he does not report it, then he will answer for his error.

2 “‘Alo ne ame aɖe ka asi nu makɔmakɔ aɖe ŋu, eɖanye gbemelã makɔmakɔ aɖe ƒe kukua alo aƒemelã makɔmakɔ aɖe ƒe kukua alo nuwɔwɔ siwo nɔa ha me dometɔ aɖe ƒe kukua ŋu la, eŋu mekɔ o, eɖi fɔ, ne menya o gɔ̃ hã.

2 “‘Or when a person touches anything unclean, whether the dead body of an unclean wild animal, an unclean domestic animal, or an unclean swarming creature, he is unclean and has become guilty even if he does not realize it.
3 Alo ne eka asi ame ƒe nu makɔmakɔ aɖe ŋu, nu sia nu si ŋu mekɔ o si ana eŋu makɔ o la ŋu le manyamanya me, eye wòva nya emegbe la, eɖi fɔ.
3 Or in case someone without being aware of it touches human uncleanness —anything unclean that may make him unclean—and he comes to know it, then he becomes guilty.
4 “‘Alo ne ame aɖe mebu nuwo ŋu nyuie hafi ka atam be yeawɔ nane o, eɖanye vɔ̃ alo nyui o, nu ka ke ƒe atam wòka o, evɔ menya o, gake wòva dze sii emegbe be yewɔe eŋumabumabui la, ekema eɖi fɔ.

4 “‘Or if someone rashly swears to do something—whether it is to do good or to do evil, no matter what it may be—and he was unaware of it, but then he realizes that he has sworn rashly, he becomes guilty.
5 “‘Eye ne ame aɖe ɖi nu siawo dometɔ ɖeka ƒe fɔ la, ekema wòaʋu nu vɔ̃ la me.
5 “‘If he becomes guilty as respects one of these things, then he must confess in what way he has sinned.
6 Eye wòalé alẽnɔe alo gbɔ̃nɔe tso eƒe lãha me vɛ na Yehowa le vo si wòda heɖi fɔ la ta, be woatsɔ asa nuvɔ̃vɔe.
6 He will also bring his guilt offering to Jehovah for the sin that he committed, namely, a female from the flock, either a female lamb or a young female goat, for a sin offering.
Eye nunɔla la alé avu ɖe eta le eƒe nu vɔ̃ la ta.
Then the priest will make atonement for him for his sin.
7 “‘Ke ne mate ŋu ana alẽ o la, ekema wòatsɔ akpakpa eve alo ahɔnɛvi eve ava sa fɔɖivɔ na Yehowa ɖe nu vɔ̃ si wòwɔ la ta: netsɔ ɖeka sa nuvɔ̃vɔ, eye wòatsɔ evelia asa numevɔ.
7 “‘If, though, he cannot afford a sheep, he must bring to Jehovah two turtledoves or two young pigeons as his guilt offering for the sin, one for a sin offering and one for a burnt offering.
8 Atsɔ wo ava nunɔla la gbɔ, eye nunɔla la natsɔ esi woatsɔ asa nuvɔ̃vɔe la asa vɔ gbã; atso veme nɛ, gake maɖe ta le enu o.
8 He is to bring them to the priest, who will present first the one for the sin offering and nip off its head at the front of its neck, without severing it.
9 Eye wòahlẽ nuvɔ̃vɔsalã la ƒe ʋua ƒe ɖe ɖe vɔsamlekpui la ŋu, ke wòaɖuɖu ʋu susɔea ɖe vɔsamlekpuia te.
9 He will spatter some of the blood of the sin offering on the side of the altar, but the remainder of the blood will be drained out at the base of the altar.
Nuvɔ̃vɔsa wònye.
It is a sin offering.
10 Eye wòatsɔ evelia asa numevɔ ɖe ɖoɖo si nu wowɔnɛ ɖo la nu; eye nunɔla la nalé avu ɖe amea ta le nu vɔ̃ si wòwɔ la ŋuti, eye woatsɔe akee.
10 He will handle the other one as a burnt offering according to the regular procedure; and the priest will make atonement for him for the sin that he has committed, and it will be forgiven him.
11 “‘Ke ne mate ŋu ana akpakpa eve alo ahɔnɛvi eve hã o la, ekema wòatsɔ wɔ memee efa me mama ɖe ewo ƒe akpa ɖeka ana ɖe nu vɔ̃ si wòwɔ la ta, be woatsɔ asa nuvɔ̃vɔe.
11 “‘Now if he cannot afford two turtledoves or two young pigeons, he must bring as his offering for his sin a tenth of an ephah of fine flour for a sin offering.
Megakɔ ami ɖe edzi o, eye megatsɔ lifi da ɖe edzi o, elabena nuvɔ̃vɔsa wònye.
He should not add oil to it or place frankincense on it, for it is a sin offering.
12 Eye wòatsɔe ava nunɔla la gbɔ, eye nunɔla la naku asiʋlo ɖeka le eŋu wòanye kpɔɖeŋuvɔsa, eye wòatsɔe akɔ ɖe Yehowa ƒe dzovɔsawo dzi ado dzudzɔ ɖe vɔsamlekpui la dzi.
12 He will bring it to the priest, and the priest will take from it his handful as a token offering and make it smoke on the altar on top of Jehovah’s offerings made by fire.
Nuvɔ̃vɔsa wònye.
It is a sin offering.
13 Eye nunɔla la nalé avu nɛ ɖe eƒe nu vɔ̃ si wòwɔ la ta, eɖanye nu vɔ̃ siawo dometɔ kae wòwɔ o, eye woatsɔe akee.
13 The priest will make atonement for him for the sin that he has committed, any one of these sins, and it will be forgiven him.
Vɔsanu susɔea azu nunɔla la tɔ abe ale si wòle le nuɖuvɔsa la gome ene.’”
The remainder of the offering will become the priest’s, just like the grain offering.’”

14 Yehowa gagblɔ na Mose be: 15 Ne ame aɖe mewɔ nuteƒe o, le esi wòɖe ŋu ɖi wɔ nu vɔ̃ ɖe Yehowa ƒe nu kɔkɔewo ŋu ta la, ekema wòatsɔ agbo si sɔ blibo, si ƒe home anye klosalo sekel siwo sɔ ɖe teƒe kɔkɔe la ƒe sekel nu la, asa fɔɖivɔ na Yehowa.

14 Jehovah continued to speak to Moses, saying: 15 “If someone behaves unfaithfully by unintentionally sinning against the holy things of Jehovah, he is to bring to Jehovah a sound ram from the flock as a guilt offering; its value in silver shekels is set according to the standard shekel of the holy place.
16 Eye wòaɖo nu vɔ̃ si wòwɔ ɖe kɔkɔeƒea ŋu la teƒe ahatsɔ home la me mama atɔ̃ ƒe ɖeka akpee.
16 And he will make compensation for the sin he has committed against the holy place and he will also add a fifth of its value.
Netsɔe na nunɔla la, ne nunɔla la natsɔ fɔɖivɔsa ƒe agbo la alé avu ɖe eta, eye woatsɔe akee.
He will give it to the priest, so that the priest may make atonement for him with the ram of the guilt offering, and it will be forgiven him.
17 “Eye ne ame aɖe wɔ nu vɔ̃ le esi wòwɔ nu siwo ŋu Yehowa de se ɖo be woagawɔ o la dometɔ aɖe le manyamanya me gɔ̃ hã la, eɖi fɔ, eye woabia akɔntae le vo si wòda la ŋuti.
17 “If someone sins by doing any of the things that Jehovah commands should not be done, even if he is not aware of it, he is still guilty and will answer for his error.
18 Eye wòatsɔ agbo si sɔ blibo tso eƒe alẽha dome ava nunɔla la gbɔ be woatsɔ asa fɔɖivɔe, eƒe home la nasɔ ɖe esi woɖo la nu.
18 He should bring to the priest a sound ram from the flock according to the estimated value, for a guilt offering.
Eye nunɔla la nalé avu ɖe eta le vo si wòda le manyamanya me la ta, eye woatsɔe akee.
Then the priest will make atonement for him for the unintentional mistake that he unknowingly committed, and it will be forgiven him.
19 Fɔɖivɔsa wònye.
19 It is a guilt offering.
Yehowa ŋue wòwɔ nu vɔ̃ ɖo heɖi fɔ.
He has certainly become guilty of sinning against Jehovah.”

Yehowa gagblɔ na Mose kple Aron be: 2 “Ne nane do ɖe ame aɖe ƒe ŋutigbalẽ ŋu, alo dzi do ɖe eŋu, alo eƒe ŋutigbalẽ ɖe bo, eye wòate ŋu anye anyidɔ ye do ɖe eƒe ŋutigbalẽ ŋu la, ekema woakplɔe ava nunɔla Aron alo viaŋutsu siwo nye nunɔlawo dometɔ ɖeka gbɔ.

Jehovah continued to speak to Moses and Aaron, saying: 2 “If a man develops on his skin a swelling, a scab, or a blotch and it could become the disease of leprosy on his skin, he must then be brought to Aaron the priest or to one of his sons, the priests.
3 Nunɔla la alé ŋku ɖe nu si do ɖe eƒe ŋutigbalẽa ŋu la ŋuti.
3 The priest will examine the infection on his skin.
Ne fu siwo le teƒea le ɣie, eye teƒea nyé ɖe eme wu eƒe ŋutigbalẽa ƒe akpa bubuawo la, ekema anyidɔe.
When the hair in the infection has turned white and the appearance of the infection is deeper than the skin, it is the disease of leprosy.
Nunɔla la nalé ŋku ɖe eŋu, eye wòagblɔ be eŋu mekɔ o.
The priest will examine it and declare him unclean.
4 Gake ne ŋutigbalẽ la ɖe bo hefu ɣie, teƒe la menyé ɖe eme wu eƒe ŋutigbalẽa ƒe akpa bubuawo o, eye fu la mele ɣie o la, ekema nunɔla la naɖe ame si ŋu dɔa le la ɖe aga ŋkeke adre.
4 But if the blotch on his skin is white and its appearance is not deeper than the skin and the hair has not turned white, the priest will then quarantine the infected person for seven days.
5 Nunɔla la alé ŋku ɖe amea ŋu le ŋkeke adrea gbe. Ne dɔa gale nenema ko, eye mekaka ɖe ŋutigbalẽa me o la, ekema nunɔla la nagaɖee ɖe aga ŋkeke adre bubu.
5 The priest will then examine him on the seventh day, and if it appears that the infection has stopped and has not spread on the skin, the priest will quarantine him for another seven days.
6 “Nunɔla la nagalé ŋku ɖe amea ŋu ake le ŋkeke adrea gbe. Ne dɔa le vɔvɔm le ŋutigbalẽa me eye mekaka ɖe edzi o la, ekema nunɔla la nagblɔ be eŋu kɔ; dzi ko wònye.
6 “The priest should examine him again on the seventh day, and if the infection has faded and has not spread in the skin, the priest will declare him clean; it was only a scab.
Amea nenya eƒe awuwo be eŋu nakɔ.
The man will then wash his garments and be clean.
7 Gake ne amea va nunɔla la gbɔ va yi eye wòkpɔe be eŋu kɔ hafi dzia va kaka ɖe eƒe ŋutigbalẽ me la, ekema ele be wòagava nunɔla la gbɔ ake.
7 But if the scab has definitely spread on the skin after he appears before the priest to establish his purification, he will then appear again before the priest.
8 Nunɔla la nalé ŋku ɖe eŋu, ne dzi la kaka ɖe ŋutigbalẽa me la, ekema nunɔla la nagblɔ be eŋu mekɔ o.
8 The priest will examine it, and if the scab has spread in the skin, the priest will then declare him unclean.
Anyidɔe.
It is leprosy.
9 “Ne anyi ƒo ɖe ame aɖe ŋu la, ekema woakplɔe ava nunɔla la gbɔ, 10 ne nunɔla la nalé ŋku ɖe eŋu.
9 “If the disease of leprosy develops in a man, he must then be brought to the priest, 10 and the priest will examine him.
Ne dɔ si do ɖe eƒe ŋutigbalẽ ŋu la fu ɣie, fu siwo le teƒea zu ɣie, eye teƒe si dɔa do ɖo la zu abi la, 11 ekema anyidɔ xoxoe wònye le eƒe ŋutigbalẽ ŋu, nunɔla la nagblɔ be eŋu mekɔ o.
If there is a white swelling on the skin and it has turned the hair white and there is an open sore in the swelling, 11 it is chronic leprosy on his skin, and the priest will declare him unclean.
Mehiã be wòagaɖee ɖe aga o, elabena eŋu mekɔ o.
He should not quarantine him, for he is unclean.

12 Gake ne nunɔla la kpɔe dze sii keŋ be anyidɔ la kaka eye wòxɔ amea ŋuti katã, tso eƒe tame va ɖo eƒe afɔgɔme, 13 eye nunɔla la lé ŋku ɖe eŋu hekpɔe be anyidɔ la xɔ eŋuti katã la, ekema wòagblɔ be dɔnɔa ŋu kɔ.

12 Now if the leprosy breaks out all over the skin and the leprosy covers the person with the disease from head to foot, as far as the priest can see, 13 and the priest has examined him and sees that the leprosy has covered all his skin, he will then declare the infected person clean.
Esi eŋuti katã fu ɣie ta la, amea ŋu kɔ.
All of it has turned white, and he is clean.
14 Gake gbe si gbe wògawɔ abi la, amea ŋu mekɔ o.
14 But whenever an open sore appears in it, he will be unclean.
15 Ne nunɔla la kpɔ abia la, agblɔ be eŋu mekɔ o.
15 When the priest sees the open sore, he will declare him unclean.
Abi la ŋu mekɔ o.
The open sore is unclean.
Anyidɔe.
It is leprosy.
16 Gake ne abia gatrɔ zu ɣie la, ekema amea nava nunɔla la gbɔ.
16 But if the open sore again turns white, he will then come to the priest.
17 Nunɔla la alé ŋku ɖe eŋu, eye ne ekpɔe be dɔ si do ɖe eŋu zu ɣie la, ekema nunɔla la nagblɔ be dɔnɔa ŋu kɔ.
17 The priest will examine him, and if the infection has turned white, the priest will then declare the infected person clean.
18 “Ne ƒoƒoe ƒo ame aɖe hemie, 19 gake nu ɣi aɖe do ɖe ƒoƒoe la teƒe alo wòɖe bo, eye wòfu hede biabiã ge la, ekema amea natsɔ eɖokui afia nunɔla la.

He is clean. 18 “If a person develops a boil on his skin and it heals, 19 but in the place of the boil a white swelling or a reddish-white blotch has developed, he must then show himself to the priest.
20 Nunɔla la nalé ŋku ɖe eŋu. Ne teƒea nyé ɖe eme wu ŋutigbalẽa ƒe akpa bubuawo, eye eƒe fu la le ɣie la, ekema nunɔla la nagblɔ be eŋu mekɔ o.
20 The priest will examine it, and if it appears to be deeper than the skin and its hair has turned white, the priest will then declare him unclean.
Anyie ƒo ɖe ƒoƒoe la teƒe.
It is the disease of leprosy that has broken out in the boil.
21 Ke ne nunɔla la lé ŋku ɖe eŋu eye wòkpɔ be fu ɣi aɖeke mele eme o, teƒea menyé ɖe eme wu ŋutigbalẽa ƒe akpa bubuawo hã o, eye wòlé akpɔ̃ la, ekema nunɔla la naɖe amea ɖe aga ŋkeke adre.
21 But if the priest examines it and sees that there is no white hair in it and it is not deeper than the skin and appears faded, the priest will then quarantine him for seven days.
22 Eye ne edze ƒãa be dɔa kaka ɖe ŋutigbalẽa me la, ekema nunɔla la nagblɔ be eŋu mekɔ o.
22 And if it has clearly spread on the skin, the priest will then declare him unclean.
Dɔvɔ̃ ye.
It is a disease.
23 Ke ne teƒe si ɖe bo la kpɔtɔ le nenema, mekeke ɖe enu o la, ekema ƒoƒoea ƒe teƒee ho, nunɔla la nagblɔ be eŋu kɔ.
23 But if the blotch stays in one place and has not spread, it is only the inflammation from the boil, and the priest will declare him clean.
24 “Ne dzo fiã ame aɖe, eye dzobi la teƒe fu hede biabiã ge alo le ɣie keŋ la, 25 nunɔla la nalé ŋku ɖe eŋu.
24 “Or if someone has a scar from the fire and the raw flesh of the scar becomes a reddish-white blotch or a white one, 25 the priest will then examine it.
Ne fu siwo le teƒea zu ɣie, eye teƒea nyé ɖe eme wu ŋutigbalẽa ƒe akpa bubuawo la, ekema anyidɔe do ɖe dzobi la me, eye nunɔla la nagblɔ be eŋu mekɔ o.
If the hair in the blotch has turned white and it appears to be deeper than the skin, it is leprosy that has broken out in the scar, and the priest will declare him unclean.
Anyidɔe.
It is the disease of leprosy.
26 Gake ne nunɔla la lé ŋku ɖe eŋu eye wòkpɔ be fu ɣi aɖeke mele teƒea o, menyé ɖe eme wu ŋutigbalẽ la ƒe akpa bubuawo hã o, eye wòlé akpɔ̃ la, ekema nunɔla la naɖe amea ɖe aga ŋkeke adre.
26 But if the priest examines it and sees that there is no white hair in the blotch and it is not deeper than the skin and it is faded, the priest will then quarantine him for seven days.
27 Nunɔla la nalé ŋku ɖe eŋu le ŋkeke adrea gbe. Ne edze ƒãa be ekaka ɖe ŋutigbalẽa me la, ekema nunɔla la nagblɔ be eŋu mekɔ o.
27 The priest will examine him on the seventh day, and if it has clearly spread on the skin, the priest will then declare him unclean.
Anyidɔe.
It is the disease of leprosy.
28 Ke ne teƒe si ɖe bo la kpɔtɔ le nenema, mekaka ɖe ŋutigbalẽa me o, eye wòlé akpɔ̃ la, ekema nane koe do ɖe dzobi la teƒe, nunɔla la nagblɔ be eŋu kɔ, elabena dzobi teƒe lae ɖi atse.

28 But if the blotch stays in one place and has not spread over the skin and it is faded, it is only a swelling of the scar, and the priest will declare him clean, because it is an inflammation of the scar.
29 “Ne dɔ aɖe do ɖe ŋutsu alo nyɔnu aɖe ƒe tame alo eƒe glã la, 30 ekema nunɔla la nalé ŋku ɖe dɔa ŋu.
29 “When a man or a woman develops an infection on the head or on the chin, 30 the priest will then examine the infection.
Ne teƒe la nyé ɖe eme wu ŋutigbalẽa ƒe akpa bubuawo, fu siwo le teƒea ƒe amadede trɔ aŋutiɖiɖi eye wòle belibeli la, ekema nunɔla la nagblɔ be amea ŋu mekɔ o; dɔe do ɖe amea ƒe ɖa alo ge me.
If it appears to be deeper than the skin and the hair is yellow and thin, the priest will then declare such one unclean; it is an infection of the scalp or the beard.
Anyidɔe ƒo ɖe eƒe tame alo eƒe glã.
It is leprosy of the head or of the chin.
31 Gake ne nunɔla la kpɔ be teƒea menyé ɖe eme wu ŋutigbalẽa ƒe akpa bubuawo o, eye fu yibɔ aɖeke mele eme o la, ekema nunɔla la naɖe dɔnɔa ɖe aga ŋkeke adre.
31 But if the priest sees that the infection does not appear to be deeper than the skin and there is no black hair in it, the priest should quarantine the infected person for seven days.

32 Nunɔla la nalé ŋku ɖe dɔa ŋu le ŋkeke adrea gbe. Ne dɔa mekaka ɖe edzi o, fua ƒe amadede metrɔ aŋutiɖiɖii o, eye teƒea menyé ɖe eme wu ŋutigbalẽa ƒe akpa bubuawo o la, 33 ekema woaƒlɔ ɖa nɛ, ke woatsò dɔteƒea ya ɖi, eye nunɔla la naɖe dɔnɔa ɖe aga ŋkeke adre.

32 The priest will examine the infection on the seventh day, and if the infected area has not spread and no yellow hair has developed in it and the appearance of the infected area is not deeper than the skin, 33 the person should have himself shaved, but he will not have the infected area shaved. Then the priest will quarantine the infected person for seven days.

34 “Nunɔla la nagalé ŋku ɖe dɔa ŋu le ŋkeke adrea gbe, ne dɔ si le tame kple ge me nɛ la mekeke ɖe enu o, eye teƒea menyé ɖe eme wu ŋutigbalẽa ƒe akpa bubuawo o la, ekema nunɔla la nagblɔ be eŋu kɔ, eye amea nanya eƒe awuwo ne eŋu nakɔ.

34 “The priest will again examine the infected area on the seventh day, and if the infection of the scalp and beard has not spread on the skin and it does not appear deeper than the skin, the priest must then declare him clean, and he should wash his garments and be clean.

35 Ke ne edze ƒãa be dɔa keke ɖe enu le ŋutigbalẽa me esime wogblɔ be eŋu kɔ megbe la, 36 ekema nunɔla la nagalé ŋku ɖe amea ŋu, ne dɔa keke ɖe enu la, ekema mehiã be nunɔla la nagakpɔe ɖa be fua ƒe amedede trɔ aŋutiɖiɖi hã o; amea ŋu mekɔ o.
